Title: Senate Postpones Vote on Unemployment Insurance Extension Due to Weather-Related Absences

Article:

The U.S. Senate postponed a key procedural vote on a proposal to extend long-term unemployment insurance affecting some 1.3 million Americans due to the absence of more than a dozen lawmakers caused by travel delays due to bad weather. The vote, which was scheduled for Monday evening, has been rescheduled for 10:30 a.m. Tuesday.

The bill to extend long-term unemployment benefits is the first partisan showdown in Congress for 2014. Backers of the bill are nearing the 60 votes they need to clear the procedural vote, with four Republicans and 55 members of the Democratic caucus expected to vote to begin debate on the bill. However, this is still one vote shy of the 60 votes needed to overcome a Republican filibuster.

The extension of benefits is a political priority for congressional Democrats and President Barack Obama, who is trying to make income equality a centerpiece of his second term. Obama has reached out to several GOP senators to try to persuade them to support the bill.

Many Republicans argue that a $6.4 billion extension would hurt the economy and act as a disincentive to job creation. Others have signaled they might back an extension if the cost is offset elsewhere in the budget.

Sen. Mark Kirk of Illinois, a Republican who often works across the aisle, missed a call from Obama because he was not in the office. Kirk said he wants to help people but insisted Congress must find a way to pay for the measure.

Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, is one of the four Republicans who said she would vote to begin debate on the bill. However, she would not rule out blocking it later if cost offsets are not added.

The other three Republicans are Dean Heller of Nevada, a co-sponsor of the bill, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire.

Democrats see themselves in a win-win position on the test vote. They could build momentum for the bill if Republicans back it. They get a political weapon if Republicans do not. In remarks just before the vote was to have been held, Sen. John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican, noted that 17 members were not in the chamber and urged that the proceedings be delayed "so we can have a real debate" and decide how to pay for the extension.

Republicans and Democrats alike were delayed by rough winter weather that plunged the Midwest and much of the South into a deep freeze, triggering widespread travel delays. Sen. Lindsey Graham tweeted that his commuter flight to Washington returned to South Carolina shortly after takeoff due to a possible engine problem and made a safe emergency landing.

Benefits for the long-term unemployed expired last month after Congress opted not to continue a 2008 recession-era law providing nearly a year of payments, footed by U.S. taxpayers, that kicked in when state jobless benefits ran out. Democrats insist the program is critical to help Americans who are struggling and to maintain the economic recovery. Republicans argue that the program is costly and is a disincentive to looking for work. The U.S. unemployment rate stood at 7% in November, the most recent Labor Department statistics show. That means more than 10 million people were out of work, a third of them without a job for at least 27 weeks.

Over the weekend, key Republicans, including potential 2016 presidential candidate Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, insisted that an extension must include cuts elsewhere to offset the cost. House Speaker John Boehner will insist on such offsets before agreeing to an extension, a spokesman for the Republican leader said. During his weekly address over the weekend, President Obama underscored that failing to pass an extension could result in a drag on the economy.

Title: Trump Defends Administration's Response to Coronavirus Outbreak, Discusses Economic Growth and Judicial Appointments

Article:

In a town hall event, President Donald Trump defended his administration's response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, contrasting it with the Obama administration's handling of the H1N1 pandemic in 2009. Trump claimed that his administration had been given "tremendous marks" for closing the border to foreign nationals from China, where the outbreak originated, and for the relatively low number of infections in the U.S.

When asked for a long-term plan to tackle the outbreak, Trump said, "We have plans for every single possibility." He also pivoted the discussion to highlight economic growth under his administration, touting the rising Dow Jones index in the face of the virus, despite financial market volatility.

Trump also used the town hall to discuss his judicial appointments, asserting that his predecessor, President Obama, left him a slew of vacancies to fill. He claimed that he had appointed about 200 federal judges since taking office. However, it is important to note that Republicans in the Senate, led by Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, filibustered dozens of Obama-appointed judges, stalling them in the Senate.

Trump also addressed the rising national debt, which he had promised to pay off within eight years while running as a candidate in 2016. He contended that he had to let the debt go up as he went about rebuilding the military, which he argued Obama had left underfunded and in disarray.

The rapidly dwindling Democratic field also came up in the town hall, with Trump commenting on the potential challenges posed by candidates like Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. He noted that Sanders would be a formidable challenger due to his loyal base, and criticized Warren for dropping out after Super Tuesday, stating that she had split the progressive vote to the detriment of Sanders.

Trump closed the town hall with an unusual message of respect for his fellow Washington insiders, diverging from his "drain the swamp" message to praise the "great people" in Washington, both Democrats and Republicans. He added that many Democrats were on board to collaborate with him in the coming years, despite a faction he called the "radical left Democrats."

When asked how he could bring a fractured America together again, Trump bragged about his administration's accomplishments, despite constant pushback from his adversaries. He added that he believed many Democrats would collaborate with him in the coming years.

Title: Republican Party to Maintain Radicalism Despite Midterm Elections, as Government Shutdown Threats Resurface

Article:

In the aftermath of the midterm elections, the Republican Party is poised to maintain its recent ideological and procedural radicalism, as demonstrated by the resurfacing of government shutdown threats. This development comes just over two weeks after the elections, which Republican leadership had promised would bring an end to gridlock and partisan warfare.

The catalyst for this development is President Obama's long-promised executive orders on immigration reform, aimed at reducing deportations. In response, a bloc of at least 50 Republicans in Congress is reportedly maneuvering to thwart these orders by attaching language to "must-pass" legislation, which is necessary to fund the government.

Representative Matt Salmon, the chief organizer of the push, told the Wall Street Journal, "If we have an opportunity to actually do something rather than complain... why shouldn't we?" This move, if successful, could potentially lead to another government shutdown, a tactic that has been used in the past to pressure the administration on various issues.

Notably, the Tea Party, a conservative faction within the Republican Party, has been vocal in its opposition to the president's executive orders. Red State's Erick Erickson, a prominent conservative voice, called for the closure of government-controlled golf courses and the use of Camp David as a refugee holding facility in response to the executive orders.

Despite these aggressive responses, the voice of Senator Ted Cruz, a prominent Tea Party figure and potential presidential candidate, has been notably absent. This could suggest that Cruz is assessing his influence within the Republican Senate, given his immense popularity among the Tea Party.

In the past, Cruz has been an outspoken critic of the government and has advocated for aggressive measures, including a government shutdown during the 2013 debt ceiling crisis. His lack of public commentary on the current situation may indicate a strategic approach, as he gauges the level of support for such actions within the new Senate.

This development suggests that the era of government by crisis, marked by debt ceiling standoffs, government shutdowns, and other contentious issues, is not over. Instead, it appears that the Republican Party, particularly its more conservative elements, is prepared to continue this approach in the new Congress.

Title: Mitt Romney's Foreign Tour Begins Rocky in Britain

Article:

Mitt Romney's foreign tour, starting in Britain, has faced a series of public relations challenges that were not anticipated. The initial controversy arose from comments attributed to an anonymous campaign adviser in a British newspaper, suggesting that Romney understood the shared "Anglo-Saxon heritage" between the U.S. and Britain in a way President Obama did not. These comments were viewed as racist by some and were subsequently disowned by the Romney campaign.

The candidate himself caused a stir by expressing concerns about security and other issues in the lead-up to Friday's opening ceremony. His comments were perceived as doubting the eventual success of the games, stating, "You know, it's hard to know just how well it will turn out."

British Prime Minister David Cameron responded with a comment reminiscent of Winston Churchill, "We are holding an Olympic Games in one of the busiest, most active, bustling cities anywhere in the world. Of course it's easier if you hold an Olympic Games in the middle of nowhere." The implication was clear: the 2002 games Romney oversaw in Salt Lake City, Utah.

After a meeting with Romney at 10 Downing Street, the prime minister's residence, Romney retracted his earlier remarks, expressing confidence in the games. However, this walk-back appeared to come too late, as London's mayor, Boris Johnson, used Romney's earlier comment to rally tens of thousands of Londoners before the opening ceremonies.

Johnson stated, "I hear there's a guy called Mitt Romney who wants to know whether we're ready. Are we ready? Yes we are. Our venues are ready. The stadium is ready. The aquatic center is ready... the security is ready... and our athletes are ready."

In addition to the initial controversy, Romney breached British protocol by publicly disclosing a meeting with Sir John Sawers, the head of the British intelligence agency known as MI6. Such meetings are typically not acknowledged, according to British news outlets.

This three-nation trip, including Poland and Israel, was intended to demonstrate Romney's foreign policy expertise and global stature. However, it seems the tour is not getting off to the best start.

The liberal-leaning British newspaper The Guardian and the conservative-leaning Daily Telegraph both covered the British reaction to Romney during his visit. It appears there may be something about the British that causes American politicians to stumble, as they say in London.

Early in President Obama's time in the White House, he gave then-Prime Minister Gordon Brown a set of 25 DVDs of classic American movies that were incorrectly formatted to work on European players. Worse yet, at least by British standards, was the iPod loaded with American music that Obama gave Queen Elizabeth II.

The British press also looked askance at a gift from President George W. Bush of a bomber jacket to the same rather buttoned-down, aforementioned Brown.

Title: President Obama Unilaterally Increases Minimum Wage for Federal Contract Workers to $10.10 per Hour

Article:

In a move tied to his State of the Union address, President Barack Obama will unilaterally increase the minimum wage for workers under new federal contracts to $10.10 per hour, from the current rate of $7.25. This action is aimed at building momentum for a minimum wage hike for all Americans.

The executive order, which has been advocated by progressive Democratic lawmakers, applies to all contractors performing services for the federal government and is expected to affect more than 2 million employees, according to an administration official.

During Tuesday night's address, the president will press Congress to pass a Democratic plan to increase the overall federal minimum wage to $10.10 over three years, and then index it to inflation, while also raising the minimum wage for tipped workers.

Critics of the minimum wage push argue that raising the rate could have an adverse effect, discouraging businesses from hiring more workers at a time when the government is trying to spur job growth. Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell stated, "We have a crisis in employment among young people right now, and generation 18 to 30, people that got out of college, are finding there are no jobs for them. The last thing we want to do is have even fewer jobs for younger people."

However, the president is reviving the issue as he tries to focus again on the economy. Obama, who does not have the power to unilaterally raise the minimum wage for private sector workers, also used last year's State of the Union speech to call for a federal minimum wage hike.

"Let’s declare that in the wealthiest nation on Earth, no one who works full-time should have to live in poverty and raise the federal minimum wage to $9 an hour," the president said to applause in his 2013 address.

The new executive order affects only future contracts, not existing ones, and would only apply to contract renewals if other terms of the agreement changed. As a result, the order would benefit far fewer workers than the number forecasted by advocates of federal contract employees.

House Speaker John Boehner downplayed the impact the latest executive order would have. "Let's understand something: this affects not one current contract, it only affects future contracts with the federal government. And so I think the question is, how many people, Mr. President will this executive action actually help? I suspect the answer is somewhere close to zero," he said Tuesday.

In December, Reps. Keith Ellison, D-Minn., and Raul Grijalva, D-Ariz., co-chairmen of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, wrote the president urging him to take the "bold step" of signing an executive order to increase wages for federal contractors, GovExec.com reported.

At the time, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney issued a lukewarm response when asked about the lawmakers' request, according to the report. "This has always been done legislatively. And it has been done with support from Republicans and not just Democrats in the past," Carney said.

Obama, in an effort to avoid the appearance of being a lame duck president, is expected to use Tuesday's State of the Union address to make clear his intentions to use his executive powers to achieve his goals when Congress fails to pass legislation.

Minimum wage is a perennial issue that has taken on a higher profile amid the slowly recovering economy and growing public debate about income inequality. A Quinnipiac University poll this month found 71 percent of Americans in favor of raising the minimum wage—including more than half of Republicans polled.

Five states passed minimum wage measures last year, and advocates hope that number will grow as states from New Hampshire to Washington consider proposals. Many would push families above the federal poverty line, which is $15,730 for a family of two. In Iowa, a bill would hike the minimum wage from $7.25 an hour to $10.10.

Democrats across the political spectrum have lobbied for a higher minimum wage this year, after Obama got the ball rolling on the issue by calling for an increase in his February budget speech. Since then, union-organized demonstrations in front of profitable mega-chains such as Wal-Mart and McDonald's have kept it in the public eye.

Title: President Trump Accuses James Comey of Leaking Classified Information; Allegations Surround Former FBI Director's Memos

Article:

President Donald Trump on Monday accused former FBI Director James Comey of leaking classified material, following a report that more than half of the memos Comey wrote detailing Russia-related conversations with the president contained classified information. The Hill, citing "officials familiar with the documents," reported that Comey penned a total of seven memos describing his talks with Trump on the Russia case earlier this year, and four of them had markings indicating they contained classified material at the "secret" or "confidential" level.

According to the report, the memos were recently shown to Congress, and the FBI claimed they were all government documents, despite Comey's description of his notes as personal. The president tweeted, "James Comey leaked CLASSIFIED INFORMATION to the media. That is so illegal!"

The claims in The Hill regarding Comey's memos are reminiscent of the same kind of allegations against former Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, whom Comey's team investigated for mishandling classified material on her private server and email.

The report comes as Trump and his family are grappling with a New York Times report that Donald Trump Jr. and other members of the president's inner circle met last summer with a Russian lawyer with the expectation of getting "damaging information" on Clinton – information that, according to Trump's son, did not materialize.

A special counsel has been tasked with investigating Russian meddling in the campaign and possible collusion with Trump associates, ever since Trump fired Comey earlier this year. On the heels of that firing, Comey first admitted in congressional testimony that he had used an old friend at Columbia University to get his notes leaked to The New York Times about his discussions with Trump.

However, when asked about the latest claims, Columbia University professor Daniel Richman – the Comey friend who leaked part of one memo to The New York Times – told Fox News on Monday that "this is a non-story." Richman explained that no memos were given to the press, and no memos were classified at the time he received them. Richman questioned the White House claims.

Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office declined to comment on the ongoing investigation when asked about the report in The Hill. White House Counselor Kellyanne Conway called the latest report an "incredible bombshell" and said that, if the account is true, Comey was at least violating FBI rules. Conway added that Comey was "admitting under oath, handing over classified information through 'private recollection,'" and that this was what the story should be – not all this nonsense about Russian collusion and whatnot.

Title: Senate Health Care Bill Faces Setback as Two Republican Senators Withdraw Support

Article:

The Senate health care bill has once again stalled after two conservative Republican senators announced last night that they would not vote to advance the legislation due to its failure to repeal enough of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The bill, which was assembled by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell through a secretive process, would lead to 22 million more Americans being uninsured by the end of the decade, primarily due to cuts to Medicaid, and many who retain insurance under the bill would pay more for fewer benefits.

The bill was amended after the Congressional Budget Office offered this assessment, but the GOP decided not to wait for a new score before moving forward. Democratic senators are universally opposed to the legislation, while the most moderate and conservative Republicans have also refused to sign on, either because it does too much or too little to move away from Obamacare's improvements to the health care system.

The lack of a clear policy vision from President Donald Trump and his administration has left his media supporters struggling to formulate a coherent response to the bill's setbacks. Last night, Trump tweeted that "Republicans should just REPEAL failing Obamacare now & work on a new Healthcare Plan that will start from a clean slate. Dems will join in!" However, this tactical messaging ignores the question of what a good health care plan would look like and whether the Senate bill that just went down in flames met that criteria.

Without a clear policy vision, Trump's media allies have been left to their own devices. Some of Trump's propagandists argue that Trump can not fail; he can only be failed. As such, they have quickly turned their fire on McConnell and Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-WI).

Fox host Kimberly Guilfoyle said last night, "I know the president is frustrated with the situation. A lot has been promised to him and not much delivered." She continued, "I think this is a failure on the part of the leadership, to be quite honest. Because they needed to get this to stick and to coalesce and get it done."

Steve Doocy added on Fox & Friends this morning, "Ultimately, what undid this bill is -- the one that they are not going to vote on now -- is it was a lousy bill. I mean, it still had big taxes. It still had a lot of regulations. It had that insurance company subsidy slush fund that Rand Paul was talking about. It was not what the American people wanted."

If the Senate bill continues to struggle, and Trump does not publicly support McConnell, we could see calls for his replacement in the near future. Trump's lack of interest in policy leaves his supporters plenty of room to say that they didn't like the bill, without creating any dissonance about the fact that the president supported the legislation.

One of the problems Senate Republicans faced in trying to push through health care legislation is that, because they knew no bill would attract enough Democratic support to overcome a filibuster, they were trying to pass the bill with a 50-vote threshold through the budget reconciliation process. However, that process limits what can actually go into the bill, making full repeal of Obamacare extremely difficult.

In order to sidestep that process, the hosts of Fox & Friends are calling for Senate Republicans to deploy the "nuclear option" and eliminate the filibuster altogether, making all votes subject only to a majority vote. It's unclear how this would help pass a health care bill since Republicans just demonstrated they don't have 50 votes in the Senate. However, this morning, Doocy, co-host Brian Kilmeade, and former White House press secretary Ari Fleischer all seemed eager to push through that proposal.

A few hours later, Trump, who regularly watches Fox & Friends, chimed in, tweeting, "The Senate must go to a 51 vote majority instead of current 60 votes. Even parts of full Repeal need 60. 8 Dems control Senate. Crazy!"

Title: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders Speaks at NetRoots Nation Conference, Faces Protests

Article:

Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders delivered a speech to an audience of approximately 11,000 activists at the Phoenix Convention Center, marking his largest speaking engagement to date. The event coincided with the annual gathering of NetRoots Nation, a national meeting of thousands of leftist activists, bloggers, and special interests.

During a town-hall style panel earlier in the day, both Sanders and former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley faced protests from around 40 "Black Lives Matter" activists. Tia Oso, an activist, seized the microphone and stated, "We are going to hold this space and acknowledge the names of black women who have died in police custody, and then Governor O'Malley we do have questions for you!" She continued, "As leader of this country, will you advance an agenda that will dismantle structural racism in this country?"

Both O'Malley and Sanders, who are known for their leftist politics, seemed taken aback by the exchange. In part of his response, O'Malley said that "all lives matter," a statement he later apologized for, stating that he was sorry if the phrase "offended" anyone.

Sanders, amidst a torrent of jeers, turned to the moderator and asked, "What are you doing here?" and "Are you in charge here?"

The twin events on Saturday demonstrate the promise and pitfalls of the growing agitation among hard-core leftist activists. On the one hand, their attendance helped fuel Sanders' largest campaign event to date, providing an important backdrop for the media coverage that has powered his rise in the polls. On the other hand, the palpable anger among these most committed activists, stoked over the years by the explicit design of President Obama and national Democrats, is taking over the party. It is driving the national party not only into the far fringes of leftist philosophy but also a deep embrace of identity politics that is likely to alienate most voters.

One Black Lives Matter protester later explained, "It's not like we like shutting things down, but we have to. We are tired of being interrupted."

Title: American Commando Raid Results in Death of Journalist Luke Somers and Civilians in Yemen

Article:

The American commando raid in Yemen's southern province of Shabwah on Saturday resulted in the death of American journalist Luke Somers and at least eight civilians, according to various sources. Somers, a freelance journalist who had been kidnapped in Yemen's capital, Sana'a, in 2013, was the focus of a rescue mission due to an ultimatum set by his militant captors to kill him by Saturday if unspecified demands were not met.

The operation, led by United States Special Operations commandos, aimed to rescue Somers and another Western hostage held in a walled compound in the village. According to a senior military official, American intelligence, including spy satellites, surveillance drones, and eavesdropping technology, had pinpointed the location of Somers and the other hostage inside the compound.

The raid, which began at about 1 a.m., faced several challenges. The compound, located in a remote, hilly area, was guarded by about half a dozen gunmen, already jittery about a possible repeat of the previous rescue attempt. The approach to the compound was difficult, and the commandos had virtually no element of surprise, which they typically plan for and rely on. The commandos were detected when they were less than 100 yards from the compound. It is unclear what alerted the militants.

In the village, a tribal leader, Tarek al-Daghari al-Awlaki, stated that the American commandos raided four houses, killing at least two militants but also eight civilians. One of the civilians killed was a 70-year-old man. The shooting caused panic, and nine of the dead are from Mr. Daghari's tribe.

The operation on Saturday marked the latest in a series of global combat missions led by America's Special Operations forces since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. However, the challenges of distance, weather, equipment failure, pinpoint intelligence, and unpredictable actions by the adversary are ever-present. A raid in July by Special Operations forces against an Islamic State safe house in Syria also failed to free American hostages, who apparently had been relocated in advance of the mission.

It remains to be seen whether the killings represented a larger shift in the tactics of Al Qaeda, which has largely turned away from executing hostages in recent years in favor of negotiating ransoms. When they have faced military raids, Al Qaeda militants have executed hostages. The operation on Saturday seems to have been carried out due to the deadline set by the militant captors to kill Somers on Saturday.

Title: Cleveland Police Rescue Three Women Held Captive for Decades

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, three women who had been missing for over a decade were found alive in a house near downtown Cleveland on Monday. The women, identified as Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus, and Michelle Knight, were kidnapped in their teens or early 20s and were held captive in the house.

The rescue began with a frantic 911 call from Amanda Berry, who pleaded for help to reach the police. A neighbor, Charles Ramsey, heard the commotion and saw Berry trying to escape from a house. He helped her get outside, and within minutes, police arrived and took the other women from the house.

Amanda Berry, who disappeared at age 16 in 2003, made a 911 call in which she identified herself and explained that she had been kidnapped and had been missing for 10 years. Gina DeJesus, who was 14 when she vanished in 2004, and Michelle Knight, who disappeared in 2002, were also found.

Authorities arrested three brothers in connection with the case, but no names or charges have been released. One of the brothers lived at the house, while the others lived elsewhere. The women appeared to be in good health and were taken to a hospital for evaluation and to be reunited with their families.

A 6-year-old child was also found in the house, but the child's identity and relationship to the residents are not known. The women's loved ones expressed their joy and relief at their rescue.

The house where the women were found was being searched by dozens of police officers and sheriff's deputies. The homeowner, who is believed to be Ariel Castro, a former school bus driver, was arrested and is being held in jail. Attempts to reach Ariel Castro were unsuccessful.

The women's disappearance had taken a toll on their families, and their loved ones had not given up hope of seeing them again. The rescue of the three women has brought a sense of relief and joy to the community.

The investigation into the case is ongoing, and there are many unanswered questions. The women are currently being evaluated at a hospital, and their conditions are not being disclosed. This is a developing story, and more information is expected to be released at a news conference scheduled for Tuesday morning.

Title: Bernie Sanders Criticizes Bill Clinton's Record, Calls for Apology Over "Super Predator" Remark

Article:

In a forum centered on race at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, New York, Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders criticized parts of former President Bill Clinton's record and called for an apology over his use of the phrase "super predator" in the 1990s.

During the event, Sanders expressed sharp differences with Clinton's handling of crime and poverty during his two-term presidency. He also rebuked Clinton for defending his wife's use of the "super predator" term, which he said was code for "black people."

"The president owes the American people an apology for trying to defend what is indefensible," Sanders said.

When someone in the audience at the Apollo shouted that the "super predator" reference was code for "black people," the Vermont senator said, "That's exactly right."

Sanders and Hillary Clinton are competing to win the New York primary on April 19. Having performed poorly with minority voters in earlier contests, Sanders has been trying to forge stronger ties to the African-American community as the campaign moves to diverse states like New York. The event at the Apollo was one such effort, with Sanders sharing a stage with African-American supporters including entertainer Harry Belafonte and Erica Garner, daughter of Eric Garner, who died two years ago in a struggle with police who put him in a choke hold.

When asked about Hillary Clinton, Belafonte, who is also a civil-rights activist, said, "Hillary who? We've been there and done that."

The first question Sanders received from the moderator involved Clinton's extended back-and-forth with a pair of protesters in Philadelphia on Thursday. In that exchange, Clinton sought to explain his wife's use of the term "super predator." He talked about gang leaders who were getting teenagers "hopped up on crack" and sending them out to kill other African-Americans.

"Maybe you thought they were good citizens; she didn't," Clinton told the protesters.

In the same event, Clinton also defended a bill he signed as president in 1996 overhauling the welfare system by imposing limitations on federal assistance and enacting new work requirements. When protesters said the welfare law increased poverty, Clinton said, "Then why did we have the largest drop in African-American poverty in history when I was president?" He blamed Republicans for subsequently undercutting the program by yanking money intended to cushion the law's impact.

Sanders was unsparing in his criticism of the welfare legislation, casting it as a cynical ploy to win votes.

"Do you all remember that?" he asked the audience. "The premise, which was a right-wing Republican premise, was that the problem was all these people were really living high off the hog."

A consequence of the new law was that "extreme poverty … went up," Mr. Sanders said.

Clinton signed the law as he was campaigning for re-election in 1996.

"Here are people who are helpless, who are barely making it economically," Mr. Sanders said. "To go after them to win votes and cut the benefits of children and moms is unacceptable."

Clinton's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment. A day after his clash with the protesters, Clinton voiced regrets over the episode. He said he was not especially "effective" in dealing with the criticism.

Title: US-Iran Nuclear Deal and Iran's Foreign Policy: A Look at the Complexities

Article:

The ongoing US-led nuclear deal with Iran primarily focuses on Iran's nuclear program and does not address broader issues concerning Iran's relationship with the world. The debate surrounding the deal has revolved around Iran's role in the Middle East, with some arguing that the deal could embolden Iran's hostile stance, while others contend it could foster a more conciliatory foreign policy.

Journalist Steve Coll, in a recent podcast on the New Yorker, compared Iran to Sunni Arab countries in the Middle East, which are predominantly pro-American but have populations that are deeply hostile towards the US. In contrast, Iran's elites are mostly hostile towards the US, while the population is ready for change.

Coll's observations were made during a visit to Iran on Quds Day, an annual event where hard-liners chant against Israel and America. He noted that many attendees were not genuine supporters but were students brought in for the event. He also mentioned that, despite the regime's anti-Western actions and rhetoric, the Iranian population is largely past the idea of a perpetual revolutionary struggle against foreign powers.

However, the Iranian government has constituencies that believe in anti-Western policies, including security agencies, the clerical establishment, and hard-liners who wield significant influence. The Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has a history of bending to hard-liners, potentially due to his reliance on their support.

The comparison between Iran and Sunni Arab dictatorships is significant, as both have authoritarian elites with varying levels of support from their populations. This tension between Iran's anti-American elite and its more pro-normalization population is a challenge for the country's leadership and stability.

The instability of American foreign policy in the Middle East and the status quo in the region are highlighted by this contradiction. The things that make Iran's official anti-Americanism politically unviable in the long term hold true in Sunni Arab states, from Algeria to Bahrain.

Title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments in Landmark Free Speech on the Internet Case, Elonis v. United States

Article:

The nine justices of the Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in a potentially significant case, Elonis v. United States, regarding free speech on the Internet. The case revolves around Anthony Elonis, who was convicted of making threats of violence and sentenced to nearly four years in prison for posting hostile messages on Facebook about his community and his then-estranged wife, after she obtained a protective order against him. Elonis claims his threats were not serious and were merely original rap lyrics.

The case is considered the first major test of free speech rights on the Internet, and the court's eventual ruling could apply to more traditional forms of communication. According to CNN correspondent Jan Crawford, after hearing complex and convoluted arguments from both Elonis' lawyers and government lawyers, the justices seemed skeptical of both sides.

John Elwood, an attorney for Elonis, said after the arguments that he thought they went "reasonably well" but agreed the outcome would be "very hard to tell." He stated that a victory for the government in this case could have far-reaching consequences for communications online, where the intent of one's message is not always clear.

Jeff Dion, deputy executive director of the National Center for Victims of Crime, said after Monday's arguments that the government made a strong case. Dion argued that throwing out Elonis' conviction would effectively "make a rulebook on how to legally threaten your spouse." If Elonis wins, it would invalidate a majority of stalking statutes in the U.S., according to Dion.

Paulette Sullivan Moore of the National Network to End Domestic Violence added that "a threat is a threat," whether it comes via social media or otherwise. According to Scotusblog, the justices did not spend a lot of time analyzing whether the Internet was different from other forums of communication, although now and then a justice would throw in a presumably knowing reference to Eminem or to rappers more generally.

Title: Trump Announces Plan to Name Supreme Court Nominee on July 9, Likely Candidates Revealed

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has announced his intention to announce his nominee for a new Supreme Court justice on July 9. During a flight from Washington to New Jersey on Friday, Trump stated that he has narrowed the potential candidates down to approximately five individuals, including two women. The vacancy arose following the retirement announcement of Justice Anthony Kennedy earlier this week.

The president's nominee will need to be confirmed by the Senate, where the Republican Party holds a narrow majority. Trump also discussed other political matters during the flight, including his upcoming meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki next month, NATO spending, and the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Regarding the WTO, Trump stated that the U.S. has been treated unfairly but did not mention any plans to withdraw from the organization. He also declined to discuss the Supreme Court candidates' positions on the landmark 1973 Roe v Wade decision, which legalized abortion in the U.S.

During his campaign, Trump pledged to appoint "pro-life" judges to the Supreme Court, a promise that has raised concerns among women's rights groups. Among the potential candidates, Brett Kavanaugh, an appeals court judge in Washington D.C. and a former clerk to Justice Kennedy, is considered a front-runner. Other likely nominees include Amul Thapar, a Kentucky judge handpicked by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and Amy Comey Barrett, a former professor at Catholic university Notre Dame. Raymond Kethledge, a judge on the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and a former clerk to Justice Kennedy, is another possible contender.

In other remarks to reporters, President Trump indicated that he would discuss allegations of Russian election meddling when he meets President Putin in Finland on July 16. U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia attempted to influence the 2016 U.S. election in Trump's favor, a claim the Kremlin has consistently denied. Russia's annexation of Crimea from Ukraine in 2014, which led to U.S. and EU sanctions, and the war in Syria, would also be discussed, according to Trump. He refused to rule out accepting the annexation when he meets Putin, stating, "We're going to have to see." When asked whether U.S. sanctions on Russia might be lifted, Trump replied, "We'll see what Russia does."

Title: Trump Visits U.S.-Mexico Border, Threatens Tariffs on Mexican Imports

Article:

President Donald Trump visited the U.S.-Mexico border in Calexico, California on Friday, reiterating his concerns about the influx of Central American migrants seeking asylum. Trump stated, "We can't take you anymore. I'm sorry. Can't happen. So turn around," referring to the migrants.

During a discussion with border officials, Trump criticized the asylum system, claiming that people are fabricating stories of violence at home to stay in the U.S. "It's a scam. It's a hoax," Trump said. "I know about hoaxes, I just went through a hoax."

Trump's recent declaration of a border emergency aims to redirect funding for a border wall. He has been critical of the asylum system, with Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen estimating that about 100,000 migrants crossed the border illegally or asked for refuge at legal border crossings in March, a level not seen in more than a decade.

Despite the tough rhetoric, Trump has backed off a threat to close the border entirely, stating that Mexico has made progress in apprehending migrants and stopping their journey to the U.S. border. However, before leaving Washington, he reiterated a new threat: if the situation doesn't improve, he will impose tariffs of 25% on Mexican-made vehicles entering the U.S.

Trump's nomination for Ron Vitiello, a veteran border official serving as acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, was withdrawn unexpectedly on Thursday. Trump commented, "Ron's a good man, but we're going in a tougher direction." The move leaves the agency without a leader at a crucial time, and Trump didn't mention any potential replacements.

Tensions at the U.S.-Mexico border have risen due to Mexico's recent shift in migration policies. The administration of Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has begun offering humanitarian visas to Central American asylum seekers and has also cut back on deportations. The number of illegal immigrants detained by U.S. Customs and Border Protection has risen in response.

Mexico hasn't commented on whether it has stepped up migrant apprehensions as Trump has asserted, but government officials have said they believe trade and migration issues should be kept separate. The U.S., Mexico, and Canada signed a new trade pact overhauling their 25-year-old trade zone in November, but the pact needs congressional approval and has encountered some opposition. Trump scoffed at the opposition as "purely political."

After the border tour, Trump was scheduled to hold a series of fundraisers in California and Nevada on Friday and Saturday and deliver a speech at the Republican Jewish Coalition conference in Las Vegas.

Title: U.S. and China: A Call for Collaboration in Achieving Mutual Dreams of Reform

Article:

In a piece published recently, the author calls for President Barack Obama to support Chinese President Xi Jinping's efforts to achieve his vision of reform. The author recalls a personal encounter with Xi in 2012, where they discussed a photo album of Xi's father's 1980 visit to the United States, and notes similarities between Xi's "Chinese dream" and the aspirations of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

Xi's "Chinese dream" encompasses goals such as poverty alleviation, national rejuvenation, and the eradication of corruption. The author suggests that when President Obama meets with Xi in California, they will have an opportunity to collaborate and define their shared vision for the future.

Domestically, China has already begun to implement economic reforms, with Premier Li Keqiang committing to reducing government involvement in the economy and allowing market forces to guide growth. The National Development and Reform Commission has also proposed an absolute cap on greenhouse gas emissions and coal consumption. Xi's anti-corruption drive, his decision to follow in the footsteps of Deng Xiaoping's 1992 Southern trip, and his efforts to improve military-to-military relations with the United States are also indicative of his commitment to reform.

Internationally, China is demonstrating a more responsible stance, with commitments to a denuclearized Korean peninsula, improved military-to-military relations, and progress on cyber hacking and auditing issues.

The author proposes several steps for the U.S. and China to take to further their relationship. They suggest that Obama and Xi should announce the commencement of negotiations for a free trade agreement with a three-year deadline for conclusion. They also recommend setting a one-year deadline for the completion of a bilateral investment treaty and the authorization of U.S. shale gas exports to China.

Protection of intellectual property is another key issue, and the authors suggest establishing a bilateral task force to agree on specific policies that will ensure greater protection for intellectual property. Lastly, the authors propose that Obama should visit China within the next twelve months and address the Chinese people about his vision for the future of U.S.-China relations.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of the U.S. and China working together to achieve their mutual dreams of reform and to create a new, more cooperative great power relationship. The author is Stephen A. Orlins, the president of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations.

Title: US Senate Committee Requests Second Investigation into Khashoggi's Murder, Focusing on Saudi Crown Prince

Article:

The United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee has requested a second investigation into the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, with a focus on Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The request, issued under the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act, was made by Republican Senator Bob Corker and Democrat Bob Menendez on behalf of the committee.

The letter, sent on Tuesday, calls for a specific investigation into the crown prince to "determine whether a foreign person is responsible for an extrajudicial killing, torture or other gross violation" of human rights. The request requires a response within 120 days.

Jamal Khashoggi was killed on October 2, 2018, inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. The Saudi government has blamed Khashoggi's death on rogue agents but has denied claims that the crown prince had knowledge of the operation. US media have reported that the CIA believes Mohammed bin Salman ordered the murder.

In a statement on Tuesday, President Donald Trump acknowledged that the crown prince "could very well" have known about Khashoggi's brutal murder, adding, "Maybe he did and maybe he didn't!" He later stated that the CIA had not made a "100%" determination on the killing.

Following the president's comments, the Saudi government has maintained that the death was the result of rogue agents and that the crown prince did not have knowledge of the operation.

In an interview on Sunday, President Trump told Fox News that he had refused to listen to a recording of Khashoggi's murder provided by Turkey, calling it "a suffering tape."

The request for a second investigation comes as many in the US Congress and other countries continue to call for greater clarity regarding the crown prince's role in the murder. Lindsey Graham, a senator from Mr. Trump's Republican Party, has predicted strong bipartisan support in Congress for sanctions against Saudi Arabia, including "appropriate members of the royal family."

In a statement, President Trump wrote that "we may never know all of the facts" about Khashoggi's death and that the United States intends to remain a steadfast partner of Saudi Arabia to ensure the interests of the country, Israel, and other partners in the region. President Trump later said he would meet Mohammed bin Salman at a G20 meeting in Argentina next week if the crown prince attended.

The murder of Jamal Khashoggi has sparked international condemnation and has been a major crisis for Saudi Arabia. Many Saudis have expressed regret that the murder will cast a dark shadow over their country for many years to come. Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif tweeted his disgust at the Trump statement, calling it disgraceful.

Title: Stranded Americans in Yemen Await Evacuation as U.S. Weighs Safety Concerns

Article:

Muna Mansour, an American citizen from Buffalo, New York, is among dozens of Americans stranded in Yemen amidst ongoing conflict between warring parties. The United States has deemed it too dangerous to directly evacuate American nationals, leaving families like Mansour's in a precarious situation.

Mansour and her family of nine are currently cramped in a cargo hold with two other families, with limited resources and no clear plan for evacuation. Her grandchild sleeps curled around an oil drum during their journey from Aden to Djibouti.

The conflict in Yemen began when Saudi Arabia, aiming to drive out the Shiite Houthi rebels, initiated airstrikes over three weeks ago. The Houthis, who had previously held Yemen's President under house arrest, have taken control of government buildings and some territory.

The bombings have caused significant damage in cities like Aden, trapping foreigners in the country. Muna recalls witnessing the evacuation of 200 Indians from the port, while American citizens remain stranded.

The State Department has stated that the security situation in Yemen makes an evacuation of citizens too risky. "We have to make a decision based on the security situation and what is feasible to do," said State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf. "Given the situation in Yemen is quite dangerous and unpredictable, doing something like sending in military assets even for an evacuation could put U.S. citizen lives at greater risk."

A group of U.S. organizations, including the Council on American-Islamic Relations and the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination League, have filed a lawsuit against the State Department and Defense Department over the government's stance on evacuations.

Muna's ordeal began when she visited her sick father in Aden, only to find herself trapped in the city as fighting broke out around her. With Houthi forces to the north and the Gulf of Aden to the south, Aden is essentially besieged.

Muna and her fellow Americans have waited for word on their evacuation, but to no avail. The first night on their boat had a festive air, but one woman was found crying, her 15-year-old son trapped on the other side of one of the many front lines that have etched themselves into the city's streets.

U.S. Deputy Chief of Mission Christina Higgins met the stranded Americans at Djibouti Port. When asked about the sense of abandonment felt by the Americans, Higgins stated, "We've had to weigh very, very carefully what is the safest way, the best way for us to help them."

Higgins emphasized that each U.S. citizen will have to judge what is best for themselves and their families, with many choosing to shelter in place while others are being assisted in finding alternative means of travel out of Yemen.

As of now, there are no definitive records, but the 15 Americans on board the ship reported counting 75 more families waiting in Aden port who could not afford an "exit/transport" fee being charged to depart Aden. This fee, not an official tax, was being charged by local fishermen to ferry passengers to the boat to board.

The situation in Yemen remains dire for many American citizens still in danger, with no clear solution in sight.

Title: Michael Cohen Admits to Manipulating Online Polls at Donald Trump's Direction

Article:

WASHINGTON - Michael Cohen, the former personal lawyer of U.S. President Donald Trump, admitted on Thursday to paying a data firm to manipulate online polling data "at the direction of and for the sole benefit of" Trump. The Wall Street Journal reported that Cohen had paid the data firm RedFinch Solutions to manipulate two public opinion polls in favor of Trump before the 2016 presidential campaign.

Cohen, in a Twitter post on Thursday, stated, "As for the @WSJ article on poll rigging, what I did was at the direction of and for the sole benefit of @realDonaldTrump @POTUS. I truly regret my blind loyalty to a man who doesn't deserve it."

The attempts to influence the polls ultimately proved largely unsuccessful but shed light on the tactics of the Trump campaign and Cohen's role within it. On the campaign trail, Trump frequently referred to his polling numbers to help fuel his candidacy.

Cohen was sentenced last month to three years in prison for his role in making illegal hush-money payments to women to help Trump's campaign and for lying to Congress about a proposed Trump Tower project in Russia. Cohen has said Trump had directed him to commit the campaign-finance violations, which Trump has denied.

The Journal said Cohen commissioned John Gauger, who runs RedFinch Solutions, to write a computer script to repeatedly vote for Trump in a February 2015 Drudge Report poll on potential Republican candidates. Trump ranked fifth in the Drudge Report poll, with about 24,000 votes, or 5 percent of the total, according to the Journal.

Cohen also commissioned Gauger to do the same for a 2014 CNBC online poll identifying the country's top business leaders, although Trump was unable to break into the top 100 candidates, the Journal reported.

Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, said in an interview with ███ that the president has no knowledge of the polls being rigged. Trump tweeted about a CNBC poll on business leaders in 2014, calling it "a joke" and suggesting he was removed from the list because of "politics."

███ was not immediately able to confirm the details of the newspaper report. Cohen did not immediately respond to a request for comment, and neither did representatives for RedFinch Solutions and the Trump Organization. Charles James, a lawyer for Gauger, declined to comment.

Gauger said Cohen paid him in cash out of a blue Walmart bag, although not for the total amount he was owed. Cohen also promised Gauger work on the Trump campaign that never materialized, according to the Journal.

Cohen worked for Trump for many years as his self-proclaimed fixer, and once said he would take a bullet for Trump. However, the relationship has since publicly soured. Trump has called Cohen a "rat," while Cohen has cooperated with U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation of links between the Trump campaign and Russia during the campaign. Both Trump and Moscow have denied any wrongdoing.

Cohen has also agreed to testify publicly in front of the House of Representatives' Oversight Committee in a hearing scheduled to take place next month.

Title: FBI Investigation of Michael Cohen's Business Dealings Revealed in Released Search Warrant

Article:

The FBI had been investigating President Donald Trump's former personal attorney and fixer, Michael Cohen, for nearly a year before agents raided his home and office, documents released Tuesday show. The search warrant, while heavily redacted, offered new details about the federal inquiry into Cohen's business dealings and the FBI raids of his Manhattan home and office.

The federal inquiry into Cohen had been going on since July 2017, far longer than previously known. Lanny Davis, an attorney for Cohen, stated that the release of the search warrant "furthers his interest in continuing to cooperate and providing information and the truth about Donald Trump and the Trump Organization to law enforcement and Congress."

The FBI raided Cohen's Manhattan home and office last April, marking the first public sign of a criminal investigation that has threatened Trump's presidency and netted Cohen a three-year prison sentence for tax evasion and campaign-finance violations. The federal agents, who also scoured Cohen's hotel room and safe deposit box, seized more than 4 million electronic and paper files in the searches, more than a dozen mobile devices and iPads, 20 external hard drives, flash drives, and laptops.

Both Cohen and Trump cried foul over the raids, with Cohen's attorney at the time calling them "completely inappropriate and unnecessary," and the president taking to Twitter to declare that "Attorney-client privilege is dead!" A court-ordered review ultimately found only a fraction of the seized material to be privileged.

The raids on Cohen were triggered in part by a referral from special counsel Robert Mueller, who is separately looking into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Tuesday's release of the search warrant came nearly six weeks after U.S. District Judge William H. Pauley III partially granted a request by several media organizations, including The Associated Press, that the search warrant be made public due to the high public interest in the case.

The judge acknowledged prosecutors' concerns that a wholesale release of the document "would jeopardize an ongoing investigation and prejudice the privacy rights of uncharged third parties," a ruling that revealed prosecutors are still investigating Cohen's illegal payments to two women to stay silent about alleged affairs with Trump. The judge ordered prosecutors to redact Cohen's personal information and details in the warrant that refer to ongoing investigations and several third-parties who have cooperated with the inquiry. However, he authorized the release of details in the warrant that relate to Cohen's tax evasion and false statements to financial institutions charges, along with Cohen's conduct that did not result in criminal charges.

"At this stage, wholesale disclosure of the materials would reveal the scope and direction of the Government's ongoing investigation," Pauley wrote in a ruling last month. Cohen pleaded guilty over the summer to failing to report more than $4 million in income to the IRS, making false statements to financial institutions, and campaign-finance violations stemming from the hush-money payments he arranged for porn actress Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal. Cohen implicated Trump in his guilty plea, saying the president directed him to make the payments during his 2016 campaign.

Title: College Students' Views on Free Speech: A Contradictory Trend

Article:

A new report on student views of free speech, published on May 5 by the Knight Foundation in partnership with Gallup, has raised concerns about the future of free speech in the United States, given the significant role colleges play in shaping the nation's leaders.

The report reveals a paradoxical trend: while an increasing number of students support restrictions on speech deemed offensive, they also believe that free speech and the First Amendment are under threat. The proportion of students who believe colleges should be able to restrict language containing slurs has risen from 69 percent in 2016 to 78 percent in 2019. Moreover, a surprising 71 percent (up from 63 percent) of students think colleges should be able to restrict the use of "stereotypical costumes," a matter typically beyond the jurisdiction of college administrators.

Simultaneously, however, a smaller proportion of students believe the First Amendment is secure—59 percent, compared to 73 percent in 2016. A majority of students also believe that the climate of their campus stifles free expression, while many acknowledge that liberals are freer to speak their mind than conservatives.

The seemingly contradictory findings suggest that large numbers of campus liberals are aware of the receding free speech in colleges and elsewhere, yet they continue to advocate for further speech restrictions. It is more likely that this paradox reflects a growing perception among liberals that "hate speech" and other insensitive forms of expression fall outside the bounds of protected free speech.

This is supported by the fact that staggering numbers of students continue to believe that "hate speech" is legally restricted. Only 30 percent of respondents answered affirmatively when asked if hate speech is protected by the First Amendment, with nearly half claiming that it is not. The outlook is even more dismal when examining Democrats, as only 23 percent know that hate speech is protected. While this could be interpreted as a mere misunderstanding of the First Amendment, it aligns with the large majorities in favor of college restrictions on insensitive forms of expression, implying that many college liberals believe their censorship preferences are also enshrined in law.

America's college students are its future politicians, media figures, teachers, and bureaucrats. Unfortunately, the report suggests that their tilt toward an authoritarian view of speech has only grown.

Title: SNL Tackles Performative Activism: A Critique of Corporate and Individual Actions

Article:

Saturday Night Live (SNL) addressed the topic of performative activism in its recent episode, critiquing both corporate and individual actions that may appear supportive of social causes but lack genuine commitment. The show's focus was on two sketches, one targeting the controversial Pepsi ad and another satirizing armchair activism.

The Pepsi ad, which featured Kendall Jenner joining a protest movement and offering a can of Pepsi to a police officer, was met with widespread criticism upon its release. In the SNL sketch, a fictional representative of the ad's creators, played by Beck Bennett, realizes the ad's tragic flaws, such as trivializing the Black Lives Matter movement, using diverse individuals as props, and ignoring historical police treatment of people of color.

The second sketch, "Thank You, Scott," parodied armchair activism, where individuals express support for social causes through social media but do not engage in more substantial actions like making phone calls, writing letters, volunteering, or donating money. In the sketch, Louis CK's character, Scott, is praised for his minimal efforts, such as sharing an article on Facebook and adding "Black Lives Matter" to his Twitter bio.

While the sketches serve as a reminder of the importance of genuine commitment and cultural sensitivity, they also highlight the challenges of navigating social issues in the digital age, where appearances can sometimes overshadow actual actions.

Title: Trump Nominates Ben Carson as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump announced on Monday that he has chosen former campaign rival Ben Carson to become the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). In a statement, Trump expressed his excitement about the nomination, praising Carson's intelligence and passion for strengthening communities.

Carson, who had previously downplayed any role in the Trump administration, stated in a Monday statement that he felt he could "make a significant contribution, particularly by strengthening communities that are most in need." He also tweeted that he would accept the position.

Although Carson was rumored to be a contender for positions such as Veteran's Affairs, Education, or Health and Human Services, his nomination for HUD may initially seem unusual. However, Carson has spoken and written about the department and issues affected by its actions numerous times during his time as a primary candidate. He also hinted at a potential HUD job offer from Trump in a Facebook post last month.

Carson ran against Trump during the Republican primary battle but endorsed the businessman after dropping out of the White House race in March. He became one of Trump's most visible surrogates. Carson's position in the cabinet requires Senate confirmation before it becomes official.

Carson, who grew up in inner-city Detroit, has often recounted his childhood experiences in his books and motivational speeches. In his 1996 autobiography "Gifted Hands," Carson wrote about the humiliation he felt using food stamps to pay for bread and milk, and how he began to excel at school only after receiving a free pair of glasses that allowed him to see the lessons written on chalkboards.

Carson has not confirmed whether his family ever lived in federally-funded housing or received Section 8 subsidies to help pay rent. As a political figure, he has criticized such public assistance programs for creating "dependency" on the government among low-income minorities. In a 2015 speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference, Carson stated, "I'm interested in getting rid of dependency, and I want us to find a way to allow people to excel in our society."

Title: Treasury Department Delays Employer Mandate of Obamacare for One Year

Article:

The Treasury Department announced on Tuesday that a key part of the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, will be postponed for one year. The employer mandate, or the shared responsibility rules, will not require businesses to offer health coverage to their employees or face penalties until 2015.

The announcement came as a surprise, as the White House was building momentum for its public education campaign and trying to signal that the health insurance exchanges would start enrollment on time in October. The delay in the employer mandate is not expected to derail the enrollment process, but it may affect public perception and provide critics with ammunition to discuss the law's implementation.

The administration insists that the new health insurance exchanges or marketplaces will start enrollment on time this October. The employer mandate is not central to the coverage push, as most large businesses already offer health benefits. However, the delay could mean that fewer people will obtain coverage next year.

Republicans have used the announcement to renew calls for the law's repeal and replacement. Repeal is unlikely as long as President Barack Obama is in office, but some groups have renewed their calls for defunding the health law. The delay could also resonate in the 2014 House and Senate campaigns.

One immediate question people are asking is whether this is the only delay the Obama administration will announce or if it is the first in a series of delays, with the individual mandate being a prime target. The White House and allies have stated that the main elements of the law will be ready to go in October, and they emphasize that the employer mandate is a segment of the law, but not its core.

The individual mandate, which survived a Supreme Court challenge last year, is expected to face resistance if it is delayed. Insurance companies would likely object to the delay, as they need the individual mandate to provide costly new services to cover everyone, sick and healthy, as the law requires. The employer mandate penalty for businesses with more than 50 employees was $2,000 per employee, but that has been put on hold after a noisy outcry from business groups and commentary about the law's impact on businesses during the economic recovery. Business groups have stated that the rules and regulations about employee coverage are cumbersome. The Treasury, which is responsible for this piece of Obamacare, said it had agreed to go back to the drawing board on Tuesday.

Title: House Impeachment Managers Deliver Articles to Senate, Demand for Witnesses

Article:

On January 15, 2020, the articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump were delivered to the Senate by House Clerk Cheryl Johnson and House Sergeant at Arms Paul Irving. The impeachment managers, led by House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler and House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, also included Reps. Hakeem Jeffries, Sylvia Garcia, Val Demings, Zoe Lofgren, and Jason Crow.

The Senate's decision on witnesses has become a contentious issue in the impeachment trial. House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler stated that if the Senate does not obtain the witnesses and documents the House impeachment managers want, it is participating in an "unconstitutional and disgusting cover-up."

The demand for witnesses and documents from the Senate is a point of contention, with the House wanting the Senate to continue the investigative work that the House began. This demand is seen as inconsistent with the Senate's pace and approach to the impeachment trial.

The House has been in an awkward situation since the pace of its investigation diverged from the pace of its impeachment. Speaker Nancy Pelosi wanted to devote more time to impeaching Trump over Ukraine, but the investigation took longer, causing the impeachment to take precedence. The House secured some meaningful witnesses, but a more deliberate process would have allowed for a more thorough investigation.

The House failed to subpoena key witnesses such as John Bolton, whose testimony is now said to be central to the integrity of a Senate trial. The release of new, disturbing Lev Parnas documents has provided a boost to the Democrats, but the House impeached before receiving these documents. If Speaker Pelosi had not delayed transmitting the articles, the Senate trial could have ended before the release of the documents.

The documents raise questions that would be natural to answer in an impeachment inquiry, but the inquiry had already ended. The Senate's decision on witnesses will depend on the political dynamics of the contest between Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer.

The impeachment trial is taking place in the run-up to an election, and both parties are engaging in political maneuvering. The Senate Republicans' argument for not calling witnesses is that the broad outlines of Trump's conduct are already known, and the Senate only needs to decide if his conduct rises to the level of removal. However, if Republicans maintain Trump did not engage in any misconduct, it raises the question why key witnesses such as John Bolton should not testify.

Title: Reagan Daughter Denounces Father's Racist Remarks in 1971 Tapes as "Ugliness"

Article:

Patti Davis, the daughter of former President Ronald Reagan, has denounced her father's recently uncovered racist remarks in a Washington Post op-ed, describing the comments as "ugliness" but asking for forgiveness. The recording, released by the National Archives and published Tuesday by The Atlantic, features Reagan, then-governor of California, referring to United Nations delegates from African countries as "monkeys."

In the op-ed published Thursday, Davis wrote, "There is no defense, no rationalization, no suitable explanation for what my father said on that taped phone conversation." The recording, made in October 1971 during a private phone call with then-President Richard Nixon, includes Reagan venting about delegates who voted against the U.S. to have the United Nations recognize the People's Republic of China.

Davis, in her op-ed, asked the public to forgive her late father for words "that should never have been uttered in any conversation," but that these remarks were an "aberration." She wrote, "The words he used in his conversation with Nixon can not be interpreted as anything but ugliness."

Davis also stated that she never heard her father make such remarks while growing up, and that bigotry and racism were addressed in her family by making it clear that these were toxic and sinister beliefs that should always be called out and shunned.

However, this is not the first time the former Republican president has been criticized for racist remarks. During his 1966 campaign for governor in California, Reagan told a crowd of supporters that, "If an individual wants to discriminate against Negroes or others in selling or renting his house, it is his right to do so," according to Politico. Reagan also helped create the "welfare queen" stereotype, contributing to a narrative that black women abuse taxpayer dollars to support lazy and lavish lifestyles.

Historians have also cited "racist policies" Reagan implemented during his presidency that disproportionately harmed people of color, laying the groundwork for his "War on Drugs."

The previously unheard audio recording has surfaced during President Donald Trump's relentless Twitter attacks on four minority progressive congresswomen and Baltimore Democratic Rep. Elijah Cummings. Trump has often referenced Reagan during his presidency and even shares a slogan Reagan used during his 1980 campaign, 'Make America Great Again.' Trump has repeatedly defended his statements, including tweeting that he doesn't have "a racist bone in his body." A July Quinnipiac poll found that 51% of Americans view Trump as a racist.

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Speech: A Shift in Tone and Emphasis, but Few Specifics

Article:

In a departure from his usual free-flowing speeches, Donald Trump delivered a carefully crafted foreign policy address on Wednesday, focusing on a more measured tone and avoiding some of his controversial proposals. Notably absent from the speech were explicit mentions of his proposed border wall with Mexico, nuclear weapons for South Korea and Japan, or withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

Trump did criticize the Iran nuclear deal, but stopped short of promising to tear it up or demand a renegotiation on day one. Instead, he reiterated his stance that Iran would not be allowed to acquire nuclear weapons, a position mirroring President Obama's before the controversial agreement with Teheran.

The speech included a harsh critique of Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, but Trump did not commit to unwavering support for Israel or outline specific plans to protect Middle Eastern Christians from ISIS genocide. He did, however, promise to swiftly destroy the Islamic State and did not repeat his claim that President Bush lied about Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction to justify the Iraq War.

Trump's call for an "America first" policy, a slogan associated with isolationists who opposed aiding allies during World War II, raised questions about his understanding of American law and foreign affairs. He also pledged to prevent American companies from moving abroad and to pressure allies to pay more for their defense, but did not detail how he would achieve these goals.

Critics of President Obama's foreign policy may welcome Trump's call for a more robust military, a tougher stance against Islamic radicalism, and an America-centric policy. However, his speech contained few concrete remedies for restoring economic strength, a key factor in America's ability to project power abroad, according to Trump.

One of the most critical sections of the speech was Trump's assessment of Hillary Clinton's performance as Secretary of State, where he accused her of misleading the nation about the Benghazi attack and failing to respond effectively during the crisis. This, Trump suggested, demonstrated Clinton's inability to lead in a crisis, a theme likely to be a recurring one if Trump secures the nomination.

Title: Sequester Debate Unchanged as Economy Shrinks Due to Defense Spending Cuts

Article:

The recent news of the economy shrinking towards the end of the year, attributed to a 22.2 percent drop in defense spending, has been viewed by some as a warning of potential economic consequences if larger automatic reductions, known as the sequester, take effect from March 1. However, this news is not expected to significantly alter the ongoing debate over the sequester.

If Congress fails to reach an agreement to prevent the sequester, the Defense Department would face a $500 billion cut, while $700 billion would be deducted from other domestic discretionary programs. Steve Bell, a veteran of Capitol Hill who worked on the Senate Budget Committee for 39 years, including much of that time as a top aide, stated that there is a sense of resignation among many members of Congress regarding the potential impact of the sequester.

Bell, who is now with the Bipartisan Policy Center in Washington, D.C., said in an interview that the pro-defense people have lost momentum, while the big deficit hawks have gained momentum. He added that a strong minority consensus is emerging, stating, "Let the sequester occur. It's the only spending cuts we're ever going to get out of this entire mess from the last four years."

The Bipartisan Policy Center has warned that the threat of future cuts could cause companies to take preemptive measures, such as layoffs and other actions. Steve Bell stated, "The sequester, and its impact on defense, we believe, will lead to furloughs of civilian defense workers. It will lead to either the sale or bankruptcy of very small subcontractors, things that are occurring right now in the Washington, D.C., area. People are selling their small businesses to larger defense contractors because they can't stay in business. And we think the net effect will probably be, conservatively, a million lost jobs just from the defense sequester alone."

Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, described Wednesday's news as a "clamorous klaxon horn sounding danger." In a statement, he said, "We must avoid sequestration because of the damage it would do to the economy, to important domestic investments, and to our national security. Today's GDP report demonstrates what is at stake economically. Top economists have warned us that sequestration could send us back into recession, and we should heed their warnings."

Defense contractors, who have much at stake, also expressed concern. Marion Blakey, president of the Aerospace Industries Association, stated, "It's what we have been warning about for months and months, because we do know that the cuts to defense spending that are already in place through the Budget Control Act are causing our companies to pull back, laying off workers. That's going on right now. It has real effects in terms of their ability to invest in R&D, to train. There are a variety of aspects that all have an economic impact. We know if a sequester goes into effect, we're going to see a much more dramatic acceleration of job losses."

Blakey cited a study by George Mason University economists that forecast 2 million lost jobs in the first year of a sequester. Douglas Holtz-Eakin, president of the American Action Forum, a former Congressional Budget Office director, and a favorite of Capitol Hill conservatives, does not disagree that the sequester is a bad idea. However, he thinks too much is being made of the fourth-quarter GDP data.

Holtz-Eakin notes that the third quarter saw defense spending rise robustly, and he expects the Commerce Department number-crunchers to eventually revise upward the fourth-quarter data. In an interview, he said, "It would be better not to have [the sequester] happen, but this is not why. You can make too much of today's GDP report pretty easily... if you ignore the weird timing and look between midyear and now, defense spending dropped at about a 6 percent annual rate. And that's what we expect to be happening."

The U.S. military withdrawals from Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as the Pentagon following orders to downsize over 10 years, explain part of what we're seeing, Holtz-Eakin said. "Is the sequester a good idea? No. It was supposed to be such a bad idea that we'd do something good. The fact that it was a bad idea originally has not changed. It's still a bad idea. It should not happen."
