However, Holtz-Eakin's comments have made defense contractors and many others nervous. He said, "I do not think that if the 2013 sequester happened, it would be the end of the world. I think the economy could still grow." But he said the 10 years worth of sequester cuts to defense and domestic discretionary spending is the wrong strategy. It's more like the European-style austerity that has helped throw many of those nations into recession. The focus, according to Holtz-Eakin, should be on entitlement cuts.

The reason we got the sequester in the first place was due to the competing and partisan views of reality in Washington. Wednesday offered little relief on that front. White House spokesman Jay Carney blamed Republicans for letting matters get to the present stage. He said in his Wednesday briefing, "Talk about letting the sequester kick in as though that were an acceptable thing belies where Republicans were on this issue not that long ago, and it makes clear again that this is sort of political brinksmanship of the kind that results in one primary victim, and that's American taxpayers, the American middle class."

To which House Republicans attempted to hold up a mirror to President Obama. Brendan Buck, a spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner, said in a statement, "The President's own policies are causing our economy to stall. The President's sequester is already hurting our military and our economy. It's time for the President to work with us to replace the sequester with common-sense spending cuts and entitlement reforms."

Title: Obama Proposes One-Year Extension for Cancelled Health Insurance Policies

Article:

President Barack Obama has proposed a one-year extension for health insurance policies that would otherwise be cancelled due to the Affordable Care Act. The proposal aims to alleviate the controversy surrounding the cancellation of individual insurance policies and the subsequent blame game between the administration and the health insurance industry.

At a press conference on Thursday, Obama stated, "The bottom line is insurers can extend current plans that would otherwise be cancelled into 2014." The announcement follows a series of public backlash and criticism over the cancellation of individual insurance policies due to the Affordable Care Act.

Industry CEOs have been summoned to a White House meeting on Friday, which is expected to be filled with discussions about the responsibilities and accountability of both parties involved. The proposal has been met with skepticism from health insurers, state insurance commissioners, and leading actuaries, who question the feasibility of the extension.

Health insurance plans have already set their prices for the Affordable Care Act plans based on a specific number of customers and the right mix of healthy and sick individuals. If they do not receive the expected number of customers, they warn that the mix will be disrupted, and prices will increase, potentially creating a new challenge for the administration.

Karen Ignagni, president and CEO of America's Health Insurance Plans, the leading health insurance trade group, stated, "Changing the rules after health plans have already met the requirements of the law could destabilize the market and result in higher premiums for consumers."

Cori Uccello, the senior health fellow at the American Academy of Actuaries, added, "Changing the [Affordable Care Act] provisions could alter the dynamics of the insurance market, creating two parallel markets operating under different rules, thereby threatening the viability of insurance markets operating under the new rules."

The proposal comes as a political solution to a policy problem, according to Bill Pierce, a former Department of Health and Human Services official who has also worked in the health insurance industry. Pierce, now a senior director at APCO Worldwide, stated, "You can not solve a policy problem with a political solution."

Obama acknowledged the administration's role in the rollout issues of the health care law, stating, "What we want to do is to be able to say to these folks, you know what, the Affordable Care Act is not going to be the reason why insurers have to cancel your plan." However, the feasibility and implications of the proposed extension remain uncertain.

Title: Protesters Gather at Baton Rouge Convenience Store Following Fatal Police Shooting of Alton Sterling

Article:

A day after the fatal shooting of Alton Sterling, a 37-year-old man, by police in the parking lot of a convenience store in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, protesters gathered at the site. The incident, which occurred at around 12:30 a.m. on Tuesday, has sparked widespread outrage and calls for transparency.

The scene was marked by concentric rings of protesters, with the outermost ring consisting of young men driving cars around the block, blaring "Fuck the police." In the next ring, neighbors gathered, sharing stories and memories of Sterling, and in the center, a trio of devastated people stood near the store's entrance.

Tawandra Carr, a neighbor who had a playful relationship with Sterling, was the last person to speak to him before the incident. At about 12:30 a.m., Carr approached Sterling in the parking lot, and the two pretended to argue before breaking into laughter. Sterling seemed in a good mood, according to Carr, unaware that an anonymous caller had told police that Sterling had threatened him with a pistol, and officers were on their way.

Sterling had packed up his wares for the night, but Carr persuaded him to sell her a bootleg copy of the movie "Central Intelligence" for two dollars. Suddenly, two police cars arrived from opposite directions and pulled into the parking lot. Carr's account starts to coincide with a video made by a bystander at this point.

The video shows the officers tackling Sterling onto the hood of a car and then to the ground, where they pin him. In the midst of overlapping yelling and cursing, one of the officers cried out, "He's got a gun!" and both officers drew their weapons.

Abdullah Muflahi, who owns the Triple S Food Mart and had always allowed Sterling to sell his music and movies in the parking lot, arrived shortly after the incident. He pulled out his phone and started recording. The officers were on top of Sterling, and there was a cluster of two or three shots. The police then rolled off, and Sterling lay with blood pooling on his chest.

An officer appeared to reach into Sterling's pocket and pull out what Muflahi said was a gun. Muflahi kept his phone video a secret, fearing that the police would confiscate it. In short order, they did, taking the security camera footage from his store as well.

Veda Washington, Sterling's aunt, arrived later. She had helped raise Sterling and took him in when his mother died in 1992 when he was a teenager. When she arrived at the scene, she alternated between chanting "Black lives matter" and wailing in mourning for the nephew she regarded as a son.

The officers involved in the shooting, Blane Salamoni and Howie Lake, have been placed on paid administrative leave, as is standard practice for officers involved in shootings. Salamoni's father is a high-ranking member of the Baton Rouge police, and in 2009, before he became a police officer, Salamoni was charged with disturbing the peace, but the charge was dropped. The other officer, Lake, was involved in another shooting in 2014.

On Wednesday morning, the Louisiana governor, John Bel Edwards, announced that the state was handing over the investigation to federal authorities after calls for transparency from community leaders and Sterling's family. By Wednesday night, the mood among protesters at the Triple S was tense, with people expressing anger, disillusionment with the police, and fear. However, the mood quickly shifted as gospel music played, and people started to sing along. Veda Washington, Sterling's aunt, took the microphone and called for peace in their protests.

Title: House Passes Comprehensive Legislation to Combat Prescription Drug Epidemic

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives passed a comprehensive bill on Friday aimed at addressing the prescription drug epidemic, which has resulted in more overdose deaths in recent years than car accidents. The bill passed with a vote of 400-5, marking the last of 18 bipartisan pieces of legislation the House passed this week to address the drug crisis.

The abuse of opioids, synthetic painkillers, has become a significant issue in recent years. According to the Centers for Disease Control, more than 28,000 people died from overdoses from these drugs in 2014, and overdose deaths have quadrupled since 1999.

The legislation aims to combat the crisis in several ways, including helping pregnant mothers who suffer from addiction, increasing access to naloxone (a drug that can reverse the effects of an overdose), and creating a task force of patients, medical officials, advocacy groups, and federal agencies to establish guidelines for prescribing pain medication.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy stated at a press conference, "This has been a very big week in the House. Addiction divides families. Addiction tears communities apart. Addiction takes lives." He continued, "This week, action was taken. It was a bipartisan action."

Speaker Paul Ryan has made the issue a top priority, highlighting the legislation multiple times throughout the week. In a press conference with House leadership, he invited Reps. Susan Brooks of Indiana and Robert Dold of Illinois, both of whom sponsored opioid measures that passed this week, to discuss the personal impact of the epidemic.

The Senate passed comprehensive legislation in March, authorizing $725 million in grants for state and local governments to strengthen drug monitoring, improve addiction treatment, and expand prevention, education, and law enforcement efforts. The bill the House passed on Friday consolidates the different measures passed throughout the week into one comprehensive package.

The House and Senate are expected to create a conference committee to iron out the differences between their measures and send the legislation to President Obama, who is expected to sign it. However, issues of funding remain, with the White House proposing $1.1 billion in new funding to combat the addiction problem, but the current legislation calling for a lesser amount without providing the funding.

Democrats in both chambers of Congress attempted to pass amendments that would have provided $600 million in funding, but Republicans blocked both efforts and plan to address the issue in the regular appropriations process later this year. Sen. Rob Portman, R-Ohio, the author of the Senate's opioid legislation, has been actively pushing the House to act more swiftly and in a comprehensive way on this issue. Portman expressed confidence that the House and Senate versions can be consolidated into a single comprehensive bill and sent to the president's desk soon.

Title: Buttigieg Accused of Plagiarism in Speeches Reminiscent of Obama

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg is facing accusations of plagiarism after a series of tweets and speeches that appear to mimic the language and phrasing of former President Barack Obama.

Over the weekend, Buttigieg tweeted a series of statements that drew comparisons to a tweet from Obama in 2012. Buttigieg wrote, "If we can light up a high school gym—we can light a neighborhood. If we can light up a neighborhood—we can light a city. If we can light up a city—we can light up our country."

A number of Twitter users compared this to a tweet from Obama in 2012, where the president wrote, "One voice can change a room. And if it can change a room, it can change a city. And if it can change a city, it can change a state."

Co-host of "The View" Meghan McCain commented, "Oh COME ON! I know Pete thinks he's the next Obama but this is ridiculous."

The Buttigieg campaign told Fox News that the tweet was in reference to an event earlier on the campaign trail where the lights went out and attendees used their cellphones as lights.

Parkland survivor and conservative activist Kyle Kashuv accused Buttigieg of making a habit of mimicking Obama and further claimed the presidential candidate was plagiarizing while sharing a mash-up of similarities between Buttigieg and Obama's speeches. Kashuv tweeted a video made by The Recount with the message, "So it turns out Pete Buttigieg is just blatantly plagiarizing Barack Obama. Cmon man at least come up [with] your own platitudes..."

Liberals also noticed a pattern, with another clip of Buttigieg using similar language to Obama being shared by a writer for Common Dreams, a publication that identifies as "providing breaking news & views for the progressive community."

The Buttigieg campaign has not yet responded to requests for comment on the plagiarism allegations.

Title: White House Prevents CDC Director from Testifying on School Reopening Amidst Ongoing Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

The White House has blocked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Director, Robert Redfield, from testifying before Congress regarding the reopening of schools amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. On Friday, it was announced that Redfield would not be allowed to speak at the hearing for the House Committee on Education and Labor's Subcommittee on Early Childhood, Elementary, and Secondary Education scheduled for July 23.

House Education Committee Chairman Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.) criticized the White House's decision, stating, "It is alarming that the Trump administration is preventing the CDC from appearing before the Committee at a time when its expertise and guidance is so critical to the health and safety of students, parents, and educators."

Scott also condemned the White House's "lack of transparency" at such a critical point during the pandemic as "difficult decisions" are being made regarding schools. He added, "This lack of transparency does a great disservice to the many communities across the country facing difficult decisions about reopening schools this fall."

The White House's decision comes amid ongoing deliberation about reopening schools in the fall. As more than 38 states are seeing increases in coronavirus cases, President Donald Trump has continued to demand schools reopen in the fall. When the CDC released its guidelines for safely reopening schools, the president took to Twitter, lambasting their recommendations and demanding revisions.

However, Redfield made it clear that the CDC does not plan to revise its guidelines but instead plans to provide more information. In a tweet on July 8, Trump stated, "I disagree with @CDCgov on their very tough & expensive guidelines for opening schools. While they want them open, they are asking schools to do very impractical things. I will be meeting with them!"

As of Saturday morning, there are more than 3.7 million known coronavirus cases in the United States, with the death toll surpassing 142,000 and over 1.7 million reported recoveries.

Title: White House Decision on Encryption Access for Tech Companies

Article:

The White House has made a decision regarding access to encrypted data on technology products, which extends beyond merely cooperating with companies like Apple and Google in criminal and national security investigations. The administration has determined that it will not compel these companies to breach the security of their products.

Investigators will now have to rely on alternative methods to obtain data stored in the cloud in unencrypted form or transmitted over phone lines, as these are covered by a law affecting telecommunications providers but not technology giants.

Last year, FBI Director James Comey expressed concern after Apple introduced an operating system that encrypted nearly all data contained in an iPhone. The system was designed to ensure that Apple did not retain the keys, giving users control through the codes or fingerprints they use to access their phones. As a result, Apple, upon receiving a court order for data, could not access the encrypted information.

Comparing the system to a door law enforcement could not enter or a car trunk they could not unlock, Comey's concern about the so-called "going dark" problem received support from the director of the National Security Agency and other intelligence officials.

After a year of study and extensive White House debate, President Obama and his advisers have reached a broad conclusion that an effort to compel companies to give the government access would fail, both politically and technologically.

Peter G. Neumann, one of the nation's leading computer scientists and a co-author of a paper that examined the government's proposal for special access, stated, "This looks promising, but there's still going to be tremendous pressure from law enforcement. The N.S.A. is capable of dealing with the cryptography for now, but law enforcement is going to have real difficulty with this. This is never a done deal."

Title: Incumbents Struggle as Ebola, ISIS, and Stock Market Volatility Dominate Election Narrative

Article:

The final stretch before the November 4th election is proving to be a challenging one for incumbents, as domestic and overseas crises dominate the political landscape. President Barack Obama was forced to cancel several campaign appearances this week to oversee the Ebola response, highlighting the growing troubles that are upending plans for the final stretch before the election.

The current election cycle is particularly acute, with challenges ranging from the Ebola virus to ISIS jihadists to a volatile stock market. Instead of highlighting their accomplishments to constituents, incumbents are on defense.

Julian Zelizer, a professor of history at Princeton University, noted that "October 2014 is starting to remind me of October 2006, which in my professional time was the worst cycle for Republicans, and the best for Democrats." In 2006, Bush's Republicans, like Obama's Democrats, could not catch a break. Powerless in the face of the sectarian explosion engulfing Iraq and scarred by Hurricane Katrina, Bush limped into the elections and Democrats marched off with the Senate and the House of Representatives.

Today, Democrats in tough elections do not want to be seen with Obama, and Kentucky Senate candidate Alison Lundergan Grimes has refused to say if she voted for the president. The gloomy October is making it easier for Republicans to press their case against Obama and incumbent Democrats.

Republican candidates are seizing on the Ebola crisis, with GOP Rep. Cory Gardner demanding action amid Republican calls for a travel ban covering the epicenter of Ebola in West Africa. In a Colorado Senate debate on Wednesday, Gardner said, "If the president is not willing to put into a place a travel ban, then we should have 100 percent screening of the people who are coming from those affected areas."

Democratic Sen. Mark Udall, trailing Gardner in the Rocky Mountain state, hit back by accusing his opponent of complicity in budget cuts for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Potential Republican 2016 challengers are also pitching in, despite Obama's assurances that the chances of catching Ebola are "extraordinarily" low. Senator Rand Paul said in an interview with CNN Thursday, "If someone has Ebola at a cocktail party, they're contagious and you can catch it from them."

The multiple crises have also played into a critique that the president is too passive and reacts to, rather than dictates, events. Few charges are as damaging for a president as the sense he has lost control, and the cascade of dramas over the last six weeks or so has often left the White House struggling to catch up.

There is also trouble for the White House abroad in the run-up to the mid-terms, and Republicans also see an opening against Obama and incumbent Democrats in the fight against ISIS. In one spot, New Hampshire senatorial candidate Scott Brown warned, "Radical Islamic terrorists are threatening to cause the collapse of our country. President Obama and Senator Shaheen seem confused about the nature of the threat. Not me."

Meanwhile, stock market losses complicate Democratic attempts to highlight what good economic news there is out there—including increasingly robust jobs growth and a dip in the unemployment rate to 5.9 percent, the lowest level in six years.

Despite being in the box seat in most Senate races, Republicans are hardly basking in popularity—a fact encouraging to Democrats as 2016 looms. The Republican brand is also battered, following gridlock in Congress and a government shutdown last year, and the unfinished tussle between the establishment and the Tea Party.

"The story of the Republican Party under Obama, no matter how many problems the president faces, is that they have consistently managed to shoot themselves in the foot," said Zelizer, who is also a CNN contributor.

Title: House Approves School Security Measures, No Action on Gun Control

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives has approved a bill to allocate more funds for metal detectors, locks, and other school security measures, but has taken no steps towards tightening gun control laws, one month after a shooting at a Florida high school that resulted in the deaths of 17 individuals.

On Wednesday, lawmakers voted 407-10 in favor of legislation to allocate between $50 million to $75 million annually from 2019 through 2028 for school security and safety training. No parallel measure is currently pending in the Senate, where a more ambitious bill is being debated.

Representative Steny Hoyer, the No. 2 House Democrat, stated that the bill, on its own, is not sufficient to address the issue of gun violence. He called for a serious effort to pass legislation that expands background checks and bans military-style assault weapons.

The House bill does not allow any of the funding to be used for arming teachers or other school personnel. The White House has stated that the bill would be improved by lifting this restriction.

Since the Parkland massacre, student protesters have successfully lobbied for tighter gun controls in Florida. Hundreds of them gathered outside the Capitol to urge Congress to take action on placing new limits on firearms and gun sales.

In the Senate, a bill to strengthen existing background checks of gun purchasers is being debated and enjoys broad bipartisan support, but has not been scheduled for debate. Congressional aides report that discussions are underway about folding the school safety and background check bills into a government funding bill that lawmakers aim to pass by March 23.

Eleven organizations, including some gun control and law enforcement groups, have written to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, urging the passage of the background checks bill this month.

Since the Florida shooting, the Republican-led Congress and the Trump administration have considered measures to curb gun violence while trying to avoid crossing the powerful National Rifle Association lobby group or threatening the right to bear arms enshrined in the U.S. Constitution's Second Amendment. Neither the House nor Senate bills address many of the gun control initiatives backed by students, teachers, and families of shooting victims at the Florida school.

In testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Katherine Posada, a teacher at the school, recounted the horror she experienced the day of the shooting and urged Congress to ban assault-style weapons like the AR-15 rifle used by Nikolas Cruz, who has been charged in the murders.

"Some of the victims were shot through doors, or even through walls – a knife can’t do that," Posada said. "How many innocent lives could have been saved if these weapons of war weren’t so readily available?"

Title: Three Missing Women Found Alive in Cleveland After Decade-Long Captivity

Article:

Three young women, Amanda Berry (27), Gina DeJesus (23), and Michelle Knight (32), who had been missing for several years, were found alive on Monday evening in a home in Cleveland, Ohio. The women, whose disappearances generated significant attention in local media over the past decade, were discovered after Berry's frantic cries for help brought a neighbor to the door.

Amanda Berry disappeared at age 16 on April 21, 2003, when she called her sister to say she was getting a ride home from her job at a Burger King. About a year later, Gina DeJesus vanished at age 14 on her way home from school. Police said Knight disappeared in 2002 and is 32 now. The three women were found inside a home where the shades were always drawn, and no one in the neighborhood seemed to have suspected that kidnapping victims might be inside.

Three brothers in their 50s have been arrested in relation to the women's disappearances. They are 52-year-old Ariel Castro, 54-year-old Pedro Castro, and 50-year-old Onil Castro. As of midday Tuesday, authorities had not released any details about what they found inside the home or exactly what they've learned from the three women.

According to The Associated Press, the women are being treated at a Cleveland area hospital, where they're reported to be in fair condition. The three suspects are expected to be charged within the next 36 hours.

Neighbors have provided accounts of the women's discovery and the man who they would see coming and going from the home. Charles Ramsey, a neighbor, reported hearing screaming and seeing a young woman trying to escape from the house. Ramsey helped Berry escape by kicking and breaking the bottom of a door, allowing her to crawl out. Police arrested Ariel Castro at a nearby McDonald's restaurant and brought the other two women out of the house, witnesses said.

A young child also emerged from the home, according to local news reports. As for Ariel Castro, the man who lived in the home, neighbors reported seeing him parking his red pickup truck behind his house, locking the gate, and entering through a back door. The house was often dark, with shades blocking the windows.

As this story develops, more details are expected to emerge. The three women are being treated at a Cleveland area hospital, and the three suspects are in custody and expected to be charged within the next 36 hours.

Title: President Obama to Highlight Progress in Veterans Affairs, but Critics Point to Ongoing Scandals and Mismanagement

Article:

On Veterans Day, President Barack Obama will lay a wreath at Arlington National Cemetery and discuss his administration's progress in caring for veterans. However, critics of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) argue that little has changed, citing fresh scandals and persistent mismanagement.

According to White House officials, Mr. Obama will emphasize progress in five areas for veterans, including reducing the backlog of benefits claims, increasing access to health care services, and decreasing homelessness among veterans. In conjunction with Mr. Obama's announcements, Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe is set to declare that his state is the first to eliminate veterans' homelessness statewide.

The President will also call on Congress to act on three pieces of legislation to expand education benefits for veterans. However, problems within the VA continue unabated. An internal VA audit has found that secret waitlists occurred not only in Phoenix but at 110 VA facilities.

VA officials have yet to correct a computer system error that led to tens of thousands of combat veterans being denied VA health care enrollment, despite the problem being brought to light in August. The administration has tried, under VA Secretary Robert McDonald, to move beyond the crisis that erupted in Phoenix in April 2014 over delayed health care for veterans and phony waitlists, which led to the resignation of former Secretary Eric K. Shinseki. The agency claims it has handled about 7 million more health care appointments for veterans in the past 12 months than in the previous year.

"Because of many of the reforms that Secretary McDonald has put into place, we have seen important progress made at the VA when it comes to ensuring that our veterans have access to the health care and benefits that they deserve," said White House press secretary Josh Earnest.

Nearly 18 months after the waitlist scandal broke in Phoenix, the problems there are not resolved. An inspector general's report in October found that seven more Phoenix-area veterans died after delayed treatment and lapses in medical care.

Mr. McDonald also acknowledged during a House hearing last month that his department is suffering "a leadership crisis." In September, for example, one of his top deputies quit under pressure from congressional investigators looking into a scandal over padding the salaries and relocation expenses of senior VA managers. Five VA officials invoked their Fifth Amendment rights at a House Committee on Veterans' Affairs hearing last week in connection with the probe.

Committee Chairman Jeff Miller, Florida Republican, said the VA is still suffering from a culture that fails to hold wrongdoing accountable.

"Until the VA rids itself of those who engage in scandalous behavior, the department will always be mired in scandal," Mr. Miller wrote in an op-ed in The Hill Tuesday. "But unfortunately, indefensible civil service rules that put the job security of failing VA bureaucrats ahead of the safety of the veterans they are charged with serving are prolonging the agency's problems indefinitely."

Pete Hegseth, president of Concerned Veterans for America, says the VA under Mr. McDonald "is not fundamentally serious about fixing the systematic problems plaguing the department."

Government watchdogs in the past year have found numerous additional cases of VA whistleblowers facing retaliation, and of VA leadership failing to discipline those responsible for mismanagement or dangerous health care practices. The Office of Special Counsel wrote directly to Mr. Obama on Sept. 17 about continued problems at the Phoenix VA Medical Center, including the lack of training of emergency room nurses and substandard care at other facilities.

OSC head Carolyn Lerner told the president that the lack of accountability for the problems in Phoenix "sends the wrong message to the veterans served by this facility, including those who received substandard emergency care." Meanwhile, she said, the VA continues to go after employee whistleblowers with a vengeance.

"The VA has attempted to fire or suspend whistleblowers for minor indiscretions and, often, for activity directly related to the employee's whistleblowing," she told Mr. Obama. In a speech last week at the National Press Club, Mr. McDonald claimed that the VA has "proposed disciplinary action against 300 individuals for manipulating scheduling."

"I just wish that there would be more fact-checking on some of the numbers that are used, because there are a lot of myths out there," he added. However, his claim is dubious. The VA's own statistics submitted to Congress showed that, as of last week, there were proposed disciplinary actions against 27 employees and one senior executive specifically for patient wait-time manipulation. Of those 27, three have been fired. Sharon Helman, the Phoenix VA medical center director, was fired for accepting improper gifts, not because of her role in the waitlist scandal. The department has proposed disciplinary action against 305 employees for various issues, including 20 probationary workers and other nonmedical employees such as food service workers and transportation supervisors. Funding for the VA has increased 73 percent since 2009, but examples of waste at the agency are rampant. Construction of a VA hospital in Denver is more than $1 billion over budget. An investigation earlier this year uncovered that a VA executive received almost $300,000 in relocation expenses to move from Washington to Philadelphia.

Title: Public Opinion on Interpretation of U.S. Constitution Divided Along Party, Age, and Demographic Lines

Article:

The ongoing Senate debate over Judge Neil Gorsuch's nomination to the Supreme Court has highlighted deep partisan and ideological divisions in Congress and the public regarding how the high court should interpret the Constitution.

According to a survey conducted in October, about half of the public (46%) believes the U.S. Supreme Court should make its rulings based on the Constitution's original meaning, while an identical share (46%) prefers decisions to be based on the Constitution's current meaning. This divide has remained relatively stable in recent years.

Republicans and Democrats hold starkly different views on this issue. Approximately 74% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor decisions based on the Constitution's original meaning, while 23% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents hold the same view. This gap is slightly wider than it was in February 2014, when 68% of Republicans and Republican leaners and 27% of Democrats and Democratic leaners favored the originalist approach.

There are significant differences in these views by age, race and ethnicity, education, and religious affiliation.

Adults younger than 30 favor decisions based on the Constitution's current meaning by about a two-to-one margin (63% to 31%), while those ages 30 to 49 are more divided (44% original meaning, 45% current meaning). A 54% majority of those 50 and older prefer decisions based on the Constitution's original meaning.

Racial and ethnic differences also emerge, with blacks (63%) more likely than whites (41%) to favor decisions based on the Constitution's current meaning. Adults with at least a college degree, particularly those with postgraduate degrees, are more likely than those with less education to favor decisions based on the Constitution's current meaning.

White evangelical Protestants overwhelmingly favor decisions based on the Constitution's original meaning (79%), while the religiously unaffiliated are more likely to favor decisions based on the Constitution's current meaning (64%).

Title: New CNN/ORC Poll Shows Mixed Reviews for President-elect Donald Trump's Transition and Presidency

Article:

Two weeks after the 2016 presidential election, a new CNN/ORC Poll reveals a divided American public regarding President-elect Donald Trump's performance during the transition and expectations for his presidency.

A majority (53%) of Americans believe Trump will do a good job as president, while 40% approve of his ability to handle the economy, a figure that surpasses the confidence levels for former presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and Ronald Reagan before their first inaugurations.

The poll indicates that Americans anticipate Trump will achieve several of his campaign promises, with 75% expecting him to repeal and replace Obamacare, 68% believing he will renegotiate NAFTA, and 60% predicting he will create good-paying jobs in economically challenged areas.

However, opinions are more divided on other issues such as "draining the swamp" (51%), defeating ISIS (50%), and building a wall along the border with Mexico (48%).

Overall, 66% of Americans believe a Trump presidency will bring change to the country, but only 43% expect it to be change for the better, a significant drop compared to the 63% who thought Obama would bring change for the better in November 2008.

Trump's favorability ratings have risen post-election to 47% favorable and 50% unfavorable, with these ratings outpacing the previous high reached just after the Republican National Convention in July (43% favorable).

Regarding Trump's transition, 46% approve of his handling, while 45% disapprove. These marks are lower than approval ratings for Obama, Bush, or Clinton during their transitions to the presidency.

On one point of concern, few say Trump's efforts have gone far enough to assuage their worries about potential conflicts of interest. About 60% say the arrangement Trump has proposed for handling his business while serving as president—to have his adult children run the Trump Organization—does not go far enough to prevent conflicts.

The poll suggests that Trump is shaping up to be one of the most polarizing presidents-elect in recent years. While there is relatively high confidence in his ability to deal with the economy, there is also an outsized lack of confidence and a diminished middle ground.

On handling foreign affairs, confidence in Trump is sharply downside-up, yet still, few land in the middle. Almost half (49%) say they have no real confidence, while 27% say they have a lot of faith in the president-elect. Just 23% say they have "some confidence."

Overall, Trump ranks toward the middle of the pack on providing leadership and making appointments, but his no-confidence numbers far outpace those for his predecessors. On providing real leadership, 33% have deep confidence, but 43% say they have no confidence. And thinking about appointing the best people to office, 32% say they have a lot of confidence in Trump, yet 45% say they have no confidence in him to choose appointees.

These numbers could shift as Trump fills out his cabinet and staff; polling measuring confidence in previous presidents-elect was conducted closer to their inauguration after many critical appointments had been made.

Several demographic divides that emerged during the campaign appear to persist post-election. Women are less likely to see Trump as a good president than men, and residents of rural areas are more than twice as likely as urbanites to think Trump will do a good job. Among those in union households, a typically Democratic constituency where Trump had stronger appeal than most Republicans, 53% expect Trump to do a good job as president.

Overall, the share saying things in the US are going well today has dipped from its late-October high, with 47% saying things are going well, down from 54% then. That shift is mostly partisan. While there has been an uptick in the share of Republicans who think things are going well (from 21% to 32%), the share of Democrats who say the same has dropped about twenty points (85% to 66%).

About half of Americans overall say that four years from now, they expect the country to be better off than it is today, 46% say it'll be worse off, and just 3% say it'll be the same. That's worse than impressions of how the country would be after four years of Obama, but a little better than assessments of how it'd be doing four years into George W. Bush's presidency.

Title: Trump Defends Criticism of Clinton's Campaign Success and Disputes Soft Foreign Policy Allegations

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Sunday defended his criticism that Hillary Clinton's campaign success is largely based on her being a female candidate and dismissed assertions about him having a soft foreign policy.

During an interview on "███ Sunday," Trump stated, "The only card she has is the woman card." He further added, "Even women don't like her. If she were not a woman, she would not even be in this race."

Trump's comments come after his sweep in five Northeast primary contests on Tuesday, where he said, "The only card she has is the woman's card. And frankly, if Hillary Clinton were a man, I don't think she'd get 5 percent of the vote."

In response to criticism that his foreign policy speech last week sounded like a liberal Democrat's, Trump argued, "We need to knock off ISIS and get out of there." He continued to argue that overthrowing dictators has been a failed foreign policy strategy that has led to instability in the Middle East.

"Every move we've made in the Middle East has been wrong," Trump said, arguing that other countries should pay more to protect the world and that more taxpayer money must go to U.S. infrastructure.

"We can't have this anymore," Trump said. "We are spending all of our money in the Middle East. We need to strengthen our military and pull back... In the meantime, our country is becoming Third World." Trump also stated, "I will be tougher than Clinton."

GOP primary rival Texas Sen. Ted Cruz told ABC's "This Week" that Trump's policy speech "reflects a weak and naive approach to foreign policy."

Trump also argued that his attacks on Clinton are no worse than those of her primary challenger, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who has questioned Clinton's qualifications.

While both Clinton and Trump's favorability ratings among women are low, Trump's are worse, especially among female general election voters. However, Trump argued Sunday that his numbers will improve if and when he faces Clinton in the general election.

"Once I start on Hillary, the numbers will change," he said. "Watch what happens with Hillary. Watch what happens with her numbers."

Title: House Democrats Introduce Resolution to Block President Trump's National Emergency Declaration, Setting Up Potential First Veto

Article:

House Democrats have initiated a move to counter President Trump's national emergency declaration along the U.S.-Mexico border by introducing a resolution to block the decree, potentially leading to the president's first veto. The resolution, proposed by Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), enjoys significant support from fellow majority Democrats in the House. As of Friday morning, Castro announced that the measure had 222 cosponsors, including Republican Rep. Justin Amash.

In a press call with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), Castro's resolution was described as a response to what Pelosi called the "FakeTrumpEmergency" and the border wall the president is seeking to fund. The level of support for the resolution all but guarantees its passage in the House. However, there is a possibility that the Republican-controlled Senate could also follow suit, potentially revealing a significant divide within the party over the president's decision.

Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) has already expressed support for such a measure, and several other Republicans have voiced concern over the president's declaration. This scenario could see the resolution clearing the Senate, leading to a striking fissure in the party over the president's decision, and likely prompting Trump to issue his first veto.

In a letter to colleagues, Pelosi stated, "We have a solemn responsibility to uphold the Constitution, and defend our system of checks and balances against the President's assault." She argued that the president's decision to bypass the constitutional legislative process to secure funding for the border wall violates the Constitution and must be terminated.

Trump, on the other hand, maintains that the wall is necessary to protect the country from illegal immigration, crime, and drugs. He has highlighted construction already underway and pledged to continue with more as he braces for both a congressional and legal battle. In response to a lawsuit launched earlier this week by more than a dozen Democrat-led states, he criticized "Open Border Democrats and the Radical Left."

The brief resolution filed Friday simply states, "The national emergency declaration is hereby terminated." The House passed the measure during a short pro forma session, with Rep. Don Beyer (D-Va.) presiding over an almost empty chamber. Pelosi has promised that the House will "move swiftly" to pass the measure, predicting that the resolution will be referred to the Senate and then sent to the President's desk.

Trump declared the emergency last Friday, a decision tied to his signing of a government spending package that averted a second shutdown. While that package included $1.4 billion for 55 miles of border barrier – significantly less than Trump sought – Trump aims to use the emergency declaration and other tools to secure billions more. The money would be transferred from a federal asset forfeiture fund, Defense Department anti-drug efforts, and a military construction fund. Federal officials have yet to identify which projects would be affected.

Title: Obama Endorses Justin Trudeau for Canadian Election Amid Blackface Controversy

Article:

Former U.S. President Barack Obama endorsed Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for re-election on Wednesday, offering him support amidst the recent controversy over Trudeau's use of blackface. The endorsement comes as Trudeau seeks to remain in office following next week's elections, but his campaign has been impacted by the release of photos and videos showing Trudeau with his face painted black or brown for various costumes.

Trudeau apologized for his actions, but admitted he could not confirm that those were the only instances he had worn blackface. In a tweet, Obama expressed his support for Trudeau, stating, "I was proud to work with Justin Trudeau as President. He's a hard-working, effective leader who takes on big issues like climate change. The world needs his progressive leadership now, and I hope our neighbors to the north support him for another term."

Obama and Trudeau have been friends since Trudeau was elected in 2015, and their friendship has continued even after Obama left office in 2017. The endorsement, however, highlights a contrast with Obama's handling of U.S. presidential primaries, in which he has not publicly endorsed any candidate, not even his former vice president, Joe Biden.

Some Canadians have expressed discomfort with Obama's endorsement as a form of foreign election interference. Drew Fagan, a professor of public policy at the Munk School of Global Affairs, described it as "unusual." However, there is no evidence of actual interference at this time.

Elections Canada spokeswoman Natasha Gauthier told the BBC that determining foreign influence would require an examination of expenses, the parties incurring them, and their reasons. Obama has endorsed foreign leaders in the past, such as French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Title: Senate Adopts Amended 'Gang of Eight' Immigration Framework

Article:

The United States Senate has adopted the amended 'Gang of Eight' immigration framework, a bipartisan proposal aimed at overhauling the nation's immigration system. The vote, which took place on Monday, resulted in a 68-32 majority, falling short of the symbolically significant 70-vote threshold that some had anticipated.

The legislation required 51 votes to pass, and it significantly outperformed that minimum. Fourteen members of the Republican conference crossed party lines to support the bill, while every 'no' vote was cast by a Republican. The Senate's debate focused primarily on the Republican party, with Senators sitting at their desks and voting one by one as the roll was called. Vice President Biden presided over the chamber, admonishing the gallery against overt expressions of approval or disapproval.

The House of Representatives is now set to consider the bill, but House Speaker John Boehner has already stated his intention to disregard the Senate-passed bill. The House saga may not begin for some time, and even Senator Marco Rubio, one of the bill's main proponents, has signaled support for the creation and passage of a distinct House bill.

Republican 'ayes' in the Senate vote included Alexander (TN), Ayotte (NH), Chisea (NJ), Collins (ME), Corker (TN), Flake (AZ), Graham (SC), Hatch (UT), Heller (NV), Hoeven (ND), Kirk (IL), McCain (AZ), Rubio (FL), Murkowski (AK).

House Deputy Whip, Rep. Peter Roskam (R-IL), has described passing the Senate bill as a "pipe dream" in his chamber. House Speaker John Boehner has emphasized the need for immigration reform to be grounded in "real border security." The immigration reform discussion now shifts to the House of Representatives.

Title: Congress Approves Fiscal Crisis Package with Special-Interest Tax Breaks, Worth $76 Billion

Article:

Congress has approved a last-minute deal aimed at preventing middle-class tax hikes, which includes over 50 temporary tax breaks for various industries, totaling approximately $76 billion. The tax breaks, extended for another year through the fiscal crisis package, have been criticized by lawmakers for including special-interest favors such as tax breaks for Hollywood, Puerto Rico rum producers, and the alternative energy industry.

The tax breaks include:

1. A rule allowing TV and film producers to write off the first $15 million in production costs inside the U.S., valued at $248 million over 10 years.
2. A provision allowing motorsport race tracks to more quickly write off improvement costs, valued at $78 million.
3. A 50% tax credit for expenses related to railroad track maintenance through 2013, worth $331 million.
4. Increased tax rebates to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands from a tax on rum imported into the United States, worth $222 million over 10 years.
5. A tax credit of up to $2,500 for buying electric-powered vehicles, expanded to include electric-powered motorcycles, at a cost of $7 million.
6. A tax credit for the production of wind, solar, and other renewable energy, at a cost of $12.2 billion.

The biggest of the tax breaks is a research and development tax credit, which helps U.S. manufacturers compete against foreign competition, according to the National Association of Manufacturers. Another provision helps restaurants and retailers expand by allowing them to more quickly write off the costs, according to the National Restaurant Association.

While each industry defends their tax treatment as vital, Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) stated that the inclusion of these tax breaks in the package feeds "cynicism." McCain described the process as "crammed into the bill literally in the middle of the night." He added, "The American people deserve better and we have now earned their well-deserved disdain about the way we do business."

Title: Release of Republican Memo Alleging FBI and DOJ Abuse in Russia Probe Sparks Controversy

Article:

President Donald Trump, on Saturday, claimed that the release of a previously classified Republican memo, which alleges bias by the FBI and Department of Justice (DOJ) during the 2016 presidential campaign, vindicates him in the ongoing Russia probe. Trump's tweet read, "This memo totally vindicates ‘Trump’ in probe. But the Russian Witch Hunt goes on and on. There was no Collusion and there was no Obstruction (the word now used because, after one year of looking endlessly and finding NOTHING, collusion is dead). This is an American disgrace!"

House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) released the memo on Friday, alleging that officials at the FBI and DOJ used bias against Trump's campaign, ultimately leading to the appointment of special counsel Robert Mueller to investigate charges of collusion between aides working for then-candidate Trump and Russian officials.

Trump approved the memo's release on Friday and said its revelations were a "disgrace," adding, "A lot of people should be ashamed of themselves."

Reaction among lawmakers was divided. Rep. Pete King (R-N.Y.), also on the House Intelligence Committee, called for public hearings about the FBI and Justice Department actions that led to FISA warrants allowing the surveillance of former Trump adviser Carter Page.

However, fellow Republican Sen. John McCain of Arizona blasted the memo's release, saying it served "no American interests" to make the information public.

Democrats were mainly in unison in their condemnation of the Nunes memo, including House Intelligence Committee Vice Chairman Adam Schiff of California who said it was "deeply misleading and factually inaccurate." House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi also criticized the memo, releasing a statement on Friday calling it a "desperate attempt to distract the American people from the truth about the Trump-Russia scandal."

Democrats on the House Intelligence Committee are pushing to release their own memo and, in a statement on Friday, said the Nunes document failed to provide "vital context." Trump said Friday he "would be inclined" to allow a Democratic rebuttal if it passed a "security and legal review," according to a White House statement.

Democrats contend the four-page memo mischaracterizes highly sensitive classified information and was intended to undermine the Mueller criminal probe that was launched in May 2017 as an outgrowth of an earlier FBI investigation.

Jerrold Nadler, the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, said in a statement that Trump's decision to allow the release of the memo was "part of a coordinated propaganda effort to discredit, disable and defeat the Russia investigation."

On Saturday, Nadler circulated a memo to House Democrats disputing the conclusions of the Nunes memo and arguing that Page was a lawful target of surveillance. "Carter Page was, more likely than not, an agent of a foreign power. The Department of Justice thought so. A federal judge agreed," Nadler wrote in the memo.

Title: Government Shutdown: Uncertainty Surrounds Duration and Resolution

Article:

As of the current writing, there are no ongoing negotiations regarding the federal government shutdown, which marks the first such event in 17 years. The Democratic-controlled Senate rejected a House bill on Tuesday morning that called for a House-Senate conference to resolve the disagreement. Senate Democrats rejected the House request due to Republican efforts to tie continued government funding to attempts to restrict the Affordable Care Act.

Senate Democrats, led by Sen. Harry Reid, argue they are not opposed to revising Obamacare but are unwilling to do so under the threat of a government shutdown or debt default. "No matter how many times they try to extort the American people and the Democrats here in the Senate, we're not going to re-litigate the health care issue," Sen. Reid said on the Senate floor. "We're not going to do that. If they have problems with [Obamacare], we'll be happy to sit down and talk with them about a reasonable approach to do that, but we're not going to with a gun to the heads of the American people."

Speaker John Boehner and his House Republican conference have yet to offer a clear path out of the current crisis. Boehner stated in the House, "Our country has big problems. Today our government has big problems." The duration of the shutdown remains uncertain, with predictions from Stan Collender, a partner at communications firm Qorvis and a former senior Capitol Hill aide, suggesting the shutdown could last at least a week.

Democrats, for the time being, appear to have a unified front, which tends to provide more leverage in politics. In contrast, some Republicans have expressed doubts about the House GOP strategy. If Democrats maintain their position that negotiations will not begin until the House passes the Senate's "clean" spending bill and reopens the government, Speaker Boehner would need to compromise, relying on some of his Republicans and House Democrats to pass the spending bill. This could potentially lead to another House GOP revolt against his leadership.

Democrats also seem to have the advantage of public opinion, according to a new Quinnipiac poll, which found far more people opposing an Obamacare-induced government shutdown than favoring it—72 percent to 22 percent. Republicans may struggle to blame the shutdown on Democrats due to decades of anti-government rhetoric. Even now, with the shutdown newly in effect, the Republican message that Democrats are to blame is being muddied by GOP rhetoric.

Title: Democratic Presidential Race Intensifies as Labor Day Approaches

Article:

As the summer comes to an end, the race for the 2020 Democratic U.S. presidential nomination is set to intensify, with former Vice President Joe Biden's lead facing increased pressure. Biden, 76, has maintained a comfortable lead over his competitors, but his campaign has been marked by doubts over his age, fitness for office, and his ability to represent a party that has grown increasingly liberal.

The Democratic field, lacking a clear consensus candidate, is fractured along ideological and generational lines. While Biden enjoys widespread name recognition due to his eight years as Barack Obama's vice president and a long Senate career before that, he may suffer as voters focus on other candidates. This could open the door for his closest competitors, U.S. Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, or another rival, to gain momentum.

Democratic operative Joel Payne, who worked on Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign, described Biden as the weakest front-runner in a contested primary in a long time, attributing his standing largely to voters' familiarity with him rather than his performance on the campaign trail.

The Democratic field has shrunk slightly in the past month, with U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand dropping out last week. However, 20 contenders continue to vie for the nomination. Ten Democrats will square off on Sept. 12 at a debate in Houston.

Delacey Skinner, a Democratic strategist, noted that most people don't know many of the candidates. Jeff Link, a longtime Democratic strategist in Iowa, likened the primary-season campaign to an American football game, with Labor Day marking the start of the second half.

Biden has faced criticism for his gaffes and episodes of faulty memory, sparking concerns over his age and his capacity to challenge Trump if he is the party's nominee. Biden is also viewed skeptically by some Democrats who see him as an out-of-touch moderate in a party moving leftward.

Beyond Biden, the story of the contest's first few months has been the rise of Elizabeth Warren, whose relentless campaign schedule and formidable state-level organization have made her a serious threat to win the nomination. She has particularly emerged as a rival to Biden in Iowa, a state he needs to win to reinforce his argument that he is the candidate best equipped to take down Trump.

However, questions persist about Warren's ambitious liberal agenda and her ability to attract moderate and black voters, as Biden does. Skinner believes Warren can expand her appeal beyond siphoning liberal voters from Sanders and other candidates on the left.

All top-tier contenders have faced questions about their ability to unite a deeply divided party and ultimately defeat Trump. Sanders, a self-described "Democratic socialist," has seen his support slide compared to his 2016 presidential bid. U.S. Senator Kamala Harris had a seemingly breakout moment in the first Democratic debate in June but has since fallen back in the polls.

Pete Buttigieg, mayor of South Bend, Indiana, drew attention early in his campaign, but concerns persist about his lack of national experience and his handling of race relations and policing in his city.

Joe Zepecki, a Democratic strategist in the general election battleground state of Wisconsin, noted that flawed candidates are common at this stage of the campaign, and eventually, the party will coalesce behind a nominee.

While this may be true, the enduring questions surrounding Biden's age and fitness for office may mean Democrats will lack the "safe" choice they have had in the past, whether the candidate has been Al Gore in 2000, John Kerry in 2004, or Clinton in 2008 and 2016.

Iowa's Link said the 2020 race remains fluid, and even lower-tier contenders such as U.S. Senator Cory Booker or former U.S. Representative Beto O'Rourke could still make a charge. The objective for candidates at this stage, Link said, is to "organize, organize, organize - and get hot at the end."

Title: The Weekly Standard Ceases Publication: A Tribute to a Writer's Magazine

Article:

The conservative political and cultural magazine, The Weekly Standard, announced its closure today, marking the end of a publication that has been a hub for conservative political opinion writing, clear-eyed political journalism, and a unique blend of cultural criticism for over two decades.

Founded in the mid-1990s, The Weekly Standard was more than just a platform for conservative political discourse. It was a writer's magazine, defined by the distinct intelligences of the extraordinary people in its orbit. The magazine was known for its blend of gloriously middlebrow cultural criticism, unabashed idealism about America, seasoned realism about politics, and a sharp yet always sympathetic disdain for the ridiculous humanity of the elite institutions' inhabitants.

The magazine's personality was, in many ways, embodied by its longtime editor in chief, Bill Kristol. Known for his political philosophy and his ability to quote the great romantic poets on a dime, Kristol was deeply immersed in the minutia of the political moment, open to crazy ideas, always speaking half in jest, and somehow friends with practically everyone.

The Standard's strength lay in its ability to bring in great writers and let them be great. From the elitist anti-elitism of David Brooks' cultural writing in its early days to the sharp young-fogey heterodoxy of Matt Continetti's political writing in its middle age, the magazine was an incredible incubator of great writing.

The magazine's in-house writers, such as Christopher Caldwell, John Podhoretz, Matt Labash, Jon Last, Andy Ferguson, and many others, have defined the magazine's tone and made it special. The Standard was also a good venue for outside writers, spotting talent and providing a platform for their work.

The magazine's back-of-the-book section, dedicated to books, culture, faith, philosophy, and technology, was particularly noteworthy. This section showcased long, discursive essays on old books and new ideas, on faith and philosophy, on culture and technology. The Standard understood that politics is downstream of culture, and its back-of-the-book section reflected this understanding.

The Weekly Standard was a nursery of genius, as Thomas Paine once said, and the magazine offered proof of this statement. This article gives its thanks to The Weekly Standard and its writers for their contributions to political discourse and literary excellence.

Title: States Scramble to Protect Abortion Rights as Supreme Court Prepares to Hear Abortion Case

Article:

In 1973, the Supreme Court issued a landmark decision in the case Roe v. Wade, enshrining the constitutional right to an abortion. However, with a conservative-leaning Supreme Court and mounting attacks on abortion rights, states across the country are taking steps to protect a woman's right to choose in the event that the historic court decision is overturned.

Bonyen Lee-Gilmore, who works on state media campaigns for Planned Parenthood, stated, "The reality is that the balance of the Supreme Court is not in our favor. We have to be prepared [if] Roe falls. That's just part of the reality of living under the Trump administration."

The effort to protect abortion rights began last year when New York became the first state to enshrine the right to an abortion in its state law, effectively codifying Roe v. Wade. Since then, Illinois, Rhode Island, and Vermont have passed similar laws, while Michigan, New Jersey, and the District of Columbia are considering codifying the right to an abortion. In 2019, statehouses passed more legislation protecting or expanding abortion access than in the entire previous decade.

However, in the aftermath of the confirmation of two conservative justices to the Supreme Court in 2018, red states have been taking the opposite approach, preparing for a post-Roe world. In 2019, four states—Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri, and Tennessee—passed legislation known as trigger laws, which would ban abortion if the Supreme Court overturns Roe, and 12 states passed abortion bans. In total, eight states now have trigger laws on the books, and 20 have laws that could be used to restrict the right to an abortion if Roe were overturned.

Andrea Miller, president of the National Institute for Reproductive Health, stated, "States are going in widely divergent directions when it comes to both abortion rights and abortion access. We have a group of states last year that were tripping over each other in a race to the bottom to try to ban abortion outright, and then we also had a real record year on the other side."

According to Planned Parenthood, roughly 25 million women of reproductive age live in a state where abortion could be banned if Roe is overturned. Millions more are already forced to jump through hoops to access abortions, including 72-hour waiting periods, mandatory counseling, and invasive ultrasound procedures.

In March, the Supreme Court will hear its first abortion case since the confirmation of conservative justices Brett Kavanaugh and Neil Gorsuch. The case concerns a 2014 Louisiana law, which requires abortion providers to have admitting privileges at local hospitals, a stipulation that opponents of the bill argue would leave the state with only one provider for a population of more than 4.5 million. Although the justices are not expected to overturn Roe outright in this case, legal experts argue that if the court were to rule in favor of the law, access to abortion in states like Louisiana could exist in name only.

Title: Obama Criticizes Justice Department's Decision to Drop Flynn Charges, Cites Risk to Rule of Law

Article:

Former President Barack Obama has criticized the Justice Department for dropping charges against Michael Flynn, his ex-national security adviser, stating that it puts "the rule of law is at risk." The comments were made during a private conversation with former members of his administration, a recording of which was leaked to Yahoo News and reported on Saturday.

In the web conversation with the Obama Alumni Association, Obama expressed concern over the Justice Department's decision, stating, "The news over the last 24 hours I think has been somewhat downplayed — about the Justice Department dropping charges against Michael Flynn... That’s the kind of stuff where you begin to get worried that basic - not just institutional norms - but our basic understanding of rule of law is at risk."

However, Obama misstated the charges against Flynn, who was accused of making false statements to the FBI, not perjury. In 2017, Flynn pled guilty to lying to the FBI about his conversations with the then-Russian ambassador but later sought to withdraw his guilty plea.

Obama cited the Flynn case as a critical reason to vote for his former Vice President, Joseph R. Biden, in the November election against President Trump. He told the group, "So I am hoping that all of you feel the same sense of urgency that I do."

A former president criticizing internal Justice Department decisions is rare, as former chief executives typically avoid wading into political waters. Obama's comments were among his strongest attacks on the Trump administration so far, suggesting that he may become more outspoken as this year's election approaches.

On Thursday, the Justice Department dropped the case against Flynn, stating that the FBI's 2017 interview with Flynn was not conducted with "a legitimate investigative basis" because three weeks earlier, the bureau sought to close the probe, saying it had not uncovered any wrongdoing. Anti-Trump former FBI agent Peter Strzok pushed to keep the case open, according to bombshell court documents released earlier this month.

President Trump has pointed the finger at the Obama administration for the Flynn prosecution, which he has repeatedly blasted as corrupt. "He was targeted by the Obama administration to try to take down a president," the president said of Flynn on Thursday. "And I hope a big price is going to be paid."

"The Obama administration Justice Department was a disgrace, and they got caught. It’s treason," Mr. Trump continued.

Title: State Department Delays Release of Clinton Emails Due to Classified Information

Article:

The State Department has admitted that the process of reviewing potential classified information in former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton's emails has caused a delay in their release, leading to a violation of a federal judge's orders. John F. Hackett, the top open records officer for the department, stated that the government only recently realized the extent of classified information in Mrs. Clinton's communications and is currently working to ensure they are not disclosing sensitive information.

The department was supposed to have released 15 percent of Mrs. Clinton's emails by the end of July, but as of now, less than 12 percent have been released, with approximately 1,721 pages still to be published. This falls short of the goal set out by Judge Rudolph Contreras earlier this year.

Mrs. Clinton and her allies have consistently maintained that she did not conduct any classified business on her personal email account, which she used instead of an official secure State Department account. However, an inspector general has found information that should have been classified at the time Mrs. Clinton was sending it. As a result, the State Department is now having to redact all of that information from the released emails.

All of Mrs. Clinton's messages are government records and should have been stored at the State Department for open records searches. Her unique arrangement of using a private email server meant that, for six years, those messages were not part of the official record, and the State Department was not able to conduct a full, responsive search.

The State Department only demanded Mrs. Clinton return her emails to the department in 2014, nearly two years after she left office. She complied in December 2014, turning over 55,000 pages, constituting about 30,000 messages. She claimed to have expunged another 32,000 messages that were purely private, and maintains she is now in compliance with the law.

Mr. Hackett estimates that the State Department can make up the 1,700-page deficit over the next two months, releasing 6,106 pages of emails in August and another 7,156 in September. This will still leave more than 60 percent of the messages to be released from October through January, the deadline when Judge Contreras has ordered all 30,000 messages to be public.

Title: Michael Cohen Allegedly Paid Technology Expert to Manipulate Online Polls for Trump in 2015

Article:

WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump's former personal attorney Michael Cohen paid a technology expert to manipulate online polls in Trump's favor in 2015, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. John Gauger, the owner of Red Finch Solutions and chief information officer at Liberty University, said Cohen offered him $50,000 to manipulate two news sites' polls, the Journal reported Thursday, citing a government document and a person familiar with the matter.

Gauger said Cohen handed him a Walmart bag loaded with about $12,000 in cash during a 2015 meeting at Cohen's Trump Organization office. Cohen also reportedly threw in a boxing glove he said was once worn by a Brazilian mixed-martial arts fighter. However, Cohen never paid Gauger the remainder of the promised $50,000, the Journal said.

Cohen did not deny the report in a tweet Thursday morning, saying, "What I did was at the direction of and for the sole benefit of Trump."

"I truly regret my blind loyalty to a man who doesn't deserve it," wrote the man who once said he would "take a bullet" for the president.

Cohen did deny giving Gauger cash. "All monies paid to Mr. Gauger were by check," he said, according to the Journal.

Gauger did not appear to have much success at moving the needle in the polls he was paid to manipulate. In January 2014, Cohen asked Gauger to sway a CNBC online poll on the top American business leaders with a program that could vote for Trump repeatedly, the Journal report said. But Trump did not break into the top 100.

In February 2015, Cohen asked Gauger to boost Trump in a Drudge Report poll on potential 2016 Republican presidential candidates, according to Gauger. Trump ended up coming in fifth with 5 percent of the vote.

Cohen also asked Gauger to create a Twitter account with the handle @WomenForCohen that would be run by a female friend of Gauger's to portray Cohen as a "sex symbol" and hype his statements in favor of Trump's presidential campaign, the Journal reported.

Gauger said the last time he spoke to Cohen was in April 2018, after the lawyer's office, home, and hotel room were raided by the FBI. "It’s not a big deal," Gauger said Cohen told him about the investigation.

Last month, Cohen was sentenced to three years in federal prison after pleading guilty to crimes related to tax evasion, campaign finance violations, and lying to Congress. Although Gauger said Cohen never paid him the full promised amount, Cohen did ask the Trump Organization in January 2017 to reimburse him $50,000 for "tech services," prosecutors for the Southern District of New York said when Cohen was charged in August. The request was made in a handwritten note, along with his bill for the $130,000 in hush money paid to adult film star Stormy Daniels. That payment comprised one of the campaign finance violations to which Cohen pleaded guilty. He claims the payment, which constituted an illegal campaign contribution, was made at Trump's direction.

Title: Tillerson: All Options on Table in Dealing with North Korea, Diplomatic and Military

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has stated that while the U.S. does not wish to engage in military action against North Korea, all options, including military intervention, remain on the table if a significant threat arises. Tillerson made these remarks during a visit to South Korea on Friday, a day after stating that diplomatic efforts have failed to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear program.

Tillerson's Asia tour began in Japan and will conclude in China. The top American diplomat is traveling without a press contingent. In South Korea, Tillerson declared, "The policy of strategic patience has ended." He further stated, "We are exploring a new range of diplomatic, security, economic measures. All options are on the table."

Regarding potential military action, Tillerson said that while the U.S. would prefer to avoid armed conflict, "If they elevate the threat of their weapons program to a level that we believe requires action, then that option's on the table."

Joseph DeTrani, former special envoy for six-party talks with North Korea, told NPR's Audie Cornish, "I think he's being very straight with China, and the regional allies in the Asia region—South Korea and Japan—that we're looking at negotiations all the way to preemption. If there's an imminent strike against the United States, we have to look at all options on the table."

North Korea's nuclear threat and recent missile tests have cast a long shadow over Tillerson's trip. In a news conference with Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida on Thursday, the Korean peninsula was mentioned more than 40 times.

On Friday, concerns about North Korea prompted a missile evacuation drill on Japan's coast, where more than 100 residents of a town heard sirens and were told to take cover in an exercise that is seen as unprecedented.

DeTrani told NPR, "We've got to be as creative, we've got to be as forward-leaning as possible to give North Korea those off-ramps so they realize there are opportunities available to them that will not be available if they continue on the path of building nuclear and missile capabilities."

"And part of that will be international legitimacy—normal relations with the United States—but also part of that will be having a better relationship with the country that, whether they like it or not, they're tethered to, and that's the People's Republic of China," DeTrani added.

Tillerson will head to China this weekend, where he is expected to push Beijing to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear and missile programs. He is also expected to plan for a visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to meet with President Trump at Trump's private club in Mar-a-Lago, Florida, next month, although this has not been formally announced yet.

For its part, China wants its relations with the U.S. to remain stable, so as not to distract from a leadership reshuffle this fall.

Title: Supreme Court to Address Controversial Issues During Presidential Election

Article:

The Supreme Court is set to begin its next term on Monday, with a series of contentious issues that neither President Barack Obama nor Mitt Romney appear eager to discuss. The justices' docket includes the racially polarizing question of affirmative action, same-sex marriage, and the federal government's terrorist surveillance program.

The case on the University of Texas's affirmative action program, scheduled for argument on October 10, could reintroduce an issue that has been absent from the national political discourse for over a decade. The first presidential debate, focusing on domestic issues, is set for exactly one week before this case. The vice presidential debate is scheduled for October 11.

Richard Taylor, a business diversity advocate and former Massachusetts transportation secretary under Romney, expressed doubt that either candidate would publicly comment on these issues. "I’ve got to believe at this point in the campaign neither the president or Governor Romney is going to want to give a quote on any of this," Taylor said.

In court briefs, the Obama administration has supported the University of Texas's right to run its affirmative action program, which is being challenged by Abigail Fisher, a white undergraduate applicant who was denied admission. However, Obama aides have a history of being cautious about engaging in debates over race, particularly those related to education-related affirmative action.

A federal government policy statement on the use of race in education was delayed for three years due to protracted interagency debates before its release in December 2019. John Brittain, a civil rights activist and law professor at the University of the District of Columbia, noted the administration's reluctance to address race and equality, stating, "The administration had a paralysis of analysis... Overall, the Obama administration just has a reluctance to take on race and equality, and when they do so everything is so carefully sanitized and scrubbed to make sure it’s the least offensive thing possible."

The Supreme Court's docket could potentially influence the presidential race, as it did last term with the 5-4 decision upholding the crux of Obama's signature health law. However, it is unlikely that the justices will rule on any of these issues before the election.

Title: President Obama Signs Bipartisan Budget Bill, Ending Fiscal Brinkmanship for Two Years

Article:

President Barack Obama signed a bipartisan budget bill on Thursday, marking an end to the cycle of fiscal brinkmanship for the next two years. The Senate approved the spending measure last week, following its passage in the Republican-dominated House. The president also signed the National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal 2014.

The bill, signed while Obama was vacationing in Hawaii, reduces across-the-board cuts already scheduled to take effect, restoring about $63 billion over two years. It includes a projected $85 billion in other savings. The deal prevents another government shutdown for nearly two years.

The bill authorizes appropriations for Department of Defense programs and related spending at other agencies. The act sets out a Pentagon base budget of $526.8 billion in the 2014 fiscal year.
