However, the defense authorization does not go as far as the president wants in closing the Guantanamo Bay detention facility. As in past years, Obama attached a signing statement complaining of "unwarranted and burdensome restrictions" on transferring detainees out of the prison. Although the law eases those restrictions a bit, making it easier to transfer detainees to foreign countries, Congress still does not allow the White House to move detainees to U.S. soil, making it nearly impossible to close the prison.

Obama has stated that the restrictions are "unwise" and insists that "the executive branch must have the authority to determine when and where to prosecute Guantanamo detainees."

Title: Candidates Campaign in Final 24-Hours, Employing Rock Superstars in Battleground States

Article:

In the final 24-hour stretch of the 2012 Presidential Campaign, both candidates, President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, focused their efforts on a select group of voters in a few key states. The candidates traversed six states on Monday, with Mitt Romney starting his day with a rally in Orlando, Florida.

Romney declared, "One final push is going to get us there!" before moving on to Virginia, Ohio, and New Hampshire. Both campaigns have transformed the final day of campaigning into a musical extravaganza, with each candidate enlisting popular musicians to support their campaign messages.

Bruce Springsteen accompanied Obama on his tour through Wisconsin, Ohio, and Iowa, while Jay-Z is expected to join Obama in Ohio. Romney, on the other hand, was supported by The Marshall Tucker Band in Columbus, Ohio, and Kid Rock in Manchester, New Hampshire, in the evening.

In Madison, Wisconsin, Obama, with a hoarse voice, urged voters to help him "finish what we started." He criticized Romney for attempting to "repackage the same old, bad ideas" as change and used the Clinton administration's economic record of the '90s as evidence that Democratic ideas "work."

"This should not be that complicated. We tried our ideas, they worked. We tried their ideas, they didn't work," Obama said.

Romney, in Florida, continued to emphasize that Obama is hindering the economic recovery and that his removal from office would unleash the potential of America's entrepreneurs.

"The door to a brighter future is open, it's waiting for us. I need your vote, I need your help," Romney said. "Tomorrow, we begin a new tomorrow."

Romney claimed his campaign has gained momentum in recent weeks and transformed into a "movement." Indeed, Romney saw a significant increase in the polls following his first debate against Obama. However, the race remains close at the national level, and in the battleground states where the election will be decided, voters are evenly split.

By most estimates, Obama enters Election Day with a slight advantage in the electoral vote count. The RealClearPolitics electoral map shows states likely to vote for Obama are worth 201 electoral votes, while those likely to vote for Romney are worth 191. A total of 270 electoral votes is required to win.

The toss-up states include Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Wisconsin. Ohio, with 18 electoral votes, is considered crucial for either candidate, and both candidates were campaigning there on Monday.

A poll released Sunday in The Pittsburgh Tribune showed the race in Pennsylvania locked at 47 percent in the final week. The president's team, however, considered the Pennsylvania move a "Hail Mary" and a sign that Romney still does not have a clear pathway to reaching the required electoral votes.

Both candidates pledged to govern in a bipartisan manner for the next four years as they attempted to reach independent and undecided voters.

"I want all parties to work together," the president said at a rally in Hollywood, Florida. "We're not Democrats and Republicans first. We're Americans first... As long as I'm president, I will work with anybody, of any party, to move this country forward."

Title: Trump Appeals to Supreme Court to Block Release of Tax Returns

Article:

President Donald Trump has appealed to the Supreme Court, requesting it to reverse a court order mandating his accountants to hand over eight years of tax returns. This move marks a significant escalation in Trump's efforts to keep his financial records private.

The federal appeals court in New York last week upheld a subpoena issued to Trump's accounting firm, Mazars USA, for his personal and corporate financial records from 2011 to 2018. In their petition to the Supreme Court, Trump's personal lawyers described the records request as "politically motivated" and argued that the subpoena should not be allowed to infringe upon the immunity the Constitution grants to the president.

Jay Sekulow, Trump's lawyer, stated, "We have filed a petition with the U.S. Supreme Court seeking to overturn the Second Circuit decision regarding a subpoena issued by the New York County District Attorney." The petition asserts that the subpoena violates the U.S. Constitution and is, therefore, unenforceable.

A three-judge panel of the Second Circuit last week allowed Manhattan prosecutors to obtain Trump's financial records as part of a grand jury investigation. Cyrus Vance Jr., the Democratic district attorney for New York County, agreed not to enforce the subpoena because Trump's lawyers vowed to quickly appeal to the Supreme Court. Vance's office is investigating payments allegedly made to silence two women who claim they had affairs with Trump.

Trump's lawyers have argued that the president has blanket immunity from criminal prosecution. During a recent oral argument before the circuit court, Trump's personal lawyer William Consovoy argued that the president could not be prosecuted even if he shot someone on Fifth Avenue in New York City.

The three judges on the circuit court panel, all Democratic appointees, did not rule on all of Trump's broad claims of immunity and whether the president could be prosecuted. However, they ruled that any immunity Trump had did not cover a subpoena to his accounting firm.

Trump has faced criticism for not voluntarily releasing his tax returns, breaking with a decades-long tradition of presidents doing so. This Supreme Court petition represents a final attempt by Trump to keep the documents hidden.

This case is one of two legal battles over subpoenas for Trump's financial records that were expected to reach the Supreme Court. In a separate case in Washington, D.C., a federal appeals court on Wednesday cleared the way for House Democrats on the Oversight Committee to pursue Trump's financial records from Mazars. Trump's lawyers indicated they would also appeal that decision to the Supreme Court.

Title: SpaceX Launches First Private Rocket to Carry American Astronauts into Orbit

Article:

On Saturday, a rocket ship built by Elon Musk's SpaceX company, carrying two American astronauts, blasted off from Earth, marking a new era in commercial space travel and the first time in nearly a decade that the United States has launched astronauts into orbit from U.S. soil. NASA's Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken rode into space aboard a Falcon 9 rocket and a sleek, white-and-black Dragon capsule, lifting off at 3:22 p.m. from the same launch pad used for the Apollo moon missions. Minutes later, they safely entered orbit.

The mission, named Demo-2, is scheduled to arrive at the International Space Station on Sunday for a stay of up to four months. After their return to Earth in a "Right Stuff"-style splashdown at sea, the astronauts will have completed the first crewed flight by a private company.

The mission unfolded amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and racial unrest in the U.S. NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine expressed hope that the flight would serve as a morale-booster for the nation. "Maybe there's an opportunity here for America to maybe pause and look up and see a bright, shining moment of hope at what the future looks like, that the United States of America can do extraordinary things even in difficult times," he said before launch.

With the successful launch, SpaceX, founded by Musk, became the first private company to launch people into orbit, a feat previously achieved only by three governments: the U.S., Russia, and China. The flight also ended a nine-year launch drought for NASA, the longest such hiatus in its history. Since retiring the space shuttle in 2011, NASA has relied on Russian spaceships launched from Kazakhstan to take U.S. astronauts to and from the space station.

The mission is the latest milestone for NASA's commercial crew program, a partnership between the agency, SpaceX, and Boeing. The first attempt on Wednesday was scrubbed at the last minute due to bad weather. Space exploration and adjacent businesses, such as space tourism and long-haul travel on Earth, are expected to grow into a more than $800 billion industry in the next decade.

NASA has also partnered with private companies for its Artemis program, which aims to land the first woman and the next man on the moon by 2024. In addition to SpaceX, NASA has selected a team led by Blue Origin, founded by Amazon.com's Jeff Bezos, and Dynetics, a subsidiary of Leidos Holdings, to work on the landing systems for the Artemis program.

The commercial crew program's future launch dates are not yet scheduled, according to NASA. After a series of flight tests by both Boeing and SpaceX this year and in 2019, NASA is now free to focus on building spacecraft and rockets for deep space missions while the companies focus on providing human transportation services to and from low-Earth orbit.

Title: Mitt Romney's Mormon Faith Remains a Campaign Focus

Article:

Mitt Romney's Mormon faith has emerged as a significant aspect of his presidential campaign, with the media scrutinizing his religious beliefs and their potential impact on voters. Despite the Latter-day Saints (LDS) Church having a significant presence in the Senate, Romney's Mormonism remains a mystery and potential obstacle for many voters.

The White Horse prophecy, attributed to Joseph Smith, the founder of Mormonism, has gained attention due to its connection with Romney's political aspirations. This prophecy, which predicts the rise of Mormons in times of economic and constitutional crisis, has been a topic of conversation among church members and has been linked to important themes in mainstream Mormonism, such as the belief in the divinely inspired Framers and the special role of Mormons in preserving the Constitution.

However, Romney has been cautious about discussing his religious beliefs in detail, referring to his faith as similar to that of other Americans. This has left journalists and observers searching for clues about Romney's religious views. The attention given to Mormon views of the Constitution provides a glimpse into how this issue may play out on the campaign trail.

The White Horse prophecy, which predicts the preservation of the U.S. Constitution by Mormons, is a controversial and well-known aspect of the prophecy. This prophecy is known to many church members and continues to be a topic of conversation among Mormons today. Romney has mentioned the divine influence on the Constitution several times during his campaign, suggesting a belief in its divine inspiration.

The prophecy is one of the most debated aspects of Romney's Mormon faith, even among believers. Like Mormonism itself, which has a distinctively American heartbeat, the prophecy is intertwined with American history and politics. The prophecy warns of trouble in the Middle East and anti-Mormon sentiment in the government, predicting the near-destruction of the U.S. Constitution. However, it also predicts the preservation and saving of the Constitution by the White Horse, who will stand by the Constitution as it was given by divine inspiration. The prophecy also mentions a Black Horse, which is commonly interpreted as representing American blacks, who will side with England and France, but eventually submit to the White Horse as the religion fulfills its world-conquering destiny in an Armageddon-style war with the Russians, while keeping an eye on the looming threat of China.

In conclusion, Mitt Romney's Mormon faith remains a significant and controversial aspect of his presidential campaign. The White Horse prophecy, with its predictions of economic and constitutional crises and the role of Mormons in preserving the Constitution, has gained attention and is a topic of conversation among church members and political observers. Romney's beliefs and potential connection to the prophecy remain a mystery, with the candidate being cautious about discussing his religious views in detail. The prophecy's connection to American history and politics, as well as its role in shaping the beliefs of Mormon church members and leaders, provides a unique insight into the intersection of religion and politics in the United States.

Title: Doug Jones' Victory in Alabama Senate Race Reflects Trends in Recent Democratic Wins

Article:

In a historic victory, Democrat Doug Jones has become the first Democrat to win a statewide office in Alabama since 2008, defeating Republican Roy Moore in a special election on Tuesday to fill the Senate seat previously held by Jeff Sessions. Jones secured 49.9% of the votes, while Moore garnered 48.4%. This marks the first time a Democrat has won a Senate race in Alabama since 1992, when GOP Senator Richard Shelby was still a Democrat.

The Alabama Senate special election exhibited several unique factors, including a GOP nominee accused of pursuing relationships with teenage girls, a controversial figure in the state, a mid-December vote, and a Democratic nominee who outspent his GOP rival by a significant margin during the general election phase of the campaign.

However, the Alabama results also reflect trends observed in prior elections, such as the race for governor in Virginia this year, that could indicate favorable conditions for Democrats in the 2018 mid-term elections, where control of the House of Representatives and now the Senate will be at stake.

This emerging Democratic advantage includes energized support from non-white voters, elevated party turnout in metropolitan areas, and stronger performance in well-educated suburban communities. Conversely, Republican turnout in white rural counties, which provided a significant boost to Donald Trump in 2016, has reportedly lagged in two key contests, the Virginia gubernatorial election and Tuesday's Alabama Senate race.

James A. Barnes, a member of the CNN Decision Desk and co-author of the 2018 Almanac of American Politics, provided insights into the Alabama Senate race and its implications for the upcoming mid-term elections.

Title: WIRED Concedes "Right-Wing Stunt" Contains Valid Concerns About WHO's Handling of COVID-19

Article:

A technology magazine, WIRED, published an article on Sunday that acknowledged a "right-wing stunt" as containing a valid notion regarding the World Health Organization's (WHO) handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The tweet from WIRED read, "A right-wing stunt to pin the blame for Covid-19 on the World Health Organization actually contains a useful notion. There is at least some reason to suspect that WHO knowingly and consequentially misled us."

The article, written by WIRED's "Ideas Contributor," expressed surprise at finding himself in agreement with conservative views, citing a call from Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) to investigate the WHO to determine if the United States should freeze their significant, taxpayer-funded contribution. The author describes his unexpected alignment with conservatives, stating that he is not in favor of cutting WHO funding or conducting the investigation immediately, but he is not as sure as Scott that WHO is guilty as charged.

The article points out the WHO's controversial tweet from January that claimed there was no evidence from China suggesting human-to-human transmission of COVID-19, despite ample evidence to the contrary. The author suggests that the "right-wing stunt" could be seen as an assessment of evidence and consequences that led to a lack of faith in the WHO.

As the global Wuhan coronavirus pandemic continues, people of all political stripes have shifted significant blame to the Chinese Communist Party for concealing the nature of the disease. Blame has then naturally trickled down to the WHO, who seemed to have, for whatever reason, a vested interest in protecting the CCP.

While the media has consistently criticized President Trump for his response to the outbreak of the Wuhan Coronavirus in the U.S., particularly in the early days, it is difficult for even his most unflappable foes to ignore the errors and misguidance of the WHO.

Title: Understanding Trump's Communication Style: Serious, Not Literal

Article:

In an article for The Atlantic last September, reporter Salena Zito noted a distinct difference in the way news media and Trump supporters interpret the statements made by then-presidential candidate Donald Trump. The media tends to take Trump's more outlandish statements literally but not seriously, while his supporters do the inverse.

This distinction, often referred to as the "seriously, not literally" approach, has been credited as a key to understanding Trump's communication style. Corey Lewandowski, Trump's first campaign manager, highlighted this at a post-election conference at Harvard, stating, "You guys took everything Donald Trump said so literally. The American people didn't."

Peter Thiel, a major Trump backer, made a similar point at the National Press Club in October, stating, "The media always is taking Trump literally. It never takes him seriously... I think a lot of the voters who vote for Trump take Trump seriously, but not literally."

Trump himself has hinted that he agrees with this interpretation. Last week, he admitted that he never meant his statement in April, "We're not going to let Carrier leave," literally. He explained, "I said, 'Carrier will never leave.' But that was a euphemism. I was talking about Carrier like all other companies from here on in."

The press's treatment of Trump as a joke, not appreciating the fact that for many voters, the media's scorn is a badge of honor, is a point of criticism in this distinction.

While this distinction is a useful analytical tool for understanding candidate Trump's communication, it is questionable as a prescription for how to treat an actual president or president-elect of the United States.

For instance, when Trump claims millions of people voted illegally, or speaks on the telephone with the president of Taiwan, how should the news media go about interpreting these statements "seriously but not literally"?

Perhaps the "seriously, not literally" distinction should not be taken too literally. Perhaps what Trump supporters really mean is that he should get a free pass whenever his mouth gets him in trouble.

Trump has stated, "I know words, I have the best words." He has also claimed he could be more presidential than anybody, except maybe Abraham Lincoln. He would be well-advised to take his own words seriously, if not literally.

What a president says matters. Credibility—with citizens, allies, enemies, and markets—is a finite resource, easily depleted when you think you'll never be held to account for what you blurt out.

Title: Former Vice President Dick Cheney Criticizes Senate Report on CIA Interrogation Techniques

Article:

Former Vice President Dick Cheney, in an interview on Fox News' "Special Report with Bret Baier," criticized a recently released Senate report on CIA interrogation practices, labeling it as "full of crap," "terribly flawed," and "deeply flawed." Cheney, who had not read the entire 500-page report summary, defended the controversial techniques used during the interrogations, including waterboarding and rectal hydration.

Cheney questioned the willingness to protect the United States against future attacks, stating, "What are you prepared to do to get the truth against future attacks against the United States?" He also refuted claims that President George W. Bush was kept in the dark about the interrogations, asserting that Bush was informed of everything he needed to know.

The Democrat-led Senate intelligence committee released the report on Tuesday, which criticized the CIA's interrogation practices as "brutal and far worse" than the agency represented to lawmakers. The report also claimed that the techniques were not effective and that the CIA provided "inaccurate" information about the practices to Congress and the White House.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., the head of the intelligence panel who ordered the release of the report, alleged on the Senate floor that the CIA techniques in some cases amounted to "torture." She argued that the report's release was necessary to uphold a just society governed by law and to prevent similar actions in the future.

The White House and President Obama supported the decision to release the report, despite concerns from lawmakers and some within the administration that it could lead to a backlash against Americans. The Obama administration reportedly put more than 6,000 Marines overseas on high alert in response to the report's release.

Title: Supreme Court's Role in Legal Challenges Facing President Trump May Be Tested

Article:

WASHINGTON ( ███ ) - The Supreme Court's role in legal disputes involving President Donald Trump could be tested by a series of personal legal challenges, including those related to his taxes, businesses, and the 2016 election campaign. The Supreme Court, which has a 5-4 conservative majority including two justices appointed by Trump, has already provided victories on some policy issues for the Republican president, such as upholding his travel ban targeting people from several Muslim-majority countries.

However, as the focus of some of the major legal challenges shifts from Trump's policies to the president himself, there could be disappointments for him, particularly if the Supreme Court upholds the ability of Congress to pursue investigations of the president, according to some legal experts.

Conservative legal scholar J.W. Verret, an expert in corporate and securities law at George Mason University in Virginia, stated, "That means upholding lower court decisions finding proper legislative purpose in recent inquiries regarding tax and financial fraud subpoenas."

Trump and his administration have defied a series of subpoenas issued by the Democratic-led House of Representatives, seeking testimony from current and former administration officials, as well as documents covering matters such as his tax returns, banking records, family business interests, and Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 election and Trump's actions to impede the inquiry.

The president and his lawyers have defiantly challenged the oversight authority of Congress, a stance that Democrats have framed as an attack on the separation of powers. Trump has sued to try to block enforcement of certain subpoenas, losing thus far in lower courts. House Democrats, who are divided on whether to launch the impeachment process, appear poised to press the matter by bringing their own court actions to try to enforce their subpoenas.

Other lawsuits, including one brought by congressional Democrats, also accuse Trump of violating an anti-corruption provision in the Constitution, called the emoluments clause, by continuing to accept payments from foreign governments through his businesses, including a downtown Washington hotel.

Some of Trump's losses in lower courts are already on appeal, and potentially could come before the Supreme Court with decisions issued during the heat of the election season.

Stuart Gerson, a Republican former Justice Department official and former acting U.S. attorney general, said the Supreme Court might be skeptical if the aim of subpoenas by Democratic lawmakers is merely to "educate the American people and build up a tide for impeachment that doesn't exist now."

"There's no black and white," Gerson added. "It will be 'win some, lose some,' and the Supreme Court, I think, given its precedent, will define a middle ground."

William Consovoy, Trump's lead lawyer on cases involving his business dealings, did not respond to a request seeking comment. The White House declined to comment for this story.

Trump has professed his faith in the Supreme Court and the importance of a president's role in making lifetime appointments to the top U.S. judicial body. Trump has said his promise to name conservative justices was a "main reason" why he was elected in 2016. His two appointees, Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh, have deepened the conservative hold on the court.

Aside from the travel ban, Trump's policy victories at the Supreme Court have included implementation of his ban on most transgender people in the U.S. military and blocking Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross from being deposed in a lawsuit over the contentious plan to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census. His administration has sought to bypass lower courts by rushing certain appeals of adverse rulings to the high court.

Trump's lawyers have justified stonewalling subpoenas by arguing that the Democratic demands exceed congressional authority, are overly broad, or improperly invade Trump's private affairs. Federal judges have rejected those arguments, citing Supreme Court precedent that Congress has broad authority to investigate corruption or improper conduct in the workings of government.

If federal appeals courts uphold judges' rulings that side with Congress, Verret predicted the Supreme Court would deliver "either a 9-0 outcome in support" of the lower courts or would simply refuse to hear the administration's appeal, leaving the lower court rulings intact.

"This goes to precedent involving core congressional oversight power," Verret added.

People exit and stand outside of the U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., June 17, 2019. ███/Leah Millis

The Supreme Court's first taste of the fight between Trump and congressional Democratic could come in two fast-moving cases. Trump is trying to block subpoenas for financial records issued to his accounting firm, Mazars LLP, and two banks with which he has done business: Deutsche Bank AG and Capital One Financial Corp. Judges in Washington and New York, respectively, ruled that the subpoenas could be enforced. Trump has appealed in both cases and could seek to bring them to the Supreme Court if he keeps losing in lower courts.

The emoluments issue also could be heading toward the justices. The Supreme Court will likely have the final say concerning potential conflicts of interest tied to Trump's Washington hotel and other business interests "because courts have never had to deal with this in 200-plus years," said Ciara Torres-Spelliscy, a law professor at Stetson University College of Law in Florida.

Title: Paris: 12 Killed in Attack on Satirical Newspaper Charlie Hebdo

Article:

A terrorist attack occurred on Wednesday in Paris, France, at the offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, resulting in the deaths of 12 people, including the editor and a cartoonist. This is France's deadliest terror attack in at least two decades.

French President Francois Hollande described the attack as "a terrorist attack without a doubt." He stated that several other attacks have been thwarted in France "in recent weeks." No immediate claim of responsibility for the attack has been made.

In response, France raised its security alert to the highest level and increased protective measures at houses of worship, stores, media offices, and transportation. Top government officials are holding an emergency meeting, and Hollande plans a nationally televised address in the evening. Schools across the French capital have closed their doors.

World leaders, including President Barack Obama and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, have condemned the attack. However, supporters of the militant Islamic State group have celebrated the slayings as well-deserved revenge against France.

The Islamic State group has repeatedly threatened to attack France. Just minutes before the attack, Charlie Hebdo had tweeted a satirical cartoon of the extremist group's leader giving New Year's wishes. Another cartoon, released in this week's issue and entitled "Still No Attacks in France," had a caricature of an extremist fighter saying "Just wait — we have until the end of January to present our New Year's wishes."

The 12 dead included two men who went by the pen names Charb — the editor and a cartoonist — and the cartoonist Cabu, according to Agnes Thibault-Lecuivre, a spokeswoman for the Paris prosecutor's office. Two police officers were also among the dead, including one assigned as Charb's bodyguard after prior death threats against him, a police official told The Associated Press, speaking on condition of anonymity because of the ongoing investigation.

Multiple masked men armed with automatic weapons attacked the newspaper's office in central Paris. Nearby worker Benoit Bringer told the iTele network that the attackers went to the second floor and started firing indiscriminately in the newsroom. Christophe DeLoire of Reporters Without Borders described the incident as "the darkest day of the history of the French press."

Video images on the website of public broadcaster France Televisions showed two gunmen in black at a crossroads who appeared to fire down one of the streets. A cry of "Allahu akbar!" — Arabic for "God is great" — could be heard among the gunshots.

The attackers left in a waiting car and later switched to another vehicle that had been stolen, according to Luc Poignant of the SBP police union.

US officials have been in close contact with the French since the attack, according to Obama's top spokesman, Josh Earnest. "We know they are not going to be cowed by this terrible act," Earnest said.

On social media, supporters of militant Islamic groups praised the move. One Twitter user who identified themselves as a Tunisian loyalist of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State group called the attack well-deserved revenge against France.

Elsewhere on the Internet, the hashtag #JeSuisCharlie was trending as people expressed support for the weekly and for journalistic freedom.

Charlie Hebdo has been repeatedly threatened for its caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad and other controversial sketches. Its offices were firebombed in 2011 after a spoof issue featuring a caricature of the prophet on its cover. Nearly a year later, the publication again published crude Muhammad caricatures, drawing denunciations from around the Muslim world.

Wednesday's attack comes on the same day as the release of a book by a celebrated French novelist depicting France's election of its first Muslim president. Hollande was due to meet with the country's top religious officials later in the day.

Title: Senate Expresses Concern Over Trump's Trade Policy, Votes to Involve Congress in Section 232 Tariffs

Article:

The United States Senate took a symbolic step on Wednesday to express concern over President Donald Trump's trade policy, voting to include language in a government funding bill that would provide a role for Congress in tariffs implemented for national security reasons, known as Section 232 of the trade laws.

The nonbinding vote, which saw 88 senators voting in favor and 11 against, underscores the depth of concern on Capitol Hill regarding Trump's tariff strategy. Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) stated that the vote is significant, as many senators have discussed their anxiety about tariffs with the president and his Cabinet.

The president has used Section 232 to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, including imposing financial penalties on key trading allies such as the European Union, Canada, and Mexico. However, Republicans have been wary of using legislation to push back against Trump before the midterm elections.

Senate Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) attempted to attach legislation requiring congressional approval for tariffs applied for national security reasons to both a defense policy bill and the farm bill, but was blocked both times. Corker stated after the vote that he would continue to push for the Senate to pass stand-alone legislation on Trump's tariff authority.

Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) added that Congress has to rein in the abuse of presidential authority and restore Congress's constitutional authority in this regard. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) has stated he will bring up tariff legislation in the committee, and some GOP senators on the panel have voiced support for narrowing Section 232 of the trade law.

Trump allies have warned lawmakers against passing legislation, arguing it would undercut the president's negotiating ability. Sen. David Perdue (R-Ga.) criticized senators before the vote, stating that they were tying Trump's hands. Perdue was one of the 11 Republican senators who voted no.

The other Republican senators who voted no were Sens. John Barrasso (Wyo.), Shelley Moore Capito (W.Va.), Mike Crapo (Idaho), Mike Enzi (Wyo.), Lindsey Graham (S.C.), Dean Heller (Nev.), Cindy Hyde-Smith (Miss.), James Inhofe (Okla.), Jim Risch (Idaho), and Tim Scott (S.C.).

Title: Iraq War's Legacy Looms Large in Obama's Syria Decision-Making

Article:

President Barack Obama's response to the escalating conflict in Syria appears to be influenced significantly by the events in Iraq, according to former administration officials and analysts. The legacy of the Iraq War is a significant factor in the president's and his advisers' approach to the Syria crisis, as they aim to avoid repeating past mistakes.

Threats of chemical weapons use in Syria have prompted the administration to balance the need for a strong response against Obama's repeated "red line" statements regarding the use of nerve agents or poison gas by President Bashar Assad's regime.

Greg Craig, a foreign policy adviser on Obama's 2008 campaign and his first White House counsel, noted the impact of the Iraq history, stating, "He does not want to jump to conclusions or shoot from the hip."

The administration's caution is rooted in the memory of the Central Intelligence Agency's (CIA) 2003 statement, made to President George W. Bush, that Iraq had nuclear weapons. No such weapons were ever found, and the CIA also reported, incorrectly, that Saddam Hussein had an active chemical and biological weapons program.

Former Clinton national security adviser Sandy Berger, now with the Albright-Stonebridge Group, commented, "This is actually pretty good example of the kind of situation where it pays to learn the lessons of Iraq." Jeffrey Lewis, an arms control expert with the Monterey Institute of International Studies, added, "My sense is that they are reluctant to get involved on the basis of evidence that is not, to use a familiar term, a ‘ slam dunk.'"

A White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, acknowledged the impact of the Iraq War on the administration's decision-making, stating, "Given our own history with intelligence assessments, including intelligence assessments related to weapons of mass destruction, it’s very important that we are able to establish this with certainty and that we are able to present information that is airtight in a public and credible fashion to underpin all of our decision-making."

The official further emphasized the need for "a threshold that is demanded given how serious this issue is." The challenges faced by U.S. troops in Iraq may also be a key factor in Obama's reluctance to commit more resources to Syria by directly arming rebels or setting up a no-fly zone.

Title: GOP Presidential Hopefuls Adapt Stances on Common Core, Immigration, and Israel

Article:

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, a potential 2016 Republican presidential candidate, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging the federal Common Core education curriculum. This move positions him among other GOP hopefuls who have recently recalibrated their positions on various issues to align with conservative primary voters.

Jindal, who initially endorsed Common Core in 2010, now views it as an example of federal overreach. His change in stance follows similar shifts by other potential 2016 candidates, such as Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida and Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, who have revised their positions on immigration and foreign assistance, respectively.

According to Darrell M. West, vice president and director of governance studies at the Brookings Institute, these changes are strategic adjustments to the evolving political climate within the Republican Party. "They are adapting to new GOP winds and trying to put themselves in the strongest possible position," West said. "This means getting tough on the Common Core, which conservatives hate. It also means becoming more negative on comprehensive immigration reform and making sure they are supportive of Israel."

In the case of Jindal, he has been signaling an increasing aversion to the Common Core, under pressure from conservative and tea party activists in his state. On Wednesday, Jindal filed a lawsuit alleging that the Obama administration illegally coerced states into adopting the standards, which 44 states and the District of Columbia have adopted.

Senator Marco Rubio made a bold statement on immigration a day prior to Jindal's announcement, declaring that there is "no realistic path forward on comprehensive [immigration] reform for the foreseeable future." Essentially, he declared his own legislation dead and suggested a piecemeal approach to addressing the issue, starting with stemming the flow of illegal immigrants into the country.

Meanwhile, Senator Rand Paul has been attempting to reassure voters that he has never supported cutting aid to Israel, despite previous statements to the contrary. The ongoing war in Gaza has fueled a strong response from the party's pro-Israel voices.

Flip-flops in political stances are not uncommon, and often occur well in advance of primary elections. For instance, Mitt Romney was pro-choice as a candidate for governor of Massachusetts but became pro-life ahead of his 2008 and 2012 bids for the GOP presidential nomination. Former Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton voted to authorize the Iraq war in 2002 before running against it in the 2008 Democratic primary.

Michael McKenna, a GOP consultant, views these shifts as a testament to the democratic process. "These shifts are part of what makes popular sovereignty so great — those who want to get elected have to (ultimately) express the will of the majority of the electorate, or they don't get elected," McKenna said in an email. "And usually people like to do it when not too many folks are watching the evolution. Because it can get misconstrued as being indecisive or, worse, pandering."

Title: Hearings Stir Debate on Intellectual Humility, Uncertainty, and Bigotry

Article:

The recent Supreme Court confirmation hearings have sparked a debate on intellectual humility, uncertainty, and the potential for bigotry in public discourse. At the center of this controversy lies the question of events that allegedly occurred at a party 36 years ago, for which there is no corroborating evidence.

The hearings have raised crucial questions about how to handle uncertainty, weigh conflicting testimonies, and measure the credibility of testimonies in light of cognitive science's findings on human beings' inaccuracies in detecting falsehoods. The events of a person's high school years have also been a subject of discussion, with some questioning whether they should define an individual's adult life.

In the midst of this debate, some have quickly taken sides, either supporting or criticizing the individuals involved. If initial evidence did not provide a clear answer, some have found new reasons to reinforce their initial positions.

The polarized nature of the discourse has led to an increase in base mobilization, where persuasion is no longer a priority in public conversations. Statements are made to rally one's own group, rather than to seek understanding or truth. For instance, Senator Cory Booker has been criticized for his histrionic approach to the evidence, while Brett Kavanaugh has been accused of stoking culture war rage to mobilize the Republican base.

This polarization has also led to an epidemic of bigotry, as individuals make assumptions about disfavored groups based on stereotypes. Instances of bigotry have led to miscarriages of justice in the past, such as the conviction of Alfred Dreyfus in 1894, the Central Park Five in 1990, and the Duke lacrosse case.

In the past month, thousands of people have formed opinions about Kavanaugh's behavior based on their perceptions of "privileged" individuals, while others have rallied behind him due to perceived hostility from the "Left." This polarization and the potential for bigotry in decision-making have become significant concerns in the ongoing debate.

Title: Protests in Ferguson Continue Amidst Tension and Violence

Article:

In the city of Ferguson, Missouri, tensions remain high as protests continue following the grand jury's decision not to indict Darren Wilson in the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown. Despite the violence and looting that occurred late Monday, many protesters remain undeterred, expressing their desire for justice.

Outbreaks of violence were reported, including the flipping, vandalizing, and setting on fire of a police cruiser, as well as the use of pepper gas and arrests by law enforcement. National Guardsmen in riot gear were stationed at the Ferguson Police Department, with protesters and police separated by a single lane of road.

Protesters chanted slogans such as "We are not your enemy" and "We just want justice," while some residents armed themselves to protect their properties. Volunteers helped clean up vandalized stores and eateries, and boarded up broken windows and doors.

Missouri Governor Jay Nixon ordered additional National Guardsmen to the area, increasing their numbers from 700 to 2,200. He stated, "We are bringing more resources to Ferguson and other parts of the region to prevent a repetition of the lawlessness experienced overnight. We must do better and we will."

Demonstrations in Ferguson devolved into chaos on Monday night, with buildings burned, stores looted, and shots fired. Protests also took place in several other states, with activists chanting slogans such as "They have given us no justice! We will give them no peace."

Authorities are hopeful that the majority of protests in the weeks following Brown's death will remain peaceful. St. Louis police are investigating the death of a man found shot and set on fire, which they have not ruled out as being linked to the violence in Ferguson.

Title: Activist Groups Advocating for Open Borders Endorse Democratic Presidential Candidates

Article:

Illegal alien activist groups, such as United We Dream Action, are endorsing Democratic presidential candidates Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders in the 2020 primary elections. The endorsements come as these candidates aim to gain support in key Super Tuesday primaries in states with significant illegal alien populations, including California, Texas, Virginia, Massachusetts, and North Carolina.

United We Dream Action, an organization with illegal aliens among its membership, announced dual endorsements for Warren and Sanders, praising their support for ending all deportations of illegal aliens. The endorsement video states, "After four years of Trump, there’s absolutely no question that detention camps need to be closed, deportations need to be stopped, and the enforcement machine needs to be taken apart brick by brick."

Both candidates support key provisions of the 'Free to move, free to stay' platform, including shutting down for-profit detention camps, reducing the budgets for ICE and CBP, stopping and reviewing deportations in the first 100 days, issuing executive orders to protect immigrants, dismantling the "racist enforcement machine," and supporting legislation that provides a pathway to citizenship without provisions to harm immigrants.

The endorsement is particularly beneficial for Warren and Sanders in California, a state with the largest illegal alien and foreign-born population in the country. By election day in November, one-in-five of all California voters will have been born outside the U.S.

In North Carolina, Sanders is receiving assistance from the open borders lobbying organization Mijente and the Hispanic American Democrats of Mecklenburg County. Members of each group have been canvassing for Sanders, with Oliva Chapela stating, "You don’t know how many Latinos that I have canvassed and knocked that literally when I tell them about Bernie, they are like ‘Yeah, of course.’"

In prior primaries, such as the Iowa Democrat Caucus, illegal aliens and noncitizens have organized for Sanders, as reported by various media outlets.

Both Warren and Sanders have endorsed a platform that includes decriminalizing U.S.-Mexico border crossings, amnesty for the majority of the 11 to 22 million illegal alien population, and taxpayer-funded healthcare for all illegal aliens, noncitizens, and foreign nationals.

John Binder, a reporter for ███, reported on the endorsements and can be followed on Twitter at @JxhnBinder.

Title: Biden Campaign Advisers Request Removal of Rudy Giuliani from TV News Channels

Article:

Senior advisers to Joe Biden, the Democratic presidential candidate, have written to major TV news channels requesting the exclusion of President Donald Trump's personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, from their programming. The letter, disclosed by The Daily Beast, was penned by Anita Dunn, a former acting White House communications director under Barack Obama, and Kate Bedingfield, Biden's deputy campaign manager.

In the letter, Dunn and Bedingfield argue that Giuliani, who is deeply involved in the Ukraine scandal that has prompted an impeachment inquiry, is spreading false and debunked conspiracy theories on behalf of Donald Trump. They contend that by giving him airtime, the networks are allowing him to introduce increasingly unfounded and desperate lies into the national conversation.

Giuliani has been a frequent presence on network and cable news shows since the emergence of an anonymous whistleblower's complaint alleging that Trump was seeking help from the Ukraine government in his 2020 re-election bid. Under US election law, it is illegal to solicit or gain electoral benefit from any foreign entity.

Giuliani's comments on the Ukraine matter have become increasingly contentious, with some pundits questioning his mental state. He has been involved in heated exchanges with fellow guests on Fox News and has made contradictory statements regarding his involvement in the Ukraine investigation. He has also invoked wild conspiracy theories involving Hillary Clinton, the philanthropist George Soros, and other right-wing bogeymen.

The most consistent theme in Giuliani's on-air comments has been his attempt to smear Biden, who has been a leading contender for the Democratic nomination to challenge Trump in the presidential election next year. On ABC's This Week on Sunday, he repeated claims that in 2016, the then-vice president pressured Ukraine to fire its chief prosecutor because he was investigating corruption in a gas company on whose board sat Biden's son, Hunter.

However, in fact, the investigation into the company, Burisma, was dormant by 2016. Top officials in the Ukraine government have made clear that no evidence of corruption relating to either Biden was found.

In their letter, the two Biden aides write, "We demand that in service to the facts, you no longer book Rudy Giuliani, a surrogate for Donald Trump who has demonstrated that he will knowingly and willingly lie in order to advance his own narrative." They also touch on the controversy over Giuliani's actual relationship to Trump and his freelance role in US foreign policy, stating that he "is not a public official, and holds no public office that would entitle him to opine on the nation's airwaves."

Dunn and Bedingfield also demand that if Giuliani does appear, "an equivalent amount of time [should be given] to a surrogate for the Biden campaign." In response, Giuliani described the letter as an instance of "the usual left-wing censorship."

Title: U.S. Supreme Court Struggles to Reach Consensus on Key Cases, Suggesting Delayed Decisions

Article:

WASHINGTON - Members of the U.S. Supreme Court appear to be grappling with finding a resolution for a significant case, as suggested by Justice Stephen Breyer during a March 28 oral argument. Breyer's comment, made in a closely watched case concerning the redrawing of electoral districts to maintain one party's power, highlights the apparent difficulty the nine justices are experiencing in issuing rulings at their usual pace.

With five conservatives and four liberals, the court's ideological divide may make finding common ground challenging. President Donald Trump's appointee Neil Gorsuch, who marks his first anniversary as a justice on Tuesday, has restored the court's conservative majority after a 14-month period of ideological parity.

During their current term, which began in October and runs through the end of June, the justices must address more weighty and complex cases than usual. One of their most significant cases – deciding the legality of President Donald Trump's travel ban on several Muslim-majority countries – will not be heard until April 25.

To date, the high court has issued only 18 rulings in cases already argued this term, lagging behind its normal pace. Numerous major cases remain unresolved, including one on Wisconsin electoral boundaries heard in October and a similar case heard last month involving the same practice of "partisan gerrymandering" in Maryland.

Other major cases include a divisive case pitting gay rights against religious liberty, involving a Christian baker who refused to make a wedding cake for a gay couple, as well as cases concerning fees paid by non-members to unions representing public employees, the right of workers to bring class-action claims against employers, the ability of police to obtain cellphone location data to tie criminal suspects to crimes, and a California law regulating Christian-based anti-abortion facilities.

Supreme Court experts anticipate the justices will issue a larger-than-normal number of 5-4 rulings in the coming months, increasing the chances of conservative Justice Anthony Kennedy, who often sides with the court's four liberals in major cases, casting the deciding votes.

"It's reasonable to suggest there are going to be fewer unanimous decisions and more division," said Nicole Saharsky, a lawyer who frequently argues cases before the court.

The court usually issues rulings more quickly when the justices are unanimous. To date, it has issued 11 unanimous rulings and seven with dissenting votes, including three that were 5-4. The court's most contentious rulings are typically issued in June.

Part of the slowdown in rulings may be related to the presence of Gorsuch, who has shown signs of being a conservative voice on the bench. Gorsuch has also demonstrated a willingness to question the reasoning of his colleagues, a practice that can delay rulings.

"There could just be new dynamics one way or another," said John Elwood, who has argued multiple cases before the Supreme Court.

The impasse over partisan gerrymandering was first evident when the court heard arguments on Oct. 3 in a challenge by Democratic voters to Republican-drawn state legislative districts in Wisconsin. Five months later, the justices appeared no closer to resolving the matter when they heard the similar Maryland dispute involving a Democratic-drawn U.S. House of Representatives district.

The court seemed similarly divided in the worker class action case argued on Oct. 2, the first day of the term. The justices will have to decide whether workers can be forced by companies to sign agreements waiving the right to bring class-action claims against their employer.

Based on the Dec. 5 oral argument, Kennedy will also be the deciding vote in the case of whether the Denver-area Christian baker can be penalized under a Colorado anti-discrimination law or whether the U.S. Constitution's promise of free speech protects him.

The nine justices have not always been at odds with each other, even on contentious matters. There was no dissent when the court, in February, rejected Trump's bid to immediately end a program that protects hundreds of thousands of immigrants brought illegally into the United States as children.

The court also showed no divisions when it declined to intervene in another electoral boundaries fight, this time in Pennsylvania.

The slow pace of rulings may, in part, be due to scheduling, said Kannon Shanmugam, another regular Supreme Court lawyer.

"The court has had hard, divisive cases earlier in the term," he said. "It's not surprising it might take a while."

Title: Giuliani Clarifies Statements on Trump's Payment to Stormy Daniels and James Comey Firing

Article:

Rudy Giuliani, the latest addition to President Donald Trump's legal team, released a statement on Friday to clarify his comments made in several interviews this week regarding the hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels and the firing of James Comey.

In an exclusive interview with Fox News' "Hannity" on Wednesday, Giuliani revealed that Trump reimbursed his personal attorney Michael Cohen for the $130,000 payment made to Daniels in the weeks leading up to the 2016 election in exchange for her silence about an alleged sexual encounter with Trump in 2006.

In his statement, Giuliani did not walk back the statement that Trump reimbursed Cohen. However, he attempted to clear the air on several other potentially problematic statements.

"These are my views," Giuliani's statement began. "First: There is no campaign violation. The payment was made to resolve a personal and false allegation in order to protect the President's family. It would have been done in any event, whether he was a candidate or not."

Giuliani's comments on Fox & Friends on Thursday seemed to imply that the payment had political implications. He said, "It wasn't for the campaign," but then added, "Imagine if that [allegation] came out on Oct. 15, 2016, in the middle of the last debate with Hillary Clinton?"

This remark raised questions of whether the payment was campaign-related, and possibly a campaign finance violation, which Trump's legal team denies.

Giuliani continued in his statement, "Second: My references to timing were not describing my understanding of the President's knowledge, but instead, my understanding of these matters."

Trump, last month, had denied having any knowledge about the payment to Daniels in the weeks leading up to Election Day. While Giuliani said this week that Trump made the reimbursement, he also said Thursday that Trump did not know all the details until about 10 days ago.

Giuliani also clarified a comment he made about the firing of James Comey. Giuliani had suggested that Trump fired Comey because he "would not, among other things, say that [Trump] wasn't a target of the [Russia] investigation."

"It is undisputed that the President's dismissal of former Director Comey—an inferior executive officer—was clearly in his Article II power," Giuliani said Friday. "Recent revelations about former Director Comey further confirm the wisdom of the President's decision, which was plainly in the best interests of our nation."

Earlier on Friday, Trump defended Giuliani, saying, "When Rudy made the statements—Rudy is great, but Rudy has just started and he wasn't familiar with everything. He's a special guy and he understands that this is a witch hunt."

Title: NSA's Data Collection: Amassing Metadata from Telephone and Email Traffic

Article:

The National Security Agency (NSA) has been accumulating databases of "metadata," which includes logs of all telephone calls and similar data on email traffic, following the September 11 attacks. The email data collection program was discontinued in 2011, although it appears that the same data may now be gathered through alternative means.

According to recently disclosed documents, America's phone and Internet companies grew apprehensive of NSA demands as the years passed, fearing customer backlash due to their records being shared with the government. In response, the NSA devised a solution: storing the data itself. This reportedly led to the creation of a vast data storage center in Utah, leveraging the declining cost of storage and the advancement of sophisticated search software.

These extensive databases were once referred to as "bit buckets" in the industry—collections of electronic data waiting to be sifted through. James Lewis, a cybersecurity expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, explained, "They park stuff in storage in the hopes that they will eventually have time to get to it, or that they'll find something that they need to go back and look for in the masses of data. Most of it sits and is never looked at by anyone."

An obscure passage in one of the Snowden documents, rules for collecting Internet data that the Obama administration wrote in secret in 2009 and that the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court approved, suggested that the government was concerned about its ability to process all the data it was collecting. The rules allowed the government to hold on to the data if it could not keep up with the processing. The rules stated that "the communications that may be retained" for up to five years "include electronic communications acquired because of the limitation on the NSA's ability to filter communications."

A private expert who occasionally advises the NSA on this technology commented, "This means that if you can't desalinate all the seawater at once, you get to hold on to the ocean until you figure it out."

Title: Iran Nuclear Deal: A Cautious Assessment of Its Impact on War Prospects

Article:

The recent nuclear agreement between six world powers and Iran, known as the Lausanne framework, has been met with skepticism and criticism, particularly from hawkish factions. The deal, it is argued, is reminiscent of the 1938 Munich Agreement, where British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is said to have appeased Adolf Hitler, leading to the outbreak of World War II.

However, a careful examination of the Lausanne framework reveals a different narrative. The Iranians have agreed to significant concessions, including the reduction of their nuclear centrifuges by 68 percent for at least a decade, a limit on uranium enrichment to 3.67 percent for 15 years, and a 97 percent reduction in their current stockpile of low-enriched uranium. The once-secret enrichment plant at Fordo will be converted to a "research center," and the heavy water reactor at Arak, capable of producing weapons-grade plutonium, will be redesigned and rebuilt to prevent this.

Despite these concessions, Iran's history of deception and support for terror groups like Hezbollah and murderous regimes like Syria remains a concern. To address this, the U.S. and its allies have demanded regular and intrusive access for international inspectors, not just of Iran's nuclear facilities, but of their supply chains. Sanctions that have crippled a broad swath of the Iranian economy will remain in place and be lifted gradually and only when the U.S. and others are satisfied that their demands are being met.

Critics of the deal accuse President Obama of selling out Israel, comparing him to Neville Chamberlain. However, this comparison is misleading. Iran is not a vanquished power, and the demands placed on Iran are far from the complete disarmament that Chamberlain demanded of Germany in 1938. Diplomacy and arms reduction is a process of gradualism, with each side cautiously taking interim steps and searching for common ground.

Furthermore, the Obama administration has taken steps to support Israel's security, such as increased funding for the Iron Dome missile defense system and the provision of bunker buster bombs to Israel. Former Reagan foreign policy advisor Elliott Abrams and Ehud Barak, Netanyahu's former defense minister, have praised the Obama administration's efforts in this regard.

While the deal is not perfect, and the Iranian government's intentions remain suspect, the Lausanne framework provides a means of monitoring Iran's nuclear activities more closely than any other country in the world. If Iran cheats, the world will be able to detect it, and further action can be taken. The deal, therefore, offers a cautious hope for avoiding war in the Middle East.

Title: Media Response to President Trump's Helsinki Summit Clarification Remains Critical

Article:

President Donald Trump's attempt to clarify his statements made during the Helsinki summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin has been met with skepticism and criticism from the mainstream media. The president's explanation that he misspoke during the summit, stating that he meant to say "would not" instead of "would," has been widely dismissed and, in some cases, mocked.

The president's demeanor during his clarification was less than enthusiastic, and he added that in addition to Russian hackers, it could have been "other people" interfering in the 2016 election. This statement drew particular skepticism, with some media outlets and personalities questioning the authenticity of his remarks.

CNN's Erin Burnett described Trump's explanation as a "dog ate my homework" alibi, while The Washington Post observed that Trump's delivery of the statement was classic, offering a dual message to both those who insist on respecting the nation's systems and mores and those who support Trump for his willingness to disrupt traditional politics.

Another clarification was made after the press ran with a terse Trumpian response— "no"—to ABC reporter Cecilia Vega's question about whether he believes Russia is still meddling in American politics. However, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders later stated that Trump was simply saying "no" to the idea of taking questions, not addressing Moscow's current capabilities.

The New York Times questioned whether this latest episode would be an indelible stain or simply fade into the next one, while some commentators have gone as far as to accuse Trump of being a traitor. This is a charge that reveals the deep-seated disdain some journalists hold for Donald Trump.

It is important to note that the media's response to President Trump's statements and actions is a reflection of the ongoing political discourse and does not necessarily indicate a consensus or unified position among all media outlets or journalists. The media's role is to report on events and provide analysis, and it is up to the reader or viewer to form their own opinions based on the information presented.

Title: Walker's Position on Birthright Citizenship Remains Unclear

Article:

The ongoing debate surrounding the end of birthright citizenship for children of undocumented immigrants has been a hot topic in recent political discussions, with Donald Trump advocating for its termination. This issue is not new to the conservative political sphere, and several candidates, including Scott Walker, have expressed support for the idea.

However, Walker's stance on the matter remains unclear. In an interview with NBC's Kasie Hunt, his response seemed to be more of a dodge rather than a clear affirmation of support. When asked directly if he supports ending birthright citizenship, Walker responded:

"Well, like I said, Harry Reid said it’s not right for this country—I think that’s something we should, yeah, absolutely, going forward—HUNT: We should end birthright citizenship? WALKER: Yeah, to me it’s about enforcing the laws in this country."

His campaign later clarified his statement, asserting that enforcing the laws, securing the border, and implementing E-Verify would end the birthright citizenship issue.

In a subsequent interview with CNBC's John Harwood, Walker stated that he has no opinion on the issue, only expressing his intention to secure the border before addressing birthright citizenship. This response has been met with confusion, as it contradicts the assertive, anti-establishment stance that Walker's campaign had recently adopted.

The lack of clarity in Walker's position on this constitutional issue has raised questions about his ability to take a firm stance on key political matters. This is among the more notable instances of ambiguity in recent political discourse, following Jeb Bush's statement that he could not give his opinion on the Iraq war due to potential offense to the troops.

Title: TSA's Effectiveness in Airport Security Called into Question as Research Suggests Alternatives

Article:

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has recently concluded a month-long contest aimed at shortening the time travelers spend in airport security lines. The TSA plans to award $15,000 in prize money to the applicants with the best ideas, but one suggestion, disbanding the TSA and liberalizing security, has been proposed.

Air travel has been a common experience for individuals since late 2001, and the check-in procedures have become cumbersome. Before flying, passengers must present ID, undergo searches of their person and property, and limit what they bring in their carry-on luggage. Many airports recommend passengers arrive no later than 90 minutes to two hours before their departure time to clear security.

The TSA's policies have been a subject of debate, with some considering them an unacceptable invasion of privacy, while others argue they are necessary for security. However, a report from the RAND Corporation states that air travel is incredibly safe. Between 2001 and 2011, more than 6 billion enplanements occurred, and during that time, more people died in incidents related to mechanical failures on aircraft than in security-related scenarios. When security-related incidents did occur, perpetrators were often apprehended by passengers, not by airport security.

If security is needed, how does the TSA perform compared to alternatives? One of its main jobs is to detect explosives. An internal agency report in 2011 found TSA was largely ineffective in this regard. When tested, agents at two of the nation's busiest airports failed to detect fake bombs 60 percent or 75 percent of the time. Compare these rates to those of private airport security. The Government Accountability Office reported that private screeners missed fake explosives only 40 percent of the time, and this was in 1990, when security technology was much less advanced than today.

The TSA's poor performance can be attributed to its bureaucratic structure. Unlike for-profit firms, the agency does not face the right incentives. In a market setting, private firms contend with profit and loss. Earning a profit signals that a firm is providing a valuable service to the public and should continue its activities. A loss conveys the opposite. This profit-and-loss mechanism gives private firms incentives to please their customers and invent new and better ways to provide their services.

A bureaucratic organization such as the TSA, however, does not face such feedback. Instead, a bureaucracy looks to increase its share of government funds. It does so in two ways. First, it tries to signal to the larger government that its work fulfills major government objectives and should be expanded. TSA officials do this by claiming their agency prevents acts of terrorism. Second, a bureaucracy expands by exhausting its budget and demonstrating that it can not accomplish its goals with the resources given. In the context of the TSA, this implies the organization has an incentive to get worse, not better, by continuously expanding its budget and security procedures. If the TSA were to rapidly improve speed and efficiency, this would show the government that the agency could do the same job with fewer resources. Budgets would be cut, and personnel would be released. Unlike a private firm facing competitive pressures, the TSA does not benefit from reducing costs, improving performance, and increasing speed.

The TSA's recent contest may show that the organization knows it's less than loved by travelers, but we shouldn't expect it to radically improve our flying experience. The contest won't change the underlying incentives it faces. The TSA, a government-run bureaucracy, lacks the incentives to adapt, innovate, and cut costs. If we are really looking to increase airport security and reduce air-travel time, we should abolish it.

Abigail R. Hall, a research fellow at the Independent Institute, a nonpartisan research and educational organization based in Oakland, Calif., made these suggestions.

Title: Obama's Visit to Hiroshima: Focus on Nuclear Disarmament and the Loss of Innocent Lives

Article:

In 2009, President Obama expressed his aspiration for a world without nuclear weapons. However, the reality of nuclear proliferation, particularly by North Korea, has posed a challenge to this vision. As Obama's presidency nears its end, he has chosen to revisit this ideal in Hiroshima, a city that serves as a reminder of the devastating impact of nuclear weapons.

The administration has stated that the president's trip will focus on the future, but it is fraught with potential for misinterpretation. In describing the visit, Deputy National Security Advisor Ben Rhodes emphasized that the president would highlight the loss of innocent lives, not only from the "extraordinary loss of life of innocent Japanese civilians" at Hiroshima but also the overall "toll that war takes on innocent life." Rhodes described Hiroshima and Nagasaki as symbols of "the toll of nuclear weapons."

Historic context, however, appears to be absent from Rhodes' narrative, and potentially from the president's visit. This context includes the 2,403 innocents killed at Pearl Harbor and the millions of American, Allied, and Japanese casualties spared by the rapid culmination of the war in August 1945.

Obama's presence in Hiroshima could also undermine burgeoning efforts at Japanese-South Korean reconciliation. The visit may affirm the Korean view that Washington has "chosen" Tokyo over Seoul and now accepts revisionist history depicting Japan as the victim.

Hiroshima represents not just the tragedy of a weapon of war, but also the consequences of aggressive regimes and the wars they impose. The Axis Powers may be gone, but modern-day despots remain. More important than an end to nuclear weapons, President Obama should instead call upon all nations to unite against totalitarian regimes that still seek to impose their will over weaker neighbors.

Title: Congress Repeals Auto Lending Guidance Regarding Discrimination Allegations

Article:

In a move that has been criticized by some as potentially discriminatory, President Trump has signed a bill that repeals a guidance document issued by the Obama administration in 2013 regarding auto dealers' ability to mark up interest rates on auto loans. The repeal allows car dealerships to once again negotiate higher interest rates on auto loans, a practice that has been linked to racial disparities in lending.

The Obama administration's rule was implemented in response to reports indicating that black and Hispanic car buyers were paying higher interest rates on their loans compared to white car buyers. These "indirect" loans originate from a third-party financial institution, which returns a portion of the higher interest rate back to the car dealership.

Supporters of the practice argue that it provides car dealers and lenders with the flexibility needed to offer discounted auto loans to their most favorable customers.

The auto lending rule is unique because it was a guidance document, not a regulation, and was not technically subject to the normal regulatory process. As a result, it was not submitted to Congress for review, and interested groups never had the opportunity to provide comments on the rule.

The repeal of the rule was made possible by the Congressional Review Act (CRA), a law that allows Congress to overturn agency regulations. The CRA typically allows 60 legislative days for Congress to overturn a rule, but, as a guidance document, the auto lending rule did not go through the normal regulatory process.

The House voted 234 to 175 to repeal the rule, and the Senate voted 51 to 47. The votes were largely along party lines, with Democrats voting to keep the rule in place. Under the CRA, the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection is barred from issuing any similar rule unless Congress grants it specific authority.

Title: Tesla CEO Elon Musk Proposes Journalistic Rating Website Amid Media Criticism

Article:

Tesla CEO Elon Musk took to Twitter on Wednesday to express his discontent with the media, issuing a series of tweets that criticized the "hypocrisy of big media companies" and floated the idea of a website where the public could rate journalists and articles for credibility.

Musk began by stating, "The holier-than-thou hypocrisy of big media companies who lay claim to the truth, but publish only enough to sugarcoat the lie, is why the public no longer respects them." He continued by claiming that journalists are under constant pressure to maximize clicks and earn advertising dollars, or risk being fired.

"Tricky situation, as Tesla doesn't advertise, but fossil fuel companies & gas/diesel car companies are among the world's biggest advertisers," Musk said.

In response to a Twitter user's comment on his remarks, Musk suggested, "the media has earned this mistrust. But maybe there is a solution." Musk also discussed creating a site, possibly called Pravda, where people could rate the core truth of any article and keep track of the credibility of a journalist or news outlet. He also created a poll, asking followers to choose whether the website was a good idea.

Pravda was the name of a Communist newspaper in the former Soviet Union.

Recent backlash towards Musk's company, Tesla, due to a number of crashes involving its vehicles, has been a topic of discussion. In one incident in Utah this month, the driver of a Tesla that crashed into a truck at 60 mph told police that she had the vehicle's autopilot feature turned on. Musk reacted at the time, tweeting that it was "super messed up that a Tesla crash resulting in a broken ankle is front-page news and the ~40,000 people who died in US auto accidents alone in the past year get almost no coverage."

During Wednesday's comments, Musk also responded to individual reporters, including one who drew a comparison to President Trump. In response to a reporter who said Musk was continuing "his slow transformation into a media-baiting Trump figure screaming irrationally about fake news," the Tesla CEO replied, "Thought you'd say that. Anytime anyone criticizes the media, the media shrieks 'You're just like Trump!'"

Musk continued, "Why do you think he got elected in the first place? Because no one believes you anymore. You lost your credibility a long time ago." To another journalist, who wrote that "blaming the messenger is the hot new thing everyone's doing," Musk replied, "Oh hey another sanctimonious media person who thinks he's above criticism."

"Try being truthful & the public will believe you again," Musk said.

Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Title: Vice President Pence to Work at White House Despite Aide's COVID-19 Diagnosis; White House Staff Adjusts to New Guidelines

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence will be present at the White House today, contrary to an earlier report suggesting he would work from home and self-isolate following an aide's positive Coronavirus test last week. Despite his presence, administration officials confirm that Pence is voluntarily maintaining a distance from others due to precautionary measures.

Pence has tested negative for COVID-19 since his exposure. Notably, President Trump's personal valet and Vice President Pence's press secretary, Katie Miller, have also tested positive for the virus. The President has had contact with both individuals within the past week.

Meanwhile, the Navy's top admiral and three key members of the Coronavirus Task Force are self-isolating or working from home following potential exposure to COVID-19. These individuals include Dr. Anthony Fauci, CDC Director Dr. Robert Redfield, and FDA Commissioner Dr. Stephen Hahn.

On ABC's "This Week" program, Lawrence Alan Kudlow, director of the United States National Economic Council, was asked about potential measures for White House staffers. Kudlow replied, "We will take the advice of the White House medical unit, which is the best in the business. There may be [precautions]. I do not want to rule anything in or rule anything out."

Senior White House Adviser Kevin Hassett admitted, "It is scary to go to work. You know, it's a small, crowded place. It's, you know, it's a little bit risky. But you have to do it because you have to serve your country."

New White House guidelines include testing anyone who sees the president, increasing the use of masks, and more rigorous screening of anyone who enters the White House grounds. Chief of Staff Mark Meadows asserts that enough is being done to protect the president, stating, "I can tell you, this is probably the safest place that you can come to."

The White House has already implemented daily Coronavirus tests for the president, vice president, and those closest to Trump. After Pence's press secretary tested positive, President Trump expressed that he was "not worried" about the virus spreading in the White House.

Title: Trump Withdraws U.S. from Trans-Pacific Partnership, Signs Executive Orders on Trade, Taxes, and Regulations

Article:

President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday, formally withdrawing the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade deal. The TPP involved the U.S. and 11 other Pacific Rim nations, but Congress had not ratified the agreement despite strong support from business groups and former President Barack Obama.

The withdrawal puts Capitol Hill and foreign governments on notice that the president will demand better deals on a one-on-one basis. Trump declared that the move was a "great thing for the American worker."

Trump's populist stance on trade has shaken up alliances in Washington. He received applause from union leaders during a meeting at the White House, but prominent Republican lawmakers have vowed to defend their party's traditional support for open markets and free trade.

In addition to the TPP withdrawal, Trump signed executive orders freezing nonmilitary federal hiring and reinstating the Mexico City Policy, which limits federal funding for abortions abroad. The abortion rule has been routinely adopted by Republican administrations and canceled by Democratic administrations since President Reagan enacted it in 1984.

Trump's actions on the TPP and the Mexico City Policy have received mixed reactions.
