While some, such as Senator Bernie Sanders, have applauded the TPP withdrawal, others, like Senator John McCain, have criticized it as a "serious mistake" that will have lasting consequences for the U.S. economy and strategic position in the Asia-Pacific region.

In the coming days, Trump is expected to sign an executive order to begin renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with Canada and Mexico. Trump has blamed NAFTA for the massive exodus of manufacturing jobs from the U.S. since it went into effect in 1994.

At a breakfast meeting with business executives, Trump said he wanted American firms to "make our products here again." He plans to reduce corporate tax rates from the current 35 percent to as low as 15 percent, but he said rolling back federal regulations that impede business growth would have a bigger impact. Trump also plans to cut income taxes for middle-class families.

Seated around the conference table were the top executives from Dell Technologies, Ford Motor Co., Lockheed Martin Corp., Dow Chemical Co., Under Armour Inc., Whirlpool Corp., Johnson & Johnson, U.S. Steel Corp., SpaceX, International Paper, and Corning Inc.

Title: GOP's Potential Divide on Susan Rice's Secretary of State Nomination

Article:

The potential nomination of Susan Rice as the next U.S. Secretary of State could lead to a public confrontation between President Barack Obama and his 2008 election opponent, John McCain. However, the Republican Party's unity in opposing Rice's nomination remains uncertain.

If Obama decides to nominate Rice, a close friend and the current U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, it could create a significant showdown between the president and McCain, who has been the most vocal critic of Rice within the GOP and has pledged to block her nomination.

The crux of McCain's criticism revolves around Rice's role in the aftermath of the September 11 Benghazi attack, which resulted in the death of U.S. Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens and three other Americans. In the days following the attack, Rice, as the public face of the White House's response, communicated a preliminary assessment that the incident was a spontaneous response to a demonstration.

McCain argues that Rice either showed incompetence by sticking to the CIA-approved talking points for several days or was engaged in a willful cover-up. In response, McCain has vowed to do everything in his power to block Rice's nomination and suggested that no Clinton replacement at State should be approved until the full details of the Benghazi attack are known.

However, McCain's efforts to rally the Republican Party against Rice seem to be meeting resistance. Notably, McCain's closest Senate ally, Lindsey Graham, declined to join in threatening to filibuster Rice during a recent interview, stating that he would wait to hear Rice's explanation before making a decision.

Other Republican senators, such as Marco Rubio and Joe Lieberman, have also expressed reluctance to pre-judge Rice's nomination. This suggests that, should Rice be nominated, a filibuster might not be the outcome, as was the case with Condoleezza Rice's secretary of state nomination eight years ago.

In conclusion, while John McCain is vocal in his opposition to Susan Rice's potential nomination, the Republican Party's unity in blocking her nomination remains uncertain. The outcome of Rice's nomination process could mirror Condoleezza Rice's nomination eight years ago, with the opposition party making noise but not actually filibustering.

Title: Federal Judge Rules President Trump Cannot Block Twitter Users for Political Views

Article:

A U.S. district judge has ruled that President Donald Trump cannot block Twitter users for their political views, citing a violation of the First Amendment. The ruling was made by U.S. district judge Naomi Reice Buchwald on Wednesday.

In her decision, Judge Buchwald wrote, "We then proceed to the substance of plaintiffs’ First Amendment claims. We hold that portions of the @realDonaldTrump account—the ‘interactive space’ where Twitter users may directly engage with the content of the President’s tweets—are properly analyzed under the ‘public forum’ doctrines set forth by the Supreme Court, that such space is a designated public forum, and that the blocking of the plaintiffs based on their political speech constitutes viewpoint discrimination that violates the First Amendment."

The judge further stated, "We reject the defendants’ contentions that the First Amendment does not apply in this case and that the President’s personal First Amendment interests supersede those of plaintiffs."

The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment from ███.

The lawsuit was filed in July 2017 by the Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University in New York, along with seven individual Twitter users, against President Trump. At the time, former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer noted in June 2017 that Trump's tweets are official statements, and the White House often sends out official statements every time the President tweets.

Title: GOP Struggles to Break Away from Fox News' Influence After 2012 Election Loss

Article:

Following the 2012 presidential election, some Republican strategists have pledged to distance themselves from Fox News, aiming to address the party's perceived reliance on the right-wing news channel. This self-proclaimed "grand experiment" of aligning a political movement with a cable news network was deemed a failure in 2012, but there is little indication that enough Republicans will have the courage or desire to break free from Fox News' influence.

The network's hardline, conservative approach, which has garnered it several million viewers, was effective in catering to a dedicated, right-wing audience. Fox News is projected to generate over $1 billion in profits this year. However, in terms of supporting a national campaign and facilitating a nationwide conversation about the country's future, Fox News' performance this year was markedly poor.

Throughout the campaign, Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate, often found himself in trouble when he adopted Fox News' rhetoric, damaging his presidential prospects. Instances of this include misrepresenting facts surrounding the terrorist attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, parroting the Fox talking point about the "47 percent" of voters who are lazy and shiftless, and Romney's puzzling embrace of reality TV show host-turned Fox News commentator Donald Trump.

Fox News viewers were not spared either. Throughout the year, they were fed a steady diet of misinformation about the candidates and were misled about the state of the race. This misinformation left Fox viewers disheartened on Election Night when Romney's supposed landslide failed to materialize.

The coverage of the campaign by Fox News has been widely criticized as an editorial and political fiasco. The coverage failed to sway the election in favor of the Republican candidate and remained detached from campaign reality for months at a time.

Following another lopsided loss to President Obama, Republican strategist Mike Murphy urged Republicans to adopt a view of America that is not derived from "Rush Limbaugh's dream journal." The Fox News dream journal bears a striking resemblance to Limbaugh's.

San Francisco Chronicle columnist Jon Carroll questioned whether Romney's defeat marked the end of the Fox News era, suggesting that the Fox model may have reached its limits in terms of ratings and electoral success.

Conservatives should have considered the long-term implications of handing control of a political movement to figures like Roger Ailes and his misinformation machine. They should have thought twice about allowing irresponsible media outlets like Fox News to supersede leadership within the Republican Party.

As Fox News became the de facto leader of the Republican Party, the driving electoral force, and with Ailes entrenched in his kingmaker role, candidates had to court Fox News in search of votes and the channel's coveted free airtime. The Republican Establishment is synonymous with figures like Rush Limbaugh, Roger Ailes, Karl Rove, and their media products, from Hannity to Levin.

New York magazine labeled Ailes "the head of the Republican Party." This is why a GOP source told the magazine, "You can't run for the Republican nomination without talking to Roger. Every single candidate has consulted with Roger."

This meant that campaigns were forced to become part of the channel's culture of personal destruction and to wrap themselves in Fox News' signature self-pity. Candidates, including Mitt Romney, often adopted the right-wing narrative that the conspiratorial press was out to sabotage their campaigns.

The right-wing bubble was a comfortable place to inhabit for those who viewed Obama as a historic monster or required constant reminders of this fact. The bubble was the place where followers were fed the feel-good GOP narrative about Obama's presidency being a disaster, that Americans suffered from 2008 buyer's remorse, and that the president's re-election defeat was all but pre-ordained.

The one-part-panic, one-part-denial message may have appealed to obsessive Obama-haters, but it did not prepare conservatives for the reality of the campaign season. And it cost the GOP a lost year in the Fox News bubble.

Title: U.S. and Mexico to Hold Talks Amid Threat of Tariffs and Border Crisis

Article:

Top officials from the United States and Mexico will commence negotiations on Monday in an attempt to avoid President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on imports from Mexico and address the influx of migrants at the border. The president is currently in London for a pre-planned overseas trip, leaving others to address a potential trade crisis.

The extent of what Mexico can do, and what will be considered sufficient, to appease the president remains unclear. Trump's Republican allies have warned that tariffs on Mexican imports could negatively impact U.S. consumers and the economy.

In a tweet on Sunday, Trump taunted negotiators for a swift resolution, stating, "Mexico is sending a big delegation to talk about the Border. Problem is, they’ve been ‘talking’ for 25 years. We want action, not talk."

On Monday, Mexican Economy Minister Graciela Marquez will engage in talks with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Two days later, delegations led by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Foreign Relations Secretary Marcelo Ebrard will also meet in Washington.

Trump has issued similar high-stakes threats in the past, only to back off at critical moments. However, a top White House official warned that the president is "deadly serious" about the tariffs. Trump has threatened 5% tariffs on Mexican imports starting June 3.

The president claims Mexico has taken advantage of the United States for decades but that the abuse will end with the imposition of tariffs on Mexican imports. His frustration with the flow of migrants is not new, but it is a subject he often revisits, as he did last week after special counsel Robert Mueller's rare public statement on the Trump-Russia report.

The tariff threat comes as the administration has been pushing for the passage of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which aims to update the North American Free Trade Agreement. Some Republicans have expressed concern that the tariffs could derail that effort.

Republican Sen. John Kennedy of Louisiana called the tariffs a "mistake" and said it was unlikely Trump would impose them. Republicans on Capitol Hill and GOP allies in the business community have expressed serious unease with the tariffs. Some see this latest threat as a negotiating tactic and doubt Trump will follow through. Earlier this year, Trump threatened to seal the border with Mexico only to change course.

The president "has been known to play with fire, but not live hand grenades," Kennedy said on CBS's "Face the Nation." "It's going to tank the American economy," he said. "I don't think the president's going to impose these tariffs."

Republicans have repeatedly tried to dissuade Trump from trade wars and have questioned the White House's ability to rely on executive authorities to impose some of the tariffs as national security issues. At the same time, Trump's efforts to revamp immigration laws have garnered little support in Congress.

"I think what the president said, what the White House has made clear, is we need a vast reduction in the numbers crossing," Kevin McAleenan, acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, said on CNN's "State of the Union."

Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, suggested that Mexico could take several steps to decrease the record numbers of migrants at the border. He proposed that the Mexican government could seal its southern border with Guatemala, crack down on domestic terrorist organizations, and make Mexico a safe place for migrants seeking to apply for asylum.

Economists and business groups have raised alarms over the tariffs, warning that they will impair trade and increase the costs of many Mexican goods that Americans have come to rely on. However, Mulvaney downplayed those concerns, stating, "American consumers will not pay for the burden of these tariffs."

He also suggested that the tariffs were an immigration issue, separate from the trade deal the United States is trying to negotiate with Mexico and Canada. Several top GOP lawmakers have expressed concerns that Trump's tariff threat could upend that deal. The chairman of the Finance Committee, Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa, said last week the tariffs would "seriously jeopardize" passage of that agreement, which needs approval in Congress.

Title: U.S. Drone Shot Down in Yemen, Missile Fired at American Drone in Gulf of Oman Incident

Article:

In a series of recent events, a U.S. MQ9 Reaper drone was fired upon by Iranian forces on Thursday, following the alleged Iranian attack on oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman. This incident occurred after a distress call from the MV Altair tanker, a Marshall Islands-flagged but Norwegian-owned crude oil tanker, at 6:12am local time. The drone arrived eight minutes later, but a missile, believed to be a modified SA-7, was fired at it at 6:45am local time, missing the drone.

According to U.S. officials, the first distress call from the MV Altair tanker went out at 6:12am local time. The unmanned MQ9 Reaper drone arrived eight minutes later. At 6:45am local time, a missile was fired at the drone, but missed. The U.S. military stated that the missile was fired from Iran's mainland. The drone was fired upon after it arrived on station to assist the Norwegian tanker.

In addition, U.S. officials reported that a U.S. MQ9 drone was shot down in Yemen by Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in recent days.

These events come amid heightened tensions in the region following the attack on oil tankers, which has put the U.S. and Iran on the brink of a direct conflict. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has blamed Iran for the "blatant assault" on oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman earlier Thursday.

Pompeo stated, "This assessment is based on intelligence, the weapons used, the level of expertise needed to execute the operation, recent similar Iranian attacks on shipping, and the fact that no proxy group operating in the area has the resources and proficiency to act with such a high degree of sophistication."

President Trump stated on "Fox and Friends" Friday morning that the attack had "Iran written all over it." He added, "Iran is a nation of terror and they've changed a lot since I've been president, I can tell you."

U.S. officials released a video on Friday, allegedly showing Iran's Revolutionary Guard removing an unexploded limpet mine from one of the vessels. The black-and-white footage, as well as still photos released by the U.S. military's Central Command on Friday, appeared to show the limpet mine on the Japanese-owned Kokuka Courageous, before a Revolutionary Guard patrol boat pulled alongside the ship and removed the mine, Central Command spokesman Capt. Bill Urban said.

Title: Congressional Democrats Coalesce Around Biden Ahead of Texas Campaign Tour

Article:

Representative Vicente Gonzalez of Texas, who switched his support from Julian Castro to Joe Biden in September, has been leading a quiet effort to rally the Congressional Hispanic Caucus behind Biden's candidacy. This move comes as the Biden campaign has announced endorsements from a group of former Castro supporters in Texas since Castro endorsed Elizabeth Warren.

The list of endorsements includes state representatives Rafael Anchia, Ryan Guillen, Eddie Lucio III, Oscar Longoria, and Armando Martinez. Previously, Biden's team announced the support of former San Antonio Mayor Phil Hardberger, state Sen. Jose Menendez, state representatives Rhetta Bowers and Garnet Coleman, and Dallas County Clerk John Warren. He also has the support of Texas representatives Eddie Bernice Johnson, Marc Veasey, and Filemon Vela.

Biden, who currently has the most endorsements from black and Hispanic members of Congress and congressional Democrats overall, is expected to campaign in Texas this week with fundraisers scheduled in Dallas and Houston. According to a CNN poll in December, Biden garnered 35 percent support in Texas, 20 points ahead of Bernie Sanders, his nearest competitor.

Representative Colin Allred, a Democrat from a battleground district, recently endorsed Biden, joining a growing number of moderate Democrats who are backing the former vice president. Allred compared Biden's appeal to that of former Democratic Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, stating that they also had the ability to win over disaffected Republicans and independents while also turning out the Democratic base.

"I know that Joe Biden is very popular in my district, and he will certainly win my district in 2020, and I think that that's probably the case across the country," Allred said, explaining why other moderate Democrats are getting behind the former vice president. This endorsement comes as vulnerable House Democrats are reportedly coalescing around Biden amid fears that a more liberal nominee could cost them their seats.

Title: Founding Fathers' Warnings on Partisan Outrage Resonate in Modern Politics

Article:

The Founding Fathers, in their warnings about the emergence of political parties, have found a modern echo in the current political landscape. George Washington, one of the Founding Fathers, referred to political parties as "factions," a term pronounced with disdain. In his writings, Washington expressed concerns about the wrangling of political parties, which he believed would agitate the community with ill-founded jealousies and false alarms.

Thomas Jefferson, another Founding Father, shared similar sentiments, stating that he would not go to heaven with a party if he could not. The modern political scene, with its partisan divisions, mirrors the concerns expressed by these historical figures.

The article notes that political parties have become conglomerates of factions, each with a narrow focus on issues that cater to their specific interests. One such faction is made up of feminists, gays, and blacks, while another is a group of voters who prioritize issues such as religion, gun rights, and traditional values.

The article suggests that the problem arises when factions take over political parties, leading voters to confuse loyalty to faction and party interests with loyalty to the nation's interests. Elections, in this context, become a contest to determine which factions have gained control over which parties.

The article also discusses the dangers of electing a candidate solely based on their identity, citing examples such as the election of Jimmy Carter and Barack Obama, who were perceived as representing specific demographics. The article warns that such decisions can lead to unintended consequences, as was the case with Carter's presidency and the impact of Obama's election on race relations.

The article concludes by reiterating the Founding Fathers' original American ideology, which emphasized the subordination of narrow and selfish interests to the greater good. The article suggests that the current political landscape, with its focus on factions and self-interest, has strayed from this original ideology, leading to a breakdown in the political process and a search for the common good that has failed. The article warns that the nation may be on a path towards becoming a collection of self-interested factions, with the common good taking a backseat.

Title: Second Round of ObamaCare Signups Begins Amid Improved Shopper Experience and Legal Challenges

Article:

The second round of ObamaCare signups commences this Saturday, with a goal of enrolling 3 million Americans and re-enrolling the approximately 7 million individuals who enrolled during the fall of 2013. This enrollment period, which concludes on February 15, is expected to offer an improved shopping experience for consumers, but it faces challenges from Capitol Hill and federal court.

President Obama and top administration officials have set a target of enrolling 9.1 million people in 2015, marking a 28% increase from the previous year. This round will see 77 new health insurance providers participating, a sign that they view the marketplaces as a business opportunity.

The first enrollment period was marred by technical issues, with federal and some state-run ObamaCare websites crashing, failing to fully register some customers, and providing incorrect information. These problems were largely resolved within several weeks, and federal officials have stated that the federal site is now improved and ready for the new enrollment period.

However, the Affordable Care Act continues to face opposition, with 56% of Americans in a recent Associated Press-GfK poll stating they would prefer to repeal the law completely, compared to 41% who would implement it as written. The Republican-controlled House of Representatives is reportedly planning hearings and investigations during the lame-duck congressional session on issues such as premium increases and the law's impact on the federal deficit.

In addition, the Supreme Court has agreed to hear a legal challenge on the law's tax credits, which make premiums affordable for millions. The court is not expected to hear the case until the spring, after the 2015 open enrollment period is over.

Website outages are a possibility during this year's enrollment period, but a full-scale meltdown seems less likely. HealthCare.gov has been revamped to handle peak loads and beyond, and will serve as the online portal for coverage in 37 states, while the remaining states run their own insurance exchanges. Consumers can also apply in person or through call centers.

The pool of potential customers is estimated to be 23 to 27 million people who do not have access to affordable coverage on the job. For most newcomers, the online application process has been simplified, with the number of computer screens reduced from 76 to 16. Navigation is easier, and window shopping is available without first having to create an account.

Premiums for 2015 are a wild card, with the average increase expected to be modest. However, prices can vary dramatically from state to state, even within regions of a state. Many returning customers could face premium increases if they do not shop around.

The administration is seeking to lower expectations, with Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia M. Burwell's target being a total enrollment of 9.1 million people in 2015. This sign-up period will be the first time that renewal has been tried for current customers, and it also overlaps for the first time with tax-filing season.

For those already signed up, coverage will renew automatically if they do nothing, but this may not produce the best result. Returning customers could miss out on lower-premium options and get stuck with outdated and possibly incorrect subsidies. In most cases, they have until December 15 to update their income information or switch insurance plans, in order to have the changes take effect on January 1.

The tax issues will emerge during next year's filing season. Current customers who received tax credits this year will have to file new tax forms to prove they received the correct amount. Too much subsidy, and their tax refunds will be reduced. Too little, and the government will pay them.

People who remain uninsured risk a penalty that will be deducted from their tax refunds. Millions may qualify for waivers, but getting exemptions could involve a paperwork ordeal. Community-based counselors helping uninsured people report strong interest, but they express concerns about this year's abbreviated sign-up season.

Title: Former Vice President Dick Cheney Warns of North Korean Crisis to GOP Lawmakers

Article:

Former Vice President Dick Cheney, in a meeting with GOP lawmakers on Tuesday, offered a blunt assessment of the ongoing crisis in the Korean peninsula, stating, "We're in deep doo doo." The concern stems from the unpredictable and potentially unstable North Korean leader, Kim Jong Un.

The situation in North Korea has become a matter of global concern, with the United States and its allies closely monitoring the region. According to recent U.S. intelligence, North Korea is believed to have completed preparations for mobile ballistic missile launches, and these missiles are reportedly ready for launch.

The Obama administration has indicated that a North Korean missile test could occur at any time. U.S. satellites are monitoring the Korean peninsula, and missile defense systems have been deployed in Japan and around Tokyo. Some Chinese tour groups have also canceled visits to North Korea.

Admiral Samuel J. Locklear, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, has characterized the crisis as a "clear and direct threat to U.S. national security and regional peace and stability." The volatile situation has left many wondering about North Korea's next move, as Kim Jong Un seems to have few options that do not involve a missile launch.

The potential for a military response from the United States remains a possibility, should North Korea proceed with a missile launch. The response would need to be forceful and unequivocal, sending a clear message that the U.S. is not playing games and means business.

The situation in North Korea remains a pressing concern for those living in areas within range of potential missile launches, including the West Coast of the United States. The crisis continues to unfold, and the world awaits Kim Jong Un's next move.

Title: The Evolution of the Civil Rights Movement: A Reflection on the 50th Anniversary of the March on Washington

Article:

Fifty years after the historic March on Washington, the contemporary civil rights movement faces criticism for its perceived shift from a grassroots, justice-focused movement to a politically-motivated, fundraising entity. The article, written by an unnamed author, argues that the modern civil rights movement, in part due to its success in dismantling segregation, has become preoccupied with imagined slights and manufactured controversies, rather than addressing the welfare of real people.

The author compares the two eras, highlighting the stark contrast between the challenges faced by Martin Luther King Jr. and the current state of the movement. King, who faced physical threats and violations of civil liberties, is contrasted with Al Sharpton, whose career is described as a catalog of the ridiculous and outrageous in pursuit of media attention.

The article notes King's profound engagement with biblical prophets and Reinhold Niebuhr, and his belief that "unearned suffering is redemptive." In contrast, Sharpton's career is marked by incidents such as falsely accusing a man of rape and denouncing a Jewish businessman as a "white interloper."

The author argues that the fight against segregation has been won, but the contemporary civil rights establishment struggles to acknowledge this. They suggest that cultural breakdown, rather than officially sanctioned discrimination, is a significant factor in the struggles of black Americans.

The article concludes by criticizing the contemporary civil rights establishment for using the charge of racism to shut down argument and deflect uncomfortable conversations, rather than fostering dialogue and progress. The author suggests that the modern movement is a testament to the legacy of the great movement's degeneration, rather than a continuation of its ideals.

Title: Kerry Emerges as Frontrunner for Secretary of State Position

Article:

With John Kerry reportedly being the only serious candidate for the Secretary of State position, following the withdrawal of Susan Rice, the appointment of Kerry is the "working presumption" according to a senior State Department official. However, White House officials have stated that the decision is not finalized, as the current lineup, which includes Chuck Hagel as Defense Secretary and Michael J. Morell as the permanent C.I.A. director, is perceived as reminiscent of past national security teams.

If appointed, John Kerry would be the first white man to serve as Secretary of State since Warren Christopher in early 1997. His predecessors include Madeleine K. Albright, Colin Powell, Condoleezza Rice, and Hillary Clinton. Kerry's colleagues in the Senate have expressed confidence in his ability to pass through confirmation hearings, with Senator John McCain, a Republican from Arizona, already referring to him as "Mr. Secretary."

The composition of President Obama's team has come under renewed scrutiny following Rice's withdrawal. If she remains as the ambassador to the United Nations, she will continue to be part of Obama's cabinet and national security team. Rice is also considered a potential successor to Thomas E. Donilon as national security adviser. However, Donilon is not expected to leave his post for a year or two, unless he is named White House chief of staff.

Michèle A. Flournoy, a former under secretary of defense for policy, is still a candidate for the first female Defense Secretary. However, internal discussions suggest that the challenge of the next few years, which includes working with Congress to reduce the defense budget and eliminate major cold war-era weapons systems, requires a candidate like Chuck Hagel, a Republican from Nebraska, who is seen as better able to win votes from his former colleagues.

Flournoy has also been mentioned as a possible C.I.A. director, but Michael Morell, who ran the analysis division of the agency, is the favorite of C.I.A. officials. John Brennan, a close aide to Obama and a former agency station chief in Saudi Arabia who has directed counterterrorism activity from his basement White House office, is also a candidate for C.I.A. director. However, officials note that his current post already gives him sway over all 18 intelligence agencies.

John Kerry has worked hard to strengthen his relationship with President Obama. Although Obama has at times considered Kerry long-winded and a throwback to a previous generation of diplomats, aides said, Kerry impressed Obama and Donilon when he was sent to deal with Hamid Karzai, the unpredictable president of Afghanistan, after Karzai's supporters rigged a presidential election in 2009 and refused a second round of voting.

Kerry also visited Pakistan several times to ease recurrent tensions, including a two-week visit after the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. Pakistani officials tried to get Kerry to write what they called a "blood oath" that the United States would never take action to seize Pakistan's nuclear arsenal. Kerry found a diplomatic way out, saying the United States had no "designs" on Pakistan's weapons.

Title: Clinton Campaign's Internal Strategy Documents Reveal Friendly Relationships with U.S. Media and Manipulation Strategies

Article:

Internal strategy documents and emails among Hillary Clinton's campaign staff have shed light on friendly and highly useful relationships between the campaign and various members of the U.S. media, as well as the campaign's strategies for manipulating those relationships. The documents were provided to a source identifying himself as Guccifer 2.0, who was reportedly responsible for prior significant hacks, including one that targeted the Democratic National Committee and resulted in the resignations of its top four officials.

On Friday, Obama administration officials claimed that Russia's "senior-most officials" were responsible for that hack and others, although they provided no evidence for that assertion. As these internal documents demonstrate, a central component of the Clinton campaign strategy is ensuring that journalists they believe are favorable to Clinton are tasked to report the stories the campaign wants circulated.

At times, Clinton's campaign staff not only internally drafted the stories they wanted published but even specified what should be quoted "on background" and what should be described as "on the record." A January 2015 strategy document—designed to plant stories on Clinton's decision-making process about whether to run for president—singled out reporter Maggie Haberman, then of Politico, now covering the election for the New York Times, as a "friendly journalist" who has "teed up" stories for them in the past and "never disappointed" them.

Nick Merrill, the campaign press secretary, produced the memo, according to the document metadata. That strategy document plotted how Clinton aides could induce Haberman to write a story on the thoroughness and profound introspection involved in Clinton's decision-making process. The following month, when she was at the Times, Haberman published two stories on Clinton's vetting process; in this instance, Haberman's stories were more sophisticated, nuanced, and even somewhat more critical than what the Clinton memo envisioned. But they nonetheless accomplished the goal Clinton campaign aides wanted to fulfill of casting the appearance of transparency on Clinton's vetting process in a way that made clear she was moving carefully but inexorably toward a presidential run.

Given more than 24 hours to challenge the authenticity of these documents and respond, Merrill did not reply to our emails. Haberman declined to comment. Other documents listed those whom the campaign regarded as their most reliable "surrogates"—such as CNN's Hilary Rosen and Donna Brazile, as well as Center for American Progress President Neera Tanden—but then also listed operatives whom they believed were either good "progressive helpers" or more potentially friendly media figures who might be worth targeting with messaging. The metadata of the surrogate document shows the file was authored by Jennifer Palmieri, the communications director of the campaign.

As previously reported by ███, pundits regularly featured on cable news programs were paid by the Clinton campaign without any disclosure when they appeared; several of them are included on this "surrogates" list, including Stephanie Cutter and Maria Cardona.

The Clinton campaign likes to use glitzy, intimate, completely off-the-record parties between top campaign aides and leading media personalities. One of the most elaborately planned get-togethers was described in an April, 2015, memo—produced, according to the document metadata, by deputy press secretary Jesse Ferguson—to take place shortly before Clinton's official announcement of her candidacy. The event was an April 10 cocktail party for leading news figures and top-level Clinton staff at the Upper East Side home of Clinton strategist Joel Benenson, a fully off-the-record gathering designed to impart the campaign's messaging.

A separate email chain between Clinton staff (one that was not among those provided by Guccifer 2.0 but appeared on the DCLeaks.com site earlier this week) contains plans for a separate off-the-record media get-together in May. Food and drinks were provided by the campaign for the journalists covering it, on the condition that nothing said would be reported to the public. Many of the enduring Clinton tactics for managing the press were created by the campaign before she even announced her candidacy. A March 13, 2015, memo from Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook provides insight into some of the tactics employed by the campaign to shape coverage to their liking. In particular, Mook was concerned that because journalists were assigned to cover Clinton, they needed to be fed a constant stream of stories that the campaign liked. As he put it, a key strategy was to "give reporters who must cover daily HRC news something to cover other than the unhelpful stories about the foundation, emails, etc."

Title: Vice President Pence Straddles Delicate Line in Administration's Response to Anti-Racism Protests

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence is attempting to inject a more conciliatory tone into the Trump administration's response to anti-racism protests, while maintaining a delicate balance that does not reveal a dissonance with President Donald Trump's "law and order" positioning.

During a White House meeting with state attorneys general, police union representatives, and local sheriffs, Pence offered a refined version of Trump's stance that economic stability is the solution to racial injustice. However, he acknowledged that the economy alone cannot deliver racial justice.

Pence's ability to adapt to the times and modify his posture as needed is one of his defining characteristics, setting him apart from his defiant boss. This trait could potentially benefit the administration during this period of social unrest.

In contrast to Trump's hard-line comments, Pence has been engaging in quiet outreach to affected communities. For instance, he met privately with prominent black conservatives to solicit their thoughts on how the administration should proceed. This approach is emblematic of the challenge Republicans face as they grapple with Trump's incendiary rhetoric on race and the simultaneous desire to build a big-tent coalition.

During the 2016 election, Pence clung to a pro-police stance, aligning with the tough-on-crime platform he and Trump ran on. However, the killing of George Floyd has highlighted differences between the president's strategy and that of his deputy.

Pence's absence during Trump's visit to St. John's Episcopal Church, where the president waved a Bible in front of the historic house of worship that had been partly burned during riots, raised questions among White House officials and outside allies. Pence's decision to stay back at the White House was attributed to deference, as it was considered a presidential moment.

The differences between Trump's hard-line comments and Pence's quiet outreach to affected communities underscore the challenge Republicans face as they navigate Trump's incendiary rhetoric on race and the desire to build a broad coalition. This was further illustrated by the contrast between Trump's comments about former Secretary of State Colin Powell and Senator Mitt Romney's participation in a faith-based protest against police brutality.

Rev. Charles Harrison, a Pence ally, expressed concerns about the president's remarks regarding tone but is hoping to discuss race relations with Pence soon. Harrison, who worked closely with Pence during his time as Indiana governor, praised Pence's openness to conversations about race relations.

Title: Nearly Half of U.S. COVID-19 Deaths Occur in Long-Term Care Facilities, According to Research

Article:

A new analysis of state-reported data by the Foundation for Research on Equal Opportunity (FREOPP) reveals that nearly half of all COVID-19 fatalities in the United States have occurred in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities. Across 39 states that report the location of COVID-19 deaths, 42 percent have occurred in nursing and residential care facilities.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that 2.1 million Americans live in nursing homes or long-term care facilities, which is 0.6 percent of the total population. The 42 percent figure may be undercounting nursing home deaths, as some states, such as New York, exclude from their nursing home death tallies those who die in a hospital, even if they were originally infected in an assisted living facility.

Researchers at the International Long Term Care Policy Network, a global organization that shares research and best practices, found that 40.8 percent of reported COVID-19 fatalities across 18 countries took place in nursing homes.

Several reasons contribute to the high number of COVID-19 cases and deaths in nursing homes. Most residents of nursing homes are elderly or infirm, with many suffering from long-term ailments or weakened immune systems. People live close together, sharing living quarters and common spaces like cafeterias. There is also evidence that the coronavirus spreads more efficiently indoors.

Some states made policy choices in the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic that may have made nursing homes even more vulnerable to the disease. Governors in some states, including Michigan, New York, and Pennsylvania, prevented nursing homes from turning away patients with active COVID-19 infections. These policies likely helped spread the disease to some of the most vulnerable populations.

Other states, like Florida, have locked down nursing homes and prioritized shipments of personal protective equipment (PPE) to those facilities, putting them on the same level as hospitals. That may help explain why Florida has had fewer overall deaths than other large states—despite 40 percent of those deaths occurring in nursing homes—and it's something other states should copy.

As states emerge from total lockdowns and begin to restart their economies, policies must adapt to reflect the growing body of evidence about COVID-19 vulnerabilities. We now have a better idea about the overall fatality rate of the disease—about 0.3 percent, lower than was feared at earlier stages in the crisis. We also know more about how the disease spreads and which populations need the most protection.

Avik Roy, president of FREOPP, writes that the concentration of deaths in nursing homes should give younger, healthier Americans more confidence about returning to some semblance of normal life and should inform public policy decisions about how to slow the disease's spread. These data have implications for policy making as states look to safely reopen their economies.

Roy states, "The fact that nearly half of all COVID-19 deaths have occurred in long-term care facilities means that the 99.4 percent of the country that doesn't live in those places is roughly half as likely to die of the disease." This suggests that schools and many businesses can be reopened without the risk of huge spikes in hospitalizations or deaths, according to Roy, and that states must learn from their earlier missteps in handling nursing home outbreaks. These data have implications for policy making as states look to safely reopen their economies. The coronavirus is going to be a long-term problem, but the next step in fighting it is for governments to lift economically ruinous lockdowns when possible and focus on saving the lives most at risk.

Title: Media Matters Pressures Advertisers to Withdraw Support from Fox News Host Sean Hannity

Article:

Left-wing activist group Media Matters is using allegations surrounding Alabama GOP Senate candidate Roy Moore as a means to pressure advertisers of Fox News host Sean Hannity. Moore is accused of making sexual contact with a 14-year-old girl while he was a 32-year-old attorney, in addition to pursuing romantic relationships with other teenage girls around the same time.

Media Matters is reportedly smearing Hannity to his sponsors, accusing him of defending child sex abuse. Hannity has explicitly stated that anyone guilty of what Moore is accused of doing has no place in politics.

Over the weekend, Media Matters operatives pressured several advertisers into pulling their ads from Hannity's show. In one instance, Angelo Carusone, Media Matters' president, tagged a sponsor of Hannity's show while claiming that Hannity defends "sexually preying on children."

In response to one such tweet from Carusone, coffee company Keurig announced that it would be pulling ads from Hannity's show. Another sponsor, Realtor.com, announced that it would not be running ads on Hannity in the future. 23andMe also stated that it is not currently running TV ads on Hannity.

Media Matters has been targeting Hannity's advertisers for months, launching a "Stop Sean Hannity" campaign in August. The group published a list of Hannity's sponsors and urged left-wingers to let advertisers know that they "will get burned if they continue to associate with Hannity."

Previously, Media Matters targeted Hannity's advertisers in May after the Fox News host pushed a conspiracy theory surrounding murdered DNC staffer Seth Rich. That campaign caused several advertisers, including military insurance group USAA, to pull their ads from Hannity's show. Conservative activists responded by targeting the advertisers for MSNBC's Rachel Maddow and other liberal hosts. USAA eventually reinstated its advertisements on both MSNBC and Fox News.

Media Matters' effort to defund Hannity comes after they and other left-wing activists successfully pressured Fox News into firing Bill O'Reilly following sexual harassment allegations against the host.

Title: McConnell Rejects Schumer's Call for Live Testimony During Impeachment Trial

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on Tuesday dismissed Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer's demand for live testimony during the upcoming impeachment trial against President Trump, stating that Democrats in the Senate now seek to address the House's alleged oversights.

McConnell claimed that Schumer wants to expand on the work of House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff by calling additional witnesses beyond those the House chose to pursue.

"The House chose this road — it's their duty to investigate," McConnell said on the chamber floor.

McConnell argued that the House failed to pursue "useful witnesses" in court and that Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her colleagues did not wait for due process.

"They threatened to impeach the president if they had to go to court at all," McConnell said, adding that the House's articles of impeachment, as they stand, appear "inadequate to prove what they want to allege."

McConnell's remarks followed Schumer's publication of a letter to the majority leader and a press conference earlier this week, where he demanded live testimony from four key witnesses, including White House acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, senior adviser Robert Blair, former National Security Adviser John R. Bolton, and his associate deputy director Michael Duffey.

Schumer stated that these individuals have direct knowledge about President Trump's decision-making regarding the withholding of aid to Ukraine.

"To conduct a trial without the facts is saying we are afraid. We have something to hide," Schumer said.

The two leaders are expected to meet "soon" to agree on rules and procedures for the trial, which is anticipated to begin next month. The specifics of the meeting and the outcome of the trial are currently unavailable.

Title: Kanye West Distances Himself from "Blexit" Campaign and Politics

Article:

Rapper Kanye West, who previously wore a MAGA cap and shared the stage with President Trump at the White House, has distanced himself from the "Blexit" campaign, a push to encourage black voters to leave the Democratic Party. In a series of tweets on Tuesday, West stated that he had no association with the "Blexit" campaign and that he was disassociating himself from politics.

In one tweet, West clarified that he had introduced Candace Owens, the black conservative promoting the "Blexit" campaign, to the person who designed the campaign's logo. However, the logo designer did not want their name associated with the campaign, so Owens used West's name instead.

"I never wanted any association with Blexit. I have nothing to do with it," West tweeted.

In another tweet, West expressed his disillusionment with politics, stating, "My eyes are now wide open and now realize I've been used to spread messages I don't believe in. I am distancing myself from politics and completely focusing on being creative!"

West had previously outlined a political platform on Twitter, expressing support for creating jobs, prison reform, common-sense gun laws, and accountability for those who misuse power. He also expressed compassion for people seeking asylum and parents fighting to protect their children from violence and war.

While West's political platform did not seem MAGA-compliant on the surface, it is unavailable to determine whether this shift in stance is a result of his distancing from the "Blexit" campaign or a broader change in political beliefs.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Announces Republican Members for Benghazi Committee

Article:

House Speaker John A. Boehner has appointed seven Republican members to the select committee on Benghazi, with the goal of investigating the security lapses leading up to the September 11, 2012, attack on the U.S. diplomatic post in Libya. The committee will also explore the U.S. response to the attack, the Obama administration's initial effort to portray the attack as a mob uprising, and efforts to pursue the attackers.

Trey Gowdy, a former prosecutor and South Carolina Republican, will serve as the committee's chairman. Gowdy is known for his tough questioning of former Internal Revenue Service official Lois G. Lerner in his role on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee.

The committee's members include two women, Martha Roby, a second-term congresswoman from Alabama, and Susan W. Brooks of Indiana, a former U.S. attorney. Jim Jordan of Ohio, a member of the oversight panel and a former chairman of the Republican Study Committee, was appointed to represent conservatives. Peter J. Roskam, another Republican member, serves as chief deputy whip and represents Speaker Boehner's leadership team on the panel.

Mike Pompeo of Kansas and Lynn A. Westmoreland of Georgia, both members of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, were also appointed. Assurances from Boehner and Gowdy notwithstanding, Democrats have accused Republicans of using the tragedy as a political tool and to raise campaign funds ahead of the midterm elections.

Speaker Boehner has stated that the committee's goal is to find the facts regarding the four families who lost loved ones and the American people. Boehner has also emphasized the importance of an eclectic mix of members and finding the truth to uphold the system of checks and balances.

Title: Chicago Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson Asks for Internal Investigation After Being Found Lying in Car

Article:

CHICAGO (AP) — Chicago Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson asked the city's police department to conduct an internal investigation on himself Thursday after he was found lying down in a car.

A passerby found Johnson early Thursday in a car parked near a stop sign and called 911. Police department spokesman Anthony Guglielmi said in a statement that Johnson indicated he parked his car after feeling lightheaded. Officers checked on Johnson's well-being and did not observe any signs of impairment.

"There were no charges of intoxication, no information of intoxication as far as I know," Guglielmi said.

Guglielmi says Johnson requested the investigation because he believes officers and the superintendent "ought to be held to the highest standard."

"So what that means is they're going to interview the officers, they're going to look at all available evidence just to make sure that this is above-board and happened as described," Guglielmi said.

The 59-year-old Johnson underwent kidney transplant surgery in August 2017. His son Daniel was the donor.

Guglielmi said Johnson visited a doctor earlier this week regarding a medication change. He said the superintendent on Wednesday expressed concerns about feeling exhausted. Guglielmi says Johnson visited a doctor Thursday to be evaluated on issues concerning his blood pressure.

Johnson was hospitalized in June after doctors found a small blood clot in his lung during a stress test done as Johnson approached the two-year anniversary of his transplant. The clot was treated with medication and rest.

Johnson was appointed superintendent in March 2016 by then-Mayor Rahm Emanuel. His predecessor, Garry McCarthy, was fired days after the release of a video of the 2014 fatal shooting of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald by officer Jason Van Dyke. Van Dyke was convicted of second-degree murder last year and is serving a nearly seven-year prison sentence.

Title: Time Magazine Names Pope Francis Person of the Year 2013

Article:

Time magazine has named Pope Francis as its Person of the Year for 2013. This marks the third time a pope has received this honor, with Pope John Paul II being chosen in 1994 and Pope John XXIII in 1963. The Argentine pontiff, who was known as the "slum cardinal" for his visits to the poor and his preference for subway travel as archbishop of Buenos Aires, beat out other contenders such as former U.S. National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden and gay rights activist Edith Windsor for the award.

The selection was made by Time's editors, who considered suggestions from the magazine's more than 2 million Twitter followers. Vatican spokesman Father Federico Lombardi stated that Pope Francis, the first non-European pope in 1,300 years, the first from Latin America, and the first Jesuit, was not seeking fame.

In a statement, Lombardi said, "It is a positive sign that one of the most prestigious recognitions by the international media has been given to a person who proclaims to the world spiritual, religious, and moral values and speaks out forcefully in favor of peace and greater justice."

Pope Francis's style is characterized by frugality. He shunned the spacious papal apartment in the Vatican's Apostolic Palace to live in a small suite in a Vatican guest house, and he prefers a Ford Focus to the traditional pope's Mercedes. A champion of the downtrodden, he visited the island of Lampedusa in southern Italy in July to pay tribute to hundreds of migrants who had died crossing the sea from North Africa.

In September, Francis gave a groundbreaking and frank interview, in which he said the Vatican must shake off an obsession with teachings on abortion, contraception, and homosexuality, and become more merciful. In July, Francis told reporters he was not in a position to judge homosexuals who are of good will and in search of God, marking a break from his predecessor, Benedict, who said homosexuality was an intrinsic disorder.

With the Catholic Church marred in recent years by sex abuse scandals, Francis formed a team of experts on Thursday to consider ways to improve the screening of priests, to protect minors, and to help victims. However, Barbara Blaine, president of the Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests (SNAP), a victim advocacy group, said in a statement Wednesday that more action was needed.

"After nine months of essentially ignoring the church's most severe crisis, (Pope Francis) hastily announced last week that he'll appoint an abuse study panel," Blaine said. "He has not, however, made a single child safer."

Title: Economic Impact of Federal Government Shutdown on National Park Communities

Article:

The ongoing federal government shutdown, currently in its eighth day, is causing economic hardships for communities surrounding national parks, particularly those that rely on tourism. The small town of Terlingua, Texas, located near Big Bend National Park, is one such community.

The Big Bend Natural History Association, a nonprofit organization, estimates it will lose approximately $35,000 per week in sales from its bookstores in closed park buildings due to the shutdown. The Far Flung Outdoor Center, a local resort and outfitter, has reported a half dozen cancellations at its dozen cabins.

Greg Henington, owner of the Far Flung resort and a local outfitter, stated, "The uncertainty is what hurts us the most." While the overall economic impact of the shutdown is limited, communities dependent on national parks for economic activity are experiencing fewer visitors and less spending at area businesses such as hotels, restaurants, outfitters, and bookstores.

The National Parks Conservation Association estimates that, during this time of year, there are usually half a million visitors a day to the nation's 400 parks. This traffic generates roughly $18 million daily for nearby communities, from the Everglades in Florida to Yosemite in California, according to the nonprofit group.

Kathryn Petralia, co-founder of Kabbage, an online small business lender, noted, "They need every dollar that comes in the door." Kabbage is providing loans to small- and medium-size businesses that may experience delays in obtaining Small Business Administration loans due to federal staffing cuts.

National Park Service officials did not respond to a request for comment, and SBA officials were not immediately available for comment.

In Macon, Georgia, about 157,000 people a year visit the Ocmulgee National Monument Native American site and spend an estimated $9 million, according to the National Parks Conservation Association. However, with Macon's largest tourism attraction now closed, visitors unable to see artifacts including ancient ceremonial and burial mounds in the monument during a holiday lights show this month.

Gary Wheat, chief executive officer of Visit Macon, the city's tourism booster, stated, "We see a lot of repeat travelers, but if you're not open, you risk losing those people from coming back."

In Port Angeles, Washington, near Olympic National Park, the main road to a winter play area called Hurricane Ridge has been closed since the federal shutdown due to a lack of staff to plow a mountain road. As a result, the Hurricane Ridge Ski and Snowboard Area has remained closed during one of its busiest weeks of the year, costing about $5,000 a day in lost revenues and prompting the furlough of about 16 part-time workers.

John Fox, like most of the other workers, relies on the ski area as a second job. "It would be nice income for the holidays for everyone to have," said Mr. Fox, 33 years old, whose main job is as a ferry worker in Port Angeles. "It's very disappointing, but it's definitely out of our hands."

Big Bend National Park has also been disrupted during a seasonally busy time. Nearly 10% of the park's 440,000 annual visitors come in December when desert temperatures are mild. Although much of the park was initially kept open, officials closed the campgrounds "due to sanitation and resource impact concerns," according to a notice on the park's website.

Other national parks are experiencing a buildup of uncollected garbage and sewage. In an email last week, a National Park Service spokesman stated the agency would follow a contingency plan of closing areas if issues arise such as garbage buildup.

Mr. Henington, the outfitter, expressed concern that people will avoid Big Bend altogether if the federal shutdown continues. "People will just think it's not worth going out there," he said.

Title: Wisconsin Republican Primary Results Suggest Deep Divide Within GOP

Article:

Ted Cruz's victory in the Wisconsin Republican primary has solidified his position as the "anti-Trump" candidate in the presidential nomination race, according to analysts. Cruz beat Donald Trump by 13 points, securing 48 percent of the vote compared to Trump's 35 percent. However, Cruz's victory does not indicate unity within the Republican Party, as he claimed in his victory speech.

The analysis suggests that Cruz's win was largely due to anti-Trump sentiment rather than pro-Cruz support. More than half of Cruz's supporters, and two-thirds of Ohio Governor John Kasich's supporters, expressed fear of a Trump presidency, rejecting the leading candidate in the race.

Governor Kasich underperformed in Wisconsin with only 14 percent of the vote, but he remains adamant about taking his campaign to the convention as the only "mainstream" Republican still in the race. This has resulted in a split of the anti-Trump vote.

In the event of a general election between Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton, only 61 percent of GOP primary voters said they would vote for Trump, with 19 percent saying they would vote for a third-party candidate, 10 percent saying they would vote for Clinton, and 8 percent saying "no one."

If it's Cruz vs. Clinton in November, only 66 percent of Wisconsin Republicans said they'd back Cruz, with 18 percent saying they'd vote third party, 6 percent saying Clinton, and 6 percent saying "no one."

These numbers indicate a deep divide within the GOP between Trump supporters and Republican voters who oppose him. If Trump is not the nominee, many of his supporters say they will abandon the party altogether, especially if they believe Trump is treated unfairly at the convention.

In the event of a contested convention, if Trump arrives without a majority of the delegates, it becomes easier to deny him the nomination. However, denying Trump could potentially split the party, while not denying him could make him the face of the party.

The next test comes in two weeks with the New York primary, home turf for both Trump and Clinton, who, like Trump, needs to overcome an embarrassing defeat in Wisconsin. If either underperforms, it will be clear that Wisconsin was a turning point. Both will be damaged, but still on track to head to their respective conventions with the most delegates. The math, at this stage in the race, is almost impossible to overcome.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Appoints Former FBI Director as Special Counsel for Russia Investigation

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein has appointed former FBI Director Robert Mueller to oversee the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) investigation into any alleged collusion between the Trump 2016 campaign and the Russian government. In a press release on Wednesday, Rosenstein stated, "In my capacity as acting Attorney General, I determined that it is in the public interest for me to exercise my authority and appoint a Special Counsel to assume responsibility for this matter."

Rosenstein clarified that his decision is not a finding that crimes have been committed or that any prosecution is warranted. He stated, "What I have determined is that based upon the unique circumstances, the public interest requires me to place this investigation under the authority of a person who exercises a degree of independence from the normal chain of command."

Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein emphasized the independence and integrity of the U.S. Department of Justice, stating, "Each year, the career professionals of the U.S. Department of Justice conduct tens of thousands of criminal investigations and handle countless other matters without regard to partisan political considerations." He added, "Considering the unique circumstances of this matter, however, I determined that a Special Counsel is necessary in order for the American people to have full confidence in the outcome."

Rosenstein concluded, "Our nation is grounded on the rule of law, and the public must be assured that government officials administer the law fairly. Special Counsel Mueller will have all appropriate resources to conduct a thorough and complete investigation, and I am confident that he will follow the facts, apply the law, and reach a just result."

Title: YouTube Bans Proud Boys Founder Gavin McInnes, Citing Copyright Infringement

Article:

YouTube has banned the account of Gavin McInnes, the founder of the Proud Boys, citing copyright infringement, according to the Daily Beast. McInnes, who was already banned by various social media platforms, had nearly a quarter-million subscribers on his YouTube channel.

In August, Twitter suspended McInnes' account before a "Unite the Right" rally in Washington, D.C. At the end of October, Facebook and Twitter banned McInnes and Facebook groups affiliated with the Proud Boys, one day after the Daily Beast reported on McInnes' promotion of his infamous Oct. 12 speech at a New York Republican club, which ended with his Proud Boy followers brawling in the street with left-wing activists.

To promote his speech, which celebrated the decades-old murder of a Japanese socialist, McInnes posted pictures of himself on Instagram in racist "Asian eyes" glasses. In the aftermath of the event, McInnes—who recently made his account private—posted a picture of the Japanese assassination with a Nike slogan superimposed over it: "Just do it."

On Saturday, The Blaze announced McInnes would not be working with them, although roughly one week before the outlet had announced he would be hosting a show. McInnes, who before becoming an alt-right darling was best known for co-founding Vice, was poised to host "Get Off My Lawn," a show that was reportedly similar to his "Get Off My Lawn" podcast.

In mid-November, The Washington Post reported that a Washington state sheriff's office had issued a report saying the FBI considered the Proud Boys to be an extremist group. The office of Clark County Sheriff Chuck E. Atkins said in the report, "The FBI categorizes the Proud Boys as an extremist group with ties to White Nationalism. The FBI has warned local law enforcement that the Proud Boys are actively recruiting in the Pacific Northwest and that some in the group have contributed to the escalation of violence at political rallies held on college campuses."

However, last week, The Oregonian reported that according to Oregon's top FBI agent, the FBI had not designated the Proud Boys as an extremist group. Special Agent in Charge Renn Cannon told reporters that the FBI never intended to designate the Proud Boys as an extremist group when it briefed Clark County law enforcement leaders about regional threats. Cannon stated, "We do not intend and did not intend to designate the group as extremist... That was not our intention. That's not what we do. We will not open a case if someone belongs to antifa or even the Proud Boys. There has to be a credible allegation or a threat of violence before someone opens a case."

Title: Theresa May Steps Down as Conservative Leader, Triggers Leadership Contest

Article:

Theresa May, the United Kingdom's second female prime minister, has announced her resignation as Conservative leader, effectively ending her turbulent three-year premiership. In a speech at Downing Street, May expressed gratitude for the opportunity to serve the country she loves, acknowledging her inability to deliver Brexit as a matter of deep regret.

May's announcement follows a meeting with Graham Brady, the chair of the backbench Tory 1922 Committee, who was prepared to trigger a second vote of no confidence in her leadership if she refused to resign. The prime minister will remain in Downing Street to shoulder the blame for expected poor results for her party in the upcoming European elections and to host U.S. President Donald Trump during his visit.

The Conservative Party will set out the terms for a leadership contest, with the process expected to begin on 10 June and last approximately six weeks. The timetable for the contest, as set out by the Conservative Party, is as follows:

* Nominations closed on 10 June.
* The first round of voting was held on Thursday 13 June.
* Subsequent rounds have been pencilled in for the 18th, 19th, and 20th.
* The postal vote element, when the approximately 140,000 Conservative party members will choose the country's new prime minister, will be completed in the week beginning Monday 22 July.

Boris Johnson, the former foreign secretary, is considered the frontrunner to be the next prime minister, with more than a dozen senior Tory figures considering entering the race. Rory Stewart, Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove, Penny Mordaunt, and Sajid Javid are among the likely contenders from the current cabinet.

May's departure comes after three years of wrangling with Brexiters on her own backbenches about the future relationship with the European Union. The loss of her majority at the 2017 general election, after a widely regarded disastrous campaign, also contributed to her difficulties.

Damian Green, May's longtime friend and former first secretary of state, defended her record on Friday, stating that she was dealt an extremely difficult hand due to the seismic shock of the Brexit referendum and the subsequent loss of the Conservative Party's majority. Green also noted the increasing impatience and hostility towards the political class in the wake of the Brexit impasse.

Title: Parallels Between Watergate Scandal and Hillary Email Investigation Draw Comparisons by Bob Woodward

Article:

Veteran journalist Bob Woodward, who played a pivotal role in uncovering the Watergate scandal that led to President Richard Nixon's resignation, has drawn parallels between the Watergate scandal and the ongoing investigation into Hillary Clinton's email practices while she was Secretary of State.

In an interview, Woodward noted that the Clinton email controversy shares similarities with Nixon's prolonged battle over the White House tapes 40 years ago. Initially, Clinton seemed to be a strong contender for the Democratic nomination and the presidency. However, recent developments have sparked speculation about the viability of her candidacy and the possibility of her facing criminal charges for mishandling classified documents, a crime that has resulted in the prosecution of lesser-known individuals.

Woodward, who was a staffer in the Nixon White House before, during, and after the Watergate scandal, highlighted several eerie similarities. In 1972, Nixon was poised for a landslide re-election, with foreign policy successes and a strong economy. However, the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate office building and the subsequent investigation led to the unraveling of Nixon's presidency.

In the Watergate scandal, the Justice Department created a special prosecutor with subpoena powers, and numerous individuals from Nixon's staff were called to testify before Congress and behind closed doors with the special prosecutor. Investigative reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein published numerous stories detailing the investigation, including the existence of an Oval Office taping system that recorded the president's meetings.

Nixon refused to turn over the tapes, but the Supreme Court eventually ordered him to do so. The tapes revealed evidence implicating Nixon in the Watergate cover-up, leading to his resignation or the threat of impeachment and removal from office. Nixon never faced trial or jail time, but his presidency was effectively ended.

Woodward posed questions about Clinton's actions, such as why she had a private email system and why she refused to turn over her emails in the first place. He also questioned whether Clinton, like Nixon, had something to hide and whether the missing emails could contain information about the Benghazi scandal or relationships between Clinton Foundation donors and her decisions at the State Department.

The Clinton administration has recently allowed inquiries into her emails, and she is now being investigated by three government agencies: the Justice Department, the State Department, and the Intelligence Community. The outcome of these investigations remains uncertain, but Woodward noted that once special prosecutors are appointed or congressional investigations begin, they often find evidence of wrongdoing.

The investigation into Clinton's emails could potentially present significant challenges for her presidential campaign, although it may not result in the earth-shattering consequences of Nixon's forced resignation in August 1974. The irony lies in the fact that one of the staff members on the Watergate Committee that investigated Nixon's files and tapes was a young lawyer named Hillary Rodham.

Title: Orange County's Political Shift: From Republican Stronghold to Democratic Advantage

Article:

In the mid-1990s, Orange County, California, was the most Republican county in the United States by raw numbers. The political landscape was dominated by the Republican Party, with Democrats being an afterthought. However, changes were beginning to emerge, as demonstrated by the victory of Democrat Loretta Sanchez over GOP firebrand "B-1 Bob" Dornan in the 1996 congressional election.

The county's Republican dominance was evident in the grand election night parties, often held at a posh hotel near John Wayne Airport. These events were attended by virtually every Republican elected official, as well as Democratic officials. The biggest tussles were between conservatives and the RINOs (Republicans in Name Only).

Orange County was not just Republican, but it was the Republican Mecca. The county played a significant role in propelling political figures such as Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon into politics. However, as the county's defense-based economy and demographics changed, so did its politics.

In 2016, Hillary Clinton received more votes than Donald Trump in Orange County, marking a significant shift. The midterms saw a more pronounced change, with Democrats taking every congressional race and making serious gains in state legislative seats. The county's Republican Party, which had been operating as if nothing had changed, is now facing a significant challenge.

The shift in Orange County has far-reaching implications for the state as a whole. California Republicans counted on Orange County's overwhelmingly GOP vote totals to overcome their disadvantage elsewhere in statewide races. With Orange County's most Republican large county now evenly split, the question remains: Where will Republican votes come from to help balance Democratic strongholds elsewhere?

The recriminations are ongoing, with some blaming the president, immigration, or the party's leadership for the changes. Regardless of the cause, the GOP needs to face up to reality and come up with new strategies to stay relevant, or the death spiral will continue.

As of now, 27% of voters in Orange County are No Party Preference. Statewide, No Party Preference registrants have surpassed GOP voters. The number of registered Democrats has fallen by about 110,000 since the 2016 election, while the number of Republicans has dropped by about 340,000.

There is opportunity in these numbers. It's not as if California voters are in love with the Democrats. There are plenty of issues that Republicans can tap into, such as road congestion, a housing crisis, service cutbacks, crime hikes, poverty rates, and growing pension liabilities. However, the party's poor leadership and outdated thinking have gotten it nowhere.

At the state level, Republicans always get obliterated now. The two non-liberals who came closest to winning in the last election cycle both lacked the GOP label. These trends have been in the works for two decades, but OC's final flip from red to blue adds a punctuation point to California Republican decline. Perhaps the GOP can be heartened by an old Reagan quotation: "The future doesn't belong to the fainthearted; it belongs to the brave."

Title: Florida Governor Rick Scott's Decision to Expand Medicaid Program Sparks Debate Among Conservatives

Article:

Florida Governor Rick Scott, a vocal critic of the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, has announced that Florida will accept federal funds to expand its Medicaid program. This decision has sparked controversy among conservatives, with some viewing it as a pragmatic move to provide affordable health insurance to Floridians, while others see it as a capitulation of principles.

Charles Krauthammer, a conservative political commentator, discussed the situation on 'Special Report' last night, stating that "it's honorable to take the money because people in [Florida] are paying federal taxes, are subsidizing people in other states." He further explained that it is a choice between providing health insurance to constituents and continuing the fight against Obamacare, suggesting that the law's passage through Congress, the President's signature, and the Supreme Court's approval make it difficult to repeal the law in the near future.

Governor Scott's decision to expand Medicaid comes after voters declined to elect a candidate who promised to repeal Obamacare in full during the 2016 election. This decision has led some to question whether Governor Scott's conservative credentials are being called into question, given his past efforts to repeal the law.

Several other states with conservative governors, including Louisiana, Texas, and Wisconsin, have refused to participate in the Medicaid expansion program. The question remains whether Governor Scott's decision to accept federal funds for Medicaid expansion is a pragmatic move to provide health insurance to Floridians or a shift in political stance.

Title: Trump's Proposed Involvement with Voice of America Sparks Controversy

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed displeasure with the media's coverage of his presidency, which has been marked by allegations of corruption, incompetence, and lies, among other issues. To counter this perceived negative portrayal, Trump has reportedly taken steps to limit his media consumption to conservative outlets like Fox News, and has been known to provide feedback to hosts on their segments.

However, the president's efforts to control media coverage have extended beyond his personal media consumption. In an attempt to influence the narrative domestically, Trump has considered using the federal government's funding of Voice of America (VOA), a news organization with an annual budget of $218.5 million that broadcasts to 236.6 million people worldwide. VOA, which exclusively served foreign audiences until 2013, plays a role in shaping foreign perceptions of the United States and its leaders.

It is unclear if Trump is aware of VOA's role and mission, or if he views it as a means to disseminate propaganda about his administration. In January 2017, VOA's director, Amanda Bennett, stated that her team would "absolutely" not be "manipulated by the Trump administration."

The use of federal funds for domestic media manipulation has sparked controversy, with critics arguing that such actions undermine the principles of a free press and the First Amendment. The White House has not provided further details on the proposed involvement with VOA.

Title: Email Traffic Reveals Clinton Campaign Aware of Senate Inquiry into Uranium One Deal

Article:

A series of emails, part of a hacked collection belonging to John Podesta, the chairman of Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, has been released on the WikiLeaks website. These emails reveal that top staffers for Clinton's campaign were informed about a Senate inquiry into the State Department's approval of the sale of American uranium assets to a Russian company, Uranium One.

The email thread, sent by Maura Pally, a senior vice-president at the Clinton Foundation, to Podesta at 12:18 p.m., reads:
