"Putting on all of your radars that Grassley sent a letter to AG Lynch (dated June 30th though we just saw it) asking questions about contributions to the Clinton Foundation and the Uranium One deal. Letter is attached. Craig is connecting with comms team to be sure they are aware as well."

The email was forwarded to several members of the campaign staff, including Jennifer Palmieri, Kristina Schake, Tony Carrk, and Christina Reynolds.

Sen. Charles Grassley (R-IA) had previously written a letter on June 30, 2015, expressing concern over the rapid approval of the transaction, which controlled nearly 25 percent of the country's uranium deposits.

The New York Times reported in April 2016 that the Clinton Foundation had ties to several investors involved in the Uranium One deal. The transaction, which resulted in the acquisition of U.S. based uranium assets by Atomredmetzoloto (ARMZ), a subsidiary of Rosatom, a Russian government-owned company, raised national security concerns due to the foreign involvement.

Grassley, in his letter, requested answers from the attorney general by July 16, 2016, on several questions, including the role of the Department of Justice in the Uranium One/ARMZ transaction, the personnel involved, and whether Secretary Clinton's relationship with the Clinton Foundation required her to recuse herself from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) review of the Uranium One/ARMZ transaction.

The email traffic does not provide specific answers to these questions, but it does demonstrate the routine and intimate interaction between members of the campaign staff and the Clinton Foundation. It is unavailable whether the Department of Justice played a role in the Uranium One/ARMZ transaction, who the involved personnel were, or if Secretary Clinton recused herself from the CFIUS review.

Title: Trump Pardons Conservative Commentator, Contemplates Pardons for Martha Stewart and Rod Blagojevich

Article:

President Donald Trump on Thursday announced the pardon of conservative commentator and filmmaker Dinesh D'Souza, who pleaded guilty in 2014 to U.S. campaign finance law violations. Trump also indicated he was considering pardons for lifestyle maven Martha Stewart and former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich, prompting criticism that the president is subverting the rule of law.

D'Souza, who is an outspoken critic of former President Barack Obama, was sentenced to five years of probation after pleading guilty to illegally reimbursing two "straw donors" who donated $10,000 each to the unsuccessful 2012 U.S. Senate campaign in New York of Wendy Long, a Republican he had known since attending Dartmouth College in the 1980s.

Trump's decision to pardon D'Souza has sparked controversy, with some constitutional scholars, legal analysts, and Democratic lawmakers accusing Trump of undermining the rule of law with pardons based on political considerations. Critics argue that the president is sending a message to individuals caught up in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into potential collusion between the Trump 2016 presidential campaign and Russia, including Trump's longtime private lawyer Michael Cohen, whose business dealings are separately under scrutiny in New York.

Trump is also considering a pardon for Stewart, who was convicted in 2004 on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice, and making false statements in an insider-trading probe. Trump also said he might commute the 14-year prison sentence of former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich, a Democrat convicted of corruption charges.

White House spokesman Hogan Gidley denied that celebrity was a consideration in whom the president decides to pardon. "Look, there are plenty of people the president is looking at right now under the pardon process," he said.

The U.S. Constitution gives the president the power to issue pardons, and Trump has used that authority to benefit convicted figures revered by some on the political right, such as former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio and Scooter Libby, the chief of staff to former Vice President Dick Cheney.

Trump pardoned Libby in April, and Arpaio in August 2017, less than a month after his conviction for criminal contempt in a case involving racial profiling of Hispanics. Arpaio was known for his crackdown on illegal immigrants in Arizona's Maricopa County.

Trump also pardoned boxer Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight champion, last week, posthumously, who was jailed a century ago because of his relationship with a white woman.

Stewart and Blagojevich were both involved with Trump's "Apprentice" reality TV television show. Blagojevich was convicted of corruption offenses including soliciting bribes for appointment to the U.S. Senate seat Obama vacated after being elected president in 2008.

Title: U.S. Presidential Candidates' Foreign Policy Stances and International Challenges

Article:

In the run-up to the U.S. presidential election, both candidates are facing international challenges that require their attention, with the European economic situation and the Middle East conflicts being prominent examples. Stephen D. Biddle, a scholar at the Council on Foreign Relations, stated that both candidates tacitly agree to pretend that their policies can significantly impact the American economy, while in reality, they are both influenced by foreign events beyond their control.

President Barack Obama's trip to Mexico for the Group of 20 leaders' gathering marks his third international summit meeting in a month. During his time in Los Cabos, he will discuss the financial crisis in Greece and meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, following accusations of Moscow supplying arms to Syria. Meanwhile, his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, will tour swing states during Obama's absence.

The president will also engage in talks with Iran regarding its nuclear program, with the aim of curbing Tehran's nuclear activities. Optimism over these talks has waned, giving way to fears of an impasse that could benefit Iran.

Foreign policy has not been a significant concern for American voters, with only 4% of respondents in the latest New York Times-CBS News poll citing it as their top election issue. Despite this, Mr. Romney has occasionally used foreign policy to criticize Mr. Obama, stating that he would "just look at the things the president has done and do the opposite" regarding Israel. On the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Romney expressed a willingness to take military action against Iran if necessary.

Kristen Silverberg, a former State Department official under President George W. Bush who is advising Mr. Romney, criticized the Obama administration for its perceived lack of leadership, stating that it has "sat out" significant international events such as the Iran protests and the Syrian uprising.

Jamie M. Fly, executive director of the Foreign Policy Initiative, a conservative group, expressed a growing sense that "what is required is American leadership rather than the president's leading-from-behind foreign policy that has failed to address an imploding Syria, a nuclearizing Iran, an economic crisis in Europe, and a revanchist Russia."

While foreign policy can present challenges, it also offers advantages for a president. Engaging in international diplomacy on Air Force One lends a statesmanlike stature, allowing the president to dismiss criticism as mere politics. In response to Mr. Romney's comments about Israel, Ben LaBolt, an Obama campaign spokesman, stated, "Mitt Romney is yet again trying to score cheap political points by distorting President Obama's record of support for Israel."

Mr. Obama's foreign policy record, including the withdrawal of troops from Iraq, the toppling of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's government in Libya, and robust action against terrorists, is often cited as an advantage. James M. Goldgeier, dean of American University's School of International Service, described Mr. Obama as the "first real national security Democrat" since President John F. Kennedy.

Nancy E. Soderberg, a national security aide and United Nations diplomat under President Bill Clinton, noted that it is "par for the course" for an incumbent to address international challenges while the challenger has a free ride. However, she also pointed out that the European economic crisis could negatively impact Mr. Obama's re-election efforts, stating, "Europe's weakness is likely to blow back on Obama's efforts this fall—just at the wrong time."

Title: Deadly Storms and Flooding Ravage Texas and Oklahoma

Article:

Storms have been moving through Texas and Oklahoma, bringing tornadoes and torrential rains that have led to deadly flooding. According to authorities, at least 10 people have died as a result of the storms this weekend.

In Oklahoma, four people have died, including a firefighter in Claremore, near Tulsa, who was swept into a storm drain on Sunday, and a Tulsa woman who died on Saturday after her automobile hydroplaned on a highway.

In Houston, Texas, authorities have recovered the bodies of at least two people, and at least 12 people are missing. During a press conference, Houston Mayor Annise Parker stated that "large parts of the city were 'high and dry,'" but some highways and neighborhoods were still inaccessible.

President Obama called the flooding "terrible" and said he spoke with Texas Governor Greg Abbott this morning. "I assured Gov. Abbott that he could count on the help of the federal government," he said. "We have FEMA personnel already on the ground. They are coordinating with Texas emergency management authorities, and I will anticipate that there will be some significant requests made to Washington. My pledge to him is that we will expedite those requests."

In Texas, some parts have received more than 20 inches of rain this month, according to The Weather Channel. Houston received more than 10 inches of rain last night, causing water to pool in city streets and even on highways. Interstate 10, a major east-west thoroughfare in the city, was closed this morning, and Twitter users sent pictures of cars apparently floating across Interstate 45.

Louie Bond, a magazine editor and former editor of Wimberley's newspaper, said, "The ground was saturated. The cypress trees along the river are stripped down to bare toothpicks." Wimberley and nearby San Marcos, a pair of Blanco River towns off the Interstate 35 corridor linking Austin and San Antonio, appear to have been the hardest-hit towns in the United States.

However, in Ciudad Acuña, a Mexican city of about 140,000 on the border due west of San Antonio, a tornado that leveled blocks of buildings at sunrise on Monday killed at least 13 people.

Title: Thousands Protest U.S. Immigration Policies Across America, Call for Reunification of Separated Families

Article:

Thousands of protesters took to the streets in cities across America to demonstrate against the nation's immigration policies and demand the reunification of parents and children who were separated at the U.S.-Mexico border, according to published reports. More than one week ago, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to end the practice, but many families still remain separated as the government sorts through their cases.

In all, an estimated 600 protests were scheduled in cities spanning from New York City to Los Angeles. The marchers included open-border advocates as well as conservatives who say families should not be separated. The total number of protesters could rise to hundreds of thousands, according to some reports. Social media was flooded with photos of those participating and watching the demonstrations.

In New York City, protesters shouted "Shut detention down," a reference to demonstrations held at ICE offices across the country. Barry Hooper of San Francisco told the Associated Press he attended the protest with his wife and two daughters to "let the president know that this is not acceptable." Liliana, his 7-year-old daughter, held a sign she made that read, "Stop the separation."

Protesters in San Francisco carried flags and signs with slogans that read, "Deport Trump," and "I Really Care, Do You?" – a jab at the words written across a jacket the first lady wore during a visit to an immigrant detention center. Amid a global furor over the immigrant crisis, Melania Trump wore a jacket with the words, "I really don't care, do u?" written across the back in large white letters. Trump later said the message on his wife's jacket was directed at the "Fake News Media."

Celebrities and politicians who oppose Trump were among those participating in a demonstration in Los Angeles, according to the Associated Press. California Democrats who turned out for the event included Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) and Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.). Migrant children taken from their parents will suffer lifelong trauma, Harris said.

A rally near the city hall in Portland, Maine was so large that police shut down streets as a reported 2,000 people "chanted, cheered and prayed," the wire service reported. In downtown Denver, an estimated 4,000 people attended a boisterous rally. Some of the protesters wore foil blankets, a symbol of similar blankets they gave to children separated from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border.

Others carried signs that included the messages: "Keep the kids, deport the racists" and "Break walls, build families." Elsewhere, smaller groups banded together in city parks and downtown squares in virtually every state. Some carried tiny white onesies with the words, "What if it was your child?" and "No family jails," according to reports.

The rallies were funded by the American Civil Liberties Union, MoveOn.org, the National Domestic Workers Alliance, and The Leadership Conference, Fox News reported. Local organizers did most of the planning and coordination efforts. Many of them used informal networks that formed during the worldwide women's marches that happened on Trump's inauguration and its anniversary, the report stated.

As the protests were underway, Trump doubled-down on the immigration issue through a series of tweets, including:

Title: "Romney's Four-Year Tenure as Massachusetts Governor: A Look at His Collaborative Approach and Legislative Accomplishments"

Article:

In the run-up to the November elections, both President Obama and Republican Mitt Romney will highlight their differences. However, the two men's lives share striking similarities, particularly in their experiences as political executives. This article is part of NPR's "Parallel Lives" series, focusing on Mitt Romney's four-year tenure as governor of Massachusetts (2003-2007).

During his time in office, Romney faced a Massachusetts Legislature that was 85% Democratic. He attempted to boost the number of Republicans during his first two years, but this effort was unsuccessful, as Republicans lost seats in the midterm elections. Frustrated, Romney shifted his focus, stating, "From now on, it's me-me-me."

Within weeks, Romney unveiled a universal health insurance plan, which became his signature accomplishment as he launched a 2008 bid for the White House. Passing this bill required close collaboration with Democrats, and at its ceremonial signing at Boston's Faneuil Hall, Romney spoke as a political uniter.

At the bill's signing, Romney stood alongside Democratic Sen. Edward Kennedy, who died in 2009. The two men had debated sharply on the same stage in 1994 during Romney's unsuccessful bid to unseat Kennedy. However, in 2006, Kennedy had only praise for Romney, stating, "To our governor, and to our Senate president and our speaker, we all say, 'Well done.'"

Thomas Whalen, a Boston University political historian, suggests that passing the state's health care law pushed Romney outside his comfort zone. Whalen states, "He was capable, you know, when he was willing to, to get down in the trenches, [to] cut deals, to pigeonhole legislators, to get his reform health care package through."

Apart from health care, Romney defined success not with big-picture legislative accomplishments but with confrontation. In a 2008 campaign ad, Romney boasted about taking on his Legislature, stating, "I like vetoes; I vetoed hundreds of spending appropriations as governor." Romney issued some 800 vetoes, and the Legislature overrode nearly all of them, sometimes unanimously.

At a recent Obama re-election rally on the steps of the Massachusetts Statehouse, Democratic legislator Pat Haddad was heckled by Romney supporters. Haddad warned that if Romney is elected president, "You're gonna get the same guy who never wanted to engage the Legislature. He never wanted to look for new jobs; he was always only looking for his next job."

However, Romney campaign spokesman Ryan Williams argues that this is the kind of criticism one receives for shaking up the status quo. Williams states, "Obviously, when you do that and make the tough decisions, you're not going to make friends everywhere."

Democrat Ellen Story, who served in the Legislature during Romney's tenure, recalls a governor who was aloof and not approachable. Story remembers Romney having a policeman screen visitors and not allowing lawmakers to use the bank of elevators just outside his office.

Former Massachusetts Senate Minority Leader Richard Tisei praises Romney for his handling of a $3 billion deficit, stating, "He walked into a very difficult situation, and I think the fact that he was able to close the budget gap without increasing income or sales or any other broad-based tax, No. 1. And No. 2, he was able to control spending."

At the time, Tisei says, people in Massachusetts appreciated Romney's effort. However, this week, the Obama campaign released a new ad that aims to turn Romney's time as governor against him, stating that the state under Romney had "one of the worst economic records in the country."

By the end of his term, Romney's approval rating in Massachusetts was only 34%. In recent polls, the number has barely changed. Political historian Whalen suggests that this is not surprising, stating, "I think Romney's biggest problem here in Massachusetts is not that he necessarily did a disastrous job. He did not. But he raised the expectation bar so high that, you know, he just didn't deliver."

This critique is similar to the one often leveled against the president whom Romney seeks to unseat.

Title: Romney's Foreign Policy Vision in Final Debate: A Tough Battle Ahead

Article:

Mitt Romney's advisers anticipate a challenging debate on foreign policy, which will take place on Monday in Boca Raton, Florida, as the focus on this issue is a strength for President Barack Obama. The Romney campaign views this debate as the last opportunity to significantly impact the election in the swing states that will determine the outcome.

According to top advisers, Romney's chances of winning the debate are slim due to the electorate's perceived lack of interest in foreign affairs at present. The differences between the two candidates on key issues such as ending the Afghan war and the Syrian conflict are minimal, making it difficult to draw clear distinctions.

President Obama has used the successful operation that led to the death of Osama bin Laden as a political advantage in debates and speeches, emphasizing strength and achievement. This strategy has been effective in demonstrating Obama's foreign policy successes.

The Romney campaign is hopeful that the candidate will not worsen his position in the debate, but they are not as confident about winning the race as they were before the first presidential debate. The debates have not significantly altered the race, according to Vin Weber, the Romney campaign's special adviser on policy. Weber stated, "The candidates are close, and the economy is the Number One issue. Foreign policy is really important, but it is not driving this election."

A top Republican official expressed a more straightforward view: "I don't think there are a lot of soft voters who are waiting to hear a position on the Eurozone." This could be problematic for Romney, as another strong debate performance could be the deciding factor in his favor.

The two campaigns share a similar perspective on the state of the race as of this weekend: Obama currently holds a slight edge, particularly in the Midwest states of Iowa, Wisconsin, and Ohio, which makes a Romney victory challenging. However, Romney is performing well in Florida, has a slight advantage in Colorado, and is near-even in Virginia, offering more hope than before the first debate.

Romney's foreign policy has not been his strongest area throughout the campaign, from his assertion that Russia is the biggest strategic threat to the U.S., to his bumpy Europe trip, and ending with his politicized statement following the Libya killings and a clumsy exchange about that terrorist attack in the last debate.

Matt Bennett, co-founder of Third Way, a Democratic-leaning think tank, commented, "So far, Romney is batting zero when it comes to landing a punch on foreign policy or national security." Bennett added, "He has whiffed in every single at-bat, and there's no evidence he can do any better when he's doing it for 90 minutes."

Title: NATO's Evolution and Challenges: A Call for Tough Decisions

Article:

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), established in 1949, has faced increasing scrutiny and debate in recent years, with the latest controversy sparked by U.S. President Donald Trump's comments on the alliance's commitment to defend its newest member, Montenegro.

The essence of NATO lies in the principle of collective deterrence, where an attack against one member, as per Article V of the NATO charter, is considered an attack on all members. This mutual defense is the cornerstone of the alliance, deterring potential aggressors by demonstrating a strong, united front.

However, the question arises: What happens when an alliance becomes so large and diverse that not all members share similar traditions, values, agendas, or national-security threats? The original European members of NATO, considered themselves kindred neighbors under the nuclear umbrella of the United States. With the inclusion of West Germany in 1955, NATO's mission was altered to not only keep the U.S. in and the Soviet Union out, but also to raise Germany up rather than keeping it down.

NATO's collective defense was designed to offer breathing space against the superior forces of the Soviet Red Army, until the United States could bring in reinforcements or threaten to use its superior nuclear forces against would-be aggressors.

As the alliance has grown, it has become less a defensive military alliance and more a de facto cultural institution to homogenize Europe along Western lines. For some in Europe, NATO is envisioned not so much as a collection of planes and tanks, but instead as an expanded version of the European Union.

The more diverse NATO has become, the less unified it has become, especially with the demise of the original threat of the Soviet Union. As post-Cold War Europe grew calmer and more affluent, NATO members became less likely to believe that they would ever need to sacrifice to invest in their mutual defense.

In the aftermath of the Cold War, NATO was eager to enlist eager Eastern European and Balkan nations that rightly had feared Russia even after the end of the Soviet Union. However, southeastern Europe and the Balkans were also home to age-old feuds and surrogate wars between rival empires, from World War I to the Bosnian War in the early '90s.

One, vastly increasing its membership can only make NATO weaker, not stronger. In some sense, when everyone is in an alliance, no one really is. Vladimir Putin may gamble to find out whether affluent Dutch or Belgian youth will really be willing to die fighting for the territorial integrity of distant Bulgaria. If not, then Article V will be exposed as a farce, and NATO itself will be finished.

If Albania and Montenegro are in NATO, why not Austria, Finland, Kazakhstan, Macedonia, and Serbia? Will Mexico join Canada and the U.S. to round out the North American membership?

Two, the borders of the "North Atlantic Treaty Organization" are now ill-defined. Recep Tayyip Erdogan's Turkey is becoming an updated version of the old Islamic Ottoman caliphate. It is an enemy of the Kurds and Israel, both staunch U.S. allies. If Turkey gets into a "defensive" conflict with Israel, would young soldiers from Kansas want to risk death to "defend" an anti-American, authoritarian NATO theocracy from a pro-American liberal democracy?

Tough decisions, not more weary and sanctimonious rhetoric, are needed to revitalize NATO. The alliance must insist that all members quickly meet their military obligations of spending 2 percent of their GDP on defense. If a rich country in peace reneges on its promise of military readiness, why would anyone expect it to fulfill its pledge of assistance in wartime?

NATO should insist on common values and agendas, and its members should formally identify their likely collective enemies. The alliance must ensure that any nation in NATO belongs in NATO—and thus is worth risking what could become a nuclear war on its behalf.

Title: The Ongoing Debate on Iran Nuclear Negotiations: A Closer Look at the Unmentioned Parallel Nuclear Weapons Program

 Article:

 The ongoing nuclear negotiations between Iran and the P5+1 (China, France, Germany, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States) have been a subject of debate since the April Fool's Day 'framework' was announced in Lausanne, Switzerland, in late March 2015. The Obama administration, along with Secretary of State John Kerry and their advisors, have attempted to portray the contentious talks as a great success, despite contradictory statements from the European Union, France, Iran, and the U.S. regarding the agreed-upon terms.

 Amir Taheri, in a piece at the New York Post on April 4, 2015, referred to the diplomatic discussions as a "diplomatic dog's dinner" of competing and contradictory statements, suggesting that it is not a genuine agreement at all.

If we consider what is known about Iran's nuclear weapons program, it becomes apparent that the ongoing discussions about centrifuges, enrichment levels, inspection regimes, and sunset clauses are merely window dressing. The real Iranian nuclear weapons program is likely hidden behind a wall of secrecy, guarded by Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC) and the Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS—Iran's primary intelligence agency).

It is well-known that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered the IRGC to "get the bomb" in the waning days of the 1980s Iran-Iraq war. Details about the subsequent 25-year Iranian commitment to comply with that order are less well-known.

As the "father of the Pakistani bomb," Abdul Qadir Khan, wrote in documents obtained by the Washington Post in 2010, Pakistan provided Iran with blueprints and parts for centrifuges and shared its secret list of worldwide suppliers. This is how the Iranian nuclear weapons program began. However, neither the IAEA (International Atomic Energy Agency) nor the public knew anything about this until the Iranian opposition group, the National Council of Resistance of Iran (NCRI), exposed Iran's program in August 2002.

The Iranian regime, a signatory to the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), went into panic mode and came up with a plan to limit the damage. The Iran Lobby in America would play a key role in that damage control operation.

Much like the Iranians' mentors in the clandestine WMD business—the Soviet KGB—had done earlier when some of its illicit weapons programs made media headlines, the Iranians conceded a few of the sites that were now exposed: Natanz, Isfahan, Arak, and later Fordow. Lavizan-Shian, where the regime had worked on nuclear warhead design, was deemed too sensitive, so it was simply razed to the ground in 2003, and its components moved elsewhere.

Natanz, the buried uranium enrichment site where some 9,000 centrifuges currently operate, became the centerpiece of the regime's new information operation. It was opened to IAEA inspections, figured prominently in the IAEA's quarterly reports, and was allowed on the P5+1 nuclear negotiations agenda.

Similarly, it was with Isfahan, the conversion plant; Arak, the heavy water reactor that gives Iran a parallel plutonium route to the bomb; and Fordow, a deeply buried centrifuge facility.

Everyone has been kept busy arguing, discussing, and negotiating about the sites Iran got caught with—and now, more recently, a non-existent 'agreement' that each of the parties describes in its own, mutually contradictory, terms. Indeed, all the negotiating teams from the IAEA, Britain, China, the European Union, France, Germany, Russia, and the U.S. are being kept so busy that nearly everyone has forgotten all about the fact that Iran's entire nuclear program was an illicit clandestine one until the NCRI exposed it—or that virtually every site in that program that's now public was revealed by someone other than Iran.

Parchin, a military site where the IAEA believes Iran has conducted nuclear trigger explosives tests, provides a good example of how the regime deals with demands to open places to inspection it would rather remain closed: they just say "no." And, as with Lavizan-Shian a dozen years earlier, they conduct a "clean-up" operation to tear down buildings and destroy parts of the complex they'd prefer not show up in any more satellite images.

Naturally, Parchin has not been included in any of the P5+1 talks, nor has the U.S. delegation even suggested that it ought to be. It has been the same with other suspicious sites like Khondab and Lavizan-3, now revealed publicly, but left completely off the agenda. This is not to even consider how many additional clandestine sites Iran has been operating, but are as yet not revealed.

The critical issues before us then are not so much about the number of centrifuges, or which generation of centrifuges, or what level of enrichment will be allowed to Iran going forward at the showcase sites: rather, we must ask why and how our negotiators have themselves been spun up to dither endlessly, but only about sites already in the public domain. Iran's secret parallel nuclear weapons program remains unmentioned and untouched.

In Part 2 of this series, the critical role of the Iran Lobby will be examined.

Clare M. Lopez is the Vice President for Research & Analysis at the Center for Security Policy.

Title: GOP Optimistic About Senate Primary Results, Predicting Closer Control of the Senate

Article:

Establishment Republicans are expressing optimism that the results of Tuesday's Senate primaries in Kentucky, Georgia, and Oregon will yield candidates favorable for defeating Democrats in November, potentially bringing the party one step closer to controlling the Senate.

The primary race in Kentucky, featuring a challenge to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, has garnered significant national attention. McConnell is predicted to secure a landslide victory over tea party candidate Matt Bevin, but the margin could be crucial in November. Recent polls indicate McConnell could win by 20-30 percent, according to The Washington Post. However, a substantial turnout for Bevin on Tuesday could signal a challenging general election for McConnell against Kentucky Democratic Secretary of State Alison Lundergan Grimes, a self-described "Bill Clinton Democrat."

In the Georgia primary to replace retiring GOP Sen. Saxby Chambliss, none of the five contenders are expected to secure the necessary 50 percent support to avoid a run-off in July between the top two vote-getters. Businessman David Perdue, who is making his first foray into public service, is currently polling up to 10 percent higher than Chamber of Commerce-backed Rep. Jack Kingston. Kingston is competing for second place with former secretary of state Karen Handel, a favorite of Sarah Palin, according to The Washington Post.

If Perdue becomes the nominee, the Post added, the odds of securing a victory in November could be against him, given that only seven sitting senators have never previously held elected office. However, the Democratic recruit, businesswoman Michelle Nunn, is a first-time candidate, and recent polls indicate Perdue currently leads Nunn in a potential match-up by single digits. Polls also show that a match-up between Nunn and Kingston puts Nunn ahead by an average of just 2.5 percent.

In Oregon, Republicans are closely monitoring the fortunes of pediatric neurosurgeon Monica Wehby, who is facing state Rep. Jason Conger. Wehby has appeared poised for a sure victory, but a report alleging Wehby stalked an ex-boyfriend may have impacted her momentum heading into the final days. The extent to which the news may have affected her chances is unclear, particularly given that many Oregon voters vote by mail, the Post noted, predicting she will prevail. If she wins, Wehby would challenge Democratic Sen. Jeff Merkley, who narrowly won in 2008.

While a Republican has not been elected senator in Oregon in over 10 years, early polls indicate Wehby would be running neck-and-neck with Merkley, providing the GOP a credible chance to take the seat. One poll in April gave Wehby a 4-point lead, while another gave Merkely a 12-percent advantage.

Title: Proposal for a Pre-Designed Randomized Clinical Trial in Response to Acute Infectious Disease Outbreaks

Article:

The Ebola virus has made its way to the United States on several occasions, with at least two instances of its spread to healthcare workers. Given the extensive spread of Ebola in West Africa, more cases in travelers or healthcare workers would not be surprising. The disease has been known since the times of the plague, and unfortunately, more cases are expected.

Despite the identification of Ebola and related viruses nearly 50 years ago, there is still a lack of knowledge regarding the best therapies for people infected with the virus. In the midst of an epidemic, it is crucial to learn the most effective ways to quickly treat critically ill individuals, not only to stem the tide of disease in the United States but for the benefit of the global community.

In any epidemic, there are early cases and late cases. Learning from the early cases can help in making informed decisions when things get worse. Three years ago, cases of severe E. coli infections began to appear in Germany. By the end of the epidemic, hundreds had become ill, and at least 50 people died. However, by studying this large cluster of cases, much could have been learned about which treatments were optimal; instead, the epidemic ended with little knowledge about how to treat the next outbreak.

The reason for this lack of knowledge is that every doctor treated his or her patients according to their best individual judgment, given the information available to them. However, judgment varies, and treatment varies as a result, leading to different outcomes. Since so little was learned, when future E. coli outbreaks occur, we—and our patients—risk finding ourselves in the same sub-optimal position again. This is the current state of Ebola.

There is a solution to this problem. Medical research has advanced greatly through controlled clinical trials, in which ill persons are randomized to receive one treatment or another, and then outcomes are compared. From such randomized clinical trials has come the knowledge that has improved chemotherapy for nearly all cancers, as well as treatments for HIV infections. The randomized clinical trial minimizes the bias of personal judgment and permits a head-to-head comparison of whether treatment A or B is better.

That's what is needed for Ebola, and for the next epidemic—whatever it is and whenever it comes, which it will. However, regulatory processes are slow and essentially too time-consuming to be able to establish a randomized clinical trial in real-time as an epidemic is unfolding. Therefore, the author proposes a modest solution:

Our health authorities should pre-design a generic randomized clinical trial for acute infectious diseases. The trial design should be well-vetted, and blessed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Food and Drug Administration, the National Institutes of Health, and appropriate ethics committees. When a possible outbreak appears on the horizon, the President, via the Surgeon General, would be empowered to call a public emergency, and the pre-approved generic trial would be launched.

All that would need to be decided at that point is what treatment should constitute A and what should be B. For nailing down treatment approaches, a panel of known experts—say in Ebola virus—should be convened to provide their best judgments. When cases arrive, patients would be immediately offered the possibility of enrollment in the randomized clinical trial.

Since the treatment choices would be the best available, presumably few would refuse, and as data is gathered over time, it would become clear which treatment is more effective, A or B. If it turns out to be B, the panel then asks: Is there a reasonable treatment C? The next trial would then compare B and C, and so on.

This approach would allow us to be continuously learning what works and what does not, and continuously improving treatment. Such a protocol would demonstrate an orderly approach to handling an epidemic, an approach that could be exported to other countries as well. And, of course, anticipation and order are important antidotes to fear.

Let's start now, with Ebola, though rest assured that there will be another epidemic coming our way before too long. And another after that. Let's prepare.

Title: EgyptAir Flight MS804: Debris Found, Search for Black Boxes Continues

Article:

EgyptAir flight MS804, carrying 66 passengers and crew, disappeared from radar screens 230 minutes into a flight from Paris to Cairo on Thursday morning, local time. The aircraft was traveling at an altitude of 11,000 meters (37,000ft) and was 175 miles from the Egyptian coast when it vanished. Debris, including a "body part," two seats, and suitcases, has been found in the Mediterranean Sea, according to Egyptian authorities.

The Airbus A320, which left Paris at 11.09pm on Wednesday (21.09 GMT/07.09am Thursday AEST), was scheduled to land at 3.29am Paris time but disappeared 45 minutes before landing and 40 seconds after entering Egyptian airspace. The plane was carrying 56 passengers and 10 crew, including two babies and one child. The nationalities of the passengers were as follows: 30 Egyptians, 15 French citizens, two Iraqis, one person each from Britain, Belgium, Sudan, Chad, Canada, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Portugal, and Algeria.

The aircraft had passed through airports in Tunisia and Eritrea in the four journeys it made on Wednesday before the Paris-Cairo flight, but no warning flags were raised. EgyptAir's vice-chairman, Ahmed Abdel, said there were "no reported snags" from the crew in Cairo or Paris, nor was there any special cargo or notification of dangerous goods on board.

The area of the Mediterranean where the plane went down is heavily trafficked and monitored, within reach of British listening posts in Cyprus, close to Israel, and near to the US Sixth Fleet. Searches are continuing in the area where the debris was found, with an international air and sea operation underway to find the aircraft's two black box flight recorders, which might hold the key to what happened.

The water in that section of the Mediterranean can be 2,000 meters (6,500ft) deep. The equipment involved in the search for MH370 is able to search depths of at least 6,000 meters. If the EgyptAir A320 is the same as the Germanwings model that crashed last year, it will have two recording components: a cockpit voice recorder, which tapes what the pilots say, and a flight data recorder, which stores some of the 2,500 technical measurements in a modern aircraft. Both are stored at the back of the aircraft and wrapped in titanium or stainless steel, to best survive a crash. They are able to withstand one hour of 1,100C heat and weight of up to 227kg. The boxes can take years to be found – two years in the case of Air France flight 447, which disappeared in 2009 in the Atlantic.

Greece's lead air accident investigator, Athanasios Binis, said, "The most important thing is that the plane's two black boxes are found. If the cockpit flight recorder and flight data recorder are found, along with wreckage, then a real investigation can begin." He added, "There are three reasons for a plane [to go down]. Meteorological, technical, and human. The first has now been ruled out because the weather was quite good. Whether a technical factor or human factor, either inside or outside the plane, is to blame remains to be seen. All possibilities are open."

François Hollande, the French president, said, "We have a duty to know everything about the cause and what has happened. No theory is ruled out and none is certain right now." He added, "When we have the truth we will draw our conclusions; whether this was an accident or something else, perhaps terrorist. We will have the truth."

The Egyptian prime minister, Sherif Ismail, said it was too early to rule out any explanation for the incident, including terrorism. "We can not exclude anything at this time or confirm anything. All the search operations must be concluded so we can know the cause."

Serafeim Petrou, the head of Greece's air traffic controllers board, said, "The plane did not give any vocal or electronic signal before it disappeared," adding that "nothing can be excluded" on causes. "An explosion could be a possibility but, then, so could damage to the fuselage. I think at this point we are talking about wreckage, wreckage at the bottom of the sea, and tracing the cause is going to take time."

Jean-Paul Troadec, the ex-president of the French air accident investigation bureau, said, "We have to remain very careful" about possible causes. "We can make certain hypotheses... there's a strong possibility of an explosion on board from a bomb or a suicide bomber. The idea of a technical accident, when weather conditions were good, seems also possible but not that likely. We could also consider a missile... If the crew didn't send an alert signal, it's because what happened was very sudden. A problem with an engine or a technical fault would not produce an immediate accident. In this case, the crew did not react, which makes us think of a bomb."

The director of Greece's Civil Aviation Authority, Konstantinos Lintzerakos, said air traffic controllers were in contact with the pilot as the plane passed through Greek airspace, and that he did not report any problems. Controllers tried to make contact again with the pilot 10 miles before the flight exited the Greek flight information range, Lintzerakos added, but the pilot did not respond.

Title: Nike Recalls Fourth of July-Themed Shoe Featuring Betsy Ross Flag

Article:

Nike has recalled a Fourth of July-themed sneaker featuring the Betsy Ross flag, following controversy over the symbol's historical association with slavery. The controversy arose after Nike announced the new shoe, which was adorned with the Betsy Ross flag on the heel, and shipped to stores.

According to reports, the decision to recall the shoe was made at the request of Colin Kaepernick, former NFL football player and current Nike representative. A Nike spokesperson stated, "Nike has chosen not to release the Air Max 1 Quick Strike Fourth of July as it featured the old version of the American flag."

The Betsy Ross flag, which features 13 stars in a circle on a field of white and red stripes, has been a symbol of American folklore, representing the 13 original colonies. However, some argue that the flag has been co-opted by white nationalists, leading to calls for its removal from public spaces and products.

The controversy over the Betsy Ross flag has sparked debate over the appropriateness of using national or civic symbols that have been associated with racist ideologies. Some argue that these symbols should not be ceded to racists, while others argue that they should be reclaimed as symbols of American history and values.

It is worth noting that the historical accuracy of Betsy Ross's role in designing the flag is a matter of dispute. The Washington Post reports that there is little evidence to support assertions by her descendants that she was a national heroine in the 1870s.

The decision to recall the Nike shoe has sparked backlash, particularly among those on the right. Arizona Governor Doug Ducey announced that he is canceling incentives the state had offered Nike to build a plant there. Ducey stated, "Instead of celebrating American history the week of our nation's independence, Nike has apparently decided that Betsy Ross is unworthy, and has bowed to the current onslaught of political correctness and historical revisionism."

Title: Ben Carson Accuses CNN of 'Smear Campaign' Over Inquiry into Violent Childhood Incidents

Article:

In a heated interview on CNN's 'New Day' on Friday, former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson repeatedly criticized recent inquiries into his violent childhood as "pathetic" and accused host Alisyn Camerota of leading a "smear campaign."

On Thursday, CNN reported that it was unable to corroborate any of Carson's past accounts, including claims he once punched a classmate and stabbed another. According to CNN, at least nine of Carson's childhood classmates had no recollection of events as described by Carson.

When Camerota asked Carson about CNN's report, a visibly frustrated Carson raised his voice from a whisper to a more forceful inside voice.

"This is a bunch of lies attempting to say I'm lying about my history, I think it's pathetic," Carson responded. "Basically, what the media does is they try to get you distracted."

Carson also addressed specific discrepancies, namely why the CNN reporters who traveled to Detroit were unable to identify any of his past victims.

"The names I used for instance are fictitious names because I do not want to bring people into something like this because I know what you guys do to their lives," Carson explained. "That's not the real name, but yes he's a very real person. I talked to him yesterday."

Carson also defended his changing of the name and relation of the young man he claimed to have stabbed as an adolescent, stating that he used fictitious names to protect the individuals' privacy.

The interview became increasingly contentious as Camerota pressed Carson on his complaints of media bias, with Carson accusing CNN of participating in a "longstanding journalistic practice of vetting presidential candidates."

Carson also faced questions about a 2014 speech during which he said "we'd be Cuba if there were no Fox News," and joked that some Americans are "stupid." When Camerota attempted to clarify which Americans he was describing as "stupid," Carson became defensive and refused to provide a clear answer.

Immediately after the contentious interview, Carson appeared on Breitbart News' Sirius XM radio program to continue his attack on the media.

"I am going to fight CNN tooth and nail," Carson said. "They will see, believe me, they will see."

Carson also accused CNN of coming from a place of falsehood, while he claimed to be coming from a place of truth.

"Truth always wins," Carson added.

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Avoids Addressing Allegations of Anti-Semitism in Women's March Movement

Article:

During a demonstration with a Women's March group near Central Park, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) was confronted about the growing issue of alleged anti-Semitism within the Women's March movement. Instead of addressing the concerns, Ocasio-Cortez shifted the focus to the Trump administration, claiming, without providing evidence, that the White House has an anti-Semitism problem.

In a separate incident, right-wing activist Laura Loomer confronted Ocasio-Cortez, asking, "Why are you standing with people who openly support Hamas, a terrorist organization that kills Jewish people?"

Ocasio-Cortez neither addressed the allegations of anti-Semitism within the Women's March movement nor denounced the alleged anti-Semitic sentiments among its members. The Women's March movement has been embroiled in a scandal over allegations of anti-Semitism, including support for Louis Farrakhan, the removal of Jewish leaders, and co-president Tamika Mallory's refusal to affirm Israel's right to exist. The Democratic National Committee and Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-Fla.) are among those who have cut ties with the organization due to these allegations.

Title: Trump Establishes White House Faith-Based Initiative to Protect Religious Freedom

Article:

In observance of the National Day of Prayer, President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday, establishing a new White House faith-based initiative to safeguard religious freedom.

Addressing faith leaders in the White House Rose Garden, President Trump stated, "As president, I will always protect religious liberty. Prayer has always been the center of American life. It's forged the identity and destiny of this great nation that we all love." Vice President Mike Pence added, "The American people believe in prayer."

The faith initiative aims to enable individuals to exercise their beliefs freely and provide equal access to government funding for faith-based organizations. The executive order calls for the executive branch to uphold "conscience protections" that allow people and institutions to practice their faith without fear of discrimination or retaliation by the federal government.

The order states, "It shall be the policy of the executive branch to vigorously enforce Federal law's robust protections for religious freedom." It also directs the Treasury Department not to target churches or religious groups for speaking about political issues.

Johnnie Moore, an unofficial spokesman for the president's faith advisors, praised the move, stating, "This executive order is the product of the President's unwavering prioritization of faith and religious liberty and reflects the smart work of people like Jared Kushner and advisors in the policy and public liaison divisions who met with hundreds and hundreds of leaders and government officials to assess ways in which the government can partner more effectively with communities of faith."

Evangelist Franklin Graham and California pastor and evangelist Greg Laurie also expressed support for the new initiative. However, Michael Wear, an author and former Obama White House staffer, expressed cautious optimism, stating, "It remains to be seen whether this Administration is truly interested in building an initiative that is focused on helping diverse faith communities serve those in need, or if the real value they see is in using the office as a platform where elite political supporters can pose as statesmen."

The White House Office of Faith-Based Neighborhood Partnerships was initiated by President George W. Bush in 2001. Under President Barack Obama, Joshua DuBois established an advisory council where members were appointed to one-year terms. The National Day of Prayer is held on the first Thursday of May, and this year's theme is "unity in America."

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Accuses Hillary Clinton of Defamation Over 'Russian Asset' Claim

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii has accused former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton of defamation over a statement that implied Gabbard was a Russian asset. In a letter from the Gabbard campaign's legal counsel, the campaign insists that Gabbard is not a Russian asset and that Clinton knew the statement was untrue when she made it.

The letter, part of Gabbard's continuing pushback, was issued in response to Clinton's appearance on the podcast Campaign HQ with David Plouffe on Oct. 17. During the conversation, Clinton said, "I'm not making any predictions, but I think they've got their eye on somebody who is currently in the Democratic primary and are grooming her to be the third-party candidate. She's the favorite of the Russians. They have a bunch of sites and bots and other ways of supporting her so far. And, that's assuming Jill Stein will give it up, which she might not because she's also a Russian asset. Yeah, she's a Russian asset. I mean, totally."

The following day, a CNN reporter asked a Clinton spokesperson if Clinton was talking about Gabbard, to which the spokesperson replied, "If the nesting doll fits." This implied that the statement was indeed about Gabbard.

The Gabbard campaign's letter further states that Gabbard is "a patriotic loyal American, a sitting four-term United States Congresswoman and a Major in the United States Army National Guard" and that "she is a loyal American who has taken an oath declaring her allegiance to the United States of America both as a soldier and as a member of Congress."

Early reports about Clinton's comments suggested that the former secretary of state meant that Gabbard was being groomed to be a third-party candidate by Russians, but it was later clarified that she was referring to Republicans. The Gabbard campaign's letter accused Clinton of putting a "spin" on the statement to avoid liability.

"This Republicans-not-Russians spin developed only after you realized the defamatory nature of your statement, and therefore your legal liability, as well as the full extent of the public backlash against your statement," the letter said. "Moreover, the Republicans-not-Russians spin can not explain away your statement that Congresswoman Gabbard is 'a Russian asset,'" it continued. "That is, of course, because your Republicans-not-Russians spin is rubbish."

Gabbard has gone on record stating she has no intention of running as a third-party candidate if she fails to win the Democratic nomination. The letter concluded by presenting a statement for Clinton to post on her Twitter account and send to major media outlets, apologizing. The proposed statement would say that she "was wrong," made a "grave mistake and error in judgment," and that she "supports" and "admires" Gabbard's work. The letter also demanded that Clinton "immediately" hold a press conference to make a verbal retraction of her past statement.

Fox News reached out to the Gabbard campaign asking if the congresswoman intends to sue if Clinton does not meet these demands, but they did not immediately respond.

Title: Trump to Sign Executive Order Imposing Sanctions on Foreign Entities Interfering in U.S. Elections

Article:

President Donald Trump is planning to sign an executive order as early as Wednesday, which will impose sanctions on foreign companies or individuals found to be interfering in U.S. elections based on intelligence agency findings, according to two sources familiar with the matter. This move comes as intelligence agencies, military, and law enforcement prepare to defend the upcoming November 6 congressional elections from predicted foreign attacks.

The executive order's targets could include individuals or entire companies accused of interfering in U.S. elections through cyber attacks or other means, a U.S. official told the sources. The order is intended to establish new norms in cyberspace and set boundaries for bad behavior, the official stated.

The order will place a range of agencies in charge of deciding if election meddling has occurred, led by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and including the CIA, the National Security Agency, and the Homeland Security Department, according to the sources. A recent draft of the order reviewed by a U.S. official defines election interference as hacking attempts against "election infrastructure" and efforts to sway public opinion through coordinated digital propaganda or systematic leaks of private political information.

U.S. intelligence officials have found that Russian hackers breached the Democratic National Committee and leaked confidential information during the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Congress has been purposefully left out of the executive order drafting process, the official said, as the administration wants to preempt legislation being considered in the House and Senate that addresses similar issues.

Congress has introduced various pieces of Russia-related legislation, including the "Deter Act" to set out punishments for election meddling, and a sanctions bill aimed at punishing Moscow for cybercrime and its activities in Syria, Ukraine, and elsewhere. Both Democrats and Republicans are looking to address what they consider Trump's weak stance on accusations of Russian interference in 2016, following Trump's meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin at a summit in July, during which Trump accepted Putin's denials over the word of his own intelligence agencies.

Acting on a Russia sanctions bill passed more than a year ago, the U.S. Treasury imposed major sanctions against 24 Russians, striking at allies of Putin in one of Washington's most aggressive moves to punish Moscow.

Title: "Civility in Politics: A Growing Movement Toward Common Ground and Constructive Dialogue"

Article:

In the wake of the contentious Kavanaugh hearings and subsequent debates, a growing concern for the state of civility in American politics has emerged. A recent Axios poll found that more than half of Americans have discussed the Kavanaugh confirmation battle at work, and almost three-quarters of Americans have talked about it with friends and family. Surprisingly, over three-quarters of Americans say their discussions about the Supreme Court appointee have been civil.

This finding is in stark contrast to an annual poll tracking discourse in the United States, where 93 percent of Americans think the U.S. has a civility problem. The percentage of Americans viewing the opposite party unfavorably has doubled in the last two decades, and 86 percent of Americans say conflicts between Democrats and Republicans are strong or very strong.

The lack of civility in politics has been a topic of concern for notable figures across the political spectrum. Michelle Obama, in a recent speech at a voter registration rally in Las Vegas, expressed her disdain for the "nastiness of our politics." Senator Jeff Flake (R-AZ) during the Kavanaugh hearings expressed his concern over tribalism, stating that it is "tearing our country apart."

In the Virginia Senate race, a Republican challenger pledged a "vicious, ruthless campaign" to unseat the Democrat incumbent, implying without evidence that his opponent committed sexual assault. A Democratic representative from California warned members of Donald Trump's Cabinet to be prepared for an onslaught of heckling and public shaming if they continue to support the president's policy on undocumented immigrants.

To address this issue, individuals and organizations are advocating for a shift in the default model for public discourse from fact-light, talking-point-based, and anger-laced argument to willingly seeking and finding common ground with the other side. Elected officials who demonstrate a willingness to work with those with different political views should be supported, and candidates who speak out against speech and policies designed to divide us should be chosen.

Organizations such as the Common Ground Committee, Living Room Conversations, Better Angels, and The Bridge Alliance are working to remove the threat of incivility and promote constructive dialogue. These organizations stress listening, accepting nuances, putting country before self-interest, and asking Americans with varying political beliefs and backgrounds to do the same.

The Common Ground Committee, for example, brings prominent leaders with opposing views together in public forums to find common ground. After the "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, Donna Brazile (former interim DNC chairwoman) and Michael Steele (former RNC chairman) participated in a CGC public forum to discuss government's role in bridging racial divides. Brazile and Steele engaged with respect and a sense of conviction that we can all move beyond deep, destructive tribalism.

In conclusion, the growing movement for civil discourse, finding common ground, and focusing on solutions rather than arguments is a positive step towards reducing toxic polarization and evoking civil dialogue. By demonstrating the value and power of civil discourse, we can shift the cultural norm from winning at all costs to finding common ground whenever possible. This will allow our leaders to make progress quicker and more frequently on the issues that matter.

Title: Majority of Voters Favor Repeal of Obamacare, Poll Finds

Article:

A new poll conducted by Fox News indicates that more than half of registered voters would vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, if given the opportunity. The survey, which polled 1,017 voters nationwide from July 21-23, found that 53 percent of respondents would vote to repeal the law, while 40 percent would vote to keep it.

The poll also revealed that 47 percent of respondents believe Obamacare will cost their family more money, while 34 percent said their healthcare costs would remain the same. The expectation of increased healthcare costs comes at a time when 63 percent of the public is dissatisfied with the current state of the country, and 57 percent report seeing no signs of economic recovery.

The poll's findings show a significant divide along party lines. Seventy percent of Republicans believe Obamacare will cost them more, while 21 percent of Democrats believe it will save them money. A large percentage of Republicans (85 percent) and independents (65 percent) also expressed a desire to repeal the law, compared to 72 percent of Democrats who said it is worth keeping.

Regarding the White House's decision to delay the employer mandate on coverage for a year, 45 percent of respondents overall found it "unacceptable," while 46 percent described it as "no big deal." Seventy-one percent of Democrats said they were fine with the decision, while 68 percent of Republicans and 55 percent of independents disagreed with the decision to delay.

The survey also asked participants if the "Medical Loss Ratio" portion of the healthcare law had returned any savings to them in the form of refunds on some of their premium costs. Only 8 percent of respondents reported that this part of the law, which limits the amount insurance companies can spend on administrative functions, had already saved them money.

Title: DOJ Sides with District Court Ruling, Argues for Full ACA Invalidity

Article:

The Department of Justice (DOJ) has announced its support for a district court ruling that declared the Affordable Care Act (ACA) unconstitutional. This move escalates the Trump administration's legal battle against the health care law.

In the past, the DOJ argued that the ACA's pre-existing condition protections should be struck down. Now, the administration argues that the entire law should be invalidated. U.S. District Judge Reed O'Connor ruled in December that the ACA's individual mandate is unconstitutional, and the rest of the law is therefore invalid.

The DOJ stated on Monday that it agrees the decision should stand as the case works its way through the appeals process in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit. "The Department of Justice has determined that the district court’s judgment should be affirmed," the department said in a short letter to the appeals court.

The move is likely to prompt new denunciations from Democrats, who had already criticized the Trump administration's earlier call for the pre-existing condition protections to be struck down. This stance was a major issue in last year's midterm elections, and many Republican candidates in tough races struggled with whether to say they agreed with the Trump administration's position.

The lawsuit, which was brought by 20 GOP-led states, centers on the argument that since Congress repealed the tax penalty in the ACA's mandate for everyone to have insurance in 2017, the mandate can no longer be ruled constitutional under Congress's power to tax. The challengers then argue that all of ObamaCare should be invalidated because the mandate is unconstitutional.

Most legal experts say that, according to legal precedent, even if the mandate is ruled unconstitutional, the rest of ObamaCare should remain unharmed, as that is what Congress voted to do in the 2017 tax law that repealed the mandate's penalty. This report was contributed by Justin Wise and was updated on March 26 at 5:50 a.m.

Title: Tulsa Police Officer Acquitted in Shooting of Terence Crutcher

Article:

On September 16, 2016, Terence Crutcher, a 40-year-old motorist, was shot and killed by police officer Betty Jo Shelby in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The shooting led to protests in Tulsa. On May 17, 2017, a jury found Shelby not guilty of first-degree manslaughter.

Terence Crutcher, a black man, was enrolled at Tulsa Community College and was a father. The officers involved in the incident were Betty Shelby and Tyler Turnbough, both white. The shooting occurred on 36th Street North and Lewis Avenue, Tulsa, Oklahoma, with coordinates 36°12'22.1'' N 95°57'34.6'' W.

At 7:36 p.m. on September 16, 2016, police received a 9-1-1 call about an abandoned vehicle in the middle of 36th Street North just west of Lewis Avenue. One caller said that the vehicle was blocking traffic, and another said that a man was running from the vehicle, saying it was going to blow up but might have been under the influence of drugs.

Police stated that Crutcher kept reaching into his pocket, refused to show his hands, walked towards his vehicle despite being told to stop, and then angled towards and reached into his vehicle. Critics have disputed this, stating that the driver's side window was up when Crutcher was shot. Turnbough tased Crutcher, and Shelby shot him.

Approximately two minutes after the shooting, an officer checked Crutcher's pockets, and approximately 45 seconds later, someone crouched to offer aid. Police said Crutcher died in the hospital later that day. Tulsa police chief Chuck Jordan said no weapon was recovered from Crutcher's body or vehicle.

Police dashcam and helicopter video as well as the dispatch audio were released by police on September 19, 2016. Tulsa Police Chief Chuck Jordan called the video "disturbing" and "difficult to watch." The officers involved were placed on paid administrative leave.

Crutcher's family, protestors, and the American Civil Liberties Union of Oklahoma called for Shelby to be charged with his death. Autopsy results released by the Oklahoma State Medical Examiner indicated that Crutcher had "acute phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication" at the time of the shooting. The report also indicated that tenocyclidine (TCP), a psychostimulant and hallucinogen which is more potent than PCP, was present.

Criminal charges, trial, and acquittal of police officer

Tulsa County District Attorney Steve Kunzweiler charged Shelby with first-degree manslaughter. On May 17, 2017, a jury found Betty Shelby not guilty. Betty Shelby then later quit the Tulsa Police Department and became a Rogers County, Oklahoma Sheriff's Deputy.

Title: College Commencement Ceremonies Divided by Identity Politics: A Look at the Controversial Trend of Separate Graduation Events

Article:

During the commencement season, young people across the country celebrate the completion of their college careers, marking their interest in various fields such as ideas, innovation, art, and sciences. However, the camaraderie inherent in the college experience is under attack by a divisive tool known as identity politics. This divisive strategy is creating divisions in the very experience that is meant to expand one's worldview and sense of belonging.

College is intended to be a transition into adulthood, a shift from living with parents to living independently and encountering people different from oneself. The intention is not only to receive an education from books but also to expand one's understanding of the world beyond oneself.

Recently, there has been a growing concern that the obsession with identity politics and the division it brings has overwhelmed the academy. The leftist strategy of promoting self-regard, otherness, suspicion, and division is taking root in the very institutions that are meant to encourage students to look outside the known, enter the unknown, and make it better with their presence.

A study by the National Association of Scholars indicates that at least 75 American colleges have black-only graduation ceremonies, and 43 percent of surveyed colleges offer segregated residential halls. The organization refers to this as 'neo-segregation.'

In 2017, Harvard University held a separate commencement ceremony for African American graduates, which made national news. The New York Times had a headline that read, "Colleges Celebrate Diversity with Separate Commencements." In this coverage, the newspaper noted that the event was Harvard's first commencement for black graduate students, and many of the speakers talked about a different, more personal kind of struggle, the struggle to be black at Harvard.

An organizer of Harvard's separate graduation ceremony told The Associated Press, "We really wanted an opportunity to give voice to the voiceless at Harvard. So many students identify with the African diaspora but don't necessarily feel welcome as part of the larger community, and they don't feel like their stories are being shared."

The argument for the separate event is that the Ivy League university they've attended for years does not accept them and has racial issues. The answer to that, according to proponents of the separate-but-equal commencement events, is a segregated commencement event, as they are leaving the university, reinforcing the perception they don't feel, or aren't, accepted.

In any institution involving thousands of people, there will be aspects of racism, sexism, and homophobia. A valuable aspect of a diverse community is that these issues can be confronted and challenged, as part of that community.

Those who laud the separate-but-equal commencement events argue that college students have always associated based on interest and affinities. This is true - there are debate clubs, political science societies, drama leagues, language clubs, etc. In some campus housing, you find people choosing floors that also reflect similar interests like language, math, art history, engineering, or architecture.

Coming together in association based on intellectual affinity transcends political partisanship, race, sex, and gender. These leagues are based on ideas and interests, not on slivers of our identities and therefore do not require the exclusion of people because of what they look like or who they love.

Ward Connerly, president of the American Civil Rights Institute and a former University of California regent, explained to The Times that events like black commencements "serve only to 'amplify' racial differences. 'College is the place where we should be teaching and preaching the view that you're an individual, and choose your associates to be based on other factors rather than skin color,' he said."

However, the left's scourge of identity politics requires division and otherness; it is a premise requiring the view of people unlike yourself as unknowable and unrelatable, and therefore that you, too, are unknowable and relatable.

Being understood through empathy and the common experience, in these cases, of being a student at Harvard, is what would normally bring people together. Differences in life experience, home life, and interests make friendships and relationships even more interesting and valuable.

This is how people's lives and points of view are changed and improved. This is how communities are built and thrive. And it is exactly what threatens the reliance on division, suspicion, and hate that the left relies on to organize and control people.

The heart of the American experience, relationships, empathy, and understanding, and becoming united with people unlike yourself, is the existential threat to the left and to their political narrative, and it is why the left remains obsessed with conditioning people into accepting the dangerous fraud of identity politics.

Title: Obama Suggests Iraqi Political Action Key to Defeating Islamic State

Article:

President Barack Obama reiterated on Monday his stance that the United States has yet to develop a comprehensive strategy for defeating the Islamic State (IS), a position that has drawn criticism in the past. However, during a press conference in Germany, he offered some insights into his statement, suggesting that the U.S. is withholding its commitments to Iraq to pressure the government to take the political steps necessary for any anti-IS strategy to succeed.

A "complete strategy... requires commitments on the part of the Iraqis as well," Mr. Obama said, speaking at a press conference wrapping up a two-day summit of the Group of Seven industrialized Western countries. The Iraqi government, he added, must establish "how recruitment takes place, how that training takes place."

At the same time, Obama emphasized that Iraq must take steps to build an "inclusive" government that serves Iraq's Shiite, Sunni, and Kurd communities equally. "If Sunnis, Kurds, and Shia all feel as if their concerns are being addressed, and that operating within a legitimate political structure can meet their need for security, prosperity, nondiscrimination, then we ’ll have a much easier time," he said.

Earlier in the day, the president met with Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, who was invited to the Western-powers confab to review the anti-IS battle and to present his case for more international assistance.

Obama alluded to the reluctance of the Shiite-dominated government in Baghdad to enlist and arm Sunnis in the country's security forces as an impediment to a successful campaign against IS. Noting that, at the moment, there is actually more training capacity in Iraq than recruits coming forward to be trained, he said, "A big part of the answer there is our outreach to Sunni tribes.... It has not been happening as fast as it needs to."

The U.S. has encouraged Iraq to create a national guard as a means of facilitating the creation of local security forces and the arming of Sunni tribes, but legislation to that effect has languished for months.

The president did not absolve the U.S. and other countries of responsibility for the setbacks Iraq has experienced in the fight with IS, noting in particular that neighboring and Western countries have failed to stem the flow of foreign fighters into Iraq and Syria.

The international effort to address the influx of foreign fighters seeking to fight for IS – an effort Obama launched last September with a special session of the United Nations Security Council – has "made some progress, but not enough," he said.

The U.S. and European countries have to do a better job of stopping their citizens who aim to join the ranks of IS, but he also singled out Turkey for failing to adequately control its border with Syria – the border that most foreign fighters cross to join IS.

"If we can cut off some of that foreign fighter flow, then we are able to isolate and wear out ISIL forces that are already there," Obama said, using the acronym for IS that the U.S. government prefers. "We are taking a lot of them off the battlefield," he added, "but if they’re being replenished, then it doesn’t solve the problem over the long term."

Obama made the "no complete strategy" comment last August, when he said the administration had to consult with Congress and foreign partners who would be called on to join an anti-IS coalition before formulating a plan to "degrade and ultimately destroy" IS.

"I don’t want to put the cart before the horse," he said then. "We don’t have a strategy yet."

Obama's suggestion nearly a year later that the formulation of a "complete strategy" is being held up at least to some degree by a lack of Iraqi political action does not appear to have satisfied all the president's critics.

"What has President Obama been doing for 10 months?" Republican National Committee spokesman Michael Short said in response to the president's comments sent out to reporters.

"Nearly a year after first saying he didn’t have a strategy to combat ISIS," said Mr. Short, using another acronym for IS, "President Obama again today said there is still not a complete strategy to take on the terrorist group."

However, some regional analysts heard Obama's comment as a warning to the Iraqi government – and principally to Prime Minister Abadi – that receiving stepped-up assistance depends on their political actions.

"This was very definitely aimed at Abadi and the Iraqis," says Lawrence Korb, a senior national security fellow at the Center for American Progress in Washington and a former Pentagon official. "It was meant to send him a message to get going and do some of the things we think are holding up progress" against IS.

The White House saw in Abadi "a more inclusive leader" than Nouri al-Maliki, the Shiite hard-liner he replaced, but has since realized that Abadi is either unwilling or politically unable to draw in a suspicious Sunni community, Mr. Korb says.

Title: Biden's Critique of English Jurisprudential Culture at Biden Courage Awards Sparks Controversy

Article:

Last week, former Vice President Joe Biden spoke at the Biden Courage Awards ceremony in preparation for his presidential campaign launch. In his speech, Biden criticized a central pillar of Western civilization, claiming that English jurisprudential culture is inherently racist.

Biden's statement, according to historians and legal scholars, is historically inaccurate. The "rule of thumb" story, which Biden referenced, has been debunked for years. There was no "rule of thumb," as feminist scholar Christina Hoff Sommers points out. "On the contrary," she writes, "British law since the 1700s and our American laws predating the Revolution prohibit wife beating."

Moreover, Biden's characterization of "English jurisprudential culture" as "white man's culture" is profoundly disturbing. English jurisprudential culture is rooted in the belief in the rule of law, due process of law, and equal rights under law. English jurisprudential culture is responsible for preserving the natural rights we hold dear, rights which were imperfectly but increasingly extended over time to more and more human beings, particularly minorities.

In 2009, former President Barack Obama, a leftist figure, explained that he sought a system at Guantanamo Bay that "adheres to the rule of law, habeas corpus, basic principles of Anglo-American legal system." Protection of individual rights, and in particular, minority rights, lies at the heart of English jurisprudence.

Biden's reduction of those rights to racial privilege is both false and frightening. It suggests that those principles ought to be undermined for purposes of disestablishing a supposed racial hierarchy. Get rid of English jurisprudential law, presumably, in order to fight racism.
