Ironically, the reduction of Western civilization to racial supremacy is not just a strategy of the intersectional left; it's a strategy of the despicable alt-right, which champions Western civilization as white civilization and then seeks to rip away the universalism of its principles from nonwhite people. Thus, the very term "Western civilization" is under assault by a variety of political forces seeking to tear out eternal truths and natural rights in the name of tribalism.

However, that's not what Western civilization is about at all. Western civilization was built on Judeo-Christian values and Greek reason, culminating in a perspective on natural rights that is preserved by institutions like English jurisprudence. It is thanks to those philosophical principles that free markets, free speech, and free association have grown and flourished. Only if we re-enshrine those principles, rather than undermine them, will our prosperity and freedoms be preserved.

Title: Rising Veterans' Disability Payments and the Impact on Employment

Article:

The United States government provides disability payments to veterans, separate from medical costs associated with treating an injury. These payments are set at varying levels to compensate for an assumed inability to work. Since 2000, the average payout has increased by 60 percent (inflation-adjusted), and the proportion of veterans receiving some form of compensation has nearly doubled.

While most veterans who receive disability checks are genuinely in need, there is a perception that the system can be manipulated. Claiming the right combination of symptoms, regardless of actual suffering, can potentially lead to a monthly, tax-free disability check for life. There are even blogs available to guide individuals through the process of claiming an injury that may be difficult to disprove.

In some cases, the process requires minimal effort. A veteran who left the Navy in 2005, for example, filled out a form and underwent a medical exam to document a fractured shoulder sustained in the line of duty. Soon after, they received a rating and their first monthly direct-deposit payment.

The veteran, feeling no entitlement beyond medical care, attempted to discontinue the payment but was informed that there was no process for doing so. The ability to hold a full-time job had no bearing on their disability rating.

As a nation, we have a duty to care for those who have fought our battles. However, the current disability-compensation regime warrants closer scrutiny, not only for financial prudence but also to avoid fostering a culture of dependency. A recent study by Mark Duggan, an economist at Stanford, linked rising disability payments to increased unemployment among veterans. The author suggests that such payments may reduce the "recipient's propensity to work" because disability checks eliminate the need for a job.

Title: Republican Party's Shift Away from Free Trade Principles

Article:

The Republican Party, traditionally known for its adherence to free market principles, appears to be abandoning its commitment to free trade in favor of protectionist policies, particularly under the Trump administration.

During the 2016 presidential campaign, then-candidate Donald Trump's frequent criticisms of trade and trade agreements influenced other Republican candidates, such as Sens. Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, to advocate for "fair" trade, a term often associated with protectionism.

Since taking office, President Trump has pursued a comprehensive protectionist agenda, threatening foreign governments with a potential trade war and imposing tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from various countries, including the European Union, Canada, and Mexico. These tariffs may be followed by automobile tariffs. Trump justifies these actions by claiming that imports from these countries "threaten to impair the national security" of the United States, despite six of the top 10 providers of steel to the U.S. being NATO allies.

In response to this diplomatic backlash and potential negative economic impact, Republicans in Congress have taken no action. This inaction is not due to a lack of power, but rather a lack of political will. They could pass legislation to reverse the imposition of tariffs or reclaim some of the authority they delegated to the president to impose tariffs, as suggested by Sens. Mike Lee and Ron Johnson.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, in recent appearances on Sunday shows, argued that tariffs on European and Canadian imports are necessary for the sake of free trade and that they represent the United States "standing up for the process." However, these arguments are misleading.

Imposing tariffs is unlikely to persuade other countries to lower their own tariffs, as McCarthy suggests. Historically, the United States has encouraged other countries to lower their trade barriers by being decisively pro-free trade. Leading by protectionism will only lead to more protectionism.

Furthermore, these tariffs will increase the cost of producing goods made with steel within the United States, making it more difficult for U.S. manufacturers to compete with foreigners who make goods out of steel without the added cost of tariffs. This will result in lost U.S. manufacturing jobs.

McCarthy's claim that the Trump administration is "standing up for the process" through tariffs is also misleading. The national security argument is questionable when levying tariffs against NATO allies. In fact, during a U.S. Department of Commerce investigation, the Department of Defense wrote a letter stating that no tariffs were needed to protect national security, as the DOD's military needs are fulfilled by only 3% of the domestic steel production.

The potential dangers of Trump's move will become clear when those former allies drag the U.S. before the World Trade Organization and the U.S. loses, as experts predict. Many have long surmised that the Republican Party stands for little more than low taxes, but its commitment to free trade, a traditionally Republican principle, is waning.

Title: Trump Administration's Border Separation Policy Faces Criticism as Optics Issue

Article:

The Trump administration's policy of separating children from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border has faced criticism this week, with some calling it inhumane and unacceptable. The policy, which has been criticized for its "optics," or public perception, may lead to a reevaluation of the current approach.

Senator Jeff Merkley (D-OR) provided an example of the rhetoric surrounding the issue, stating, "Ripping children out of their parents' arms to inflict harm on the child to influence the parents is unacceptable."

Former First Lady Laura Bush also weighed in, writing in a Washington Post column that the policy is "cruel." First Lady Melania Trump herself expressed dismay, stating in a formal statement that she "hates to see children separated from their families" and urges "successful immigration reform."

The policy has been a contentious issue, with some arguing that it is necessary to enforce immigration laws, while others argue that it is inhumane. It is important to note that an illegal entrant into the United States brings no rights with them, and they are dependent on the kindness of strangers.

The matter is complex, with valid arguments for and against laxity on immigration. The policy has sparked international concern and sympathy for the families affected, with many questioning the morality of separating children from their parents.

It is unclear what the future holds for the policy, as both sides of the argument have valid points. Some argue for strong and persuasive vetting of prospective immigrants, while others argue that America's shrinking workforce needs more workers and contributors to Social Security and Medicare.

It is likely that both Republicans and Democrats take aboard these seemingly opposed considerations, but are obliged by the politics of the moment to tear out each other's throats. The policy is not just about children being separated from their parents, but about human destiny and the kind of country we hope to be 50 years hence. There are no winners in this cause at present.

Title: Polls and Fundraising Suggest Disastrous Election Outcome for Republicans

Article:

With less than 100 days remaining before the 2020 election, recent polls and fundraising data suggest a potentially disastrous outcome for the Republican party.

According to a new Washington Post-ABC News poll, only 38% of Americans approve of President Donald Trump's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, while 60% disapprove. In a similar poll conducted in March, 51% approved of Trump's handling of the pandemic, with 45% disapproving.

The shift in public opinion towards Trump's handling of the pandemic has coincided with a move towards Joe Biden in general election polling. The former vice president currently leads Trump by 15 and 11 points in two new national polls released this week.

In addition to the shift in public opinion towards Trump, Democrats have also seen a significant increase in party identification. According to a new Gallup poll, 50% of Americans identify as Democrats or Democratic leaners, while 39% describe themselves as Republicans or Republican leaners. This represents a major shift from January, when Republicans had a 47% to 45% edge on party identification in Gallup polling.

Furthermore, Democratic candidates in the 11 most competitive Senate contests in the country raised a collective $67.3 million between April 1 and June 30, compared to $46.8 million for their Republican counterparts, according to tabulations made by the Wall Street Journal. The same trend is seen in the House, where Democratic candidates raised $457 million in the second quarter of 2020, compared to $365 million for Republican candidates.

According to the Center for Responsive Politics, the fundraising difference is even larger in swing districts currently held by well-funded Democratic incumbents. In 13 races holding primaries in June and July that are considered competitive by the Cook Political Report, incumbent Democrats have 9 times more money in the bank than the best-funded Republican challengers.

On Friday, the Cook Political Report moved 20 House races in favor of Democrats, an unprecedented shift to one party. As House editor David Wasserman wrote, "President Trump's abysmal polling since the pandemic began is seriously jeopardizing down-ballot GOP fortunes. We may be approaching the point at which dozens of House Republicans will need to decide whether to cut the president loose and run on a 'check and balance' message, offering voters insurance against congressional Democrats moving too far left under a potential Biden administration."

The Senate has also been in play for at least nine months, but Democratic chances of winning control of the chamber have improved significantly in the last few weeks. According to the Cook Report, Democrats need a net gain of four seats for a majority, but can control the Senate by gaining three seats and winning the White House. With less than four months to go before Election Day, the most likely outcome is a Democratic net gain of 3-5 Senate seats.

On the presidential level, Trump is in equally bad shape. The Cook Report gives Biden 279 electoral votes in the solid, likely, or leaning Democrat categories, as compared to just 188 for Trump. This week, the University of Virginia's Crystal Ball moved seven traditional Republican strongholds from safe Republican states to likely Republican states and into the slate of potential competitive races in the presidential race.

"Trump is extremely unlikely to win if the polls continue to look the way they do now," the Cook Report notes. "And if these numbers represent a new normal, we need to account for the possibility that this election won't be particularly close, and that new states may come into play. In other words, if the national picture remains bleak for Trump, then the slippage he's seen from earlier this year wouldn't just be limited to a handful of swing states."

Title: Dr. Ben Carson Steps Down as Johns Hopkins School of Medicine Commencement Speaker Following Controversial Remarks

Article:

Neurosurgeon Dr. Ben Carson has stepped down as commencement speaker at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine following a backlash over controversial comments regarding same-sex marriage. In a letter to Dean Paul Rothman, Carson wrote that the national media attention surrounding his traditional marriage beliefs would be best for the students if he voluntarily withdrew as the commencement speaker this year.

Carson's controversial remarks were made during his March 26 appearance on Fox News' Hannity. He compared efforts to overturn bans on same-sex marriage to those advocating for bestiality and the North American Man-Boy Love Association (NAMBLA).

The backlash led to a student-led petition for Carson's removal as commencement speaker, with more than half of the graduating class reportedly signing it. Carson was also criticized by colleagues at Johns Hopkins who found his comments "hurtful" and "extremely discouraging."

In a statement to a news outlet, the co-director of Johns Hopkins University's Program for the Study of Women, Gender, and Sexuality, Professor Todd Shepard, described Carson's statements as "nasty, petty, and ill-informed." Carson eventually apologized for his comments, but later called his critics "racists."

Carson has previously written that marriage equality could lead to the fall of America like the "fall of the Roman Empire." As of April 2, Carson was scheduled to give the keynote address at a banquet hosted by the Illinois Family Institute, an anti-gay hate group.

According to the Baltimore Sun, Carson also stepped down as speaker for the Johns Hopkins University School of Education diploma ceremony. New speakers have not been chosen for either commencement address.

Title: Felicity Huffman Sentenced to 14 Days in Prison for College Admissions Scam

 Article:

 Actress Felicity Huffman, known for her role in the television series "Desperate Housewives," has been sentenced to 14 days in prison for her involvement in the "Varsity Blues" college entrance scam. The sentence also includes a $30,000 fine, 250 hours of community service, and one year of probation.

 Huffman, 56, is due to self-report to a federal prison facility on October 25. In a statement issued shortly after the sentencing, Huffman accepted the judge's decision and expressed remorse for her actions.

 "I accept the court's decision today without reservation," Huffman said in the statement. "I have always been prepared to accept whatever punishment Judge Talwani imposed. I broke the law. I have admitted that and I pleaded guilty to this crime. There are no excuses or justifications for my actions. Period."

 Huffman also apologized to her daughter, her husband, her family, and the educational community for her actions. She added that she has learned a lot about her flaws and aims to serve her sentence, complete her community service hours, and make a positive impact on her community.

 Before announcing her decision, Judge Indira Talwani stated that she was not punishing Huffman for a flawed college admissions process but for taking an extra advantage to put her child ahead of others.

 Huffman tearfully apologized to her daughters and husband in court, stating that her actions had caused significant damage. She pleaded guilty to charges of conspiring to commit mail fraud and honest service mail fraud and admitted to paying $15,000 to falsify her daughter Sophia's SAT score.

 Huffman's lawyers had asked Talwani to impose a one-year probation term, 250 hours of community service, and a $20,000 fine. However, federal prosecutors asked the judge to sentence Huffman to one month of incarceration, followed by 12 months of supervised release and a fine of $20,000.

 The college admissions scam, the largest ever prosecuted by the Department of Justice, involved 50 people, including Huffman and more than 30 other wealthy parents. The indictment alleges that the parents paid bribes to college entrance tutor guru William "Rick" Singer to get their children into elite colleges, including Stanford, the University of Southern California, Princeton, and Georgetown. Singer, who collected $25 million in bribes during the years-long scam, pleaded guilty in March and is yet to be sentenced.

 Actress Lori Loughlin, best known as Aunt Becky on the sitcom "Full House," and her husband, fashion designer Mossimo Giannulli, are fighting charges they paid Singer $500,000 to get their two daughters into USC as recruits for the university's crew team, despite the fact they had never participated in the sport.

 Huffman's lawyers presented Talwani with letters vouching for her character from the actress's relatives, including her husband, actor William H. Macy, and former colleagues such as Eva Longoria, a fellow cast member on "Desperate Housewives." Huffman and Macy allegedly made arrangements to pursue the scheme a second time for their younger daughter, but did not do so. Macy was not charged in the scam.

Title: Federal Reserve Rate Cut: Limited Impact on Personal Finances, Experts Say

Article:

The Federal Reserve has reduced its benchmark interest rate again, a move that, while significant for the U.S. economy, is expected to have a muted impact on Americans' personal finances, according to experts. This is because the recent cuts do not offset the increases of previous years, and as the key rate approaches zero, financial institutions are less inclined to pass borrowing benefits along to consumers.

The Fed's key rate, which affects a wide range of consumer and business loans, was reduced to a range of 1.75% to 2% on Wednesday. This follows a similar reduction in July, despite a relatively healthy economy, due to concerns about slowing economic growth and global trade tensions.

The latest move may have the following implications for consumers:

1. Mortgage Rates: Mortgage rates remain near historic lows, with the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 3.56% as of last week, compared to 4.6% a year ago, according to mortgage buyer Freddie Mac. Greg McBride, chief financial analyst at Bankrate.com, estimates that a full percentage point difference is "the single biggest impact on consumers" in this low-rate environment. Lower interest rates on mortgages can lead to savings for homeowners who refinance or for those shopping for a house.

2. Other Forms of Borrowing: The rate for other forms of borrowing, such as credit cards, home equity loans, or personal loans, will not see significant changes. Credit card rates, for example, track the bank prime rate, which is 3% above the federal funds target rate. The prime rate will move down immediately after the Fed's decision, but many credit card issuers may not adjust rates downwards due to default risk or increased profits.

3. Savings Accounts: Interest rates on savings accounts were already historically low and will likely remain so. The average interest rate on a savings account in the U.S. is 0.09%, according to the FDIC. While some lenders offer high-yield savings accounts with rates well above the national average, these rates are likely to dip after the most recent announcement.

In light of these changes, experts advise consumers to take steps to strengthen their finances, such as paying down debt, refinancing at lower rates, and boosting emergency savings. This, they say, will enable households to better weather an economic downturn whenever it may occur.

Title: GOP Leader Predicts Keystone XL Pipeline Approval by President Obama

Article:

In an appearance on MSNBC on Tuesday, Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus expressed confidence that a Republican-controlled House and Senate will pass a bill to approve the Keystone XL pipeline, and that President Barack Obama will likely sign it.

When asked about specific legislation a Republican Congress would pass following the elections, Priebus stated, "We will pass a budget in both chambers, number one. And we will pass the Keystone pipeline, number two. I actually think the president will sign the bill on the Keystone pipeline."

The GOP leader argued that there will be greater political pressure on the president to approve the pipeline project due to legislative action. The Keystone XL pipeline, an oil pipeline between Canada and the U.S., has been a contentious issue for years, with many Republicans and some Democrats pushing for the Obama White House to sign off on the project. Critics have argued that the job creation will be negligible and that the pipeline would have significant environmental costs and contribute to climate change.

In April, the State Department instituted another delay in making a decision on the project, which Republicans and advocates on both sides decried as politically motivated.

During the interview, Priebus also expressed expectations for big gains in the elections but stated that he would not be pleased unless Republicans are able to win in at least one swing state. "I wouldn't be happy unless — we've got to win a purple state or two, as well as taking the majority [in the Senate]," he said.

Most forecasts show that Republicans are favored to win seats in the House and take control of the Senate, where Democrats in red states have struggled to distance themselves from the Obama White House. "In a good environment with a very unpopular president, we ought to win in tough states," Priebus added.

Title: Hillary Clinton Proposes End to Deportation for Millions of Illegal Immigrants, Trump Criticizes Plan

Article:

Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton has announced her intention to end deportation for millions of illegal immigrants in the United States if elected president. Speaking before the National Associations of Black and Hispanic Journalists in Washington, Clinton also pledged to introduce legislation within the first 100 days of her potential administration to add hundreds of billions of dollars to the economy.

Clinton urged voters to help Democrats retake the Senate in November, claiming that they would "fast track" her proposal. She stated, "This is a clear high priority for my administration. We will be prepared to introduce legislation as quickly as we can."

In contrast, Republican nominee Donald Trump's campaign claimed that Clinton's plan would grant her "king-like powers" that would harm Americans. Trump has vowed to build a wall along the southern U.S. border to keep out illegal Mexican immigrants and has called Clinton's plan amnesty for those in the U.S. illegally, stating it would "totally open borders."

Clinton's comments suggest that she would follow President Obama's example of taking executive action on immigration reform. The Supreme Court in June split 4-4 on Obama's 2014 plan to defer deportation for roughly 4.3 million parents of Americans and other lawful permanent residents. Clinton, like Trump, would attempt to appoint a justice for the high court's ninth and open seat to help win favorable decisions on such issues.

Clinton's campaign website states, "Hillary believes DAPA is squarely within the president's authority and won't stop fighting until we see it through." The website also mentions Clinton's intention to defend the president's 2012 executive action to defer deportation for millions of people brought into the United States illegally by their parents.

The Clinton campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Saturday. Trump senior policy adviser Stephen Miller, who has long argued that "amnesty" would take away jobs from unemployed Americans, issued a five-page statement on Friday attacking Clinton's policies dating back to May 2015. The Senate bill died in the GOP-controlled House.

Trump has called for a temporary ban on all Muslims entering the U.S. in the wake of several deadly attacks inspired or directed by ISIS. Trump has since suggested a ban only for Muslims coming from such Middle East terror hotspots as Syria.

Miller argued on Friday that Clinton's first-100-day pledge is also dangerous. "Her pledge — in the middle of a national security and a border security crisis — demonstrates her callous and cruel disregard for the safety of the American people," Miller wrote. "This administration has released hundreds of thousands of criminal illegal immigrants, and yet Clinton says she wants to go even further, ending virtually all deportations and ending all protections Americans have against open borders."

Title: Obamacare Enrollment Data Transparency: Calls for Greater Openness Amidst Controversy Over Inflated Numbers

Article:

Controversy over inflated Obamacare enrollment numbers has renewed demands for the administration to be more open about sign-up data and other crucial aspects of the health care law. This is not just a concern from Republican opponents on Capitol Hill; consumer groups, health experts, and even strong Obamacare advocates are pushing for increased transparency.

The House Oversight Committee revealed on Thursday that nearly 400,000 dental plans were included in recent enrollment figures, leading to the misconception that the administration had reached the 7 million target for Obamacare's first year. The committee has called CMS Administrator Marilyn Tavenner and former Obamacare adviser Jonathan Gruber to testify next month about the "repeated transparency failures and outright deceptions."

The second season of Obamacare began last Saturday, but there has been no enrollment update since Sunday morning, when HHS Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell tweeted that there were more than half a million log-ins on HealthCare.gov on the first day and that 100,000 applications were submitted. By contrast, several of the 13 health insurance exchanges run by states have been regularly releasing traffic and enrollment-related data. Massachusetts, for instance, is issuing daily traffic counts.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) declined to provide an enrollment update on Friday afternoon. The agency has said it would provide detailed monthly reports of plan selection, although this would fall short of the detailed list of suggestions that the Association of Health Care Journalists sent to the agency in late October. The group requested weekly or biweekly releases with more granular data than last year's reports provided.

Federal health officials have yet to fully explain the nature of what Burwell said Thursday was an "unacceptable" mistake in including the dental plan data in the August and October enrollment totals. However, in a letter to House Oversight Committee Chairman Darrell Issa, Tavenner suggested that part of the problem was the still unfinished back end of HealthCare.gov—the part that communicates with insurance companies.

The administration seemed able to turn the numbers around pretty quickly when Obamacare's initial drama started turning around. During the month after the disastrous rollout of HealthCare.gov last October, HHS was virtually a black box—except for when it released faulty information, such as its initial explanation that the website's main problem was too much traffic by an eager public. As the administration's emergency "tech surge" began to salvage the failing site, HHS pivoted sharply, holding near-daily conference calls with reporters to update repair progress.

Data disclosure continued to lag, however; the administration refused to release any figures for more than two months. In December, it began giving detailed monthly reports. Those stopped after May and the close of the regular enrollment season—until the brief flawed announcement from Tavenner before a congressional panel in September.

"A mistake was made in calculating the number of individuals with effectuated Marketplace enrollments. While there were 7.3 million effectuated enrollments, approximately 393,000 individuals had both Marketplace medical and dental coverage as of August 15, 2014," Tavenner noted in her letter to Issa. The mistake was repeated in a November update. CMS now says 6.7 million had private Obamacare coverage as of Oct. 15.

The agency does have highly detailed enrollment data for other health programs it oversees, including Medicare Advantage and Part D prescription drug coverage for seniors. However, Capitol Street Managing Director Ipsita Smolinski said, "It's kind of apples and oranges" to compare data from the exchanges and those programs.

Yet if that kind of information was public for Obamacare, data discrepancies like the one that emerged Thursday would be more easily identified, said Larry Levitt of the Kaiser Family Foundation. "This could raise broader questions about whether detailed enrollment data by insurer and plan should be made public or kept confidential because it is proprietary," he said.

However, it took some time before such detailed data became available for the Medicare prescription drug program, and the federal system handling Obamacare is not even finished. "I don't think it's sinister," Betsy Imholz, special projects director at Consumers Union, said. "I just think it's so complex and evolving; I just think we're at the beginning of the process."

Title: MGM Resorts, Las Vegas Shooting Victims Reach Settlement Worth $735 Million to $800 Million

Article:

MGM Resorts International and the victims of the 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting have reached a settlement worth between $735 million and $800 million, according to a statement by MGM on Thursday. The settlement is not an admission of liability for the shooting that left 58 dead and hundreds wounded or injured.

"Our goal has always been to resolve these matters so our community and the victims and their families can move forward in the healing process," said Jim Murren, chairman and CEO of MGM Resorts. "This agreement with the Plaintiffs' Counsel is a major step, and one that we hoped for a long time would be possible."

Robert Eglet, a lead attorney for the plaintiffs, said the agreement marks a milestone in the recovery process. "While nothing will be able to bring back the lives lost or undo the horrors so many suffered on that day, this settlement will provide fair compensation for thousands of victims and their families," Eglet said.

The gunman, a 64-year-old reclusive gambler, sprayed bullets on a crowd of 22,000 concertgoers from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, which is owned and operated by MGM Resorts. He fired for between 10 to 15 minutes at the country music festival, killing 58 people. As many as 700 people were wounded or injured trying to escape the area.

The shooter was found dead in his hotel room with an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound. Investigators have not been able to determine his motive in carrying out the massacre. Police found 23 guns inside his hotel suite and discovered that he had brought more than 10 suitcases to the room over several days, authorities said. Lawsuits filed since the shooting questioned how and why the hotel did not know he was hoarding high-powered weapons and ammunition in his hotel room in the days leading up to the attack.

According to a regulatory filing released in May, MGM said it could pay as much as $800 million for lawsuits related to the mass shooting. The document noted that the company has about $751 million in insurance coverage that can be used to help cover such costs.

Chelsea Romo, who lost her left eye and still has shrapnel in her right eye after being shot in the head during the shooting two years ago, said, "To know that something good can come from something so horrible is I guess the only thing I could ask for out of all of this."

Jason McMillan, a 37-year-old Riverside County sheriff's deputy who was shot and paralyzed, said he was glad they reached a settlement. "The scars and injuries from that night can never be erased," he said. "I'm glad we could reach a resolution that allows us to put this nightmare behind us so our family can move forward and start focusing on the future."

Steve Melanson, whose wife Rosemarie was injured in the shooting, spoke to CNN after learning of the settlement. "We had no idea a settlement was reached until today. We're happy that they came to an agreement and settlement," he said. "But no amount of money can bring the 58 people who were killed back. No amount of money can cure the extreme pain that my wife is still suffering."

Rosemarie Melanson spent 13 months in the hospital after the shooting and has had more than a dozen surgeries. Her husband said her surgeries are not over, and she has another surgery this month due to complications from being shot. "She was shot once, but the bullet exploded inside of her, leaving her riddled with shrapnel that tore through her body. Our whole family has been on a roller-coaster that won't stop. She has another surgery scheduled this month," he told CNN. "But ultimately, we are so thankful that she is alive."

He stressed that the path to recovery will be a life-long journey for her. "It is not over for us. She has made wonderful progress. There are so many families. Our medical bills are in the millions, (but) fortunately, our insurance is good. It's covered most of it. But what about those who do not have insurance or good coverage? The settlement will hopefully offer a little closure to many who have suffered," he said.

Title: Obama Administration's Stance on Religious Liberty and the Little Sisters of the Poor Case

Article:

President Obama met with Pope Francis at the White House Wednesday, reiterating his administration's support for religious liberty. "We stand with you in defense of religious freedom," Obama said, emphasizing that people are only truly free when they can practice their faith freely.

However, the Obama administration's stance on religious liberty has been a subject of controversy, as seen in the ongoing legal battle with the Little Sisters of the Poor. A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that the religious order must comply with the Affordable Care Act's contraception mandate, which requires their health insurance carriers to subsidize contraceptive and some abortion services for employees or face fines from the IRS.

The ruling by a three-judge panel of the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver is a setback for the Little Sisters, a global Catholic order with U.S. headquarters in Catonsville that has cared for the elderly poor since 1868. The order argues that the HHS Mandate, a provision of the Affordable Care Act, infringes on its First Amendment rights by compelling it to support practices that violate its core religious beliefs.

"Today the 10th Circuit ruled that government can force the Little Sisters to either violate their faith or pay massive IRS penalties," lead attorney Mark Rienzi said in a statement. "We're disappointed in today's decision."

In a separate matter, the administration has faced criticism for its response to the human-rights crisis in Syria and Iraq, where Christians and other religious minorities have been targeted by extremist groups. The situation in these regions has been compared to the darkest episodes of World War II, with ISIS and other Islamist extremists waging genocide against Christians, Yazidis, Mandaeans, and other defenseless religious minorities.

In the summer of 2014, ISIS launched its caliphate from Mosul, marking Christian homes with the red letter "N," for "Nazarene," before confiscating them and exiling their owners. Since then, ISIS has pursued Christians and other minorities with a systematic intensity, aiming to erase all traces of their ancient presence. Christians and Yazidis have been beheaded, enslaved, abducted and sold, forcibly converted to Islam, and stripped of all their property. Their houses of worship and cultural artifacts have been expropriated or demolished.

In response to a question about President Obama's stance on abortion, it is unavailable as the article does not provide information on the Pope's awareness of President Obama's views on the matter.

Title: Historical Investigations into Police Misconduct and Reform Efforts in the United States

Article:

The history of police misconduct in the United States has been marked by several significant investigations, the first of which was undertaken by the Lexow Committee in 1894. The most common complaint against the police at that time was "clubbing," or the routine use of nightsticks or blackjacks to physically assault citizens.

The Wickersham Commission, established in 1931 to study the criminal justice system and examine Prohibition enforcement, provided a critical assessment, including evidence of brutal interrogation tactics. The commission attributed these practices to a lack of professionalism within the police force.

Following the 1967 urban uprisings, the Kerner Commission found that police actions were the final incidents before the outbreak of violence in 12 out of 24 surveyed disorders. The commission's report suggested measures such as building community support for law enforcement and reviewing police operations in urban areas to ensure proper conduct by officers.

Despite these commissions and subsequent calls for reform, incidents of police violence have persisted. Examples include the brutal police beating of Rodney King in 1991, the subsequent rebellion, and the killings of Michael Brown and Eric Garner. The final report of the Obama administration's President's Task Force on 21st Century Policing resulted in procedural changes like implicit-bias training, police-community listening sessions, and slight alterations to use-of-force policies and systems for identifying potentially problematic officers early on.

However, even a member of the task force, Tracey Meares, noted in 2017 that "policing as we know it must be abolished before it can be transformed." The underlying philosophy of these reforms is that stricter rules will lead to less violence, but police officers continue to break these rules. Recent events have seen police officers slashing tires, shoving elderly individuals on camera, and arresting and injuring journalists and protesters. These officers face minimal repercussions, as evidenced by the case of Daniel Pantaleo, a former New York City police officer whose chokehold led to Eric Garner's death. Despite the incident being filmed, Pantaleo remained on the job for five more years.

Title: Democrats Unveil "Clean Electricity Standard" and Climate-Focused Policies

Article:

Democrats have unveiled a comprehensive plan, known as the "Clean Electricity Standard," which mandates utilities to provide 100% zero-carbon power with escalating requirements beginning almost immediately. The plan also includes new requirements for states to submit plans demonstrating how they will meet net-zero emissions targets.

The plan calls for the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to deeply integrate climate considerations into natural gas-related decisions. It also proposes new financial support and requirements for low-carbon buildings codes and infrastructure.

The plan includes vastly stronger vehicle emissions rules and support for electric vehicle (EV) infrastructure. A "buy clean program" is also proposed to promote the decarbonization of energy-intensive manufacturing.

The plan mandates significant methane emissions cuts for the oil-and-gas industry. It also proposes the creation of a "National Climate Bank" to stimulate investment in low-carbon technology deployment.

Energy and Commerce Chairman Frank Pallone signaled that Democrats are aiming to establish the groundwork for potential legislation if they gain control of Washington in the 2020 elections. Pallone expressed pessimism about Republican support for an aggressive bill, stating, "There’s a fundamental problem here which I would be crazy not to acknowledge, which is most of them are climate deniers."

Yesterday's unveiling showed lawmakers collaborating with outside groups to align on the same page. The plan received supportive statements from groups including the Center for American Progress.

Carbon pricing is not a central focus of the plan, with no explicit tax or fee included, and no large federal cap-and-trade system. However, the plan allows power companies to "buy and trade clean energy credits from one another or purchase them via auction."

The plan notes that states who do not submit or receive approval for net-zero plans will be "automatically subject to a backstop carbon fee." The plan also credits nuclear power and fossil generation with carbon capture in the "clean electricity standard."

Some advocates, such as the upstart Sunrise Movement, have criticized the plan for not going far enough, with Sunrise's Lauren Maunus stating, "It falls short of the scale and scope of action the U.S. must take to tackle the dual crises of climate change and skyrocketing inequality." The group Friends of the Earth has also criticized the plan.

Title: Trump Administration Accelerates Resolution of Title IX Complaints Against Colleges and Universities

Article:

The Education Department under President Donald Trump is resolving Title IX gender-discrimination complaints against universities and colleges at a significantly faster pace than during the Obama administration, according to federal data. The administration's desire to expedite these investigations, which often involve alleged sexual assaults on campus, reflects years of protest from universities and some conservative groups that the Democratic administration of former President Barack Obama was using individual assault cases to open broad, years-long investigations into university practices.

Under President Obama, Title IX complaints that closed between 2010 and 2016 remained open an average of 150 days. In 2017, when President Trump took office, the average length of an open complaint was 88 days. Cases opened in the first four months of this year were resolved after an average of 39 days.

In 2010, the average number of days for the Department of Education to resolve Title IX complaints against colleges and universities was:
- Trump in office: 200 days
- Obama in office: 150 days
- 2011: 150 days
- 2012: 150 days
- 2013: 78 days
- 2014: 150 days
- 2015: 150 days
- 2016: 150 days

Last year, the Education Department under Secretary Betsy DeVos opted to end an Obama-administration practice of broadening individual student's complaints to look for systemic issues in how schools were handling sexual assault and harassment. Schools often complained the inquiries were excessive or unfair.

Civil-rights advocates disagreed, saying Mr. Obama's more expansive approach drilled to the root of discrimination. The current practice of closing cases as quickly as possible, they said, risks overlooking systemic violations that may be affecting more than one student.

Catherine Lhamon, who headed the Education Department's civil rights office in Mr. Obama's second term, said the only times the department opened broader cases were for high-profile investigations involving Michigan State University and the University of Southern California. Both cases featured much-publicized medical faculty members accused of assaulting numerous patients.

Ms. Lhamon said those cases reflect a broader reality that sexual harassment exists widely on campuses, and that one person's case can shed light on whether the university has mishandled similar situations.

"That's a red flag that if you don't look, someone else will be harmed," Ms. Lhamon said. "So why would the department that is charged with preventing harm against every student, why would you think, 'We don't need to look?'"

The data, released to The Wall Street Journal under the Freedom of Information Act, contain all Title IX complaints against colleges and universities between 2010 and early May of this year.

Under President Trump's administration, the percentage of investigations ending in resolution agreements, which lay out policy changes for the institution and include a monitoring period, also fell. Nearly one in 12 cases ended in resolution agreements during President Obama's tenure, compared with closer to one in 50 under President Trump.

Most complaints that didn't reach resolution agreements were dismissed, though the Trump administration has also dismissed a higher number of cases, the Journal found. More than 90% of the cases since 2017 have been dismissed, while in the six years prior, that figure was closer to 67%.

The Education Department can dismiss a case because the department determines it lacks jurisdiction or if it finds the allegation fails to state a violation, lacks sufficient detail, or is speculative or incoherent. The Journal's data don't indicate the justification for individual case dismissals.

Liz Hill, an Education Department spokeswoman, said resolving complaints without long delays is a priority for the Office for Civil Rights.

"Part of what makes OCR's mission meaningful is that OCR weighs in on crucial civil-rights issues in a timely way," she said. "Without an effort at timely resolution, a student complaining of civil-rights violations in, say, middle school might not get an answer from OCR until he or she has graduated from high school."

The administration has more broadly been looking to change the department's approach to enforcement of Title IX, the 1970s-era law prohibiting gender discrimination in educational settings. In September, Mrs. DeVos rescinded a controversial Obama-era policy that directed schools to use a standard of evidence that was less rigorous than some schools had been employing. The standard, known as "preponderance of the evidence," meaning simply "more likely than not," is the typical standard applied in civil-rights lawsuits; however, some due-process advocates said that standard made it too easy for schools to find an accused person guilty. The administration hopes to release its own set of rules as early as September, and Education Department officials may mandate a higher standard of evidence, according to people familiar with their conversations.

Title: Hillary Clinton Taps Law Professor Maya Harris to Lead Policy Team, Focuses on Women of Color Voting Bloc

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the former U.S. Secretary of State and 2016 Democratic presidential candidate, announced a trio of policy advisors for her campaign on Tuesday. Two of the appointees, Jake Sullivan and Ann O'Leary, were expected, having served in Clinton's previous roles. The third member, Maya Harris, is a law professor and senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, who has written extensively about the growing political influence of women of color.

In her paper titled "Women of Color: A Growing Force in the American Electorate," Harris argues that politicians and political strategists should address the concerns of women of color as a distinct voting bloc, rather than as part of broader efforts aimed at women, youth, or specific racial or ethnic groups. Harris contends that women of color are a rapidly growing voting bloc and that any politician who wants to win them needs to prioritize their interests on the policy agenda.

The paper does not delve into specific policy proposals, but Harris's basic political theory could signal how Clinton's campaign might attempt to replicate the coalition that propelled President Barack Obama to victory in 2008. The paper highlights the increasing political power of women of color, noting that they represent 74 percent of the growth in eligible women voters since 2000.

The paper also includes a chart that illustrates the high voter turnout rates among women, with African-American women voting at higher rates than any other demographic. This suggests that Clinton's campaign may focus on policies that appeal to women, particularly women of color, to drive high turnout in the 2016 election.

In contrast to Obama's approach, Clinton's campaign may emphasize policies that directly address the concerns of women, rather than focusing on specific racial or ethnic groups. While Obama sought to avoid proposing policy specifically aimed at the African-American community, Clinton's position is different due to the demographic makeup of the electorate. A majority of the electorate is female, and a majority of voters of color are female. If Clinton manages to polarize the electorate perfectly along gender lines, she would win the election, even if every man voted for her opponent.

In hiring Maya Harris to help lead policy on her campaign, Clinton may be signaling her intention to prioritize the concerns of women of color and to develop policies that appeal to this growing voting bloc. Harris's paper provides a roadmap for Clinton to engage with and mobilize women of color, who are poised to play a significant role in future elections.

Title: Oprah Winfrey's Potential 2020 Presidential Run Gains Momentum Following Golden Globes Speech

Article:

Oprah Winfrey's longtime partner, Stedman Graham, has indicated that Winfrey would consider a presidential bid if called upon. In an interview with The Los Angeles Times, Graham stated, "She would absolutely do it." This comment has further fueled speculation that Winfrey is seriously contemplating a presidential run.

The NBC network and numerous celebrities have referred to Winfrey as "our future president" following her powerful speech at the Golden Globes, which addressed civil rights and the #MeToo movement, highlighting rampant sexual harassment. The iconic talk show host was also the subject of a joke by the award's host, Seth Meyers, who playfully discouraged her from running for U.S. president.

Winfrey's acceptance of the Cecil B. DeMille Award, the first ever awarded to a black woman, and her subsequent speech about the Me Too and civil rights movement, has sparked widespread speculation about her political aspirations. In her speech, Winfrey stated, "For too long, women have not been heard or believed if they dared to speak their truth to the power of those men. But their time is up. Their time is up. Their time is up."

Liberal MSNBC host Joy Reid tweeted, "Switched back to the Golden Globes to watch Oprah get her award. Never let it be said that I don't respect the president of the United States." Multiple other commentators and celebrities have also expressed their support for Winfrey's potential presidential run in 2020.

After paying tribute to civil rights and the press, Winfrey concluded her speech with a hopeful note that "a new day was on the horizon" because of people who will "take us to the time when nobody ever has to say'me too' again."

Title: China Demands Release of Huawei CFO Amidst US Probe, Global Market Impact

Article:

China is demanding the release of Meng Wanzhou, the chief financial officer of telecoms giant Huawei, who has been detained in Canada. Meng, the daughter of the company's founder, could face extradition to the US, where she is under investigation for potential violations of US sanctions against Iran.

Meng was arrested in Vancouver on 1 December, but the news was not made public at her request. The charges against her remain unknown. Huawei, one of the largest telecommunications equipment and services providers in the world, recently passed Apple to become the second-biggest smartphone maker after Samsung.

The arrest has caused a significant impact on global markets, with European shares hitting a two-year low and indexes across Asia dropping sharply following the arrest. Analysts attribute this to revived worries over the US-China trade war. A Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson stated, "The detention without giving any reason violates a person's human rights."

Beijing has made solemn representations to Canada and the US, demanding that both parties immediately clarify the reasons for the detention and release the detainee to protect her legal rights. Concerns that the arrest would affect the 90-day tariff truce negotiated between the two nations at the G20 have not yet materialized, as China announced on Thursday that it would "immediately" implement the measures agreed.

The arrest coincides with moves to restrict the use of Huawei technology in Western countries. The US, Australia, and New Zealand have blocked the use of the Chinese firm's equipment in infrastructure for new faster 5G mobile networks. Canada's ministry of justice has set a bail hearing for Meng for Friday.

The arrest is a top trending topic on Chinese social media, with many users criticizing the US and Canada for what they call "low" and "bullying" tactics. Some Western governments fear Beijing will gain access to fifth-generation (5G) mobile and other communications networks through Huawei and expand its spying ability, although the firm insists there is no government control.

The US has brought a number of legal cases against Chinese technology firms, with accusations such as cyber-security theft and violations of Iran sanctions. Donald Trump last month reinstated all the US sanctions on Iran that had been removed under a 2015 nuclear deal. Mr. Trump had been fiercely opposed to the deal, which saw Iran limit its controversial nuclear activities in exchange for sanctions relief.

Title: Trump's "America First" Policy: A Shift in U.S. Foreign Policy

Article:

The inaugural address of President Donald Trump has sparked concerns worldwide regarding a potential shift in American foreign policy. While the flurry of executive orders and Cabinet nominations has been encouraging to conservative skeptics, the foreign-policy section of the address has received less attention but deserves significant scrutiny.

In his speech, Trump outlined a world in which foreign relations are viewed as a zero-sum game, with other countries gaining at America's expense. He stated, "For many decades, we’ve enriched foreign industry at the expense of American industry; subsidized the armies of other countries while depleting our own."

Trump's foreign-policy stance differs significantly from previous administrations. Unlike John F. Kennedy's inaugural address, which pledged to support any friend and oppose any foe to assure the success of liberty, Trump makes no distinction between friend and foe. He declared, "From this day forward, it’s going to be only America First."

This phrase, "America First," has historical implications, as it was the name of the organization led by Charles Lindbergh that advocated for American neutrality during World War II. While Trump may not have intentionally imitated Lindbergh, the phrase and its connotations have not gone unnoticed abroad.

Critics argue that Trump's "America First" policy is a reassertion of American exceptionalism. However, it is more accurately described as the antithesis of American exceptionalism, as it makes America no different from other countries that define themselves by blood-and-soil nationalism.

Some suggest that Trump's policy is a bargaining chip to negotiate better terms of trade or alliance. Others argue that Trump's views are unstable, citing his conflicting statements about NATO. However, these claims are demonstrably wrong, as an inaugural address is not an off-the-cuff riff but a carefully crafted expression of the president's philosophy.

Trump's "America First" policy is not just theory. The abrupt withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a significant first fruit of his foreign-policy doctrine, demonstrates this shift. The prime minister of Singapore, who knows the region well, warned that if the U.S. pulled out of TPP, "you’ll be finished in Asia."

For 70 years, the U.S. has sustained an international system of open commerce and democratic alliances that has enabled America and the West to grow and thrive. Abandoning this global leadership at our peril is a concern shared by many.

Title: "Call for Caution Regarding Marco Rubio's Political Strategy Amidst Controversy"

Article:

Recent headlines surrounding Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) have raised concerns among conservative supporters, with accusations of political maneuvering and alleged collaboration with Democrats on immigration reform. The controversy stems from a series of headlines published by conservative media outlets such as Breitbart.com, RedState.com, The Daily Caller, and the Washington Examiner, as well as comments from prominent conservative thought leaders.

The headlines in question include:

* "Obama Plans Major Push for Gang of Eight Immigration Bill"
* "Secret Emails: Cato, Norquist, Rubio Use Boston Terror Attacks to Push Immigration Reform"
* "Pro-Immigration Reform Consultants Work Together to Craft Immigration Testimony, Attack Jim DeMint and Heritage Foundation"
* "They Lied to Us Then About Immigration, They are Lying Now"

These headlines, along with National Review's Rich Lowry's recent piece, have led to accusations that Rubio and his staff are undermining the conservative cause and collaborating with Democrats. The controversy has also led to allegations of Rubio being used as a "conservative Hispanic human shield" by Democrat mastermind Chuck Schumer.

In a recent open letter, the author expressed concern that Rubio would become involved with a "gang of liberals and RINOs," anticipating this would be the outcome. The fallout for Rubio has been more severe than anticipated, with Rubio's staff contributing to the controversy through actions such as Alex Conant's Twitter spat with a skeptical conservative reporter. Conant's comments, which tacitly labeled those who support policies that benefit law-keepers and taxpayers as racists, created an uproar on the Right.

The controversy has led some to question Rubio's political future and his ability to effectively represent conservative values on a national stage. The author of the article urges Rubio to take heed of the criticism and exercise caution in his political strategy moving forward.

Title: Iowa Republican State Convention Marked by Disagreements and Calls for Unity

Article:

The Iowa Republican State Convention on Saturday was marked by disagreements and calls for unity, with some longtime party activists expressing concerns about the influence of Texas Representative Ron Paul's supporters. The event took place before the national convention in Florida this summer, and the rancor observed in Iowa may indicate potential challenges for Mitt Romney during the national convention.

The day was filled with parliamentary threats and disputes over speaking out of turn. The unrest can be attributed to the significant presence of Paul supporters, who will make up all but a handful of Iowa's 28 delegates going to Tampa. Out of the 25 delegates up for a vote at the convention, 21 support Paul. These delegates are unbound, meaning they can vote for whomever they choose at the national convention.

Bethany Gates, a delegate from Benton County, expressed concerns that aligning with Paul could harm the party's image and the state's first-in-the-nation caucus status. "So far, we've already had two different candidates that are declared a winner," she said. "If we go to national with a third candidate... we are going to look ridiculous."

The controversy stems from party officials reporting that former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney won the caucus in January, only to later name former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum the winner after a recount. Paul came in a close third, but his supporters have continued to organize on his behalf.

Saturday's event also included calls for unity from several speakers, including longtime Iowa Senator Chuck Grassley and State Party Chairman A.J. Spiker. Grassley urged the crowd to deliver the swing state to Romney, stating, "Either it's four more years of President Obama, or it's a new day. And every one of you want it to be a new day."

Despite calls for unity, Spiker, who left the Paul campaign to assume his new role earlier this year, failed to mention Romney's name during his speech. Prominent blogger Craig Robinson, who was undecided during caucus season, stated that the outcome of the convention does not represent what happened at the caucuses and is not helping the Iowa GOP.

Jeff Taylor, a Paul supporter who was chosen as a national delegate this weekend, argued that internal disagreements could be beneficial for the party. "We'd have a bigger audience for the conventions if we were a little bit more of a throwback to the old days, before it was all so cut-and-dried and... a slick package," he said.

If Paul supporters have their way, the convention in Tampa may be anything but the slick package Romney and much of the GOP are hoping for.

Title: Canadian House of Commons Unanimously Rebukes President Trump's Criticism of Prime Minister Trudeau

Article: The Canadian House of Commons unanimously passed a motion on Monday, rejecting "disparaging ad hominem statements" from U.S. officials, a clear reference to President Donald Trump and his advisers. The motion was proposed by MP Tracey Ramsey, a member of the New Democratic Party, in response to President Trump's criticism of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau over the weekend.

The rebuke came after President Trump criticized Prime Minister Trudeau for vowing to retaliate against tariffs recently imposed by the U.S. on Canadian steel and aluminum products. In a press conference on Saturday, Mr. Trudeau stated, "I have made it very clear to the president that it is not something we relish doing, but it is something that we absolutely will do, because Canadians, we’re polite, we’re reasonable, but we also will not be pushed around."

President Trump responded to Mr. Trudeau on Twitter, calling him "dishonest" and "weak." The president's surrogates also amplified the attack during media appearances over the weekend. White House trade adviser Peter Navarro said, "There’s a special place in hell for any foreign leader that engages in bad faith diplomacy with President Donald J. Trump and then tries to stab him in the back on the way out the door."

In addition to rejecting the insults aimed at Mr. Trudeau, the motion passed on Monday also stated that lawmakers "strongly oppose the illegitimate tariffs imposed by the U.S. government against Canadian steel and aluminum workers" and "stand in solidarity with the Government of Canada in its decision to impose retaliatory tariffs."

MP Ramsey stated, "At this difficult moment in our history with our U.S. neighbors, Canadians need to know that all sides of this House stand united as one." The symbolic House vote was held to show the solidarity and united front of Canada's Parliament against the divisive actions of the president of the United States after his visit to Canada and the G-7 meetings this weekend.

Title: FBI Agent's Text Suggests Lack of Evidence for Trump-Russia Collusion, According to Republican Senator

Article:

In a radio interview on Tuesday, Wisconsin Sen. Ron Johnson, the chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, revealed a text message sent by Peter Strzok, the FBI's top agent on the Trump-Russia investigation, that suggests he saw no evidence of Trump campaign collusion.

During the interview with WISN-Milwaukee radio host Jay Weber, Johnson read aloud a May 19, 2017 text that Strzok sent to Lisa Page, an FBI lawyer and his mistress. Strzok wrote, "You and I both know the odds are nothing. If I thought it was likely, I'd be there no question. I hesitate in part because of my gut sense and concern that there's no big there there."

Johnson stated that the text referred to the Mueller investigation, which had just begun two days earlier. Strzok joined that team but was removed in July after the Justice Department's inspector general discovered his anti-Trump text exchanges with Page.

As the FBI's deputy counterintelligence chief, Strzok was picked in July 2016 to oversee the investigation into possible Trump campaign collusion with the Russian government. Prior to that, he was a top investigator on the Clinton email inquiry.

"I think that's kind of jaw-dropping," said Johnson, a Republican, of the Strzok text. "In other words, Peter Strzok, who was the FBI deputy assistant director of the counterintelligence division, the man who had a plan to do something because he just couldn't abide Donald Trump being president, is saying that his gut sense is that there's no big there there when it comes to the Mueller special counsel investigation."

The text message was included in 400 pages of text messages exchanged between Strzok and Page. Lawmakers have started reviewing the trove of documents for evidence of anti-Trump and pro-Clinton bias.

Johnson also addressed the revelation last Friday that the FBI "failed to preserve" five months worth of text messages exchanged between Strzok and Page. A Justice Department official told Johnson's committee and five other congressional panels that a "misconfiguration" issue caused "many" FBI-issued mobile devices to not back up to the bureau's servers.

The FBI said it does not have text messages for Strzok and Page for the period between Dec. 14, 2016, and May 17, 2017—the day that Mueller was appointed. Johnson stated that Congress needs to see the missing text messages because Strzok and Page were "completely unguarded in their communication."

"So we're getting insight into exactly what is happening inside the FBI at the highest levels," he said. "And who knows who else they might implicate in terms of corruption."

Johnson released two pages of Strzok-Page messages from May 19, 2017. They show the pair seemingly discussing the new Mueller investigation and whether they wanted to join. The messages show that Strzok and Page discussed the historical significance of the investigation and its potential impact on their career trajectory.

The messages also reveal Strzok's apparent attempt to coax Page into joining the Mueller investigation, with Strzok stating that it was "maybe the most important case of our lives." Strzok then appeared to express his desire to "fix" and "finish" the Clinton investigation, which was referred to as "MYE" in the texts.

"You shouldn't take this on," Page then wrote. "I promise you, I would tell you if you should." After several exchanges discussing their positions at the FBI, Strzok suggested to Page that he did not want to take on the Mueller job because of his "gut sense and concern there's no big there there."

Title: House Oversight and Government Reform Committee Issues Subpoenas in Multiple Investigations

Article:

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, chaired by Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.), has issued subpoenas to several government departments as part of ongoing investigations.

On August 8th, the committee issued a subpoena to the Treasury Department for hundreds of thousands of pages of documents related to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) targeting of conservative groups, including any communications between the White House and IRS or Treasury Department on the matter.

On August 7th, Issa sent two subpoenas to the State Department for information regarding the September 11, 2012, attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, where four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador to Libya J. Christopher Stevens, were killed.

The State and Treasury departments have until August 16th to respond to Issa's subpoenas.

In addition, Rep. Lamar Smith (R-Texas), chairman of the Science, Space and Technology Committee, issued a subpoena as part of the committee's probe into the "secret science" behind the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Clean Air Act regulations.

The IRS controversy, often dismissed by Obama and White House officials as a "phony scandal" due to progressive groups also being targeted, has continued to be a point of contention for House Republicans and the Senate Finance Committee. The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has received only a fraction of the more than 600,000 pages of documents related to the IRS scandal.

The Benghazi controversy is also ongoing, with Issa's panel already receiving access to 25,000 pages of Benghazi documents from the State Department. However, these documents are not allowed to be retained by congressional investigators. Since May, Issa has issued four document subpoenas to the State Department seeking additional information, with more subpoenas seeking testimony from department officials.

"After ignoring requests for months, the State Department has left no alternative but to issue subpoenas for documents relevant to our investigation," Issa said on August 7th. "State Department tactics to delay and impede accountability have exhausted the Committee's patience. Further subpoenas may also be necessary if the Department is not forthcoming on other requests."

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is currently involved in a legal battle with the Justice Department over the Fast and Furious scandal, in which thousands of U.S.-made guns were allowed to "walk" to Mexican drug cartels as part of a botched investigation into weapons trafficking. The House approved civil and criminal contempt resolutions against Attorney General Eric Holder for failing to comply with a subpoena issued as part of the probe. The Justice Department refused to enforce the criminal contempt resolution against Holder. The House committee then sued the Justice Department in August 2012 in federal court to enforce the civil contempt resolution, a case that is still pending.

Issa, a critic of President Obama, complained in a Friday letter to Treasury Secretary Jack Lew that the IRS has "engaged in a systematic effort to delay, frustrate, impede, and obstruct the Committee's investigation."

The Science, Space and Technology Committee, chaired by Rep. Lamar Smith, has unsuccessfully sought information from the EPA since September 2011 outlining how it determines allowable levels of airborne pollutants. Smith is demanding that the EPA turn over by August 19th unreleased public health studies conducted by Harvard University and the American Cancer Society, which the EPA used in developing regulations on particulate matter and ozone.

Democrats on the Science Committee mocked the GOP's efforts, saying they were clearly done at the behest of special-interest groups. "I have to assume you'll be passing this data to, excuse my language, industry hacks," said Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas), ranking member of the Science panel. "To so blatantly be doing the bidding of polluting industries is simply mind-boggling."

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Shift: From "Bad Cop" to "Good Cop" with New Appointees

Article:

President Donald Trump, during his first 15 months in office, has been characterized as the "bad cop" in international relations, with his tough rhetoric and aggressive actions towards NATO allies, North Korea, Syria, and China. However, with the appointment of a team of foreign policy hardliners, including Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, National Security Adviser John Bolton, and U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley, there is a possibility that Trump may shift his role to the "good cop."

Throughout his presidency, Trump's supposedly more sober and judicious appointees, such as former national-security adviser H.R. McMaster and former secretary of state Rex Tillerson, have played the role of the "good cop" to Trump's "bad cop." This dynamic is reminiscent of the Nixon-Kissinger relationship, where Nixon postured as the aggressive leader, while Kissinger negotiated behind the scenes to secure compromises.

The new team of foreign policy hardliners is expected to question the status quo and take risks in restoring U.S. strategic deterrence. Trump's shift to the "good cop" role could mean that he will no longer worry the Europeans, frighten the North Koreans, and assail the Russians and Chinese. Instead, he may express his fears that he can scarcely control the righteous anger of his new foreign-policy team.

Trump ran on avoiding entangling overseas interventions, and his new role as the "good cop" may align more closely with his swing-state, blue-collar supporters. Trump's art-of-the-deal style has been to play the mediator who claims that there must be some way to find common ground between two adversaries. As a "good cop," he can say to the Chinese, North Koreans, Iranians, and others, "Let's make a deal so I don't have to call in the tough guys, who are starting to scare me as much as they scare you."

Trump also has a special affinity for Defense Secretary James Mattis, but in the past, Mattis was stereotyped as a "good cop" trying to talk Trump out of aggressive actions. Now, however, Trump can join Mattis in a "good-cop" role, as the two pose abroad as unified voices of caution who want agreements rather than confrontations.

Even in role-playing, it is wise to have Mattis and Trump on the same side. One reason Trump has a special affinity for Mattis is that his caution and reluctance to intervene abroad fit Trump's own campaign sloganeering.

Trump now can outsource his lone-wolf hawkishness to new hard-liners Bolton and Pompeo, and remind enemies that his art-of-the-deal compromising is their last chance at an agreement. In sum, the tough reputations of the highly regarded Pompeo and Bolton now allow Trump to be what he always was—a dealmaker.

Title: Obama Defends TPP Pacific Rim Free-Trade Deal, Criticizes China's Exclusion

Article:

In his weekly address to the nation, U.S. President Barack Obama defended the newly concluded Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) Pacific Rim free-trade deal, which excludes China. The 12-country accord, finalized after five years of negotiations, features the strongest labor and environmental standards in history, according to Obama.

The TPP, once approved by all signatories, could be the largest regional trade pact ever. Obama stated, "Without this agreement, competitors that do not share our values, like China, will write the rules of the global economy." He further added, "They'll keep selling into our markets and try to lure companies over there, meanwhile they'll keep their markets closed to us."

The TPP aims to set the rules for 21st-century trade and marks one of Obama's key diplomatic and economic achievements. The deal has faced opposition from activists who argue it favors big business over consumers and governments, and US congressional leaders have already expressed reservations even before the details have been released.

Hillary Clinton, who, as secretary of state under Obama, promoted the negotiations aimed at sealing the TPP and is now the Democratic frontrunner in the race for the 2016 presidential election, has come out against it. Clinton said Wednesday that given what she knows about the deal, it falls short of her "high bar" for creating American jobs, raising wages, and advancing U.S. national security.

Under the deal, 98 percent of tariffs will be eliminated on a wide range of products, including beef, dairy products, wine, sugar, rice, horticulture, seafood, manufactured products, resources, and energy. The countries involved are the U.S., Canada, Japan, Australia, Brunei, Chile, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore, and Vietnam. The details of the agreement are yet to be fully disclosed.

Title: High School Students Across the U.S. Adapt to School Safety Concerns in Wake of Mass Shootings

Article:

In the aftermath of the Texas high school shooting that left 10 people dead, two students from Mount Pleasant Community High School in Iowa are contemplating the safety of their usual seats in the school cafeteria. Calysta Wilson and Courtney Fletcher, both juniors, believe their table, which is closest to the doors, would be the first target for a potential gunman.

"We sit at the table closest to the doors," Calysta, 17, said during a softball game. "In the case that you came in as a shooter and you killed the first person you saw, I would die. I would not make it."

The grim reality of school violence has led to a shift in conversations among many high school students, from "This could never happen here" to "What do we do when this happens?" As the persistence of mass shootings and the protocol of active shooter drills become a part of their lives, students often consider the safety of their classrooms, even running scenarios in their heads about their likelihood of getting shot.

Since the Sandy Hook Elementary School mass shooting nearly six years ago in Newtown, Connecticut, there have been more than 200 school shootings nationwide, including the recent rampage in Parkland, Florida, which inspired a youth-led movement to reform gun laws.

Students now discuss the location of doors and windows in their classrooms as risk factors, calculate escape routes, and ponder hiding spots in wide-open rooms. "It's like the front lines of a war," said Emily Rubinstein, a sophomore at a New York high school. "Being seated in front of the classroom could be what makes you live and what makes you die."

Emily has given a great deal of thought to her safety as she moves through her school day. She considers her English classroom the safest, as it has just one door, is down a hallway that makes it hard to find, and has an unusual cutout corner with no desks. Math class, on the other hand, is where she is most exposed. She sits in the second desk of the second row, in a direct diagonal path from the door. During lockdown drills, she has learned that the safest place to be is pressed up against the wall where the door is, so that if a shooter looks into the room, it will appear empty. However, in math, she has calculated that her chances of reaching that position are low.

"I sit really, really close to the door," she said. "If someone came running down the hall with a gun, I wouldn't have time."

Despite these thoughts, Emily said these plans have not affected her schoolwork, friendships, or her extracurricular activities. "We have all these thoughts," she said. "But there's still part of my mind that's like, 'No, it couldn't happen to me.'"

Many schools have decided that it could. A 2016 report from the United States Government Accountability Office found that two-thirds of school districts conduct exercises to prepare for an active shooter. Bartlesville High School, an hour north of Tulsa, Oklahoma, has regularly held safety drills and lockdowns since 2012, when a student was arrested for making a threat against the school. In Martinsburg, West Virginia, Spring Mills High School held a "code red" lockdown this year without telling some teachers the event was just a drill, to make sure the staff was truly prepared.

Title: Biden's Victories in Primary Elections Signal Clear Path to Democratic Nomination

Article:

In the primary elections held on March 10, 2020, former Vice President Joe Biden demonstrated a significant lead over Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, setting the stage for Biden to become the Democratic Party's nominee for the 2020 presidential election. This is not due to Biden acquiring an insurmountable delegate lead over Sanders on the night of the six contests, but rather due to the expected results in upcoming states such as Florida, Illinois, Ohio, and Arizona, where Biden is expected to win by double-digit margins.

The results of the primary elections on March 10 confirm a trend that has been evident since Super Tuesday, which is that Biden is performing better than Hillary Clinton did in the 2016 primaries, while Sanders is performing significantly worse.
