The results in states such as Mississippi and Michigan, which played a significant role in the 2016 election, highlight this trend.

In Mississippi, Biden's showing in the primary mirrors Clinton's performance in the state four years ago, with the more centrist candidate winning with approximately 80% of the vote, while Sanders finished in the mid-teens. The ideologically moderate black vote in the South, a key demographic, appears to favor Biden over Sanders.

In Michigan, Sanders' performance in the 2016 primary, where he narrowly beat Clinton, is expected to be significantly lower this time around, with Biden on track to win by roughly 13 percentage points. Sanders' underperformance in Michigan is particularly noteworthy, as he won Kalamazoo County by 22 points in 2016, but narrowly lost it to Biden this time. In Washtenaw County, Sanders' stronghold in 2016, he lost to Biden by a narrow margin.

The results in Missouri were even more stark, with Sanders losing the state to Clinton in a photo-finish in 2016, but Biden looking on track to win it by a massive 25 points. The contrast between Sanders' 2016 and 2020 performances in these states is undeniable.

Even in states where Sanders has enjoyed his greatest strength, such as Washington and Idaho, his performance is weaker this time around. In Washington, Sanders' 72% victory in the 2016 caucuses has become a neck-and-neck race with Biden, while in Idaho, Sanders' 56-point blowout in the 2016 caucuses has become a narrow lead for Biden.

The Sanders campaign's performance in these primary elections is a clear indication of a floundering and deflating campaign, while the Biden campaign, facing no other viable opponents, has become virtually unstoppable in its march to the Democratic nomination. It remains to be seen whether the former vice president will prove more capable than the 2016 nominee of beating President Donald Trump in the general election. However, the results on Tuesday night give Democrats reason to suspect that he might.

Title: Obama to Announce Expanded Background Checks for Gun Sales as Part of New Executive Actions

Article:

President Barack Obama will meet with Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Monday to discuss options for tougher gun restrictions, and is expected to announce in the coming days a new executive action with the goal of expanding background checks on gun sales. The set of executive actions, described as "imminent" by people familiar with the White House plans, is expected to fulfill a promise by the President to take further unilateral steps to help curb gun deaths.

Plans for the action are not yet complete, and those familiar with the process warn that unforeseen circumstances could delay an announcement. However, gun control advocates are expecting the new actions to be revealed next week, ahead of Obama's annual State of the Union address, set for January 12.

The White House would not comment directly on the exact timing or content of Obama's executive orders. White House spokesman Eric Schultz said that the President expected a set of recommendations on unilateral action to arrive at the beginning of the year. Plans began to become clearer on New Year's Day with a White House announcement accompanying Obama's weekly address, stating that on Monday the president would meet with Lynch.

"Change, as always, is going to take all of us," Obama said in his weekly address. "The gun lobby is loud and well organized in its defense of effortlessly available guns for anyone. The rest of us are going to have to be just as passionate and well organized in our defense of our kids."

"We know that we can't stop every act of violence," Obama said. "But what if we tried to stop even one? What if Congress did something -- anything -- to protect our kids from gun violence?"

White House spokesman Schultz said Obama was "expressing urgency" for a list of steps he can take on his own after high-profile incidents of gun violence at the end of this year.

"It is complicated. That's why it's taken some time for our policy folks, our lawyers, and our experts to work through this and see what's possible," Schultz said.

A spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association said the group had no comment. The group previously told CNN that Obama's "gun control agenda was rejected by Congress. Now, he is doing what he always does when he doesn't get his way, defying the will of the people and using executive action."

The group said at the time that Obama had his "wish list of gun control" in California but "it didn't prevent the San Bernardino attack."

"The fact is, the President's gun control agenda will only make it harder for law-abiding citizens to exercise their right to self-defense," said NRA spokeswoman Jennifer Baker.

Gun control advocates and White House officials say the focus remains on the so-called "gun show loophole," which allows certain sellers of guns -- at gun shows and elsewhere -- to avoid conducting background checks before making sales. Months after the Newtown, Connecticut, elementary school massacre that claimed 26 victims in 2012, the then-Democratic majority Senate rejected a similar proposal.

Congress would still need to act in order to make background checks fully universal. However, advocates and administration lawyers have struck upon a provision in the law that could allow for Obama to expand the background check requirement to additional sellers.

Federal law currently requires all individuals "engaged in the business" of selling guns to obtain a license and conduct background checks on buyers. However, others who only make occasional sales or are selling firearms from a personal collection are exempted from the background check requirement.

Gun control advocates say Obama could take action himself by issuing a regulation that provides expanded guidance on who falls under the "in the business" standard. One group, the Michael Bloomberg-helmed Everytown for Gun Safety, has provided recommendations to the White House that include creating a test for assessing who must become licensed to continue selling guns. Factors would include volume and speed of sales, and whether or not the seller relies on advertising to sell guns.

The group also recommended Obama define a gun in a "personal collection" as having been in the seller's possession for at least a year.

Before leaving for his winter vacation in Hawaii, Obama met with Bloomberg at the White House to discuss gun control.

Aside from the background check provision, people familiar with Obama's plans say his new gun control announcement will include new funding for government agencies to better enforce existing gun laws. Other gun control advocates are pushing the administration to set an annual sales threshold of 25 guns for a seller to be defined as "engaged in the business" of selling guns, and thus required to obtain a license and conduct background checks. That would be one of several factors used to determine whether or not a seller meets the definition of "in the business." Others would include whether or not they advertise.

Aside from the gun-show loophole, advocates are anticipating the administration will bolster regulations on the reporting of lost and stolen guns. Currently, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives is only required to investigate a gun theft if 10 or more guns are stolen and one of them is used in a crime. The administration is expected to tighten those requirements by reducing the minimum number of guns stolen that would prompt an investigation, and potentially eliminating the requirement that one of the guns is used in a crime.

Title: Mississippi Elementary School Renamed in Honor of Barack Obama

Article:

Parents and children in Mississippi have chosen to rename an elementary school serving predominantly black students in honor of the first black president, Barack Obama. The Davis International Baccalaureate (IB) Elementary School in Jackson will be renamed as such at the start of the 2018-19 school year.

The name change was approved by school stakeholders in a vote held on October 5, as announced by PTA President Janelle Jefferson at a Tuesday evening meeting of the district's board of trustees. According to Jefferson, the school community sought a name that reflects a person who embodies ideals and public stances consistent with what they want their children to believe about themselves.

Discussions to rename the magnet school from one honoring Confederate President Jefferson Davis began in August. More than 95% of the school's students are black. PTA president Jefferson stated, "Jefferson Davis, although infamous in his own right, would probably not be too happy about a diverse school promoting the education of the very individuals he fought to be enslaved named after him."

As part of a three-week process, staff and students at the school offered suggestions for new names and then held a vote. Board President Camille Simms expressed her agreement with the new name at Tuesday's meeting. School board member Jed Oppenheim applauded the school for taking the initiative, stating, "I think this is a powerful narrative."

PTA president Jefferson told the Associated Press they would conduct "some very aggressive fundraising campaigns" to pay for new signs and stationery with Obama's name.

Title: Supreme Court's Health Care Decision Alters Public Perception of the High Court

Article:

The Supreme Court's decision to uphold the national health care law has not significantly changed opinions on the controversial measure, but it has noticeably affected Americans' views of the high court, according to a new CNN/ORC International poll.

The poll, released on Monday, shows that 50% of Americans agree with the Supreme Court's decision, while 49% disagree. The partisan divide is evident, with 80% of Democrats agreeing with the decision, 80% of Republicans disagreeing, and independent voters split, with 52% disagreeing and 47% agreeing.

The poll was conducted from Thursday through Sunday, entirely after the high court's ruling on the Affordable Care Act. CNN Polling Director Keating Holland notes that, despite the expected partisan divide, only about one in five Americans (20%) and only 35% of Republican rank and file are angry about the decision. Similarly, only 16% of Americans, and only one in three Democrats, feel enthusiastic about the court's ruling.

However, perceptions of the high court have changed significantly. "As recently as April, Republicans and Democrats had virtually identical positive opinions on the Supreme Court," Holland says. "But that's no longer the case. That's the biggest change that the court decision has created."

The court's approval rating among Democrats jumped by 23 points, to 73%. Among Republicans, it fell by 21 points, to 31%. Approval of the Supreme Court among independents edged up five points, to 53%.

Opinions of Chief Justice John Roberts are also divided along partisan lines, with a majority of Democrats holding a favorable view of him compared to only 30% of Republicans. However, more than a third of all Americans (35%) are unsure how they view Roberts, probably a result of the low profile that he and his colleagues have kept for many years. Roberts sided with the liberals on the high court to uphold the law.

Overall, 30% say the high court is too liberal, with 22% saying it's too conservative and 46% saying it's about right.

The Republican-led House of Representatives has scheduled a July 11th vote to attempt to repeal the health care law. The survey indicates that 51% say Congress should repeal all provisions of the measure, with 47% saying no.

Regarding the individual mandate itself, 48% favor it and 51% oppose the mandate. One thing that Americans do agree on is that the health insurance mandate is a tax, as ruled by the Supreme Court. Six in ten feel that way.

"But it is also worth noting that the number of Americans who favor all or most of the provisions in the bill has gone up a bit since last year," Holland says. "Despite roughly half looking to repeal all the provisions in the law, only one in eight say they oppose everything in the bill."

The CNN poll was conducted by ORC International from June 28-July 1 with 1,517 adult Americans questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 2.5 percentage points.

Do you agree or disagree with Thursday's Supreme Court ruling? Share your thoughts in the comments below.

Title: Michael Flynn's Aborted Nuclear Deal with Saudi Arabia and Russia: A Failed Plan for Strategic Security

Article:

Michael Flynn, former National Security Advisor, was involved in a proposed nuclear deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia during the Obama administration. The deal, which never materialized, was not primarily aimed at generating energy but rather securing strategic alliances, according to Thomas Cochran, a nuclear nonproliferation proponent involved with the Advanced Clean Energy (ACU) project.

The plan, as outlined by Cochran, would have seen the Saudis and other Arab states purchasing a security arrangement involving the U.S., Russia, France, and the U.K., with the ultimate goal of compensating Russia for lost military sales to Iran. The deal was intended to encourage Russia to decrease its support for Iran, in exchange for substantial financial gains not only from nuclear deals but also from arms sales.

The proposed deal, had it been implemented, would have provided a significant financial boost to the U.S. nuclear industry and Russia, potentially saving an industry struggling to find willing customers domestically and abroad. However, the deal faced obstacles during the Obama administration, including Russian sanctions and the ongoing Iran treaty negotiations, which would have been disrupted by the proposed plan.

Flynn's deal with Russia was not disclosed during his tenure as National Security Advisor, adding to a growing list of reporting failures. These failures extended beyond his alleged undisclosed associations with former Russian ambassador Sergei Kislyak, which reportedly led to his dismissal. Flynn also failed to disclose his extensive dealings with the Turkish government, dinner with Vladimir Putin, income from Russian state media, payments from a Russian cybersecurity firm, and a researcher's work with Russian hackers.

Despite these undisclosed connections, the Trump administration initially ignored them. However, with the investigation by the Special Counsel and the Senate Intelligence Committee, the significance of Flynn's omissions has become a major issue.

Title: Texas Senator Ted Cruz Supports Texas Senate Bill 1, Aimed at Limiting Abortions After 20 Weeks

Article:

U.S. Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) has publicly expressed his support for Texas Senate Bill 1, a controversial legislation that aims to ban abortions after 20 weeks of gestation and raise the standards of care at abortion clinics by requiring them to meet the same standards as ambulatory surgical centers.

In a statement, Sen. Cruz expressed gratitude to the thousands of Texans who are engaging in the legislative process to advocate for the unborn. He cited the recent murder trial of abortionist Kermit Gosnell as a compelling reason for the need for action.

Sen. Cruz criticized those who advocate for few restrictions on abortion, stating that their position can be interpreted as supporting "anytime, on-demand, and everywhere" abortions. He emphasized the importance of the principles of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness, arguing that life comes first.

Over the past week, Sen. Cruz has reflected on the Founding Fathers, the Declaration of Independence, and the concept of natural rights. He suggested that the Founding Fathers would find legalized infanticide abhorrent and unconscionable. He noted that, in many states, women can terminate a pregnancy after 20 weeks gestation, which he finds problematic given the understanding of fetal pain.

Sen. Cruz asserted that liberty and late-term abortion cannot co-exist, and while most Americans understand this, far too many do not. He concluded by stating that the bill in Texas, which pro-lifers are championing, is not intended to harm women but to protect the unborn from agony and death.

Title: U.S. Airstrikes Against Islamic State Militants: Background and Identification of Notorious ISIS Member

Article:

The United States considers targeted strikes against specific militant leaders as lawful acts of war or self-defense, especially when capturing the militants is not feasible. This was evident during the U.S. air campaign against the Islamic State (IS) in 2014, which was declared as part of the existing armed conflict that Congress authorized against Al Qaeda following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The IS was a component or affiliate of Al Qaeda for years but split away due to internal disagreements.

One of the most notorious ISIS members, Mohammed Emwazi, first gained prominence in August 2014, when the IS released a video showing the beheading of journalist James Foley. Emwazi, who was initially known as an unidentified, masked man with a British accent, went on to behead another journalist, Steven J. Sotloff, in a video released two weeks later.

The Washington Post revealed Emwazi's identity in February 2015, reporting that he grew up in a well-off family that moved to Britain when he was a child and that he had studied computer science at the University of Westminster. This revelation sparked intense scrutiny of the causes of radicalization among Muslim immigrants in Europe.

Emwazi was part of a group of friends, known as the "North London Boys" by some intelligence analysts, who prayed at the same mosque and became captivated by an Egyptian-born cleric, Hani al-Sibai. Sibai is thought to have close links to the Tunisian branch of Ansar al-Shariah, a Salafist group linked to a deadly attack in June on tourists in Tunisia.

The leader of this network was Bilal al-Berjawi, who was stripped of his British citizenship in 2011 after he went to Somalia to join the Islamist group known as the Shabab. Berjawi was killed by an American drone strike the next year. Another friend, Mohamed Sakr, was also killed by a drone strike in Somalia in the same year.

Title: The Impact of Ongoing Protests on the 2020 Presidential Race: A Neutral Analysis of Biden and Trump's Stances on Police Violence and Criminal Justice Reform

Article:

The ongoing protests against police violence and racial injustice are unfolding across the United States, accompanied by instances of looting and unrest. The impact of these events on the upcoming presidential race between President Donald J. Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden remains uncertain.

Many political analysts predict that the unrest is benefiting Mr. Biden, as they view the protests as a manifestation of widespread dissatisfaction among minority groups, which they believe will drive voters to the polls in large numbers.

However, it is important to note that the polls are still early, and their accuracy is uncertain, especially in the current lockdown environment. While President Trump has made a few missteps, such as his controversial walk across Lafayette Square to St. John's Church, some critics have also questioned the actions of the Democrats, such as their decision to kneel for nine minutes while partially dressed in traditional African garb.

The discussion surrounding the protests and police violence has largely overlooked Mr. Biden, who has made a few statements and public appearances but has not taken a more active role in addressing the issues. Some argue that Mr. Biden, who served in the U.S. Senate from 1973 to 2009 and as vice president for eight years, may be reluctant to discuss his role in past legislation, such as the 1994 Crime Bill, which is widely criticized for contributing to mass incarceration in the United States.

President Trump, on the other hand, has taken a different approach, advocating for criminal justice reform and helping to pass the First Step Act, which has led to the release of people of color who were incarcerated for long periods for minor drug offenses.

The nation's views on race and crime are changing, and it remains to be seen how the two candidates will address these issues in the coming months. As the former vice president emerges from his self-imposed COVID-19 isolation, it will be interesting to see how he addresses the ongoing protests and works to bring an end to the violence, arson, and riots.

Title: Obama Administration's Unilateral Policy Implementation Sparks Controversy

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2010 midterm elections, the Republican party expressed optimism, perceiving President Obama's first two years in office as a period of bipartisan disregard and intentional provocation towards Republicans in order to pass progressive policies. With the GOP gaining control of a small percentage of the federal government, it was anticipated that Obama would reach across the aisle. However, the Obama Administration's approach has deviated significantly from this expectation.

Instead of reforming existing laws, the Administration has opted to not enforce them. This strategy has been applied to various pieces of legislation, including the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), the DREAM Act, and No Child Left Behind.

A White House official stated, "We work to achieve our policy goals in the most effective and appropriate way possible. Often times, Congress has blocked efforts [such as No Child Left Behind and DREAM Act] and we look to pursue other appropriate means of achieving our policy goals."

On gay rights, the administration has also asked agencies to take a less active role. In February 2011, the Justice Department announced it would not defend DOMA against court challenges, an unusual step for the agency, which typically defends legal challenges to laws on the books. This tactic has its roots in the earliest days of the administration, with the Department of Justice announcing in October 2009 that it would not prosecute medical marijuana users or suppliers in states where it is legal, despite state laws contradicting federal law.

This expansion of executive power has been met with criticism, with constitutional scholar Jonathan Turley noting that "President Obama has fulfilled the dream of an imperial presidency that Richard Nixon strived for... this is a President who is now functioning as a super legislator."

Progressives, who previously abhorred such expansions of executive power during the George W. Bush administration, have largely supported President Obama's unilateral power expansions, from drone strikes that kill American citizens to recess appointments made without a recess. This raises questions about the potential consequences of such powers in the hands of "the other side."

Hypothetical scenarios, such as a Republican president announcing that his Environmental Protection Agency is going to halt enforcement of pollution regulations or a Republican's IRS not enforcing the Obamacare mandate, highlight the potential dangers of unilateral policy implementation.

Progressives are encouraged to consider the implications of their support for these unprecedented expansions of executive power.

Title: Majority of Americans Hope for Partial or Full Overturn of 2010 Health Care Law, According to New York Times and CBS News Poll

Article:

A new poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News indicates that more than two-thirds of Americans hope the Supreme Court will overturn some or all of the 2010 health care law. The Supreme Court is expected to decide a challenge to the law by the end of this month.

The poll found that just 24 percent of respondents hoped the court would keep the entire health care law in place. Forty-one percent of those surveyed said the court should strike down the entire law, while another 27 percent said the justices should overturn only the individual mandate, which requires most Americans to obtain health insurance or pay a penalty.

These numbers have not changed much in recent months and appeared to be largely unaffected by the more than six hours of arguments in the Supreme Court in March.

There was greater Republican opposition to the law than Democratic support. About two-thirds of Republicans in the recent survey said the entire law should be overturned, while 43 percent of Democrats said all of the law should be upheld.

More than 70 percent of independent voters said they wanted to see some or all of the law struck down, with a majority saying they hoped to see the whole law overturned. Twenty-two percent of independents said they hoped the entire law would survive.

Responses varied by education as well. Nearly a third of respondents with a college education said they would like to see the law upheld, compared with about 20 percent of those without a college degree.

Legal scholars and political scientists are divided over whether the justices take account of public opinion in making their decisions. In a 2010 study published in The Georgetown Law Journal, Lawrence Baum of Ohio State University and Neal Devins of the College of William & Mary concluded that the justices were not much concerned with mass opinion.

"Supreme Court justices care more about the views of academics, journalists, and other elites than they do about public opinion," they wrote. "This is true of nearly all justices and is especially true of swing justices, who often cast the critical votes in the court's most visible decisions."

The nationwide poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 31 through June 3 on land-lines and cellphones with 976 adults, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

Title: Supreme Court Blocks Enforcement of Louisiana Abortion Law, Potential Implications for Abortion Rights

Article:

The Supreme Court issued a stay on Thursday, blocking enforcement of a Louisiana abortion law that could have nationwide implications for abortion rights. The case, June Medical Services v. Gee, concerns a 2014 Louisiana law requiring abortion providers to have admitting privileges at a local hospital.

In September 2018, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals allowed the law to stand, breaking with Supreme Court precedent. The plaintiffs, represented by the Center for Reproductive Rights, appealed to the Supreme Court and asked for a stay of the law, which was set to go into effect on February 4. Last week, Justice Samuel Alito issued an order blocking the law until Thursday.

The ruling on Thursday blocks enforcement of the law while the Court considers whether to hear the case. If the Court does hear June Medical Services v. Gee, it could be a chance for the justices to revisit and possibly overturn Roe v. Wade, a landmark 1973 decision that legalized abortion nationwide.

The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 to block enforcement of the Louisiana law, with Chief Justice John Roberts joining the Court's four more liberal members. Justices Alito, Kavanaugh, Clarence Thomas, and Neil Gorsuch voted to allow the law to go into effect.

The ruling was a victory for abortion rights advocates, albeit a temporary one. "The Supreme Court has stepped in under the wire to protect the rights of Louisiana women," said Nancy Northup, president and CEO of the Center for Reproductive Rights, in a statement to media outlets. "The three clinics left in Louisiana can stay open while we ask the Supreme Court to hear our case."

Laws requiring admitting privileges have proliferated around the country in recent years. Abortion opponents have argued that these laws are necessary to protect women's health, but courts have generally failed to find evidence for this. Abortion is generally a very safe procedure for the patients who undergo it, and they typically don't need to be admitted to a hospital.

Moreover, abortion providers don't need to have admitting privileges for their patients to visit a hospital. As Judge Richard Posner of the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals wrote in an opinion striking down a Wisconsin admitting privileges law, "A woman who experiences complications from an abortion (either while still at the clinic or at home afterward) will go to the nearest hospital, which will treat her regardless of whether her abortion doctor has admitting privileges."

Some abortion opponents say laws like Louisiana's ensure women a seamless experience if they do suffer complications. Catherine Glenn Foster, president and CEO of Americans United for Life, told ███ that when she had an abortion herself, "I thankfully did not have any kind of emergency there at the clinic. But had I had, I would have wanted a smooth transfer procedure in place."

Meanwhile, the laws have resulted in abortion clinic closures, since it's often difficult for abortion providers to get hospital admitting privileges. That's a concern for opponents of the Louisiana law, which, according to Travis Tu, lead counsel on the case for the Center for Reproductive Rights, would turn Louisiana into "an abortion desert." It would close at least two of the three remaining clinics in Louisiana, a state with 1 million women of reproductive age, Tu said.

In Whole Woman's Health, the Supreme Court ruled that a Texas admitting privileges law was unconstitutional, finding that it "provides few, if any, health benefits for women, poses a substantial obstacle to women seeking abortions, and constitutes an 'undue burden' on their constitutional right to do so."

The Louisiana law is nearly identical to the Texas law, but in September, the Fifth Circuit upheld the Louisiana version, essentially placing itself in direct conflict with the Supreme Court. The Center for Reproductive Rights appealed, asking the Supreme Court to hear the case.

Now that the Court has stopped enforcement of the law, it must decide whether to hear the appeal. If it decides not to take the case, the stay issued on Thursday would end automatically, and the law would go into effect. If the Court does decide to take the case, it will have to decide whether to follow the precedent set in Whole Woman's Health, striking down the Louisiana law, or reverse itself and uphold the law. In the process, it could decide to overturn the protection for abortion rights set forth in Roe v. Wade.

Whole Woman's Health was decided when Justice Anthony Kennedy, typically seen as a moderate, was still on the Court. Now he's been replaced by Kavanaugh—who, while he refused to directly answer questions about Roe during his confirmation hearing, is seen by advocates on both sides as a potential deciding vote to overturn the landmark abortion decision.

Kavanaugh issued an opinion dissenting from Thursday's decision to issue the stay. He argued that the Louisiana law should be allowed to take effect to allow abortion providers to determine if they could, in fact, obtain admitting privileges. Then, if they could not, he said, they could file another challenge to the law.

"In order to resolve the factual uncertainties presented in the stay application about the three doctors' ability to obtain admitting privileges, I would deny the stay," he wrote.

"I was pleased to see the dissent from Justice Kavanaugh," said Foster, noting that he was under no obligation to weigh in publicly.

"As Justice Kavanaugh said, the question presented to us at this time is whether the law imposes an undue burden," she added. "That's the analysis he's looking towards."

If the Court agrees to hear June Medical Services v. Gee, advocates on both sides will be watching Kavanaugh closely, as the future of abortion law in America may be at stake.

Update: This story has been updated with comments from Catherine Glenn Foster, president and CEO of Americans United for Life.

Title: Trump's Legal Dramas and Their Impact on the Democratic Party

Article:

The ongoing legal issues involving President Trump have dominated media coverage since April 30, 2018, with the special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian election interference and the Southern District of New York's investigation into Trump attorney Michael Cohen's business dealings being the main focus. This coverage has been sensationalist and hyperbolic, often portraying each new development as a prelude to Trump's downfall.

However, the Democratic Party has not benefited from Trump's legal dramas, as some might expect. On the contrary, Trump's approval rating has been on the rise, with his highest rating in a year at 44 percent in the Real Clear Politics average. Meanwhile, the Democratic advantage on the congressional generic ballot has been cut in half since December, from plus 13 points to plus 6.5 points.

One possible explanation for Trump's continued approval is the strong economy, with its positive job market and wage growth. Another is the desire for peace, as President Trump's desire to meet with Kim Jong-un of North Korea has been embraced by voters.

However, another explanation is that the American electorate has not fundamentally changed since the Clinton presidency. The electorate still holds a "bifurcated view" that separates the man from his policies, and as long as the policies seem to be working, the man's opponents find themselves waiting for voters to recognize and repudiate defects of character.

Trump became president despite majority personal disapproval, and his victory depended on a coalition between his devoted fans and more traditional Republican voters who, despite misgivings, supported him because they concluded that the alternative was worse personally and politically.

The incessant focus on Trump's legal issues not only occupies the attention of Democrats and the anti-Trump Resistance to the exclusion of other topics but also relieves them of any responsibility to come up with a substantive message. The voters, by contrast, read the headlines with a cursory or prurient interest as they go about their lives in the real world of work, family, community, and faith.

The tax bill passed in December, yet Trump's approval began its most recent rise in March, when he announced his first round of steel and aluminum tariffs. It is Trump's desire to combat offshoring and deindustrialization, more than the tax bill, that is galvanizing his base and strengthening his economic message.

College-educated voters and suburban women disgusted with Trump may be enough to win the Democrats a slim House majority. However, Democrats won't find themselves in a truly commanding position until they make inroads among the Rust Belt voters who abandoned Hillary Clinton for the president. The more the party focuses on Robert Mueller and Stormy Daniels, the less likely it is to recognize the appeal of Trump's economic message and to adjust accordingly. The more the party falls for the self-flattery, empty rhetoric, question begging, and maze-like complexity of media narratives—not to mention the more it succumbs to the fever-dream of impeachment—the less likely it is to recoup the power it once enjoyed.

Title: Representative Charlie Rangel Criticizes Tea Party, Labels Them a "Cult"

Article:

In a recent statement, U.S. Representative Charlie Rangel (D-NY) expressed his criticism of the conservative wing of the Republican Party, specifically the Tea Party movement. Rangel referred to the Tea Party as a "cult" and described their actions as "illness."

During a speech, Rangel stated, "Politics is changing for me at this late age, to have to deal with a cult-type of group of people." The congressman, who has been in office since 1971, has recently allocated millions of taxpayer dollars to a New York library named in his honor.

Rangel criticized the Tea Party for their efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. He said, "When a handful of people can control a larger number of people, to repeal a law that has been passed by the House, the Senate, and declared constitutional by the courts - and they campaign on the issue that it should be repealed- this is past Civics 101. This is illness."

Rangel's comments have sparked controversy and criticism, with some accusing him of butchering a sense of civics and constitutional law. The individual mandate of Obamacare was ruled constitutional by the Supreme Court, but there are ongoing legal challenges against the law and its regulations.

Rangel's statement that repealing laws is an "illness" has been met with criticism and has been added to the liberal-lunacy highlight reel of 2013. Some argue that supporters of Obamacare may be the ones suffering from mental illness, given their support for a law that has been criticized for its potential impact on economic vitality and individual liberty.

The Tea Party movement is often described as a collection of like-minded individuals who have banded together for political clout. Rangel's labeling of the movement as a "cult" has been met with criticism, as the Tea Party has not been known for using taxpayer funds to build facilities named in their honor, unlike some members of Congress.

Rangel's comments illustrate a growing trend in American politics, with some politicians and pundits labeling small government advocates as radical, dangerous, and mutinous to government action. The Tea Party movement has been a prominent force in American politics since the 2009 taxpayer protests, and their influence continues to be felt in the political landscape.

Title: FBI Warns of Zoombombing Incidents as Zoom's Popularity Surges

Article:

In a recent development, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has issued a warning about using the video conferencing platform Zoom, following a series of incidents known as "Zoombombing." This form of harassment involves intruders hijacking video calls and posting offensive content such as hate speech, pornography, and racial slurs.

Dennis Johnson, a doctoral student at California State University, Long Beach, was a victim of such an incident last week during his dissertation defense. Johnson, who was the first member of his family to graduate from college, had a large audience of around 40 people, including friends, family, classmates, and his dissertation committee.

During his presentation, an intruder drew male genitalia on the screen, causing confusion among the participants. The attacker then scrawled a racial slur that was visible to everyone on the call. Johnson was left shaken, and the intended celebration was ruined.

Similar incidents have disrupted Alcoholics Anonymous meetings in New York, Sunday school in Texas, online classes at the University of Southern California, and a city meeting in Kalamazoo, Michigan. With schools closed and millions of people working from home, Zoom has become increasingly popular. The company reported that 200 million people used the app daily in March, up from just 10 million in December.

In response to the concerns, Zoom has taken steps to address the issues. It published a guide on how users can protect meetings and changed settings for accounts used by schools and universities to make their meetings more private by default. However, the company is currently facing scrutiny due to reported flaws in its software that could allow hackers to spy through a computer's webcam or microphone.

New York Attorney General Letitia James has sent a letter to Zoom asking about its security and privacy protections. Security researcher Patrick Wardle, who previously worked at the National Security Agency, has also turned up flaws in Zoom's software. Zoom says it has released fixes for these issues.

In a blog post, Zoom CEO Eric Yuan acknowledged the company's shortcomings and stated that they are focusing on fixing their privacy and security problems. "We recognize that we have fallen short of the community's – and our own – privacy and security expectations," Yuan wrote. "For that, I am deeply sorry, and I want to share what we are doing about it."

Title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Reopening Joint Industrial Complex with South Korea

Article:

North and South Korea have reached an agreement to hold talks on reopening the Kaesong industrial complex, a symbol of cooperation between the two nations that was shuttered in April. This marks the first step toward cooperation between the two countries since its closure.

Pyongyang had previously rejected all offers to discuss reopening the Kaesong industrial complex. Some observers speculate that North Korea's acquiescence now signals it is feeling dangerously isolated from China, a vital ally that has indicated frustration with North Korean intransigence and has warmed up to US-led efforts to isolate Pyongyang.

According to the International Crisis Group's senior analyst Daniel Pinkston, during a meeting between North Korean and Chinese officials last month, China may not have been "as generous as the North Koreans have been expecting in terms of aid, trade, and investment." Jo Dong Ho, a North Korean Studies professor at Ewha Womans University, stated that Chinese pressure has left the North with "no choice but to cooperate with the South to get the economy going."

Koh Yu-hwan, a North Korea expert at Seoul's Dongguk University, suggested that Pyongyang's announcement is timed for US-China talks scheduled for later this week. Kim Yong Hyun, a Seoul-based professor of North Korean Studies at Dongguk University, stated that China is the "key" when it comes to North Korea strategies.

China has taken a tougher stance on North Korea, as the US hoped it would. It has supported tighter United Nations sanctions in response to the February nuclear test and stepped up border inspections. Most notably, a leading Chinese state bank shut accounts of North Korea’s Foreign Trade Bank, its main foreign exchange institution.

Two weeks ago, China hosted a top North Korean envoy, a visit that was expedited in advance of the U.S.-China summit that starts Friday. The North has since adopted a less confrontational stance and declared a willingness to return to the negotiating table.

Chinese academics are more willing now to openly consider the prospect of a North Korean collapse. However, China is not taking steps that could hasten the end of the Kim regime, such as cutting supplies.

If the talks happen, they will be the first time officials from the two countries meet directly since February 2011. The North has preferred private talks through nongovernmental channels such as businessmen, but the South has been emphatic in its demands for government-to-government talks.

All outstanding issues that have strained cross-border relations will be on the table, including the disconnecting of the hotline between the North and South earlier this year. The closure of the complex came on the heels of tightened UN sanctions after North Korea's third nuclear test in February and the holding of regular US-South Korea military drills. The North pulled its 50,000 workers from the complex and blocked deliveries. South Korean workers eventually departed as well.

Agreeing to talks could indicate that "the cost of closure of Kaesong is greater than [the North] had anticipated," said Daniel Pinkston, according to CNN. Launched during the "sunshine" era of North-South engagement as a symbol of cooperation, it provides inexpensive labor for South Korean companies and critical foreign currency for isolated North Korea, largely shut out of the global financial system by sanctions.

"There's political symbolism, economic aspects, and nationalistic Pan-Korean elements wrapped up in it as well. The loss if Kaesong is not reopened is more than material," Pinkston said in an interview with the Guardian.

Title: Senior Trump Official Anonymously Criticizes President in New York Times Op-Ed

Article:

A senior official in President Donald Trump's administration has written an opinion piece in the New York Times, criticizing the President's decision-making and expressing concerns about his fitness for office. The author, who remains anonymous, describes a group of officials working to thwart parts of the President's agenda to protect the country from his "worst impulses."

The official writes that there were early discussions among Cabinet members about invoking the 25th Amendment, a constitutional provision that outlines the process for removing a president who is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. However, the official states that no one wanted to precipitate a constitutional crisis, and they are instead working to steer the administration in the right direction.

The opinion piece comes amidst a series of reports describing chaos within the White House, including excerpts from a book by famed Watergate reporter Bob Woodward. Defense Secretary James Mattis reportedly rejected a recommendation from Trump for the U.S. military to kill Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, according to Woodward's book. Mattis dismissed the book as "a uniquely Washington brand of literature," and Trump has called it "total fiction."

Trump himself responded to the opinion piece by calling it a "gutless editorial" and a "failing" New York Times. He also questioned whether the anonymous author was committing treason and suggested that the Times should turn the author over to the government. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who is currently on a visit to India, denied authorship of the piece.

The opinion piece has fueled accusations that Trump is unstable and unfit for the presidency, and has resurrected talk among some Democrats about potentially impeaching the President should they take control of the U.S. House of Representatives in November elections. The identity of the author remains unknown, and there is speculation in Washington about whether the piece came from someone within the White House or another government agency.

Title: U.S. Lawmakers Debate Military Intervention in Syria as Obama Weighs Options

Article:

In the aftermath of Syria's accusation that Israel, a close U.S. ally, launched rockets into the country, American lawmakers have expressed varying opinions on whether the United States should supply Syrian rebel forces with weapons.

Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican, argued that President Barack Obama should intervene militarily, stating, "The whole situation is becoming more and more expansive, and unfortunately, the red line that the president of the United States had written was apparently written in disappearing ink."

The Obama administration recently acknowledged evidence of chemical weapons use in Syria, a situation that Obama had previously identified as a "red line." However, the president has expressed a desire to gather all the facts before taking any action.

Sen. McCain suggested establishing a "safe zone" in Syria, taking out the Syrian government's air assets, supplying the rebel forces with the necessary weapons, and avoiding American boots on the ground.

Rep. Peter King, former chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, expressed concern that providing weapons to the rebel forces might be "counterproductive," as he believes some of the rebels could end up in the wrong hands, potentially strengthening al-Qaeda elements.

Sen. Pat Leahy, D-Vermont, agreed that some groups within the rebel forces include radical elements. Rep. Tom Cotton, a veteran of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, felt more strongly, stating that arming the rebels is "something that should have been done months ago."

Rep. Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, suggested that the U.S. could be "hugely helpful" in bringing down the Assad government by providing intelligence and training, but not boots on the ground.

White House deputy press secretary Josh Earnest stated that the president feels "that the Israelis are justifiably concerned about the threat posed by Hezbollah obtaining these advanced weapon systems." The president, according to Earnest, has often expressed his view that Israel, as a sovereign government, has the right to take the actions necessary to protect its people.

Title: Hundreds of Workers Arrested in Mississippi Immigration Raids at Food-Processing Plants

Article:

Federal immigration officials, under the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), conducted raids on seven agricultural processing plants across Mississippi on Wednesday, resulting in the arrest of approximately 680 individuals believed to be working in the U.S. without authorization. The raids were carried out by more than 600 ICE agents, who surrounded the targeted plants to prevent workers, primarily Latino immigrants, from escaping.

The raids, according to an ICE statement, were conducted by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's Homeland Security Investigations (HSI). In addition to the arrests, agents seized company business records. The targeted plants are near Jackson and are owned by five companies, as reported by The Associated Press.

One of the plants is owned by Koch Foods Inc., a U.S. poultry processor with more than 13,000 employees and an estimated $3.2 billion in annual revenue, according to Fortune. Another plant, in Canton, Miss., is owned by Peco Foods Inc., the eighth-largest poultry producer in the U.S., according to the company's website. Neither company responded to requests for comment.

The arrested workers were transported to a local Mississippi National Guard hangar, where they were interviewed about their immigration status, including whether they already had deportation orders.

Julia Solórzano, an attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center, stated, "Today's raids are part of the ongoing war against immigrant families and the communities in which they live." She also noted the timing of the raids, which occurred days after immigrants were targeted by a gunman in El Paso, Texas.

The size of the raid operation recalls a similar incident in 2008, when more than 400 unauthorized workers were arrested in a meatpacking facility in Iowa under the George W. Bush administration. No further details about the current status of the arrested individuals or the future plans of the companies involved were available at the time of publication.

Title: Partisanship and the U.S.-Israel Relationship: A Look at the Netanyahu-Obama Rift

Article:

The ongoing controversy surrounding Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's address to the U.S. Congress has highlighted the role of partisanship in upending the status quo, particularly in relation to the U.S.'s relationship with Iran.

The White House has found itself navigating the partisan divide, with Netanyahu's controversial visit to Congress potentially dismantling a bipartisan consensus that once posed a significant domestic threat to the U.S.'s rapport with Iran. This potential deal, which could be a crowning achievement of President Obama's foreign policy legacy, has been a contentious issue due to opposition from both Republicans and staunch pro-Israel members of the Democratic party.

Netanyahu's decision to accept an invitation from House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) without notifying the White House or the State Department has been criticized, with even Fox News anchors questioning his treatment of the president. His refusal to meet with Democratic Senators Dick Durbin (Ill.) and Dianne Feinstein (Calif.) further exacerbated the perceived partisanship.

The repercussions of this partisan stance have been significant. As reported by The New York Times, a former Israeli official lamented, "Since when does an Israeli prime minister say no to a meeting with Democrats?"

The Obama administration's response has been firm. The White House has snubbed Netanyahu, with both President Obama and Vice President Joe Biden choosing not to meet with him. The administration has also not confirmed whether anyone will attend the annual summit of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a powerful pro-Israel lobby. [Update: Rice and Samantha Power, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N., will attend.]

In a highly public manner, the White House has taken the fight to Netanyahu. National Security Advisor Susan Rice described Netanyahu's speech as "destructive" to U.S.-Israeli relations, a strong term that goes beyond diplomatic language. Secretary of State John Kerry used his testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee to remind everyone that Netanyahu supported the U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003.

This partisan rift has significant implications for those who believe a U.S. accord with Iran would spell doom for Israel. However, for those who advocate for diplomacy and negotiations, they might find partisanship to be a useful tool in this instance. As Dov Zakheim writes at Foreign Policy, "Netanyahu's determination to address Congress has all but destroyed any chance the Hill's passing new sanctions and overriding a presidential veto. The deal will therefore go ahead."

Title: Congress Members Announce Absence from President-elect Trump's Inauguration, Citing Policy Disagreements and Concerns Over Administration's Actions

Article:

Several members of Congress have announced their intention to skip President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, citing policy disagreements and concerns over the administration's actions. In response to questions about the appropriateness of Mr. Trump's Twitter posts given the biography and record of Representative John Lewis, Vice President-elect Mike Pence stated that the president-elect "has the right to defend himself" and that Mr. Trump aimed to call attention to Democratic policy failures in America's cities.

A spokesman for the Trump transition team declined to provide further comment.

Among those who have announced they will not attend the inauguration are Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the dean of the House of Representatives, and Representative Barbara Lee of California. Conyers stated that he would work to ensure accountability within the administration and adherence to the Constitution and national laws. Lee expressed concern over Mr. Trump's treatment of the African-American community and the potential reflection of such views in his policies.

Other members of Congress who have announced their absence from the inauguration include Representatives Raúl M. Grijalva of Arizona, Maxine Waters of California, Luis V. Gutiérrez of Illinois, Katherine M. Clark of Massachusetts, William Lacy Clay of Missouri, Nydia M. Velázquez, Jerrold Nadler, and José E. Serrano of New York, Marcia L. Fudge of Ohio, Earl Blumenauer and Kurt Schrader of Oregon, and Mark Pocan of Wisconsin.

Mr. Trump received scant support from the black community before his transition, with only about 8 percent of blacks voting for him on Nov. 8. The relationship between the president-elect and the black community appears to have further deteriorated with the appointment of Stephen K. Bannon, the former head of Breitbart News, as White House chief strategist, with some fearing that Bannon will bring nationalist and racist views to the West Wing.

The Rev. Al Sharpton led a march in Washington on Saturday, with Mr. Trump's Twitter posts reportedly driving more people to brave the cold to demonstrate.

Title: Trump Proposes Child Care Affordability Plan in Philadelphia Suburbs, Attacks Clinton on "Deplorables" Remark

Article:

In a visit to the Philadelphia suburbs on Tuesday, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump unveiled his "Child Care Affordability Plan." The plan, aimed primarily at suburban women voters, includes tax deductions for child care expenses, six weeks of paid maternity leave, and the creation of "Dependent Care Savings Accounts" to finance various expenses, including childhood development and elderly care.

Trump addressed a supportive crowd in Aston, Pennsylvania, stating, "It's pro-family, it's pro-child, it's pro-worker. These are the people we have to take care of." Trump's daughter, Ivanka Trump, who has been advocating for child care issues in her role as campaign adviser, introduced her father, telling the crowd that "we need to create policies that champion all parents."

Trump also criticized Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton for her "basket of deplorables" remark, slamming her in both Pennsylvania and at an earlier rally in Iowa. Clinton's campaign responded with a television ad juxtaposing Trump's comments about voters with his own past attacks on voters, including a comment from last year about then-GOP primary rival Ben Carson: "How stupid are the people of Iowa? How stupid are the people of this country to believe this crap?"

Maya Harris, a senior policy adviser for the Clinton campaign, described Trump's child care plan as "half-baked," with financing to come from other programs like unemployment insurance. Harris added, "The lack of seriousness of this proposal is no surprise, given his history of disrespecting women in the workplace and the fact there’s no evidence he ever provided paid family leave or child care to his own employees."

The Clinton campaign has released new radio ads highlighting her "lifelong commitment to fighting for children and families." Among her proposals is a plan to make preschool universal for 4-year-olds. The Trump campaign views Pennsylvania as a key part of its effort to secure the 270 electoral votes needed to win the presidency, though the state has not backed a GOP presidential candidate since 1988.

Current polls give Democratic nominee Clinton an edge in Pennsylvania, with an average of around 6 points, according to the website RealClearPolitics. Some of those same surveys show low marks for Trump among suburban women, one of the targets of Trump's speech in Aston.

The specifics of Trump's child care proposals, according to the campaign statement, include:

* Trump's proposed tax deductions for child care expenses are capped, with individuals making more than $250,000 and joint filers making more than $500,000 not eligible.
* Lower income taxpayers would be eligible for rebates through the Earned Income Tax Credit.
* Trump's proposed Dependent Care Savings Accounts could be financed by tax-deductible contributions and tax-free appreciation, and parents could use them to finance traditional child care, after-school programs, and tuition for private schools, as well as elder care for aged parents.

The campaign did not provide cost estimates, but indicated that they would be financed through elimination of waste and fraud in current programs.

Title: Michael Brown's Parents File Civil Lawsuit Against Ferguson, Former Officer Darren Wilson

Article:

The parents of Michael Brown, the unarmed man who was fatally shot by a Ferguson, Missouri police officer last August, have filed a civil lawsuit against the city, former police chief Thomas Jackson, and Darren Wilson, the officer who shot Brown. The lawsuit was filed by Michael Brown Sr. and Lesley McSpadden at the St. Louis County Courthouse on Thursday morning.

The lawsuit alleges that Wilson "unjustifiably shot and killed" Brown, using "an unnecessary and unreasonable" amount of force. The lawsuit, which can be read at the St. Louis Public Radio site, also claims that Jackson was responsible for hiring, training, and supervising Wilson.

Following the lawsuit's filing, family attorney Benjamin Crump stated that the Ferguson Police Department's internal culture made events like Brown's death predictable. "To this day, we still do not believe that the shooter of an unarmed 18-year-old teenager has never been cross-examined," Brown said after the lawsuit was filed.

Crump added that the family has been seeking a "thorough independent review" in which Wilson could potentially be challenged. Crump also noted that the family will not be seeking a specific amount in monetary damages.

The legal team expects the civil suit to rely on much of the same evidence presented in state and federal investigations into the police shooting. However, attorney Anthony Gray stated that the lawsuit will provide a "more accurate picture of what took place that day."

The investigations into Brown's death did not result in indictments for Wilson. However, a Department of Justice report on the city's police department found "a pattern of unconstitutional policing."

Title: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer Faces Decision on Confirmation Process for Trump Nominees

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) is facing pressure from both sides as he navigates the confirmation process for President Trump's nominees. On one hand, he is confronted with a restless Democratic caucus and a group of activists, allegedly funded by George Soros, demanding he block eight Trump nominees. These groups, self-proclaimed as a "Resistance," are pushing for a "scorched earth" approach, aiming to obstruct good appointees. On the other hand, moderate voices within the Democratic caucus urge Schumer to calm the passions and act responsibly.

The Democratic Party's response to President Trump's election has reached a critical point, with delayed concession, recount attempts, and accusations of Russian interference. Now, the Senate Democrats, including seven up for reelection from Trump-win states, are opposing presidential appointments without pretense of regular order or apology. This has led to a media firestorm, with major news outlets reporting attacks on nominees by Democrat-funded groups, while Democratic Senators offer outraged sound bites.

The Democratic Party finds itself at a crossroads, with the potential for significant consequences. Under President Obama, Democrats have lost 1,042 governing seats in Congress, state legislatures, governorships, and the presidency. If the party continues its lurch to the left, it may risk alienating the American electorate and facing further losses.

Senator Schumer's actions could determine the future of the Democratic Party. If he succumbs to the demands of the Radical Left, the Democratic Party may face a decline in public respect and support. Conversely, if Schumer restores propriety to the role of Minority Leader, the "scorched earth" approach will wane.

Americans do not subscribe to extremism or radical responses to electoral loss. If the Democratic Party continues to engage in anti-democratic behavior, it risks losing the respect of the American people and any hope of restoring a centrist identity.

Schumer's decision will have far-reaching implications for the 2018 and 2020 elections. If he chooses to obstruct the confirmation process, President Trump may label the Senate Democrats' actions as off-balance, out-of-touch with America, and his party hijacked. This could lead to increased Democratic defections and a further decline in the party's standing.

On the other hand, if Schumer ensures a swift and orderly confirmation process for Trump's nominees, he may help restore the Democratic Party's reputation and avoid the potential decline into Whig status. The choice Schumer makes may determine the Democratic Party's fate for years to come.

In the words of Robert Frost, "Two roads diverged in a wood, and I—I took the one less traveled by, and that has made all the difference." Schumer's decision could have lasting consequences for the Democratic Party and the confirmation process as a whole. Americans are watching, and they want a respectful, fair, and orderly process. Anything else smacks of extremism.

Title: South Koreans Carry on with Life as Normal Amid North Korean Threats

Article:

In the bustling metropolis of Seoul, South Korea, there is no discernible fear or anxiety among the populace despite the ongoing threats from North Korea. The city, which is just 30 miles from the demilitarized zone separating the two countries, is a scant minutes' target if a full-scale war were to break out.

North Korea possesses an array of artillery and other conventional weapons that make its military a credible threat, especially to South Korea. Pyongyang is also believed to have thousands of tons of chemical agents, although it has denied possessing such weapons.

Despite these threats, South Koreans seem to have grown accustomed to the constant warnings and threats from the North. "We know North Korea doesn't want war," said one South Korean resident. "They want money and food." The resident added that North Korea has tried various tactics, such as missile launches, the nuclear threat, and its million-man army, to blackmail the South.

Former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, who visited Seoul this week, told a gathering at the Asian Leadership Conference that North Korea understands that an attack on South Korea, much less the United States, would mean "regime-ending" retaliation. He encouraged the South Koreans to focus on jobs, human dignity, the environment, and poverty reduction.

South Koreans seem overwhelmingly willing to take this advice. In the week the author spent in Seoul, they found only one woman who remembered participating in civilian air raid drills 30 years ago. Today, Seoul's 25 million people have no ambition to live in constant fear.

However, the threat of armed provocation is very real in a select few flashpoint areas. The prospect of war is unthinkable in Seoul, but in these areas, the threat is indeed real.

The author stood on a street corner near CNN's Seoul offices and looked up at the jagged peaks behind the Blue House, the South Korean presidential office. If missiles ever did come streaking toward the South Korean capital, they would likely arc above those mountains. The nearest shelter would be the subway system. The author considered how long it would take to reach the subway, even if they were lucky enough to see the missiles still short of their targets. The calculations were not at all comforting.

Like everyone around them, the author decided to think about something else.

Title: Kathy Griffin Apologizes for Controversial Trump Decapitation Artwork

Article:

Comedian Kathy Griffin has issued an apology for a performance art project that involved her holding a model of a decapitated head designed to resemble President Donald Trump. The controversial artwork, which drew widespread criticism and backlash, may have inadvertently brought about a rare moment of national unity since Trump's unexpected election.

Griffin's stunt was reportedly inspired by a scene from a 2011 episode of Game of Thrones, which featured the severed head of former President George W. Bush. Producers later apologized for the scene and edited it out of later screenings.

In the aftermath, Griffin initially defended her actions, tweeting, "Obviously, I do not condone any violence... I'm merely mocking the mocker in chief." However, she later deleted these tweets and removed the image from her social media accounts.

The photo, which marked a new low for Griffin, known for her provocative humor, was particularly shocking due to Griffin's admission of wrongdoing. Until now, her critics might have assumed she was unaware of crossing a line, but she seemed genuinely remorseful when she tweeted, "I am sorry. I went too far. I was wrong."

Griffin acknowledged that the image was "too disturbing" and "not funny," and that she understood "how it offends people."

The backlash on social media was swift and widespread, with famous and not-so-famous individuals across the political spectrum condemning Griffin's actions. CNN, where Griffin co-hosts New Year's Eve, terminated its contract with her. CNN's Anderson Cooper tweeted, "For the record, I am appalled by the photo shoot Kathy Griffin took part in. It is clearly disgusting and completely inappropriate."

President Trump also responded, tweeting, "Griffin should be ashamed of herself... My children, especially my 11-year-old son, Barron, are having a hard time with this. Sick!"

Former First Daughter Chelsea Clinton shared similar sentiments, tweeting, "This is vile and wrong. It is never funny to joke about killing a president." Actress Debra Messing, a Hillary Clinton supporter, said, "It wasn't right when people (sic) hung lynched Obama effigies, just as what Kathy Griffin did isn't right now."

Even the Secret Service reacted, stating, "Threats made against @SecretService protectees receive the highest priority of all our investigations."

Kathy Griffin crossed a line, even for Trump critics, and her actions sparked a significant backlash on social media. The controversy may have inadvertently brought the country together in defense of President Trump, marking a rare moment of unity.

Dave Berg, author of Behind the Curtain: An Insider's View of Jay Leno's Tonight Show, co-produced the show for 18 years. Follow him on Twitter: @TonightShowDave.

Read diverse opinions from our Board of Contributors and other writers on the Opinion front page, on Twitter @USATOpinion and in our daily Opinion newsletter. To submit a letter, comment, or column, check our submission guidelines.

Title: Libyan Crisis: Two Camps Form Amid Calls for Stability as Former General Gains Allies

Article:

A power struggle is unfolding in Libya as a former general, Khalifa Haftar, seems to be gaining allies among armed factions in a self-described campaign to restore stability. The country's interim parliament, dominated by Islamist politicians, and their rivals are emerging as two distinct camps. Haftar's forces have attacked Islamist militias in Benghazi and claimed credit for an attack on the General National Congress (GNC), the parliament's official name.

In an attempt to diffuse the crisis, acting prime minister Abdullah Al-Thinni called on the GNC to vote immediately on a 2014 budget and to confirm his successor, the prime minister-elect, before a recess and elections for a new interim legislature. If confirmed, the new premier would be Libya's fifth since the fall of the Qaddafi dictatorship in 2011. However, past changes of leadership have failed to stop interference by powerful militias, and the GNC has been regularly deadlocked since its election in 2012.

Tripoli remains calm but tense as residents await the legislators' response to Mr. Thinni's proposal. Foreign embassies are on alert amid fears of widening conflict. The crisis reflects a rift between Islamist politicians who dominate the GNC and their non-Islamist rivals, but it is also drawing in armed groups who seem to be predominantly motivated by regional ties and opportunism.

Last Friday, forces under Mr. Haftar attacked Islamist militias in Benghazi that he said authorities had failed to rein in. On Sunday, militiamen apparently aligned with Haftar attacked the GNC building in Tripoli. Haftar is demanding that the parliament cede its role to a constitutional drafting committee elected in February; he insists that he does not aspire to lead Libya.

In Benghazi, Haftar has won a degree of support from residents who hope he can put an end to a pattern of bombings, shootings, and abductions often blamed on hardline Islamist militias. Powerful militias from the city of Zintan, who reportedly took part in Sunday's attack on the GNC, seem to support Haftar, and yesterday, the Benghazi-based special forces unit of Libya's fledgling army pledged support as well, according to Reuters reports. Ibrahim Jadhran, a militia leader in eastern Libya who has seized oil ports to use as leverage to obtain greater regional autonomy, has also reportedly joined Haftar's camp, according to the Libya Herald.

The GNC's speaker has summoned other militias, notably from the city of Misrata, to Tripoli to resist what he describes as an anti-democratic power-grab by Haftar's camp, according to the Associated Press. It is unclear whether Misrata militias, which have a history of rivalry with their Zintan counterparts, have entered the city.

If the GNC heeds Thinni's appeal to vote without delay on the budget and prime minister from a secret location, as an unnamed legislator said it was, according to AP, it could ease tensions over the interim parliament and help prevent further fighting. The former cabinet member, who spoke on condition of anonymity, described the proposal as "very reasonable," but cautioned that Libya will need diplomatic guidance from allies such as the US and the European Union to resolve the crisis.

Failure to reach a compromise could push Libya into further bloodshed that might draw in more of the country's armed groups. However, ordinary Libyans have no stomach for fighting, the former cabinet member says. While some residents of Benghazi see in Haftar a possible source of stability, others there remain skeptical of his apparent lack of a long-term agenda for the city and unclear ambitions. "Is he qualified to run a city?" the former cabinet member asks. "Does he believe in elections? Would he act with vengeance?"

Title: U.S. and China Announce Greenhouse Gas Reduction Targets Ahead of Global Climate Agreement

Article:

The United States and China, the world's two largest carbon dioxide emitters, unveiled ambitious targets on Wednesday to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in an effort to foster a global agreement on climate change next year.

President Obama announced that the U.S. would cut its emissions by 26% to 28% below 2005 levels by 2025, a deeper reduction than previously planned and more than the 17% reduction previously targeted through 2020. Most of the action will be required after President Obama leaves office in 2017.

Chinese President Xi Jinping did not commit to a specific reduction in emissions but said China, which is still building coal-burning plants, would set a target of capping its greenhouse gas emissions by around 2030.

President Obama described the U.S. goals as "ambitious," stating that the accelerated pace of cuts will improve public health and boost jobs. He praised China for agreeing to "slow, peak and then reverse" its carbon emissions eventually.

China is also pledging to get about 20% of its energy from non-fossil fuel sources by 2030. It was unclear how feasible it would be for either country to meet their goals, and President Obama's pledge was sure to confront tough opposition from ascendant Republicans in Congress.

Incoming Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has frequently denounced President Obama's "war on coal" and wants to cut funding to the Environmental Protection Agency. In a statement after the deal was announced, Mr. McConnell said the new targets agreed to by President Obama are "unrealistic."

"Our economy can't take the president's ideological War on Coal that will increase the squeeze on middle-class families and struggling miners," Mr. McConnell said. "This unrealistic plan, that the president would dump on his successor, would ensure higher utility rates and far fewer jobs."

He added, "The president said his policies were on the ballot, and the American people spoke up against them. It's time for more listening, and less job-destroying red tape. Easing the burden already created by EPA regulations will continue to be a priority for me in the new Congress."

Environmental groups praised the deal, saying it would create momentum for a global climate-change pact in Paris next year among nearly 200 nations. Andrew Steer, president of the World Resources Institute, said, "It's a new day to have the leaders of the U.S. and China stand shoulder-to-shoulder and make significant commitments to curb their country's emissions. They have both clearly acknowledged the mounting threat of climate change and the urgency of action. It's heartening to see this level of cooperation."

It was the first time that China has agreed, at least in principle, to cap its greenhouse gas emissions. President Obama said his visit to China produced a "remarkable scope" of agreements with Beijing, including a pact to extend visa limits for Chinese citizens and an understanding to expand an information technology agreement on the export of electronic goods.

Title: American Prisoners Freed by North Korea: A Diplomatic Milestone

Article:

President Donald Trump welcomed three American prisoners freed by North Korea on Thursday morning, marking a significant diplomatic milestone between the longtime adversaries. The freed prisoners, Kim Dong-chul, Tony Kim, and Kim Hak-song, were escorted back to the U.S. by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. They arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside of Washington, D.C., at 2:42 a.m. Thursday.

Shortly after their arrival, President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump boarded the plane to meet the Americans before accompanying them to the tarmac. President Trump, addressing a crowd of journalists, stated, "I am pleased to inform you that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is in the air and on his way back from North Korea with the three wonderful gentlemen that everyone is looking so forward to meeting."

The release, largely seen as a goodwill gesture by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, could pave the way for a new era of U.S.-North Korea relations after heightened tensions last year saw President Trump and Kim threaten each other with nuclear strikes. The U.S. had long demanded the Korean-American citizens' release, with two of the men taken captive last year, while Kim Dong-chul has been detained since 2015. No other Americans are believed to be imprisoned in North Korea.

Kim Dong-chul, Tony Kim, and Kim Hak-song were taken to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center for medical examinations after their meeting with the president and Vice President Pence. President Trump tweeted Wednesday morning that they appeared to be "in good health." However, U.S. officials are likely cautious after the last American to be released from North Korean custody, Otto Warmbier, died shortly upon his return to the U.S. Warmbier's family is suing North Korea, stating their son, who suffered from severe brain damage, was "brutally tortured and murdered" by the country.

The Americans' release came during Pompeo's second visit to North Korea this year. In his latest trip, The New York Times reported, Pompeo secured the Americans' freedom Wednesday after ensuring stronger ties with North Korea in exchange for the country's promise to desert its nuclear weapons program.

"For decades, we have been adversaries," Pompeo said during a lunch hosted by the North Koreans. "Now we are hopeful that we can work together to resolve this conflict, take away threats to the world, and make your country have all the opportunities your people so richly deserve."

Alongside the detainees, Trump told reporters from the tarmac of Andrews Air Force Base that his "proudest achievement will be when we denuclearize that entire [Korean] peninsula." Vice President Pence stated in an interview on ABC's "Good Morning America" that the release of the prisoners signaled a willingness by the North to negotiate in a way that appears "different" from past efforts.

Throughout much of his first year in office, Trump repeatedly exchanged threats and insults with North Korea, once warning in a speech to the United Nations that he would "totally destroy" the country if Pyongyang threatened the U.S. and its allies. Trump is expected to meet with Kim for the first time in Singapore, though the White House has yet to reveal further details, and officials cautioned that the president may not yet have given his final approval. The meeting could take place in late May or early June.

Title: Treasury Secretary's Potential Adjustment of Withholding Tables in Tax Debate Remains Hypothetical

Article:
