In the ongoing tax debate in Washington D.C., a new proposal has emerged, suggesting that Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner could temporarily shield middle-class taxpayers from potential tax hikes if no agreement is reached to prevent the expiration of Bush-era tax rates in January. This proposal does not involve ignoring tax laws or collecting different amounts of tax than what is due.

The proposal suggests that Geithner could adjust the withholding tables used by employers to determine how much to deduct from workers' paychecks for their taxes. By leaving the withholding tables unchanged for lower-income workers, it could create the appearance that their taxes have not increased. However, this is a risky strategy, as it requires a precise prediction of the eventual tax rate and the exact time it will take effect.

It is essential to clarify that this proposal does not change the amount of tax owed. If the tax rate increases, individuals will still owe more money. The proposal's purpose is to adjust the withholding tables, not the tax rates themselves.

In terms of solving the ongoing tax debate, this plan does not offer a resolution. The proposal remains a hypothetical solution, and its implementation would depend on various factors, including the exact tax rate and the timing of its implementation.

Title: Germanwings Flight 4U 9525 Crashes in French Alps, Killing All 150 On Board

Article:

An Airbus A320 aircraft operated by Germanwings, a low-cost subsidiary of Lufthansa, has crashed in the French Alps, likely resulting in the deaths of all 150 people on board, French officials stated. The plane, Flight 4U 9525, was traveling from Barcelona, Spain, to Duesseldorf, Germany.

As night fell on the area, French authorities called off the search operations, with plans to resume Wednesday morning, according to France 24. Germanwings CEO Thomas Winkelmann reported that the plane began descending after reaching its regular height and dropped for eight minutes. The plane's cruising altitude is 38,000 feet, according to FlightAware.com.

Winkelmann said the plane lost contact with French radar and French air traffic control at 10:55 a.m. local time when it was at a height of about 6,000 feet. "We cannot say at this point in time why our colleague decided to lower the plane as swiftly as he did," Winkelmann said. "We do not have any information about why he brought the plane down so quickly to a lower height."

At a subsequent news conference in Barcelona's El Prat airport, Heike Birlenbach, a Lufthansa vice president, said, "For the time being, we say it's an accident. There's nothing more that we can say right now. Everything else would be speculation." Eric Heraud, a spokesman for the French Civil Aviation Authority, said the plane did not send out a distress signal, according to The Associated Press. Earlier reports said it had. The AP quoted Heraud as saying a combination of loss of radio contact with control and the plane's descent "prompted the control service to declare a distress." Winkelmann said Germanwings could not confirm a distress signal had been sent.

Flight 4U 9525 left Barcelona at 10:01 a.m. The aircraft was scheduled to land in Duesseldorf at 11:39 a.m., according to Flightaware.com. Winkelmann said the aircraft was delivered to Lufthansa in 1991 and had been operating for Germanwings, a low-cost Lufthansa subsidiary, since 2004. Its last routine check was Monday, he said, in Duesseldorf. Its last major inspection was in the summer of 2013, he said. Winkelmann said the captain who flew the plane was an experienced pilot who had flown for Lufthansa and Germanwings for 10 years.

The nationalities of the passengers have not been released, pending notification of kin, Germanwings said. However, the Education Ministry in German North Rhine-Westphalia state said 16 high-schoolers and two teachers from a school in Haltern, Germany, were aboard the flight. "This is the darkest day in the history of our town," Haltern Mayor Bodo Klimpel said.

Mourners began streaming into Barcelona's airport just hours after the morning flight took off—but never landed. The Lufthansa subsidiary Germanwings has set up a Spanish language hotline for family and friends of those who were on the plane. The Spanish government says roughly a third of the 150 people on board had Spanish surnames. "The Spanish king and queen issued their condolences from France. They were in Paris on a state visit, but cut short their trip, and rushed home to Spain," the article reports.

At a news conference, French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve said a black box was located at the site of the crash, and would be used to investigate what caused the plane to go down. The exact location of the crash is unclear, but the terrain where the plane went down is difficult to access, officials said, hampering search efforts. We do know the Airbus A320 crashed in a remote part of the Alpes-de-Haute-Provence region. Eric Ciotti, head of the regional council in southeast France, said the crash site was Meolans-Revels, near the popular ski resort of Pra Loup. However, Airbus said the crash occurred in nearby Prads-Haute-Bleone.

Earlier, French President Francois Hollande said, "The conditions of the accident suggest there would be no survivors." On Twitter, he expressed his condolences to the victims' families. German Chancellor Angel Merkel was "shaken" at the news of the crash, her spokesman Steffen Seibert said. Spanish President Mariano Rajoy called the crash a "tragedy."

Alain Vidal, France's secretary of state for transportation, told Europe 1 that the plane crashed in an area that is inaccessible by road. He said helicopters flying overhead spotted the debris and some bodies. Local officials said rescue workers were airlifted to the site.

The A320 is one of the most popular planes in the world for short- and medium-haul flights. In a statement, Airbus said:

"The aircraft involved in the accident, registered under D-AIPX was MSN (Manufacturer Serial Number) 147 delivered to Lufthansa from the production line in 1991. The aircraft had accumulated approximately 58,300 flight hours in some 46,700 flights. It was powered by CFM 56-5A1 engines."

Le Monde says Tuesday's crash is the deadliest in French territory since 1981, when 180 people died in the crash of an Inex-Adria Aviopromet plane at Mount San Pietro. In July 2000, an Air France Concorde flying between Paris and New York crashed during takeoff near Paris, killing 113 people.

Title: Afghan Security Forces End Siege on Sikh Temple in Kabul, 25 Dead

Article:

Afghan security forces have concluded an hours-long operation at a Sikh religious complex in Kabul, resulting in the death of 25 individuals, according to the Ministry of Interior. The attack, which occurred on Wednesday, was claimed by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL, also known as ISIS). The Taliban had earlier denied involvement in the siege that left at least eight others wounded.

Witness Raju Singh Sonny told the AFP that a man dressed in a police uniform entered the temple in central Kabul, shot a guard, and began attacking worshippers in the main hall. Several other attackers also entered the building and moved from room to room, shooting people, according to Sonny.

Interior ministry spokesman Tariq Arian later confirmed the operation's conclusion, stating that all attackers were killed. Security forces cordoned off the area, located in old Kabul, after gunmen stormed the complex, as per the government's statement.

Narindra Singh Khalsa, a parliamentarian from the minority Sikh community, told the AP news agency he was near the Gurdwara - the Sikh place of worship - when the attack occurred and ran to the site. Those killed included a child whose body was brought to a Kabul hospital, according to emergency services and the hospital.

In photographs shared by the interior ministry, about a dozen children were seen being rushed out of the Gurdwara by Afghan special forces, many of them barefoot and crying. Khalsa later told Reuters News Agency that many people were still inside the building. "The gunmen started their attack at a time when the Dharamsala was full of worshippers," he said, referring to a sanctuary area in the temple compound.

The SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors activities by armed groups, reported that ISIL had claimed responsibility for the attack on its Aamaq media arm. Earlier this month, an affiliate of ISIL attacked a gathering of minority Shia Muslims in Kabul, killing 32 people.

The attack comes a day after the US announced it would cut its aid to the Afghan government by $1bn over frustrations that political leaders could not reach an agreement and form a team to negotiate with the Taliban. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Kabul on Tuesday in an attempt to resolve a standoff between President Ashraf Ghani and his rival Abdullah Abdullah, who also proclaimed himself president following a contested election.

The US and the Taliban signed a deal last month that was intended to pave the way for talks between the Afghan leadership and the rebels, but with Kabul unable to agree on who is in government, the talks have stalled. Sikhs, who number fewer than 300 families, have faced widespread discrimination in the country and have also been targeted by armed groups.

In 2018, a suicide bombing targeting the Sikh community and claimed by ISIL killed more than a dozen people in the eastern city of Jalalabad. Under Taliban rule in the late 1990s, Sikhs were asked to identify themselves by wearing yellow armbands, but the rule was not enforced. In recent years, large numbers of Sikhs and Hindus have sought asylum in India, which has a Hindu majority and a large Sikh population.

Title: DeVos Defends School Reopening, Threatens Federal Funding for Non-Compliant Schools

Article:

Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos reiterated her stance on Sunday that there is no danger in sending children back to school amid the coronavirus pandemic and maintained her threat to withhold federal funds from schools that do not resume in-person classes.

During an interview on "Fox News Sunday," DeVos stated, "There's nothing in the data that suggests that kids being in school is in any way dangerous." She cited lower incidences of COVID-19 in children compared to other age groups and successful reopenings in other countries, such as Germany, Denmark, Norway, and Sweden.

Host Chris Wallace questioned the comparison, stating, "Is it really fair, is it reasonable to compare the situation in countries that have 20 new cases in a day with a country that has 68,000 new cases in a day?" DeVos responded, "We're talking about schools and other countries' experiences with reopening schools. And it has been shown to be very successful."

Wallace countered, "Schools happen in an environment. If there's 30 cases in a country, that's very different than a place where it's out of control and there are 70,000 new cases in a day."

DeVos argued that places with high case numbers are the exception, stating, "When hot spots do appear, they have to be 'dealt with differently.'" Schools that do not reopen should not be eligible for federal assistance, she said.

Wallace questioned DeVos' authority to unilaterally cut off funding, stating that most of the funds are allocated for disadvantaged students or students with disabilities. DeVos responded, "American investment in education is a promise to students and their families. If schools are not going to reopen and not fulfill that promise, they should not get the funds, and give it to the families to decide to go to a school that is going to meet that promise."

President Donald Trump has criticized guidelines on reopening schools issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), stating they are "very tough," "expensive," and "impractical." DeVos clarified that the guidelines are only recommendations and are meant to be "helpful" for educators determining how to reopen.

Dr. Tom Inglesby, director of the Center for Health Security of the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, told Wallace that children are at a lower risk of serious infections than adults but not zero. He also noted that the efficiency of children spreading the virus in school is unclear, with some countries experiencing relatively uncommon spread while others, such as Israel, have had large outbreaks in schools after reopening.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi criticized DeVos' comments, stating they amounted to "malfeasance and dereliction of duty." Pelosi said, "We all want our children to go back to school. Teachers do. Parents do. And children do. But they must go back safely." She added, "They ignore science, and they ignore governance in order to make this happen."

Title: President Trump Orders National Guard Troops Withdrawal from Washington D.C. Amid Criticism

Article:

President Donald Trump ordered the withdrawal of thousands of National Guard troops from Washington D.C. following a weekend of largely peaceful protests against police brutality in the city. The decision came after a week of unrest following the death of George Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police.

Members of the administration defended the president's authority to call active-duty military to stand by in case they were needed to quell the unrest. In a tweet on Sunday, Mr. Trump stated, "I have just given an order for our National Guard to start the process of withdrawing from Washington, D.C., now that everything is under perfect control. They will be going home, but can quickly return, if needed."

The use of National Guard and active-duty military troops to calm the unrest sparked criticism, including from within the president's ranks. Secretary of Defense Mark Esper broke with the commander-in-chief on the issue, stating that the protests did not meet the heightened level to call for military intervention.

About 1,600 active-duty military troops were sent to the nation's capital last week after a church and other buildings near the White House were set ablaze, and monuments were tagged with graffiti. However, the troops were not deployed to confront citizens.

District Mayor Muriel Bowser ordered Utah National Guard members out of a hotel near downtown last week, citing a budget issue. She made it clear that she did not want military-style police patrolling the streets.

Attorney General William Barr said he thought members of the administration were on the same page that troops should be used as a last resort. Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf defended the administration's moves, stating that the unrest diminished after the increase in law enforcement presence.

Title: Tensions in Kashmir: A Shared Responsibility for India and Pakistan

Article:

The ongoing tensions in Kashmir have been attributed to the actions of both India and Pakistan, with calls for a permanent peaceful resolution. The article discusses the case of Adil Ahmad Dar, a Kashmiri man who became a suicide bomber, and the factors that led to his radicalization.

Dar's father recounted instances of police brutality and mass protests in Kashmir in 2016, during which Indian troops reportedly killed about 100 protesters and blinded several hundred. Dar himself was shot in his leg during these protests. The article suggests that the structural violence and political repression in Kashmir played a significant role in Dar's radicalization.

The article also discusses the role of the Pakistani terrorist group Jaish-e-Muhammad, which claimed responsibility for the attack. The group was banned in 2002 following an attempt to assassinate the country's military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, but has continued to operate due to the reluctance of Pakistani officials to aggressively pursue or punish militant leaders.

India's use of air power inside Pakistan for the first time since 1971 is also mentioned, with the article suggesting that this represents a significant departure from existing norms of engagement between the two countries. The article notes that India's actions may make it difficult for the country to dial back its response in the future.

Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan has counseled calm and returned the Indian pilot captured from an attack plane that Pakistan downed. However, the article questions whether Khan or his successors will be able to maintain such composure if India continues to encroach on Pakistani sovereignty to hunt down terrorists.

In a separate context, the article discusses the 2020 U.S. presidential race and the policy proposals of candidates Elizabeth Warren, Joe Biden, and Pete Buttigieg. The article notes that Warren has provided more detail on Medicare financing and overall policy detail than her competitors, but criticizes her approach for trying to force people to join Medicare rather than allowing them to opt in.

Finally, the article discusses the ongoing impeachment investigation of U.S. President Donald Trump. The article suggests that there is enough circumstantial evidence to support impeachment, but questions whether it will be enough to convince Republicans and lead to Trump's removal.

Title: Michelle Obama Named Most Admired Woman, Barack Obama Most Admired Man for 11th Consecutive Year

Article:

In a survey conducted by Gallup, former First Lady Michelle Obama has been named the Most Admired Woman in the world for the first time, marking a change in the top spot after 17 years of Hillary Clinton's dominance. Barack Obama, her husband and former President, has been named the Most Admired Man for the 11th consecutive year.

The survey, which has been conducted annually since 1946, asks Americans to name the man and woman they admire most, living anywhere in the world today. This year's survey was conducted from December 3-12.

Michelle Obama, who is currently touring to promote her recently released autobiography, won by a significant margin this year. Oprah Winfrey placed second, with Clinton and Melania Trump following.

In the men's category, Barack Obama has been the winner for the 11th consecutive year, including one year as president-elect, eight as president, and two as former president. President Donald Trump ranked second for the fourth year in a row.

Queen Elizabeth, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, talk show host Ellen DeGeneres, former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley, human rights activist Malala Yousafzai, and House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi are among the top 10 most admired women this year.

The top 10 most admired men this year includes former President George W. Bush, Pope Francis, Microsoft founder Bill Gates, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, former President Bill Clinton, the Dalai Lama, former Vice President Joe Biden, Tesla CEO Elon Musk, and Vice President Mike Pence.

The list is notable for the absence of two men who often ranked high but passed away in 2018, Sen. John McCain and the Rev. Billy Graham. McCain finished in the top 10 six times, while Graham had more top 10 finishes than any man or woman, a record 61 times.

Barack Obama is now just one first-place finish short of tying Dwight Eisenhower for the most times being Most Admired Man. Eisenhower won the distinction 12 times. This year marks only the 13th time in 72 measurements that the incumbent president did not win. Usually, the president does not win when he has subpar job approval ratings, as is the case with Trump.

The full results of the survey, including the methodology, can be found on the Gallup website.

Title: The Electoral College: A Historical Compromise and Its Controversial Modern Implications

Article:

The Electoral College, a system established by the Founding Fathers to elect the President of the United States, has been a subject of debate since its inception. Alexander Hamilton described it as "excellent, if the manner of it be not perfect." The Electoral College was a compromise between a popular vote and Congress selecting the President.

In the Electoral College system, each state is assigned a number of Electors equal to the sum of its Senators and Representatives in Congress. This results in a total of 538 Electors, with a 270 majority needed to elect the President. The Electoral votes are awarded to the winner of the popular vote in each state, with the exception of Nebraska and Maine, where votes are allocated proportionally.

The Electoral College was a compromise designed to address concerns about a "democratic mob" influencing the election and potential corruption if Congress directly elected the President. The system was also a compromise in that it leveraged the popular vote to determine a winner by state, but a body of Electors from each state would ultimately determine the winner.

Since its establishment over 200 years ago, there have been over 700 proposals to eliminate or reform the Electoral College in Congress. The provisions for electing the President and Vice President have been among the most amended parts of the Constitution. The last serious attempt to change the Electoral College began in 1966, but the proposal was defeated, falling short of the two-thirds majority required to amend the Constitution.

In response to the ongoing debate, some states have signed a pact to bypass the Electoral College without amending the Constitution. This pact would award Electoral College votes to the winner of the national popular vote, regardless of the outcome in individual states. For example, if a democratic candidate won the popular vote in California but a Republican won the national popular vote, all of California's Electoral votes would be awarded to the Republican candidate.

The Electoral College system's supporters argue that it encourages candidates to build coalitions and pay attention to the entire country instead of a few populous mega-cities. Opponents argue that the system discourages candidates from paying attention to the entire country and instead focuses on a few battleground states. The debate continues as to whether the Electoral College system accurately represents the will of the people and ensures fair elections.

Title: House Republicans Divided Over Legal Status for Undocumented Immigrants, Focus on Border Security

Article:

Republican lawmakers in the U.S. House of Representatives have expressed disagreement over granting legal status to the estimated 11 million undocumented people residing in the United States, following a 2 1/2-hour closed-door meeting on Wednesday. The meeting was held to discuss immigration reform, with a focus on bolstering border security.

According to several lawmakers, there appears to be no consensus over calls for granting legal status to the 11 million, many of whom have lived in the United States for years. Republican Representative Steve King suggested that his colleagues are split "50/50" on the issue.

The Republican-led House and Democratic-led Senate will likely need to reach an agreement, as the Senate approved a comprehensive immigration bill last month that includes a pathway to citizenship. Backers of the Senate bill insist that a path to citizenship must be part of any final bill that they help send to President Barack Obama to sign into law.

The Republican lawmakers stated that there was consensus on the need to secure the U.S. border further against illegal crossings. They suggested that House Speaker John Boehner could seek passage of such a bill as a first step toward a larger agreement.

The Republican leaders issued a statement rejecting a Senate-passed bill that puts the 11 million on a 13-year path to citizenship. Senator Jeff Flake, who helped write the Senate bill and served 12 years in the House, expressed disappointment, stating, "It's hard not to be discouraged right now."

The Senate bill removes the threat of deportation for most illegal residents, but features several hurdles to citizenship, including learning English, paying back taxes, and passing criminal background checks. It authorizes $46 billion for border security and to revamp the visa system to help high-tech firms, farmers, and other businesses hire foreign workers.

Obama and his fellow Democrats have been calling for prompt action by the House. Earlier on Wednesday, the president told a group of Hispanic lawmakers that he was willing to do whatever it takes to help enact a bill. Even former President George W. Bush, who rarely wades into policy debates, gave a boost to efforts in Congress.

House Republicans, who hold a 234-201 majority over Democrats, gave no indication of fast action on a major bill. "It is going to be a process of months, not days or weeks," Representative Tom Cole of Oklahoma told Reuters in a telephone interview after Wednesday's meeting.

Meanwhile, House Majority Leader Eric Cantor is reportedly working on a plan to grant citizenship for children of illegal immigrants who are in the United States through no fault of their own, according to Republican lawmakers. In the past, Republicans have blocked such legislation.

However, even that relatively modest step is controversial among some of the most conservative House Republicans. Representative Mo Brooks stated, "Anyone who has come to our country, their first step on American soil is to thumb their nose at American laws... we should not award them with our highest honor, which is citizenship."

Earlier, the White House signaled that Obama will become more publicly engaged in the intensifying immigration debate in Congress. The administration released a report arguing that passing sweeping immigration reforms such as the Senate's would expand the economy 3.3 percent by 2023 and reduce the federal deficit by almost $850 billion over 20 years.

Thomas Donohue, president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which wants comprehensive immigration reforms enacted, expressed hope that public support would prompt House Republicans to eventually back a major bill. "If the arguments are compelling, this deal is not over by any means," he said.

The November presidential election, in which Obama captured more than 70 percent of the growing Hispanic vote, was seen by many Republicans as a wake-up call that their party must do more to appeal to minorities. The call for comprehensive reform resonates with some Republican senators and with some prospective Republican presidential candidates.

However, it holds less appeal to House Republicans who fear challenges from the conservative Tea Party movement if they back a pathway to citizenship, a core demand of Democrats. According to a recent study by the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, which tracks congressional races, only 24 of the 234 House Republicans represent districts that are more than 25 percent Hispanic.

Title: Senate Confirms Chuck Hagel as Defense Secretary in Tight Vote

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed Chuck Hagel's nomination as Defense Secretary on Tuesday, concluding a contentious battle that revealed deep divisions among senators regarding President Barack Obama's Pentagon pick. The vote was historically close, with 58 senators in favor and 41 opposing.

Despite Hagel's background as a former Republican senator, the resistance to his nomination demonstrated an unusual level of distrust among many senators towards the individual chosen to lead the Defense Department, as the country is currently winding down the Afghanistan war and assessing emerging threats from Iran, Syria, and other regions in the Middle East and North Africa.

Republicans had initially delayed the nomination due to demands for more information from the Obama administration regarding the September 11 Libya attacks. Additionally, they raised concerns about Hagel's past statements and votes on various issues, including Israel, Iran, and nuclear weapons.

Senator John McCain, a leading Republican, clashed with Hagel over his opposition to President George W. Bush's decision to send additional troops to Iraq in 2007, a time when the war seemed to be nearing a critical point. Hagel, who voted to authorize military force in Iraq, later opposed the conflict, comparing it to Vietnam and arguing that it diverted attention from Afghanistan.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid questioned the delaying tactics employed by his Republican colleagues, stating, "Twelve days later, nothing. Nothing has changed." He defended Hagel, asserting, "Sen. Hagel's exemplary record of service to his country remains untarnished."

Reid attributed the delay to partisanship over Obama's second-term national security team. Both Reid and Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Carl Levin, a Democrat, emphasized the urgency to act, given the impending automatic, across-the-board budget cuts affecting the Pentagon.

Hagel will succeed Defense Secretary Leon Panetta and join Obama's retooled national security team. The Senate's split decision saw Republicans turning on their former party colleague, while Democrats stood by Obama's nominee.

Hagel also faced criticism over a May 2012 study he co-authored for the advocacy group Global Zero, which called for an 80 percent reduction of U.S. nuclear weapons and the eventual elimination of all the world's nuclear arms. The group argued that with the end of the Cold War, the United States can reduce its total nuclear arsenal to 900 without compromising security. Currently, the U.S. and Russia have approximately 5,000 warheads each, either deployed or in reserve.

In an echo of the 2012 presidential campaign, Hagel faced criticism from well-funded, Republican-leaning outside groups that labeled him "anti-Israel" and pressured senators to oppose the nomination. The groups ran television and print ads criticizing Hagel.

Opponents were particularly incensed by Hagel's use of the term "Jewish lobby" to refer to pro-Israel groups. He later apologized, stating he should have used another term and should not have suggested that these groups had intimidated members of the Senate into favoring actions contrary to U.S. interests.

Throughout the confirmation process, Hagel spent weeks reaching out to members of the Senate, meeting individually with lawmakers to address their concerns and seeking to reassure them about his policies. Hagel's performance during his confirmation hearing was inconsistent, which some believe may have contributed to the close vote. However, it did not result in a significant erosion of Democratic support for the president's choice, and Hagel already had the backing of three Republicans prior to the final vote. Senator Rand Paul, R-Ky., also switched to support Hagel in the final vote.

Title: President Trump's Job Approval Ratings Surge to Highest Levels Since Presidency

Article:

President Donald Trump's job approval numbers have reached their highest levels since the beginning of his presidency, according to the RealClearPolitics poll of polls. As of the latest data, Trump's approval rating stands at 47 percent, surpassing his previous record of 46 percent by a full point. Simultaneously, his disapproval rating has dipped to 49.5 percent, marking the first time it has been below 50 percent since February 2017, the month after he assumed the presidency.

In the past ten days, Trump's approval rating has improved by a net 6.5 points, with his average approval rating being three points lower at 44 percent and his disapproval rating being 3.5 points higher at 53 percent just over a week ago.

The improvement in Trump's numbers is largely attributed to his handling of the medical and financial crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Recent polling shows either a plurality or an outright majority approve of the job he is doing in handling this crisis. A recent Gallup poll showed a 60 percent approval rating.

Trump's early travel ban, implemented on January 31, is being viewed more favorably with each passing day. The European Union did not institute travel bans until about two weeks ago, and the current situation in Europe is a point of comparison. Trump's travel bans are estimated to have prevented around half a million travelers from epidemic areas from entering the country.

Trump's daily press briefings have allowed him to communicate directly with the American people, with millions tuning in. These briefings have been moved to prime time, which has increased viewership. The media have begun to blacklist these briefings, with some far-left outlets, such as CNN and NBC News, already taking this action.

Trump's leadership in slashing red tape, cutting regulations, and involving the private sector has been noted. His daily briefings feature impressive experts like Dr. Anthony Fauci and Dr. Deborah Birx. The media are attempting to pit these experts against Trump, but the public appears to appreciate a president willing to have a public debate about the appropriate response to the medical and economic crises.

Trump is working well with Democrats, such as Governors Newsom of California and Cuomo of New York, which is crucial given that these two states are major hot spots. He also worked with Democrats in the U.S. Senate to pass the $2 trillion stimulus package. The public is seeking cooperation between political parties during this time, and Trump's ability to work with Democrats is being viewed positively.

The media are being criticized for their handling of the situation, and Trump is being praised for his ability to handle their actions with skill. This skill is giving the public confidence in Trump's competence, as he is not perceived as being caught off guard or lacking answers during the crisis.

A recent poll shows that the public approves of everyone's handling of the coronavirus situation, except the media. The media are being criticized for their questions, with some finding them to be inappropriate, such as asking how many deaths are acceptable.

In conclusion, the president's job approval ratings have reached their highest levels since the beginning of his presidency, and the public appears to approve of his handling of the coronavirus crisis. The media are being criticized for their handling of the situation, and Trump is being praised for his ability to handle their actions with skill.

Title: Trump's 2020 Budget Proposal Faces Criticism for Relying on "Accounting Gimmicks" and Overly Optimistic Economic Growth Projections

Article:

President Donald Trump's proposed budget for 2020 aims to address the growing national debt, which surpassed $22 trillion recently. In a message to Congress, Trump stated that the budget plan provides a clear roadmap for controlling federal spending and debt. However, the 150-page budget proposal has been met with criticism for relying on "accounting gimmicks" and overly optimistic economic growth projections.

The budget proposal, released on Monday, would run trillion-dollar deficits in each of the next four years and take 15 years to balance, even with optimistic assumptions about future economic growth. This is five years longer than the Trump administration's first budget promised. The budget also fails to deliver on Trump's campaign promise to eliminate the national debt in eight years.

Under the projections included in the budget plan, the country would run a deficit of $631 billion in 2025, hardly smaller than the $666 billion deficit in the final fiscal year of President Barack Obama's time in office. Over 10 years, Trump's budget would add more than $7.9 trillion to the national debt.

The real outcome is likely to be much worse than the estimates provided by the White House. The budget assumes 3 percent annual economic growth for the next decade, a figure that's well in excess of what most economists expect. The Federal Reserve, for example, projects 2.3 percent growth over the next year.

Without those overly rosy assumptions, the national debt would likely be $2 trillion higher by 2029, according to an analysis by the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget (CRFB), a nonpartisan group that advocates for balanced budgets. The group says the budget is likely to add about $10 trillion to the national debt by 2029.

Maya MacGuineas, president of the CRFB, stated, "President Trump's budget aims to reverse an unsustainable fiscal situation and put debt on a downward path relative to the economy. Unfortunately, as in previous years, he relies on far too many accounting gimmicks and fantasy assumptions and puts forward far too few actual solutions."

The latest projections from the Congressional Budget Office assume lower levels of future revenue than the Trump budget does. As a result, the CBO does not expect the deficit to decline during the next decade, and expects that it will reach $1.3 trillion annually by 2029.

While the budget proposal includes $660 billion in savings from repealing and replacing Obamacare, this policy seems virtually impossible now that Democrats hold the House. Already, Democrats are slamming Trump's budget for the non-defense discretionary cuts the administration has proposed.

The budget also faces criticism for attempting to hide spending increases for the Pentagon by moving those new funds into off-the-books accounts originally meant to pay for America's foreign wars. The administration says it wants to tackle wasteful spending in welfare and other domestic programs, but there's plenty of wasteful spending at the Pentagon, too.

Balancing a budget that's $22 trillion in the red is not easy, but the first requirement should be to stop making matters worse. Chris Edwards, director of tax policy studies at the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank, wrote, "Federal debt is soaring even after a decade of economic growth. Debt is imposing a rising cost that burdens all of us. Politicians have always had incentives to spend, but never before has Washington been so irresponsible."

Trump's budget also calls for the extension of the 2017 tax cuts, which are currently expected to expire in 2025. As Edwards points out, the budget could balance within 10 years—even with lower expected revenues—if annual spending growth was restrained to 1.8 percent. That's a reasonable figure. Unfortunately, this budget ignores it.

Title: State Legislatures Take Center Stage in Political Battles as Gridlock Persists in Washington

Article:

Analysts suggest that issues addressed by state legislatures this year, which include gun control, health care, education, and police procedures, may have more immediate and lasting effects than anything approved in Washington, D.C., where the government is divided. The roots of the polarization in state legislatures can be traced back to elections in 2010, when Republicans made significant gains in statehouses and pushed for policies such as restricting labor unions and abortion access, while expanding gun rights, according to Sarah F. Anzia, a political scientist at the University of California, Berkeley.

At around the same time, national organizations representing various interest groups, including teachers and gun owners, became more active in state capitals because they found it easier to make headway in places like Sacramento and Charleston, W.Va., than in Washington due to gridlock in Congress.

The number of states with either supermajorities of Democrats that also have Democratic governors (California, Nevada, and Oregon, among others) or Republicans with Republican governors (Alabama, Ohio, and Tennessee, among others) has grown. This means that many lawmakers rarely feel the need to compromise.

"If you are a Republican in one state, you are probably going to be pushing the same agenda as a Republican in another state, and the same is true for Democrats," said Dr. Anzia. "That hasn't always been true, and the result is that now more than ever, state legislatures are key players in these partisan battles over politics."

In Minnesota, the only state left with a divided legislature, promises of bipartisanship sometimes devolved into stalemate. During a budget standoff last month, Tim Walz, the Democratic governor who campaigned last year on a pledge to work across the aisle, angrily denounced Republicans for blocking gun control efforts and supporting deep tax cuts, saying those policies "fit better in Mississippi and Alabama than they do in Minnesota."

Title: Trump Terminates Navy Secretary Richard Spencer Over Gallagher Case and Contracting Issues

Article:

In a series of tweets, President Donald Trump announced the termination of Richard Spencer, the Secretary of the Navy, by Defense Secretary Mark Esper. Trump criticized Spencer for his handling of the trial of Navy Seal Eddie Gallagher and other performance issues.

Trump wrote on Twitter, "I was not pleased with the way that Navy Seal Eddie Gallagher's trial was handled by the Navy. He was treated very badly but, despite this, was completely exonerated on all major charges. I then restored Eddie's rank. Likewise, large cost overruns from past administration's contracting procedures were not addressed to my satisfaction. Therefore, Secretary of the Navy Richard Spencer's services have been terminated by Secretary of Defense Mark Esper."

Trump did not specify the contracting issues he referred to, but he and Spencer have had disagreements over the delivery schedule of the Navy's next aircraft carrier, the USS Gerald Ford. Delays have plagued the carrier's weapons elevators, and Spencer publicly bet Trump last January that if the problems weren't resolved by the next time the warship put out to sea, the president could fire him—only for the carrier to conduct sea trials last month with only some of its elevators working.

The relationship between Trump and his administration's top Pentagon leaders has been marked by increasing turmoil over the past year, starting with retired Gen. Jim Mattis' resignation as Defense secretary in December after a presidential order, which was later partly reversed, to pull U.S. troops out of Syria. Trump has since gone through three acting Defense secretaries—including, briefly, Spencer—before Esper was confirmed in July. On Esper's watch, Trump has again ordered a pullout from Syria, only to again partially reverse it under pressure from the Pentagon and Congress.

Sen. Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.), chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said in a statement, "Both Secretary Esper and President Trump deserve to have a leadership team who has their trust and confidence. It is no secret that I had my own disagreements with Secretary Spencer over the management of specific Navy programs, and I look forward to receiving and considering a nomination for the next Secretary of the Navy as soon as possible."

Gallagher was acquitted over the summer of murdering a wounded prisoner in Iraq but convicted of posing for a photo with the militant's body and was demoted. Days after Trump restored Gallagher's rank earlier this month, Navy officials said the top admiral responsible for the SEALs was notifying Gallagher and three of his superior officers that boards were being convened to consider expelling them from the commando unit.

"I hereby acknowledge my termination as United States Secretary of the Navy, to be effective immediately," Spencer wrote in a letter to Trump, which was posted on Twitter by CNN. Spencer did not refer in the letter to the communications with the White House that the Pentagon cited in its announcement.

Outgoing Secretary of the Navy Spencer's acknowledgment-of-termination letter states, "I can not in good conscience obey an order that I believe violates the sacred oath I took in the presence of my family, my flag, and my faith to support and defend the Constitution of the United States." This appears to be a reference to Trump's direction that the Navy not eject Gallagher from the SEALs.

After Esper and Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Mark Milley spoke with Trump about Gallagher's case on Friday, Hoffman said, "Secretary Esper learned that Secretary Spencer had previously and privately proposed to the White House—contrary to Spencer's public position—to restore Gallagher's rank and allow him to retire with his Trident pin." Despite asking for Spencer's resignation over the proposal, though, Esper "has directed that Gallagher retain his Trident pin," the insignia that marks him as a SEAL, Hoffman said.

"Eddie Gallagher's and his family's fervent hope is that this truly is the end of the road, and he can go into retirement" as a SEAL, said Timothy Parlatore, Gallagher's lawyer.

Whatever the apparent mismatch between the Pentagon statement and Spencer's letter, Trump's unusual intervention in the Gallagher case is at the root of the clash that led to Spencer's departure. Former Navy Secretary Ray Mabus said, "This all started with the president. We wouldn't be here if it wasn't for his actions, and I don't think you can lose sight of that." Mabus, who held the top Navy post in the Obama administration, added, "He undermined good order and discipline. He dishonored the SEALs by saying they couldn't hold a review board. So that's what got us into this mess. This is just one more example showing that if you deal with this president, it's not going to end well."

A former senior Defense official who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss a situation in which the facts are unclear, agreed, "This is typical Trump. This is the Trump circus. Everything he touches turns into this convoluted process of politics that we're seeing today over at the Pentagon."

Title: President Trump Questions Michael Cohen Over Secretly Recorded Conversation

Article:

President Donald Trump has questioned his former attorney, Michael Cohen, regarding a conversation they had that was secretly recorded by Cohen. The conversation, which was aired by CNN on Tuesday, pertained to a payment to a former Playboy model who alleged an affair with Trump.

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, Trump expressed his disapproval of Cohen's actions, asking, "What kind of a lawyer would tape a client?" The president did not directly name Cohen or criticize him harshly but instead posed a series of questions about the recording.

In the recording, Cohen can be heard discussing the establishment of a company for the transfer of information related to American Media Inc. head David Pecker. The conversation suggests a payment, with Trump saying, "pay with cash," although the sound quality is unclear as to whether Trump is suggesting paying or not.

The recording is legal under New York law, as it only requires one party to consent to allow a conversation to be recorded. However, experts have stated that the tape does not prove any criminal wrongdoing. The tape is one of 12 that the government seized during a raid of Cohen's apartment, office, and hotel room earlier this year. The contents of the other tapes are not publicly known at this time.

Trump had previously criticized the FBI after the bureau raided Cohen's office in April, calling it an "attack on our country." However, he has largely refrained from explicitly tweeting about or commenting on Cohen as the case progresses in the Southern District of New York.

Cohen, who worked for years as the president's fixer at the Trump Organization, is reportedly under investigation for bank fraud and campaign finance law violations. He has recently raised speculation that he might cooperate with investigators after stating his "first loyalty" is to the country, not Trump.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Visits State Beach During Government Shutdown

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie faced criticism over the weekend after photos emerged of him enjoying a day at Island Beach State Park, a state-operated beach that was closed to the public due to a government shutdown. The New Jersey Star-Ledger published aerial photos of Christie and his family on the beach, with the governor lounging in a beach chair and his family participating in activities such as paddleboarding and enjoying beverages.

At a press conference in Trenton on Sunday, Christie was asked if he had gotten any sun that day. "I did not," he reportedly said. "I did not get any sun today." When told there were photos of the governor on the beach, his spokesman said that the governor was briefly on the beach talking to his family. "He did not get any sun," the spokesman added. "He had a baseball hat on."

On Saturday, Christie had defended using the state park that was closed to the rest of the state's residents due to the budget impasse. He told the newspaper that his family does not use any state services while at the park, and emphasized that his residence is separate from the park.

Twitter users reacted to the news with a variety of memes and comments. One of the most pointed headlines to come out of the beach controversy was from the Asbury Park Press, which wrote, "Gov. Christie, get the hell off the beach!"

Christie's second term as governor ends in January 2018, when presumably he will have ample time to enjoy the beach. On Monday morning, the governor tweeted a photo of a beach, touting many open beaches in New Jersey. Municipal parks and beaches are open (and were reportedly packed over the weekend), but state beaches remain closed due to the shutdown.

Christie called in to a local Fox News affiliate on Monday to say that if the Legislature passes a budget, he will sign it. Fox anchor Teresa Priolo asked Christie if his beach visit signaled that he was out of touch with the people of his state.

"Most of the time when they catch politicians with hidden cameras and planes flying over you, they catch you with someone you're not supposed to be with," Christie said. "I was actually with who I was supposed to be with and where I was supposed to be. And I really wonder about journalists who spend money flying planes to look whether people are actually where they said they would be. I'm sure there are Pulitzers coming, it will be great."

Meanwhile, Christie's own Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno posted her disapproval of Christie's beach visit on Facebook. Guadagno, a Republican, has been Christie's second-in-command since 2010 and is now running for governor herself. In a Quinnipiac poll, the Democratic candidate, Phil Murphy, leads Guadagno 55-26 percent.

Title: House Republican Leaders Call for Hearing on State Department's Refusal of Security Requests in Benghazi Attack

Article:

Two House Republican leaders, Representatives Darrell E. Issa and Jason Chaffetz, announced on Tuesday that they would hold a hearing on October 10 to investigate the September 11 terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the death of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens. The lawmakers cited 13 security-related incidents in Benghazi in the six months prior to the attack, including a Facebook page that threatened Ambassador Stevens.

In a letter to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, the representatives stated that the U.S. mission in Libya had made repeated requests for increased security in Benghazi, but these requests were denied by officials in Washington. The State Department, however, has pledged its cooperation with the congressional investigation.

The Pentagon is reportedly preparing data to help identify and potentially capture militants suspected of conducting the Benghazi attack. Meanwhile, State Department officials have said that Mrs. Clinton will respond immediately to the lawmakers' requests and will cooperate fully with the investigation.

Several former government officials have stated that no reasonable security presence could have successfully defended the consulate against the sophisticated, multi-stage assault by extremists armed with automatic weapons, rocket-propelled grenade-launchers, and mortars. The attack occurred amid widespread protests directed against U.S. facilities throughout the Arab world, sparked by an Internet video denigrating Islam's Prophet Muhammad.

For more than a week, administration officials maintained that the attack was "spontaneous," stating that it had developed out of an angry demonstration outside the consulate. However, the U.S. director of national intelligence now says that this information was the result of erroneous early analyses of the events and officials have linked it to terrorist groups.

Republicans have criticized the administration for taking eight days to use the term "terrorist attack" to describe the assault and have accused the administration of downplaying the seriousness of the attack due to its contradiction of President Obama's election-campaign narrative about the success of his campaign against al Qaeda. More hawkish conservatives have said the attack was provoked by "weakness" on the part of the administration in the Middle East.

The hearing on the Benghazi attack is likely to highlight the deep differences between the parties' views on the best stance to take in the face of popular fury at the United States as a result of the anti-Muhammad film. It may also see some Democrats attempting to point a finger at Republicans, as the attack followed two years of major cuts by Congress to State Department funding for embassy construction and diplomatic security.

The investigation will join at least four other probes into the attack, including a special panel convened by Mrs. Clinton to report on security prior to the attack, an inquiry by the State Department's acting Inspector General, a criminal investigation by the FBI, and a Libyan criminal investigation.

Title: B&G Foods Initiates Review of Cream of Wheat Packaging Following Racial Stereotype Criticism

Article:

B&G Foods, the parent company of Cream of Wheat, has announced an immediate review of the brand's packaging due to concerns regarding the depiction of a chef on the boxes. This decision follows similar moves by the parent companies of Aunt Jemima, Uncle Ben's, and Mrs. Butterworth's to overhaul their imaging in response to renewed calls for racial equality.

In a news release, B&G Foods stated, "We understand there are concerns regarding the Chef image, and we are committed to evaluating our packaging and will proactively take steps to ensure that we and our brands do not inadvertently contribute to systemic racism." The company also emphasized its stance against prejudice and injustice of any kind.

The breakfast cereal, which consists of enriched farina, has been criticized for the use of a smiling Black chef on its packaging since the 1890s. The mascot on early boxes was known as Rastus, a racial caricature of a Black man, which is considered derogatory. The image was replaced in the 1920s and is believed to be a depiction of a Chicago chef named Frank L. White, who died in 1938.

Quaker Oats was the first to announce on Wednesday that it would retire Aunt Jemima from packaging on its brand of syrup and pancake mixes, stating that the character is "based on a racial stereotype." Hours later, Mars, the owner of Uncle Ben's brand, announced it "is the right time to evolve the Uncle Ben’s brand, including its visual brand identity."

Conagra Brands also announced on Wednesday that it has "begun a complete brand and packaging review on Mrs. Butterworth's." The shape of the brand’s syrup bottles is believed to be a racial caricature of the stereotype for Black women.

The review of Mrs. Butterworth's brand comes after the announcements made by Aunt Jemima and Uncle Ben's. The changes in these brands follow a growing movement to remove racial stereotypes from consumer products.

Title: Anne Holton Steps Up as Surrogate for Hillary Clinton Campaign

Article:

Anne Holton, the wife of Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Kaine and daughter of a former Republican governor in the swing state of Virginia, is increasingly taking a more prominent role on the campaign trail for the Democratic presidential nominee, Hillary Clinton. Holton, who has a background in law and politics, is leveraging her unique position to push Clinton's education platform and potentially help shore up support among women voters who may be having second thoughts about Clinton.

In a recent Washington Post/ABC News poll, Clinton's popularity among registered voters hit a new low, with 41 percent of Americans having a positive view of Clinton and 56 percent having a negative view. Her popularity among women sank to 45-52 percent, a significant drop from a month prior.

While former President Clinton can speak to his wife's accomplishments, it may be tougher for him to present Clinton as a relatable figure to women voters who may be on the fence. On the stump, Holton is comfortable highlighting Clinton's role as a new grandmother and focusing on the particulars of the candidate's education platform.

Holton has been making appearances in key states, such as New Hampshire and Virginia, where she toured Virginia Western Community College and pushed Clinton proposals to make college tuition free for some students. She also made stops in Virginia to campaign and attend a volunteer appreciation event.

Holton's father, A. Linwood Holton Jr., was a moderate Republican who in 1970 became the first GOP governor to be elected in Virginia in nearly a century. Holton's father worked to integrate the schools in response to court-ordered desegregation, even sending a young Anne Holton to attend a public school in Richmond with a black student majority.

The Clinton campaign declined an interview request from FoxNews.com. On the Republican side, vice presidential nominee Mike Pence's wife, Karen Pence, hasn't been as visible as Holton but is starting to show up more on the trail. Two weeks ago, Karen Pence, who also has an accomplished background in education, accompanied her husband on a swing through Georgia.

Title: President Obama's Thanksgiving Address: Emphasizing Gratitude for Immigrants, Freedom, and Compassion

Article:

In his Thanksgiving Day address, President Barack Obama did not explicitly mention the term "immigration," but he expressed gratitude for immigrants among the nation's many blessings.

"We give thanks for the men and women who set sail for this land nearly four centuries ago, risking everything for the chance at a better life—and the people who were already here, our Native American brothers and sisters, for their generosity during that first Thanksgiving," Mr. Obama said.

Following the Pilgrims, Mr. Obama expressed gratitude on Thanksgiving for the generations who followed, "people of all races and religions, who arrived here from every country on Earth and worked to build something better for themselves and for us."

The president has been advocating for immigration reform legislation all year, urging House Republicans to approve a bill that was already passed by the Democrat-controlled Senate. In his holiday message, Mr. Obama did not make any references to political battles.

Mr. Obama and his family will spend the holiday at the White House "just like many of you—sitting down with family and friends to eat some good food, tell stories, watch a little football, and most importantly, count our blessings."

Among those blessings, he said, are America's men and women in uniform.

"We give thanks for the freedoms they defend—the freedom to think what we want and say what we think, to worship according to our own beliefs, to choose our leaders and, yes, criticize them without punishment," the president said. "People around the world are fighting and even dying for their chance at these freedoms. We stand with them in that struggle, and we give thanks for being free."

The president also called on Americans to remember people who need a helping hand.

"We give thanks to everyone who’s doing their part to make the United States a better, more compassionate nation—who spend their Thanksgiving volunteering at a soup kitchen, or joining a service project, or bringing food and cheer to a lonely neighbor," he said. "That big-hearted generosity is a central part of our American character."

"No matter our differences, we’re all part of one American family," Mr. Obama said. "We are each other’s keepers. We are one nation, under God."

Title: Gun Rights Group to Hold Open Carry March in Fort Smith, Arkansas, Despite Attorney General's Opinion

Article:

A gun rights group, Arkansas Carry, plans to hold an invitation-only "open carry" march in Fort Smith, Arkansas, this weekend to highlight a disputed law that allows the open carry of handguns. The new law, Act 746, took effect on August 16, but Arkansas Attorney General Dustin McDaniel has stated that the law does not remove restrictions on carrying weapons openly.

The new law defines a journey as traveling "beyond the county in which the person lives," which Arkansas Carry argues clarifies the law and allows for open carry. However, the attorney general's opinion states that the law does not authorize so-called "open carry."

Steve Jones, the chairman of Arkansas Carry, said the group coordinated the event with police and prosecutors. Fort Smith Police Chief Kevin Lindsey wrote in an email to officers that there would not be a violation of the law unless "an officer could prove that there was an unlawful attempt to employ a handgun, knife, or club as a weapon against a person."

Sgt. Daniel Grubbs, a spokesman for the department, said, "The chief is not really getting into the debate of agreeing or disagreeing with the AG's opinion. It's 'you've given us a scenario, here's what you'd like to do, as long as everyone is lawfully in possession, they're legally able to possess one and they do not commit any type of crime, no one is going to be arrested.'"

A spokesman for McDaniel declined to comment on Saturday's event. In last month's advisory opinion, the attorney general stated that the "journey" exception was meant to allow Arkansans to "protect themselves from the dangers of the open road." However, the opinion also stated that the new law does not authorize open carry.

Jones said the group is looking at holding similar marches in other cities to highlight the law. The Arkansas Carry group has about 200 members in the state.

Title: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi Faces Internal Challenges as Democrats Buck Leadership on Key Issues

Article:

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi is facing increasing challenges in maintaining control over the Democratic party, as evidenced by recent events such as the impeachment motion and the resignation of former Representative John Conyers.

On Wednesday, a motion to impeach President Trump was introduced by House Democrats, despite Pelosi's months-long insistence on holding off on impeachment proceedings. Fifty-eight Democrats voted in favor of impeachment, despite Pelosi's objections. In a joint statement, Pelosi and Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer stated, "Now is not the time to consider articles of impeachment."

Pelosi's hesitance to push for impeachment has put her at odds with left-wing activist groups who have been demanding Trump's impeachment since before he was sworn into office.

The resignation of John Conyers last Friday marked another instance where House Democrats have acted independently of Pelosi's authority. Sworn affidavits signed by four of his former staffers describe Conyers, who resigned on Friday, as a serial sexual harasser who preyed on his female staffers and demanded sexual favors from them. Conyers also allegedly abused taxpayer resources to pursue sexual relationships with women.

Initially, Pelosi defended the 88-year-old Conyers as "an icon" and deferred to a House Ethics Committee investigation, a process that can stretch out for years. It took Pelosi 10 days to call for Conyers' resignation, which she did only after facing the prospect of a revolt from members furious over Conyers remaining in office.

The first two Democrats to demand Conyers' resignation were New York Rep. Kathleen Rice, who has called for Pelosi to step down from her leadership position, and Washington Rep. Pramila Jayapal, a first-term congresswoman. Ohio Rep. Tim Ryan, who unsuccessfully challenged Pelosi for House Minority Leader last year, also pressured Democratic leadership, demanding last Wednesday that the investigation into Conyers finish up by the end of the week.

On the same day, Rice, a second-term congressman, stormed out of a meeting with House Democrats about Conyers because she didn't believe they were taking the matter seriously enough. New York Rep. Joseph Crowley and California Rep. Linda Sanchez, the chair and vice-chair of the House Democratic Caucus, took the opposite position, urging restraint and trying to draw the process out.

"I don't know all the facts, I don't know the specific allegations," Sanchez said, adding that she "can't sit and judge a member and call for their resignation unless I've been party to hearing all of the evidence and hearing the defense of the evidence."

"Calling for the resignation of someone doesn't actually create the resignation," said Crowley, adding that he would wait for the ethics committee's investigation.

The very next day, Pelosi, Crowley, and Sanchez caved to their more junior colleagues and demanded Conyers' resignation.

It is unavailable whether Kathleen Rice, who is a distant family relative of this reporter, played a significant role in the internal dynamics that led to Conyers' resignation.

Title: Obama Proposes Increased Spending in Fiscal Year 2016 Budget

Article:

President Obama announced on Saturday that the United States can afford the significant spending increases in his proposed fiscal year 2016 budget, which is set to be unveiled on Monday. In his weekly address, Mr. Obama argued that the federal government has the necessary funds for investments in infrastructure, education, and other priorities due to shrinking deficits. However, he also advocated for tax increases on the wealthy to fund his proposed $74 billion increase in spending.

The budget would also repeal the automatic spending cuts known as sequestration, potentially leading to higher spending in the future. The president's budget is expected to face opposition from the Republican-controlled Congress, setting the stage for a potential fiscal battle.

In the address, President Obama outlined his budget's key points, including investments in paid leave, child care, community college education, research, infrastructure, manufacturing, and expanded internet access. He emphasized the nation's deficit reduction over the past several years, stating that deficits have been reduced by about two-thirds since he took office.

However, it is important to note that while deficits have decreased, the national debt continues to rise. The national debt stood at $10.6 trillion when President Obama took office.

Republicans are countering President Obama's message of "middle-class economics" by advocating for measures aimed at assisting working families. House GOP leaders have proposed expanding the 529 college savings accounts, which allow families to save for college tax-free. The White House had initially proposed taxing these accounts, but withdrew the plan following heavy public criticism and private pressure from prominent Democrats.

Representative Lynn Jenkins (R-KS) criticized the president's decision to abandon the 529 tax proposal, stating, "It was a terribly misguided idea, but it took a public outcry for the president to realize it... First, the president should put his full weight behind our plan to expand and strengthen 529 accounts... Because we should be rewarding people who work hard and play by the rules—not punishing them."

Representative Jenkins also urged the president to approve the Keystone XL oil pipeline, a measure that cleared the Senate this week but faces a potential veto from President Obama.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee to Receive Classified Document on Drone Policy

The Senate Intelligence Committee will receive a classified document on Thursday, which seeks to justify the administration's policy of targeting Americans overseas via drone attacks. The announcement was made by Dianne Feinstein, the committee's chairwoman, on Wednesday.

The document in question is the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) opinion regarding the use of lethal force in counterterrorism operations. Feinstein stated that it is crucial for the committee's oversight function to fully understand the legal basis for all intelligence and counterterrorism operations.

The development comes before the confirmation hearings for John Brennan, President Barack Obama's CIA director nominee. The president has directed the Department of Justice to provide the congressional Intelligence committees access to classified OLC advice related to the subject of the Department of Justice White Paper.

The 16-page white paper, titled "Lawfulness of a Lethal Operation Directed Against a U.S. Citizen who is a Senior Operational Leader of Al Qaida or an Associated Force," is a policy paper rather than an official legal document.

The drone strikes, a significant part of John Brennan's legacy as the president's principal adviser on terrorism, have been a subject of controversy. According to a count by the public policy group New America Foundation, at least 28 of al Qaeda's leading members have been killed in drone strikes, including the U.S. citizen Anwar al-Awlaki, who played an operational role in al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

The targeted killing of al-Awlaki, who was killed by a drone, and his teenage son in a separate strike, has been a point of contention for human rights groups in the United States. The justification for the attack was defended by the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Rep. Mike Rogers, on Wednesday.

In his confirmation hearing, John Brennan is expected to address the drone policy, among other issues. His stance on the legality of drone strikes, as expressed in a 2012 speech, is that they are legal under the Authorization for Use of Military Force resolution passed by Congress after the September 11 attacks and because they minimize collateral damage.

Title: ACLU Seeks Mental Health Counseling for Separated Immigrant Children

Article:

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has requested a federal judge to order the U.S. government to establish a fund for providing mental health counseling to approximately 2,000 immigrant children who were separated from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border. The request was made in court papers filed on Thursday, following a turbulent week for U.S. immigration officials who failed to meet a court-ordered deadline for reuniting children under the age of five.

The ACLU's court filing comes after a lawsuit that led to U.S. Judge Dana Sabraw in San Diego ordering the government to reunite families separated at the border last month. The family separation policy was part of President Donald Trump's efforts to curtail illegal immigration, which the administration ended last month following widespread protests.

According to the court document, nearly half of the 103 children under five remain separated due to safety concerns, the deportation of their parents, and other issues. The ACLU also alleged that the government failed to communicate with the plaintiffs about the release of immigrants, a promise made to the judge.

In addition to mental health counseling, the ACLU also asked the judge to order the government to provide detailed information by Monday about all children not yet reunited and to expedite background checks and verifications of family relationships. The government must reunite all parents and the remaining children by July 26.

The government acknowledged in its Thursday court filing that it had missed the Tuesday deadline for reuniting the youngest children with their parents but said it had now complied with the judge's order. The government's struggle to reunite around 100 children under five has raised questions among immigration advocates about the coherence of their plan for reuniting the remaining families.

Immigration officials have stated that the process was slowed by background checks, and in Thursday's court papers, they identified one parent with a warrant for murder in Guatemala and others with suspected human trafficking violations. Other parents were barred from being reunited for less serious violations, such as drunk driving convictions.

In a statement, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, Attorney General Jeff Sessions, and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar said, "Throughout the reunification process, our goal has been the well-being of the children and returning them to a safe environment." Beth Krause, a supervising lawyer at the Legal Aid Society's Immigrant Youth Project, said, "The reunification process has been chaotic and has unequivocally come at a cost."

Title: Rep. Duncan Hunter Resigns Amidst Campaign Funds Misuse Case, Cites Congressional Accomplishments and Military Service

Article:

Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.) has tendered his resignation to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and California Governor Gavin Newsom on Tuesday, with an official departure set for January 13. The 42-year-old congressman pleaded guilty last month to a single count of conspiracy to misuse at least $150,000 in campaign funds for personal expenses.

In his resignation letter, Hunter did not address his guilt or innoccy and instead highlighted his congressional achievements and emphasized his military service. Hunter joined the Marines following the 9/11 terror attacks and, in his letter, he detailed the ways he has helped his constituents improve their lives.

"I learned from an early age the importance of liberty, the value of patriotism, and what a strong and secure border can bring to a community," he said. "During my time in Congress, I had the privilege of helping thousands of individuals in my district."

Hunter also expressed pride in giving a voice to military personnel and standing with those who protect the nation's freedoms. According to the indictment, Hunter and his wife spent part of the campaign funds on a birthday party for their daughter at an expensive hotel, as well as funding social outings with friends at a French bistro in Washington, D.C.

Prosecutors also accused Hunter of spending part of the money on extramarital affairs with lobbyists and congressional aides. His wife, Margaret, was also charged in the case but accepted a plea deal in June, which required her to testify against her husband. The couple could have faced up to decades in prison prior to their plea agreements.

Republicans enjoy an 11-point registration advantage over Democrats in California's 50th District. Former congressman for California’s 49th District, Rep. Darrell Issa, is considered one of the front-runners to fill the vacant seat.

Governor Newsom, a Democrat, has yet to announce if he will call for a special election; he has the option under state law to leave the seat vacant until November, according to The San Diego Union-Tribune.

Title: Georgia State Representative Erica Thomas and Eric Sparkes Dispute Allegations of Racial Harassment

Article:

Georgia State Representative Erica Thomas (D) and Eric Sparkes, a man she accused of racial harassment, have been embroiled in a dispute over an incident that occurred at a local Publix grocery store.

On July 20, Thomas took to Twitter, stating that a white man had verbally assaulted her, calling her a "lazy SOB" and telling her to "go back to where she came from" because she had too many items in the express lane. Thomas is nine months pregnant and her husband, who is on active duty, was not present to defend her.

In a subsequent Facebook live video, Thomas described the incident, stating, "People are getting really out of control with this white privilege stuff." She explained that she was in the "10 items or less" aisle with more than the allowed number of items due to her pregnancy and the man, whom she later identified as Sparkes, approached her and made the racist remarks.

However, Sparkes, who has since appeared at Thomas's press conference to challenge her story, denies the allegations. In a Twitter post, he stated, "I walked into Publix, I bought my three items. There were three checkout lanes. One was express, the other two were empty. I kept my tongue shut. I went to pay for my items in one of the empty lanes."

Sparkes claimed that he was approached by Thomas, who had more than the allowed number of items in the express lane. He stated that he politely inquired about the situation with two customer service associates from Publix, who informed him that corporate policy did not allow them to do anything but that customers could speak up. Sparkes then left the store, thought about the situation, and returned to confront Thomas.

According to Sparkes, he and Thomas exchanged words, and he stated, "You're selfish." He claimed that Thomas approached him and made further comments, but he did not remember her exact words. Sparkes said he then called Thomas a "selfish little b*tch."

Sparkes has since denied Thomas's claims that he told her to "go back where you came from." He stated, "Her words stating on Twitter and her Facebook video saying I told she needs to go back to where she came from are untrue. I'm Cuban. I'm not white."

In a further twist, Sparkes claimed that Thomas is using the incident for political gain, stating, "This woman is playing the victim for political purposes because she is a state legislator." He added, "I'm a Democrat and will vote Democrat for the rest of my life, so call me whatever you want to believe. For her political purposes, make it black, white, brown, or whatever. It is so untrue."

The incident has sparked a heated debate on social media, with some supporting Thomas's account of the events and others supporting Sparkes's denial of the allegations. The full truth of the incident remains unclear, and further investigation may be necessary to determine exactly what transpired between Thomas and Sparkes at the grocery store.

Title: Mitt Romney's Tax Return History: A Look Back at His Stance and Previous Actions

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, has faced mounting pressure to release more than two years of tax returns, a demand that he has so far resisted. Romney argues that two years of tax returns, including his full 2010 return and an estimate of 2011 tax information, are sufficient and that he has complied with the law.

This stance is consistent with Romney's position during his 2002 campaign for Massachusetts governor. In that race, his Democratic rival, Shannon O'Brien, released her tax information and called on Romney to do the same. In May 2002, Romney stated, according to the Boston Herald, "People who run for public office are exposed to extraordinary scrutiny and that's as it should be, but there are some things that are not required for release, that are private, and I think my own income taxes, and my net worth and so forth are things I'd like to keep between myself and my family."

Romney's longtime strategist, Eric Fehrnstrom, cited the family's "privacy" and noted that state law did not require candidates to provide anything more than a financial disclosure form filed with the state Ethics Commission. However, Romney has also called for greater tax transparency in the past when it served his political purposes.

In the 2002 race, Romney sought to turn Enron into a campaign issue when it was revealed that O'Brien's husband, Emmett Hayes, had lobbying ties to the scandalized energy and commodities firm. Hayes had filed his taxes separately from O'Brien, and Fehrnstrom, then Romney's deputy campaign manager, demanded that O'Brien come clean about her husband's financial ties to Enron.
