"Her hands are not clean," Fehrnstrom said, according to the Herald. "She can't claim to be disclosing anything until she discloses the returns of her husband, the Enron lobbyist. Under Shannon O'Brien, the state Pension Board lost millions by buying Enron stock when it was collapsing - what is she hiding?"

Fehrnstrom made the demand even as Romney was refusing to release his own returns, which drew accusations of hypocrisy from editorial boards. However, Fehrnstrom defended the campaign's posture, saying that O'Brien was trying to hide important information from voters by declining to reveal her husband's returns, while Romney was simply acting on principle.

The tax return issue also made an appearance in Romney's first political campaign, his 1994 Senate run against Ted Kennedy. In that race, Romney assumed the role of transparency advocate. "It's time the biggest-taxing senator in Washington shows the people of Massachusetts how much he pays in taxes," Romney said in April of 1994, according to a report in the Boston Globe. Romney said he would release his own tax returns if Kennedy did, but the Senator refused, and so Romney did as well.

Title: Presidential Candidate Pete Buttigieg Claims God Is on His Side of the Gay Marriage Debate; Vice President Mike Pence Responds

Article:

In a recent address to an LGBT campaign group, Democratic Presidential hopeful and South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg criticized Vice President Mike Pence's religious belief that marriage should be between one man and one woman. Buttigieg, who is openly gay and married, stated, "I wish the Mike Pence's of the world would understand, that if you have a problem with who I am, your quarrel is not with me. Your quarrel, sir, is with my creator."

Buttigieg also referred to Pence when insisting that his gay marriage brought him "closer to God." In response, Pence, who has been a staunch believer in traditional marriage for his entire political career, has not issued any comments to provoke such pointed remarks.

Speaking in response to the mayor's comments, the Vice President told CNBC that Buttigieg "knows better" than to say "things that are critical of my Christian faith and about me personally." Pence added, "He knows me, but I get it. You know, it's like, again, 19 people running for president on that side in a party that's sliding off to the left. And they're all competing with one another for how much more liberal they are."

Pence noted that, as governor of Indiana, he "worked very closely with Mayor Pete" and that they "had a great working relationship."

In a separate response, Karen Pence, the Vice President's wife, also addressed Buttigieg's comments, declaring, "In our country, we need to understand you shouldn't be attacked for what your religious beliefs are." She added, "I think kids need to learn that, at a young age, that this is OK, what faith people have. We don't attack them for their faith."

Title: Ben Carson's Future Plans: Discussion of Vice Presidential Role and Campaign Strategy

Article:

Ben Carson, the former neurosurgeon who ended his presidential campaign last month, is reportedly considering a role as Vice President. According to The ███, members of Carson's campaign team are set to meet on March 29 in Palm Beach, where Carson owns a mansion. The meeting aims to discuss the future of Carson's political endeavors, including the utilization of a 700,000-person mailing list, a Political Action Committee (PAC) supporting Carson as a potential vice presidential pick, and a potential speaking program for Carson.

The main focus of the meeting, according to sources, is to position Carson favorably for a potential vice presidential offer from Donald Trump, should he become the nominee. The attendees of the meeting include Ben Carson Jr., Robert Dees, Ed Brookover, Logan Delaney, and Mike Murray.

When asked for comment, former campaign manager Ed Brookover directed inquiries to Hope Hicks, a spokesperson for Trump's campaign. Hicks did not respond to a request for comment. Shermichael Singleton, handling media requests for Carson, declined to answer questions. Delaney and Dees also did not respond to requests for comment.

Brookover has already joined the Trump campaign, as announced in a press release last Friday. He will be heading up a "Delegate Selection Team."

After ending his presidential campaign at the Conservative Political Action Conference two weeks ago, Carson announced that he would be heading up the group My Faith Votes, which aims to mobilize Christian voters in the general election. Carson is the "National Honorary Chairman" of the group, according to their website.

Carson has been more forgiving of Trump's past criticisms, dismissing the real estate mogul's comparison of his temperament to that of a child molester during the campaign. In a recent interview with Yahoo, Carson stated, "You have to admit, to some degree, it did work. A lot of people believed him."

The exact details of Carson's role in a potential Trump administration remain unclear. It is also unavailable if any members of the current Trump campaign will be present at the meeting.

Title: White House and Congressional Leaders Struggle to Change System Amid Shutdown and Debt Ceiling Crisis

Article:

The recent government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis has left many questioning the effectiveness of President Barack Obama's strategy to sideline Republicans. Despite the ongoing negotiations, there seems to be a lack of confidence that the system will fundamentally change.

As the White House and congressional leaders attempt to explain temporary fixes to the ongoing issues, the next few days will be crucial in determining the government's funding, the country's debt status, and the timing of future deadlines.

President Obama has been praised for his commitment to preserving Obamacare and maintaining budget basics, but the House GOP remains a significant force, with many tea party members continuing to push for their agenda.

Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) described his actions as a "divine and patriotic calling" at the Values Voters summit, indicating that future shutdown and debt limit standoffs are possible. Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), the ranking member of the Senate Budget Committee, expressed his belief that the issue must continue to be raised.

The White House argues that they are not negotiating with those demanding a "ransom" and instead are merely listening and talking. They also express satisfaction in putting the House Republicans in a difficult position for statewide and national elections.

However, the reality remains that, despite having a slim majority in one chamber of Congress, Republicans have successfully forced the president to choose between risking a global economic meltdown and accepting parts of their agenda. The world has warned about a market revolt that has not yet materialized.

The White House and congressional leaders are now faced with the challenge of finding a long-term solution to avoid future crises, but the outcome remains uncertain.

Title: President Trump and Former President Obama's Differing Stances on Syria

Article:

In a recent statement, President Donald Trump condemned the chemical attack in Syria as "reprehensible," attributing the heinous actions of the Bashar al-Assad regime to the past administration's perceived weakness and irresolution. This statement echoes Trump's campaign rhetoric, where he criticized former President Barack Obama's Syria policy.

During the same time in 2013, as a private citizen, Trump advocated for the U.S. to stay out of the Syrian conflict. On Tuesday, Trump's statement did not specify any actions his administration might take in response to the recent attack or his future stance toward Assad. Press Secretary Sean Spicer stated that the president's statement "speaks for itself" and that further discussions with allies will be held to determine the appropriate action.

In 2013, when the U.S. concluded the Assad regime had used chemical weapons, Trump tweeted that the U.S. should "stay the hell out of Syria." As the conflict in Syria intensified and the Obama administration considered an expanded U.S. role, Trump remained consistent in his message, advocating for non-involvement and viewing Syria as not America's problem.

In August 2013, when the U.S. and international community concluded that the Syrian government had again used chemical weapons, the Obama administration was reportedly considering a military strike. Trump questioned the wisdom of such a move. On August 30, 2013, a U.S. intelligence assessment found more than 1,400 Syrians were killed in the chemical weapons attack. Trump's tweets focused on how that made the U.S. look.

Obama ultimately sought congressional approval to carry out strikes in Syria, a move widely seen as a way to back away from the red line he had drawn, shifting the responsibility for a decision to escalate involvement in Syria onto Congress. It became clear that Congress was unlikely to agree on authorizing force, and that they did not want the responsibility.

On September 5, 2013, Trump expressed concern that Obama had set the red line in the first place. A day later, Trump offered a seemingly joking solution: use Obamacare in Syria so "they would self-destruct." Secretary of State John Kerry ultimately worked out a multinational agreement, including Russia, in which Assad would agree to give up his chemical weapons. Trump's assessment was not positive.

In the end, Trump concluded that Obama's handling of Syria made America look weak, a view that continues to be reflected in Trump's statements, as evidenced by his recent statement on Tuesday.

Title: Obama Abandons College Savings Tax Plan Following Intense Lobbying Effort

Article:

President Barack Obama has rescinded a controversial plan to tax college savings accounts, known as 529 plans, following a lobbying effort led by key members of his own party. The decision comes after House Republicans expressed their intention to expand the tax break, aiming to highlight the president's reversal.

Sources report that the president was lobbied on Air Force One by House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and received a call from House Budget Committee ranking Democrat Chris Van Hollen while flying from India to Saudi Arabia. Pelosi reportedly insisted that Obama drop the plan, effectively halting a policy that had been criticized for its potential negative impact on the middle class.

The president's proposal to tax 529 plans, which experts suggest primarily benefit upper-middle-class and wealthier families, was part of his broader plan to shift taxes to the wealthy and provide benefits to lower-income individuals. However, opposition to this specific element emerged swiftly, first from conservatives and then from mainstream groups and some Democrats.

On Tuesday, a Democratic aide confirmed that Van Hollen had expressed his concerns about the issue to Pelosi on Air Force One. The White House responded by abandoning the plan, with the president's other tax and education proposals remaining intact.

House leaders are now planning to bring a bipartisan bill to the floor in late February for a vote, which aims to expand tax savings for 529s. This move provides Republicans another opportunity to showcase their small tax victory.

Republicans had criticized the White House's proposal from the outset, with anti-tax crusader Grover Norquist labeling it a plan to impose taxes on middle-class families saving for their children's education. The criticism continued, with House Speaker John Boehner issuing a statement Monday, quoting experts who argued the proposal would harm average Americans.

Democrats also voiced their concerns, with moderate Wisconsin Democrat Rep. Ron Kind joining Republican Kansas Rep. Lynn Jenkins to propose a bill to expand and strengthen 529s. This legislation is expected to be presented on the floor next month.

House Ways and Means Chairman Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) expressed disappointment in the president's decision, urging him to collaborate with Republicans to pass the Rep. Lynn Jenkins' plan to strengthen and expand these important accounts.

Not everyone shared the same sentiment, however. Former White House economic adviser Jared Bernstein suggested the White House might have been "blindsided" by the criticism of the tax plan, especially since it is a small part of a proposal that aims to boost college access for lower-income individuals. He argued that the White House could have adjusted the plan to allow lower-income individuals to continue using the accounts.

Some left-leaning groups supported nixing the savings vehicle, attributing its demise to the perception that it was widely used by the middle class. However, data indicates that only 3 percent of families use the 529 plans, and the majority of these families make more than $200,000 per year. Iowa Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley, former chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, stated that the average amount saved in such plans by Iowa families is less than $20,000.

Grassley concluded, "The tax code encourages all kinds of behavior, and saving for college is usually something everybody supports. The president's dropping his misguided plan is a victory for common sense."

Title: Prominent Trump Supporters Express Dissatisfaction with Attorney General Jeff Sessions

Article:

Some of President Donald Trump's most ardent media supporters have expressed dissatisfaction with Attorney General Jeff Sessions. In an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday, Trump expressed regret for choosing Sessions as attorney general. The White House stated on Thursday that Trump still has confidence in Sessions, but noted that dismissing Sessions would be within Trump's presidential authority.

Despite the White House's assertion of confidence in Sessions, some of the most vocal pro-Trump voices are openly criticizing Sessions. Longtime Trump adviser Roger Stone told a Washingtonian writer on Wednesday, "I know that Sessions does not have the confidence of the President. He should resign."

GotNews writer Chuck Johnson suggested in a Facebook post on Thursday that Trump should fire Sessions and appoint Texas Sen. Ted Cruz as attorney general, stating, "Cruz is pro-Constitution and an order of magnitude smarter than Sessions." Right-wing blogger Mike Cernovich, whose work Donald Trump Jr. has publicly praised, criticized Sessions as "out of touch," adding that the attorney general "has to go."

New York Post columnist Michael Goodwin called for Trump to fire Sessions even before the NYT interview. In a column on Monday, Goodwin wrote, "He can begin by firing two other people — Attorney General Jeff Sessions and his deputy, Rod Rosenstein."

Fox News host Sean Hannity and radio host Rush Limbaugh have not explicitly called for Sessions' resignation or dismissal, but both have expressed dissatisfaction with Sessions. Hannity criticized Sessions on his radio show Wednesday for not reopening the investigation into former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's email server.

"I don't know where Jeff Sessions is, maybe something's happening that we don't know about," Hannity said. He added, "I'm like, OK, we have a new attorney general, statute of limitations have not gone anywhere, why isn't this woman being investigated?"

Radio host Rush Limbaugh similarly appeared to side with Trump over Sessions on Thursday. "And this recusal just blindsided [Trump]," Limbaugh said. "I'll tell you why. I think Trump believed, since Sessions was so willing in the Senate to go against amnesty and to go against comprehensive immigration reform, I am convinced that Trump thought that Sessions was a fighter just like Trump sees himself. And then when Sessions recused, Trump was surprised."

"And if I were in Trump's shoes I would be so livid about [the Russia investigation] I wouldn't be able to contain myself the way he is. It is that absurd," Limbaugh added. "This is totally ridiculous."

Title: Florida Senator Marco Rubio Criticizes U.S.-Cuba Relations, Claims No Improvement for Cuban People

Article:

Florida Senator Marco Rubio garnered significant applause during the Republican debate in Miami on Thursday, as he expressed strong criticism of former President Barack Obama's policy of re-establishing diplomatic relations with Cuba.

Rubio, the son of Cuban migrants, is aiming to secure the Florida primary on Tuesday and revive his campaign for the White House. During the debate, he was asked about Obama's planned trip to Cuba later this month, still governed by the communist Castro regime.

When asked why the United States should not engage further with Cuba, Rubio argued that the U.S. changes had allowed money to flow to the Castro regime, stating, "Nothing will change for the Cuban people... In fact, things are worse than they were before this opening." He further explained that the only result of "the opening" was that the Cuban government had more sources of money.

Donald Trump, who currently leads Rubio in Florida polls, had previously stated that opening Cuba was acceptable. Under attack in the Miami debate from candidates trailing him in the polls and the mounting delegate count, Trump said, "I want a much better deal with Cuba" and reiterated a familiar line, "We don't make any good deals."

"I do agree that something should take place," he added. "After 50 years, it's enough time, folks. But we have to make a good deal here."

In response, Rubio listed several anti-Castro grievances and was met with enthusiastic applause, drowning out attempts to ask Senator Ted Cruz, the son of a Cuban father and an American mother, the next question. Cruz was asked if he would break diplomatic relations with Cuba.

Cruz responded, stating, "The question illustrates 'a real difference between us' on foreign policy." Cruz claimed that Trump supports the "same basic trajectory" of policy as Obama and Hillary Clinton, Obama's first secretary of state, have established.

John Kasich, the fourth man onstage, was asked if he would encourage U.S. companies to do business with Cuba. Kasich stated that he would not.

Trump, meanwhile, reiterated, "We would not do the deal unless it would be a very good deal for us." The article does not contain information on the responses of other candidates during the debate.

Title: George Stephanopoulos Faces Backlash Over Clinton Foundation Donations

Article:

Several Twitter users have expressed discontent towards ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos this week, calling for his resignation. The backlash stems from Stephanopoulos' donations to the Clinton Foundation and perceived bias in his reporting.

Tweets directed at Stephanopoulos include:

- "@GStephanopoulos I'll sign a petition to have you fired, you Clinton hack" - Orwellian Apocalypse (@GoogleDoesEvil) May 15, 2015
- "@GStephanopoulos does Team Hillary write your copy, or do you simply clear it with them?" - Mark Stickle (@MarkStickle) May 14, 2015
- "@GStephanopoulos And after that, new details on your $50,000 Clinton Foundation donation. Right? RIGHT?" - Amy (@a_doodle) May 14, 2015

Additional tweets question Stephanopoulos' relationship with the Clintons, such as:

- "@GStephanopoulos Did George keep lookout for Hillary when Bill had female guests in the Oval Office? Asking for a friend" - Beatlegal09 (@Beatlegal09) May 15, 2015
- "@GStephanopoulos come on midget man, the gig is up. You are a Clinton hack" - Adorable Deplorable (@NoTransparency) May 15, 2015

Some tweets also criticize Stephanopoulos' donation to the Clinton Foundation and his perceived bias in reporting, such as:

- "@GStephanopoulos You should donate to help Nepal! But maybe to an organization with better than 85% overhead" - Beelzebub ’ s Tesseract (@CJHerod) May 15, 2015
- "@GStephanopoulos Any other news since yesterday? I heard about a biased stooge donating to a former boss's slush fund. You should cover it" - Anthony Bialy (@AnthonyBialy) May 15, 2015

Further investigation reveals that Stephanopoulos donated $75,000 to the Clinton Foundation and is listed as a notable member of the Clinton Global Initiative in 2010 and 2011. ABC News admitted Stephanopoulos was a member but stated he did not pay any fees. Instead, the CGI listed him as a member because he moderated a panel for the foundation in those years.

Andrew Stiles at the Washington Free Beacon contacted ABC about the donations, and ABC replied ten minutes after the left-wing site Politico broke the news. This led the Washington Post to demand ABC apologize for seemingly shopping around a scoop to a friendlier news outlet.

Title: NFL Discusses Social Justice Issues, Not National Anthem Protests, at Annual Meeting

Article:

National Football League (NFL) officials discussed social justice issues and political activism during their annual meeting in New York City on Tuesday, rather than addressing the controversy surrounding players kneeling during the U.S. national anthem. The meeting took place amid protests by demonstrators outside the venue, who showed support for the players.

NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell told reporters that the meeting focused on issues in the communities, aiming to make them better. President Donald Trump's repeated criticism of players for kneeling during the national anthem, which he reiterated as recently as Monday, has led to a wider practice of the silent protests.

Outside the Manhattan luxury hotel where team owners, players, and their union leaders met, about two dozen people demonstrated their backing for the protesting athletes, kneeling on the sidewalk while holding placards that read "Take a knee against police brutality."

The small but growing number of players who have taken to kneeling during the national anthem are protesting the killing by police of unarmed black men and boys across the United States, as well as racial disparities in the criminal justice system. More than half of all NFL players are black.

Goodell appeared less interested in stifling the silent protests and instead praised players' character, saying he wanted to help their political activism. "Today's discussion with our players was very productive and very important. It reflected our commitment to work together with our players on issues of social justice," said Goodell.

Goodell, who cut his news conference off after one question, said the league will meet again with players, probably in the next two weeks, and will spend more time talking to reporters when the two-day meeting concludes on Wednesday.

An NFL spokesman had said the president might not see an outright ban on the national anthem protests soon, if ever, and predicted that the meeting would focus on ways for all sides to work together.

Team owners and 13 players had a "productive meeting" of their own earlier on Tuesday at the league offices about how to collaborate on positive social change and addressing inequality, according to a statement by the NFL and the players' union, the NFL Players Association.

Players and their union have bristled at Trump's assertion they are unpatriotic. Though still a minority, more players have begun kneeling since the new football season began, and some sympathetic teammates have linked arms with the kneelers while standing themselves.

Former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, who first popularized the gesture last year, said he settled on kneeling as a form of protest because it is widely seen as a gesture of respect. Kaepernick, who is a free agent, was not invited to attend the meeting.

Title: China Announces Tariffs on US Products Worth $60 Billion in Escalating Trade War

Article:

China has announced plans to impose tariffs of up to 25% on US products worth $60 billion, the latest move in an escalating trade conflict between the two nations. The Chinese government stated on Friday that it would levy duties of 25%, 20%, 10%, and 5% on the targeted products if the US administration follows through on threats to tax $200 billion of Chinese goods.

In a statement, the Chinese State Council Tariff Commission criticized the US for unilaterally escalating trade tensions, stating, "In violation of the bilateral consensus reached after multiple rounds of negotiations, the United States has again unilaterally escalated trade frictions."

China has listed 5,207 US products that will be subject to these tariffs, with the aim of "safeguarding its own legitimate interests." The targeted products include meat, coffee, nuts, alcoholic drinks, minerals, chemicals, leather products, wood products, machinery, furniture, auto parts, and more.

In response, Sarah Sanders, the White House press secretary, stated, "Instead of retaliating, China should address the longstanding concerns about its unfair trading practices."

The US and China trade goods and services worth approximately $650 billion annually, making it the largest trading relationship between two countries worldwide. However, China exports far more to the US than vice versa, making it more challenging for the country to counteract US tariffs.

These new tariffs would affect about 38% of all American exports to China, which are worth approximately $170 billion in total.

Trade tensions between the US and China have been escalating since April 2017, when President Donald Trump directed the US Commerce Department to investigate whether imports of steel and aluminum from China and other countries posed a threat to national security. The investigation led to tariffs on steel and aluminum products from China and many other countries in March. Beijing responded with equal measures.

In July, the US imposed tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods to pressure China into abandoning what the Trump administration describes as unfair practices such as intellectual property theft. Beijing retaliated with penalties of an equal scale, targeting American products such as motorcycles and communications satellites.

The most recent threat from the Trump administration came this week, when it warned that it could impose steeper tariffs than originally planned on another batch of imports from China. The White House had previously considered imposing a 10% tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods; under the new plan, tariffs of 25% would be applied.

Protectionist moves by the US have also drawn responses from other major trading partners, including Canada, Mexico, and the European Union, who have retaliated with their own tariffs in response to US taxes on steel and aluminum.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Announces Measures to Limit President Trump's Military Actions Regarding Iran

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced plans to introduce a War Powers Resolution aimed at limiting President Trump's ability to conduct military operations against Iran. The announcement comes in response to Trump's decision to conduct an airstrike in Iraq that resulted in the death of Iranian Gen. Qassem Soleimani, head of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' elite Quds Force.

Pelosi and other Democrats have been critical of Trump's decision, claiming he did not properly notify Congress in advance and warning about the risk of escalation in the region. Trump has also threatened additional action if Iran retaliates for Soleimani's death.

On Saturday, the White House sent Congress formal notification of the drone strike under the War Powers Act, a senior administration official told The Associated Press. The notification, required by law within 48 hours of the introduction of American forces into an armed conflict or a situation that could lead to war, had to be signed and sent to Congress.

Trump has stated that "legal notice is not required" for him to take additional action, but claimed that his online posts provided notification to Congress that he "will quickly & fully strike back, & perhaps in a disproportionate manner" if Iran attacks "any U.S. person or target."

Iran has vowed to retaliate and avenge Soleimani's death, and has announced they will be abandoning the 2015 nuclear deal, signaling threats of further nuclear proliferation. Trump had tweeted Saturday that even Iran's cultural sites were potential targets for U.S. military action.

Earlier that day, Iraqi lawmakers approved a resolution calling to expel U.S. troops from the country, who were sent there more than four years ago to aid in the fight against the Islamic State terror group.

Title: New York City's Jewish Community Faces String of Alleged Hate Crimes, Including Monsey Attack

Article:

A series of alleged hate crimes targeting Jewish institutions and individuals in New York City has left the Jewish community reeling. The most recent and horrific incident occurred on Saturday night in the suburb of Monsey, where a rabbi's home was attacked, leaving several people seriously wounded.

The alleged assailant, Grafton Thomas, entered the rabbi's home shortly after 10:00 p.m. during the seventh night of Hanukkah and began slashing people with a longsword. The motivations of Thomas are unknown, and friends report that he is mentally ill. However, he is an African American man, which may not necessarily indicate a connection to white supremacy, the alt-right, or the rhetoric of President Donald Trump, as some have suggested.

In May, during a U.S. House of Representatives' Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties hearing, concerns were raised about a supposed rise in white nationalism and hate crimes. However, the perpetrators of these attacks in New York City are often not the MAGA-worshipping alt-right terrorists that the hearing was concerned about. According to Tablet's Armin Rose, the majority of the alleged perpetrators in New York are either black or Hispanic.

Far-right anti-Semitism is not the only form of contempt for Jewish people. Campus leftism can sometimes be tinged with anti-Semitism, and progressive activists have associated with known anti-Semites. The Jersey City shooters had a connection to the Black Hebrew Israelites, a black nationalist cult best known for precipitating the Covington incident.

It is unclear whether Thomas, by virtue of being black, is a likely member of a group or an activist for a leftist or black nationalist cause. In fact, it would be unsurprising if he had no broader motivation. Murder is usually non-ideological, and just a tiny number of killings each year can be credibly connected to a political agenda.

According to Batya Ungar-Sargon in Forward, there is little evidence that these attacks are ideologically motivated, at least in terms of the ideologies of hate that are most familiar. The left should not ignore anti-Semitism when its perpetrators are inconvenient targets who contradict the progressive doctrine of intersectionality. The same goes for the right, which often turns a blind eye to anti-Semitism among its own ranks.

Everyone should be concerned and angry about attacks and intimidation directed at Jewish people, but it is also crucial to demand more reporting and more accurate reporting about the scale of the problem. Nationally, it is not clear that anti-Semitic violence is rising dramatically, as tallies often include anti-Semitic taunts, schoolyard bullying, and online writings. In New York City, anti-Semitic incidents increased by 53 percent from 2018 to 2019, according to the NYPD, but the overwhelming majority of anti-Semitic incidents are classified by police as "criminal mischief," which typically means vandalism and graffiti. Just 13 percent of incidents involved violence.

Title: New York State Senator and City Councilman Accused in Plot to Purchase GOP Spot in NYC Mayoral Race

Article:

New York State Senator Malcolm Smith, a Democrat, was arrested Tuesday morning and led from his Queens home in handcuffs for allegedly attempting to buy his way onto the Republican ticket in this year's New York City mayoral election. City Councilman Daniel Halloran, a Republican, and four other local politicians, all Republicans from the New York metropolitan area, were also arrested and stand accused of conspiring with Smith.

According to the complaint, Smith agreed with a cooperating witness and an undercover F.B.I. agent, posing as a wealthy real estate developer, to pay off leaders of Republican county committees in New York's five boroughs. The bribes were intended to obtain specific certificates authorizing him to run for mayor as a Republican, despite being a registered Democrat.

U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara stated in a statement that Smith "drew up the game plan," while Halloran, the city councilman, "quarterbacked" the effort to find party chairmen in the state who were open to receiving bribes. Halloran was allegedly to receive $20,500 in exchange for supporting Smith's bid for the GOP nomination, while two other officials were to allegedly receive " $40,000 in bribes with a promise of $40,000 more."

Smith's lawyer, Gerald Shargel, told the Times that Smith "is a dedicated and highly respected public servant and he steadfastly denies these charges." Smith, according to his official biography, first won election to the state senate in 2000. He was the state senate's president pro tempore when Democrats controlled the chamber in 2008-10. In recent years, however, he has often been at odds with his fellow Democrats.

Current Mayor Michael Bloomberg (I) is prevented from seeking a fourth term. City Council Speaker Christine Quinn is thought to be the leading contender for the Democratic nomination. The Republican frontrunner, according to the Daily News, is Joe Lhota. He was a deputy mayor during the administration of Republican Mayor Rudy Giuliani.

Title: China Threatens Retaliation Against U.S. Tariffs, Pushes Back on Hong Kong Interference

Article:

China has responded to the looming U.S. tariffs, stating that the measures violate agreements reached by Presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping. In a statement, the Chinese government vowed retaliation, without specifying the nature of its response. The U.S. and China are currently embroiled in a trade dispute, with both nations imposing tariffs on each other's goods.

The U.S. plans to impose 10% tariffs on an additional $300 billion in Chinese imports, a move that has taken the two nations off the track of resolving their dispute through negotiation. The State Council Tariff Committee, which has overseen the tit-for-tat retaliation, stated that China "has no choice but to take necessary measures to retaliate."

In a separate development, a foreign affairs ministry spokeswoman expressed hope that the U.S. would leave Hong Kong as an internal matter for the Chinese government to deal with. Trump has previously linked the trade war with the ongoing turmoil in Hong Kong, stating that an agreement with China has to be on "our terms."

U.S. stocks finished the day higher after a volatile session, with trade headlines causing investor unease. The U.S. has announced tariffs set for September 1 and December 15, while China has halted purchases of agricultural goods and allowed the yuan to weaken. However, top negotiators held a phone call earlier this week, and the U.S. delayed the imposition of some of the new import taxes.

Negotiators also agreed to have another call in the coming two weeks, and people familiar with the situation said earlier that the Chinese delegation is sticking to their plan to travel to the U.S. in September for face-to-face meetings.

China's statement indicates that Beijing doesn't think the U.S. delaying some of the tariffs is enough. China is sticking to the position that no new duties should be imposed at all, and its retaliation "may not be limited to tariffs."

Hu Xijin, the editor-in-chief of the Communist Party's Global Times newspaper, echoed this sentiment. He tweeted before the Thursday announcement that China wants both sides to respect the consensus reached when Trump and Xi met in Osaka in June. "I doubt the Chinese side will resume large-scale purchase of U.S. farm goods under the current circumstances," he said.

Less than 12 hours before the Chinese statement on retaliation, Trump appeared to float the possibility of another meeting with Xi. In a flurry of tweets, he defended his tariff decisions, praised Xi, and urged the Chinese president to "humanely" resolve the protests that have gripped Hong Kong for more than two months.

China's position on the trade negotiations has been consistent and clear. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Hua Chunying said, "We hope that the U.S. side will do as what they say." China's position on Hong Kong is that it is a purely internal affair, and the U.S. should not interfere.

Trump ended his Twitter post with an apparent overture to Xi, writing "Personal meeting?" without clarifying whether he was suggesting another summit. Hua said the two leaders "have always kept in touch through meetings, calls, and letters."

Title: Sequestration Threatens U.S. Military Readiness for Combat Missions

Article:

The automatic budget cuts known as sequestration could leave the U.S. military unprepared for the most challenging combat missions, according to the Pentagon. In April, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel told Congress that the military is "eating its seed corn." The cuts will heavily impact maintenance and training, further eroding the readiness of the force and will be costly to regain in the future, Hagel said.

The Air Force is reportedly in a special bind due to the cuts in flying hours. At Seymour Johnson Air Force Base in North Carolina, training flights are part of the daily routine. F-15 fighter jets roll down the flight line and launch into a cloudy sky. The base is home to the Air Combat Command's Fourth Fighter Wing, which is made up of four squadrons of fighters. They practice and practice so they can be ready to deploy anywhere in the world, at any time.

However, the leadership has been told to save money, resulting in a reduction of flying hours. Lt. Col. James Howard, of the 336th Fighter Squadron, had to ground the squadron so that the other units on this base could keep flying. The longer the pilots remain idle, the longer it will take for them to get ready to fly again. Fighter pilots must fly and drill their skills on a regular basis, from dogfighting to helping ground troops under fire. Otherwise, they lose their certification.

Some Pentagon budget hawks argue these complaints are part of the military's propaganda effort to avoid budget cuts. They say the military is hoping to win sympathy by deliberately cancelling high-profile programs, like appearances by the Blue Angels and Fleet Week in New York.

Republican Sen. John McCain argues that the military should be protected from these automatic cuts. On Meet the Press last month, McCain said Congress should do for the military what it did for the Federal Aviation Administration after travelers complained about flight delays caused by budget cuts.

Todd Harrison, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments, suggests that Congress and the military are banking on the chance that next year the budget will be back to normal. In other words, it could be better to ground a few pilots now, hoping you won't have to make permanent cuts, like having fewer pilots or fewer planes.

The Pentagon hopes to get limited relief soon by asking Congress for permission to shift money around in order to protect top priorities like flying time. However, the long-term solution is a budget deal—which is not even visible on the horizon.

Title: Senate Rule Change Accelerates Confirmation of Obama's Judicial Nominees

Article:

The United States Senate has witnessed a significant shift in the confirmation of judicial nominees under President Barack Obama, following a rule change initiated by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) in November 2013. This rule change has enabled the Senate to confirm numerous judges, many of whom will hold lifetime appointments and extend the administration's influence for years to come.

Since the rule change, the Senate has confirmed 68 district and circuit court judges, compared to 36 during the equivalent period of the 113th Congress before the rules change, according to Senate statistics. The rule change has rendered all nominees, except those to the Supreme Court, eligible for approval with a bare majority, as opposed to the previous requirement of a 60-vote supermajority to overcome a filibuster.

The rule change has been met with resistance from the Republican party, who have employed their remaining procedural tools to delay the approval of judges and executive branch nominees. However, the era of lengthy confirmation battles appears to be over.

Democrats argue that the rule change will leave a lasting impact on the courts, with the installation of liberal-leaning justices at various levels. Marge Baker, a vice president at People for the American Way, stated, "The rules change has made a huge difference. The legacy of this Congress has been the impact that the president and the Senate have made with judicial vacancies."

The rule change has also been met with support from Democrats, who argue that it has cleared a backlog of judges and addressed judicial emergencies. However, the rule change has been criticized for contributing to a legislative stalemate and a decline in the Senate's efficiency.

The rule change has also had consequences for executive branch nominees, with Senate Republicans blocking a number of Obama's ambassadorial choices before the Senate recessed for August. In the pre-nuclear rule change days, the Senate might have unanimously approved a group of new ambassadors before recessing, but those days are over.

The effectiveness of the rule change remains a topic of debate, with both parties offering their perspectives on its impact. Confirmation rates are up, but the nomination process still moves slowly towards approval. The exact impact of the rule change on individual nominees is unclear, as it is impossible to determine which votes were made in protest of the rules change and which were made in protest of an individual nominee.

Democratic aides and researchers argue that at least 20 key judicial and executive nominees would have been blocked or delayed for months under the old rules. In their view, Jeh Johnson would not be Homeland Security secretary, John Koskinen would still be waiting for a vote, and former Rep. Mel Watt (D-N.C.) would still be in Congress, not leading the Federal Housing Finance Agency.

The rule change has been criticized for empowering the president and weakening the Senate's role as a check on the executive branch. A Senate Republican aide stated, "It's empowered Obama and has taken power away from elected representatives that could offer a check on Obama." The GOP also argues that the Senate is less efficient than it was a year ago, with each nomination consuming an hour or more of the Senate's time.

Title: National Poll Shows Ben Carson's Support Dropping Among Republican Voters

Article:

A new national poll released today indicates a decline in support for 2016 presidential candidate Ben Carson, who was previously leading the race for the Republican nomination. The neurosurgeon currently has 16 percent support, according to the Quinnipiac University poll, a drop of 7 percentage points in the last month. This places him behind frontrunner Donald Trump, who has 27 percent support, Sen. Marco Rubio with 17 percent, and Sen. Ted Cruz with 16 percent. All other GOP candidates have 5 percent or less support.

In early November, Carson was neck-and-neck with Trump for the lead. However, the new poll shows Carson in a battle with Rubio and Cruz, both of whom are seeing their highest support in months.

The decline in Carson's support can be attributed to doubts among Republican voters about his experience and leadership abilities. Only 42 percent of Republican voters now believe Carson has the right experience to be president, a significant drop from 64 percent four weeks ago. Similarly, only six in ten say he has strong leadership qualities, down from 76 percent in early November.

Carson's fall in support has also affected other areas, including honesty and trustworthiness, and overall favorability, where Carson had been high. In a hypothetical general election match-up, his 10-point lead over Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton from last month has evaporated. The new poll shows 46 percent for Clinton and 43 percent for Carson, respectively.

Clinton also improved in hypothetical faceoffs with Cruz and Rubio. Carson's 25-point lead among independents has disintegrated to just a single point, while Clinton now leads Carson by 16 points among women, where they had been neck-and-neck just four weeks ago.

Clinton still holds a wide lead on the Democratic nomination race, ahead 60 to 30 percent over Sen. Bernie Sanders. The poll shows Clinton solidifying support among women and liberals.

The new numbers were finalized before Carson's recent trip to Jordan to meet with Syrian refugees, a move aimed at bolstering his foreign policy credentials in the wake of the Paris attacks. However, most of Carson's support has dropped equally across the board, particularly among evangelical voters, where he dropped 13 points.

Trump remains steady on the top of the national polls, the undisputed frontrunner less than two months from the Iowa caucuses.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Condemns White Nationalist Robocalls Ahead of Primary

Article:

In the lead-up to Wisconsin's primary election, Republican Governor Scott Walker has distanced himself from a series of racially charged robocalls made by the American National Super PAC and its white nationalist founder, William Johnson. The calls, which have been flooding Wisconsin landlines, support Donald Trump's presidential campaign and contain coded language that appeals to white nationalist sentiments.

The robocall, narrated by an elderly woman, promotes Trump as a candidate who "will respect all women and help preserve western civilization." In the context of white nationalist rhetoric, this phrase is interpreted as a promise to maintain white supremacy and oppose immigration and welfare policies perceived as benefiting minorities.

The calls, while relatively mild compared to Johnson's previous efforts, have caused controversy due to their timing and the political climate in Wisconsin. Governor Walker, who built his political power base in the state's suburbs, has been criticized for his policies that disproportionately affect minority communities.

The New Republic published an in-depth article two years ago that examined the racial polarization in Milwaukee and its suburbs, where the chairman of one county's Republican Party referred to a predominantly African-American neighborhood as "the colored section" in 2014. White flight between 1960 and 2010 tripled the population of three rural counties around Milwaukee, while the percentage of African-American residents in those counties is under 2 percent. The black poverty rate within the city is the second-highest in the country.

Throughout his political career, Governor Walker has implemented policies that have been criticized as harmful to minority communities, such as cutting funding for public transportation and advocating for private-school vouchers that have been accused of decimating public education. He has also supported privatizing prisons and cutting taxes, which have made it difficult to restore funding for these programs.

The racial polarization in Wisconsin has been fueled by talk-radio hosts like Charlie Sykes, who regularly traffics in white resentment politics. Sykes, who has referred to Michelle Obama as "Mooch," has grown rich by spewing racial divisiveness, and has frequently featured Governor Walker as a guest.

The timing of the white nationalist robocalls, coupled with the implementation of Wisconsin's new voter-ID law, has added to the controversy. The law, which could disenfranchise as many as 300,000 mostly minority and student voters, is part of a broader Republican effort to limit the voting power of traditional Democratic constituencies. The law's implementation comes after the Supreme Court eviscerated the Voting Rights Act, which was first passed to protect the voting rights of minorities.

Governor Walker and his allies have condemned the robocalls and Trump as polarizing figures, but critics argue that the governor and his allies have a history of advocating for policies that disproportionately affect minority communities. Despite their denials, their actions and rhetoric have been criticized as inherently racist, and the white nationalist robocalls have simply brought this racism out into the open.

Title: U.S. Stock Market Dips Amid Global Economic Uncertainty, but Experts Remain Calm

Article:

Investors experienced a turbulent Monday as the U.S. stock market followed Asian markets downward, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average opening with a significant 1,000-point drop. However, concerns about China's struggling economy do not necessarily signal a global recession, according to several analysts.

On Monday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 15,871.35 after a 3.6 percent decline, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index came close to a 4 percent decline. The selloff followed a 1,000-point drop over the previous five days. Outside the U.S., declines in Europe, Japan, and Hong Kong were approximately 5 percent, with an 8.5 percent plunge on China's benchmark stock index prompting a "Black Monday" label in Shanghai news reports.

For shaken investors outside China, analysts suggest keeping Monday's swoon in perspective. Austan Goolsbee, a former top White House economic adviser now at the University of Chicago, told NPR that there are several factors that make him feel better now than in the fall of 2008. He cited the root of the crisis not being events happening in the United States, less borrowing involved in the current situation, and an equity bubble rather than a fundamental economic issue.

Forecasters expect the latest reading on economic growth, coming this week, will show US expansion at a pace slightly above 3 percent annualized. The volume of home sales ticked up positively in the latest monthly report, reaching the highest rate in eight years, and improvement in the job market has brought unemployment down to 5.3 percent of the labor force.

While the effects of what happens in China may not stay in China, they shouldn't be exaggerated, according to forecasters. The cooling of China's economy ripples outward to affect emerging-market nations more than developed ones. For the U.S., this might have only small economic effects, perhaps modestly weaker export opportunities to emerging nations, offset by some positive benefits as Americans reap more gain than harm from sagging commodity prices.

Volatility in the stock market can seem unsettling, but it serves a purpose, according to analysts. It can help avoid market bubbles by showing some tug and pull in the markets as investors collectively argue about appropriate prices for investments. For long-term investors, dips can be buying opportunities. With the S&P index down more than 10 percent from levels seen in July, some investment strategists see this as a good buying opportunity or perhaps getting close to it.

For millions of Americans, a preliminary hurdle is simply saving enough money to invest at all. According to one bankrate.com survey earlier this year, more than half of Americans have no money in stocks or stock mutual funds. For those saving for retirement, another hurdle is a "twice-burned" aversion to stocks, including among Millennials who were vicarious witnesses to the dotcom bust and Great Recession.

David Kelly, chief global strategist at JPMorgan Funds, acknowledges scenarios where things could go from bad to worse, even in the U.S. However, he calls such scenarios merely possible, "not likely."

Title: "Media Madness: An Analysis of Howard Kurtz's Book on the Trump White House and the Press"

Article:

Howard Kurtz's latest book, "Media Madness," offers an analysis of the tumultuous relationship between the Trump administration and the media. The book delves into the ongoing battle between the president and the press, which Kurtz frames as "the war over the truth."

Kurtz, a Fox News commentator, attempts to apportion blame between both sides, but he is quicker to criticize the media for underestimating Trump's chances in the 2016 election than he is to lay blame at Trump's feet for his embrace of alternative facts.

The book portrays Trump as a surrogate for his electoral base of disenchanted white working-class voters, and therefore, according to Kurtz, should be afforded greater patience, even as he tramples on the truth. However, the book acknowledges that Trump is "loose with his language," fails to "vet" his pronouncements, and "sometimes regurgitates half-baked comments."

Despite these admissions, Kurtz places the onus on the media, contending that it mistakenly takes Trump literally while arguing that Trump's casualness does not always merit a press-driven fusillade.

The book provides a detailed account of the White House as a chaotic, seat-of-the-pants operation, reminiscent of a cross between Lord of the Flies and Goodfellas. The book recounts several instances of Trump's anger and outbursts, such as his confrontation with former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer and his one-time campaign manager, Paul Manafort.

The book also sheds light on the power dynamics within the White House, including tensions between key figures such as Kellyanne Conway and Jared Kushner. The book portrays Conway as being displeased with Kushner's perceived attempts to limit her access to the Oval Office, while Kushner denies any involvement in the episode of palace intrigue.

As to be expected, Kurtz goes easy on Fox News, his current employer. He notes that Sean Hannity and Jeanine Pirro are Trump's favorite interviewers, but writes that the news desk can hold Trump's feet to the fire.

However, the book comes up short as a critique of the media. While it captures the mainstream media's visible biases, it lets the president off way too easily. Kurtz bemoans the media's tarnished reputation but says little of Trump's. That's called stacking the deck.

Title: FBI Surveillance of Martin Luther King Jr. and Comparisons to Trump Investigation

Article:

The FBI conducted surveillance on Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1960s, allegedly due to concerns about his associates' ties to the Russian government. The investigation involved electronic surveillance and the examination of salacious material of a sexual nature. The administration that initially authorized the spying has denied these allegations.

In a controversial article published by Standpoint, Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer David Garrow details his discoveries about King's private behavior, which were met with resistance from various media outlets. The revelations, if true, suggest that King and the FBI had a complex relationship, with the FBI bugging hotel rooms where he stayed and investigating him in a manner that raises questions about the prurient nature of the investigation.

The allegations against King include participating in a rape and an orgy, offering advice during the alleged rape, and making suggestive comments to women. The FBI document alleges that King "immediately and forcefully raped" a woman while another watched, and that he made lewd comments during an orgy the following day.

Garrow, who has written extensively about King, comes to these conclusions after reading FBI summaries of audio surveillance of King. The tapes remain under lock-and-key at the National Archives until 2027. The raw FBI reports, particularly those that rely on informants, often contain gossip, rumors, and lies told by those seeking advantage. However, because these reports come straight from audio tapes, their level of authenticity may be higher than other information gathered by the bureau.

The allegations against King have been met with a curious indifference from the American media, with some suggesting that the allegations are too off-putting to report. The allegations have made headlines in other countries, but have received little attention in the United States. Some have suggested that the allegations put a damaging spotlight on King's historical stature and require a thorough historical review.

The comparison between the FBI's surveillance of King and the investigation into Donald Trump in 2016 is uncanny, but the parallels diverge when it comes to media coverage. While the Trump investigation has been the subject of extensive media coverage, the allegations against King have received little attention in the United States. The allegations against King may or may not be true, but they raise questions about the FBI's actions and the behavior of a historical figure who is often revered as a secular saint.

Title: Two Minnesota Republicans Allegedly Physically Assaulted by Unidentified Individuals

Article:

Two Republican politicians in Minnesota have reported physical attacks in the past few days, according to reports from The Associated Press and the Star Tribune.

State Representative Sarah Anderson (R) was allegedly assaulted on Sunday by an unidentified male who she confronted after finding him damaging her yard signs. Anderson told the AP that police have a tentative identification of the man who punched her during the confrontation, and they plan to interview him.

Another Republican, Shane Mekeland, a candidate for Minnesota House District 15b, was attacked on Friday during a campaign event at a bar, according to the Star Tribune. Mekeland was left with a concussion, and his attacker made a statement, not specifically aligned with either party, that indicated anger towards Mekeland for supposedly abandoning the middle class.

Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) and former Attorney General Eric Holder (D) have faced criticism in recent months for calls to protest GOP candidates and lawmakers. Holder, who served under former President Obama, responded on Twitter last week, stating, "OK, stop the fake outrage. I’m obviously not advocating violence. (In fact, when I was AG, violent crime in the US was historically low.)" He went on to say, "Republicans are undermining our democracy and Democrats need to be tough, proud, and stand up for the values we believe in - the end."

Title: Walter Shaub Resigns as Director of Office of Government Ethics, Cites Desire for Greater Freedom to Push for Ethics Reforms

Article:

Walter Shaub, the Director of the Office of Government Ethics (OGE), announced his resignation on Thursday, ending a tenure marked by frequent clashes with the Trump administration. In a letter to the president, Shaub expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to lead the OGE's staff and the community of ethics officials in the federal executive branch.

Shaub, who was appointed by former President Barack Obama in 2013, will resign on July 19, six months before his term was set to conclude. He has accepted a position as senior director of ethics at the Campaign Legal Center, a group advocating for transparency and ethics in government.

During President Donald Trump's tenure, Shaub and the administration have clashed over issues including the steps taken by the president to distance himself from his business empire and the administration's disclosure of ethics waivers for former lobbyists serving in the White House. Shaub stated in an email to The Wall Street Journal that he was not pushed out by the White House, but rather chose to leave before the end of his term due to the Campaign Legal Center offering him a platform for greater freedom to push for changes to federal ethics rules.

The White House accepted Shaub's resignation and plans to nominate a successor "in short order," according to the White House. The Office of Government Ethics aims to prevent conflicts of interest for government employees but has limited means to enforce federal ethics rules, aside from publicly raising questions about possible conflicts.

Shortly after Trump's election victory, Shaub made it clear that he would not hesitate to criticize the president over ethics issues. In November, the ethics office sent a series of tweets at Trump urging him to divest fully from his business interests. In January, Shaub denounced as insufficient Trump's proposal to guard against conflicts of interest, stating it did "not comport with the tradition of our presidents over the past 40 years."

Trump placed his assets into a trust and turned over management of his business to his adult sons, but retained ownership of the business. He can withdraw funds from the trust if its trustees—his eldest son and a longtime company lawyer—deem it appropriate. In an interview with CBS News on Thursday, Shaub again criticized the president for not taking adequate steps to distance himself from his business.

In March, Shaub criticized the White House for not taking more aggressive action against senior adviser Kellyanne Conway after she urged viewers in a television interview to "go buy Ivanka's stuff," referring to the brand owned by Trump's elder daughter. The White House said it had counseled Conway on the issue and determined she was unlikely to again break the federal law barring government officials from endorsing brands.

In May, Shaub issued an unusually forceful response to an effort by the White House to block the ethics office's attempt to obtain its ethics waivers, which allow administration officials to work on issues they handled in their previous private-sector jobs. Shaub declined the request that his office suspend its effort to obtain the waivers and included hundreds of pages of material backing up his right to request them. The White House ultimately provided the waivers to the agency, which publicly disclosed them.

The departure of Shaub means that Trump has the power to appoint a successor. A director must be confirmed by the Senate and is appointed to serve a five-year term. Don Fox, who served as the ethics office's general counsel from 2008 to 2013 and as acting director from 2011 until 2013, said Shaub was "far more outspoken" than his predecessors about "what he perceived as the ethical shortcomings of this administration."

"Walt spoke out because he felt he had to," said Fox, adding he couldn't think of another administration "that was ever this disdainful of government ethics." A White House spokeswoman didn't respond to a request for comment on Fox's criticism.

In a statement released by the Campaign Legal Center, Shaub said he hoped in his new role to bolster federal ethics rules. "In working with the current administration, it has become clear to me that we need improvements to the existing ethics program," he said. "I look forward to working toward that aim at Campaign Legal Center, as well as working on ethics reforms at all levels of government."

Title: House Republicans Push Forward with Full Repeal of Affordable Care Act

Article:

House Republican leaders are advancing with plans to hold a vote on Wednesday to fully repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, following a debate on the repeal measure on Tuesday. This is the second full repeal vote in the chamber, two weeks after the Supreme Court upheld most of the law as constitutional.

The vote on Wednesday is unlikely to pass the Democratic-controlled Senate, and President Obama has vowed to veto any such measure if it reaches his desk. Since 2011, the House has held 29 other votes aimed at dismantling specific parts of the law.

The House Rules Committee allotted five hours of floor debate for the latest measure, with lawmakers discussing the issue for four and a half hours on Tuesday. The remaining time is reserved for the day of the vote.

Democrats criticized the Republicans for focusing on repealing the health care law instead of addressing economic issues. Representative Keith Ellison, D-Minn., stated, "We could spend five hours talking about jobs. We could consider a jobs plan that the president offered before this very body. But we won't, because we have to go repeal health care again for the thirty-first time."

Democrats also argued that the Supreme Court's ruling to preserve the law indicated that Republicans should focus on other issues. Representative Donna Edwards, D-Md., said, "It's time for Republicans to move on."

Republicans maintained their stance on the issue, which they believe helped secure their majority during the 2010 midterm elections. They argued that the high court only declared the law constitutional, not good policy. House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, R-Mich., stated, "House Republicans promised the American people that if granted the majority, we would repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Let's face it, ObamaCare is nothing like what was promised."

Republicans reaffirmed their commitment to repealing the law. Representative Lee Terry, R-Neb., said, "I have voted to repeal this 30 times, and I will keep doing it until we get it right."

Title: Republican Leaders Remain Silent on Trump's Threat to Special Counsel Robert Mueller

Article:

In the face of President Donald Trump's direct attacks on Special Counsel Robert Mueller, the Republican party appears to be in a state of silence regarding potential constitutional crisis. Despite some Republicans having previously signed on to legislation preventing Trump from unilaterally firing Mueller, there seems to be a lack of urgency as they claim Trump is not currently planning to do so.

However, key Republican leaders, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, John Cornyn, John Thune, Richard Burr, Chuck Grassley, Kevin McCarthy, Devin Nunes, Bob Goodlatte, and a majority of the other Republicans on the Senate Intelligence Committee, have not provided comments on the matter.

House Speaker Paul Ryan's spokesperson stated that "As the speaker has always said, Mr. Mueller and his team should be able to do their job." This statement does not indicate any concrete action or consequences for firing Mueller.

Sen. Marco Rubio stated on Meet the Press that he remains confident that Mueller's investigation will be fair, thorough, and arrive at the truth. Sen. James Lankford described Trump as "exceptionally frustrated," but did not offer any suggestions for action when Trump lashes out in frustration.

Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) expressed hope that enough people would prevail on the president to not fire Mueller, stating, "I hope that that's the case. And I would just hope that enough people would prevail on the president now: ‘Don't go there.’"

Flake's comments suggest a general reluctance among Republicans to take action until after Trump has acted, implying a lack of proactive measures to prevent a potential constitutional crisis. The silence from key Republican leaders leaves the future of the Mueller investigation uncertain.

In the meantime, calls for donations to Democratic nominee funds in targeted districts and nominee funds in Nevada and Arizona have been made, indicating a growing concern among some Americans for the future of the investigation and the potential consequences of Trump's actions.

Title: Five Memorable Anecdotes from Hillary Clinton's Book on the 2016 Election

Article:

Hillary Clinton's book, "What Happened," detailing her experiences during the 2016 election, is set to hit bookshelves on Tuesday. The book is described as the story of "what I saw, felt, and thought during two of the most intense years I've ever experienced." Here are five of the most memorable anecdotes shared by Clinton in her book.

1. President Obama's Encouragement: Clinton writes that President Obama signaled to her early in 2013 and 2014 that she should run for president. Obama's support, according to Clinton, meant a great deal to her, as he believed she was the Democratic Party's best chance to hold the White House and continue their progress.

2. Advice from George W. Bush: As Clinton decided whether to attend President Trump's inauguration, she sought advice from former President George W. Bush. Bush, who had his own family disagreements with Trump, advised Clinton to go to the inauguration, arguing it was for the good of the country.

3. Mistaken Identity: Clinton mistook former Rep. Jason Chaffetz for Trump's chief of staff Reince Priebus when he approached her on Inauguration Day. Chaffetz, who had been critical of Clinton during the Benghazi investigation, captured the moment on Twitter. Clinton, in her book, admitted that she "came this close" to tweeting back at Chaffetz, saying she thought he was Priebus.

4. Ryan Zinke's Introduction: During the lunch at the Capitol following the swearing-in ceremony, Clinton describes an awkward encounter with Trump's soon-to-be Interior secretary, Ryan Zinke. Zinke, who had previously called Clinton the "antichrist," introduced Clinton to his wife. Clinton wrote that she was surprised by the introduction and reminded Zinke that he had called her the "antichrist."

5. Huma Abedin's Loyalty: After the FBI reopened an investigation to examine emails found on former Rep. Anthony Weiner's laptop, Clinton writes that some people thought she should fire longtime adviser Huma Abedin, Weiner's wife. Clinton, however, chose to stand by Abedin, stating that she had done nothing wrong and was an invaluable member of her team.

In the wee hours of the morning on election night, Clinton writes that she and her husband were alone, exhausted after ten years without sleep. Clinton writes that they lay down on the bed and stared at the ceiling, with Bill taking her hand and the two of them remaining silent.

Title: Taylor Swift Endorses Democratic Candidates in Tennessee Midterm Elections

Article:

Pop superstar Taylor Swift has endorsed two Democratic candidates in the upcoming midterm elections in Tennessee. In an Instagram post on Sunday, Swift announced her political stance and expressed her support for Phil Bredesen for Senate and Jim Cooper for House of Representatives.

Swift wrote, "I'm writing this post about the upcoming midterm elections on November 6th, in which I'll be voting in the state of Tennessee." She further stated, "I always have and always will cast my vote based on which candidate will protect and fight for the human rights I believe we all deserve in this country."

The 28-year-old singer expressed her opposition to Republican congresswoman Marsha Blackburn, who is running for the Senate. Blake Kitterman, vice president of Tennessee Young Democrats, told NPR that Swift's endorsement could potentially influence many young voters.

Kitterman said, "The basic values that she has as a person, and that I would hope everyone else in the country has, do not really surprise me. It's a clear cut choice between Marsha Blackburn and Phil Bredesen, and I'm happy and reassured that she supported the right candidate in my mind."

Swift's Instagram post highlighted her stance on LGBTQ rights, gender, and racial equality, and her opposition to candidates who do not support these values. She wrote, "I can not vote for someone who will not be willing to fight for dignity for ALL Americans, no matter their skin color, gender, or who they love."

Andy Cole, the vice chairman of the Tennessee Young Republicans, expressed doubt about the impact of Swift's endorsement on young voters. Cole said, "We've seen celebrities endorse Democrats before. Most Tennessee voters are worried about which candidate is going to give them a good job, which candidate is going to get out and fix the education system, which candidate is going to do the things Tennessee voters need... We're glad she has an opinion, and we love to see younger people have opinions, because frankly, I think too often, younger people have been disengaged."

According to a study by Pew, millennials are among the most liberal generations in the U.S., with the majority supporting Democrats in their districts. However, young voters are not showing up at the polls, with only 20% of young people between the ages of 18 and 24 voting in the past four midterm elections.

In her post, Swift urged her young fans to vote in November. Kitterman of the Tennessee Young Democrats said that even without Swift's support, an increasing number of younger voters will be turning out to vote this year. Kitterman said, "There are multiple threats now going against us, and I think that is a factor in pushing millennial turnout." He added, "Taylor Swift only reinforces this built-up tension that we have in ourselves. Whereas before we thought that we could have no impact, now we have no choice but to exhaust all options to try and make an impact."

According to a recent poll by The Tennessean and CBS, Blackburn has surged to an eight-point lead over Bredesen.

Title: US-Israeli-Palestinian Tensions Escalate as US Abstains from UN Vote on Israeli Settlements

Article:

The prospect of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is in jeopardy, according to US Secretary of State John Kerry. In a speech, Kerry criticized Israeli settlements on occupied land, stating they are a major obstacle to peace and a violation of international law. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu responded by accusing Kerry of an unbalanced approach and paying "lip service" to Palestinian terrorism.

The UN Security Council passed a resolution last Friday, calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The US chose not to veto the resolution, leading to an angry response from Israel. The issue of Jewish settlements is one of the most contentious points between Israel and the Palestinians, with more than 500,000 Jews living in about 140 settlements built since Israel's 1967 occupation.

The two-state solution, a final settlement that would create an independent state of Palestine within pre-1967 ceasefire lines, is the declared goal of Israeli and Palestinian leaders and many international diplomats. The United Nations, the Arab League, the European Union, Russia, and the United States routinely restate their commitment to the concept.

Kerry emphasized that the two-state solution is the only way to achieve a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and to ensure Israel's future as a Jewish and democratic state. He criticized the current Israeli government, stating that its policies are leading towards a one-state solution rather than a two-state solution.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu responded by saying he was disappointed with Kerry's speech, which he described as "unbalanced." Hanan Ashrawi, a spokeswoman for the Palestinian Liberation Organisation, stated that Palestinians have adhered to past agreements but Israel has not.

Donald Trump, the US President-elect, has made it clear he has no plans to push Israel into a corner. In two tweets issued on Wednesday, Trump expressed support for Israel and criticized the UN for treating Israel with disdain and disrespect. Critics have urged the president-elect to use more conventional channels to communicate on international matters.

The UN resolution passed last Friday stated that the establishment of settlements has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law and a major obstacle to the achievement of the two-state solution and a just, lasting, and comprehensive peace. The US decision to abstain infuriated Mr. Netanyahu, who has taken diplomatic reprisals against the countries that voted in favor of the resolution. Meanwhile, an Israeli committee has postponed a vote to authorize construction of almost 500 new homes in Jewish settlements in occupied East Jerusalem.

Title: Wisconsin Gubernatorial Race: Walker and Burke in a Tight Race as Election Day Approaches

Article:

In the aftermath of his recall election victory in 2012, Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin was hailed as a conservative icon, having successfully stripped public unions of their bargaining powers and surviving a union-led campaign to remove him from office. However, in the lead-up to the 2014 gubernatorial race, Walker appears to be in a tight contest against his Democratic opponent, Mary Burke, a former Trek Bicycle executive and member of the Madison School Board.

Walker, who once confidently lectured Mitt Romney in 2012, now finds himself in a challenging position against Burke. In the final days of the campaign, the governor has been vocal about his record on job creation, a contentious issue in his political history. Despite his efforts to remind voters of his victory over the unions, Walker has also emphasized his plea for voter support to continue his economic policies.

At campaign events this week, Walker has been visibly strained, coughing and wearing a bandage on one thumb from a hunting accident. In a departure from his previous campaign, Walker and his running mate, Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch, have focused on smaller accomplishments, such as sending a $322 rebate to Wisconsin taxpayers this year. Walker has also received applause for his proposal to require drug tests for recipients of public assistance.

As the election day approaches, both Walker and Burke appear to have support from approximately 47% of voters, according to Walker's own estimates. The remaining votes are expected to come from "Obama-Walker voters," Wisconsinites who may have voted against Walker in the 2012 recall but for President Obama in the same year. President Obama campaigned for Burke in Milwaukee on Tuesday, praising her as a "practical person" who understands the importance of creating jobs without prioritizing political ideology.

The Wisconsin gubernatorial race remains closely contested as both candidates seek to win over undecided voters in the final week of the campaign.

Title: Mass Shooting in Las Vegas Leaves 59 Dead, 515 Injured

Article:

At least 59 people have been killed and another 527 injured in a mass shooting at a Las Vegas concert. The gunman, identified as 64-year-old Nevada resident Stephen Paddock, opened fire from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Hotel towards an open-air music festival attended by 22,000. He killed himself as police stormed the room where 10 guns were found.

The shooting occurred during the final shows of the three-day Route 91 country music festival. Thousands were enjoying a performance by top-billing singer Jason Aldean when the first of several bursts of automatic gunfire rang out. Hundreds of concert-goers scrambled for cover, flattening themselves against the ground, rushing for the exits, or helping others to escape as Paddock sprayed the site from his high vantage point.

Investigators have found no link to international terrorism, despite a claim from the so-called Islamic State. In an address from the White House, President Donald Trump described the attack as "pure evil." He praised the efforts of the emergency services, saying their "miraculous" speed saved lives, and announced he would be visiting Las Vegas on Wednesday.

With First Lady Melania by his side, he later observed a moment of silence on the White House lawn. The final shows of the three-day Route 91 country music festival were in full swing when the gunman struck.

Stephen Paddock, from a community of senior citizens in the small town of Mesquite north-east of Las Vegas, booked into the hotel on 28 September, police say.
