His motives for carrying out the deadliest mass shooting in recent US history remain a mystery. Some investigators have suggested psychological issues, but there is no confirmation of this.

His brother, Eric, is dumbfounded that he acted this way. Las Vegas Sheriff Joe Lombardo described the shooting as a "lone wolf" attack. "We have no idea what his belief system was," he said.

So-called Islamic State (IS) has claimed to be behind the attack, saying that Paddock had converted to Islam some months ago. But the group provided no evidence for this and has made unsubstantiated claims in the past. FBI Special Agent Aaron Rouse told a news conference: "We have determined at this point no connection to an international terrorist organization."

The investigation continues to gather pace, with searches at Paddock's Mesquite home, where more weapons were found, and a second property. Paddock lived in Mesquite with Marilou Danley. Police have interviewed her but say she does not appear to have been involved as she was out of the country. They are hoping to speak to her again. Police say he used some of her identity documents to check in to the Mandalay Bay.

The authorities have yet to confirm the identities of any of the 58 killed. Jordan McIldoon, 23, from British Columbia in Canada, has been identified as a victim of the attack by CBC News. A nurse, Sonny Melton, of Big Sandy, Tennessee, has been named as another victim by The Jackson Sun newspaper.

In a Facebook post, his wife, Dr Heather Gulish Melton, said she "lost my true love and knight in shining armor. I appreciate the prayers but I just need some time." An off-duty Las Vegas police officer was another of those who died.

The scenes which played out in this stunned city were at once frantically urgent and wearily familiar. They fled from a gunman who left a city in chaos. For a time, Las Vegas looked and felt like a war zone. Hospitals were overwhelmed. There were not enough ambulances. A plea for blood donations echoed across the airwaves.

And now the mourning, the relief, the tears, the elation, the grief, and a hundred other emotions are barely beginning. For a Western democracy, the United States has seen an astonishing amount of horror like this. But even for this country, what happened here is carnage on a different scale. Nevada has some of the least stringent gun laws in the United States. People are allowed to carry weapons and do not have to register themselves as a gun-owner. Background checks are done when people buy guns, but they are also allowed to sell them privately.

Former congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords, who survived a shooting six years ago, called for political leaders in Washington to introduce tougher gun laws following the Las Vegas attack. Her husband Mark Kelly read out a joint statement on the steps of the Capitol saying thoughts and prayers from the White House were not enough to stop the next shooting.

Title: Ian Bremmer Apologizes for Fabricated Quote Attributed to President Trump

Article:

Ian Bremmer, a journalist and New York University professor, has admitted to fabricating a quote attributed to President Donald Trump. In a tweet on Monday, Trump criticized Bremmer for the "completely ludicrous quote" he had attributed to him.

In the fabricated quote, Bremmer claimed Trump had said North Korean leader Kim Jong Un would make a better president than former Vice President Joe Biden. Bremmer initially defended the quote, stating it was "plausible" and a commentary on the "state of media and the twitterverse today."

However, after Trump's tweet on Monday, Bremmer apologized, stating his initial post was "meant in jest." He added, "The President correctly quoted me as saying it was a 'completely ludicrous' statement."

During his four-day state visit to Japan, Trump had tweeted about Kim Jong Un calling former Vice President Biden a "Swampman" and a "low IQ individual & worse." Bremmer's fabricated quote was not mentioned in Trump's tweets during the visit.

This is not the first time Bremmer has been criticized for his comments about Trump. In 2016, he was accused of making inappropriate comments about Trump's wife, Melania, during a television appearance. Bremmer later apologized for those comments.

Title: Fact-Checking the Second Presidential Debate: A Closer Look at the Candidates' Statements

Article:

During the town-hall style debate at Hofstra University on Tuesday, President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney faced off in their second debate. With Obama aiming to recover from a lackluster performance in the first debate and Romney seeking to deflect attacks that did not come his way last time, the truth sometimes got caught in the crossfire. Here is a factual analysis of how closely the candidates adhered to the facts during the debate:

Obama: "I said that this was an act of terror."

While Romney contested that Obama never made this statement, on the day after the Benghazi attack, the president did strongly suggest it was a terrorist strike. However, he did not say outright that the Benghazi attack was an act of terrorism.

On the day after the death of U.S. Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens and three other Americans, Obama stated, "No acts of terror will ever shake the resolve of this great nation, alter that character, or eclipse the light of the values that we stand for." The ambiguity in this statement has been a point of contention, with Romney and his supporters arguing that the president was speaking broadly and not about the Benghazi attack specifically.

In the days following the attack, the White House seemed reluctant to call it a terrorist attack. On Sept. 16, U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Susan Rice went on several TV talk shows and declared that the U.S. government's preliminary assessment was that the violence sprang from a "spontaneous" demonstration related to an anti-Muslim video.

Director of National Intelligence James Clapper has stated that Rice's account was based on the initial take of U.S. intelligence agencies. They subsequently changed their view and now assess the incident as a pre-planned terrorist attack.

Obama: "Look, the cost of lowering rates for everybody across the board 20 percent, along with what he also wants to do in terms of eliminating the estate tax, along what he wants to do in terms of corporates changes in the Tax Code — it costs about $5 trillion."

Gov. Romney's tax plan is estimated to cost $5 trillion — including the cost of extending the Bush tax cuts. Obama's math overshot by about $1 trillion, by most estimates.

The president said Romney's budget plan would cost $8 trillion — $5 trillion in tax cuts, $2 trillion in additional military spending, and $1 trillion from the extension of the Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. Romney's tax plan is estimated to cost $5 trillion — including the cost of extending the Bush tax cuts.

Romney says that he would offset the cost of those tax cuts, in part by eliminating or scaling back taxpayers' ability to take credits and deductions. He has not given full details, but again floated the idea of a $25,000 cap on deductions, as he did in the first debate. Before that, he had discussed a $17,000 cap.

Title: Missouri Fails to Override Veto on Controversial Gun Measure by One Vote

Article:

In a narrow vote, the Missouri legislature failed to override the governor's veto of a bill that aimed to nullify federal gun regulations, including background checks and restrictions on high-capacity magazines. The vote was 23-13 in the state Senate, falling one vote short of the required two-thirds majority.

The bill, which was designed to make Missouri a sanctuary for gun-toting felons and the mentally ill, has been criticized for its potential violation of the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution. The clause states that the Constitution and federal laws are the supreme law of the land, and any state laws to the contrary are invalid.

The claim that a state can unilaterally nullify federal law has been widely criticized as preposterous, even by some of the strongest gun advocates. Robert Levy, who led the litigation to establish the individual right to bear arms, has conceded that the Missouri bill flouts the Constitution.

The controversy over gun policy in the U.S. has been a contentious issue, with some states, such as Colorado and Iowa, adopting stricter gun control measures, while others, like Missouri and Kansas, are pushing for more lenient gun laws. The debate has been marked by heated rhetoric, with the National Rifle Association (NRA) often at the center of the controversy.

The NRA has been criticized for its role in recall elections in Colorado, where two legislators who supported stricter gun control measures were removed from office. The NRA has also been accused of misleading voters and pushing for unconstitutional laws.

The failure of the Missouri bill to override the governor's veto is a significant development in the ongoing gun control debate. The NRA and its supporters have vowed to continue their efforts to push for lenient gun laws, while gun control advocates are calling for more responsible gun ownership to prevent tragedies.

The debate over gun control is complex and emotional, with both sides presenting compelling arguments. It is essential for voters to be well-informed and to consider the potential consequences of their decisions. The gun control debate is far from over, and it will likely continue to be a contentious issue in the U.S. for the foreseeable future.

Title: Obama Administration Decides to Prosecute Osama bin Laden's Son-in-law in Civilian Court, Sparking Debate

Article:

The Obama administration's decision to prosecute Osama bin Laden's son-in-law, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, in a federal court in New York City instead of a military tribunal at Guantanamo Bay has reignited a debate over how to deal with suspected terrorists. This decision also recalls one of the largest unfulfilled promises of President Obama's presidency: his pledge as a candidate in 2008 to close the detention center at Guantanamo Bay.

As Abu Ghaith pleaded not guilty to conspiring to kill Americans in a New York Federal Court today, Republicans in Congress were criticizing the Obama administration for prosecuting a suspected al Qaeda terrorist in a civilian court, just about a mile from the 9/11 memorial built over Ground Zero.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., wrote in a statement, "Abu Ghaith has sworn to kill Americans and he likely possesses information that could prevent harm to America and its allies. He is an enemy combatant and should be held in military custody."

The White House claimed there was a "broad consensus" across the federal government, from the Department of Defense, the Department of Justice, and the Department of Homeland Security, to prosecute OBL's son-in-law in civilian court.

"The intelligence community agrees that the best way to protect our national security interests is to prosecute Abu Ghaith in an Article III court," Principal Deputy White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest told reporters today. "We're able to question him as a part of the regular process in detaining individuals like this, but we're also able to put him through Article III courts to ensure that he's held accountable for his crimes."

Still, McConnell said that the administration's justification "makes little sense" and the intelligence community "deserve the same access to intelligence and methods of defeating the enemy available to the team that found Bin Laden."

"At Guantanamo, [Abu Ghaith] could be held as a detainee and fully and continuously interrogated without having to overcome the objections of his civilian lawyers," McConnell said.

Rep. Mike Rogers, R-Mich., the chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, said civilian court "is not the appropriate venue" and the administration "should treat enemy combatants like the enemy."

"Al Qaeda leaders captured on the battlefield should not be brought to the United States to stand trial," Rogers said. "The president needs to send any captured al Qaeda members to Guantanamo."

A spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner, who opposes closing Guantanamo and previously fought against efforts by the Obama administration to prosecute 9/11 suspects in New York City, said the speaker "agrees" with Rogers.

New York Republican Rep. Pete King, R-N.Y., said he preferred that Abu Ghaith face trial in a military tribunal rather than civilian court, and he questioned what type of standard today's hearing could set.

"While a federal court trial of Abu Ghaith in lower Manhattan would not present the same security issues as a trial of Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, I strongly believe as a matter of policy that military tribunals are the proper venue for enemy combatants," said King, a member of the House committees on Intelligence and Homeland Security. "If the Abu Ghaith trial does go forward in federal court, it must not be used as a precedent for future enemy combatants who should be tried at Guantanamo."

However, not all members of Congress oppose the administration's actions. New York Democratic Rep. Jerrold Nadler, who represents the congressional district where Ground Zero is located in lower Manhattan, said he is "pleased Sulaiman Abu Ghaith will have to face justice in New York."

"I have long urged that we try terrorists in our civilian courts under the laws of the United States. We have done so successfully in the past, and we must continue to do so," Nadler, D-N.Y., said in a statement. "We are a nation committed to the rule of law, and we will demonstrate our values to the world even in the face of the most despicable mass murder in our history."

Title: Marco Rubio's Proposal for Border Control Strategy in Immigration Reform

Article:

Marco Rubio, a key member of the bipartisan Gang of Eight, is advocating for a change in the immigration reform bill currently under deliberation in the Senate. Rubio is pushing for Congress, rather than the Department of Homeland Security, to write the border control strategy that would be a prerequisite for most of the other elements of reform.

Rubio's proposal is a response to concerns about border security, a threshold issue for many Republicans. Rubio argues that Americans don't trust the government to get it right and wants lawmakers to craft the plan at the outset, rather than leaving the details to the Obama administration.

The Gang of Eight, a group of four Democrats and four Republicans, is aiming to secure as many as two dozen Republican votes to demonstrate the bill's bipartisan support and compel the House to act. However, the group must maintain the support of the vast majority of Senate Democrats who favor the current version of the bill.

Reform proponents are concerned that the Senate supermajority may be an elusive goal, potentially undermining the bill, particularly on border security. Marshall Fitz, a veteran of the 2006 and 2007 reform fights, expressed this concern, stating, "We are advocating for a strong and tight and effective a bill as possible. If that means we are targeting 62 votes, then 62 on a strong bill is better than 75 on a weak bill that looks like a special interest bonanza."

Rubio has expressed doubts about the current version of the legislation's ability to garner enough votes to break a filibuster, let alone the 70-plus votes that Gang of Eight leaders want. Rubio has stated that many Republicans view border security as a threshold issue, and the requirements must be tightened before they can consider backing the bill.

Rubio's influence in the Gang of Eight deliberations is significant, with the group making several concessions to accommodate his preferences. These concessions range from a cut-off date for legalizing recent undocumented immigrants to an extended debate in the Judiciary Committee. Rubio has also secured a fix for a stronger system for tracking visa holders after initially expressing disappointment when the committee rejected a stronger system.

Rubio is actively engaging with potential allies, reaching out to senators such as Dean Heller of Nevada and Rob Portman of Ohio, as well as border state senators and undecided Democrats to gauge their demands for the bill. He is also consulting with border security officials outside the administration and House members focused on border issues, according to Rubio's office.

Rubio is also invoking the IRS scandal to sell his proposal, suggesting that a lack of trust in the government's ability to handle such matters necessitates congressional oversight. The specific parameters of Rubio's proposal are yet to be determined.

Title: Report Finds U.S. Job Recovery Post-Great Recession Marked by Lower Wages and Increased Income Inequality

Article:

A report commissioned by the U.S. Conference of Mayors has revealed that the United States has regained all the jobs lost during the Great Recession, which began at the end of 2007. However, the report, prepared by the firm IHS, shows that the annual wage in sectors where jobs were lost was $61,637, while the annual wage in sectors where jobs were restored is only $47,171 - a net loss estimated at $93 billion and representing a "wage gap" of 23 percent.

The jobs being created in the American economy are under scrutiny, with concerns being raised about their ability to support families and households. The report undercuts the importance of claims made by President Obama during a recent White House news conference, where he stated that the U.S. has added more jobs than any year since 2006 and is experiencing a six-month streak with at least 200,000 new jobs each month.

Economist Pamela Villareal of the National Center for Policy Analysis stated, "When you look at the sectors of the economy that have grown since, say, 2011, a lot of the growth has occurred in retail, food service, hospitality. These are sectors that typically pay lower wages." She suggested that more growth in high-paying high-tech jobs could be achieved by reducing some of the regulations and taxes that are discouraging job growth in the United States.

Another finding of the IHS report is that income inequality, defined as the unequal distribution of income across the various participants in the economy, has grown during the recovery from the Great Recession. IHS economist Jim Diffley noted that the trend of the rich growing richer and the poor growing poorer extends back decades. The top 20 percent of income-earning households in 1975 took home 43.6 percent of all income earned in the United States, the study finds, while that same top quintile of households now takes home 51 percent of all income.

Diffley stated, "There's no particular policies of this administration that drove that change that we can identify." He added, "It tells you about the structure of the economy as it's evolved over time, over a much longer time than, than Barack Obama has been president." Diffley also noted that presidents and governors often receive too much credit when the economy is good and too much blame when the economy is bad.

Title: Judge Rules Paul Manafort Breached Plea Deal, Lied to Investigators

Article:

In a ruling on Wednesday, U.S. District Court Judge Amy Berman Jackson determined that Paul Manafort, former campaign chief for President Donald Trump, breached his plea deal with Special Counsel Robert Mueller by lying to prosecutors, the FBI, and a grand jury.

Manafort, who had pleaded guilty to some charges and avoided a separate trial in August for financial fraud related to his work as a political consultant in Ukraine, was found to have made multiple false statements about three different topics, including his contacts with Konstantin Kilimnik, a Russian political consultant who is believed to have ties to Russian intelligence.

However, the judge cleared Manafort, 69, of allegations that he lied on two other subjects. The verdict could potentially lead to harsher sentences or the re-filing of charges against him.

Last year, Mueller stated that Manafort lied "on a variety of subject matters" after signing the plea deal. In August, Manafort was convicted on eight counts of fraud, bank fraud, and failing to disclose bank accounts. A month later, he pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy against the U.S. and one charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice in a plea bargain with Mueller.

The plea deal meant Manafort would face up to 10 years in prison and would forfeit four of his properties and the contents of several bank accounts. However, deadlocked charges from the previous trial would be dismissed.

The charges against Manafort primarily related to his political consulting work with pro-Russian politicians in Ukraine, largely predating his role with the Trump campaign. Manafort worked for the Trump presidential campaign for five months in 2016 and was in charge when Trump clinched the Republican party nomination.

President Trump has consistently branded the Mueller investigation a "witch hunt" and insisted there was no collusion between his team and Russia. Manafort was charged by Mueller last October and during the trial, he was accused of using 31 foreign bank accounts in three different countries to evade taxes on millions of dollars. Prosecutors presented evidence of Manafort's luxurious lifestyle, stating it was only possible because of his bank and tax fraud.

Title: President Obama Outlines Steps to Address VA Scandal, Stops Short of Firing Secretary Shinseki

Article:

President Barack Obama, in a public address on Wednesday, outlined steps to address the ongoing Veterans Affairs (VA) scandal, while refraining from calling for the resignation of VA Secretary Eric Shinseki. Obama described Shinseki as a "great soldier" who has "put his heart and soul into this thing."

The president has dispatched White House deputy chief of staff, Rob Nabors, to oversee a broader review, with Nabors currently in Phoenix, where allegations of patient deaths tied to delayed care first surfaced. Obama acknowledged the need for improvement, stating, "We've got to do better."

However, the president indicated he would wait for the conclusion of internal investigations before determining whether more top officials should resign. Obama emphasized, "If these allegations prove to be true, it is dishonorable, it is disgraceful and I will not tolerate it -- period."

Leading Republicans swiftly criticized Obama's remarks, with Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell stating, "it's time for serious action and accountability." Sen. John McCain, a veteran and former prisoner of war, called Obama's statements "wholly insufficient in addressing the fundamental, systemic problems plaguing our veterans' health care system."

The Department of Veterans Affairs Inspector General's Office is currently investigating 26 facilities nationwide over allegations of manipulated waiting times and other issues. The House of Representatives has approved a bill that would give the VA secretary greater authority to fire or demote senior executives.

Rep. Jeff Miller, R-Fla., chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, accused the VA of a "well-documented reluctance to ensure its leaders are held accountable for mistakes." The controversy erupted in Phoenix last month, with allegations of delayed care that may have led to patient deaths and a cover-up by top administrators.

Two Republican senators have introduced legislation to prohibit payment of bonuses to employees at the Veterans Health Administration through next year. The House passed a bill in February that would eliminate performance bonuses for the department's senior executive staff through 2018.

Sen. John Cornyn, the No. 2 Republican in the Senate, has called on Obama to reconsider his plan to nominate Jeffrey Murawsky to replace the VA's undersecretary for health care, Robert Petzel, who has stepped down. The White House has stated that Obama remains confident in Shinseki's leadership and is standing behind Murawsky's nomination.

Title: Chief Justice John Roberts' Conservative Voting Record Raises Concerns for Democrats

Article:

The upcoming term of the Supreme Court, commencing on Monday, is anticipated to be significant, with cases concerning gun control, abortion, L.G.B.T. rights, and immigration on the docket. The term may indicate the extent to which the court's conservative majority will obstruct the agenda of the next Democratic president and Congress.

The Supreme Court is reportedly on the brink of a conservative shift, leading to concerns among Democrats. While Chief Justice John Roberts has expressed respect for precedent and concern for the court's legitimacy, historical data suggests that Democrats have reason to be apprehensive. The chief justice is not typically a swing vote among the four liberal and four conservative justices, nor a moderate. Instead, he is expected to align consistently with the conservative justices.

During his 2005 confirmation hearing, Chief Justice Roberts emphasized his "respect for precedent, even-handedness, predictability, stability." However, his voting record, analyzed over the last 14 years, reveals a partisan tendency, particularly in cases that overturn precedent. In 21 such cases, he voted to overturn precedent in 17, or 81%, making him the second, after Justice Clarence Thomas, in terms of frequency in a precedent-overturning majority over the last 14 years. In 15 such cases with partisan implications, the chief justice voted for conservative outcomes 93% of the time.

The analysis, conducted by Take Back the Court, relies on the methodology used by the Supreme Court Database, maintained by the law school at Washington University in St. Louis. To determine whether an outcome was liberal or conservative, the organization assumed that if at least four liberal justices voted for a decision in a split ruling, then the outcome was consistent with Democratic Party values and goals. Conversely, if at least four conservative justices voted similarly, the outcome was considered consistent with Republican Party values and goals.

The chief justice's voting record, according to this analysis, is as conservative as those of his most extreme current and former colleagues—Justices Thomas, Samuel Alito, Brett Kavanaugh, and Antonin Scalia. In all 42 split-decision cases that the chief justice has presided over involving racial minorities, immigrants, workers, and abortion, he voted for conservative outcomes 100% of the time.

Title: California and Oregon Automatically Register Voters, Breaking Barriers in U.S. Voting History

Article:

California Governor Jerry Brown signed a bill on Saturday that will initiate the automatic registration of adult citizens to vote. Starting in 2016, every adult citizen in the state who obtains a driver's license, renews a license, gets a state identification card, or fills out a change of address form with the Department of Motor Vehicles will be registered to vote, unless they decline. Oregon became the first state in the country to implement such a law earlier this year, making California the second.

Historically, governments in the United States have often erected barriers to prevent people from voting, such as property ownership requirements, poll taxes, or literacy tests. However, many of these barriers have fallen over time, making it easier for people to register. Nevertheless, many states, including California, still close off registration weeks to a month before an election, an artificial obstacle that can prevent eligible voters from participating if they miss the deadline.

These new proposals remove those obstacles. Oregon's law will register all adult citizens in the DMV's database, while California's law will be implemented more gradually, as people get or renew their licenses or state IDs, or change their addresses. Both make it the government's responsibility to ensure that all eligible voters are registered.

The concept of automatically registering voters is novel in the U.S. Support and opposition have been breaking down along party lines, with Democrats generally in favor and Republicans opposed, although they have not argued against the principle of easing registration. Critics have raised concerns about potential privacy issues and voter fraud, but supporters argue that people can always opt out, and the registered voters' data is more publicly accessible than DMV information.

In terms of voter fraud, critics have expressed concerns about the potential registration of unauthorized immigrants. However, California began issuing driver's licenses to unauthorized immigrants this year, but these licenses are distinctively marked, and people with them would not be registered to vote automatically. Oregon requires proof of citizenship for all driver's license applicants.

National Democrats are increasingly adopting mandatory voter registration as a major cause. In a speech on voting rights this June, Hillary Clinton called on all states to automatically register citizens to vote when they turn 18, unless they choose to opt out. Legislators in 15 other states have introduced bills similar to Oregon's new law, and the Brennan Center is tracking them.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Proposes $20 Trillion Medicare for All Plan, Faces Criticism from Rivals

Article:

In a significant move, Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has proposed a $20 trillion federal spending plan over the next decade to provide universal healthcare to all Americans without raising taxes on the middle class. The proposal, titled "Medicare for All," aims to address criticism of her previous lack of clarity on how she would fund her sweeping healthcare plan.

The details of Warren's plan involve requiring employers to transfer to the government almost all the $8.8 trillion she estimates they would otherwise spend on private insurance for employees. This transfer, according to Warren, would generate nearly half of the required funds to cover the cost of Medicare for All, along with existing taxes.

Employers with fewer than 50 employees that do not already sponsor coverage are exempt from the proposal. In a concession to unions, Warren's plan allows employers offering health benefits under collective bargaining agreements to reduce their contributions to federal coffers, provided they pass the savings on to employees.

Warren's proposal has faced criticism from moderate rivals, including former Vice President Joe Biden, who has labeled it as "mathematical gymnastics." Some independent experts have also questioned the realism of Warren's numbers.

The politics surrounding government-funded healthcare have resurfaced after Warren released her proposal. Biden, who favors building on the Affordable Care Act, has criticized Warren's plan as eliminating private insurance coverage and as a tax increase on workers.

President Donald Trump has branded Medicare for All as socialism. Warren's chief architect of Medicare for All, Senator Bernie Sanders, has previously released several options to pay for it, including a 4% income tax "premium" that kicks in after the first $29,000 for a family of four, affecting the middle class.

Independent experts have raised doubts about the Warren campaign's estimates. John Holahan, an economist at the Urban Institute, stated, "They are making more aggressive assumptions about the same things we already made aggressive assumptions about."

Passing such legislation through Congress poses a significant challenge, as a Republican-controlled Senate is unlikely to approve anything approaching Medicare for All. If Democrats take the Senate majority, the party may not have enough votes to break a filibuster.

A critical question for Warren is whether her $20 trillion cost estimate is accurate. The Urban Institute think tank recently pegged the cost closer to $34 trillion over 10 years. If Warren is underestimating the cost by that much, her predictions about needed tax revenue would come up well short.

The practical application of Warren's proposed employer contribution will be closely scrutinized, as it could create winners and losers among companies depending on their health care costs, which can reflect such factors as the age of the workforce and the generosity of benefits.

Over the weekend, Warren and more than a dozen other candidates will be in Iowa, which holds the nation's leadoff presidential caucuses in three months. Healthcare remains a dominant issue as the first votes of the Democratic contest near.

Title: Schumer Proposes Open Primaries to Counteract Tea Party Movement

Article:

Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from New York, has suggested that the Democratic Party should push for more open primaries as a means to counteract the Tea Party movement. In a speech at the Center for American Progress on Thursday, Schumer outlined a plan to implement a nonpartisan "blanket" primary system, where all candidates compete and the top finishers advance regardless of party affiliation.

Schumer argued that this system would force right-wing candidates to appeal to centrist voters, thereby pushing out the most extreme candidates. He suggested adopting a system similar to that in California, Louisiana, and Washington state, where all voters, regardless of party, can vote, and the top two vote-getters, regardless of party, then enter a runoff.

Schumer contends that the Tea Party movement is being influenced by a few wealthy donors whose limited-government philosophy does not reflect the ideas of millions of voters who identify as Tea Party supporters but who benefit from government programs such as Social Security or public education.

Schumer proposed that Democrats should go on the offensive by portraying the government as a "force for good," focusing on issues such as raising the minimum wage, making college more affordable, and building bridges, roads, and broadband infrastructure.

Sal Russo, chief strategist for the Tea Party Express, predicted that this strategy would not resonate with Tea Party supporters. "The tea party is not going to be assuaged by suggesting that even a bigger and more expensive federal government is the answer," Russo said.

The Tea Party movement emerged in 2009 in response to public anger over the government bailout of private banks and President Obama's early moves to boost government spending. Insurgent candidates, fueled by Tea Party enthusiasm, unseated longtime Republicans in primaries in 2010 and helped Republicans win control of the House and gain seats in the Senate. However, several Tea Party Senate candidates lost races that analysts had said could have been won by more mainstream candidates.

Schumer's hour-long speech indicates that Democrats are starting to view Tea Party lawmakers as significant competition, according to Dan Holler, communications director for the conservative activist group Heritage Action for America. "I think what Sen. Schumer is trying to accomplish is to divide the tea party," Holler said. "It speaks to the success the movement has had not only in terms of moving the Republican Party to a vision of smaller government but changing how Washington operates."

Schumer also expressed concern about signs of xenophobia or cultural fear among Tea Party supporters and suggested that the Tea Party's limited-government message is a reaction to the country's shift to a more urban economy, comparing it to Prohibition in the 1920s.

Title: U.S. PPE Aid Delivery to Foreign Countries Paused Amid Global Shortage

Article:

The delivery of coronavirus-related Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) aid to at least 13 countries, including Vietnam, Bangladesh, Honduras, and the Philippines, has been put on hold due to a review process, according to an administration official. The delay in aid delivery has raised concerns about potential damage to relationships with allies who could be crucial in supplying critical supplies in the future.

The U.S. task force is reportedly discussing the potential role of foreign aid in assisting the U.S. during a potential second wave of the virus. Vice President Mike Pence is said to recognize the importance of waiting for the right time to provide assistance while acknowledging the benefits of foreign assistance.

American diplomats are also grappling with China's attempts to exploit the shortages by supplying aid to Western countries. The U.S. has been providing aid to various countries, including Myanmar, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Laos, and others, in the form of protective gear.

There is bipartisan agreement on the need to resupply American hospitals and address domestic shortages. However, the slow and insufficient international aid is causing concern, as it may contribute to the continued spread of the virus in vulnerable communities.

Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.) expressed his concern, stating, "Our domestic response needs to be the priority, but the amount of aid offered internationally has been too slow and too small, risking the continued spread of the virus to Americans and to communities in countries with weaker infrastructure, immense poverty, and ongoing humanitarian crises."

The U.S. government has not actively discouraged U.S. companies from exporting PPE overseas, but FEMA is reportedly asking USAID to send back most of the reserves of protective gear it has stored in warehouses in Dubai and Miami for use in the U.S. The U.S. government emphasizes that it is not providing countries with hard-to-find equipment that could be used to fight coronavirus in the United States instead.

A senior State Department official stated, "When it comes to PPE in particular, right now our assistance is not a zero-sum game. We are not providing assistance that could be headed to Detroit or to Kansas City. That's not what we're doing." The official added that the hold on aid delivery is not intended to be permanent and will be lifted when industries are able to ramp up production and the U.S. has enough capacity to supply both domestic and international needs.

Title: U.S. Healthcare System Capable of Preventing Ebola Outbreak, Says Administration

Article:

The Obama administration is working to alleviate concerns about Ebola in the United States, stating that despite some initial missteps, the healthcare system is taking the necessary measures to prevent an outbreak. Dr. Anthony Fauci, infectious diseases chief at the National Institutes of Health, asserted that the U.S. healthcare infrastructure is well-equipped to stop Ebola.

On Friday, a high-level briefing at the White House underscored the administration's efforts to reassure the public. Five senior administration officials, including Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell, Lisa Monaco, President Barack Obama's top homeland security adviser, and Dr. Fauci, addressed reporters.

Monaco stated that the U.S. is not considering a travel ban to prevent individuals from the hardest-hit West African countries from entering the U.S. Instead, efforts are focused on identifying high-risk individuals before they leave the outbreak zone. According to Monaco, dozens of people have been stopped from boarding flights in the region.

"The most effective way to go about controlling this is to prevent those individuals from getting on a plane in the first place," Monaco said.

The first case of Ebola in the U.S. was diagnosed last week, with the patient being sent home from a Dallas hospital despite revealing a visit from Liberia. Texas officials are now monitoring 50 people, 10 of whom are considered at high risk, who came into contact with the patient. Four of them have been quarantined, and there have been issues with disposing of the infectious waste left in the patient's apartment.

"There were things that did not go the way they should have in Dallas," acknowledged Fauci, director of NIH's National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. "But there were a lot of things that went right and are going right."

Health officials have stated that someone who had close contact with the patient after they became ill—the only time Ebola is contagious—might also contract the disease. However, they believe further spread is unlikely due to the public health steps currently in place.

"We respect your concern. We understand your concern. But the evidence base tells us that that is not going to happen," Fauci said.

The White House announced that Obama will meet with his national security advisers on Monday to discuss the Ebola outbreak and the administration's response.

The administration has long maintained that the best way to contain Ebola is to address it at its source. The Pentagon's spokesman stated that up to 4,000 troops could be deployed to West Africa, a number that has gradually increased as military leaders assess the need.

Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby said the military has begun medical testing for Ebola at two new labs in Liberia. Service members are also constructing two treatment centers for Ebola victims and a hospital for infected medical personnel, with the latter expected to be completed by the end of October.

Kirby stated that the service members will not treat patients or come into contact with infected individuals. However, they are being trained on how to avoid contracting Ebola and have plans in place to deal with any service member who might become infected.

"We're going to train them up on what Ebola looks like, feels like, does. While they're there, they're going to be constantly monitored on a regular, frequent basis," Kirby said. "There will be a screening process to make sure that once they're no longer there, that we're able to stay in touch with them, make sure that they have not... felt or experienced any symptoms."

He added that troops will have personal protection equipment if needed and will be trained in how to use it. He stated that he is unaware of any special staffing or other changes at military hospitals in the U.S. to prepare them for caring for Ebola patients.

Currently, about 230 U.S. troops are deployed for the Ebola mission. Approximately two dozen are in Senegal setting up a transportation center, with the rest in Liberia. The Army announced on Friday that up to 3,200 soldiers from various units around the country will be going to Liberia, including 1,800 from Fort Campbell, Kentucky, who will arrive late this month. Other troops from Fort Hood and Fort Bliss, Texas, and Fort Bragg, North Carolina, are also being deployed, along with support units from Fort Benning and Fort Stewart, Georgia, and Fort Eustis, Virginia.

Title: Clinton to Announce Vice Presidential Pick on Friday, Tim Kaine Emerges as Leading Contender

Article:

Hillary Clinton is set to reveal her vice presidential running mate on Friday, according to people close to the search process. The Democratic presidential nominee is planning to make her first public appearance with her running mate at a campaign rally in Miami on Saturday at Florida International University.

Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia has emerged as a leading contender, receiving support from President Barack Obama and former President Bill Clinton. Clinton's choice of Kaine would be a strategic move, as Florida is a crucial battleground state, and Kaine speaks fluent Spanish, appealing to the state's large Hispanic population.

Clinton has been tight-lipped about her vice presidential pick, fearful of leaks before a well-orchestrated weekend rollout. Her campaign has offered supporters the chance to be the "first to know" her vice presidential pick, similar to Barack Obama's strategy in 2008.

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack and Labor Secretary Tom Perez, who would be the first Hispanic and African-American vice presidential candidates, respectively, were also considered. However, their limited experience in national security and government made them less likely to be selected, according to Democrats close to the process.

The selection of a running mate opens a new chapter in Clinton's political life, as she chooses her own partner for the first time in her presidential campaign. Clinton was deeply involved in the selection of Al Gore as her husband's running mate in 1992, but this choice is hers alone.

The Clinton campaign has been closely watching the Republican convention, particularly Donald Trump's speech, but has decided against making an announcement early Friday morning. The Democratic ticket's debut is designed to build anticipation for the party's convention starting Monday in Philadelphia. After their formal nomination, Clinton and her new running mate are expected to embark on a bus tour to key campaign battlegrounds.

Clinton has intentionally not informed anyone who has gone through the vetting process of her final decision, in hopes of keeping her choice a secret until the last possible moment. The selection of either Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Sen. Sherrod Brown of Ohio, or Sen. Cory Booker of New Jersey would influence the balance of power in the Senate, as their replacement would be named, at least initially, by a Republican governor in their state.

Title: Activist Erica Garner, Daughter of Eric Garner, Dies at 27

Article:

Erica Garner, the daughter of Eric Garner, has passed away at the age of 27. She died on Saturday in a New York hospital after being in a coma following a massive heart attack.

Garner became an activist following her father's death in 2014 on Staten Island, New York, during a police arrest. Eric Garner died as a result of a police chokehold while being arrested on suspicion of selling single cigarettes without tax stamps.

Her last words, "I can't breathe," became a rallying cry for activists. A grand jury declined to indict the officer involved in the incident, and the city agreed to pay a $6 million civil settlement.

Erica Garner had been in a coma since suffering cardiac arrest on Christmas Eve. Her mother, Esaw Snipes-Garner, reported that her daughter suffered her first heart attack not long after giving birth in August.

In a statement on her official Twitter account, her family and friends wrote, "Her heart was bigger than the world. It really really was. She cared when most people would not have. She was good. She only pursued right, no matter what. No one gave her justice."

During the 2016 campaign, the activist endorsed Sen. Bernie Sanders for president in the Democratic primaries and appeared in a campaign ad on his behalf. She also criticized New York City's Democratic Mayor Bill de Blasio over policing matters.

Shortly after Erica was hospitalized, Sen. Sanders issued a statement on Twitter regarding her activism: "My thoughts are with Erica Garner. I have had the privilege of joining with her at a number of events and was deeply impressed with her courage and insights."

Title: Trump's Fourth of July Speech Contains False Claims About Coronavirus and Administration's Response

Article:

In his Fourth of July speech, President Donald Trump reflected on the nation's history and its accomplishments, but also made several false claims about the coronavirus and his administration's response to the pandemic.

Trump claimed, "We've learned how to put out the flame" of coronavirus, implying that the US has effectively controlled the virus. However, this statement is misleading as the country has experienced its highest daily rate of cases over the past week. In the days leading up to Trump's remarks, the US set a new global record for the most number of coronavirus cases recorded in a day.

The President's claim that the US response to the pandemic is "moving along well" is disingenuous, as the country's response is not "moving along well" when compared with other countries. While coronavirus cases remain high in the US, other countries in Europe and across the world have seen clear downward trends in the number of new confirmed coronavirus cases. The European Union has also banned US residents from traveling there given the sudden spike in coronavirus cases in the US.

Trump also falsely suggested that the recent rise in US coronavirus cases is due to increased testing, and claimed that a majority of the cases that test positive for coronavirus are "totally harmless." However, experts say the recent surges in coronavirus cases are outpacing the increase in tests. Out of the at least 2.8 million cases of coronavirus in the US, Johns Hopkins estimated a fatality rate of 4.6% as of Saturday.

The commissioner of the US Food and Drug Administration declined to defend the President and repeatedly refused to say whether Trump's remark is true or false. The White House has not returned CNN's request for comment on the President's claim.

Trump also touted efforts led by his administration to manufacture the equipment needed to fight the outbreak, claiming, "We've made ventilators where there were none." However, it's not true that the Trump administration was left no ventilators by the Obama administration, something Trump has falsely claimed on numerous occasions. In March, there were 16,660 ventilators available in the national stockpile for immediate use, according to a spokesperson for the Department of Health and Human Services.

Trump also stated, "We are unleashing our nation's scientific brilliance. And we'll likely have a therapeutic and/or vaccine solution long before the end of the year." However, Trump's timeline is more optimistic than both experts' and his own previous predictions. Last week, some top health officials said the US could be on track to have a vaccine by the end of the year, but not "long before." While several vaccine candidates have shown positive early data, all of them still have to undergo more trials.

Title: Health Care Debate in Upstate New York Swing District to Reflect National Trends

Article:

In the closely contested 24th Congressional District of New York, a rematch between former Democratic Representative Dan Maffei and incumbent Republican Ann Marie Buerkle is expected to revolve around the Supreme Court's recent ruling on the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as "Obamacare."

Maffei, who lost to Buerkle in 2010 due to his support for the ACA, is advocating for a shift in focus from past debates to economic improvement. Buerkle, who won by a narrow margin in 2010, remains committed to repealing the ACA.

Maffei stated, "I don't think people want to repeat past battles over and over again. The health care bill is the law of the land, the court ruled it constitutional, so let's improve it." He emphasized the need to focus on jobs and the economy, rather than revisiting the contentious health care debate of 2009.

Buerkle, who is known for her conservative stance, has been tapped by Republican leadership to speak out on the ACA. She has been vocal on the issue, addressing the press with Speaker John Boehner and Majority Leader Eric Cantor following the Supreme Court's ruling, and delivering the national Republican address on the topic over the weekend.

Buerkle links the repeal of the ACA to the economic recovery the district needs. For instance, she cites a local medical device factory that could be subject to a 2.3 percent tax should the ACA be fully implemented.

The health care debate in this district could serve as a national barometer for how the issue plays out in swing districts and among independent voters across the country. The region, still grappling with the effects of the recession and loss of manufacturing jobs, is particularly sensitive to economic improvement.

Retired Fair Haven resident Harris Brown, who plans to vote for Buerkle but desires less partisanship in Washington, expressed a desire for economic growth to improve health care. "If the economy is good, then health care will take care of itself," Brown said.

The health care debate in this district is likely to reflect broader trends in the upcoming elections, with Democrats arguing that the Supreme Court has spoken on the ACA and focusing on economic improvement, while Republicans argue that the ACA infringes on individual freedoms and is a burdensome regulatory measure.

Title: Trump and Omar Exchange Harsh Rhetoric: President Calls Omar "America-Hating" and "Anti-Semite," Omar Responds with Allegations of Racism

Article:

President Donald Trump and Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) have engaged in a heated exchange of rhetoric this week, with the President labeling Omar as "America-hating" and an "Anti-Semite" in a series of tweets. Omar responded by accusing the President of racism.

On Tuesday, Trump tweeted, "I think it's clear that President Trump wants to make a foil out of 'the squad,'" referring to Omar and her fellow liberal freshman representatives, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY), Rashida Tlaib (D-MI), and Ayanna Pressley (D-MA). Trump's tweet followed a previous post in which he called the group a "Nightmare for America."

CBS News Political Director Caitlin Conant noted during her appearance on "Faith Nation" that Trump has used the group's perceived anti-American views to his advantage in the 2020 election. However, Conant also pointed out that in 2016, Trump won in part due to independents who might prefer to discuss issues such as the economy and the courts rather than the ongoing Twitter feud between the President and "the squad."

Conservative groups have seized upon comments made by Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) a few months ago, in which she stated, "I'm more Palestinian in the halls of Congress than I am in the country." This statement has been used to question the loyalty of the "squad" members.

In a 2018 interview, Omar made controversial comments about Islamophobia and terrorism. When asked about the rise in Islamophobia, Omar stated, "Our country should be more fearful of white men across our country because they are actually causing most of the deaths within this country." She also suggested profiling and monitoring white men to combat radicalization.

Omar is also the subject of an ethics complaint filed by the conservative group Judicial Watch over allegations of potential immigration fraud, marriage fraud, and perjury related to her marriage to her brother.

The ongoing feud between Trump and Omar has been met with criticism from both sides, with some viewing it as a toxic and divisive distraction from more pressing issues. However, the President's approval rating remains higher than any of the "squad" members, with Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) having the highest approval rating at 23%.

Title: Retired St. Louis Police Captain David Dorn Killed During Riots, No Arrests Made in Case

Retired St. Louis Police Captain David Dorn was fatally shot while attempting to protect a friend's pawn shop during violent riots that erupted across the U.S. in response to the death of George Floyd. The incident occurred on Monday night, and Dorn's body was found outside Lee's Pawn & Jewelry around 2:30 a.m. on Tuesday. The Associated Press reported that no arrests have been made in the case so far.

Dorn, 77, was a friend of the pawn shop's owner and regularly assisted him whenever the store's alarms were triggered. His wife, St. Louis police Sgt. Ann Marie Dorn, told the St. Louis Dispatch that Dorn was dedicated to helping disadvantaged youth during his time on the force.

Dorn retired from the St. Louis police force in October 2007 after serving 38 years. His close friend, St. Louis County police Chief Tim Fitch, who knew Dorn for 30 years, told the media that Dorn and his wife helped disadvantaged youth while he was on the force.

President Donald Trump honored Dorn in a tweet after his death was reported. "Our highest respect to the family of David Dorn, a Great Police Captain from St. Louis, who was viciously shot and killed by despicable looters last night. We honor our police officers, perhaps more than ever before. Thank you!" Trump tweeted, along with a photo of Dorn in uniform.

Dorn's death is one of many police officers who have been killed or attacked during the riots. Four officers in Missouri were shot while trying to contain rioters. A police officer in Las Vegas was in "grave condition" and on life support after being shot. An officer was also shot in Iowa after an ambush. Two officers in Richmond, Virginia, were shot after responding to a report of an armed person, though it is still unclear if the person was involved with the riots.

In Buffalo, New York, two officers were injured after an SUV ran into a line of police trying to maintain the peace. Another officer was run over by a speeding vehicle in the Bronx.

███, a leading provider of conservative news, is a popular source of news, cutting through the mainstream media's rhetoric to provide readers with the most important, relevant, and engaging stories of the day. Become a member to get inside access to ███.

Title: Carly Fiorina's Business Experience and Political Stance Under Scrutiny in GOP Presidential Race

Article:

Carly Fiorina, the former Hewlett-Packard CEO and the sole female candidate in the Republican presidential race, has a compelling life story and a unique position in the political landscape. Born in Austin, Texas, Fiorina became the first woman to lead a Fortune 20 company, shattering one of the hardest glass ceilings in America. As the Republican primary race heats up, attention is being paid not just to Fiorina's bid for the nomination, but also to her potential as a running mate for the eventual male nominee.

Fiorina's main claim to the national stage, by her own admission, is her business experience and acumen. "I think [voters] very much appreciate someone who understands how the economy works, how the world works, and how big bureaucracies work," she told Breitbart News while pre-campaigning in New Hampshire ahead of her Monday announcement.

However, Fiorina's tenure as CEO of Hewlett-Packard, which ended ten years ago, has been a subject of debate. Critics argue that she left the company in worse shape than she found it before her dismissal in 2005, but Fiorina often points to her chief achievement, the $25 billion takeover of Compaq in 2001, as evidence of her success.

A more significant potential issue for Fiorina is her stance on economic and social issues compared to her corporate peers. While Fiorina's views align with the GOP on critical primary issues such as minimum wage increases, immigration reform, and same-sex marriage, she is increasingly out-of-step with her corporate brethren.

The most recent evidence of this disconnect was the furor over religious freedom laws in Indiana, Arkansas, and other states. These laws, as originally drafted, might have allowed businesses in those states to discriminate against same-sex couples. The corporate backlash was swift and severe, with companies such as Eli Lilly, Cummins, Gap, Marriott, and Walmart speaking out against the laws.

Until the religious-freedom controversy erupted, Fiorina had tried to take a more nuanced view than her GOP rivals, backing government benefits for same-sex civil unions while stopping short of endorsing same-sex marriage. However, the Indiana controversy forced her into open conflict with her former business colleagues, whom she harshly criticized while defending the Indiana law.

Marriage equality is just one example of corporate America's growing independence from the Republican platform. Since an increase-the-minimum-wage movement began in Seattle a year ago, a slew of Fortune 500 CEOs, including McDonald's, Walmart, and Starbucks, have come out in favor of minimum-wage increases, a position that Fiorina and most GOP candidates oppose. CEOs are also beginning to call for immigration reform and to criticize congressional efforts to block it, as well as to blame opposition by Republican party leaders for the 2013 government shutdown crisis.

Long-time denizens of the corporate boardroom say that changing social mores as well as a changing economy have begun to alter mindsets at major companies, especially on minimum wage increases. "I think there is a gradual shift going on," says Mohamed El-Erian, the former CEO of bond giant Pimco and one of the country's most-followed observers of corporate trends. Since Fiorina left the corporate world, he says, "We've come through a period in which the share of profit in GDP is the highest ever and continuously increasing, and in which income inequality has worsened tremendously. Business is realizing there is a limit to which you can push corporate profits without starting to hurt yourself."

Title: U.S. Adult Obesity Rates Remain Steady Despite Health Concerns

Article:

The United States has seen a plateau in adult obesity rates for the first time in 30 years, according to recent data. However, this development is not cause for celebration, as the current rates remain high and pose significant health concerns. The headline "U.S. adult obesity rates holding steady, but still bad" encapsulates the gravity of the situation.

The root cause of the obesity epidemic is a topic of ongoing debate among scientists. One key factor under scrutiny is the role of sugar and sugary drinks. A correlation, rather than a causation, exists between sugar consumption and the rise of obesity and diabetes in the U.S.

Recent findings and disagreements regarding this correlation have been discussed by science writer David Despain. It is prudent for individuals concerned with health to limit their consumption of sugary items, but an alarmist "sugar is toxic" narrative is not supported by good science communication or public health.

Pediatric endocrinologist Robert Lustig is a prominent proponent of this perspective. Lustig argues that metabolic disease, a suite of ailments including heart disease, diabetes, cancer, and dementia, is primarily caused by sugar. He claims that fructose, a component of sugar, is the main culprit, metabolizing to fat and driving metabolic syndrome.

However, Lustig's assertions are contested by other scientists. Mark Kern, Professor of Exercise and Nutritional Sciences at San Diego State University, has pointed out that many of Lustig's arguments are not scientifically supported, including his demonization of fructose. According to Kern, Lustic's claims about fructose metabolizing to fat are not accurate.

David Despain has also criticized Lustig's "demonizing" of sugar and the media's tendency to embrace this perspective. It is crucial to approach discussions about sugar and health with a balanced perspective, avoiding sensationalized claims that may not be grounded in scientific evidence.

Title: Global Elections to Watch in 2015: Kentucky Governor Race, Nigerian Presidential Election, and More

Article:

In 2015, political enthusiasts in the United States can look forward to a series of significant elections across the globe, serving as a prelude to the 2016 presidential race. Among these are high-profile gubernatorial and mayoral races in the U.S., as well as pivotal national elections abroad.

In Kentucky, the state with a Republican lean in the last four presidential elections and two conservative senators, the race for governor is heating up. Current Democratic Governor Steve Beshear, who was reelected in 2011 but is term-limited, has left the political stage, with his Lieutenant Governor, Crit Luallen, also opting not to run. The only major Democratic candidate to announce so far is Attorney General Jack Conway, who lost to Rand Paul in the 2010 Senate contest by 10 points. There is hope among Democrats that Allison Lundergan Grimes, who lost to Mitch McConnell in the 2014 Senate race, will enter the fray. On the Republican side, Louisville Metro Councilman Hal Heiner and State Agricultural Commissioner James Comer have both declared their candidacy. The November Kentucky race will be a key indicator of the Democrats' ability to maintain their support in traditionally red states following the midterm elections.

In Nigeria, President Goodluck Jonathan is seeking reelection in February. The contest is expected to be dominated by the violence many anticipate from the radical Islamist group Boko Haram, which is capable of perpetrating acts such as the kidnapping of hundreds of schoolgirls in Chibok last April. Jonathan will face a rematch against former military dictator Muhammadu Buhari, who represents the All Progressives Congress, a coalition formed in 2013 that has since banked numerous defections from Jonathan's People's Democratic Party. Jonathan aims to secure support from the country's Christian south, as he has enraged many Muslims in his party by reneging on a gentleman's agreement that the PDP's top spot would rotate on a two-term basis between a Muslim and a Christian.

Another election to watch is Saudi Arabia's municipal elections, marking the first time women can both vote and run for office. Although only half of the councils' seats are elected and the councils themselves have limited power, these elections are significant as they represent the first time women can participate in the political process.

Spain's 2015 general election will feature the country's two dominant parties, the right-wing People's Party (PP) and the left-wing Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), both waning in popularity. Current Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy is leading the PP, but his administration's approval ratings have suffered due to unpopular austerity measures, accusations of corruption, and economic malaise. The country witnessed the emergence of Podemos, a left-wing populist party, during the 2014 European Parliamentary election, which gained 8 percent of the national vote. Podemos aims to rewrite the constitution, oust corrupt leaders, raise taxes for more public services, and shorten the work week to reduce unemployment.

In Chicago, Mayor Rahm Emanuel is fighting for his political life in his reelection bid. With the leader of the Chicago Teachers Union, Karen Lewis, announcing she would not challenge him due to illness, Emanuel's path to victory is smoother. However, he could still face challenges in the city's runoff system, which might unite a fractured opposition should he fail to gain 50 percent of the vote in the first round. Anti-Rahm sentiment remains high, with an August Chicago Tribune poll finding that Emanuel's approval rating is only 35 percent. However, a recent poll from David Binder Research shows that his main opponents, Ald. Robert Fioretti and Cook County Commissioner Jesús G. "Chuy" García, have yet to gain significant support.

Title: House Approves Two-Year, $2.7 Trillion Budget Deal, Increasing Federal Spending and National Debt

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives has approved a two-year, $2.7 trillion budget deal that increases federal spending by about $320 billion annually and is estimated to add approximately $1.7 trillion to the national debt over the next 10 years. The budget deal, which was hammered out over the past week between Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, shatters budget caps and exceeds the spending baseline set by the 2011 bill that imposed the so-called "sequestration."

The budget deal, which passed with a vote of 284-149, was supported by all but 16 House Democrats. President Donald Trump, who had previously stated he would "never sign another bill" that increased the deficit, has been supportive of the new agreement. He met with Republican lawmakers for a lunch on Thursday, urging affirmative votes.

Sixty-five Republicans in the House supported the deal, while 132 voted against it. Rep. Justin Amash (I-Mich.), a former Republican who is now the lone independent in the House, voted "nay."

A majority of Republicans voting against a budget deal inked by a Republican president might seem noteworthy, but today's GOP lawmakers only vote for fiscal conservatism when it does not matter. When it did matter, they were more than happy to add to the deficit. In 2016, when Trump was elected and Republicans gained control of all aspects of the federal government's budget-making authority, the United States was carrying about $19 trillion in debt. Today, in part due to the 2018 budget bill the Republican-controlled Congress passed and Trump signed, the national debt has surpassed $22 trillion. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that current policies, which do not include the hike in spending approved by the House on Thursday, will add another $11 trillion by the end of 2029.

If the budget deal eventually makes it to Trump's desk and receives his signature, the 45th president will have personally added $4.1 trillion to the national debt in a little over two years in office, according to a new analysis from the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, which advocates for balanced budgets. The Senate is planning to vote on the bill next week.

One of the final speakers before the House vote was Rep. Steve Womack (R-Ark.), the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee. He reflected on the fact that lawmakers would soon be leaving Washington for a few weeks of work in district offices—for Womack, that means having some town hall meetings with constituents.

"I already know most people are going to say 'look, you guys have a spending problem up there in Washington,'" Womack said.

Title: CNN Faces Ratings Struggles as Fox News Dominates Cable News Landscape

Article:

In the competitive landscape of cable news, CNN has faced significant challenges in the first quarter of 2021, with none of its programs cracking the top 20 in the rating chart. Fox News continues to lead, while even MSNBC, often criticized for its anti-Trump stance, managed to break into the top 20 on multiple fronts.

According to data from Breitbart, Fox News placed eight shows in the top ten and 14 in the top 20. MSNBC filled the remaining slots. CNN's highest-rated program, "The Lead" hosted by Jake Tapper, ranked 22nd with 1.387 million viewers. Tapper's show may have performed well due to President Trump's daily briefings airing during his otherwise anemic timeslot. Sean Hannity, on Fox News, topped everyone during the quarter with an average of 4.22 million viewers, more than triple CNN's top show.

In fact, the only Fox program CNN was able to beat was "Fox and Friends First," which airs before dawn and still managed to come in 40th with 721,000 average viewers. "Fox and Friends First" humiliated CNN's disastrous morning show, "New Day," which was only able to attract 580,000 average viewers.

Overall, Fox News had its biggest viewing quarter in the network's history, averaging 3.4 million primetime viewers and 1.9 million total-day viewers. CNN managed to average 1.43 million primetime viewers, with MSNBC coming in at 1.93 million. Fox News beat both combined during primetime. During primetime, CNN managed to lose to ESPN (1.43 million compared to 1.5 million), even though sports events have been largely canceled due to the coronavirus pandemic.

These ratings struggles are not a new phenomenon for CNN. If it weren't for CNN International, which is less Trump-critical, CNN might have to consider closure. While CNN's future is not immediately at risk, the president has additional ammunition to criticize the network's reporters at press conferences in the future.

Title: Seattle Town Hall Discussion Highlights Factors Driving Polarization in U.S. Politics

Article:

A Seattle Town Hall forum, titled "2016 Election: How Did We Get Here?", hosted by the University of Washington Alumni Association, brought together scholars to discuss the current presidential campaign. The discussion, which focused on the Trump phenomenon and its impact on American politics, highlighted factors such as anger, ignorance, and isolation.

The forum, led by Christopher Sebastian Parker, a political science professor at the University of Washington, began with a discussion about the recent debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. The panelists, including Rick Shenkman, a Seattle journalist, historian, and social-science author, and Mark A. Smith, a UW political scientist, agreed that debates do not typically change voters' support and expect a very close race.

The discussion focused primarily on the Trump phenomenon, with panelists offering insights into why Trump has emerged as a major-party nominee and is running strongly. One of the reasons, according to Shenkman, is that Trump, with his own money and oversized media attention, did not need party elites to support him. He spoke directly to voters who want an outsider who understands their feelings.

Shenkman's books, "Just How Stupid Are We?" and "Political Animals: How Our Stone-Age Brain Gets in the Way of Smart Politics," provide insights into the science that shows our gut instincts usually outweigh rationality in political choices. Shenkman stated, "Donald Trump came along, and he has now proven my point."

Mark A. Smith, a UW political scientist who has studied the role of religion in politics, provided an example of a choice that may not seem logical. He predicts that Mormons, uncomfortable with Trump due to their religious values, will still vote for Trump to maintain political consistency.

The panelists also discussed the role of isolation from opposing information in increasing political polarization. It is easier for people today to take in only information that confirms their beliefs. Margaret O' Mara, associate history professor at the UW, compared Trump to historical figures such as Huey Long, Father Coughlin, Joe McCarthy, and George Wallace.

Trump's rise, according to O' Mara, is partly due to the two major parties' failure to address the frustration and anger that many people feel, some of it driven by economic anxiety. The panelists agreed that whoever wins, the anger will still be present, which is a problem. Shenkman stated, "When you're angry, democracy fails because angry people do not compromise."

The discussion also touched on the role of race in politics today. Smith stated that the biggest dividing line in the campaign is around racial identity, with Trump's supporters being disproportionately white. O' Mara noted that the debate on Monday was the first time a presidential candidate in a debate said the word "racism."

In conclusion, the panelists agreed that fighting anger, ignorance, and isolation is crucial for the future of American politics. They found hope in civil discourse and education, acknowledging that it won't be easy. At the start of the forum, Parker asked people in the audience who supported Trump to raise their hands. No hands went up.

Title: White House Delays Release of Progress Report on ISIL Campaign

Article:

The White House initially planned to release a progress report on the fight against the Islamic State (ISIL) in conjunction with President Obama's State of the Union address on Tuesday, but the report was delayed due to coordination issues. White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest confirmed the delay on Friday.

The report, which was issued three days late, claims that the 65-nation coalition led by the U.S. has made significant progress in its campaign to degrade and destroy ISIL. The report states that the coalition has intensified the fight to liberate ISIL-controlled territory in Iraq and Syria.

The White House reaffirmed President Obama's and the administration's commitment to eliminating the threat posed by ISIL. The report emphasizes the need for patience and flexibility in the multi-year fight against ISIL, acknowledging that there will be challenges along the way.

The report highlights several achievements, including the fact that 12 coalition countries have conducted over 9,500 air strikes in Iraq and Syria. These airstrikes have reportedly destroyed over 3,450 ISIL vehicles and tanks, over 1,120 artillery and mortar positions, 1,170 oil infrastructure components, and more than 13,500 fighting positions, checkpoints, buildings, bunkers, staging areas, and barracks in Iraq and Syria. The report also mentions the destruction of 39 ISIL training camps.

The report does not specify the 12 coalition countries that have conducted the majority of the air strikes, nor does it provide details on the specific locations of these strikes. The report also does not provide information on the number of casualties or the current status of the fight against ISIL.

Title: GOP Holds Sizable Advantage in Midterm Elections, According to Polls

Article:

A new CNN poll indicates a significant advantage for the Republican Party in this year's midterm elections. The poll shows President Barack Obama's standing on terrorism issues in decline as voter concerns about ISIS rise.

The poll, released on Monday, also reveals that more Americans perceive the country as heading in the wrong direction, a common indicator of the electorate's mood. Recent days have also brought a series of polls in key Senate races suggesting Republican advantages in Kentucky, Arkansas, and Alaska, with only a narrow Democratic lead in Colorado. The odds of a GOP takeover of the Senate are looking up eight weeks before Election Day.

Veteran GOP pollster Whit Ayres comments, "It's much better to be a Republican candidate than a Democratic candidate, at least at the moment." He adds, "Yes, the Republican brand sucks, but it is the President's image that dominates midterm elections, not that of our party."

The improving Senate climate for Republicans has rekindled discussions about a "wave" in the elections. The veteran prognosticator Stuart Rothenberg wrote on Monday, "I am now expecting a substantial Republican Senate wave in November, with a net gain of at least seven seats."

However, Ayres cautions, "I don't see any evidence of a wave like we had in '06 or '08." He adds, "But a few more polls like the one you cite could get me to change my mind."

In the CNN poll numbers, the encouraging news for the President is that he and the public are largely in agreement about the appropriate response to ISIS. A majority opposes American combat boots on the ground, but 50% support using other military force, up from 34% a year ago.

However, the damning finding is that 67% of respondents believe Obama does not have a clear plan for dealing with ISIS. Additionally, only 37% approve of how he is handling ISIS, and just 41% approve of his handling of the broader terrorism issue.

The President's job approval rating remains stagnant at 43%, and the percentage of Americans who think things are going badly in the country stands at 55%, up from 50% in April.

Eight weeks is a long time, and Democrats insist they will again surprise us with superior voter outreach and turnout. However, for now, the numbers are compelling: a weak President and a worried electorate are the trademark ingredients of a wave or a significant ripple.

Title: China's National Security Law in Hong Kong: Implications and International Response

Article:

China is moving to rewrite Asia's geopolitical map with the imposition of a sweeping national-security law in Hong Kong, bypassing the territory's elected Legislative Council. The new law will criminalize "foreign interference," secession activities, and subversion of state power.

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has been gradually eroding Hong Kong's freedoms since the 1997 handover from Great Britain, despite assurances to maintain the "one-country, two-systems" framework for 50 years. The past decade has seen a significant decrease in Hong Kong's autonomy, culminating in massive demonstrations in 2019.

The new national-security law will also alter Hong Kong's Basic Law, its constitution, and allow China's security services to operate openly in the territory, further reducing its sovereignty.
