The CCP's move to take over Hong Kong's remaining freedoms is seen as a breach of international agreements and a demonstration of the CCP's willingness to disregard international law and morality.

The proposed national-security law's implications extend beyond Hong Kong, raising concerns about China's intentions towards Taiwan. The democratic island nation, which recently inaugurated President Tsai Ing-wen for a second term, has rejected Beijing's attempts to force Taiwan into a similar "one country-two systems" model. The CCP's actions in Hong Kong may signal a more aggressive approach towards Taiwan.

The international response to China's actions in Hong Kong has been weak, with some countries considering the issue an internal Chinese affair. The United States has released a "Strategic Approach to the People's Republic of China," warning that Beijing "challenges the bedrock American belief in the unalienable right of every person to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness."

The U.S. can limit its direct options but can pressure China to veto a UN Security Council resolution condemning its abrogation of Hong Kong's Basic Law. Travel bans on high-ranking CCP officials and military officers, sanctions on technology transfer to China, and asylum for Hong Kong's democratic leaders and other at-risk individuals are potential measures.

Restricting engagement with China and offering America as a haven for Hong Kongers are small steps, but they send a message of hope to those resisting Beijing's attempts to redraw Asia's map.

Title: Solar Panels Installed on White House Roof: A Step Toward Renewable Energy

Article:

Technicians have completed the installation of solar panels on the White House roof, marking the culmination of a project initiated by President Obama to demonstrate the feasibility and environmental benefits of renewable energy. The solar panels were first proposed by Obama in 2010, with plans to install them on the family's new residence in 2011, providing solar-generated power for water heating and electricity. However, the project was delayed until late 2013.

The White House has not disclosed the number of solar panels installed or their cost due to security and other concerns. The solar panels are expected to generate 6.3 kilowatts of solar power when the sun is shining, according to the White House.

President Obama aims to use this personal example to encourage families and businesses to take steps to reduce reliance on foreign energy and cut emissions linked to global warming. Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz stated, "Solar panels at the White House are a really important message that solar is here, we are doing it, we can do a lot more."

The installation process involved drilling down to the concrete on the White House roof and using epoxy glue and threaded rods to install a gridded subassembly onto which the solar panels could be secured. The solar components, converters, and labor for the installation were all domestic, according to the White House, which declined to name the companies involved in the project due to security concerns.

James Doherty, the White House usher, commented, "Being at the White House, we do have some security concerns. We can't cover the entire roof, although that would be good from an energy savings standpoint."

Some climate change activists have criticized the years of delay as a lack of urgency. Bill McKibben of the environmental group 350.org described the project as symbolically significant but also depressingly protracted. "At this pace, we'll solve global warming right about the time that we're 30 feet under water," McKibben said in an interview.

President Obama is not the first to deploy solar energy at the White House. President Jimmy Carter invested $30,000 in a solar water-heating system for West Wing offices in the late 1970s, but his successor, Ronald Reagan, removed the panels upon moving in. President George W. Bush's solar systems powered a maintenance building and some of the mansion, as well as providing heated water for the pool.

Title: Expanded Participants in June 2016 Trump Tower Meeting Confirmed

Article:

The number of individuals who attended the controversial June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower has grown to eight, according to recent reports. The meeting, which included Donald Trump Jr., Kremlin-linked attorney Natalia Veselnitskaya, and music publicist Rob Goldstone, among others, has reignited claims of potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.

Rinat Akhmetshin, identified by NBC as a Russian-American lobbyist, has confirmed his attendance at the meeting. Akhmetshin, who denies any ties to Russian intelligence agencies, told the Associated Press that Trump Jr. had asked Veselnitskaya for evidence of illicit money flowing to the Democratic National Committee. However, Veselnitskaya stated that she did not have such information.

Akhmetshin also reportedly mentioned that Trump Jr., Manafort, and Kushner seemed eager for the meeting to conclude. Two more men are believed to have attended the meeting, including former State Department contractor Anatoli Samochornov, who has ties to Veselnitskaya, and another unnamed individual.

Trump Jr.'s attorney, Alan Futerfas, told Fox News that he could not confirm Samochornov's attendance at the meeting, but stated that one of the two other attendees was a U.S. citizen. Other reports characterize an unnamed attendee as a "former Russian counter-intelligence officer" and a friend of Russian singer and billionaire scion Emin Agalarov.

Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) stated, "The growing and still mysterious meeting roster adds another deeply disturbing fact about this secret meeting." Schiff continued, "Whether the additional party or parties present during the meeting with these top Trump campaign personnel at the time Donald Trump had seized the nomination were connected directly with Russian intelligence or not, it is clear the Kremlin got the message that Donald Trump welcomed the help of the Russian government in providing dirt on Hillary Clinton."

Neither Kushner's attorney nor spokesperson have commented on this matter. Goldstone and Manafort did not respond to Fox News' request for comment.

Title: The Potential Impact of a Trump Presidency on the Supreme Court and the Republican Party

Article:

Many conservatives and libertarians are considering voting for Donald Trump due to concerns about liberal control of the Supreme Court. They believe that Hillary Clinton's potential judicial appointments would be detrimental, while Trump, despite his flaws, is perceived as supportive of originalist jurists who uphold limited government and constitutional checks and balances.

Trump's list of potential justices, including judges such as Diane Sykes, Neil Gorsuch, and Robert Young, is seen as a positive by some conservatives. However, the article cautions against placing too much faith in Trump's list, citing his lack of understanding of the judicial process and his volatile temperament.

The article argues that a Trump presidency could have a transformative effect on the Republican Party, potentially leading to a shift away from originalism and limited government. This internal threat, it suggests, may be greater than the external threat posed by a Clinton presidency.

The article also discusses the relative independence of the Supreme Court, noting that partisan disagreements do not significantly impact the court's decisions. It warns that a Trump presidency could lead to a series of constitutional crises, citing his response to Judge Gonzalo Curiel as an example of his potential behavior.

Furthermore, the article suggests that a Trump presidency could lead to a change in the Republican Party's judicial philosophy, moving away from originalism and towards judicial deference. This shift could result in a focus on executive powers, a narrow view of freedom of speech, and tight restrictions on civil liberties.

The article concludes by warning that voting for Trump out of concern for the Supreme Court and originalism could be akin to handing the keys to an arsonist, with the potential for significant damage to both the Supreme Court and the Republican Party.

Title: US and EU Agree to Lower Tariffs, Avert Trade War

Article:

The United States and the European Union (EU) have agreed to avoid an all-out trade war and work towards lowering tariffs, following a meeting between US President Donald Trump and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker at the White House. The agreement, hailed by Trump as "a very strong understanding," marks a "new phase" in EU-US relations.

The threat of US tariffs on European cars has been put aside, with the EU planning to increase imports of US liquefied natural gas (LNG) and soybeans. The two leaders agreed to "work together toward zero tariffs, zero non-tariff barriers, and zero subsidies on non-auto industrial goods."

However, US import tariffs of 25% on steel and 10% on aluminum, imposed in March, will remain in place. A working group of senior advisers will meet to facilitate trade and lower barriers, with both sides pledging to refrain from imposing new trade restrictions during these negotiations.

The potential for a full-blown trade war had been looming due to the tariffs introduced by Trump. EU-US relations have been strained by Trump's comments towards Russian President Vladimir Putin, his attacks on NATO, and the EU. Trump's language after meeting Juncker was more positive, contrasting with his previous angry tone towards the EU, which he once described as a "foe" on trade.

Trump has faced domestic pressure due to retaliatory tariffs imposed on US goods by China, the EU, Canada, and Mexico. US chipmaker Qualcomm Inc appears to be the latest casualty of the trade row with China, having dropped a $44bn bid to take over NXP Semiconductors after China failed to give approval for it.

On Tuesday, the Trump administration announced up to $12bn in aid for US farmers hurt by the Chinese tariffs. Speaking at the White House, Trump declared a "new phase in the relationship" between the US and the EU, calling it a "very big day for free and fair trade." Juncker thanked the president and hailed a "constructive meeting."

The EU's increased LNG and soybean purchases are not a promise to interfere in market forces, but rather a response to existing market trends. "We are not turning into a Soviet-style economy," said an official. This agreement is not a revival of the controversial Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) or a significant free trade agreement, as it would require the consent of EU member states and take much longer to negotiate.

The pair also agreed to work towards reform of the World Trade Organization (WTO). Trump has accused the WTO of treating the US unfairly, though mostly the US has won in arbitration cases there. The agreement does not include any announcement on car tariffs, and it is unclear whether progress has been made on resolving this issue. Trump had threatened to impose 25% import tariffs on European cars.

EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom described the agreement as "turning a page" on trade, while German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier hailed it as a "breakthrough." German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas tweeted, "Juncker showed in Washington that it's not about who tweets most aggressively, but about whether one offers real solutions. Because Trump's grassroots also feels that it only loses when we impose more and more senseless tariffs on each other."

French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire welcomed the agreement, but called for "clarifications." He said there was no point trying to clinch any major trade deal with the US. Agriculture must be excluded, he said, because Europe could not compromise on food safety and environmental standards.

Trump scorned the proposed EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), which stalled two years ago. However, his "deal" with Juncker echoes some of TTIP's ambition. A former US Ambassador to the EU, Anthony Gardner, made this point in a tweet.

Title: Iranian Cyberattack on U.S. Navy's Unclassified Network Lasted Over Four Months, Report Says

Article:

A reported four-month-long cyberattack on the U.S. Navy's largest unclassified computer network has raised concerns among some lawmakers regarding security vulnerabilities exposed by the attack. According to The Wall Street Journal, citing current and former U.S. officials, the cyberattack targeted the Navy Marine Corps Internet, a network used for hosting websites, storing non-sensitive information, and handling voice, video, and data communications.

The hackers reportedly remained in the network until November 2020, contradicting initial reports from officials when the attack was first publicly disclosed in September 2020. At that time, officials told The Wall Street Journal that the intruders had been removed.

A senior U.S. official told The Wall Street Journal that the Iranians were able to conduct surveillance and compromise communications over the unclassified computer networks of the Navy and Marine Corps. However, another senior official stated that no email accounts were hacked, and no data was stolen. There is also no evidence that Iran was able to penetrate classified U.S. computer networks.

The cyberattack is one of the most serious infiltrations of government computer systems by the Iranians, according to The Wall Street Journal. U.S. defense officials were reportedly surprised at the skill of the hackers, who entered the network through a security gap in a public-facing website.

The military response to the hack was overseen by Vice Adm. Mike Rogers, President Obama's pick to be the next head of the National Security Agency. Congressional aides told The Wall Street Journal that Rogers would likely face questions on plans to address security issues that have surfaced as a result of the attack. A confirmation hearing for Rogers has not yet been scheduled.

Despite the length of the operation to remove the hackers, officials who spoke to The Wall Street Journal praised Rogers for his leadership of the cybersecurity response. The issue is not expected to prevent Rogers from being confirmed as NSA director.

Title: Congress Demands Private Emails of IRS and EPA Employees as Clinton Email Scandal Expands

Article:

In a series of developments, one of the tea party groups targeted by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has requested Congress to demand the private emails of some agency employees, while the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology Chairman has issued a request for instant-chat messages from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The Clinton email scandal, which initially involved former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, is now enveloping other parts of the Obama administration.

The White House, in an attempt to distance itself from the growing scandal, has maintained that President Obama and Mrs. Clinton did email, but the White House followed all record-keeping laws, and the president was unaware of Mrs. Clinton's exclusive use of a private email until last week.

Catherine Engelbrecht, founder of True the Vote, which had its tax-exempt application blocked for years by IRS employees, suggested that more than a dozen current and former IRS employees may have used personal emails to avoid public scrutiny while targeting tea party groups with intrusive scrutiny. Engelbrecht also called for congressional committees investigating the IRS to delve deeper into whether any agency employees did the same as Clinton.

In a related development, House Committee on Science, Space and Technology Chairman Lamar Smith has demanded that the EPA turn over more documents, including emails and text messages, or face subpoena. The EPA has been criticized for failing to follow open records laws, with a federal judge last week blasting the agency for its lack of transparency.

Hillary Clinton's email practices are only now coming to light, two years after she left the State Department. The department has stated that every previous secretary of state also used a private email account, and it is requesting copies of official emails to complete its records.

Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said Clinton turned over 55,000 unclassified emails to the department, but it is unclear when they will be released. The spokeswoman also said it is not automatically against the law to have used private email for public business, despite it being the best practice.

At the White House, spokesman Josh Earnest acknowledged that the State Department was asking Clinton to turn her business-related messages over, but would not speculate on whether an independent arbiter should be called in to determine what should be turned over. Earnest stated that the decision on releasing more emails is ultimately up to Clinton's team.

Title: Joe Biden Reverses Position on Hyde Amendment, Aligns with Democratic Party on Abortion Funding

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, the presumed frontrunner for the Democratic Party's 2020 presidential nomination, reversed his long-held support for the Hyde Amendment on Thursday, a move that aligns him with the party's stance on abortion funding.

In a speech at a Democratic National Committee gala in Atlanta, Biden did not mention the mounting pressure or criticism he received in recent days regarding his previous support for the Hyde Amendment. Instead, he credited the change as part of developing a comprehensive healthcare proposal.

The Hyde Amendment, named for former GOP Rep. Henry Hyde of Illinois, was first passed in 1976 and is renewed annually by Congress. It bans federal funding of abortion, allowing exceptions only in cases of rape, incest, or when a pregnant person's life is at serious risk.

Biden, who is looking to pitch a centrist approach in an increasingly progressive primary field, explained that the Hyde Amendment is another barrier to abortion access, which disproportionately affects poor women and women of color.

"I've been working through the finer details of my health care plan like others in this race, and I've been struggling with the problems that Hyde now presents," Biden said. "Circumstances have changed, and the measure stands in the way of my goals 'universal coverage' and providing 'the full range of services women need.'"

Biden's support for the Hyde Amendment marked a sharp split from most of his 2020 competitors, as well as from the Democratic Party's platform. In 2016, the party amended its presidential platform to explicitly call for the repeal of the Hyde Amendment, describing it as among the "federal and state laws and policies that impede a woman's access to abortion."

Several 2020 Democratic presidential candidates, including Sens. Bernie Sanders, Kamala Harris, Kirsten Gillibrand, Amy Klobuchar, Elizabeth Warren, and Reps. Cory Booker, Tim Ryan, and Julián Castro, have all co-sponsored legislation to overturn the amendment.

Ilyse Hogue, president of the abortion rights group NARAL Pro-Choice America, said Thursday that she was glad to see Biden had reversed course. "At a time where the fundamental freedoms enshrined in Roe are under attack, we need full-throated allies in our leaders," she said. "We're pleased Joe Biden has joined the rest of the 2020 Democratic field in coalescing around the Party's core values—support for abortion rights and the basic truth that reproductive freedom is fundamental to the pursuit of equality and economic security in this country."

Title: U.S. Stock Market Experiences Historic Losses Amid Coronavirus Fears

Article:

The U.S. stock market has been experiencing a significant downturn, with a period of historic gains coming to a halt due to fears that the coronavirus epidemic may reach America. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) finished lower for a fifth consecutive day, with the S&P 500 index also experiencing losses.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) closed at -3.61%, marking its biggest reversal from an intraday high of 461.42 points, to a 124-point loss since Dec. 21, 2018, according to Dow Jones Market Data. This puts the Dow 8.78% away from its Feb. 12 record-high close of 29,551.42, approaching correction territory at 26,596.28, defined as a drop of at least 10%, but not greater than 20%, from a recent peak.

The S&P 500 (SPX) closed at -3.58%, and the Nasdaq Composite (COMP) ended at -3.83%. The S&P 500 is off 7.97% from its recent record high on Feb. 19, while the Nasdaq is off 8.52% from its Feb. 19 all-time closing high after a tepid gain on Wednesday.

The fear of the COVID-19 disease infecting the U.S. is intensifying. The illness, derived from the novel coronavirus, SARS-COV-2, which originated in Wuhan, China, late last year, is starting to affect global trade and travel and taking a bite out of confidence about earnings and economic growth.

Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said on Tuesday that "the disruption of daily life might be severe."

The World Health Organization hasn't declared the viral infection a pandemic, but the disease, from the family of viruses known as SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, has sickened people in China, South Korea, Japan, Malaysia, Italy, and Iran. According to Reuters, Austria, Spain, Croatia, and Switzerland have also confirmed their first cases.

The virus has virtually crippled swaths of manufacturing in China, the second-largest economy in the world, and the country is a significant buyer of products and services from other countries. U.S. technology companies such as Apple Inc. (AAPL), HP Inc. (HPQ), and Mastercard Inc. (MA) depend on Chinese supplies.

At last check, COVID-19 has sickened 81,312 cases, and claimed 2,770 lives. President Donald Trump was scheduled to hold a news conference about the virus Wednesday evening.

Investors don't know how long the outbreak will last, and it is too early to determine to what degree it will hurt corporate earnings, but a number of companies, including Hasbro Inc. (HAS), HP Inc. (HPQ), and Mastercard Inc. (MA), have already said that they think it will.

Uncertainty about the U.S. presidential election's outcome is also starting to drive markets, strategists and analysts argue. A number of them think that if Sen. Bernie Sanders, an independent from Vermont who characterizes himself as a democratic socialist, wins the Democratic presidential nomination, and possibly even the presidency, stocks would take a hit as he is perceived by some as an antibusiness candidate. "The risk to U.S. stocks is pretty significant if Bernie gets the nomination," said Ed Moya, a senior market analyst with OANDA.

Even before the market slump this week, the value of stocks has been viewed as rich. One measure of stock-market values showed that the S&P 500 index was trading at 18.9 times the weighted aggregate consensus forward earnings estimate among analysts polled by ███. That is up from 16.2 a year ago, and, aside from a brief point early in 2018, it is the highest forward price-to-earnings ratio for the benchmark index since May 2002.

Government bonds yields have been sliding steadily as investors seek safe havens, and thus drive up bond prices, amid doubts about global economic growth in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, -19.60% carved fell to a record low below 1.32% earlier Tuesday, and the 30-year Treasury note TMUBMUSD30Y, -10.27% rate notched its all-time low last week.

Bond investors fear that the coronavirus might result in a global economic slowdown that might wash up on U.S. shores as a full-fledged recession. ███ economics writer Rex Nutting explained the potential for an uncontained outbreak of COVID-19 this way: "Much of the immediate economic impact of a pandemic can be traced to the efforts to contain it, rather than from the effects of the disease itself. As we attempt to quarantine those who might spread the disease, we shut down a lot of economic activity."

A Congressional Budget Office study found that a pandemic "could produce a short-run impact on the worldwide economy similar in depth and duration to that of an average postwar recession in the United States."

Title: IRS Faces Scrutiny Over Line Dancing Video Amidst Tax-Exempt Scandal

Article:

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is under renewed scrutiny following the release of a video showing a dozen of its employees line dancing. The video, which was produced at a cost of approximately $1,600, was one of three videos that were given to Congress last Friday in response to a request by Rep. Charles Boustany (R-La.), a senior member of the House Ways and Means Committee.

The line dancing video, which lasts just under three minutes, was recorded in 2010 and was shown at the end of a training and leadership conference held in Anaheim, California. The video, which features IRS employees dancing to music that sounds like "Cupid Shuffle" by performer Cupid, was produced at a time when most government agencies are implementing across-the-board spending cuts.

The video is the latest in a series of videos produced by IRS employees, with the agency also producing parodies of the "Star Trek" and "Gilligan's Island" TV shows. The "Star Trek" video, which cost about $59,000 in total, was produced for the same 2010 conference, while the "Gilligan's Island" parody was used at the beginning of a 12-hour video in 2011 to train IRS workers on various tax issues.

The "Collected and Wasted: The IRS Spending Culture and Conference Abuses" report, which is set to be released next week by a Treasury inspector general, will be the subject of a hearing by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee on Thursday.

Rep. Boustany stated, "Whether it is the tens of thousands of hard-earned taxpayer dollars spent to produce frivolous entertainment for agency bureaucrats, or the IRS’s own admission that it targeted the American people based on their personal beliefs, the outrage toward the IRS is only growing stronger."

In a written statement, the IRS called the line dancing video "unacceptable and an inappropriate use of government funds." The agency also stated that it has new policies in place "to ensure that taxpayer funds are being used appropriately."

In a separate statement, Danny Werfel, the IRS's new acting commissioner, called the 2010 conference "an unfortunate vestige from a prior era." Werfel added, "While there were legitimate reasons for holding the meeting, many of the expenses associated with it were inappropriate and should not have occurred."

The Treasury Department, of which the IRS is a part, stated that it puts "the highest priority on protecting taxpayer dollars." It added that it would work with Werfel as he reviews his agency's operations and tries to "restore public confidence in the IRS."

The 2010 conference was attended by 2,600 IRS workers from 350 offices around the country that handle tax returns for small businesses and self-employed individuals.

Title: Rep. Darrell Issa Subpoenas More Benghazi Documents from State Department

Article:

Rep. Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Oversight Committee, has issued a subpoena to the State Department on Tuesday, demanding additional documents related to the controversial talking points used in the aftermath of the 2012 Benghazi consulate attack. The subpoena seeks documents from ten current and former employees not included in the last batch of emails from the department.

Issa claims that the State Department has not complied with the administration's promises of cooperation with Congress and has issued the subpoena to compel the department to produce relevant documents. The subpoena is specifically targeting communications related to talking points from nine State Department officials.

Republicans have accused the White House of stripping the talking points, which were used by U.N. Ambassador Susan Rice in Sunday show appearances the weekend after the attacks, of all references to "terrorism" to achieve a political goal. The White House turned over 100 pages of emails earlier this month, arguing that these emails show that CIA Deputy Director Mike Morell, not State spokeswoman Victoria Nuland, was the one who first suggested removing terrorism references from the talking points.

Issa's subpoena requests the correspondences of several State Department officials, including Nuland, Cheryl Mills, a top aide to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, who Republicans have accused of being the force behind the efforts to mount a political cover-up in the aftermath of the attacks. The requests also include the records of William Burns, the deputy secretary of State, and Beth Jones, the acting assistant secretary for Near East Affairs, who has also been the subject of criticism by Republicans.

Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.), the ranking member of the Oversight Committee, argued that the subpoena is just more politics and an attempt to smear Clinton in advance of a possible 2016 presidential run.

"House Republicans appear to be obsessed with Hillary Clinton and are distracting Congress from conducting responsible oversight to protect our diplomatic personnel serving overseas," said Cummings in a statement. "This investigation has been politicized from the beginning as House Republicans accuse first and then scramble to find evidence to back up their unsubstantiated claims."

Title: South Korea Disputes John Bolton's Account of U.S.-North Korea Summits

Article:

South Korea is challenging the account of former U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton regarding President Trump's negotiations with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, as presented in Bolton's memoir, "The Room Where It Happened." The book, set for release on Tuesday, has already been the subject of media excerpts.

According to a South Korean security official, Bolton's portrayal of the events surrounding the three U.S.-North Korea summits that took place from June 2018 to June 2019 is "distorted." In his book, Bolton alleges that South Korean President Moon Jae-in set unrealistic expectations for the talks while pursuing his own agenda for Korean peninsula unification. Bolton reportedly describes Moon as "schizophrenic," according to Reuters.

South Korea's national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, stated that Bolton's published account of internal deliberations between the heads of state sets a "dangerous precedent." Chung added that unilaterally publishing consultations made based on mutual trust violates the basic principles of diplomacy and could severely damage future negotiations.

President Trump has responded forcefully to the book, denying its claims and attacking Bolton as a "wacko." In a tweet last week, Trump called Bolton's book "exceedingly tedious" and "made up of lies and fake stories." Trump also tweeted that Bolton, who he fired, was a "disgruntled boring fool who only wanted to go to war."

The U.S. Department of Justice has sued to block the book's publication, claiming that Bolton violated rules against publishing classified information. Copies of the book have already been released to the press, making the lawsuit largely moot for the sake of protecting any privileged information.

On Saturday, D.C. Circuit Court Judge Royce Lamberth ruled in the case, denying a Trump administration request to block the book's publishing date. Lamberth also warned Bolton that if he did not receive approval from the administration before publishing the book, he could forfeit his $2 million book advance and possibly more.

"Bolton has gambled with the national security of the United States," Lamberth wrote in his decision, according to The New York Times. "He has exposed his country to harm and himself to civil (and potentially criminal) liability." However, Lamberth added that the government had failed to establish that an injunction would prevent irreparable harm.

Trump cheered the ruling, tweeting that it was a "BIG COURT WIN against Bolton." Trump also said, "Bolton broke the law and has been called out and rebuked for so doing, with a really big price to pay. He likes dropping bombs on people, and killing them. Now he will have bombs dropped on him!"

███, a leading provider of conservative news, offers inside access to the most important, relevant, and engaging stories of the day. Become a member to get the latest news from ███.

Title: An Analysis of the Impact of President Trump's Impeachment on Stock Market Performance

Article:

The claim made by former President Donald Trump that stocks would crash if he were to be removed from office is a topic of debate, with some suggesting that corporate earnings and valuation could play a significant role in determining the stock market's performance.

Since Election Day 2016, the S&P 500 has experienced an annualized growth rate of 20%, significantly higher than the historical return of 9.4% since 1927. However, it is worth noting that the Trump return is only about 1 percentage point higher than the yearly gain since March 2009, an era primarily overseen by President Barack Obama.

Changes in earnings forecasts under Trump have been substantial compared to historical trends. In December 2017, analysts predicted S&P 500 earnings of about $146 a share for 2018, forecasts that, due largely to the president's tax cuts, soared over the next two months, rising four times as fast as any period tracked by the data provider. Companies delivered on these expectations, with S&P 500 operating income jumping 24% in each of the last two quarters, and analysts predicting combined EPS of $159 a share for all of this year.

Predictions for 2019 profits also soared, going from $163 a share at the start of the year to $177 a share now, an upward revision that dwarfs any since at least 2012. Additionally, there has been a small increase in valuations, with the S&P 500 fetching 20.07 times annual earnings on Election Day 2016 and 20.7 times now.

While looking at earnings in isolation ignores numerous other factors that could influence the stock market's response to political events, the income lens is a useful tool for understanding the potential impact of impeachment on stocks. Analysts are skeptical of the president's impeachment prospects and believe any market volatility or sell-off would be short-term in nature.

Craig Erlam, senior market analyst at Oanda Corp. in London, stated, "The market isn't hinging on anything substantial that hasn't already been carried through. The markets have largely rallied on tax reform, and we've seen that reflected in company earnings. But if there's political instability and the U.S. economic growth slowed significantly, that would have global implications."

Nicholas Colas, Co-founder of DataTrek Research, wrote, "Equity markets don't seem to care, and we think they are right. Rates are low, the dollar is strong, and corporate earnings remain robust. Those are the only things stock prices can (and should) actually discount."

It is important to note that past instances of presidential turmoil have shown contrasting stock returns. In February 1974, when Congress initiated impeachment proceedings against President Richard Nixon, the market was in the midst of a bear market due to an oil crisis and an implosion of the world's foreign exchange rate system. The S&P 500 tumbled more than 30% through October that year.

In contrast, in December 1998, when the House voted to impeach President Bill Clinton, stocks continued to rise during the last stage of the Internet boom. The S&P 500 climbed for five straight months until Clinton's acquittal in February 1999.

As of 9:45 a.m. in New York, the S&P 500 was virtually unchanged, and the index barely budged Wednesday in the aftermath of the convictions of Trump associates that sparked renewed discussion of a potential impeachment.

Title: Catalan Separatist Leaders Sentenced to Prison Terms, Sparking Protests in Barcelona

Article:

Protests have erupted in Barcelona, Spain, following the Supreme Court's sentencing of nine Catalan separatist leaders to prison terms ranging from nine to 13 years. The leaders were convicted of sedition for their roles in an illegal independence referendum in 2017. Another three were found guilty of disobedience and fined but not jailed.

The sentencing occurred on Monday, with the 12 defendants denying the charges. Large crowds of pro-independence protesters clashed with police at Barcelona's international airport, resulting in 108 flight cancellations, according to Spanish airport authority Aena. Thousands of Catalan independence supporters also marched in the city center, blocking some streets and access to metro stations.

The longest sentence of 13 years was handed to Oriol Junqueras, the former vice-president of Catalonia and the highest-ranking pro-independence leader on trial, for sedition and misuse of public funds. The prosecution had sought up to 25 years in prison for Junqueras.

Former Catalan President Carles Puigdemont, who is living abroad, was issued a new European and international arrest warrant on grounds of sedition and misuse of public funds. He fled to Belgium in October 2017 to avoid prosecution in Spain following the failed independence bid.

Junqueras accused Spain of jailing people for their political ideals and pledged that the separatists would return even stronger. Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez insisted the leaders had been jailed for criminal conduct.

The sentences handed down have shocked many across Catalonia. The Catalan National Assembly called for "mobilisations around the globe" using the hashtag #StandUpForCatalonia. Both FC Barcelona and the Catalan football federation condemned the prison sentences and called for "dialogue and negotiation" to resolve the situation.

In 2017, police and protesters clashed in the streets when Catalonia's pro-independence leaders went ahead with the referendum, which had been ruled illegal by Spain's constitutional court. Other separatist leaders to receive prison sentences for sedition were Jordi Sànchez, activist and ex-president of the Catalan National Assembly (9 years), and Jordi Cuixart, president of Catalan language and culture organization Òmnium Cultural (9 years).

The nine leaders, who had already spent months in pre-trial detention, were acquitted of a more serious charge of rebellion. During their closing arguments in June, defense lawyers told the court their clients denied the charges of rebellion and sedition but admitted to the lesser charge of disobedience, which could have seen them be banned from public office but avoid prison.

Prosecutors argued that the unilateral declaration of independence was an attack on the Spanish state and accused some of those involved of a serious act of rebellion. They also said that separatist leaders had misused public funds while organizing the 2017 referendum. Prosecutors argued the leaders had carried out a "perfectly planned strategy... to break the constitutional order and obtain the independence of Catalonia" illegally.

Forcadell, the former parliament speaker who read out the independence result on 27 October 2017, was also accused of allowing parliamentary debates on independence despite warnings from Spain's Constitutional Court. Some of the leaders, speaking to the BBC ahead of the trial, said the proceedings were political in nature. Any violence, they said, was on the part of police and committed against voters in a crackdown which made headlines around the world.

Three weeks after the banned 2017 vote, the Catalan parliament declared an independent republic. Madrid stepped in to impose its rule on the region, and several Catalan leaders fled or were arrested. Catalan nationalists have long complained that their region, which has a distinct history dating back almost 1,000 years, sends too much money to poorer parts of Spain, as taxes are controlled by Madrid. The wealthy region is home to about 7.5 million people, with their own language, parliament, flag, and anthem. In September, a march in Barcelona in support of Catalonia's independence from Spain drew crowds of about 600,000 people - one of the lowest turnouts in the eight-year history of the annual rally.

Title: Five Killed, Two Injured in Maryland Newspaper Shooting; Journalists Press On

A gunman opened fire at the Capital Gazette newspaper office in Annapolis, Maryland on Thursday, resulting in the deaths of five employees and injuries to two others. The shooter, Jarrod Warren Ramos, has a history of hostility towards the newspaper, including a lawsuit and harassment of its journalists on Twitter.

Ramos was charged with five counts of first-degree murder. Tom Marquardt, a retired publisher and top editor at the paper, stated, "I was seriously concerned he would threaten us with physical violence. I even told my wife, 'We have to be concerned. This guy could really hurt us.'"

On Twitter, Ramos hinted that he'd enjoy seeing two journalists "cease breathing."

In the aftermath of the shooting, the Capital Gazette journalists have shown resilience, working from a makeshift newsroom in a parking lot to ensure the newspaper is published. Their shock is profound, but they continue to serve their readers.

In the broader media landscape, there has been a predictable cycle of finger-pointing, opportunism, and condemnation of cultural and political factors thought to be at the core of recent mass shootings. It is human nature to seek an explanation for the unfathomable.

However, it is crucial to avoid hateful castigations and volatile rhetoric. Such language only serves to dehumanize and we do not need more of that. The reason for this senseless massacre remains unclear, but it is evident that no sane person would commit such an act.

There may be concerns regarding the accessibility of the weaponry involved and various toxic cultural influences, but at the heart of this issue lies a mental health concern.

Legislation such as the "red flag" gun bill, on the brink of becoming law in Massachusetts, may be a positive step. The bill focuses on the mental health aspect of gun ownership.

Let's continue to work on this issue, regardless of the various political sensitivities at play.

Title: The United States Faces a Regime of Uncertainty: An Analysis of Current Economic Policies

Article:

The United States economy is currently grappling with a pervasive sense of uncertainty, a condition coined by economist Robert Higgs as "regime uncertainty." This situation arises when investors lose confidence in the government's respect for property rights, making long-term investment difficult.

One form of regime uncertainty is policy uncertainty, which occurs when investors are confident in basic property rights but fear that changes in public policy may render their investments unprofitable. For instance, the Affordable Care Act's employer health-insurance mandate, which covers firms with 50 or more full-time employees, is a point of contention. While some Democrats propose lowering the threshold, Republicans aim to repeal it altogether, creating uncertainty for employers with 40-50 employees.

President Trump and some Democrats have expressed intentions to alter the taxation of private-equity firms, potentially doubling their tax burden. This could deter potential investors in the private-equity sector, as well as those in other industries with "carried interest" income that might be affected by changes in tax policy.

The Trump administration's stance on NAFTA, along with the opposition from many in Congress, creates uncertainty for multinational projects involving the United States, Canada, and Mexico. The temporary nature of tax cuts, due to sunset provisions, also contributes to this uncertainty.

Another issue is the national debt and the deficits that contribute to it. The debt poses straightforward problems, such as the potential for debt-service payments to become burdensome, but there are also related problems stemming from efforts to reduce the deficit. Tax cuts, for example, often have temporary sunset provisions, leading to endless debates about renewing them.

The Trump administration and Republicans in Congress aim to pass a tax cut using the reconciliation process to avoid a potential Democratic filibuster. However, these tax cuts will also be temporary, expiring in ten years. This approach to tax cuts, along with the administration's chaotic approach to healthcare reform, contributes to the overall sense of uncertainty in the economy.

To address this uncertainty, a reasonable, sober, and sustainable settlement on the national fiscal challenge is needed. Without predictability, the economy will continue to face real costs in terms of economic growth, employment, wages, and future prosperity. The current regime of uncertainty is a departure from the certainty that was once valued by the Republican Party.

Title: United States Announces Withdrawal from United Nations Human Rights Council

Article:

The United States has announced its intention to withdraw from the United Nations Human Rights Council, according to Reuters. The decision comes a day after the U.N. human rights chief, Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein, criticized the Trump administration's policy of separating migrant parents from their children as "unconscionable."

The move was expected, as it aligns with the Trump administration's stance against what it perceives as the U.N.'s anti-Israel bias. U.S. Ambassador to the U.N., Nikki Haley, had previously stated that the U.S. would leave the council unless its "chronic anti-Israel bias" was addressed. Haley has also advocated for reforms aimed at making it easier to expel egregious human rights abusers from the council.

The U.S. had previously boycotted the council under the George W. Bush administration before rejoining under Barack Obama. The Trump administration has since made a practice of withdrawing from U.N. organizations perceived as having an anti-Israel bias.

The Human Rights Council is not without criticism. While its members are theoretically required to "uphold the highest standards in the promotion and protection of human rights," some countries, such as Burundi, Cuba, Togo, and Saudi Arabia, have been admitted. The membership system, based on regional blocs, allows for easier circumvention of a full vote on admittance.

Criticism of Israel's occupation of the Palestinian territories is warranted, but the council's focus on this issue, to the exclusion of other global conflicts and human rights violations, has been a point of contention.

While human rights groups argue that it would be more productive for the U.S. to stay and advocate for reforms, the Trump administration's domestic and international human rights record has come under scrutiny. With the administration under fire for alleged egregious human rights abuses at the U.S.-Mexico border and President Trump's comments suggesting a desire for American citizens to "sit up at attention" like they do in North Korea, the U.S. is currently not considered a credible voice for reform on this issue.

Title: Trump Administration Yet to Contact State Election Officials Regarding Alleged Voter Fraud Investigation

Article:

Despite repeated claims by the Trump administration that widespread voter fraud exists and a pledge to conduct a thorough investigation, it appears that the White House and the Department of Justice have not contacted top state election officials across the country regarding the matter.

The Huffington Post reached out to all 50 secretaries of state and election officials in the District of Columbia, and none of them responded to confirm that they had been contacted by the White House or the Department of Justice regarding the investigation.

It is unclear whether the administration will release any information or evidence to support their claims of voter fraud. Some speculate that, if the White House feels pressured to provide evidence, they may release an unsourced report compiled by White House interns, referencing sources such as Alex Jones, Breitbart, or other controversial figures as evidence of voter fraud.

It remains to be seen if the administration will provide further details on the alleged investigation, but it is noteworthy that, as of now, no state election officials have confirmed contact from the White House or the Department of Justice.

Title: Ukrainian Rebels Recruit Fighters, Raise Funds in Moscow as Kremlin Denies Involvement

Article:

MOSCOW — Ukrainian rebels are openly recruiting fighters, raising money, and collecting combat gear in Moscow, the capital of Russia, despite the Kremlin's denial of supporting the pro-Russia fighters. The recruiting office for the Donetsk People's Republic does not have a street address, but volunteers can join by calling a number or writing an email.

The U.S. State Department acknowledged last month that the office exists and that Russia allows it. Recruitment efforts are advertised through colorful fliers and banners at rallies in Moscow and on the internet, calling on Russians to "Join Strelkov's Army," referring to Igor Strelkov, a former Russian security officer who heads the insurgency's militia.

The recruiting comes as the Ukrainian military intensifies its campaign against the pro-Russian insurgents and is closing in on the largest rebel stronghold of Donetsk in eastern Ukraine. At the same time, Russia has amassed about 20,000 combat-ready troops on Ukraine's eastern border, according to NATO.

Detailed instructions about the recruitment office appeared on Russia's VKontakte social network in June on the page of the Donbass People's Militia. Some Russian websites reported having recruitment posts as early as May. The VKontakte page included a phone number and email address for the militia, but phone calls went unanswered.

Artur Gasparyan, a volunteer fighter from Armenia, told Russia's Radio Svoboda that after his second attempt to contact the VKontakte group, several unidentified men scheduled a meeting with him and ten other recruits in Moscow before he was sent to fight in eastern Ukraine.

Ukraine and the West accuse Russia of arming the insurgents who seized government buildings in the cities of Donetsk in April, proclaimed independence from Kiev, and pledged closer ties to Russia. Kiev then launched its offensive against the insurgents. According to the United Nations, about 1,000 people, including hundreds of civilians, have been killed in the clashes.

The U.S. and others say that weapons are continuing to cross from Russia into Ukraine—possibly including surface-to-air missiles that may have downed a Malaysia Airlines jetliner last month, killing all 298 on board. Russia maintains it is not arming the rebels.

Support for the insurgency is widespread in Russia, where a majority of the population views the rebels as fighting a pro-Western regime they think is hostile to Russian-speaking people who live in Ukraine.

"If weapons and aid are going into eastern Ukraine, then that cannot be happening without the approval of the Kremlin," said Alexander Konovalov, president of the Moscow-based Institute of Strategic Assessments. "Several different factions of the Kremlin might have their own policies, but one man approves this," he said, referring to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Amid that support, public efforts to gather aid are widespread—whether for volunteers, supplies, or money. A flier from Strelkov's militia requesting "humanitarian aid" listed a variety of combat gear, such as army boots, optical sights for AK-47s, night-vision glasses, and camouflage. The equipment is being gathered by a group called the Foundation for Aid to Novorossiya and Donbass.

During a Moscow rally last week, the group filled a 5-ton truck with food, clothes, and military equipment. Among the donated items was a generator for an armored personnel carrier, the foundation said.

"Ordinary people will get this aid. Of course, some of this is for the militiamen. It will go straight to the leadership of the Donetsk People's Republic," said Sergei Zakharov, a resident of Kramatorsk, Ukraine, who was in Moscow to help the foundation, as men loaded boxes into the truck.

The group said it raised 6.2 million rubles (about $177,500) in just over a month between June and July.

Title: CNN Anchor's Laughter Sparks Controversy, Bolsters Trump's Support Base

Article:

A video of CNN news anchor Don Lemon laughing hysterically during a segment that mocked President Donald Trump's supporters went viral this week, sparking controversy and raising questions about the impact on the 2020 presidential election.

In the video, which was clipped from a live broadcast that aired on Saturday night, Lemon can be seen laughing and at one point slamming his head on his desk. The laughter ensued after ex-GOP strategist Rick Wilson joked that Trump would be too stupid to find Ukraine on a map, followed by calling Trump's supporters the "credulous boomer rube demo."

CNN contributor Wajahat Ali then joined in, saying, "You elitists with your geography and your maps—and your spelling!" Wilson added, "Your math and your reading! Your lines on the map!"

By Tuesday night, Lemon addressed the controversy on his show, stating, "Ask anyone who knows me, they'll tell you—I don't believe in belittling people, belittling anyone for who they are, what they believe." He continued, "During an interview on Saturday night, one of my guests said something that made me laugh. And while in the moment, I found that joke humorous. And I didn't catch everything that was said."

However, it appears that Lemon's defense—that he didn't catch everything the panelists were saying—is questionable. Lemon laughed consistently during and after the jokes, indicating that his laughter was a response to the jokes themselves.

Lemon's behavior has been criticized for reinforcing negative stereotypes and potentially alienating Trump supporters, who may view the mockery as a confirmation of their shared opposition to the mainstream media and liberal elites. The incident has also been compared to Hillary Clinton's "deplorables" comment, which, rather than turning people away from Trump, further solidified his supporters' loyalty.

The use of stereotypical Southern accents by the panelists during the segment could also have negative consequences for CNN, as it may turn off voters in rural areas who are undecided politically. Trump can point to this segment as evidence of his claim that his opponents don't respect his supporters or rural Americans.

Furthermore, the clip provides ammunition for Trump's claim that CNN is "Fake News." The laughter and stereotypical accents in the clip make it easier for Trump to tell his supporters that all news coming from CNN is biased, and therefore not reliable. It makes it more likely that they will blindly believe Trump, who hasn't insulted them, and less likely that they will believe that anyone affiliated with CNN could ever have a legitimate criticism.

Lemon, who has not apologized for his behavior, did not respond to requests for comment.

Title: The Dangers of Certitude in Climate Change Discourse

Article:

In a reflection on his career as an environmental reporter, Andrew Revkin noted a growing disparity between the scientific understanding of global warming and the claims made by climate change advocates. While the increase in global temperature since 1880, by 0.85 degrees Celsius or approximately 1.5 degrees Fahrenheit, is indisputable, the science behind many other accepted facts is a matter of probabilities. This is particularly true of the complex and fallible models and simulations used by scientists to predict future climate scenarios.

Revkin's observations serve as a reminder that hyperbole about climate change, while it may not have been accurate at the time, could potentially be counterproductive if the aim is to engage a distracted public. Instead of asserting total certainty about the science, acknowledging its limitations and uncertainties is a more honest approach.

Claiming absolute certainty about the science can undermine the spirit of science, creating doubts whenever a climate claim proves incorrect. Demanding immediate and costly changes in public policy raises questions about the ideological intentions behind such demands. Making moral judgments and treating skeptics as unintelligent or despicable does not win over many supporters.

This article is not intended to deny climate change or its potential severity. However, it is important to recognize the public's right to be skeptical of an overbearing scientism. History has shown that scientific errors combined with political power can lead to human wreckage.

The epigraph for this column is borrowed from the Polish poet Czeslaw Milosz, who understood the dangers of certitude. Perhaps if there had been less certitude and more questioning in Hillary Clinton's campaign, she would be the current president. Perhaps if there were less certitude about our climate future, more Americans would be interested in having a reasoned conversation about it.

Title: Media Coverage of Tara Reade's Allegations Against Joe Biden Lags Compared to Other High-Profile Cases

Article:

The ascent of former Vice President Joe Biden to the presumptive Democratic nominee for president has been marked by numerous challenges, including allegations of sexual assault made by Tara Reade, a former staffer who worked for Biden in the early 1990s. Reade alleges that Biden sexually assaulted her and was subsequently retaliated against professionally for complaining to his staff.

However, the media coverage of Reade's allegations has been noticeably muted compared to the extensive coverage given to similar allegations against other high-profile political figures, such as Brett Kavanaugh, Donald Trump, and Al Franken. This discrepancy in coverage has sparked debate and concern among journalists, editors, and commentators.

One possible explanation for the lack of interest in this story from Democrats and many in the media is the influence of politics and bias. The deafening silence about Tara Reade on MSNBC, for example, is difficult to account for with any other explanation. Headlines in mainstream outlets like The Washington Post, such as "Developments in allegations against Biden amplify efforts to question his behavior," contort to avoid injuring Biden.

Another plausible reason for the muted coverage is the COVID-19 pandemic, which has taken up nearly all of the media's attention. As Washington Free Beacon Editor Matt Continetti told Fox's Brett Baier, "I'm worried that this is one area that Joe Biden may be being shielded by coronavirus. As long as the attention of the nation is on the pandemic, I think he may be able to skirt some of these questions for a little while longer."

Despite the allegations, Biden has yet to directly address them. After releasing a statement denying the allegations, Biden held a virtual town hall on Tuesday, focusing on the pandemic's impact on women. In the town hall, Biden boasted of his endorsement from Hillary Clinton and ignored the allegations entirely. There were no questions about Reade.

The campaign has circulated talking points to top Democratic supporters, instructing them to say of the allegations, "this did not happen." The lack of engagement with the allegations benefits no one, least of all Biden himself.

Political dangers and credibility concerns are at the forefront of this issue. If voters find Reade's allegations credible and Biden consequently loses support, there is little the party can do after he is officially their nominee. Credibility concerns also extend to Biden, Democrats, the media, and Biden's Democratic women supporters.

Huffington Post asked nine potential vice-presidential picks about the allegations, and only one—Stacey Abrams—responded. After defending Biden's character, she went on CNN, where Don Lemon asked her directly about the allegations. Abrams dutifully repeated the Biden talking point: "I know Joe Biden and I think that he is telling the truth, and that this did not happen."

In the #MeToo era, this is a precarious position for a progressive Democrat to take. The silence or support from prominent Democratic women, such as Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Hillary Clinton, Elizabeth Warren, Kamala Harris, Tulsi Gabbard, Amy Klobuchar, Kirsten Gillibrand, Michelle Obama, and others, risks their own credibility with women.

It is possible that Biden's assumption that voters' antipathy for Trump will supersede any qualms they may have with his behavior regarding Reade or any of the other women who have complained about unwanted touching is correct. Plenty chose not to care about the multiple allegations against Trump in 2016.

However, that is even more reason for Biden, Democrats, and the media to address the allegation fully and head-on, allowing voters to decide what to believe. This story is unlikely to go away, and pretending it isn't real is ignoring a ticking time bomb.

Title: Judge Blocks Trump Administration's Birth Control Rules Nationwide

Article:

Pennsylvania Eastern District Judge Wendy Beetlestone has issued a nationwide injunction, halting the Trump administration's birth control rules from taking effect across the United States. The ruling stems from concerns that states could be impacted by fallout associated with residents losing contraceptive coverage.

In a statement, HHS spokeswoman Caitlin Oakley said the rules "affirm the Trump Administration's commitment to upholding the freedoms afforded all Americans under our Constitution."

As of Monday, employers in 37 states are no longer mandated by law to provide birth control coverage for their workers, due to new rules implemented by the Trump administration. The guidelines will not go into effect in 13 other states and the District of Columbia, following a judge's decision in Oakland, California, that blocked the rules' implementation hours before they were set to take effect.

Under the Affordable Care Act, employers were required to offer birth control coverage to their employees at no additional cost. Religious organizations that objected were previously exempt from providing coverage, but the Trump administration broadened the provisions to exempt any employers with either religious or "moral convictions" that would preclude them from offering birth control coverage.

The state of California sued to prevent the rules from going into effect. On Sunday, Judge Haywood Gilliam granted an injunction to those states that joined California's suit, but he declined to block the rules nationwide.

Gilliam acknowledged that the ruling meant women in states not covered by the injunction could lose birth control coverage, but said the "high threshold" needed to implement a nationwide injunction wasn't met.

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra hailed the decision in a statement Sunday. "The law couldn't be more clear — employers have no business interfering in women's health care decisions," Becerra said. "Today's court ruling stops another attempt by the Trump Administration to trample on women's access to basic reproductive care. It's 2019, yet the Trump Administration is still trying to roll back women's rights. Our coalition will continue to fight to ensure women have access to the reproductive healthcare they are guaranteed under the law."

Courts previously blocked a similar rule the Trump administration attempted to implement back in 2017.

Title: Rent Collection Concerns Mount as Economic Struggles Persist for Renters and Landlords

Article:

The economic fallout from the ongoing pandemic is causing growing concerns among apartment landlords that an increasing number of tenants may struggle to make their rent payments, even after most managed to pay for April. John Pawlowski, a senior analyst at real estate research firm Green Street Advisors, stated, "May 1 will be a bigger watershed. Think about when the job losses started accelerating."

According to the National Multifamily Housing Council (NMHC), a trade group for the apartment industry, only 69% of renters had made a full or partial payment during the first week of April. By April 26, the figure had climbed to nearly 92%. While dire predictions for April were mostly inaccurate, few see the pressure abating on renters or property owners.

Loan forbearance, expanded unemployment benefits, and other government programs aimed at softening the blow will only go so far. The industry, which includes small, individual owners with a few properties to large companies with national portfolios, faces a potential cascading damage. Mortgages, utilities, and property taxes still have to be paid regardless of whether rent is collected.

Large apartment landlords, including Equity Residential and Camden Property Trust, have reported strong collections, leading analysts to predict they'll fare better than smaller owners. However, many factors will influence if or when people are able to make rent in May, from the timing of job losses to whether tenants have received stimulus checks or state unemployment benefits.

Even assistance won't be enough in high-cost areas, like New York and California, according to Doug Bibby, NMHC's president. "We're nervous," said Bibby. "The only mitigating factors are the direct payments to households, individuals, and children, and the unemployment checks that are coming in -- and those are coming in sporadically."

Daryl Carter, the CEO of landlord Avanath Capital Management, anticipated that renters at his company's roughly 10,000 units from California to Florida would struggle in April and gave them a 10% discount. Despite this, he prepared to process as many as a thousand requests to modify rent. In the end, fewer than 50 residents asked for relief. He's bracing for next month to be different.

Some renters are already behind. Chris Davis, 31, used his tax refund to help pay bills in March. Then, late last month, he had to self-quarantine after his daughter got sick. Missing more than two weeks of work meant he couldn't make the $785 April rent payment for his family's two-bedroom apartment in North East, Maryland. He's been back working at a truck wash for more than a week, but catching up will be tough, let alone making a payment for May.

Other renters aren't able to apply for government benefits. A Brooklyn woman, who asked that her name not be used because of her immigration status, recently lost work as a home health aide. Because she's undocumented, she's unable to collect unemployment and is worried that she'll run through her modest savings trying to pay the $1,700 rent on her family's one-and-a-half-bedroom apartment. She plans to withhold her rent this coming month, joining a rent strike to pressure Governor Andrew Cuomo into forgiving monthly payments during the pandemic.

For Bruce Brunner, a small landlord in Minneapolis, there's a less adversarial route: working with renters on a case-by-case basis to find a solution everyone can afford. In recent weeks, he said nearly all his tenants have been able to pay because they still have jobs or were able to collect unemployment. Still, he's been flexible, working with renters to split the shortfall when necessary. "None of this is brain surgery," Brunner said. "We're just everyday people helping each other out."

Title: Attorney General Barr Asks President Trump to Stop Tweeting About DOJ Matters

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has asked President Donald Trump to stop tweeting about Department of Justice (DOJ) matters, stating that the president's comments make it "impossible" for him to do his job as the head of federal law enforcement.

In an interview with ABC News, scheduled to air Thursday evening, Barr expressed his desire for Trump to "stop tweeting." The president's comments, particularly regarding the case of his advisor Roger Stone, have been corrosive to the image of the Justice Department, which has a tradition of independence, according to Barr.

Barr clarified that Trump has never asked him to intervene in a criminal case, but the attorney general added that Trump's comments surrounding the Stone matter have been detrimental to the department's reputation.

"As I said at my confirmation hearing, I think the essential role of the attorney general is to keep law enforcement, the criminal process sacrosanct, to make sure there is no political interference in it," Barr said in the material released by ABC.

Barr admitted to directing the submission of a second memo in Stone's case recommending a lighter punishment. The initial sentencing recommendation for Stone, who was convicted by a jury last year in a case stemming from the Russia investigation, was seven to nine years in prison.

Trump criticized the recommendation on Twitter, and the same day, a senior Justice Department official told NPR that leaders at the department's headquarters in Washington found the suggested sentence too harsh. The department then directed the U.S. Attorney's Office in Washington, D.C., to submit a second memo seeking less punishment, which it later did.

Four federal prosecutors who had brought the case to that point all withdrew, according to court records. The senior DOJ official said leaders at headquarters had decided on their own, after seeing the sentencing memo, that they would request a revision.

Barr made clear in the interview with ABC that he made the decision, but the public response following Trump's post on Twitter made it appear that Barr and the department were bowing to the president's desire to protect his friend.

Democrats have demanded an investigation, and Barr has agreed to appear before the House Judiciary Committee for a hearing scheduled for next month. His relationship with the Democratic-controlled House has been strained since a dispute with its chairman, Rep. Jerry Nadler, D-N.Y., prompted Barr to skip a hearing last spring amid a dispute over witnesses and evidence.

This week, Trump praised Barr for "taking charge" of the Stone case, further compounding the perception that the attorney general was taking instructions from Trump. However, Barr, in the excerpted ABC News interview, stated that this is not the case, but the appearance that he is puts him in a difficult position—which is why the attorney general says he wants the president to keep silent.

Title: Republican Party Faces Existential Threat Amidst COVID-19 Crisis

Article:

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic is posing a significant challenge for the United States, with many critics pointing to the lack of preparedness and suitability of President Donald Trump for the job. The petulance, lack of discipline, short attention span, narcissism, lies, and need for public praise and approval that were once considered charming advantages or manageable eccentricities have been exposed as glaring deficiencies in an American president.

The Republican Party, which has heavily supported Trump, is now facing a potential loss not just in the presidency but also in the U.S. Senate in the 2020 elections. According to National Journal's Josh Kraushaar, Democratic candidates have outraised their Republican counterparts in eight out of the ten most competitive Senate races, often by substantial margins.

This development is largely attributed to Trump's handling of the crisis. Despite previous warnings about the possibility of a massive crisis, Republicans have made a risky political calculation by overlooking Trump's character flaws.

In a recent development, Democratic candidate Joe Biden is leading in several traditionally Republican states such as Ohio, Arizona, and Florida. However, it is important to note that elections are still several months away, and outcomes can change.

Critics of Trump, often referred to as Never Trumpers, have long warned about the potential risks of a leader with such character flaws. Despite Trump's acquittal in the Senate and initial political success, his handling of the COVID-19 crisis has led to a renewed focus on his leadership style and its impact on the Republican Party.

The situation recalls a biblical parable comparing a wise builder to a foolish one. The moral is that one should always build their house on a rock, as eventually, the rain comes, the streams rise, and the winds blow. The implication is that no amount of public relations spin can save a house built on sand, a metaphor that some have applied to Trump's presidency.

While it is not appropriate to wish for a deadly virus to serve as a lesson, the hope is that the current crisis will lead to a renewed appreciation for attributes like character, temperament, and experience in future leaders. This could help future Americans to benefit from the lessons being learned now.

Title: Israel Urges U.S. to Maintain Aid to Egypt Amid Political Instability

Article:

Israel has reportedly urged the United States not to suspend its annual $1.3 billion in military and economic aid to Egypt following the ouster of President Mohammed Morsi by the Egyptian military. Under U.S. law, aid must be suspended to any country where the government is overthrown by the military, but the U.S. has yet to determine whether the June 30 removal of Morsi constitutes a coup.

According to the Haaretz newspaper, Israeli leaders engaged in "marathon phone calls" with their U.S. counterparts over the weekend, expressing concerns that a suspension of aid could impact Israel's security and potentially undermine its 1979 peace treaty with Egypt. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reportedly spoke with Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon with Pentagon chief Chuck Hagel, and National Security Adviser Yaakov Amidror with his U.S. counterpart, Susan Rice.

The Israeli leaders warned that cutting military aid to Egypt could negatively impact Israel's security, particularly given the possibility of further security deterioration in the Sinai Peninsula. The peninsula, which borders Israel and the Hamas-run Gaza Strip, has seen a rise in Islamist militancy since the overthrow of former president Hosni Mubarak in February 2011, leading to increased attacks on both Israel and Egypt's own forces stationed there.

Israel fears any change in U.S. policy could undermine the Egyptian army's commitment to the 1979 treaty, as U.S. aid to Egypt, which began as a result of the treaty, has continued uninterrupted since 1979. The Israeli government has not confirmed or denied the report.

Since Morsi's ouster, Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu has ordered his ministers to remain silent on the unfolding political crisis in Egypt. A senior official in Netanyahu's office stated that Egypt is likely to experience "a period of chronic instability," and that the Muslim Brotherhood, to which Morsi belongs, is unlikely to easily give up power, potentially leading to more violence and changes in leadership.

Last week, the Israeli army confirmed it had "authorized" the deployment of Egyptian military reinforcements in the Sinai Peninsula to address security threats that pose a threat to both Israel and Egypt. The 1979 treaty imposes strict controls on the numbers of troops permitted to operate there. Israeli public radio also reported on Israel's efforts to dissuade Washington from halting aid to Cairo.

Title: New CNN/ORC Poll: Hillary Clinton Leads Democratic Race, No Clear Leader in Republican Race

Article:

In the ongoing race for the 2016 presidential nominations, a new CNN/ORC poll indicates that the Democratic contest is solidifying around Hillary Clinton, while the Republican race remains undecided.

On the Democratic side, Clinton dominates with a significant lead, while the Republican race has seen some stirring with the recent entries of Marco Rubio, Rand Paul, and Ted Cruz. However, no clear leader has emerged in the Republican race.

In the latest poll, Jeb Bush holds the top spot among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, with 17% of the vote. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker follows closely behind with 12% of the vote. Rubio and Paul stand at 11% each, with former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee at 9% and Texas Senator Ted Cruz at 7%. Former neurosurgeon Ben Carson and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, who were previously strong contenders, are now behind the leader with 4% each.

Bush's lead in the nomination contest is slight, and several contenders could overtake him with a small increase in support. Bush is most often named as the candidate with the right experience to be president (27%), the one with the best chance of beating the Democratic nominee in the general election next November (26%), and as the strongest leader in the large field of GOP contenders (21%). He is also more often seen as the candidate with the clearest vision for the country's future (19%), who cares the most about people like you (18%), and who most closely shares your values (19%).

On the question of who best represents the future of the Republican Party, Bush and Rubio are in a close race, with 18% and 18% respectively. Paul is the only other candidate in double digits on this question, with 10%.

The poll suggests that while Bush currently holds the lead in the Republican race, there is room for other candidates to gain ground, particularly Rubio, who is seen as a strong representative of the future of the Republican Party. The Democratic race, on the other hand, appears to be more solidified around Clinton.

Title: Economic Decline and Government Shutdown in the United States

Article:

The quality of life in the United States has reportedly seen a significant decline in recent years, often attributed to the Age of Obama. This perceived decline has allegedly eroded the American dream, strained the economy, and made job creation more challenging.

President Obama's administration has been criticized for dividing the nation through class warfare tactics and for failing to deliver on promises of creating good-paying, full-time jobs. The ongoing debate over the government shutdown has overshadowed these economic concerns, with the Affordable Health Care Act (Obamacare) being a major point of contention.

Critics argue that Obamacare imposes numerous regulations, taxes, and costly provisions on the economy and businesses, which could potentially lead to job losses. Small businesses are reportedly laying off workers or reducing their hours to avoid providing health insurance due to the full-time employee threshold.

The economic impact of Obamacare, as well as other troublesome economic repercussions, has been largely overshadowed by the government shutdown discussion. The shutdown has resulted in furloughs for workers, closed national parks, and affected food-safety inspections, among other issues.

In an attempt to spark a debate over Obamacare and potentially delay its implementation, House Republicans withheld a "clean" continuing resolution to fund the government. However, this strategy has not led to the desired debate or delay in Obamacare's implementation. Instead, the political focus remains on the government shutdown.

As the shutdown continues, the economy, high unemployment, slow job creation, and weak economic growth have been largely overshadowed in the public discourse. The White House, in response to the shutdown, has called on top Wall Street leaders to warn of a potential economic catastrophe if the debt limit is not raised by October 17.
