Republicans have been criticized for their response to the shutdown, with some arguing that they are not effectively communicating the negative economic impact of Obamacare. The late Jack Kemp, a former Republican politician and economist, was known for his successful arguments for tax cuts to promote stronger job growth. Republicans are urged to adopt similar strategies to criticize President Obama's economic record and the potential negative effects of Obamacare on the economy.

A Washington Post-Miller Center Poll from late September revealed that a large majority of Americans have a more pessimistic view of their economic future. The poll found that 75% of respondents found it harder to "find good jobs," 71% found it harder to "save for retirement," 66% found it harder to "get ahead financially," and 54% found it harder to "find decent, affordable housing."

It is suggested that Republicans should take a more aggressive approach in their criticism of the Obama administration's economic record and the potential negative effects of Obamacare on the economy.

Title: June 2015 Breaks Record as Hottest June on Record Globally

Article:

Federal scientists announced on Monday that June 2015 was the hottest June on record for the planet, marking the third consecutive record-warm month globally this year. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) National Centers for Environmental Information reported that the globally averaged temperature over land and ocean surfaces for June 2015 was the highest for the month of June since record-keeping began in 1880.

The record warmth was seen in June in the western U.S., parts of northern South America, several regions in central to western Africa, central Asia, and parts of southeastern Asia, according to the centers. June 2015 broke the previous record for warmest June, set just last year, according to NOAA's data.

Earlier this year, both March and May set marks for record warmth. The U.S., overall, had its second-warmest June on record, the centers announced last week. Only June 1933 was hotter. Five western states—California, Oregon, Washington, Idaho, and Utah—were all record warm.

The hot June continues the pattern of unusual warmth seen throughout the year. So far, the first six months of the year have been the warmest on record, due in part to El Niño, a climate pattern marked by warmer-than-average water in the tropical Pacific Ocean. The heat from the warm water helps boost temperatures in the atmosphere around the world.

While El Niño is a part of the warmth, the long-term trend of man-made climate change is also a contributor. NOAA reports that 14 of the 15 warmest years on record have occurred since 2000, many during years without the boost of an El Niño.

January-June was 1.53 degrees F warmer than average worldwide, NOAA said.

Title: Trump Warns of Traffic and Commercial Delays at U.S.-Mexico Border Due to Increased Immigration Enforcement

Article:

President Donald Trump issued a warning on Saturday about potential traffic and commercial delays at the U.S.-Mexico border due to increased immigration enforcement. The president's statement came after the administration's decision earlier in the week to increase the number of immigration officers processing Central American migrants attempting to enter the U.S. through Mexico.

In a series of tweets, President Trump stated, "We have redeployed 750 agents at the Southern Border's specific Ports of Entry to help with the large scale surge of illegal migrants trying to make their way into the United States." He continued, "This will cause traffic & commercial delays until such time as Mexico is able to use... its powerful common sense Immigration Laws to stop illegals from coming through Mexico into the U.S., and removing them back to their country of origin."

The president also urged congressional Democrats to collaborate with Republican lawmakers to address the "horrible, costly and foolish loopholes" in U.S. immigration statutes. He tweeted, "Once that happens, all will be smooth." The president concluded, "We can NEVER allow Open Borders!"

On Monday, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen directed Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Kevin McAleenan to expedite the "temporary reassignment of personnel and resources from across the agency to address the influx of migrants." Additionally, plans were announced to require that greater numbers of non-Mexican asylum-seekers stay in Mexico while their cases are resolved.

President Trump had earlier threatened to shut down the southern border, but on Thursday, he stated that he would first impose auto tariffs on Mexico in an attempt to reduce the rate of illegal drugs entering the U.S. "Before we close the border, we'll put the tariffs on the cars," the president told reporters in the Oval Office. "I don't think we'll ever have to close the border."

Title: John Dowd Calls for End to Russia Probe, Cites Corruption Allegations

Article:

John Dowd, personal attorney to President Donald Trump, has called for the Russia investigation led by special counsel Robert Mueller to be terminated. In an email to Betsy Woodruff at the Daily Beast on Saturday, Dowd expressed hope that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein would follow the "brilliant and courageous example" set by Attorney General Jeff Sessions in firing FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe on Friday.

Dowd initially stated he was speaking on behalf of the president, in his capacity as the president's attorney. However, he later clarified that he was speaking in his personal capacity and not on the president's behalf. The email was in response to a request for comment about McCabe's firing.

Dowd's email included the text of the president's late Friday tweet on the subject, celebrating the ouster as a "great day for Democracy." He also urged Rosenstein to follow Sessions' example and dismiss Mueller, citing an alleged Russia collusion investigation based on a "fraudulent and corrupt Dossier."

Sessions' recusal from matters related to the 2016 campaign means Rosenstein is overseeing Mueller's probe and is the one with the ability to fire the special counsel. Dowd also quoted a line from the Tennessee Williams play, "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," to emphasize his point, stating, "There ain't nothin' more powerful than the odor of mendacity... You can smell it. It smells like death."

Trump has been hinting at publicly calling for Mueller's dismissal, but has not done so explicitly. The president has publicly and privately expressed anger at Sessions over his recusal from the case of Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, and has engaged in a sustained attack against Sessions, the FBI, and the Justice Department. Trump told NBC News he fired FBI Director James Comey, in part, because of the Russia probe, which he described as a "made up story." The New York Times reported in January that Trump attempted to order Mueller be fired last June but backed down after White House counsel Don McGahn threatened to resign over the matter.

Senate Intelligence Committee Vice Chair Mark Warner (D-VA) tweeted on Saturday, "Every member of Congress, Republican and Democrat, needs to speak up in defense of the Special Counsel. Now." House Intelligence Committee Ranking Member Adam Schiff (D-CA) tweeted that "every representative should condemn this flagrant abuse of power or stop pretending devotion to duty." Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) stated in January that if Trump were to fire Mueller, it would be "the end of President Trump's presidency."

Dowd's email was sent just two days after a New York Times report that Mueller has subpoenaed documents from the Trump Organization, including some related to Russia.

Title: Senator ███ Calls for Caution in Egypt Aid Amid Ongoing Unrest

Article:

In the midst of the escalating crisis in Egypt, Senator ███, a Kentucky Republican, has expressed support for the delay in the delivery of F-16 fighter jets and the cancellation of scheduled joint military exercises. This decision comes as members of Congress reconsider the provision of military aid to Egypt.

Senator ███ introduced an amendment last month aimed at halting aid to Egypt during the current period of unrest. The amendment was based on two primary reasons:

1. The U.S. law stipulates that aid should be suspended following a coup. Given the conventional definition of a coup, the events in Egypt meet this criteria.
2. A nation in the midst of a violent civil war should not be armed with American-supplied weapons. Previously provided F-16s to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak were used against protesters who eventually overthrew his regime. These protesters were part of the forces that would later elect President Mohammed Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood.

The current regime has since been overthrown, but the American weapons remain. The question of who will use them now, and the potential consequences for U.S.-Egyptian relations, is a concern for Senator ███.

Senator ███ argues that sending $1.5 billion in aid is unnecessary when there are no clear good or bad actors and when there is no clear American national interest. As more in both parties reconsider intervention in Egypt, Senator ███ questions whether the situation has to become so violent before politicians reassess U.S. policies or deviate from Washington groupthink.

When Senator ███'s amendment to stop Egyptian aid failed three weeks ago, some in the press characterized this as a rebuke. A more accurate understanding would be that Congress is out of step with the people, as more than 80% of Americans—and Egyptians—oppose further military aid.

In recent days, news sources have shown images of unarmed protesters attempting to stop tanks (American tanks operated by the Egyptian military) and an unarmed man being shot while trying to halt a tank. Sending more American tanks is not engagement, and providing more fighter jets does not benefit the Egyptian people, according to Senator ███.

Senator ███ criticizes the hyper-interventionism in Washington, where leaders in both parties seem to act first and think second. They insist on sending Egypt billions in aid because, as Senator ███ puts it, "it's what we've always done."

Senator ███ serves on the Senate Foreign Relations and Homeland Security committees. The question remains whether the current shift in sentiment towards ending aid is merely rhetoric or whether Senator ███'s new "allies" will actually vote to end aid.

Title: President Trump Delivers Remarks at National Prayer Breakfast Following Acquittal

Article:

President Donald Trump delivered remarks at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday, a day after his Senate acquittal in his impeachment trial. The event's theme was "love your enemies."

During his speech, President Trump took veiled shots at House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Mitt Romney, who voted to convict him in the impeachment trial. He criticized individuals who use their faith as justification for doing what they know is wrong and those who claim to pray for others but do not genuinely mean it.

The president's comments appeared to be in reference to Speaker Pelosi, who had previously stated that she had prayed for President Trump during the impeachment inquiry. They also seemed to be directed at Senator Romney, the lone Republican senator to vote to convict President Trump.

President Trump expressed his gratitude to Republican lawmakers who voted against impeachment, praising their courage, wisdom, fortitude, and strength. He also reiterated his support for freedom of religion, pro-life policies, and prayer in schools.

The president held up front-page newspaper headlines proclaiming his acquittal when he entered the ballroom for the breakfast at the Washington Hilton to applause. Speaker Pelosi was seated on the opposite side of the dais and did not acknowledge the president during her prayer, in their first encounter since she ripped up a copy of his State of the Union address on Tuesday night.

In her prayer, Speaker Pelosi asked for prayers for those persecuted across the globe, including journalists in Saudi Arabia, and expressed a hope that "we treat everyone with dignity and respect."

Representative John Moolenaar, Michigan Republican and one of the hosts of the breakfast, told the president, "We want this to be a blessing for you. We want to let you know there are people from all over the world here who have been praying for you."

Title: Trump Objects to Proposed U.S. Restrictions on Jet Engine Sales to China

Article:

President Donald Trump objected to U.S. proposals that would prevent companies from supplying jet engines and other components to China's aviation industry on Tuesday, stating he had instructed his administration not to implement them. In a series of tweets and comments to reporters, Trump expressed concerns that national security should not be used as an excuse to make it difficult for foreign countries to buy U.S. products.

The president's comments came after reports over the weekend by various news media, including Reuters, that the government was considering whether to stop General Electric Co (GE.N) from further supplying engines for a new Chinese passenger jet. Trump's views on the issue contrasted with the sharp restrictions his administration has placed on U.S. companies trading with Huawei Technologies, the world's largest telecommunications equipment maker, also for national security reasons.

Trump told reporters at Joint Base Andrews before departing for a trip to California, "We're not going to be sacrificing our companies... by using a fake term of national security. It's got to be real national security. And I think people were getting carried away with it."

The United States has supported American companies' business with China's aviation sector for years. "I want China to buy our jet engines, the best in the World," Trump wrote on Twitter. "I want to make it EASY to do business with the United States, not difficult."

Trade lawyer Doug Jacobson said limitations on jet engines and chip makers would hurt U.S. companies. "This is ultimately akin to cutting off your nose to spite your face because ultimately you're hurting U.S. manufacturing companies but you're not having a material impact on your target," he said.

The United States and China, the world's two largest economies, have a complicated and competitive relationship. Trump signed a first-phase trade deal with China earlier this year after a long trade war in which the countries levied significant tariffs on each other's products, many of which remain in place.

Washington is also eyeing limits on other components for Chinese commercial aircraft such as flight control systems made by Honeywell International Inc (HON.N). Central to the possible crackdown is whether shipments of U.S. parts to China's aircraft industry could fuel the rise of a serious competitor to U.S.-based Boeing Co (BA.N) or boost China's military capabilities.

The Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) said it welcomed Trump's comments. "We applaud President Trump's tweets supporting U.S. companies being able to sell products to China and opposing proposed regulations that would unduly curtail that ability," said John Neuffer, the group's president, in a statement. "As we have discussed with the administration, sales of non-sensitive, commercial products to China drive semiconductor research and innovation, which is critical to America's economic strength and national security."

Huawei is at the heart of a battle for global technological dominance between the United States and China. Washington placed Huawei on a blacklist in May last year, citing national security concerns. The United States has also been trying to persuade allies to exclude its gear from next-generation 5G networks on grounds its equipment could be used by China for spying. Huawei has repeatedly denied the claim.

"So, national security is very important. I've been very tough on Huawei, but that doesn't mean we have to be tough on everybody that does something," Trump said.

Title: Fact-Checking Nathan Phillips' Account of Washington Incident: New York Times and Washington Post Correct Phillips' Claim of Vietnam Veteran Status, Contradict His Account of Events

Article:

Following the discrediting of Nathan Phillips' account of his confrontation with a group of students in Washington, many on the left continue to support him, despite numerous corrections and clarifications from major news outlets such as the New York Times and the Washington Post.

Phillips, who initially claimed to be a Vietnam or "Vietnam-era" veteran, has been revealed to be a stateside refrigerator technician who was frequently absent without leave (AWOL). Furthermore, it has come to light that Phillips made similar allegations against a few college students four years ago.

Initially, a single video of the incident on Twitter led many journalists to uncritically accept Phillips' account of the confrontation, as the image appeared to reinforce preconceived notions: an elderly Native American surrounded by a group of smirking pro-Trump teenagers wearing MAGA hats. However, full videos of the incident soon showed that Phillips was the one who approached the students unprovoked, beating a drum just inches from their faces.

Contrary to Phillips' claims, the Covington school students were being taunted with racist and homophobic slurs by a group of Black Hebrew Israelites. Despite this, Phillips alleged that the students were "in the process of attacking these four black individuals" and "looked like they were going to lynch them," prompting his intervention. It is unclear why Phillips did not beat his drum at the "Israelite" aggressors.

The video also contradicts Phillips' account in several other ways. For instance, there is no evidence that the students were defiantly chanting "Build that wall," and Phillips' statements do not appear to be an attempt to pacify the situation.

Despite the contradictions in his account, Phillips continues to have supporters, as he has crafted new narratives that appeal to left-liberal prejudice. In an interview with CNN, Phillips stated, "Time for lies to be not accepted anymore."

Title: Novel Fundraising Tactics Emerge in U.S. Political Campaigns

Article:

In the realm of campaign fundraising, creativity and unconventional methods have become the norm as candidates strive to stand out in a media-saturated environment and raise record amounts of cash.

President Barack Obama's campaign has ventured into unique territory by suggesting that wedding registries include the campaign, and merchandising Vice President Joe Biden's gaffes, such as a "Health Reform Still a BFD" t-shirt. The Obama campaign has also capitalized on donations for President Obama's dog, Bo, with the proceeds benefiting his master.

Congressional candidate Pam Gulleson, from North Dakota, attempted to turn a minor setback into fundraising gold when her campaign vehicle broke down on the trail in late June. She solicited donations for the repairs through an email to supporters, stating that 80 donations of $25 would cover the costs. The effectiveness of this fundraiser is uncertain, as the Gulleson campaign declined to comment on the matter.

Gimmicky raffles, offering access to candidates at dinners or sporting events, or face time with Hollywood celebrities, are also becoming common fundraising practices. Traditional fundraising events, such as rubber chicken lunches and after-work receptions, are not obsolete but are increasingly overshadowed by the need for seven-figure fundraising to remain competitive in even the most low-key congressional races.

The 2012 election is expected to be the most expensive in U.S. history, with the Center for Responsive Politics estimating a cost of at least $5.8 billion. Novel fundraisers also coincide with a surge of new donation options this cycle, such as text message, Twitter, and mobile credit card readers, making political contributions more accessible than ever.

Campaigns are eager to connect with younger voters, said Kristin Oblander, president of Atlanta-based political fundraising firm The Oblander Group. "They work because you literally get buy-in with young professionals in particular who will stay on your email lists, like you on Facebook, connect on Twitter," she said. "You just can't have the same old 100 folks in a smoky back room anymore."

Comparing the current fundraising landscape to the mid-1980s, Rep. Bart Gordon (D-Tenn.) noted that his campaign's cash solicitations via direct mail seemed revolutionary at the time. "I'd have balloon rides and parachute jumping," said Gordon, now a partner at law and lobbying firm K & L Gates, without a hint of sarcasm. "Candidates just have to find more and more novel ways to break through the clutter of so many fundraisers."

Title: EPA Chief Lisa Jackson Resigns Amidst Speculation of Keystone XL Pipeline Approval

Article:

The resignation of Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) chief Lisa Jackson last week has sparked speculation that the Obama administration may soon approve the controversial Keystone XL pipeline. According to a report by the New York Post, citing a source close to Jackson, the EPA chief resigned because she believed President Obama was planning to approve the pipeline project.

The source stated that Jackson, who was initially planning to stay in her position until November or December, decided to resign due to her opposition to the pipeline's approval. Jackson's spokeswoman, Victoria Rivas-Vazquez, referred back to Jackson's original statement that she wanted to "pursue new challenges, time with her family, and new opportunities."

The Keystone XL pipeline, a proposed oil pipeline that would transport crude oil from Alberta, Canada, to the Gulf Coast of the United States, has been a contentious issue for several years. The project has faced opposition from environmental groups due to concerns about its potential impact on the environment, particularly the risk of oil spills.

However, the pipeline is considered to be the safest and most efficient way of transporting oil sands, and the oil is likely to be extracted regardless of whether the pipeline is built in the United States or in China. The State Department's review of the pipeline is still ongoing, but there have been indications that the project is moving closer to approval.

It is unclear whether Jackson's resignation is directly related to the Keystone XL pipeline or if it is one of several factors that led to her decision to step down. Jackson's use of an extracurricular email account has been a subject of controversy in the past, and it is possible that this may have played a role in her decision to resign.

The Keystone XL pipeline has been a contentious issue for several years, and its approval or rejection is likely to have significant implications for the United States' energy policy and its relationship with Canada. The pipeline's potential economic benefits, including job creation and increased energy security, have been a major point of emphasis for supporters of the project.

It is unclear when the State Department will make a final decision on the Keystone XL pipeline, but reports suggest that a decision could be made as early as March or April. The resignation of EPA chief Lisa Jackson has added fuel to the speculation that the pipeline's approval is imminent.

Title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Treated for Suicidal Tendencies Before Fatal Crash

 Article:

 The co-pilot of the crashed Germanwings jetliner, Andreas Lubitz, underwent treatment for "suicidal tendencies" before receiving his pilot's license and achieving his dream of flying passenger jets, according to a statement from the public prosecutor's office in Düsseldorf on Monday. The Airbus A320 jet, under Lubitz's control, crashed last week, killing all 150 people onboard. French officials have suggested the crash was intentional.

 Lubitz, 27, had been treated by psychotherapists "over a long period of time," the statement said, without providing specific dates. In subsequent visits to doctors since that time, no signs of suicidal tendencies or aggression toward others were documented, according to the prosecutor.

 Under current German law, which emphasizes privacy, it was up to Lubitz to disclose his history to doctors examining his fitness to fly, according to Roland Quast, medical director of Aeromedical Center Germany in Stuttgart.

 "What is decisive is that the pilot tells the truth," Quast said. "If he lies, we don't have lie detectors."

 The medical history of Lubitz has raised questions over how much leeway medical professionals should have to inform the authorities about patients in positions that could affect public safety. Parliamentary deputies from Germany's governing coalition have called for doctors to break confidentiality when a patient shows suicidal tendencies.

 Karl Lauterbach, a Social Democrat and a medical expert, told the daily newspaper Bild that if lives could be endangered, "the doctor has a duty to inform the employer about the unsuitability of the employee to do his work."

 "That applies especially in the case of psychiatric illness and the possible danger of suicide," Lauterbach said.

 Heinz Joachim Schöttes, a spokesman for Germanwings, said Monday that the airline was aware of the prosecutor's statement about Lubitz but declined to comment.

Title: Congress Ends Government Shutdown and Averts Debt Default

Article:

Congress has ended the first government shutdown in 17 years and averted a default on U.S. debt following a late-night vote on Wednesday. The deal, brokered by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, only sets up further budgetary battles, as government funding will run dry again in January, and the borrowing limit must be lifted in February.

President Barack Obama signed the bill to reopen the government and raise the debt ceiling early Thursday morning. Government workers were instructed to return to work on Thursday. In a statement, the White House said, "Today, the president signed a continuing resolution that brings employees back to work and reopens many government functions."

The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) directed executive departments and agencies to reopen offices in a prompt and orderly manner. The Office of Personnel Management also updated its website overnight to inform federal employees to return to work on their next scheduled day, which was Thursday for most, unless instructed otherwise.

Speaker John Boehner had to rely on House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's Democratic Caucus to carry the bill to passage, violating the Hastert Rule, a mantra that the House speaker should not bring legislation to the floor without the support of a "majority of the majority" of his members.

The Senate passed the bill with 81 senators voting yes, and 18 voting against. The House then moved to clear the legislation 285-144, relying mostly on Democratic votes in the Republican-controlled chamber. The bill was opposed by 144 Republicans, including House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan.

The deal does not alter Obamacare, despite Speaker John Boehner's initial support for his conservative wing's drive to gut Obamacare as part of the government shutdown fight. McConnell and Reid worked overtime for three days to hammer out a bipartisan agreement after a House bill collapsed on Tuesday.

The legislation also includes a McConnell-written proposal that would allow Congress to disapprove of the debt-ceiling increase. Lawmakers will formally vote on rejecting the bump of the borrowing limit - if it passes, it could be vetoed by Obama. The deal would also deliver back pay to furloughed federal workers, require a study of income verification for people seeking health-insurance subsidies under the Affordable Care Act, and allows the Treasury Department to use extraordinary measures to pay the nation's bills if Congress doesn't raise the debt ceiling in a timely fashion.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Order to Strengthen Medicare, Aims to Reduce Regulations and Drug Prices

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday aimed at strengthening the Medicare health program by reducing regulations, curbing fraud, and providing faster access to new medical devices and therapies. The order was announced during a visit to a retirement community in Florida, a critical political swing state.

The executive order is the Republican president's response to some Democrats who are pushing for a broad and expensive expansion of Medicare to cover all Americans. Trump referred to such proposals as socialist and pledged to prevent them from coming to fruition, a political promise with an eye toward his 2020 re-election campaign in which healthcare is likely to be a major issue.

The order pushes for Medicare to use more medical telehealth services, leading to cost reductions by reducing expensive emergency room visits. It also aims to bring payments for the traditional Medicare fee-for-service program in line with payments for Medicare Advantage. The order directs the government to work to allow private insurers that operate Medicare Advantage plans to use new plan pricing methods, such as allowing beneficiaries to share in the savings when they choose lower-cost health services.

Trump's plans contrast with the Medicare for All program promoted by Bernie Sanders, a Democratic socialist who is running to become the Democratic Party's nominee against Trump in the 2020 presidential election. Sanders' proposal, backed by left-leaning Democrats but opposed by moderates such as former Vice President Joe Biden, would create a single-payer system, effectively eliminating private insurance by providing government coverage to everyone, using the Medicare model.

The White House is eager to show Trump making progress on healthcare, an issue Democrats successfully used to garner support and take control of the House of Representatives in the 2018 midterm elections. Trump campaigned in 2016 on a promise to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, his predecessor President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law also known as "Obamacare." So far, he has not repealed or replaced it.

In July, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) said it would propose a rule for imports of cheaper drugs from Canada into the United States. A formal rule has not yet been unveiled. The administration also issued an executive order in June demanding hospitals and insurers make prices they charge patients more transparent. Another executive order was issued in July encouraging novel treatments for kidney disease.

However, a federal judge in July shot down an executive order that would have forced drugmakers to display list prices in advertisements, and Trump scrapped another planned order that would have banned some rebate payments drugmakers make to payers. The administration is also reportedly mulling a plan to tie some Medicare reimbursement rates for drugs to the price paid for those drugs by foreign governments.

Title: Divisions Among Republicans Affect Foreign Policy Stance in 2012 Presidential Election

Article:

The ongoing squabbling among Republicans in Congress has hindered the adoption of legislation this summer aimed at enhancing the nation's technological defenses and protecting infrastructure from digital attacks. This year's Congressional debate over the Law of the Sea Treaty, similar to the 2010 debate over the New Start treaty, which aimed to reduce Russian and American nuclear missile arsenals, reflects deep philosophical divisions within the Republican ranks.

Historically, Republican divisions over foreign policy have been between a realist wing and a more fervent nationalist wing; realism usually prevailed. In the 1950s, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, an internationalist, overcame Senator Robert A. Taft and his isolationist followers. Later, President Richard M. Nixon's engagement with China and President Ronald Reagan's diplomatic outreach to the Soviet Union won out over the skepticism of cold-war conservatives.

After the 9/11 attacks, President George W. Bush ushered in a new level of infighting, from which his party has not recovered. Initially, neoconservatives like Paul D. Wolfowitz pushed a doctrine of preventive war and put it into effect in Iraq. Eventually, more pragmatic conservatives like Condoleezza Rice pulled the president back toward diplomacy.

Over the last four years, Republicans have tried to paper over their divisions. In the 2008 and 2010 elections, foreign policy hardly figured at all. However, the Republican primary contest this year has bared the deep conservative disarray. This time, a new battle, between neoconservatives and neo-isolationists, all but crowded out the party's pragmatic internationalists, like James A. Baker III and Colin L. Powell.

Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, has dealt with these divisions in two ways. He has derided President Barack Obama's handling of foreign policy, notably on Iran and Israel, with overheated rhetoric but only vague hints at alternatives. On the few matters in which Mr. Romney has offered a clearer difference, he has echoed the confrontational approach taken by Dick Cheney, John R. Bolton, and other hard-line conservatives from the Bush years. For example, he called Russia the "No. 1 geopolitical foe" of the United States and said he would designate China a currency manipulator on his first day in office. His call for Republicans to block ratification of the New Start treaty put him at odds with all five living Republican former secretaries of state, including Ms. Rice.

However, a mixture of cheerleading and fire-breathing does not make for a coherent and credible worldview. Now that he's the Republican nominee, Mr. Romney has an obligation to clarify his and his party's positions. It is imperative that he justify his plan to add more than $2 trillion in defense spending over the next 10 years and explain how the plan meshes with his proposals to simultaneously cut taxes, reduce the debt, and strengthen America's economy.

Mr. Romney should also explain what—if anything—he would do differently from President Obama in Egypt, which is perhaps the most important test today of America's support for democratic transitions around the world. He should go beyond clichés to specify how, exactly, he would strengthen military cooperation with Israel—which Israel's own defense minister, Ehud Barak, praised a month ago as "more than anything I can remember in the past."

And he needs to get specific about his tactical approach to Syria, where the United States is already trying to help the Syrian opposition, control which elements of it get foreign military aid, and isolate the murderous regime of President Bashar al-Assad.

Mitt Romney hopes to persuade Americans not only that he can fix the economy but also that he can lead at a time of great uncertainty abroad. To do so, he needs to first unite his party by offering clear alternatives to the president's policies. Vague criticisms of Mr. Obama won't cut it.

Title: U.S. Economy Loses 701,000 Jobs in March, Unemployment Rate Jumps to 4.4%

Article:

The U.S. economy experienced a significant setback in March, with a loss of 701,000 jobs, marking the first decline in payrolls since September 2010 and the steepest since March 2009, during the Great Recession. The unemployment rate rose to 4.4 percent, up from a half-century low of 3.5 percent in February.

The employment report, based on surveys conducted in the early weeks of March, does not fully reflect the depth of the economic calamity inflicted by the coronavirus pandemic. In the final two weeks of the month, 10 million Americans applied for unemployment benefits, a stark indication of the scale of the economic crash.

Restaurants, bars, hotels, airlines, cruise lines, automakers, and entertainment venues have been particularly hard-hit by the pandemic, as a growing number of jurisdictions have ordered the closure of nonessential businesses and directed residents to stay at home.

The U.S. currently has the highest number of confirmed cases of COVID-19, the respiratory illness caused by the novel coronavirus, with over 245,573 people infected, according to Johns Hopkins University data. More than 6,000 people in the country have died from the virus.

Economists' projections for unemployment vary significantly, but they generally agree that it will be severe. An analysis published by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis last week projected that unemployment could reach 32 percent in the second quarter as more than 47 million workers are laid off due to the pandemic. This would surpass the 24.9 percent peak during the Great Depression.

"Much bigger job losses are coming," said Mark Zandi, Moody's chief economist, during a conference call with reporters earlier this week. He estimated that between 10 to 15 million jobs could be lost from the economy as a result of the outbreak, with the worst taking place in April.

Lawmakers are looking to provide relief to laid-off workers with a $2 trillion stimulus package, the largest relief bill in recent memory, which President Trump signed last week. The bill includes up to $1,200 cash checks for adults who earn less than $99,000 annually and expanded unemployment benefits.

Title: CPAC 2013 Reflects Republican Party's Internal Divisions Four Months After Presidential Defeat

Article:

The Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC), which began on Thursday outside Washington, D.C., has become more of a carnival atmosphere than a conservative salon, according to a report by Associated Press (AP). The event, known for its annual gathering of conservative leaders and activists, is reflecting the state of the Republican Party four months after the party's latest presidential defeat.

The report highlights the divisions within the Republican Party, with establishment Republicans expressing frustration over the snubbing of popular GOP governors Chris Christie and Bob McDonnell, while conservatives are displeased with the presence of Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush, who are seen as part of the "country club crowd."

The event is attracting future Republican leaders, but it is also drawing figures from the past, many with headlines that are not desirable. A Republican gay group is not welcome, and hard-liners on immigration are also absent. The annual presidential straw poll is expected to again be won by a member of the Paul family, to the frustration of organizers.

For decades, the Republican Party has grappled with its moderate-conservative divide. However, the current state of the party is more complex than the traditional center vs. right paradigm, as illustrated by the CPAC gathering. Former Mississippi governor and Clinton-era Republican National Committee Chairman Haley Barbour cautions that it is important for the Republican side to stick together on message and have more message discipline, especially with the Democratic Party holding the White House.

However, as CPAC gets underway, it is the differences that are coming into stark relief. The gathering has long been seen as an early indicator of the state of conservatives, and that remains the case today. But unfortunately for the right, it is the GOP's identity crisis that is now being reflected by CPAC.

The report suggests that the three pillars of the conservative era ushered in by Ronald Reagan - a muscular defense, traditional cultural values, and devotion to free markets - are being questioned by leading Republicans. The future direction of the Republican Party is now being openly debated, with some Republican leaders questioning interventionist foreign policy, urging a more tolerant stance on gay rights, and considering the possibility of more revenue increases in exchange for a fiscal grand bargain.

Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul, who is considering a presidential bid in 2016, seeks to remake the GOP in his image by embracing a more restrained foreign policy and a federalist approach on values issues. However, other party leaders, such as Haley Barbour, hope to downplay differences and believe consensus is the only way to be relevant in the Obama era. Open internal warfare, this view goes, merely offers aid and comfort to the opposition. In other words, Republicans can't even agree on whether they should litigate their disagreements.

Title: "NPR's 'Back at Base' Project Highlights Life of Vietnam War Veteran John H. McCarthy"

Article:

In a project titled "Back at Base," NPR, along with seven public radio stations across the country, is chronicling the lives of American troops in their hometowns. Memorial Day monuments in various cities serve as reminders of the sacrifices made by these soldiers. One such monument is in the Allston-Brighton section of Boston, commemorating Staff Sgt. John H. McCarthy, who died in the Vietnam War.

John McCarthy, born and raised in Allston-Brighton, never returned home after his second tour of duty in Vietnam. His brother, Richie McCarthy, recalls his big brother as a patriot who loved his country and believed in the righteousness of the war.

Growing up, the two brothers, born about two years apart, were close. They shared a talent for art, with Jack developing a perfectionist streak that often led him to repaint his works. By 1960, Jack had developed an interest in the military and enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps on his 17th birthday.

Jack McCarthy excelled in the Marine Corps. In 1962, he was chosen for a training exercise observed by President John F. Kennedy. Later that year, he was assigned to a ship during the Cuban Missile Crisis. He was sent to Vietnam for the first time in 1965, where he worked with local South Vietnamese villagers and rooted out the Viet Cong.

In a letter home in November 1965, Jack wrote, "Dear Mom, I will really miss some of the people in this village... We have had a few more brushes with the V.C. in our area but we are getting smarter than them because we have been killing them. And they haven't hurt us for a long time."

After 13 months in Vietnam, Jack returned stateside. However, by late 1967, he was called back to Vietnam for a second tour. He was severely wounded on the morning of Feb. 18, 1968, when he stepped on an enemy explosive device. He was evacuated to a Naval field hospital in Danang and was able to send some letters home before his condition worsened.

"Dear Mom, Sorry not to have written before but I'm feeling better now and am going to be okay. I'm lucky it wasn't any worse but I've lost my right leg, and the sight of my right eye. Do not worry about it. Please," he wrote in one such letter.

Despite the efforts of surgeons, John McCarthy died on the morning of March 25, 1968, at the age of 24. His brother, Richie, reflects on his loss, saying, "When I think of him, I just think what a shame it is he could not really live his life." Dan Daley, one of Jack's childhood friends, shares a similar sentiment, stating, "You know, when I'd see his name on the wall like I was in D.C. recently, that's all I think of, what a shame, poor kid, he was so young. He never really had children or he did not really have a life, he was just starting out, and snuffed out. It was sad, he had a lot of potential, it just was not realized."

Title: New Jersey Resident Addresses Rep. Ilhan Omar at Ground Zero on 9/11 Anniversary

Article:

Nicholas Haros Jr., a New Jersey resident who lost his mother, Frances, in the September 11, 2001, terror attacks, addressed Rep. Ilhan Omar and "The Squad" during a ceremony at Ground Zero on Wednesday. Omar's comments about the attacks, which she described as "some people did something," drew criticism earlier in the year.

Haros Jr., who wore a shirt with Omar's words, spoke during a reading of victims' names and received some applause from the crowd. He stated, "Today I am here to respond to you exactly who did what to whom... On that day 19 Islamic terrorists, members of Al Qaeda, killed over 3,000 people and caused billions of dollars of economic damage. Is that clear?"

Haros Jr. went on to explain that his mother, a tireless receptionist at Keefe Bruyette & Woods, walked into work on a pleasant Tuesday morning and never returned home. He emphasized that the attacks not only took the lives of individuals but also attacked constitutional freedoms and the nation's Judeo-Christian principles.

"That's what some people did," Haros Jr. concluded. "Got that now? We are here today congresswoman to tell you and The Squad just who did what to whom. Show respect in honoring them, please."

Omar tweeted about the attacks on Wednesday, though it was unclear if her tweet was in response to Haros Jr.'s words. In a March 23 fundraiser for the Council on American-Islamic Relations, Omar's controversial comment was made.

Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Rashida Tlaib, and Ayanna Pressley, the other members of "The Squad," defended Omar, with Tlaib stating that Omar's words were taken out of context.

Haros Jr. has previously called out politicians at Ground Zero on the anniversary of the attacks, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.). He urged politicians to stop using the memories of the victims as political props.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 163,000 Jobs in July, Unemployment Ticks Up Slightly

Article:

The United States economy added 163,000 jobs in July, according to a report by the Labor Department on Friday. The unemployment rate slightly increased from 8.2% in June to 8.3%.

The high unemployment numbers present a challenge for President Barack Obama as he tries to sell voters on his stewardship of the economy before the November election. Republicans have criticized the Obama administration over the number of Americans out of work.

Republican presidential hopeful Mitt Romney commented on the jobs report, stating, "Today’s increase in the unemployment rate is a hammer blow to struggling middle-class families. President Obama doesn’t have a plan and believes that the private sector is ‘doing fine.’ Obviously, that is not the case."

The jobs figure for July was better than most mainstream estimates, with most analysts' predictions hovering around 100,000. On average in 2012, the economy is adding 151,000 jobs per month, according to the Labor Department’s Bureau of Labor Statistics. In 2011, the figure was 153,000.

The better-than-expected jobs figure gave the White House some breathing room and allowed the president to argue that the employment picture is improving, even if it is not good enough. President Obama stated during a news event at the White House, "We are not going to get there, we’re not going get to where we need to be if we go back to the policies that helped to create this mess in the first place."

Jared Bernstein, an economist who worked for the Obama administration earlier in the president’s term, cheered the "nice pop on payrolls" but cautioned not to read too much into a single month. "Keep your powder dry on this one," he said in a blog post. "There are lots of other economic headwinds out there, not least of which is a GDP growth rate below trend, and that’s usually associated with weaker job growth numbers than we saw from the payroll report."

Investors reacted positively to the news, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average shooting up close to 250 points by the afternoon. Analysts do not expect the economic outlook to change dramatically before the November elections. Mark Zandi, chief economist of Moody’s Analytics, stated, "The concerns about recession are misplaced."

Title: Kasich Disagrees with Democrats' Proposal to Prevent Terrorists on Watch List from Buying Firearms

Article:

In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, Republican presidential candidate John Kasich expressed disagreement with the Democratic proposal to add individuals on the terrorism watch list to a "no gun" list. Kasich argued that such a move could potentially hinder the monitoring of potential terrorists by alerting them that they are under review.

During the interview, CNN host Jake Tapper presented a hypothetical scenario where an individual on the terrorism watch list purchases a machine gun and ammunition, and whether authorities should be allowed to let the transaction proceed. Kasich responded, "We have to be careful in the way we do this. Everybody wants a slick little answer, a 100 percent answer. We have to figure out what is a common-sense solution."

Following the mass shooting in San Bernardino, California, on Wednesday, President Obama has called for preventing anyone on a "no fly" or terrorism watch list from purchasing firearms. In a statement on Saturday, the president said, "We may not be able to prevent every tragedy, but — at a bare minimum — we shouldn't be making it so easy for potential terrorists or criminals to get their hands on a gun that they could use against Americans."

Many Democrats have supported Mr. Obama's call, while many Republicans have opposed it as an infringement on civil liberties. In the interview, Kasich, the governor of Ohio, agreed that if someone is on a no-fly list, "we could probably keep them from getting guns."

Kasich emphasized that the key issue in preventing terrorist acts lies in the intelligence community's ability to monitor online messages. He noted that authorities were unable to read the encrypted messages exchanged among the terrorists involved in last month's Paris attacks that left 130 people dead. "If the intelligence community can not see the communications, then we're operating in the dark," Kasich said.

Kasich urged Congress to move on ensuring that authorities have access to such messages to prevent future tragedies.

Title: Interview with Libertarian Presidential Nominee Gary Johnson: Immigration, Free Trade, and Fiscal Conservatism

Article:

In an exclusive, extended interview this week, Libertarian Party presidential nominee Gary Johnson discussed his immigration policies, his stance on free trade, and his record as a fiscally conservative and socially inclusive governor.

When asked about his immigration policies as a former border state governor, Johnson emphasized his support for a more inclusive approach. He criticized both major party nominees for their controversial statements and proposals on immigration, and expressed opposition to the use of the term "illegal immigrant," describing it as "incendiary" and offensive.

Johnson and his running mate support free trade, a position that differentiates them from the two major party nominees. He described his ticket's outlook as "fiscally conservative and socially inclusive."

Johnson assailed Hillary Clinton as an ethically compromised and dishonest statist, and sharply criticized Donald Trump's ideas on immigration and trade. He touted his record of "cutting the rate of growth of government in half" as governor as a proud accomplishment, noting that he earned re-election in a blue state even after establishing a reputation as a "penny pincher."

Later this week, we will reveal Gov. Johnson's thoughts on issues such as the Second Amendment, Obamacare, the Iran deal, and the Hobby Lobby decision. Stay tuned.

Title: Senate Confirms Justice Brett Kavanaugh Amid Controversial Vote, Leaving Both Parties Critical of Process

Article:

The United States Senate confirmed Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court on Saturday, following a contentious and divisive confirmation process. The vote was 50-48, with all Democrats voting against the nominee.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) expressed hope that the confirmation would mark a turning point, signaling that the acrimony of the past few months was not a successful strategy for Democrats trying to oppose a nominee with strong legal credentials.

Following the vote, President Trump signed Justice Kavanaugh's commission, and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. administered the oath of office, restoring the court to its full contingent of nine justices.

Democrats criticized the Republican-led process, citing broken traditions regarding access to documents and the nature of background checks. They also expressed disappointment that the FBI failed to corroborate allegations of sexual assault made against Justice Kavanaugh.

Democrats also accused Justice Kavanaugh of lowering the bar with his testy testimony last month, during which he sparred with senators who accused him of lying, attempted rape, using crude language, and drinking as a teenager.

Republicans, on the other hand, criticized a perceived liberal public relations machine that they claimed fabricated erroneous stories about Justice Kavanaugh's 12-year record of rulings, concocted conspiracy theories about his nomination, and maltreated Christine Blasey Ford, the first to make misconduct allegations against Justice Kavanaugh privately.

Sen. Jack Reed (D-RI), a longtime senator, attributed the acrimony to both sides, with Republicans escalating matters. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-NC), a member of the Judiciary Committee, cautioned Republicans against using the same tactics in future nominations.

Historically, each new low set by one party has been embraced by the other. Republicans have followed the lead of former Sen. Joseph R. Biden (D-DE) in refusing to consider President Obama's 2016 nomination of Judge Merrick Garland to the Supreme Court, holding the seat open for the next president to fill.

In response to partisan filibusters of judicial nominees, both parties have resorted to the "nuclear option," changing the interpretation of the rules to defang the filibuster for most judicial nominees. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-NY) was noncommittal when asked last week whether he would try to reverse that change and restore the filibuster's power for Supreme Court nominees if Democrats regain control of the Senate.

Despite the contentious nature of the confirmation process, the Senate managed to pass two massive spending bills, clear an anti-opioid package, and make progress on other bipartisan priorities during the Kavanaugh fight. The relationships built up over decades among senators, even amid the strife, remain strong, as evidenced by the exchange of handshakes and chuckles between Sen. Richard J. Durbin (D-IL) and Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-IA) shortly after the latter was criticized by the former for his handling of the Kavanaugh nomination.

Title: "Rumors of Taxpayer-Funded Health Insurance Bailout Under ObamaCare Persist Amidst Rising Costs and Political Manipulation"

Article:

As costs associated with the Affordable Care Act, or ObamaCare, continue to rise, there is growing urgency for Congress to prevent the possibility of taxpayer-funded bailouts of health insurance companies. This week, a majority of insurers offering health plans in Florida announced premium increases ranging from 11 to 23 percent. If patients choose to drop their coverage due to these increases, health insurers will need to find alternative means to cover the losses.

Section 1342 of the ObamaCare law, also known as "risk corridors," was established to address such situations. This provision allows taxpayers to cover the losses of health insurance companies whose plans underperform under ObamaCare. In November 2014, legislation was introduced to repeal this section and protect taxpayers from being forced to cover insurers' ObamaCare losses.

Despite the Obama administration's initial announcement that it had no intention of operating this bailout program at a net cost to the American people, health insurers and their lobbyists have reportedly pressured the administration to reconsider. In response, new legislation was introduced to codify the administration's promise and prohibit the use of taxpayer funds for this purpose. However, this legislation has not progressed in the Democrat-controlled Senate, and the White House has shown no interest in supporting it.

Recent investigations by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, chaired by Darrell Issa, have revealed that health insurers widely expect to receive funds from the bailout program. One large health insurer has even filed financial statements claiming they expect part of their revenue to come from American taxpayers via the ObamaCare bailout "fund."

To circumvent Congress' power of the purse, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has reportedly found a way to use general funds available through the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to pay off health insurers, effectively bypassing Congress and using taxpayer funds for the bailout.

With ObamaCare's costs projected to exceed $2 trillion over the next decade, its impact on jobs and work hours continuing, and the prospect of a taxpayer-funded bailout of health insurers still alive, it is clear that the law has failed. The author argues that it is time to repeal and replace ObamaCare, but at the very least, the law should be amended to ensure that health insurers will not be bailed out by taxpayers due to the underperformance of ObamaCare.

Title: Former FBI Lawyer Lisa Page Breaks Silence, Criticizes Trump's Attacks

Article:

In a rare interview with The Daily Beast, former FBI lawyer Lisa Page, who gained national attention for her text messages with fired FBI agent Peter Strzok, has spoken out against President Donald Trump's attacks on her. Page, 39, stated that she could no longer remain silent in the face of the president's repeated attacks, particularly a "demeaning fake orgasm" incident at an Oct. 11 rally in Minneapolis.

"I had stayed quiet for years hoping it would fade away, but instead it got worse," she said. "It had been so hard not to defend myself, to let people who hate me control the narrative. I decided to take my power back."

Page, who left the FBI in May 2018, described the feeling of being attacked by Trump as "like being punched in the gut." She added, "It's sickening. The president of the United States is calling me names to the entire world. He's demeaning me and my career."

Trump last tweeted about Page on Nov. 15, following the conviction of his longtime associate Roger Stone. In the tweet, Trump criticized the fact that Stone was headed to jail while Page, Strzok, and others, including his 2016 opponent Hillary Clinton, went free.

Investigations have not shown Page, Strzok, Clinton, or any of the others accused by Trump to be guilty of any criminal wrongdoing. In a June 2018 report, the Justice Department inspector general's office stated that it was "deeply troubled" by the anti-Trump texts between Page and Strzok but "did not find evidence to connect the political views expressed in these messages to the specific investigative decisions" they made in the investigation of Clinton's use of a private email server.

A new report from the Justice Department inspector general on the origin of the investigations into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russian government's efforts to interfere in the 2016 election is scheduled for release on Dec. 9. Page can expect her name to appear in that report as well.

Page stated that even if the inspector general's report clears her of any wrongdoing, she does not expect her vilification among Trump's supporters to end. "While it would be nice to have the IG confirm publicly that my personal opinions had absolutely no bearing on the course of the Russia investigations, I don’t kid myself that the fact will matter very much for a lot of people," she told The Daily Beast. "The president has a very loud megaphone."

In their texts, Page and Strzok made several comments that were disparaging of Trump and supportive of Clinton. In the text exchange most often cited as evidence of their bias against Trump, Page asks Strzok to assure her that Trump is "not ever going to become president, right?"

Page stated that she had been inaccurately depicted by a "cherry-picked selection of my texts" and did not remember the messages about Trump when she first learned her texts were being investigated.

Several Trump supporters were appalled by the interview, and they decried what they saw as Page's attempt to paint herself as a victim. "Let me get this straight," tweeted Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio. "Page and Strzok sent texts about an 'insurance policy' and how they'll'stop Trump' while part of the FBI spying on Trump campaign. Now Lisa Page is blaming the President. 1 week before Horowitz’s FISA report."

Page's marriage survived, but she compared the effect of the experience to post-traumatic stress disorder, stating it is worse "because it's not over. It’s ongoing. It’s not a historical event that is being relived. It just keeps happening."

"I don’t ever know when the president’s going to attack next," she said. "And when it happens, it can still sort of upend my day. You don’t really get used to it."

Title: Trump Remains Silent on Roy Moore Allegations Amidst Asia Trip

Article:

President Donald Trump, currently in Hanoi, Vietnam for a state banquet and subsequent meetings with the country's president and prime minister on Sunday, has declined to comment on the growing allegations of sexual misconduct against Senate candidate Roy Moore. The allegations, which were first reported by The Washington Post, involve Moore's inappropriate behavior towards several women decades ago, including sexual contact with a 14-year-old girl in 1979.

In a statement issued through Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Trump stated that he believes "we can not allow a mere allegation — in this case, one from many years ago — to destroy a person's life." However, the statement also noted that if the allegations are true, "Judge Moore will do the right thing and step aside."

Moore, a former Alabama Supreme Court justice, defeated Trump's preferred candidate, Sen. Luther Strange, in the Republican primary to replace former Sen. Jeff Sessions, who became Trump's attorney general. The allegations against Moore have caused a national controversy, with several prominent Republicans, including Sen. Mike Lee of Utah and the National Republican Senatorial Committee, withdrawing their support.

When asked about the specific allegations against Moore during his Asia trip, Trump insisted that he has been too preoccupied with world affairs to pay much attention to the matter. "I'd have to look at it and I'd have to see," Trump said. "Because, again, I'm dealing with the president of China, the president of Russia. I'm dealing with the folks over here," he added, referring to his meetings with world leaders.

The allegations against Moore have caused a significant stir in the United States, with some calling for Moore to drop out of the Alabama Senate race. Moore, for his part, has given vague denials of the allegations, stating, "I don't remember anything like that" and "I don't remember dating any girl without the permission of her mother."

The controversy surrounding Moore's candidacy is the latest in a series of sexual misconduct allegations that have rocked the political landscape in the United States in recent months. The allegations against Moore come as the #MeToo movement continues to gain momentum, with numerous high-profile figures in politics, entertainment, and media facing accusations of sexual misconduct.

Title: Racial Disparities in COVID-19 Infections and Deaths in the United States

Article:

A study by ███ has revealed significant racial disparities in COVID-19 infections and deaths across the United States. In 28 states and the District of Columbia, preliminary data analysis shows that Black people have disproportionately contracted and died from the coronavirus.

In 20 of the 28 states plus DC for which a usable racial breakdown of infection data was provided, Black people make up a larger share of coronavirus infections than they do of the general population. Similarly, in 18 of the 23 states plus DC for which a usable racial breakdown of fatality data was provided, Black people make up a disproportionately large share of coronavirus fatalities.

For instance, in Michigan, Black people are 14 percent of the state's population but 33 percent of its coronavirus cases and 40 percent of its deaths. In Wisconsin, Black people are six percent of the state's population but 25 percent of its coronavirus cases and 39 percent of its deaths.

Data for Latinx populations is scarce, but what is available shows that Latinx people are dying at much higher rates in New York City relative to their share of the population, but not in any of the places that provided relevant breakdowns.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has released racial data on 10 states. Civil rights groups, medical professionals, and lawmakers have pressured the CDC to release data on who is infected and who dies from the coronavirus by race and ethnicity.

Thomas LaVeist, dean of the Tulane School of Public Health & Tropical Medicine, attributes the racial disparities to various factors, including Black Americans' higher likelihood of working essential jobs, living in densely populated, historically segregated cities, and suffering disproportionately from underlying health conditions.

Clyde Yancy, chief of cardiology at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine, calls this a "moment of ethical reckoning" and points out that infection rates were three times higher in counties with mostly Black people than in predominantly white counties. Predominantly Black counties saw a sixfold higher death rate than mostly white counties.

Yancy writes, "A 6-fold increase in the rate of death for African Americans due to a now ubiquitous virus should be deemed unconscionable." He concludes, "The scourge of COVID-19 will end, but health care disparities will persist."

Title: Call for Trump's Resignation Amidst Coronavirus Crisis

Article:

The United States, with just over 4% of the world's population, has accounted for about one-third of all global coronavirus cases and one-quarter of the fatalities, as of Friday. This disproportionate impact can be attributed, in large part, to the actions and statements of President Donald Trump.

One of the president's most controversial suggestions has been the use of hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malarial drug, as a potential treatment for the coronavirus. Trump publicly endorsed the drug, stating, "What do you have to lose?" However, a new study of Veterans Health Administration patients has concluded that COVID-19 patients who take hydroxychloroquine are more likely to die than those who do not.

In addition, Trump suggested on Thursday that ultraviolet rays and cleaning disinfectants, when injected into the body, could be potential treatments for coronavirus. These comments prompted public health experts and companies like Lysol to remind Americans that they should not ingest cleaning products.

The Trump administration has also reportedly forced out the official in charge of the federal agency responsible for developing a vaccine for the coronavirus after he raised concerns about money being directed toward hydroxychloroquine.

Trump's obsession with reopening the economy has also been a catalyst for governors in red state America to weaken social distancing regulations. His calls for the end of social distancing orders have directly contradicted the Trump White House's own guidance.

Trump's credibility has been significantly damaged, with less than a quarter of voters putting a high level of trust in what he is saying about COVID-19. The president's actions and words have done more harm than good, leading to calls for his resignation from editorial boards and politicians, both Democratic and Republican.

The call for Trump's resignation is not a partisan exercise, but a common-sense response to a president who is making the crisis worse by remaining in office. The president's detachment from reality, indifference to the suffering around us, and political self-aggrandizement have eroded the public trust and undermined the nation's response to the coronavirus crisis.

Title: Saudi Military Trainee's Alleged Al-Qaeda Connection in Pensacola Shooting Revealed

Article:

The Saudi military trainee who carried out a terror attack at a military base in Pensacola, Florida, last year, killing three US sailors and wounding several others, had a long-standing association with al-Qaeda, according to the Justice Department and the FBI. The connection was uncovered after the FBI managed to break through the encryption on the attacker's iPhones.

At a news conference on Monday, Attorney General William Barr and FBI Director Christopher Wray announced that the evidence from the attacker's devices showed that the Pensacola attack was the culmination of years of planning and preparation by a longtime associate of al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), one of the deadliest branches of the terror group.

Mohammed Alshamrani, a member of the Royal Saudi Air Force who was training at Naval Air Station Pensacola, was killed by law enforcement during the attack. The officials stopped short of saying that Alshamrani had been directed by the terror group, but said his ties to AQAP began as far back as 2015 and were "significant."

The connection between the group and the attack marked a major development in the US fight against terrorism. Since 9/11, no foreign terrorist organization has successfully directed a deadly attack in the US, according to New America, a think tank.

The officials also used the opportunity to criticize Apple for refusing to help investigators break into the devices. FBI Director Wray said that the FBI received "effectively no help" from Apple in bypassing the phones, and that third-party technology firms were also unable to help investigators.

Apple said in a statement Monday that the company does not believe in creating special access to its devices for the government because of security concerns. "It is because we take our responsibility to national security so seriously that we do not believe in the creation of a backdoor — one which will make every device vulnerable to bad actors who threaten our national security and the data security of our customers," the company said.

The Justice Department has previously called the attack an act of terrorism motivated by "jihadist ideology." Alshamrani had made anti-American, anti-Israel, and jihadi posts on social media, including one on the September 11 anniversary, that stated "the countdown has begun," and another two hours before the attack that referenced the words of an al-Qaeda cleric.

During a 15-minute shooting spree, Alshamrani shot at a photo of President Donald Trump as well as a former president. He made statements during the attack that were critical of American servicemen overseas, the FBI has said.

AQAP had claimed responsibility for the Pensacola attack and said it was in touch with Alshamrani. In February, the White House announced that Qassim al-Rimi, the leader of the group, had been killed in an airstrike in Yemen.

No other co-conspirators have been charged in the shooting, and Barr said earlier this year that investigators did not find evidence that any of the shooter's friends or fellow trainees from Saudi Arabia had advance knowledge that he was going to attack the base.

On Monday, Barr said the Saudi government continued to fully cooperate with the investigation, and the Saudi Embassy in Washington said in a statement Monday evening they are providing "full support to our American counterparts."

Investigators had initially been unable to retrieve data stored on two iPhones belonging to the shooter, and they cited that hurdle in trying to complete their investigation of the attacker's ideology and radicalization. Justice Department and FBI officials said Apple had helped provide access to iCloud and other data from the shooter's devices, but breaking the phones' encryption was key to retrieving more of Alshamrani's communications before the attack.

Title: Congressional Resolution on Syria: Limited Authorization for Use of Force Proposed

Article:

Secretary of State John F. Kerry testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday, advocating for a resolution authorizing the use of force against Syria in response to the alleged chemical weapons attack by the regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad. The administration is seeking congressional approval for retaliatory strikes, with the threat of further chemical weapons use by Assad's regime and potential nuclear weapon use by North Korea or Iran cited as potential consequences of a negative vote.

The committee agreed on a resolution late Tuesday that would prohibit "combat" troops from being deployed to Syria and allow the president to conduct strikes for a maximum of 90 days. The resolution is set for a committee vote on Wednesday. The White House is hoping the resolution will build momentum for eventual approval by both chambers of Congress.

House Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, emerged from a meeting with President Obama on Tuesday, stating he will vote to authorize an attack on Syria. However, the support of Mr. Boehner, and the administration's overall chances of winning over undecided lawmakers, is questionable, as more House members are adding their names to the list of those opposed to the authority President Obama is seeking.

The resolution, as released by senators, restricts the scope of action in Syria and presses the administration to consider arming moderate rebels fighting to overthrow Mr. Assad. The version of the resolution was negotiated by Sen. Bob Corker, the key Republican in the negotiations, and was released hours after Mr. Kerry and the top two Defense Department officials testified to the Foreign Relations Committee.

In his testimony, Mr. Kerry stated there is no doubt that troops loyal to Mr. Assad used chemical weapons against civilians in rebel-held territory on Aug. 21, and the only question now is whether the U.S. will enforce President Obama's and the world's "red line." Mr. Kerry compared those who would vote against action to the case of the MS St. Louis, a ship carrying Jewish refugees from Germany that was turned away from Cuba, the U.S., and Canada in 1939, and had to return to Europe, where many of its passengers eventually died in Nazi camps.

The claims made by Mr. Kerry were met with skepticism among some lawmakers, who expressed concerns about limited U.S. strikes leading to a regional escalation. The majority of the 18-member committee appeared to be leaning in favor of action, heeding the call of Senate leaders who are pushing for lawmakers to pass a resolution that would give a stamp of approval for Mr. Obama to act.

Meanwhile, Mr. Boehner and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat, emerged from a meeting with Mr. Obama at the White House to say they will vote to authorize force. However, a spokesman for Mr. Boehner stated it will be up to Mr. Obama to find the votes, and it's an "uphill" climb for the administration. The latest polling shows the American public is opposed to retaliatory strikes, with 59% of respondents rejecting them, according to an ABC/Washington Post poll.

Mr. Kerry and his fellow panel members are set to appear before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Wednesday, while the Senate committee will hold a closed-door session to hear classified details about U.S. plans and the intelligence supporting claims that chemical weapons were used. The Senate committee hearing on Tuesday was interrupted several times by vocal female protesters calling for Congress to reject any military action. Mr. Kerry, who made a name in national politics by protesting the Vietnam War, in which he served, said he sympathized with the demonstrating women and that it represented the importance for Congress to have a debate.

Although some analysts still question whether the Syrian regime used chemical weapons, most members of Congress seemed ready to accept the administration's case that such weapons were used on Aug. 21 and that forces loyal to Mr. Assad were responsible for the attack. "In my view, there is a preponderance of evidence beyond a reasonable doubt," said Sen. Robert Menendez, New Jersey Democrat and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Kerry punctuated that point, saying the Obama administration has learned the lessons of faulty intelligence from the experience in Iraq and has repeatedly scrubbed its intelligence to make sure it's correct.

Title: White House Warns of Severe Consequences of Sequestration

Article:

In the face of an impending blizzard in New England, the White House has taken a metaphorical approach to warn of another kind of storm: the potential effects of sequestration, the automatic, across-the-board cuts to defense and domestic spending set to take effect on March 1 unless Congress and President Obama agree on an alternative plan.

During a briefing with reporters, White House officials used a series of adjectives to describe the anticipated impacts: "large and arbitrary," "severe," "significant and harmful," "very significant," "blunt," "mindless," and "extraordinarily troublesome."

The officials outlined specific consequences that could result from the sequestration, including:
- 70,000 young children being removed from Head Start early education programs
- Hundreds of federal prosecutors being furloughed
- Reduced food safety inspections
- 600,000 women and children losing nutritional benefits
- A decrease of approximately $500 million in small-business loans

Danny Werfel, the federal controller of the Office of Management and Budget, stated, "The cuts would cause very significant disruptions that would be felt far and wide across the country. This is just the tip of the iceberg. We can’t plan our way out of these consequences or take steps to soften the blow."

The briefing was the latest effort by the Obama administration to assign blame for the consequences of the automatic cuts, should they occur. Brendan Buck, a spokesman for House Speaker John A. Boehner, attempted to deflect this blame, noting that the House has already proposed alternative spending cuts to avoid the automatic ones.

In a statement emailed to reporters, Mr. Buck said, "The president is out of excuses. We’re glad they’re laying out the devastating consequences of the president’s sequester, but the question remains: what are they willing to do to prevent it?"

A spokesman for Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky stated on Twitter after the White House briefing, "Words not used at WH briefing to describe sequestered budget cuts: 'Here’s our plan.'"

At the White House, economic officials lamented the lack of flexibility in the sequestration law, which they noted was intentional. "It was intended to drive Democrats and Republicans in Congress to compromise," Mr. Werfel said. "It does not represent a responsible way to achieve deficit reduction."

White House officials are quick to point out that Republicans in the House initially embraced the idea of the automatic cuts as a means to enforce deficit discipline. They note that 174 House Republicans, including Speaker Boehner, voted for sequestration, with Mr. Boehner proclaiming himself pleased when it passed.

Press Secretary Jay Carney stated that the notion that the automatic cuts were solely the president's idea is a "fanciful confection" invented by Republicans.
