However, none of Mr. Obama's aides were willing to admit that the president regretted signing the law that put the sequestration plan into effect. Mr. Carney explained that because of Republican opposition to tax increases, the automatic cuts became the only way to avoid a default on the national debt in the summer of 2011.

"He could not let the country default for the first time, thus the sequester," Mr. Carney said. "The whole point in its design was that it would never come to pass."

Title: U.S. Attorneys Appointed to Investigate Classified Information Leaks

Article:

Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. appointed Ronald Machen, the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, and Rod Rosenstein, the U.S. attorney for the District of Maryland, to lead separate investigations into unauthorized leaks of classified information. The two prosecutors will work with the FBI and lead criminal investigations into the leaks, with full authorization to prosecute criminal violations as a result of their investigation.

In a statement, Mr. Holder said, "The unauthorized disclosure of classified information can compromise the security of this country and all Americans, and it will not be tolerated." He added that the Justice Department takes such cases seriously and will do so in these cases as well.

President Obama defended himself from criticism for the leaks, denying that they were intentional or orchestrated to boost his foreign policy bona fides ahead of the November election. Critics, led by Sen. John McCain, have called the leaks a serious security breach and unprecedented in recent memory.

Mr. Obama pledged to launch a thorough investigation into the matter, stating that his administration has "zero tolerance" for such leaks. He also emphasized that his administration will conduct thorough investigations, as they have in the past, and that those who leak information will face consequences, including criminal charges in some cases.

On Friday afternoon, Mr. Holder announced the appointment of the two U.S. attorneys, stating, "We have mechanisms in place where if we can root out folks who have leaked, they will suffer consequences."

Title: Trump's Presidency: A Divisive Battlefield or Uniter of Parties?

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, President Donald Trump has been referred to as a "Great Uniter" by some, due to his ability to rally support within the Republican Party following his acquittal in the Senate and his State of the Union address. According to a Gallup Poll, 94% of Republicans approve of his handling of his presidency, a level of support that is comparable only to the first months of the 1991 Gulf War under President George H.W. Bush and the first months of the 2003 Iraq War under President George W. Bush.

However, Trump's presidency has not only united the Republican Party but also divided the Democratic Party. Every Democrat but three in the House voted to impeach and remove him, and every Democrat in the Senate voted to convict and prevent his ever running again. The issue of evicting Trump from the Oval Office seems to be a significant concern for Democrats, more so than getting U.S. troops out of the Middle East wars.

The ideological differences between Trump and the Democratic Party are stark. Trump's tax cuts for corporations and individuals and deregulation policies contrast with the Democratic Party's support for nationalized health care and abolition of private health insurance. The Democrats' unanimous support for "reproductive rights" is in conflict with Trump's pledge to nominate justices who will overturn Roe v. Wade.

The issue of immigration also divides the two parties. Democrats support tearing down Trump's wall, ending deportations, extending welfare benefits to border-crossers, and granting sanctuary from border security agents for criminals residing in the U.S. illegally. The changing demographics of the U.S., with Americans of European descent expected to be less than half of the population in 20 years, is celebrated by Democrats, while Republicans, who predominantly vote for the GOP, provide 85-90% of all Republican votes in presidential elections.

The Democratic Party has become more politically correct, with candidates being criticized for their past positions. For instance, former Vice President Joe Biden has been attacked for his opposition to the forced busing of children from neighborhood schools into inner-city schools, his friendship with Southern senators, and his role in the Clarence Thomas hearings. He has also been criticized for authorizing the 2003 war in Iraq.

The question remains as to whether Trump's presidency is the cause of the uncivil war in America or if it is merely the battlefield upon which America's cultural and political war is currently engaged. Some argue that Trump's success has maddened Democrats into manifesting who they are and what they believe, while others contend that the parties were divided long before Trump's presidency and will remain so long after he departs.

Patrick Buchanan, an adviser to three presidents, two-time candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, and the nominee for the Reform Party in 2000, has suggested that the irrationality and irresponsibility taking on epidemic proportions inside the Democratic Party may be a result of Trump's success. However, others argue that Trump's presidency has simply revealed who the Democrats are and what they believe, and what may yet prevent them from being taken seriously as a party that can lead the nation.

Title: President Trump Announces Plans for a "Space Force" as Sixth Branch of U.S. Armed Forces

Article:

In a meeting of the National Space Council on Monday, President Donald Trump announced plans to establish a new military branch, the "space force," which would become the sixth branch of the U.S. armed forces. The president made the announcement at a meeting in Washington D.C., stating, "We are going to have a space force. An Air Force and a Space Force. Separate, but equal."

Trump's proposal for a "space force" is not a new idea; he previously mentioned the concept in May during a ceremony at the White House. The president did not provide details about the military role of the "space force" or who would command it, but he framed space as a national security issue, stating, "I do not want China and Russia and other countries leading us."

Pentagon spokeswoman Dana White responded, "We understand the President's guidance. Our Policy Board will begin working on this issue, which has implications for intelligence operations for the Air Force, Army, Marines, and Navy. Working with Congress, this will be a deliberate process with a great deal of input from multiple stakeholders."

The president also called for a long-term build-up in the U.S.'s presence in space, expressed support for the nascent commercial space travel industry, and signed a directive to manage space traffic. The directive aims to provide a safe and secure environment in orbit as satellite traffic increases and sets up new guidelines for satellite design and operation to avoid collisions and spacecraft breakups.

Before discussing the space program, President Trump weighed in on the ongoing immigration crisis, blasting the U.S.'s current immigration laws and stating, "The United States will not be a migrant holding facility. We cannot allow that to happen in the U.S. Not on my watch. We want safety and we want security." Trump added, "If the Democrats would sit down and stop obstructing, we could have something quickly."

The Trump administration's policy of separating migrant children from their parents has come under increasing scrutiny from both sides of the aisle. The policy, which has resulted in nearly 2,000 minors being separated from their families over six weeks, has drawn sharp criticism from Democrats and even a number of influential Republicans, including former first lady Laura Bush, who called the policy "cruel" and "immoral" in an opinion piece in the Washington Post.

Title: Gallup and Rasmussen Polls Show Tight Presidential Race Between Obama and Romney

Article:

The Gallup and Rasmussen daily presidential trackers have reported a tight race between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, with a single statistically insignificant point separating the two candidates. The Rasmussen tracker, which polls likely voters on a three-day cycle, has shown a reversal from the post-Democratic National Convention (DNC) bounce, while Gallup, which surveys registered voters over a seven-day cycle, has also reported a narrowing of the gap.

In the aftermath of the DNC, Obama led by as many as five points in Rasmussen and seven points in Gallup, largely due to an effective speech from former President Bill Clinton. However, as of the latest polls, Romney leads Obama by two points in the Rasmussen poll, while Obama holds a single-point edge in the Gallup poll.

In the battleground states, Romney has virtually tied with Obama among registered voters in New Hampshire. The sample of respondents in this poll appears slightly favorable to the Republican Party, although undeclared voters make up a significant portion of the pool. The Romney campaign believes Colorado is a pure toss-up at this point, and Romney has edged into the lead in this state according to the latest polls.

In Virginia, a Washington Post poll indicates Obama is leading Romney by eight points, relying on a D+9 sample, three points higher than the 2008 partisan split. This contrasts with Rasmussen's recent poll, which showed the Virginia race at 49-48 in Obama's favor, and other polls that place the race somewhere in between. Politico's Jonathan Martin has expressed skepticism about the Washington Post poll's sample.

Title: Political Operative Charged with Misdemeanor Battery in Nevada After Alleged Confrontation at GOP Campaign Event

Article:

A political operative from Virginia, Wilfred Michael Stark, has been charged with misdemeanor battery in Nevada following an incident at a GOP campaign event. Stark, 50, of Falls Church, Virginia, was arrested Tuesday evening and released from the Las Vegas city jail on $1,140 bail on Wednesday, according to Jace Radke, a city spokesman. The court date for Stark is currently unavailable.

The incident occurred at a Las Vegas community center, where Stark allegedly pushed into the event and grabbed the manager of state Attorney General Adam Laxalt's gubernatorial campaign, according to witnesses. Stark told the officer who took him into custody that he was attacked "because he was a Democrat in a room full of Republicans," according to the arrest report.

Witnesses provided statements saying Stark declared several times, "I do this for a living." The Laxalt campaign spokesman, Parker Briden, linked Stark with American Bridge 21st Century, a group that supports Democratic candidates and is committed to holding Republicans accountable. An American Bridge official did not immediately respond to telephone and email messages.

Stark has a history of confronting Republican political figures. In March, he was arrested in Washington, D.C., on a simple assault charge for allegedly using his body to push a top aide to Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke outside a congressional hearing. American Bridge, the organization that spoke on behalf of Stark, "adamantly" denied the allegations at that time.

Stark was also arrested a year ago in suburban Virginia and charged with creating a disturbance while videotaping a parade appearance by GOP gubernatorial candidate Ed Gillespie for ShareBlue Media, an American Bridge affiliate. He was convicted of disorderly conduct, according to a report in the Fairfax County Times.

In Las Vegas, Laxalt campaign chief Kristin Davison made a citizen's arrest after she and witnesses said Stark pushed into a room and grabbed her arm hard enough to leave red marks. "Mike Stark aggressively interrupted our conversation, both by loudly yelling and physically shoving a camera and his body at the attorney general and me," Davison's signed police complaint said. "I asked him to back away and he did not."

Democratic candidate Steve Sisolak's campaign and state Democratic party officials denied any connection to Stark. "No one should ever feel unsafe at a political event," Sisolak spokeswoman Christina Amestoy said in a statement. "We strongly condemn this violence."

Title: Mini-Trade Deal with China Falls Short of Comprehensive Goals, Economists Say

Article:

President Donald Trump announced last week that the United States and China had reached a significant trade deal, but a closer look reveals that the agreement is more of a tentative proposal rather than a comprehensive deal. The deal, according to Trump, is one of the biggest in a long time, but economists argue that it falls short of the president's initial promises and may reinforce China's protectionist and authoritarian economic policies.

The deal does not compel the Chinese government to relinquish its grip on its economy, and it remains unclear whether China will stop asking foreign companies to hand over trade secrets. China will likely continue to use state-owned enterprises to artificially direct resources toward favored industries, a practice that the deal may actually reinforce.

One of the most noticeable failures of the deal is the lack of a commitment from China to abandon its protectionist policies. The deal requires China to purchase $40 billion to $50 billion worth of American agricultural products annually, a concession China already agreed to more than two years ago. This increase in agricultural purchases is not a victory, but rather a concession that pursues the very top-down, government-directed policy that Trump claimed he wanted to change.

The deal's focus on exports is also problematic. Economists argue that exports are costs, not benefits, and that the goal of trade is to import goods and services in exchange for what is exported. George Mason University's Donald Boudreaux explains, "What is true at the level of the household is here true at the level of the national economy: the goods and services that Americans export to foreigners are the costs that we willingly incur in order to be able to import into our country the goods and services that we receive from foreigners in exchange."

The trade war, which has been marked by tariffs, manufacturing slowdowns, and rampant uncertainty, has yielded few concessions from China. The United States will continue to impose tariffs on roughly $360 billion worth of Chinese imports, causing continued disruption to the supply chain at the expense of American companies and consumers.

Moreover, the opportunity cost of the Trump strategy is often overlooked. Daniel Mitchell of the Center for Freedom and Prosperity argues, "Just imagine, by contrast, where we would be if Trump had joined with our allies and used the World Trade Organization to go after China's mercantilist policies. We'd be in much better shape today." The reduction in tariffs China agreed to for many other countries, while increasing tariffs on American exports, and the numerous trade deals our trading partners have implemented since the beginning of this trade war, further highlight the opportunity cost of the Trump strategy.

In light of these factors, it is difficult to view the trade war, even one that ends with this mini-deal, as a win for the United States.

Title: Study Reveals Increase in Number of Underinsured Individuals Due to High Deductibles

Article:

A new study by the Commonwealth Fund has found that approximately one-quarter of individuals with health insurance are considered underinsured due to high deductibles and out-of-pocket expenses. The 2014 national health insurance survey estimates that 31 million insured people are not sufficiently protected against high healthcare costs, a figure that has doubled since 2003, according to The Hill.

The report indicates that rising deductibles is the primary issue for those considered underinsured, even with the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The report warns that the steady growth in the prevalence and size of deductibles could lead to an increase in underinsurance in the future, as stated by The Hill.

The survey also found that people who purchase the lowest quality health coverage are less likely to seek medical care when sick or injured due to fear of high out-of-pocket costs. Sara Collins, the study's lead author, told reporters that "people who have high deductibles do tend to skimp on healthcare" (The Hill).

According to the report, half of underinsured adults and 41 percent of privately insured adults with deductibles of at least $1,000 had medical bills totaling $4,000 or more. The report calls into question the Obama administration's promise that millions of people would gain access to affordable healthcare under Obamacare. However, the report does not account for the people who were uninsured before 2014, as stated by Collins (The Hill).

"We're unable to separately assess the effects of the law with these data," Collins said (The Hill). "What we're seeing, though, in the data is ever-growing deductibles."

Despite the increase in deductibles, healthcare costs overall have not risen as of late, something which the Obama administration has taken partial credit for, according to The Hill. Specifically, the rate of those underinsured has flattened over the last several years, with the biggest increases in the underinsured population occurring between 2003 and 2010.

The study found that those most likely to be underinsured are employed by small businesses, as reported by The Hill.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Staff Wage Gap Raises Questions About Gender Equality Advocates

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, a report by the Washington Free Beacon has revealed that during her tenure in the U.S. Senate, Hillary Clinton paid women on her staff only 72 cents for every dollar paid to men. This revelation, coming from a figure who has been a vocal advocate for gender equality, has sparked questions about the commitment of high-profile feminists and women's organizations to their cause.

According to the analysis of data compiled from official Senate expenditure reports, the median annual salary for a woman working in Clinton's office was $15,708.38 less than the median salary for a man during those years. This wage gap, a stark contrast to Clinton's public stance on gender equality, has raised eyebrows, particularly given her past statements on the issue.

In 2014, Clinton tweeted, "More work to do. # EqualPay # NoCeilings," referring to the persistent wage gap between men and women. However, the "ceilings" she spoke of seem to have been present within her own office.

In June, the Washington Free Beacon also reported on a scandal from the 1980s involving Clinton, where she defended a man who was accused of raping an underage girl, a story that became known as The Hillary Tapes. Despite this, groups like Planned Parenthood and EMILY's List continue to honor Clinton's "efforts" on behalf of women.

As for the A-list celebrities who cheered for wage equality at the Oscars, their response to the pay gap revelations remains to be seen. It remains unclear whether Clinton will face criticism from these famous feminists and popular women's rights groups, or if they will continue to focus their ire on what they perceive as the "real threat" – the suffocating patriarchy.

The answer to whether Clinton will face backlash from these groups is yet to be determined, but the wage gap revelation has certainly added a new layer of complexity to the ongoing conversation about gender equality.

Title: India's Chief of Defence Staff, General Bipin Rawat, Sparks Controversy with "Deradicalization" Comments

Article:

India's newly appointed Chief of Defence Staff, General Bipin Rawat, has stirred controversy with his recent comments suggesting the existence of "deradicalization" camps in India, drawing comparisons with the internment of Uighurs in China's Xinjiang province.

During a media address in New Delhi last week, Rawat stated, "Like what we are seeing in Kashmir... we saw radicalization happening. There are people who have completely been radicalized. These people need to be taken out separately, possibly taken into some deradicalization camps. We have deradicalization camps going on in our country."

Rawat's comments have sparked fear among Kashmiris, who claim that India is seeking to emulate China's actions in Xinjiang. Human rights groups estimate that over a million Uighurs have been detained in internment camps in Xinjiang, which Beijing refers to as "re-education camps" to eradicate alleged religious "extremism."

However, Kashmiri political analyst Zafar Chowdhary disputes the notion of radicalization in Kashmir. "I don't see this problem in Kashmir with the prism of radicalization," he said.

Professor Noor Ahmad Baba, a political analyst based in Srinagar, the main city in the Muslim-majority region under lockdown for the past five months, echoed similar sentiments. "India should not follow China because India has a claim to constituent democracy," Baba said.

Meanwhile, a senior police official in Kashmir confirmed Rawat's claims, stating that a "deradicalization" center in Kashmir is under consideration. "The Jammu and Kashmir police department has conceptualized one de-radicalization center for which funds have been granted by the Ministry of Home Affairs, but it is yet to be established," the official, who wished to remain anonymous, told the media.

Kashmir's police chief, Dilbagh Singh, also endorsed the idea of "deradicalization" centers in Kashmir. "If any such facility comes up in Kashmir, that will be a good sign. It'll definitely help people, especially those who have gone astray," Singh said.

However, Zafar Chowdhary disagreed with the "radicalization theory about Kashmir." "I don't see this problem in Kashmir with the prism of radicalization," he said.

Ajai Sahni, founding member and executive director of the Institute of Conflict Management in New Delhi, expressed concern over Rawat's political statements, stating, "It is the most unfortunate thing that a man of his stature is lowering the stature of the Indian army by making such political statements."

Retired Air Vice Marshal Kapil Kak, who has been critical of the Indian government's move to abrogate Article 370 in Kashmir, voiced his reservations against sending children to "deradicalization" camps. "There is no denying that some extremists do try to influence people in Kashmir, but it is not politically correct to raise this issue to otherwise Kashmiris. Kids being put up in deradicalization camps is a horrendous proposition," Kak said.

Kak also expressed concerns over the increasing "politicization of military and militarization of politics," which, according to him, does not bode well for India's democracy.

Gazala Wahab, executive editor of Force, India's leading magazine on national security, suggested that the politicization of the Indian army has been a "slow and insidious process." "Of course, this is extremely worrisome. A politicized military is the complete negation of democracy. In a multi-cultural, multi-religious country like India, a partisan military will be disastrous," Wahab said.

Title: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi Defends ACA Amidst Bipartisan Vote on Healthcare Bill

Article:

In a recent development, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) has expressed her continued support for the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, following a bipartisan vote on a bill that allows insurers to offer health plans that do not comply with federal laws.

On NBC's Meet the Press, Pelosi stated, "I have full confidence, as do my members, however they voted on this. This is political; they respond politically." She added that the number of Democrats supporting the ACA has remained relatively stable over the past few months, with 30 Democrats voting with Republicans on other House bills not endorsed by the president or Pelosi.

The bill in question, which allows insurers to keep health plans that do not meet federal laws, is unlikely to progress to a Senate vote. However, Pelosi suggested that House Democrats could use the vote to demonstrate their opposition to a law that may be unpopular in their districts.

Pelosi acknowledged the challenges faced by the federal health exchange website, HealthCare.gov, but emphasized that Democrats remain committed to the ACA. "I will tell you this: Democrats stand tall in support of the Affordable Care Act," she said.

Instead of focusing on the issues with the law, such as the malfunctioning website and the president's broken promise to allow insurers to offer customers their old plans, Pelosi chose to focus on positive developments. She highlighted states with successful state-run health exchanges, such as California and Kentucky, which are enrolling customers and praising the affordability of the plans.

For instance, California announced on Friday that it would soon offer online enrollment for the Small Business Health Options Program for businesses with fewer than 50 employees. As of November 12, approximately 60,000 people had selected insurance plans through the state's exchange.

Pelosi's comments come as Democrats prepare for re-election after a rocky start to the federal health exchange. The exact future of the ACA remains uncertain, but Pelosi's statements indicate a determination to maintain support for the law amidst ongoing challenges and political divisions.

Title: Michigan Attorney General Files Emergency Motion to Stop Jill Stein's Recount Request

Article:

Michigan Attorney General Bill Schuette, a Republican, has filed an emergency motion with the Michigan Supreme Court to stop the recount request by Dr. Jill Stein, the Green Party candidate in the 2016 presidential election. The motion aims to bypass the Court of Appeals to ensure a timely process.

In a statement, Schuette's office explained that Michigan voters rejected Stein's candidacy by a significant margin, but her refusal to accept the state-verified result poses an expensive and risky threat to taxpayers and abuses the intent of Michigan law. The motion requests the court to end the recount that Stein is pursuing in violation of Michigan laws that protect the integrity of elections.

Stein filed a request last week for a recount of Michigan's vote in the 2016 election after a narrow margin made the state the last to be called. President-elect Donald Trump won Michigan's 16 electoral votes by a margin of 0.2 percentage points, or just under 10,000 votes out of over 5.5 million cast.

Stein is also fighting efforts to halt the recount in Wisconsin, where Trump supporters have also tried to stop the recount in progress. In a statement, Stein's attorney, Matthew D. Brinckerhoff, said, "The Jill Stein Campaign plans to intervene and join the Wisconsin Elections Commission in defending the recount. Citizens in Wisconsin and across the country have made it clear that they want a recount and deserve to see this process through to ensure integrity in the vote."

In an interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper, Stein defended her decision to request a recount in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania – three traditionally blue swing states that proved critical to Trump's upset victory. Stein argued that predictors suggest that any tampering would be most likely to be discovered in the three states where they are looking. Stein also stated that without counting paper votes, it would be impossible to determine if any tampering occurred.

Title: Tech Investor Roger McNamee Warns of Threats to Democracy, Public Health, and Privacy Posed by Social Media, Particularly Facebook

Article:

In his new book, "Zucked: Waking Up to the Facebook Catastrophe" (Penguin), longtime tech investor Roger McNamee, who advised Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg in the early years of the company, argues that Facebook poses a threat to democracy, public health, and users' privacy.

In an interview on "CBS This Morning" on Monday, McNamee stated that Facebook, along with other internet giants like Google, have created products that exploit the weakest elements of human psychology to create habits and addictions. He claims that these companies did not take sufficient steps to safeguard users from potential misuse by malicious actors.

McNamee attributes Facebook's success in creating a revolutionary social media platform, which has been beneficial for advertisers, as the root of the problem. He argues that Facebook's ability to target users specifically, which allowed foreign actors to interfere in elections and referendums, also allows advertisers to reach their desired audience effectively.

McNamee criticizes Facebook for alleged instances of exploiting minors, citing two recent cases where Facebook was accused of charging minors for games and spying on users' activities. In response, Facebook stated, "We take criticism seriously. Over the past two years, we've fundamentally changed how we operate to better protect the safety and security of people using Facebook."

McNamee challenges Facebook's assertion that it has responded to issues or bad actors on the platform, stating that there have been cases where Facebook has been called out and did not change. He points to instances such as the Department of Housing and Urban Development citing Facebook for advertising tools that allowed discrimination in violation of the Fair Housing Act, and the Federal Trade Commission's investigation into Facebook for improperly handling user data, which led to the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

McNamee characterizes Facebook as being in a state of a 15-year apology tour, maintaining a black box that prevents users from inspecting what is happening on the platform, and then apologizing and promising to do better. He emphasizes the need for investigations into these tech companies to understand the issues and make informed decisions as voters and citizens.

"Zucked: Waking Up to the Facebook Catastrophe" by Roger McNamee (Penguin) is available in hardcover, eBook, and audio formats via Amazon.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Hardline Immigration Measures in DACA Negotiations

Article:

The Trump administration has issued a list of hardline immigration demands, including funding for a border wall with Mexico and restrictions on children from Central America, as its first move in negotiations for a deal to allow young undocumented migrants known as Dreamers to stay in the U.S. legally. The list, which also includes withholding federal grants for "sanctuary cities" and limiting legal immigration, has been met with rejection by Democrats, who have labeled it "immoral" and "far beyond what is reasonable."

The list of principles also calls for a points-based system for migrants to gain entry to the U.S. and a reduction in family-based green cards issued to spouses and minor children of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents.

In response, Democrats and advocacy groups for Dreamers have expressed horror and condemnation. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat from New Mexico and chair of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, stated that Democrats would use "every leverage point we have at our disposal to protect these Dreamers."

Last month, the Trump administration announced plans to end Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA), a program established by the Obama administration that issued renewable two-year permits to people brought to the country illegally as children, shielding them from deportation and allowing them to work and attend school. About 690,000 recipients are enrolled in the program, with the last such work permits due to expire in March 2018.

Congressional Democratic leaders had been optimistic about striking a deal, but the new list of demands has been met with criticism. Senate minority leader Chuck Schumer and House minority leader Nancy Pelosi said in a joint statement that the list "goes so far beyond what is reasonable" and "fails to represent any attempt at compromise."

Trump has previously stated that funding for the wall could be addressed separately and suggested that he did not expect it to be included in any DACA bill. Lujan Grisham also condemned the use of the futures of hundreds of thousands of people to further White House policy goals.

While Trump's list will appeal to a number of conservative Republicans, some lawmakers in the party are wary of sweeping reforms. At a Senate hearing last week, Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina who has proposed legislation to protect DACA recipients, warned, "If Congress has proven an extraordinary ability to do anything, it's to fail at comprehensive immigration reform."

Title: Conservative Book Club Reveals Top 10 Conservative Books and Movies of 2016

Article:

Christopher Malagisi, the editor-in-chief of the Conservative Book Club, has curated a list of the best books and movies for conservatives in 2016. In an exclusive end-of-the-year video interview for the ███ News Foundation, Malagisi discusses the top 10 conservative books, five runners-up, and the top seven conservative movies of the year.

The top ten books on the list include:
1. "The Righteous Mind: Why Good People are Divided by Politics and Religion" by Jonathan Haidt
2. "The Benedict Option: A Strategy for Christians in a Post-Christian Nation" by Rod Dreher
3. "The Conservative Sensibility" by George Will
4. "The Tyranny of Cliches: How the French Political Class Has Hijacked the French Revolution" by Pascal Bruckner
5. "The Strange Death of Europe: Immigration, Identity, Islam" by Douglas Murray
6. "The Right to Be Right: Ex exposing the Tyranny of Political Correctness" by Ben Shapiro
7. "The Art of the Deal: The Most Popular Business Book of All Time" by Donald J. Trump
8. "The City and the Swamp: How the Building of Rome Saved Civilization" by Victor Davis Hanson
9. "The War on History: The Cultural Revolution at 50" by Victor Davis Hanson
10. "The Devil's Pleasure Palace: The Cult of Critical Theory and the Subversion of the West" by Michael Walsh

Authors making the honorable mention list include Ann Coulter, Megyn Kelly, Brad Thor, Phyllis Schlafly, and a graphic novel creator.

Some of the top conservative movies of 2016 include:
1. "13 Hours"
2. "Hell or High Water"
3. "Hacksaw Ridge"
4. "Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party"
5. "Captain America: Civil War"
6. "Risen"
7. "Silence"

Malagisi believes that American culture has been dominated by the left, and that students are not being taught why America is exceptional. He views conservatism as the preservation of the best from 2,500 years of human history that culminated in the U.S. Constitution guaranteeing liberty and rights previously unknown across the planet. In America's form of government, citizens were entrusted to run their own republic and have great capacity to be self-governing, with only a limited government that was to be held accountable by the people.

Malagisi questions how people can preserve what they do not understand, and suggests that people can learn more about politics by engaging the culture through entertainment, whether it is books, movies, TV, music, or art. This is why Malagisi's work is focused on books, movies, and TV at the successful Conservative Book Club, an organization with some 850,000 members.

For more information on the Conservative Book Club, visit their user-friendly website or follow them on Facebook or Twitter @ConservBookClub. It is noted that Mrs. Thomas does not necessarily support or endorse the products, services, or positions promoted in any advertisement contained in the article, and does not have control over or receive compensation from any advertiser.

Title: Clinton Urges Swift Action on Syria's Chemical Weapons as Diplomatic Solution Emerges

Article:

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has stated that any move by Syria to surrender its chemical weapons to international control would be an "important step" amid signs of a diplomatic solution in the international crisis over Syria. Clinton made these comments during a visit to the White House, following U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's statement in London that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad could avoid a military strike by surrendering all his chemical weapons within a week.

Clinton expressed skepticism about Assad's compliance, stating, "This cannot be another excuse for delay or obstruction." She added, "Russia has to support the international community's efforts sincerely or be held to account."

Clinton's comments came after she met with President Barack Obama and attended the White House Forum to Combat Wildlife Trafficking. She described the Assad regime's use of chemical weapons as a violation of a global norm that is fundamental to the international order.

The White House is seeking Congress's approval for a military strike against Syria's government in response to a chemical weapons attack. However, a new proposal suggests that Syria could avoid a strike by turning over its chemical weapons stockpiles. Clinton credited Kerry and the Russian government for proposing this solution.

Clinton emphasized the need to address Syria's chemical weapons threat "as swiftly and comprehensively as possible." She called on Russia to support the international community's efforts or face accountability.

The Obama administration is stepping up pressure on a skeptical Congress to support U.S. military action in Syria, despite considering the Russian proposal to place Syria's chemical weapons under international control. Obama is conducting a series of television interviews and is due to visit the Capitol to make his case to lawmakers before delivering a televised address from the White House.

Syria's Foreign Minister Walid al-Moualem has welcomed the Russian proposal to avert U.S. strikes by putting Syria's chemical weapons under international control and quickly dismantling them. The Obama administration has expressed deep skepticism about this proposal and does not want it to be used as a stalling tactic.

The United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is considering asking the Security Council to demand Syria move its chemical arms stocks to Syrian sites where they can be safely stored and destroyed. Britain and France have given the idea tentative support.

The intensifying lobbying by the Obama administration comes ahead of a crucial U.S. Senate test vote expected on Wednesday on whether to authorize military action in response to last month's chemical weapons attack against Syrian civilians. Some members of Congress have expressed doubts about military action, and polls indicate that Americans, weary after wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, strongly oppose military action.

Mike Rogers, Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee and a supporter of strikes, said Obama had "fumbled" the message on Syria and faced a critical moment. Assad, in an interview with CBS television, denied any link between his government and the suspected Aug. 21 chemical attack near Damascus that U.S. officials say killed over 1,400 people. If there were strikes against Syria, the United States "should expect everything," Assad said.

Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democratic chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, suggested that Russia could be most effective in encouraging Assad to stop the use of chemical weapons and place all his chemical munitions under United Nations control until they can be destroyed.

A survey by USA Today on Monday found majorities of both the Senate and House remained uncommitted on whether to back military action, complicating predictions about the outcome. A fraction of lawmakers - 22 senators and 22 House members - are on record as supporting strikes, with 19 senators and 130 House members saying they are against.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee narrowly passed a resolution last week that prohibited the insertion of U.S. ground combat troops in Syria and limited the intervention to a maximum of 90 days. With the hunt on for more votes, other alternatives are being explored. Representative Chris van Hollen, a Maryland Democrat, is writing a resolution with Democrat Gerald Connolly of Virginia that would be narrower than the Senate resolution. The resolution would make it clear that the only purpose of military action is to deter Assad from future use of chemical weapons.

Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a North Dakota Democrat, is working with Democrat Joe Manchin of West Virginia on an alternative that would give the Assad government 45 days to sign an international chemical weapons ban and begin the process of turning over its weapons. "During this time, the U.S. would work to build international support and create a global response on the use of chemical weapons in Syria," Heitkamp said.

Title: Giuliani Disputes Racism Claims in Eric Garner's Death

 Article:

Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, a Republican, has stated that racism was not a factor in the death of Eric Garner last July, as police officer Daniel Pantaleo used a chokehold while attempting to arrest him. Giuliani cited two reasons to support his claim: the presence of a black sergeant at the scene, and the assertion that any suspect under similar circumstances would have been treated the same.

Protests erupted in New York City and across the country following Wednesday's announcement that Pantaleo would not be indicted in Garner's death. The protesters have drawn parallels between Garner's death and the death of Michael Brown, a black youth in Ferguson, Missouri, who was shot last August by white policeman Darren Wilson. A grand jury also failed to indict Wilson, leading to protests in Ferguson and several other cities.

Giuliani accused New York Democrat Mayor Bill de Blasio, civil rights activist Al Sharpton, and others of tearing down respect for the criminal justice system by suggesting racism was involved in the Garner incident. He argued that such comments contributed to the atmosphere of protests and, in some cases, violence.

Giuliani maintained it was racist to focus on the "handful" of incidents where blacks were killed by police, rather than the numbers who died from black-on-black crime. He stated that police should never kill anyone unjustifiably but that the majority of time should be spent addressing the high rates of crime within the black community.

In the aftermath of the grand jury announcement, Giuliani suggested that Mayor de Blasio should emphasize patience and calm and focus on the ways people in the community are actually victimized if he truly cares about them. Giuliani also criticized New York Democrat Rep. Charlie Rangel for stating that it was "totally impossible to believe that someone can die, and nobody is indicted."

Giuliani suggested that activists like Sharpton could accomplish something constructive if they spoke about crime in the black community with the same passion and intention as they did in the "few situations where police shoot someone." He argued that both Garner and Brown had committed crimes and that perhaps they "would not be dead today" if they had not resisted arrest.

Giuliani also defended the grand jury process, stating that he had always found grand juries to be "extraordinarily conscientious citizens" who take their oath and the process very seriously.

Title: Obama Distances Himself from Iraq Troop Withdrawal, Citing Iraqi Government's Rejection of U.S. Forces

Article:

President Barack Obama has distanced himself from the complete withdrawal of U.S. forces from Iraq, a policy he had long touted as a significant foreign policy achievement. In a press conference on Saturday, Obama blamed his predecessor, George W. Bush, for the absence of American troops in Iraq and rejected the assertion that he could have left a small peacekeeping force in the war-torn nation.

During the 2011 troop withdrawal, three years after the initial authorization, and following a successful re-election campaign, the full removal of U.S. forces from Iraq was cast as the White House's most significant foreign policy achievement. Obama had promised this during the earliest days of his first presidential campaign in 2008.

However, with the terrorist group Islamic State (IS) gaining territory in Iraq, Obama has begun to adjust the narrative. "What I just find interesting is the degree to which this issue keeps on coming up, as if this was my decision," Obama said. "Under the previous administration, we had turned over the country to a sovereign, democratically elected Iraqi government."

Obama's new take on the 2011 U.S. troop withdrawal differs greatly from how he portrayed it in 2012, during his re-election campaign against Republican Mitt Romney. While it's true the administration did support keeping a small residual force in Iraq, Obama frequently took credit for fully ending American involvement in Iraq and for leaving no U.S. boots on the ground in that country.

In an October 2012 debate with Romney, the president seemed to deny that he supported a status of forces agreement with the Iraqi government, a deal that would have formally allowed American troops to remain in Iraq and would have protected them from prosecution in Iraqi courts.

The White House's change in stance on Iraq comes at a time when Obama's broader foreign policy is under fire across the political spectrum. In an interview with The Atlantic over the weekend, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, Obama's 2008 Democratic primary rival and the party's 2016 presidential front-runner, questioned the administration's underlying foreign policy principle.

Republicans have been harsher in their critiques, charging that Obama is proving his incompetence with his handling of the Iraq crisis. "Truly, it seems as if there is no threat that has not managed to catch him utterly off-guard," said Rep. Trent Franks, Arizona Republican.

Analysts say the president is entirely correct about the Iraqi government having no interest in allowing U.S. forces to remain in the country. Indeed, Iraqi leaders refused to guarantee American troops immunity from prosecution in Iraqi courts, which the administration viewed as a necessary prerequisite for allowing any kind of follow-on force.

Although the Iraqis, to some degree, kicked out American troops, Obama portrayed the withdrawal as proof that the U.S. was leaving behind a sovereign, largely peaceful Iraq. However, with the Islamic State group now in control of key areas across Iraq, including the nation's largest dam, that claim has been debunked, some analysts say.

"The bigger issue is that in pulling out he tended to emphasize the story, as Bush had, that we had stood up a lasting, stable government and a functional military," said Benjamin Friedman, a research fellow in defense and homeland security studies at the libertarian Cato Institute. "That was always doubtful and has now been proven wrong."

Title: Macron Urges Caution on Iran, Trade, and Climate in Interview Ahead of U.S. Visit

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron has emphasized the strength of his relationship with U.S. President Donald Trump ahead of his visit to the United States this week, but also cautioned the president on his stances regarding Iran, climate change, and international trade. In an exclusive interview with Fox News on Friday, Macron stated, "You can not make a trade war with your allies. It’s too complicated."

The visit, which includes a dinner with Trump and first lady Melania Trump at Mount Vernon on Monday and a state dinner at the White House on Tuesday, will mark Trump's first official state visit since taking office last year. Macron is also scheduled to make a joint address to Congress on Wednesday.

Macron described his relationship with Trump as "very special," suggesting they share a commitment to fighting terrorism and reducing the influence of rogue nations and dictators. However, he urged Trump to maintain the Iran Nuclear Deal, in which economic sanctions are lifted in exchange for Iran winding down its nuclear program, ahead of a May 12 sanctions deadline.

Macron also expressed optimism that Trump will exempt European countries from the international tariffs he intends to impose on aluminum and steel. He reiterated, "You don’t make trade war with your allies."

Last year, Trump announced the U.S. would withdraw from the Paris Agreement, a 2015 agreement in which world leaders agreed to reduce carbon emissions. Macron, who was elected last year on a centrist, anti-establishment platform, also attempted to address a controversy about whether he persuaded Trump to keep U.S. forces in Syria.

Macron suggested the U.S. maintain a diplomatic presence in Syria, stating, "We will have to build a new Syria after war." He also expressed his belief in the U.S.'s important role in maintaining peace and multilateralism.

Macron also stated he would ask Congress for its support in efforts to combat terrorism and rein in rogue nations. He described the U.S. as "one of the last resorts" for peace and multilateralism. Regarding the ongoing investigation into whether the 2016 Trump presidential campaign colluded with Russia to influence the outcome of the White House race, Macron said, "I’m not the one to judge" Trump over current controversies or investigations.

Macron concluded, "We are very much attached to the same values...especially liberty and peace." He added, "The U.S. today has a very strong role to play for peace in different regions of the world and especially the Middle East."

Title: Discrepancies Between Michael Cohen's Plea and Donald Trump Jr.'s Testimony Raise Questions

Article:

The recent guilty plea by Michael Cohen, former attorney to President Donald Trump, has raised questions about Donald Trump Jr.'s testimony to Congress regarding his family's real estate negotiations with powerful Russians.

In September 2017, Donald Trump Jr. told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he was only "peripherally aware" of negotiations that Cohen has admitted to carrying on through June 2016. However, Cohen's guilty plea states that he had briefed Trump's family members about his talks, although the court documents do not specify who.

Trump Jr. also told Senate investigators that he was not aware that Cohen had reached out to the press secretary for Vladimir Putin as part of his talks with Moscow about a putative new Trump Tower project there. Cohen had previously testified that although he emailed Putin's spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, he had not heard back, and the discussions with people in Moscow concluded by January 2016.

However, in his guilty plea, Cohen acknowledged that Peskov had responded to him and he and others had continued negotiations about the project until after Trump had become the presumptive GOP nominee.

Trump Jr.'s answers allude to a number of prospective projects; he was asked by Senate investigators about news reports about a Trump Tower Moscow negotiation that took place in 2015 and 2016, which he acknowledged but did not detail.

The contrasts between Cohen's statement and Trump Jr.'s version of events may complicate potential legal problems for Trump Jr. Although seldom prosecuted, lying to Congress is against the law—as evidenced by Cohen's plea.

Sen. Richard Burr, R-N.C., chairman of the Senate intelligence committee, said he has made referrals to the office of Justice Department special counsel Robert Mueller because he said he believed people had not given his committee the truth. He declined to identify who might be involved or how often he has referred cases to Mueller, but Burr did allude to Cohen's plea as an example of what he called the consequences that could be involved.

"One instance just highlighted of late is that the special prosecutor made an indictment yesterday using the transcripts of interviews we have done in our committee to indict somebody for lying to Congress," Burr said on Friday.

"It's a loud message to everybody that is interviewed by our committee... If you lie to us, we're going to go after you."

Title: Kavanaugh Stresses Judicial Independence, Refuses to Criticize Trump in Senate Confirmation Hearing

Article:

In a three-day Senate confirmation hearing, Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh emphasized the judiciary's authority to check the power of the White House, but declined to comment on President Donald Trump's character or his criticism of the judiciary. On the second day of questioning, Kavanaugh faced pressure from Democrats over newly released emails that highlighted his views on abortion and racial issues.

The documents, released on Thursday, dated from Kavanaugh's service in the White House under President George W. Bush more than a decade ago. Democrats had objected to an earlier decision by the Senate Judiciary Committee's Republican leadership not to make the emails public.

Throughout the hearing, protesters hostile to Kavanaugh repeatedly interrupted the proceedings. Despite the disruptions, Kavanaugh remained in good humor, making no gaffes that could potentially derail his confirmation in a Senate narrowly controlled by Trump's fellow Republicans.

Some liberals have expressed concern that Kavanaugh could be a rubber stamp for Trump and protect him from lawsuits and investigations. When asked by Democratic Senator Cory Booker whether he was picked because of an expectation of loyalty to Trump, Kavanaugh responded, "My only loyalty is to the Constitution. I'm an independent judge."

Kavanaugh refused to say whether he had "the greatest respect" for Trump, a phrase Booker said he had used when describing Bush. Democratic Senator Dick Durbin said Kavanaugh's nomination comes at a time when Trump poses a threat to America's rule of law and is facing an ongoing special counsel investigation.

Kavanaugh said his 12 years as a judge demonstrated he was unafraid "to invalidate executive power when it violates the law." If confirmed, Kavanaugh is seen as likely to tilt the top U.S. court even further to the right.

In a 2003 email released on Thursday, Kavanaugh suggested striking a line from a draft opinion piece that had stated, "It is widely accepted by legal scholars across the board that Roe v. Wade and its progeny are the settled law of the land," saying that the Supreme Court could overturn it.

Asked about that document, Kavanaugh said he suggested the change because he thought the draft language was overstating the thinking of legal scholars at the time. He again declined to say whether the landmark 1973 ruling that legalized abortion nationwide, Roe v. Wade, was correctly decided, although he indicated - as he did on Wednesday - that it was a decision that merited respect as "an important precedent of the Supreme Court."

The hearing opened with Democrats complaining that various documents had not already been made public by the committee's Republican leaders. They were released by the committee minutes later. Booker called the process used by the committee to decide which documents to make public "a bit of a sham," a characterization rejected by the panel's Republican chairman, Chuck Grassley. Booker said he was willing to face possible punishment under Senate rules by releasing the documents himself, although Republicans said they had already agreed to release them.

Trump picked Kavanaugh, 53, to replace Justice Anthony Kennedy, who announced his retirement in June. The committee considering Kavanaugh's nomination will hear from outside witnesses on Friday before the hearing wraps up. Republicans hope the full Senate can vote on the nomination close to the time the Supreme Court's new term starts on Oct 1.

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein Remains in Office Despite Reports of Resignation or Dismissal

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein remains in his position, contrary to reports on Monday that suggested he had resigned or offered to do so. The White House confirmed that President Donald Trump and Rosenstein had an extended conversation about news stories published last week regarding Rosenstein's alleged discussions about secretly recording the president or invoking the 25th amendment to remove him from office.

The two are scheduled to meet on Thursday, following the president's return from the United Nations General Assembly meeting in New York. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated in a statement that the meeting was at Rosenstein's request. The White House did not comment on reports that Rosenstein was expected to be fired imminently or had resigned.

Rosenstein oversees the investigation of Russian election interference and links between the Trump campaign and Moscow. The New York Times reported last week that he discussed secretly recording the president and invoking the 25th amendment to remove Trump from office. Rosenstein has since disputed the report, stating it was "inaccurate."

If Rosenstein were to leave his position, it would potentially throw into question the oversight of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation. Under the Department of Justice succession statute, Solicitor General Noel Francisco would be left in charge of supervising Mueller. However, Trump might also be able to appoint a temporary replacement on an "acting" basis for up to 210 days, who would need to have passed Senate confirmation for another post or be a senior official from a relevant department.

As anticipation of Rosenstein's departure grew on Monday, Democrats in Congress and former federal prosecutors called on Republicans to speak out in favor of protecting the Mueller investigation. Representative Val Demings of Florida stated, "Congress must take immediate steps." Former US attorney for the southern district of New York, Preet Bharara, tweeted, "Time to protect the Mueller investigation. Now."

Rosenstein was overseeing Mueller's work after Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself due to his contacts with Russian officials during the Trump campaign. Trump has repeatedly attacked Sessions for that move. In overseeing the special counsel, Rosenstein is responsible for approving major new directions in the investigation, for signing off on the budget, and for meeting regularly with Mueller to assess the investigation's progress.

For more than a year, Trump has railed against the Russia investigation, calling it a "witch hunt" and accusing the prosecutors involved, many of whom, like Rosenstein and Mueller, are Republicans, of harboring ulterior partisan motives. Trump's relationship with Rosenstein has been strained. The president has tweeted that Rosenstein is "weak," but in August he also said the relationship was "fantastic."

Frustration moved in both directions, with Rosenstein reportedly growing "angry" at Trump in May 2017, after Trump used a memo written by Rosenstein to justify the firing of FBI Director James Comey. It was in the sensitive aftermath of that firing that Rosenstein suggested recording the president, the Times reported. One source told the Times Rosenstein had suggested recording the president "sarcastically"; others said he was serious.

Sources for the Times report included people familiar with memos kept by former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe about his conversations with Rosenstein. McCabe was fired by Trump in March, days before he was due to retire. In a statement on Monday, amid speculation that McCabe desired to undercut Rosenstein – his onetime superior at the justice department who played a direct role in the firing of McCabe's former boss, Comey – McCabe denied any hand in leaking the contents of his memos to the media.

"To be clear, I had no role in providing information of any kind to the media stories about events following director Comey's firing," McCabe said.

The 25th amendment, ratified after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, provides for various paths of presidential succession, including in case of the president being deemed "unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" by the vice-president and a majority of cabinet officers. At a briefing to discuss the UN General Assembly, top foreign policy officials were peppered with questions about Rosenstein and the 25th amendment.

"Literally, I have never been in the White House when that conversation has happened," said the US envoy to the UN, Nikki Haley. "I'm not aware of any cabinet members that are even talking about that. It is completely and totally absurd." Secretary of State Mike Pompeo added, "There was no discussion with me about the 25th amendment, so you can now report that there were two senior leaders who said your question is ludicrous."

Title: Politics and the Olympics: A Century of Intrusion

Article:

The Olympics, an event intended to celebrate sports and goodwill, has a long history of political intrusion. The upcoming Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, in February 2014, will mark the first time since 2000 that the United States will not be represented by a president, vice president, first lady, or former president. Instead, President Obama has chosen to send athletes such as openly gay tennis great Billie Jean King and two-time hockey medalist Caitlin Cahow to represent the country.

The Olympic Charter bans any "kind of demonstration or political, religious or racial propaganda" from Olympic sites. However, political protest and international gamesmanship have been a near-constant during modern games. The Council on Foreign Relations hosts a slide show highlighting controversies over the past century, narrated by NPR contributor Frank Deford.

The Olympics have been used as propaganda tools during significant historical events, such as the Cold War. The "Miracle on Ice" upset win by the U.S. men's hockey team over the Soviets in the winter of 1980 was a source of great pride for the U.S., while the Soviets celebrated their victory in men's basketball in the summer of 1972, the first time the Americans had lost an Olympic basketball game.

Political tensions have also led to boycotts. The last Olympics held in Russia, in the summer of 1980, saw a U.S.-led boycott by more than 60 nations in protest of the invasion of Afghanistan by the Soviet Union. In retaliation, the Soviets led more than a dozen socialist countries in refusing to participate in the 1984 Summer Olympics, which were held in Los Angeles.

In 1988, the games in Sydney were the first Summer Games since 1972 that were not the subject of a formal boycott. In 1976, some African nations stayed home from Montreal to protest New Zealand's inclusion due to its rugby team's recent tour in South Africa, which was during the apartheid era. China and Taiwan have also had frequent spats over the freedom to compete, with China staying home between 1956 and 1980, and Taiwan withdrawing from the 1976 games after China pressured Canada not to allow the island nation to compete.

China was eager to showcase its economic success at the Beijing Summer Games in 2008, but many groups protested the country's human rights record. Formal boycotts did not get off the ground, and President George W. Bush attended the Beijing Olympics, but both Obama and his GOP presidential rival that year, Arizona Sen. John McCain, said they would have stayed home if they were in the White House.

In 2014, the political climate surrounding the Sochi Olympics is once again a topic of discussion, with some U.S. representatives calling for the games to be moved out of Sochi due to Russia's movement of troops into Georgia in 2008. The recent enactment of an anti-gay law in Russia has also sparked controversy and anger among American gay-rights groups.

Historian and journalist Eric Marcus notes that it is "incredibly naive to think somehow you can screen out everything that's going on in the world during a given period of time, particularly in a part of the world that's problematic." The Olympics, it seems, will always be a platform for political expression and international gamesmanship.

Title: China Reports Record Rise in Imported COVID-19 Cases as Students and Expats Return Home

Article:

China reported a record rise in imported coronavirus cases on Friday, with all 41 of the new confirmed cases originating from overseas, according to the country's National Health Commission. This brings the total number of such cases to 269, with no locally transmitted cases for the third consecutive day.

The main entry points for the returnees, many of whom are students studying abroad, are Beijing and Shanghai. These students have come back after many campuses in the United States and Europe shut down to stem rapidly rising infection rates there. Additionally, China-based expats have also returned in a flight to safety as businesses begin to reopen.

Since March 11, when the World Health Organization characterized the epidemic as a pandemic, the cumulative number of imported cases in China has risen from 85 to 269, up by 216%. This is outpacing the 98% increase in the cumulative worldwide confirmed cases during the same period, according to Mi Feng, spokesman of the National Health Commission.

Authorities across China are tightening public health measures to prevent the import of the virus and a rebound in cases. Mi stated that China must strictly prevent the import of the virus from overseas and a rebound in cases.

Beijing reported 14 new imported cases on Friday, with five being Chinese students returning from abroad. Shanghai reported a record nine cases, with five students flying back from Britain, France, and Switzerland. The southern provinces of Guangdong, Fujian, and the eastern provinces of Shandong and Zhejiang, as well as Shaanxi and Sichuan, all reported cases.

In response, Guangdong's health commission announced that travelers who enter Guangdong province from abroad will be subject to a 14-day quarantine on arrival, either in personal residences or at a centralized quarantine center at the expense of the traveler.

Infected people have also entered China through the major transport hub of Shenzhen, including people making their way back to the mainland from Hong Kong by land.

While the influx of infections from overseas remains modest, they present a potential threat to Chinese authorities keen to restart factories and get consumers to spend again. Analysts have slashed forecasts for China's first-quarter gross domestic product to levels not seen since the Cultural Revolution ended in 1976, with all sectors of the economy hammered by the coronavirus outbreak this year.

The total number of confirmed cases in mainland China stood at 81,008 at the end of Friday, the health authority said. The death toll was 3,255, up by seven, a much slower rate than at the height of the crisis. The lack of locally transmitted cases for the third day running underscores a recovery that has prompted officials to relax restrictions, even in the virus epicenter of Wuhan.

On Saturday, the official Xinhua news agency reported that commercial outlets in residential communities and villages without existing cases of the virus can resume business, citing the municipal bureau of commerce. The first phase of a clinical trial of a vaccine has also begun, with 36 volunteers undergoing a 14-day quarantine at a centralized location.

Title: Partisan Divide Stalls Defense Spending Bill on Capitol Hill

Article:

The Defense spending bill, which accounts for half of the country's discretionary budget, has become the latest legislation caught in the Capitol Hill partisan divide. For decades, Republicans and Democrats have largely agreed on a bill that pays for troops, ships, and aircraft, and sets military policy.

Last week, the Senate failed to get a vote on the bill due to Majority Leader Harry Reid's reluctance to open contentious issues such as government spying and new sanctions on Iran. With world leaders nearing a deal to curb Iran's nuclear enrichment program, Reid aimed to avoid a vote on these issues being tacked onto the National Defense Authorization Act (an interim deal was reached this weekend).

Republicans argued that the leaders of the Democratic-controlled Senate made a power grab and demanded they be allowed to offer amendments and get votes on them, a practice that has been the norm for decades. They also accused Reid of using too heavy a hand in running the chamber, as evidenced by the rules change last week on filibusters. The defense bill could have been completed months ago, but it was put off until the last minute to spare President Obama a few national security black eyes.

Sen. Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma, the top Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, pleaded for some amendments, offering a whittled list of 25 GOP amendments from the list of 350 put forth by members of both parties. Reid was not interested in allowing the last bill likely out of Congress this year to become a magnet for other matters.

"Everyone has to understand this is not going to be an open amendment process," Reid told his colleagues as he sought to limit amendments and wrap up the $625 billion defense measure after some three days of debate. He contends GOP delaying tactics have forced his hand.

With just a few legislative days left in the year, the latest machinations leave in jeopardy a bill that authorizes money for personnel, war-fighting equipment, and the conflict in Afghanistan. The Senate has to pass its bill and reconcile it with a version the House approved in June.

If the Senate cannot break the impasse when lawmakers return on Dec. 9, troops will still get paid, and fighter jets will continue to be built, thanks to the separate, all-encompassing spending bill. However, major policy changes might be lost, including several new measures to stem the epidemic of sexual assaults in the military.

Doing without an authorization bill for the first time in half a century also would represent the fall of one of last bastions of comity in Congress.

Sen. Carl Levin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said, "I'm nowhere close to giving up on completing the defense authorization bill, even though we will only have days, not weeks, to complete it."

The dysfunction is "approaching an all-time low," said Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., who has participated in far more cordial, as well as more open, debates of the defense bill in decades past.

In decades past, the leadership often stepped aside and let the chairman and ranking member take charge, debating the bill for hours around-the-clock, allowing numerous Republican and Democratic amendments and plenty of votes. Amendments were offered, accepted, or rejected. Some senators eventually would abandon amendments under the long hours that former Sen. John Tower, R-Texas, would make them be there for the debate. The Senate typically spent more than a week on the bill, Monday through Friday and sometimes Saturday, rather than the current schedule of Tuesday to Thursday.

This past week, the Senate voted on two amendments dealing with the fate of the detention center in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Reid sought votes on measures addressing sexual assault in the services after some five hours of debate on Wednesday. Republicans objected as they pressed for other amendments.

By comparison, the House considered 172 amendments when it debated its version of the defense bill in June. It agreed to 148 of them by voice vote and held 21 recorded votes. Seven amendments were added to the bill through recorded votes over three days of debate, and 14 were rejected. The Senate purposely avoids the time constraints imposed in the House. But votes on just two amendments to the Senate defense bill, plus the measures on sexual assault, before final passage would have been an unusually low number for such a far-reaching measure. Inhofe said that in the past 17 years, the Senate has debated the bill an average of nine days, held an average of 11 roll call votes, and adopted nearly 100 amendments by voice vote.

The impasse, combined with the brouhaha over how Democrats unilaterally changed the Senate's filibuster rules on Thursday, left the Senate's defense stalwarts pessimistic about the road ahead. "There's a lot of turmoil, and I'd like to tell you that the 2014 elections will fix everything," McCain said. "I'm not sure that's the case. I think the problems go deeper than that."

Title: House Democrats Announce Articles of Impeachment Against President Trump and US-Canada-Mexico Trade Deal

Article:

WASHINGTON — House Democrats unveiled two articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump on Tuesday and simultaneously announced a pending deal on a new U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact. The coincidental timing of these events allows endangered House Democrats to return home for the holidays with bipartisan landmark legislation to discuss, in addition to the impeachment proceedings.

The deal, known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), was the result of intense final negotiations over the weekend. The agreement was announced Tuesday morning in the U.S. due to a signing ceremony in Mexico City scheduled for Tuesday afternoon with officials from the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is demonstrating the Democrats' ability to accomplish legislative goals while pursuing President Trump's impeachment. The pending trade pact, which revamps the 1994 Clinton-era North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), has been a priority for Trump, with some Democrats also seeking improvements to the deal.

Rep. Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.), one of eight members Pelosi tapped to be USMCA negotiators, stated at a news conference Tuesday that Democrats removed onerous provisions the White House wanted. Vice President Mike Pence claimed Democrats "acquiesced"; however, Schakowsky countered that the Trump administration sent a deeply flawed trade deal that would have raised prescription drug prices across North America. The new deal, she said, prevents big pharma from raising the price of prescription drugs across the U.S., Mexico, and Canada.

The House Judiciary Committee will consider the articles of impeachment at an evening session Wednesday, with the full House likely voting next week.

In a separate development, several freshman House Democrats shared their thoughts on the impeachment proceedings. Rep. Lauren Underwood (D-Ill.), the most endangered Illinois House incumbent, discussed the impact of impeachment at Politico's "Women Rule Summit" on Tuesday. Underwood, who flipped a suburban Chicago district voting for Trump in 2016, noted that political corruption is not a foreign concept to her constituents, given Chicago's history.

Another freshman, Democrat Sean Casten, stated that the two narrow articles on abuse of power and obstruction of Congress zero in on "where there's unambiguous, unambiguously clear evidence." Casten, who is making no further pronouncements until he's finished reading the entire record, described the articles as "the closest to no-brainers that I could think of."

Rep. Dan Lipinski (D-Ill.) is facing a Democratic primary challenge from the left. Lipinski, who represents a heavily Democratic district, stated he will "carefully consider" the impeachment articles "in light of the evidence that has been brought forward in the inquiry."

Rep. Bill Foster (D-Ill.) is facing a Democratic primary challenge from the left and has stated flatly that he supports the Articles of Impeachment against President Trump and intends to vote for them on the House floor next week.

Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.), the only Chicago-area Republican, stated that impeachment is "leaving us even more divided than before." Kinzinger added that there will be another presidential election in 11 months, and the voters will have the final say.

Rep. Darin LaHood (R-Ill.) represents a safe GOP downstate district. He stated that Democrats would rather attempt to overturn the results of the 2016 election than let the people decide in November.

Title: Supreme Court's Bostock Decision Casts Doubt on Trump Administration's New Health Care Regulation for LGBTQ Discrimination

Article:

The Trump administration finalized a regulation on Friday that permits health providers to discriminate against LGBTQ patients. However, three days later, the Supreme Court handed down a landmark decision in Bostock v. Clayton County, which has cast the legality of this regulation into serious doubt.

The Court's decision in Bostock does not only question the new health care regulation; it also raises doubts about the Trump administration's opposition to anti-discrimination protections for transgender students. With Bostock, workplace discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity is now likely to be held illegal.

Bostock held that Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which bans discrimination "because of... sex," is broad enough to forbid workplace discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity. If an employer intentionally relies in part on an individual employee's sex when deciding to discharge the employee or if changing the employee's sex would have yielded a different choice by the employer, then an employer violates Title VII, according to Bostock.

For example, if an employer permits male employees to date and have sex with women but doesn't permit female employees to do the same, it engages in forbidden sex discrimination.

Title VII is not the only federal law prohibiting sex discrimination. Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 and the Affordable Care Act also prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex. These provisions apply to nearly all public schools, colleges, universities, and hospitals because nearly all of those institutions receive federal assistance of some kind.

Bostock suggests that neither educational institutions nor health care providers may discriminate against LGBTQ individuals. If that's the case, the Trump administration's new health care regulation should fall. Lawyers challenging anti-LGBTQ discrimination by schools and health providers are likely already notifying judges of the Court's decision in Bostock, and other lawyers are preparing new lawsuits hoping to strike down the new health care regulation.

Both the Affordable Care Act and Title IX ban discrimination "on the basis of sex." Although this language is different from the statutory language in Bostock, which forbids discrimination "because of... sex," the Supreme Court has indicated that the words "on the basis of" and "because of" have the same meaning.

In Franklin v. Gwinnett County Public Schools (1992), the Supreme Court held that Title IX's ban on discrimination "on the basis of sex" imposes the same duty to avoid sexual harassment that Title VII imposes on employers. Similarly, in Safeco Ins. Co. of America v. Burr (2007), the Court considered an amendment to a federal law that changed the language of a statute from "because of" to "based on." But the Court concluded that this amendment did not matter because "there was no indication that this change was meant to be a substantive alteration of the statute's scope."

Until Bostock, the meaning of the word "sex" was hotly contested. Although the Court briefly considered a case brought by a trans plaintiff challenging discrimination by a public school district, the Supreme Court punted that case back down to a lower court. Bostock is the Court's first direct pronouncement on whether anti-LGBTQ discrimination constitutes "sex" discrimination.
