The Obama administration read Obamacare's ban on discrimination "on the basis of sex" broadly and similarly to the way the Supreme Court interpreted the word "sex" in Bostock. The Trump administration's new regulations, by contrast, read the word "sex" much more narrowly. The Trump administration claims that its narrow interpretation reads Obamacare "according to the plain meaning of the word'sex' as male or female and as determined by biology."

When a federal statute is ambiguous and can reasonably be interpreted in multiple ways, the Supreme Court's decisions permit federal regulators to choose from among those reasonable interpretations. However, Bostock eliminates any ambiguity regarding the meaning of the word "sex."

It has now been firmly established by the Supreme Court of the United States that a ban on "sex" discrimination also bans discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity. Bostock, in other words, should establish once and for all that no educational institution or health provider may discriminate against LGBTQ individuals—at least if they wish to receive federal funds.

There is, however, at least one part of the Trump administration's anti-LGBTQ agenda that is likely to survive contact with the courts. In 2017, Trump announced his intention to prohibit transgender service members from openly serving in the military. Although some lower courts struck down this ban, the Supreme Court voted 5-4 to temporarily reinstate the ban.

It's likely that the Court did so because it often defers to the elected branches on questions relating to the military or to national security. Indeed, in Rostker v. Goldberg (1981), the Supreme Court permitted the Selective Service System to engage in sex discrimination. So Rostker suggests that this administration might enjoy similar deference if it wishes to discriminate against transgender service members.

Outside of the military, however, Bostock is a sweeping decision with implications stretching far beyond employment discrimination. Although the trans military ban may survive, much of the rest of the Trump administration's anti-LGBTQ agenda is in serious trouble after Bostock.

Title: Supreme Court Clarifies Conditions for Stripping Immigrant's U.S. Citizenship

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States has ruled that federal law allows courts to revoke the U.S. citizenship of individuals who obtained it through false statements, but only if those false statements contributed to the acquisition of citizenship.

The ruling, in the case of Maslenjak v. United States, was delivered by Justice Elena Kagan and vacated a lower court's decision that stripped Divna Maslenjak, a Serbian immigrant, of her U.S. citizenship.

Maslenjak, along with her husband and two children, sought refugee status in 1998 to flee Bosnia. In 2006, she applied for U.S. citizenship, answering "no" to questions about providing false or misleading information during the immigration process. She became a U.S. citizen in 2007, but her answers were false. Her husband had served in the Bosnian Serb Army.

The Supreme Court's ruling states that the illegal act must have contributed to the obtaining of citizenship. In this case, the Court declared that the government must establish that Maslenjak's lying about her husband's military service was part of the cause of obtaining her own citizenship.

Justice Neil Gorsuch wrote a concurring decision, joined by Justice Clarence Thomas, stating that the majority's framework was too elaborate and suggested a less-elaborate holding for future cases. Justice Samuel Alito also wrote a separate concurring opinion, agreeing with the judgment but expressing a different interpretation of the immigration statute's requirements for false statements.

Ken Klukowski, senior legal editor for ███, covered the case and can be followed on Twitter @kenklukowski.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Rejects President Obama's Budget Proposal, Citing Social Security Changes and Tax Hikes

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has preemptively rejected President Obama's upcoming budget proposal, which reportedly includes tax hikes tied to modest changes in Social Security and other benefit programs. The president is set to unveil his budget on Wednesday, according to a senior administration official.

The administration's plan includes a provision to lower cost-of-living adjustments to Social Security, which would curb the growth in benefits. This move is part of the president's efforts to convince Republicans to accept increased revenues. The official stated that the plan to be unveiled next week "is not a menu of options for them to choose from -- it's a cohesive package."

However, Boehner has expressed opposition to the demand, noting that the president and his party already extracted tax increases on top earners as part of the deal to avert the fiscal crisis at the end of 2012. "In the end, the president got his tax hikes on the wealthy with no corresponding spending cuts. At some point we need to solve our spending problem, and what the president has offered would leave us with a budget that never balances," Boehner said.

Democrats have argued that the recently enacted sequester cuts are too deep and continue to press for tax increases to help close the deficit. Many Democrats oppose drastic changes to entitlements. The inclusion of the Social Security provision by Obama was meant as a gesture to Republicans, but has already drawn the ire of liberal members of Congress.

Boehner suggested the changes did not go far enough to warrant tax increases. "When the president visited the Capitol last month, House Republicans stated a desire to find common ground and urged him not to make savings we agree upon conditional on another round of tax increases. If reports are accurate, the president has not heeded that call," Boehner said. "If the president believes these modest entitlement savings are needed to help shore up these programs, there's no reason they should be held hostage for more tax hikes. That's no way to lead and move the country forward."

Obama's plan calls for additional tax revenue, including a proposal to place limits on tax-preferred retirement accounts for top earners. Obama has also called for limits on tax deductions by top earners, a proposal that could generate about $580 billion in revenue over 10 years. The administration claimed to be offering the Social Security change reluctantly.

The president's budget proposal aims to reduce the deficit by $1.8 trillion over 10 years. The reductions in growth of benefit programs, which would affect veterans, the poor, and older Americans, is sure to anger many Democrats. The inclusion of the Social Security provision in Obama's budget could face tough opposition from liberal members of Congress.

Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., fired off a statement Thursday in response to the rumor that Obama's budget could include the change. "Millions of working people, seniors, disabled veterans, those who have lost a loved one in combat, and women will be extremely disappointed if President Obama caves into the long-standing Republican effort to cut Social Security and benefits for disabled veterans and their survivors through a so-called chained CPI," Sanders said. "In 2008, candidate Barack Obama told the American people that he would not cut Social Security. Having him go back on his word will only add to the rampant political cynicism that our country is experiencing today."

Chained CPI is the Washington term for the revised inflation adjustment that would effectively curb annual increases in a broad swath of government programs, but would have its biggest impact on Social Security. The inflation adjustment would reduce federal spending over 10 years by about $130 billion, according to past White House estimates. Because it also affects how tax brackets are adjusted, it would also generate about $100 billion in higher taxes and affect even middle-income taxpayers.

Obama's budget, to be released next week, comes after the Republican-controlled House and the Democratic-run Senate passed separate and markedly different budget proposals. House Republicans achieved long-term deficit reductions by targeting safety net programs; Democrats instead protected those programs and called for $1 trillion in tax increases. Obama's budget proposal includes features from an offer he made to House Speaker John Boehner during fiscal negotiations last year. Those talks ultimately failed, but Congress did agree to increase tax rates on top earners. The reductions in growth of benefit programs, which would affect veterans, the poor, and older Americans, is sure to anger many Democrats. Labor groups and liberals have long been critical of Obama's offer to Boehner for including such a plan. Obama's new plan would also replace the sequester with other spending cuts. But it will steer clear of major cuts to Medicaid, including tens of billions in reductions to the health care plan for the poor that the administration had proposed only last year.

Title: Walgreens Boots Alliance to Close 200 U.S. Stores, Boosts Cost-Cutting Initiative

Article:

Drugstore chain Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) has announced plans to close approximately 200 U.S. stores as part of its cost-cutting initiative, which is being boosted by an additional $500 million. The company expects to reduce costs by a projected $1.5 billion by the end of fiscal 2017.

In a statement on Thursday, Walgreens stated that the cost savings opportunities were identified through a rigorous analysis, primarily in its Retail Pharmacy USA division. The company plans to close about 200 U.S. stores, reorganize corporate and field operations, drive operating efficiencies, and streamline information technology and other functions.

Philip Caruso, Walgreens' spokesman, stated that the company has not yet decided which stores will be closed, and there is no hard timeline for the store closures during the cost-cutting period. The soon-to-be closed stores make up roughly 2% of the Walgreens' 8,232 drugstores in the United States, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Walgreens also opened 71 new drugstores in this region in the first half of fiscal 2015, including 25 relocations.

Store closings aside, Walgreens reported strong earnings, with shares jumping $4.94, or 5.6%, to $92.62. Walgreens said adjusted second-quarter net earnings increased 33.2% to $1.2 billion. Second-quarter sales also increased 35.5% to $26.6 billion.

The U.S. retail pharmacy division, which includes Walgreens and Duane Reade stores, posted sales of $21 billion in the second quarter, up 7.4% over the year-ago quarter. Total sales in stores open at least a year were up 6.9% over the same quarter a year ago.

In December, Walgreens closed on a deal, valued at close to $16 billion, to purchase the remaining stake of European health and beauty retailer Alliance Boots that it did not already own. The new company, which includes more than 12,800 stores in 11 countries, was renamed Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc., and it took on ticker symbol WBA.

Title: Sarah Palin Compares President Obama to Bernie Madoff, Criticizes GOP at CPAC

Article:

Former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin delivered a fiery speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on Sunday, lambasting President Barack Obama, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, and the Republican Party's post-election efforts.

During her speech, Palin compared President Obama to white-collar criminal Bernie Madoff, stating, "He is considered a good politician, which is like saying Bernie Madoff was a good salesman. The difference being, the president is using our money." She also urged Obama to "step away from the teleprompter and do your job."

Palin's speech was one of the most well-received of the weekend, which featured prominent Republican figures such as Mitt Romney, Jeb Bush, and Marco Rubio. She reserved particular criticism for President Obama, but her barbs were not limited to him. She broadened her criticism to include the "permanent political class" who are in "permanent campaign mode."

"Never before have our challenges been so big and our leaders so small," Palin said.

Palin declined to run for president last year and decided against renewing her contract as a political commentator on Fox News. She stated that she brought a message from the "heartland of America," which was simply that "things are bad out here."

During her more than 26-minute speech, Palin displayed the same renegade sensibility that won her the admiration of many Republicans when she emerged from relative obscurity to become Sen. John McCain's running mate in 2008.

"Now is the time to furlough the consultants," she said, echoing a commonly-heard refrain at this weekend's conference. "If we truly know what we believe, we do not need professionals to tell us."

Palin also waded into one of the country's most intractable policy debates, gun control. "Background checks? Yeah, I guess to learn more about a person's thinking and associations and intentions. More background checks? Dandy idea, Mr. President – should have started with yours," she said.

On gun ownership, Palin joked about a Christmas gift her husband Todd had given her. "You should have seen what Todd got me for Christmas. Well, it wasn't that exciting. It was a metal rack, case for hunting rifles to put on the back of a four-wheeler. Then though, I had to get something for him to put in the gun case, right. So, this go around, he's got the rifle, I got the rack."

On Mayor Bloomberg's large soda ban, Palin held up a Big Gulp, sipped from a straw, and said, "Bloomberg is not around, our big gulps are safe. We're cool. Shoot, it's just pop with low-cal ice-cubes in it."

On the current state of politics in Washington, Palin said, "We do not have leadership coming out of Washington, we have reality television."

On young conservatives, Palin offered advice: "My only piece of advice to our young college Republicans is you've got to be thinking Sam Adams, not drinking Sam Adams. And that's just a joke. I do not want to hear from the CEO of some brewery accusing me of being an anti-beer-ite."

On freshman Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who introduced her, Palin said, "We need more Americans like Ted Cruz. Coming from Texas, Ted Cruz comes to town, chews barbed wire, and spits out rust."

On Obama administration transparency, Palin said, "Barack Obama promised the most transparent administration ever. Barack Obama, you lie."

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee to Hold Confirmation Hearing for John Ratcliffe as Director of National Intelligence

 The Senate Intelligence Committee will hold a confirmation hearing for Rep. John Ratcliffe (R-Texas), President Trump's nominee for the Director of National Intelligence (DNI) position. The hearing marks the first major Senate hearing since the coronavirus-induced hiatus.

Ratcliffe, a member of the House Intelligence, Judiciary, and Ethics Committees, was a staunch defender of Trump during the Russia investigation and was on the president's advisory team during the impeachment proceedings earlier this year. Trump first considered him for the DNI position last year, but he withdrew his name last August due to concerns about a potentially contentious, partisan confirmation process.

Ratcliffe told Fox News at the time, "I made the decision to withdraw from consideration because, if your political future comes down to the vote of 100 U.S. senators, and you start out day one down 47 to nothing because every Democrat is against you, my concern was there's not a lot of margin for error there."

Trump nominated Ratcliffe again in February. Richard Grenell, the U.S. ambassador to Germany, is the current acting DNI, the second to have that role after former DNI Dan Coats' resignation last summer. Joseph Maguire was acting DNI until February.

Democrats' opposition to Grenell could improve Ratcliffe's chances of being confirmed now. Earlier this month, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) sent Grenell a letter demanding answers regarding organizational changes in his office, including President Trump's recent termination of Intelligence Community Inspector General Michael Atkinson.

The DNI position was created after the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks to oversee the U.S. intelligence community. The DNI serves on the president's cabinet and acts as an adviser to the president, National Security Council, and Homeland Security Council for national security-related intelligence issues.

A former federal prosecutor, Ratcliffe often went on the attack during the Russia probe and its aftermath, questioning Special Counsel Robert Mueller's decision to write in his report that he could not exonerate the president of obstruction of justice. During a July hearing, Ratcliffe stated, "The special counsel’s job didn’t say you were to determine Trump’s innocence or to exonerate him. The bedrock principle of our justice system is a presumption of innocence—everyone is entitled to it, including a sitting president, and because of a presumption of innocence, a prosecutor never, ever needs to determine it."

Before joining Congress, Ratcliffe served as Chief of Anti-Terrorism and National Security for the Eastern District of Texas and as Mayor of Heath, Texas.

Title: Poll Shows Most Americans Skeptical of President Trump's Denials of Russian Collusion

Article:

A new poll conducted by Suffolk University indicates that most Americans do not believe President Donald Trump's denials of collusion between his 2016 campaign and Russia. The poll, which surveyed 1,000 registered voters, has a margin of error of +/-3 percentage points.

The survey found that nearly six in ten respondents have little or no trust in Trump's denials, while 35 percent say they have some or a lot of trust in the president's statements. More than a third of those surveyed expressed "some" trust in Trump's version of events.

The skepticism towards Trump comes as prosecutors continue to file court documents and plea deals in cases involving some of the president's closest associates, including his former personal lawyer Michael Cohen, who was sentenced last week to three years in prison.

The poll also found that most of those surveyed, 53 percent, have a lot or some trust in Special Counsel Robert Mueller and his investigation, while 38 percent have little or no trust in the former FBI director and his investigation to be fair and accurate. In contrast, 59 percent expressed little or no trust in the president's denials, while 35 percent said they have some or a lot of trust in him to speak the truth.

Trump has a core of unwavering supporters who endorse his argument that the Mueller investigation is a "witch hunt." The proportion who say they have "a lot of trust" in the president's denials has not budged since March, remaining at 24 percent.

The poll also found that 50 percent of respondents believe Russians "definitely" interfered in the election to help Trump, while 27 percent believe they did not. Nearly as many, 46 percent, believe Trump associates "definitely" colluded with the Russians, while 29 percent believe they did not.

The poll was conducted by landline and cellphone Tuesday through Sunday. Those who follow the news most closely are the most skeptical, with two-thirds having little or no trust in Trump's denial. Nearly six in ten, 59 percent, say the Russians "definitely" interfered to help Trump, while a solid majority, 56 percent, say they are convinced Trump associates colluded with the Russians.

David Paleologos, director of the Suffolk University Political Research Center, stated that those who are following the investigation closely tend to lean more Democratic and find it useful and gratifying to see new allegations, plea deals, and indictments. Those who are not following the investigation closely are Trump supporters, in large part, and do not buy it. They are invested in Trump's success and are pained to watch his stock declining day after day with every new indictment.

Mueller, who has not responded publicly to Trump's frequent attacks in interviews and on Twitter, has a favorable-unfavorable rating of 39 percent-31 percent. His unfavorable rating has risen over the year, up from a 37 percent-23 percent rating in the Suffolk University/USA TODAY poll in March.

Views of Mueller are in positive territory by a net 8 percentage points. Trump has a favorable-unfavorable rating of 40 percent-57 percent, in negative territory by 17 points.

Title: U.S. Deploys F-22 Fighter Jets to South Korea During Joint Military Exercises; North Korea Enters "State of War"

Article:

The United States has deployed F-22 Raptor stealth fighter jets to South Korea as part of joint military exercises with South Korea. This move comes in response to North Korea's declaration that it has entered a "state of war" with the South.

South Korean President Park Geun-hye warned North Korea that any provocative moves will be met with "a strong response." In a meeting with senior defense and security officials, she stated that if there is any provocation against South Korea and its people, there should be a strong response in initial combat without any political considerations.

North Korea's recent verbal attacks against South Korea and the United States have included threats of a nuclear strike and labeling the U.S. mainland as a "boiled pumpkin," vulnerable to attack. The two Koreas are technically still at war after their conflict in the early 1950s ended in a truce, not a peace treaty.

The U.S.-South Korean military drills have been a source of tension, with North Korea describing the U.S. practice flights over South Korea by B-52 bombers and B-2 stealth bombers as acts of U.S. hostility. There was no immediate reaction from North Korean state media regarding the deployment of F-22 Raptors to the main U.S. Air Force Base in South Korea.

South Korea has continued to allow its workers to enter and leave the Kaesong Industrial Complex, a joint economic cooperation zone between the two Koreas, despite North Korea's threats to shut it down. The heightened tensions have prompted North Korea's traditional allies, China and Russia, to urge both sides to exercise restraint.

The coming weeks may see more bouts of saber-rattling, as North Korean delegates are currently gathered for the Supreme People's Assembly, the country's rubber-stamp parliament. April 15, the anniversary of the birth of Kim Il Sung, the nation's founder and the grandfather of Kim Jong Un, is usually marked by large-scale parades. The U.S.-South Korean military exercises are due to continue until the end of the month.

Some analysts have noted that Pyongyang has carried out some sort of military provocation within weeks of every South Korean presidential inauguration. President Park took office on February 25, five weeks ago.

Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar and Rep. Rashida Tlaib Denounce Israel's Decision to Bar Them, Call for Conditional U.S. Aid

Article:

Representatives Ilhan Omar (D-MN) and Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) on Monday rejected calls for a boycott of visits to Israel by members of Congress, but emphasized that continued U.S. aid to Israel should be contingent upon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu improving conditions for the Palestinians.

During a press conference, the two representatives denounced their exclusion from entering Israel and accused Netanyahu and President Trump of colluding to prevent their visit. They suggested that members of Congress should be allowed to observe how Israel utilizes billions of dollars in U.S. aid and urged their colleagues to reconsider the level of assistance.

"We must be asking, as Israel's ally, that Netanyahu stop the expansion of settlements on Palestinian land and ensure full rights for Palestinians if we are to give them aid," said Omar.

The representatives were scheduled to visit Israel on Monday, but Netanyahu announced last week that they would not be admitted. Initially, his government had signaled that they would be allowed, but Netanyahu stated after reviewing their itinerary that they were seeking a platform to grandstand rather than engaging in a fact-finding mission.

Omar and Tlaib denied this claim, stating that they had planned to meet with members of the Knesset, Israel's national assembly, and Israeli military veterans who have advocated for Palestinian self-determination. A version of their itinerary, obtained by a reporter for Israel's public broadcaster, showed meetings with several Palestinian activists and international human rights groups, but no lawmakers or officials.

Their trip was organized by Miftah, a nonprofit Palestinian advocacy group that has drawn criticism. They stated that they learned of the group from other members of Congress and were surprised at the criticism.

"We're also taken aback and learn from everybody else that there's some issues regarding them," said Tlaib, referring to the criticism of Miftah.

In 2016, Reps. Matt Cartwright of Pennsylvania, Dan Kildee of Michigan, Mark Pocan of Wisconsin, Luis Gutierrez of Illinois, and Hank Johnson of Georgia joined a trip organized by Miftah and the American Global Institute, according to Politico.

The congresswomen suggested that Trump had intervened to thwart their visit. The president and the two representatives have been exchanging barbs for months, with Trump accusing them of anti-Semitism and the representatives leading the push for his impeachment.

"We know Trump would love nothing more than to use this issue to pit Muslims and Jewish Americans against each other," said Omar.

Tlaib, whose family is Palestinian, became emotional as she recounted experiences of harassment by Israeli authorities despite being a U.S. citizen. Tlaib was granted an exemption from the Israeli government to visit her elderly grandmother as long as she did not advocate for the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement while there, but she opted not to go, stating that she would "be caged and bow down."

"All I can do... as the granddaughter of a woman living in occupied territory is to elevate her voice by exposing the truth," she said.

Trump, who supported Israel's decision, called Tlaib "obnoxious" for prioritizing politics over her grandmother.

Democracy for America, a progressive advocacy group, had called for other members of Congress to refuse to visit Israel in solidarity with the congresswomen. However, Omar urged lawmakers to visit Israel to witness the conditions of the Palestinians.

"We can not let Trump and Netanyahu succeed in hiding the cruel reality of the occupation from us," she said.

Title: Impact of Amazon Rainforest Fires on Global Ecosystem

Article:

Ecologist Dan Nepstad, president and founder of the Earth Innovation Institute, discusses the immediate and long-term effects of fires in the Amazon rainforest with NPR's Audie Cornish.

Nepstad, who has studied the Amazon for over 30 years, explains the difficulty in determining the true extent of the fires due to their low visibility in intact forests. He states that the best way to detect forest fires is by observing smoke, as fires in open or damaged forests are easier to spot.

According to Nepstad, the current fire season is the biggest in the last decade, with persistent fires burning felled forests. He attributes this to the drying out of deep, dense vegetation, which makes the forest more susceptible to fires and results in more intense and destructive blazes.

Nepstad also discusses the long-term threat of large-scale displacement of scrub vegetation, which alters the forest and makes it difficult to recognize as a pristine forest. He believes this scenario is the most worrisome for the Amazon's future.

In terms of solutions, Nepstad suggests shifting from fire-prone systems, such as extensive cattle farming, to more intensive, tree-based systems to discourage the use of fire and promote fire prevention.

Cornish asks Nepstad about the common description of the Amazon as the "lungs of the world." Nepstad clarifies that this is a misleading statement, as the Amazon should be thought of as a cooling system for the planet, rather than its lungs. He explains that the Amazon absorbs energy through evaporation, which cools the planet, and losing the Amazon would significantly impact the way air and energy move around the globe, altering the climate.

The article concludes with a quote from Nepstad, emphasizing the global connection to the health of the Amazon.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Discusses Recusal from Russia Investigation and DACA, Immigration Reform, and Mass Shootings

Article:

In a recent interview with Maria Bartiromo for "Sunday Morning Futures," Attorney General Jeff Sessions expressed no regrets about recusing himself from any Russia-related investigations, stating that he "did the right thing." Sessions' decision in March 2017 to step aside from the Justice Department investigation into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential race reportedly upset President Trump, as special counsel Robert Mueller would now lead the investigation.

Regarding the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, Sessions stated that he was unsure if Congress would find a permanent legislative solution before the program's expiration on March 5. He noted that President Trump has offered a generous policy that goes beyond the protections offered under the Obama-era DACA program, potentially affecting an estimated 700,000 immigrants brought illegally to the United States by their parents.

Immigration reform efforts in the Senate stalled last week, despite Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell conducting full, open debates on bipartisan and other reform proposals as the March deadline approaches. Sessions' immigration reform plan offers a potential path to citizenship for as many as 1.8 million illegal immigrants.

Sessions also addressed the recent mass shooting at a Florida high school, stating that law enforcement officials need to improve their ability to identify potential mass shooters and act on any received tips. He met with a group of sheriffs and emphasized the importance of following up on tips and signs of potential mass shooters to prevent such tragedies.

Title: Senate Approves Comprehensive Immigration Overhaul, Sending Bill to House for Consideration

Article:

The United States Senate has approved a sweeping immigration overhaul bill that aims to extend legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants while increasing border security. The vote, which took place on Thursday, was 68-32 in favor of the bill, sending it to the House of Representatives for further action.

The bill, which is the most significant overhaul of America's immigration system since the 1980s, would legalize millions of currently illegal immigrants, while expanding legal immigration and increasing border security. The legislation would require businesses to check the legal status of prospective employees, and it would provide for 20,000 new Border Patrol agents, 700 miles of fencing, and an array of high-tech devices to secure the border with Mexico.

The bill also includes provisions to expand the number of visas for highly skilled workers and establish a separate program for lower-skilled workers, as well as a temporary program for farm workers.

The bipartisan bill was drafted by a group of eight senators, four from each party, who met privately for months to produce a compromise. The bill faced opposition from some senators, with Sen. Richard Shelby, R-Ala., calling it "the mother of all amnesties."

The House of Representatives, which is controlled by the Republican party, has yet to indicate whether it will take up the Senate's bill or pursue its own piecemeal approach to immigration reform. House Speaker John Boehner declined to comment on the Senate bill on Thursday, stating that the House would go on recess next week and listen to its constituents before discussing the way forward.

Despite the strong majority in favor of the bill in the Senate, Congress remains divided over the issue. Some Republicans have already declared the Senate bill "dead on arrival" in the House, while others are working on their own version of immigration legislation.

The question remains whether the Senate's vote will compel the House to follow suit. The Senate bill fell short of the 70 votes its backers were hoping to secure, a number they felt would help persuade House leaders to move forward.

The Senate bill's opponents voiced frustration as the Senate scrambled to finalize its work ahead of the looming recess. Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, on Wednesday said he felt "used and abused," as he tried to slow down the process and call for more amendments to be considered. All Democrats, in addition to 14 Republicans, voted for the legislation on Thursday, while all "no" votes came from the Republican side of the aisle.

Title: Congressional Hesitation on Repealing the Affordable Care Act Sparks Debate on Entitlement Programs and Farm Subsidies

Article:

The Republican party's promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has been met with resistance, as a significant portion of Americans, approximately half, have expressed support for the healthcare reform. This shift in public opinion has sparked a broader discussion on entitlement programs and farm subsidies in the United States.

The Affordable Care Act, initially met with opposition, has seen a change in sentiment as people become more attached to the subsidies and guarantees it provides. This phenomenon is not unique to the U.S., as similar instances can be observed in other countries, such as France, where attempts to reform job protections, like a 35-hour work week, were met with widespread protests.

The issue of farm subsidies has been a contentious one, with the U.S. spending $23.3 billion in 1985, a significant increase from the initial $3 billion in the Depression era. These subsidies have been criticized for contributing to food surpluses, obesity, and the enrichment of a select few, such as the Fanjul family in Florida.

In the past, attempts to abolish programs like the Education and Energy Departments or the mohair subsidy have been unsuccessful. The mohair subsidy, initially implemented to protect against food shortages during the Depression, continues to exist despite its irrelevance in modern times.

Entitlement programs, such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid, are the largest handouts in the U.S., with Medicare being mostly a handout due to the high cost of medical bills compared to the premiums paid. Proposing cuts to these programs is a politically challenging task.

One positive example of reform comes from the 1970s, when the Ford and Carter administrations successfully eliminated the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Civil Aeronautics Board, and the jobs of bureaucrats who regulated gas prices. Despite initial resistance, these reforms were ultimately implemented.

The ongoing debate on entitlement programs and farm subsidies underscores the challenges of implementing change in the U.S. political system, as the interests of powerful lobbyists and the public's attachment to certain benefits often complicate the process.

Title: Police Accountability: A National Issue Highlighted by the George Floyd Case

Article:

The arrest and indictment of Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin for the death of George Floyd has sparked a national conversation about police accountability. Chauvin, who had 18 complaints over his 19-year tenure, was only disciplined twice, and the systemic issues that allowed him to remain in policing duties are now under scrutiny.

According to reports, out of 2,600 complaints against the Minneapolis Police Department since 2012, only 12 resulted in an officer being disciplined. The most severe penalty was a 40-hour suspension. The fact that three of Chauvin's colleagues, who are also now indicted, watched as Floyd choked to death is also a matter of concern, reflecting on the police culture.

The protests and riots that followed Floyd's death show the consequences of a lack of accountability and public trust. Civil rights leaders have called for a national reckoning to end racism in America, but the unaccountability of bad cops is not primarily a racial issue. Instead, it is largely due to police union contracts that make it difficult to hold officers accountable for extreme misconduct.

A 2017 Reuters report found that the standard for police discipline is often harder than for a criminal conviction. In some jurisdictions, prior complaints are expunged from the record after a few months, making it practically impossible to terminate repeat offenders. This issue is not unique to Minneapolis; a 2016 Government Accountability Office report found that more than 99% of federal employees received a "fully successful" rating.

The lack of accountability is not just a problem with police but throughout government. Due process is meant to protect against abuses of state power by police and other state agents, not to protect police when they abuse their power. The clash of rights means that accountability is basically nonexistent, leading to a loss of public trust, a breakdown of civil order, and a shift from norms to rules.

Public service, and especially police work, should be a source of pride and honor, but the absence of accountability leads instead to cynicism and disrespect. A new social contract with public employees is needed, with accountability for the public good as the core organizing principle. Safeguards against unfair accountability can readily be provided, but supervisors cannot be put to the proof in a legal proceeding. Accountability is not the only change needed to revive trust in American government; leaders and institutions must also display fidelity to accepted norms.

Title: Negotiations Progress as Obama Expresses Hope for End to Government Shutdown and Debt Ceiling Crisis

Article:

As negotiations continue over the weekend to resolve the ongoing U.S. government shutdown and the looming debt ceiling crisis, President Barack Obama expressed optimism in his weekly address on Saturday that the "pain of this Republican shutdown" will soon come to an end.

The President noted it as a "positive development" that House Republicans have proposed extending the nation's borrowing limit for six weeks. He stated, "Once the debt ceiling is raised, and the shutdown is over, there's a lot we can accomplish together."

The administration has stated that the government will exhaust its authority to pay its bills unless Congress agrees to raise the debt limit by Thursday. The House and Senate are currently working on different proposals to raise the debt ceiling and reopen the government, which has been shut down for 12 days.

House Republicans have presented the administration with a proposal that would establish budget talks, although President Obama has not yet accepted it. Both sides are still in discussions. Speaker John A. Boehner held a session with GOP lawmakers on Saturday to update them on the status of negotiations.

Senate Democrats are considering a plan that would extend the borrowing limit through the 2014 elections. Senate Republicans, on the other hand, are working on a proposal that would increase the borrowing limit until January, end the government shutdown, and delay the Obamacare medical device tax.

Republicans claim that President Obama is seeking increased revenue as part of the negotiations; the President, in his weekly address, stated that he wants to reduce budget deficits "in a smarter, balanced way that lets us afford to invest in the things we need to grow."

House Armed Services Chairman Howard "Buck" McKeon, a California Republican, urged the President to sign interim measures passed by the House to reopen some government services, including national parks. McKeon stated, "The House has passed more than a dozen bills providing funding for things we can all agree on—veterans, cancer research, National Guard, national parks, Head Start, food safety, flight safety, border security, nuclear weapon security, and more." He added, "President Obama and Senate Democrats should back these bills immediately."

As negotiations progress, McKeon called on the President to work with Congress on plans to reopen the entire government and avoid defaulting on U.S. debts.

Title: Tokyo Olympics Postponed Until Summer 2021 Due to Coronavirus

Article:

The global spread of the coronavirus has led to the postponement of the Tokyo Olympics until the summer of 2021 at the earliest, as announced by Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Tuesday. Abe and the International Olympic Committee (IOC) President Thomas Bach reached an agreement to postpone the Games.

In a joint statement, the IOC and Abe stated, "The Games of the XXXII Olympiad in Tokyo must be rescheduled to a date beyond 2020 but not later than summer 2021, to safeguard the health of the athletes, everybody involved in the Olympic Games, and the international community."

The IOC and Abe also noted that the Olympic flame would remain in Japan and the Games would keep the name Olympic and Paralympic Games Tokyo 2020.

Earlier, veteran IOC member Dick Pound had told USA Today that the event was on hold, but the IOC did not confirm or deny Monday whether the Games were going to be postponed. Pound stated, "On the basis of the information the IOC has, postponement has been decided."

The United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee signaled its support for delaying the Tokyo Olympics over the coronavirus. Pound also told USA Today that the ramifications of postponing the Games would be "immense."

The IOC began detailed discussions to assess the impact of the coronavirus on the Olympic Games, including the scenario of postponement, on Sunday. The committee added that these talks, held in full coordination and partnership with organizers and Japanese authorities, would likely be finalized within the next four weeks.

Canada and Australia have already announced they would not be sending athletes to Tokyo, while USA Swimming called on U.S. officials to do the same. IOC President Thomas Bach sent a letter to athletes on Sunday explaining the decision and why it might take so long. The IOC stated that scenarios under consideration "relate to modifying existing operational plans for the Games to go ahead on July 24, 2020, and also for changes to the start date of the Games." The statement added that "cancellation is not on the agenda."

Title: Trump Administration Stands Firm on Steel and Aluminum Tariffs, Faces Criticism and Allies' Concerns

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — The Trump administration has shown no signs of backing down from its plan to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, with White House trade adviser Peter Navarro stating on Sunday that no country will be exempt from the proposed 25 percent and 10 percent duties on imported steel and aluminum, respectively.

The announcement of the tariffs on Thursday has caused market volatility, sparked international criticism, and raised concerns about a potential trade war. While President Trump's rhetoric has primarily focused on China, the tariffs will also affect significant imports from countries such as Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Japan, and the European Union.

The Pentagon had recommended targeted tariffs to avoid upsetting American partners abroad. However, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated on ABC's "This Week" that the president is taking a broader approach, and he dismissed threats of retaliation from American allies as "pretty trivial."

Trade politics are often regional rather than ideological, but the debate over the tariffs has opened a rift between President Trump and his party, leaving him with support primarily from his ideological opposites.

Senators Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) and Bob Casey (D-Pennsylvania) have expressed support for the tariffs, with Brown stating, "Good, finally," and Casey tweeting, "I urge the administration to follow through and to take aggressive measures to ensure our workers can compete on a level playing field."

However, Trump's GOP allies on Capitol Hill have expressed concerns about the tariffs' potential economic and political consequences. They argue that other industries that rely on steel and aluminum products will suffer, and the cost of new appliances, cars, and buildings will rise if the president follows through. The end result could erode the president's base of support with rural America and blue-collar workers, the president claims to be trying to help.

Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) stated, "There is always retaliation, and typically, many of these countries single out agriculture when they do that. So, we're very concerned."

Gov. Scott Walker (R-Wis.) asked the administration to reconsider its stance, stating that American companies could move their operations abroad and not face retaliatory tariffs. The Business Roundtable's Josh Bolten, a chief of staff for President George W. Bush, called on Trump to step back from his campaign rhetoric on trade.

Tim Phillips, president of the Koch Brothers-backed Americans for Prosperity, noted that Trump narrowly won in Iowa and Wisconsin, two heavily rural states that could suffer if countries impose retaliatory tariffs on American agricultural goods.

Despite the criticism, President Trump has shown no signs of backing down, tweeting, "Trade wars are good and easy to win."

Title: Attorney General to Release Redacted Mueller Report on Russian Election Interference

Article:

Washington, D.C. - Attorney General William Barr plans to release a redacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election and contacts between Moscow and President Donald Trump's campaign on Thursday morning, according to the Justice Department. Department spokeswoman Kerri Kupec did not provide a precise time, but stated that the report, which Barr has described as nearly 400 pages long, will be released to both Congress and the public.

The release of the report comes after Mueller turned over a copy of his confidential report to Barr on March 22, concluding his 22-month-long inquiry. In a four-page letter to Congress on March 24, Barr summarized what he said were Mueller's primary conclusions. He stated that Mueller's investigation did not establish that members of Trump's election campaign conspired with Russia.

Barr also wrote that Mueller presented evidence "on both sides" about whether Trump obstructed justice by acting to impede the inquiry, but he did not draw a conclusion one way or the other. Barr stated that he reviewed Mueller's evidence and made his own determination that Trump did not commit the crime of obstruction of justice.

Justice Department regulations grant Barr, a Trump appointee and the top U.S. law enforcement officer, broad authority to decide what to release and what to withhold from the report. Barr has pledged to be as transparent as possible but has stated that he will redact certain portions for reasons including protecting secret grand jury information, intelligence-gathering sources and methods, information relating to ongoing cases, and the privacy of "peripheral third parties" who were not charged.

The redactions in the report will be color-coded by category, according to Barr, explaining the reasons that parts are blacked out. After Barr released his four-page letter, Trump claimed "complete and total exoneration," condemned "an illegal takedown that failed," and accused unnamed political enemies of treasonous acts.

Since Barr released his letter, Trump has set his sights on the FBI, and accused the Justice Department of improperly targeting his campaign. Last week, Barr told a U.S. Senate panel he believed that "spying" did occur on Trump's campaign, and he plans to investigate whether it was properly authorized. Barr's comments were criticized by Democrats, already skeptical of how he has handled the report's release.

The attorney general has pledged to testify publicly about the report's conclusions before the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on May 1 and 2, respectively. The Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee voted on April 3 to empower its chairman, Jerrold Nadler, to issue subpoenas for the full report and underlying evidence.

Meanwhile, the top Democrat and Republican on the House Intelligence Committee are also asking Barr to produce all of the investigative materials compiled by Mueller's team and to make Mueller and his staff available for a briefing. In a March 27 letter seen by [redacted] on Monday, Democratic Chairman Adam Schiff and top Republican Devin Nunes told Barr they want Mueller to brief them on "the investigation's scope and areas of inquiry, its findings, and the intelligence and counterintelligence information gathered" in the investigation.

Title: Billionaire Sheldon Adelson Emerges as Top Campaign Donor in 2012 Elections

Article:

In the ongoing 2012 political campaign season marked by significant political spending, casino magnate Sheldon Adelson and his wife, Dr. Miriam Adelson, stand out as the most prolific donors. On Wednesday, it was reported that the Adelsons donated $10 million to Restore Our Future, a super PAC supporting Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney. This contribution brings their total donations to super PACs during the 2012 campaign to at least $35 million, more than twice the amount donated by their closest competitors, billionaire industrialists Harold C. Simmons and his wife, Annette.

With a net worth of approximately $25 billion, Mr. Adelson has the financial means to contribute significantly more. In an interview with Forbes magazine this year, he suggested he would consider spending up to $100 million on the 2012 elections.

Initially, most of the Adelsons' contributions went to Winning Our Future, a super PAC that provided critical support to Newt Gingrich, Romney's primary rival. Winning Our Future spent millions of dollars on advertisements criticizing Romney's record at Bain Capital during the winter months. Mr. Adelson has publicly expressed reservations about Romney, describing him as timid compared to Gingrich.

However, since Gingrich's withdrawal from the race in early May, the Adelsons have shifted their support to Romney. The two met for lunch at The Venetian, Mr. Adelson's Las Vegas hotel, later in May. Last week, it was reported that Mr. Adelson was considering a contribution of $1 million to $10 million to Restore Our Future, the pro-Romney super PAC.

Mr. Adelson has close ties to many of Romney's other supporters, particularly wealthy Jewish donors, with whom he has served on the board of the Republican Jewish Coalition. Restore Our Future's political director, Carl Forti, was also involved with the issue advocacy group Freedom's Watch, which spent $17 million during the 2008 election. The exact amount of the Adelsons' contribution to Restore Our Future has not been disclosed.

Title: Huawei Responds to US National Emergency Declaration and Export Controls

Article:

Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications company, has responded to the United States' declaration of a national emergency and the subsequent imposition of strict export controls. The executive order, issued by President Donald Trump on Wednesday, empowers the government to ban technology and services from "foreign adversaries" deemed to pose "unacceptable risks" to national security. The order does not name specific countries or companies but comes after months of US pressure on Huawei.

In a statement reported by the state-run Global Times, Huawei said, "If the US restricts Huawei, it will not make the US safer, nor will it make the US stronger. It will only force the US to use inferior and expensive alternative equipment, lagging behind other countries... and ultimately harming US companies and consumers." The company expressed its willingness to "communicate with the US to ensure product security," echoing reassurances given to the UK.

The US Commerce Department has added Huawei and 70 affiliates to its "entity list," banning the company from acquiring components and technology from US firms without government approval. The order invokes the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, which gives the president the authority to regulate commerce in response to a national emergency that threatens the US. The order directs the commerce department, working with other government agencies, to draw up a plan for enforcement within 150 days.

The US and China have recently increased tariffs in a battle over what US officials call China's unfair trade practices. Talks between Washington and Beijing have ground to a halt, causing volatility amid concerns about a global trade war. China has announced plans to increase tariffs on nearly $60bn worth of US imports beginning on 1 June, in what the Chinese government said was a retaliatory move after Washington imposed tariffs on $200bn of Chinese goods.

Huawei has strongly denied US allegations that its equipment could be used by the Chinese state to spy. Ren Zhengfei, the company's founder and chief executive, claimed in February that Huawei would reject any efforts to gather intelligence through its products even if the Chinese government required it to do so.

The US has previously labeled Huawei a threat and lobbied allies not to use Huawei network equipment in next-generation 5G networks, calling it untrustworthy. Allies who allow Huawei technology inside their 5G networks have been told they may be frozen out of US intelligence sharing. Australia, New Zealand, and Japan have banned Huawei from their 5G networks. In the UK, BT has excluded Huawei telecoms infrastructure from its own 5G rollout and removed some of its equipment from the 4G network. In January 2019, Vodafone said it had decided to "pause" the use of Huawei equipment in its core networks across Europe. The UK's defence secretary Gavin Williamson was sacked by prime minister Theresa May after a leak revealed the sensitive decision that the UK would not be totally banning Huawei from 5G projects.

Title: Possible Outcomes of Supreme Court's Potential Alteration of Roe v. Wade

Article:

The recent appointment of two justices by former President Donald Trump has sparked discussions about the potential overturning of the landmark case Roe v. Wade, which legalized abortion nationwide. However, it is essential to understand that the court's actions may not be as straightforward as some might assume. This article will explore several possible scenarios that could unfold following any changes to Roe v. Wade.

The first category, referred to as nuclear options, encompasses the most extreme and least likely scenarios. The first nuclear option would be a complete reversal of Roe v. Wade, establishing a constitutional ban on abortion. This would outlaw abortion across the United States, making it illegal for women to obtain the procedure.

A second nuclear option involves the court dismantling the right to privacy, which was established in the 1965 case Griswold v. Connecticut. The right to privacy is the foundation for Roe v. Wade, and its elimination would eradicate the basis for Roe v. Wade, returning the issue to the states and allowing them to regulate abortion as they see fit.

The second possibility is the court overruling Roe v. Wade, leaving the right to privacy intact but eliminating the constitutional right to abortion. In a post-Roe world, states would be free to regulate abortion as they wish, with some advocacy groups suggesting that as many as 22 states could potentially ban abortion entirely.

The third possibility is the court chipping away at Roe v. Wade, imposing increasingly restrictive abortion laws while maintaining the right to privacy. This could result in a patchwork of laws across the country, making it more difficult for women in certain states, particularly poor women, to access abortion services.

It is important to note that the likelihood of each scenario varies, and the court's actions may not follow a linear path. Chief Justice John Roberts, known for his incrementalist approach, may be less likely to pursue the most extreme options.

In conclusion, while the future of Roe v. Wade remains uncertain, it is crucial to understand the potential outcomes and their implications for women's reproductive rights in the United States. The possibility of more restrictive abortion laws, particularly in red states, is a real concern for many, and the impact on poor women's access to abortion services is a significant concern.

Title: Hobby Lobby Allegedly Fires Pregnant Employee, Denies Rehiring After Maternity Leave

Article:

Hobby Lobby, a well-known arts and crafts retailer, has been accused of firing a pregnant employee after she requested time off to give birth, despite earlier assurances that her job would be waiting for her upon her return. The allegations were made by former employee Felicia Allen in a report by RH Reality Check.

Allen, who started working at Hobby Lobby as a part-time cashier in 2010, discovered she was pregnant shortly after joining the company. Concerned about her job security due to her short tenure and her impending maternity leave, Allen asked her supervisor if her job would be safe. The supervisor reportedly reassured her, stating that she would still have her job upon her return.

However, when Allen was ready to have her child, she was terminated. She attempted to return to work three weeks after giving birth but was not rehired as promised. "I was like, I can't get fired," Allen told RH Reality Check. "She can't terminate me because I have to go have my child. I started asking everybody on the job, 'Can they do this?' And even the assistant manager who had just got hired [said], 'No, that's not right.'"

In addition to being misled about her ability to return to work, Allen claimed that Hobby Lobby contested her unemployment benefits. According to Allen, the company argued that she could have taken personal leave but chose not to. Allen eventually won her claim, but she left her experience at Hobby Lobby feeling that the company had discriminated against her due to her pregnancy.

Allen could not file a legal challenge due to a contract she signed with Hobby Lobby, which waived her right to sue. Most disputes with the company are settled outside of court in arbitration, according to RH Reality Check's report.

Alex Colvin, a professor of conflict resolution at Cornell University and an expert on employment arbitration, told RH Reality Check that corporations often institute an arbitration-only policy to avoid widespread lawsuits and to keep information on disputes out of the public eye.

Several employees have filed job discrimination lawsuits against Hobby Lobby in the past, alleging age, disability, race, and sex discrimination. However, due to the company's avoidance of lawsuits and the confidential nature of arbitration cases, it is difficult to evaluate Hobby Lobby's treatment of its employees beyond the company's assurances that they are paid above minimum wage and well taken care of.

In a promotional video on the Hobby Lobby website, company president Steve Green stated that the company's pro-family Christian principles guide its operations. "The beliefs that we've had—that we have grown up with all our lives—are convictions that we have that we live by personally," Green said. "As we have run our business, we feel the obligation or the desire that we want to use those same principles within our business."

Hobby Lobby has not yet responded to a request for comment regarding the allegations made by Felicia Allen. It remains to be seen how the Green family, who are known for their pro-family Christian principles, will respond to these allegations of discrimination against a new mother.

Title: U.S. Court Temporarily Halts DAPA Program Implementation, Leaves DACA in Place

Article:

The United States District Court for the Southern Division of Texas has issued a temporary injunction, preventing the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) from implementing any aspects of the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans or Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) program. This action halts the planned expansion of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which was scheduled to begin accepting new applications this week, and may not begin accepting DAPA applications as planned in May.

The court's order does not affect the existing DACA program, which remains in place. The temporary injunction is intended to preserve the status quo until a more comprehensive court hearing can rule on the merits of the case. To secure a temporary injunction, the plaintiffs must demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of their claim that the DAPA Memorandum violated the Administrative Procedures Act.

The court's order only affects the DAPA expansion outlined in the November 2014 DAPA Memorandum and the larger DAPA program. The White House has announced its intention to appeal the order, with the appeal likely to be heard by a three-judge panel of the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals around July or August of this year. If the Obama administration loses this ruling, it could then appeal for an en banc ruling from the 5th Circuit before appealing to the Supreme Court.

The earliest the Supreme Court might hear the case is March 2016, and the earliest they could issue a decision would be June 2016. This timing poses a significant problem for the Obama administration, as USCIS was expected to begin accepting DAPA application fees to fund their new Crystal City office in May 2015.

The temporary injunction's impact on the DHS funding debate in Congress remains uncertain. Speaker John Boehner has issued a statement urging Senate Democrats who have questioned the legality of Obama's amnesty to allow debate on a bill to fund the Homeland Security department. This statement is a direct challenge to Senators who have voted to prevent any debate on the House Department of Homeland Security bill that defunds Obama's amnesty programs.

Since the order leaves the existing DACA program in place while preventing the new DAPA program from being implemented, a compromise could potentially be reached where the DHS bill continues to defund the DAPA program, but Democratic Senators could offer amendments preserving the DACA program. Moderate Sen. Susan Collins (R-ME) has suggested such a compromise.

Title: Senate Cancels Half of Summer Recess to Pursue President Trump's Agenda

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) has abruptly canceled nearly half of the Senate's summer vacation, forcing lawmakers to remain in Washington to make progress on President Trump's agenda. The decision comes as the Senate faces a backlog of presidential nominations and a lengthy to-do list that includes passing a budget, repealing Obamacare, and beginning work on tax reform.

In a statement, McConnell cited the need to address the Senate's backlog of presidential nominations, which has grown due to unprecedented obstruction by Democrats. He stated, "We're getting zero cooperation on the personnel part of the Senate's portfolio, which is confirming nominations."

The decision to cancel vacation is a significant shift for lawmakers who value their time away from Washington. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) said, "I don't believe the Senate should go home if we haven't done our job."

The Senate has abbreviated vacations in the past, usually when Congress is facing an immediate spending deadline that could result in a government shutdown. Giving up two weeks of summer vacation to pursue a broader policy agenda is rare.

Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-NY) criticized the move, stating that Republicans are trying to mask their legislative failures. He said, "They're struggling with health care. They don't want to go home and face their constituents."

Democrats have erected obstacles to the quick approval of most of Trump's nominees, forcing the Senate to spend floor time on repeated filibuster votes. As of now, Trump has submitted 178 nominations, but only 46 of them have been confirmed. This is significantly lower than the number of nominees confirmed by President Obama at the same point in his first term.

Sen. Ron Johnson (R-WI) did not see the recess announcement as a desperation move. He said, "I have no problem with it whatsoever. I would have liked to [have] stayed in last week, quite honestly, to have greater input in terms of what the final Senate bill was."

Senators returned to Capitol Hill on Monday after a 10-day break to celebrate Independence Day. They had been scheduled to leave Capitol Hill on July 28 and return after Labor Day. The new schedule keeps them in Washington until Aug. 11.

House Republican leaders have not yet said whether they will follow suit, but they are under increasing pressure from conservatives who say Congress must work through the summer. The House Freedom Caucus issued a statement saying, "It is imperative that the additional weeks are coupled with decisive action."

Conservative activists hope that adding more time to the schedule will help break Democrats' resistance. Rick Manning, president of the group Americans for Limited Government, said, "It's time for the Democrats' collective temper tantrum to end, and Sen. McConnell must continue to ratchet up the pressure so that President Trump's nominees and agenda have a chance of being considered."

Senators plan to spend this week and next rewriting and then debating the Republican bill to repeal Obamacare. After that, McConnell said, they will turn to the annual defense policy bill and then could move to raise the federal government's borrowing limit. Analysts say that must be accomplished by October.

Congress also faces a Sept. 30 deadline to approve funding for basic government operations in fiscal year 2018, and Republicans need to pass a new budget to streamline the process for tax reform, which House leaders are planning this year.

Title: Democrats Lose Senate Majority in 2014 Midterm Elections: A Look at the Factors Influencing the Outcome

Article:

In the 2014 midterm elections, the Senate majority that Democrats had held for the past six years under President Barack Obama's leadership was lost. The Democrats' inability to capitalize on opportunities and cope with anticipated challenges led to their defeat.

During a late October lunch, President Obama and Senator Chuck Schumer discussed the closely contested Senate races. However, Schumer, representing New York, declined Obama's offer to campaign in battleground states. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee (DSCC) had already suggested Obama make robocalls and radio interviews to help mobilize black voters but had not proposed visits to these states.

The Democrats faced a challenging map, with Obama himself referring to it as "the worst possible group of states for Democrats since Dwight Eisenhower." They also faced the "six-year itch" of Obama's second term, during which the president's party traditionally experiences significant losses.

State-by-state, the Democrats struggled. There were disputes over the Democratic candidate in South Dakota, recruitment issues in Montana, a flawed candidate in Iowa, and a weak Republican in Georgia who still managed to embrace outsourcing. The Republicans, on the other hand, benefited from a simple message: a vote for them was a vote against Obama.

Despite these challenges, Senate Democrats could have fared worse if not for investments in field operations, bringing digital and research operations in-house, hiring key Obama campaign hands, and some luck with GOP candidate struggles in Michigan and Oregon.

Republicans also capitalized on opposition research, uncovering plagiarism allegations against Democratic Senator John Walsh in Montana. In addition, the National Republican Senatorial Committee's message to protect incumbents and their success in Mississippi and Wyoming was well-received.

The Democrats' inability to escape the association with Obama was a significant factor in their losses. The Obamacare website debacle, scandals at the Department of Veterans Affairs, the rise of ISIL, the Ebola epidemic, the tidal wave of unaccompanied minors at the U.S.-Mexico border, and the crisis over Russia's actions in Ukraine kept Obama at the center of the news, a position that Democrats on Capitol Hill did not want him in.

Guy Cecil, the DSCC's executive director, acknowledged that the individual issues and tactics the Democrats responded to effectively put the president back in the center of the conversation and nationalized the election.

At the White House, officials expressed frustration with the Senate Democrats, who they felt were too timid and mishandled their relationship with Obama. Candidates, on the other hand, were criticized for trying to distance themselves from the president while still relying on his base for support.

Prominent Democrats outside the White House criticized the administration for being out of touch, arguing that the White House political office was more of a scheduling and email text clearinghouse than a strategy center. They were grateful for Obama's fundraising efforts but felt that the White House could have done more to support the Democrats' campaigns.

This account is based on interviews with key Democratic and Republican officials involved in the decision-making that helped Republicans regain the Senate majority for the first time in eight years. They told the same story in the closing days of the races: This midterm cycle was run largely out of Washington, and was defined by missed opportunities.

Title: Trump to Impose Tariffs on $200 Billion in Chinese Goods as Early as Next Week

Article:

President Donald Trump plans to impose duties on approximately $200 billion more worth of Chinese goods as early as next week, a senior administration official confirmed on Saturday. This move escalates the ongoing trade dispute between the world's two largest economies.

The White House could announce on Monday or Tuesday that it will impose a 10 percent tariff rate on the $200 billion list of goods, the official told ███. However, these tariffs could reach as high as 25 percent, as Trump proposed last month to increase the tariff rate.

The administration has threatened these tariffs for months as a response to China's policies that have resulted in intellectual property theft or mandated technology transfers on U.S. companies doing business there. A public comment period on Trump's latest set of tariffs formally ended last week, clearing the way for the president to follow through on the threat.

In recent months, the administration has typically conducted an analysis of public comments before implementing announced tariffs, which currently affect about $53 billion in Chinese imports. However, Trump's remarks in recent weeks have indicated that he does not want to delay his plan.

Pressure from American businesses may have influenced the administration to moderate its approach slightly in the latest round. Many businesses had urged Trump to consider the effects of the tariffs on consumers, especially ahead of the retail holiday season.

"Continuing the tit-for-tat tariff escalation with China only serves to expand the harm to more U.S. economic interests, including farmers, families, businesses, and workers," the National Retail Federation and 150 other business groups said in a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer this month.

Trump has also threatened to impose tariffs on virtually all $505 billion that the United States imports from China. "I hate to say that, but behind that, there’s another $267 billion ready to go on short notice if I want," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One last week.

Trump kept up his tough talk on China earlier this week even as his administration and Chinese leaders planned to resume trade talks later this month. "We are under no pressure to make a deal with China, they are under pressure to make a deal with us. Our markets are surging, theirs are collapsing. We will soon be taking in Billions in Tariffs & making products at home. If we meet, we meet?" Trump posted on Twitter on Thursday.

A White House spokeswoman on Friday confirmed that Trump intended to move ahead with the tariffs in response to a Bloomberg report that said Trump had instructed aides to prepare to impose them. "The President has been clear that he and his administration will continue to take action to address China’s unfair trade practices. We encourage China to address the long-standing concerns raised by the United States," White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said on Friday.

Walters said Saturday she had no further comment at this time.

Beijing has threatened to retaliate with tariffs ranging from 5 to 25 percent on an additional $60 billion in U.S. products as soon as the Chinese tariffs are imposed. So far, China has responded in kind to Trump's tariffs – imposing an equivalent $53 billion in tariffs on U.S. exports to China, much of which has been U.S. agricultural goods. However, the U.S. exports only about $130 billion in U.S. goods, meaning China could have to look beyond tariffs to retaliate against Trump's latest trade action.

News of Trump's plans to proceed on tariffs on $200 billion in goods as early as next week was first reported by The Washington Post.

Title: Award-Winning Photographer and Pediatrician Killed in Afghanistan, Increased Violence Against Foreign Workers

Article:

In the past less than three weeks, two high-profile foreign workers have been killed in Afghanistan. Award-winning photographer Anja Niedringhaus, a German citizen, was shot and killed by a police officer at a checkpoint in eastern Afghanistan. Her colleague, Canadian reporter Kathy Gannon, who has covered Afghanistan and Pakistan for The Associated Press for decades, was also wounded in the attack. A month prior, a Swedish journalist was shot and killed in a heavily guarded area of Kabul.

These attacks bear a resemblance to insider attacks by Afghan security forces against their Western allies that became a crisis two years ago. The violence, also known as insider attacks, threatened the military training mission at the heart of the American troop withdrawal scheduled for this year. However, as international coalition soldiers have increasingly confined themselves to their bases, and as new strategies have been implemented to safeguard against insider attacks, such episodes have seemed to subside. Instead, foreign workers in Afghanistan have been targeted. Although the number of Western civilians targeted is still small compared to the number of military deaths, and both together are greatly outstripped by Afghan civilian casualties in the war.

Before the presidential voting on April 5, a concerted effort by the Taliban to target locations popular with expatriates was evident. An assault in January on a restaurant in central Kabul, the Taverna du Liban, left 21 people dead, most of them foreigners. Shootings at the luxury Serena Hotel last month killed nine. Such events have put the thousands of foreigners living in Kabul on high alert.

The unpredictable nature of the violence has prompted some embassies to redouble their security efforts, and has led those living outside secure areas to limit their exposure.

Dr. Jerry Umanos, a pediatrician from Chicago, was one of the recent victims. Friends and colleagues said that he was keenly aware of the risks but was drawn to working with Afghans and helping to teach a new generation of doctors in the country.

"He was a very good teacher and clinician," said Robert F. Werner, who for a time lived in the same house as Dr. Umanos in Afghanistan, in a telephone interview on Thursday. "And he also had a great sense of humor, so culturally, he just did well. The doctors loved working with him."

Title: CNN's Jim Acosta and MSNBC's Joe Scarborough Praise President Trump's D-Day Speech

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, two of President Donald Trump's most vocal mainstream media critics, CNN's Jim Acosta and MSNBC's Joe Scarborough, commended the President's speech on the 75th anniversary of D-Day.

Following the speech, Acosta, a White House correspondent for CNN, praised Trump's remarks on the Allied fighters who stormed the beaches of Normandy, stating, "This is perhaps the most on-message moment of Donald Trump's presidency today. We were all wondering if he would veer from his remarks, go off of his script, but he stayed on script, stayed on message, and, I think, rose to the moment."

Acosta's praise for Trump comes amidst controversy surrounding his role at CNN. His book, "The Enemy of the People: A Dangerous Time to Tell the Truth in America," is set to be released soon and is described as an "explosive, first-hand account of the dangers [Acosta] faces reporting on the current White House while fighting on the front lines in President Trump's war on truth."

Acosta, who has been criticized for blurring the line between reporter and pundit, was recently named the media member who "hates" Trump the most by authors L. Brent Bozell III and Tim Graham of the Media Research Center in their book "Unmasked — Big Media's War Against Trump."

On MSNBC, Scarborough, another frequent Trump critic, echoed Acosta's sentiments. He described Trump's speech as "the strongest speech of his presidency" and noted that it was a "beautiful moment" when Trump acknowledged the sacrifices of the D-Day heroes.

Viewers on both liberal networks were likely taken aback, as Acosta and Scarborough typically criticize Trump's actions. Scarborough, who shares the second spot on the list of media members who clearly loathe the president with his "Morning Joe" co-host Mika Brzezinski, had nothing but positive remarks about Trump's D-Day speech.

Title: NSA Taps into Google and Yahoo Data Networks, Alleges Washington Post Report

Article:

A new report from the Washington Post alleges that the National Security Agency (NSA) has secretly tapped into the unencrypted links behind massive cloud networks operated by companies like Google and Yahoo. This alleged activity allows the NSA to collect data at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts, including emails, videos, and audio from American citizens.

The operation, known as Operation MUSCULAR, is a joint program between the NSA and its British counterpart, the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ). The program reportedly relies on an unnamed telecommunications provider outside of the U.S. to offer secret access to a cable or switch through which Google and Yahoo pass unencrypted traffic between their servers.

Google and Yahoo have stated that their massive servers are carefully guarded and strictly audited. Google claims that buildings housing its servers are guarded around the clock by trained personnel, secured with heat-sensitive cameras, biometric verification, and more.

Two engineers with close ties to Google reportedly exploded in profanity upon seeing a drawing of the NSA's hack, which was revealed by Edward Snowden. The drawing includes a smiley face next to the point at which the agency apparently tapped into the world's data.
