White House officials and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which oversees the NSA, declined to confirm, deny, or explain why the agency allegedly infiltrates Google and Yahoo networks overseas. However, NSA Director Gen. Keith Alexander said Wednesday that the agency does not access such networks' servers without a court order.

The NSA also released a statement saying the agency only uses attorney general-approved processes in data collection. "NSA has multiple authorities that it uses to accomplish its mission, which is centered on defending the nation," the statement reads. "The Washington Post's assertion that we use Executive Order 12333 collection to get around the limitations imposed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and FAA 702 is not true. The assertion that we collect vast quantities of U.S. persons' data from this type of collection is also not true."

In a statement, Google said it was "troubled by allegations of the government intercepting traffic between our data centers, and we are not aware of this activity." Google also stated that it continues to extend encryption across more and more Google services and links.

Yahoo reportedly said, "We have strict controls in place to protect the security of our data centers, and we have not given access to our data centers to the NSA or to any other government agency."

In an interview in June, President Obama stated "unequivocally" that the NSA cannot and has not listened to the telephone calls nor targeted the emails of a U.S. person.

Read more about the latest developments in the NSA spying scandal at the Washington Post.

Title: US States Lift Lockdown Orders as Coronavirus Cases Remain High

Article:

More U.S. states are beginning to lift lockdown orders, despite warnings from U.S. leaders that social distancing guidelines will be necessary throughout the summer. Governors have cautioned that life will not quickly return to normal, and that restrictions will remain in some places to prevent the virus from resurging.

On Friday, the U.S. saw its largest single-day spike in cases. As of Tuesday, the U.S. has over 994,000 recorded coronavirus cases, according to Johns Hopkins University, and more than 56,700 deaths. Public health experts warn that lifting restrictions too soon could cause a second wave of infections.

The decision to end mandatory orders comes as over 26 million Americans seek unemployment protection, and the jobless rate climbs to around 16% of the population. Even as state governors allow orders to expire, some city mayors have issued their own separate plans to end local lockdown rules.

At one point, over 90% of the U.S. population was under mandatory lockdown orders, but some states began lifting orders over the weekend, allowing some Americans to return to hair salons and tattoo parlors. Georgia, Oklahoma, Alaska, and South Carolina have already allowed some businesses to reopen. They, along with other states, have issued plans that call for more rules to be relaxed in the coming week.

Colorado's Democratic Governor Jared Polis has said kerb-side retail pickup can begin on Monday, with hair salons, barbershops, and tattoo parlors allowed to reopen on Friday. Tennessee will allow restaurants to reopen on Monday, the same day that Mississippi's mandatory lockdown order expires. Montana's governor has allowed churches to reopen starting on Sunday, with social distancing measures still required. Restaurants and schools will be allowed to reopen on 7 May.

Eight states led by Republican governors - Arkansas, Iowa, Nebraska, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming - never issued mandatory orders to stay at home. Michigan's Democratic governor, who has angered protesters with her lockdown orders, told ABC News that it is too early to lift mandatory orders in the state.

"We've got to be nimble and we have to follow the science and be really smart about how we reengage," said Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. Despite a state-wide order to stay-at-home in California, thousands of people have flocked to beaches amid a heat wave.

But officials in both Ventura and Orange Counties, where beaches are open, said most people were adhering to social distancing guidelines, including staying 6ft (2m) apart. Many beaches are still closed, leading the sheriff of LA County to warn beach-goers that "enforcement is in full effect."

Texas' governor said he will not renew the state's stay-at-home order when it expires on 30 April because it "has done its job." Republican Greg Abbott said on Monday that retail business, as well as restaurants, cinemas, and malls can reopen - but at only 25% capacity - starting on Friday. Barbershops, hair salons, pubs, and gyms can not reopen until later in May, the governor said.

Ohio Republican Governor Mike DeWine, who has been praised for his virus response, said that non-essential surgery that does not require an overnight hospital stay can resume on 1 May. On 4 May, offices can reopen, and on 12 May, retail business can resume. "These are first steps," Mr. DeWine said. "We've got to get moving."

On Sunday, White House coronavirus taskforce co-ordinator Dr. Deborah Birx said social distancing will remain the norm "through the summer to really ensure that we protect one another as we move through these phases." Her comments come after Vice-President Mike Pence said the virus would be largely "behind us" by the 25 May Memorial Day holiday, which signals the unofficial start of summertime in the U.S.

Dr. Birx told Fox News this weekend that new cases and deaths "will be dramatically decreased by the end of May." On Monday, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo suggested some parts of his state could begin to reopen after the current stay-at-home order expires on 15 May. The governor said that transmission rates, as well as death rates, would dictate how and when the state reopens.

He urged local officials to follow national health guidelines for reopening and work together regionally, saying: "You have to be smart about it - we all have to be smart about it." Mr. Cuomo also noted he would extend restrictions in many parts of the state. There are still 1,000 new Covid-19 cases confirmed each day in New York. The death rate has dropped in New York, with 337 deaths on Sunday, compared to 367 deaths on Saturday and 437 on Friday. It represents the lowest increase since 30 March.

Title: Federal Appeals Court Strikes Down North Carolina's Voting Restrictions, Citing Discriminatory Intent

Article:

In a significant judicial decision, a federal appeals court has struck down North Carolina's voting restrictions, which were some of the strictest in the nation. The ruling comes after the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals struck down Texas's Voter ID laws and a federal district court placed an injunction against Wisconsin's.

Dale Ho, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) lawyer who argued the case in North Carolina, told The ███, "This is a huge victory." He added, "The tide is turning."

The new voting restrictions, as reported in February, were set to block over 1.3 million voters in four swing states—Ohio, North Carolina, Virginia, and Wisconsin—primarily by eliminating early voting periods and requiring specific forms of identification.

North Carolina's 2016 law affected more than 1.2 million people. Over 900,000 people utilized early voting in 2012, 130,000 used same-day registration in 2008, and more than 200,000 registered voters do not have driver's licenses. As of today, those votes are back in play.

In the 2008 and 2012 elections, Barack Obama won the state by 15,000 votes, and Mitt Romney won by 117,000 votes.

The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals did not just strike down North Carolina's new rules. The three-judge panel wrote an opinion filled with fiery rhetoric that condemned the state legislature for acting with discriminatory intent. The opinion noted that "after years of preclearance and expansion of voting access, by 2013 African American registration and turnout rates had finally reached near-parity with white registration and turnout rates. African Americans were poised to act as a major electoral force."

However, the court found that after the Supreme Court ruled that part of the Voting Rights Act was unconstitutional, the state "requested data on the use, by race, of a number of voting practices. Upon receipt of the race data, the General Assembly enacted legislation that restricted voting and registration in five different ways, all of which disproportionately affected African Americans."

The court's opinion is unusually strong, both in ordinary language and in legalese. It's not just that North Carolina's law happens to affect communities of color—the Court found that it was intended to do so all along.

This is different from the Fifth Circuit's finding that Texas's Voter ID law had a disparate impact on minority communities. It's actually calling out North Carolina for racial discrimination.

Ho explained, "Discriminatory intent means singling out a group on the basis of race and trying to disadvantage them on that basis. It doesn't matter if you hate black voters, or don't like how black voters vote. If you're targeting them, that is discrimination."

The court found that North Carolina did exactly that. Inventing a voter fraud crisis that didn't exist, the state "required in-person voters to show certain photo IDs, beginning in 2016, which African Americans disproportionately lacked, and eliminated or reduced registration and voting access tools that African Americans disproportionately used."

All this correlation, the court ruled, couldn't be an accident. There was no smoking gun—no careless comment about disenfranchising black voters—but the way the gun was loaded, aimed, and fired left no doubt about the law's purpose.

"The only clear factor linking these various'reforms' is their impact on African American voters," the court held. "The record thus makes obvious that the'problem' the majority in the General Assembly sought to remedy was emerging support for the minority party."

The cases in Wisconsin, Texas, and North Carolina represent a sea change in judicial opinion about voting restrictions. With challenges pending in Ohio, Virginia, and Kansas, it seems like voter suppression's days may be numbered.

Ho told The ███ that public opinion is shifting as well. "When these laws first got passed, people thought 'what's the big deal—I have ID.' But the truth is that while 90 percent of us do have ID, 10 percent don't... and it's those folks that these laws target. Not everyone has the same advantages that we have or live in the same circles."

In the meantime, North Carolina's photo ID requirement, changes to early voting, same-day registration, out-of-precinct voting, and preregistration have all been put on hold. A million more voters will now go to the polls.

While the state could appeal, Ho said, "I don't like their odds."

Title: Polls Show Tight Race in Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin as Obama and Romney-Ryan Ticket Narrowly Leads

Article:

According to the latest polls from Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times, the presidential race between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney remains close in three critical battleground states: Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin. The polls indicate that Obama has a slight edge in each state, with 49% of likely voters supporting him in Florida, 50% in Ohio, and 49% in Wisconsin, compared to 46%, 44%, and 47% for Romney, respectively.

The polls show only a slight boost for Romney since he named Paul Ryan as his running mate at the beginning of August. In Florida, support for Romney increased by one percentage point, while in Wisconsin, it increased by two percentage points. The Ohio numbers remained unchanged from a Quinnipiac University survey taken prior to the Paul Ryan announcement.

Peter A. Brown, assistant director of Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, stated in a statement accompanying the poll's release, "Gov. Mitt Romney's pick of U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan as his running mate has made some small difference in Florida and Wisconsin, at least at this point, when voters in these three key states are asked about their presidential vote."

Compared to Vice President Joe Biden, Ryan is seen in a more favorable light. In Florida, Ryan has a 29% unfavorable rating, compared to 44% for Biden. In Ohio, 27% of voters have an unfavorable impression of Ryan, compared to 40% for Biden. And in Wisconsin, Ryan's home state, the GOP vice presidential candidate has a 35% unfavorable rating, compared to 42% for Biden.

When voters assess the qualifications of the running mates to become president, Biden is only slightly ahead in Florida and Ohio, and slightly behind Ryan in Wisconsin. In fact, Ryan's qualified/unqualified ratio is better than Biden's.

Medicare, the government-run health care program for senior citizens, is a popular issue in all three states. The issue surfaced as a major issue on the presidential campaign trail when Romney named Ryan as his running mate, since Ryan has proposed a plan in the House that would allow private insurers to compete with traditional Medicare on an exchange.

Thursday's polls showed a majority of voters in the three battleground states saying they thought Medicare should continue operating the way it currently does, with the government providing insurance to seniors. Strong majorities also said they thought Medicare was worth the cost to taxpayers.

"By more than 4-1 margins, voters in each state say the health care program for the elderly is worth the cost and six in 10 say they favor keeping the current Medicare model," Brown wrote. "But 10% of voters in each state would support'major reductions' in Medicare to reduce the deficit and almost 50% would support'minor reductions.'"

The Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times poll was conducted by telephone between August 15 – 21. In Florida, 1,241 likely voters were polled; in Ohio, 1,253 were polled, and in Wisconsin, 1,190 were polled. The sampling error in all three states was plus or minus 2.8 percentage points.

Readers are encouraged to check out the CNN Electoral Map and Calculator and game out their own strategy for November.

Title: Illinois Voter Challenges Ted Cruz's Eligibility for Presidency in Court

Article:

An Illinois voter, Lawrence Joyce, will have his case heard in the Circuit Court of Cook County in Chicago on Friday, alleging that Republican presidential hopeful Ted Cruz is not a "natural-born citizen" and should be disqualified for the party's nomination. Joyce, a pharmacist and attorney from Poplar Grove, Ill, has objected to Cruz's placement on the Illinois primary ballot next month.

Joyce's previous objection, made to the state's Board of Elections, was dismissed on February 1. He appealed the decision and was granted a hearing for Friday before Judge Maureen Ward Kirby. Joyce challenges Cruz's right to be president in the wake of questions put forth by GOP rival Donald Trump about being born in Canada. Cruz maintains he is a natural-born citizen since his mother is American-born.

Republican contender Ben Carson has reportedly shown no interest in pursuing the matter, according to Joyce, who said he raised the issue with the Carson campaign. If Cruz wins the GOP nomination, Democrat Congressman Alan Grayson of Florida has threatened to file a lawsuit contesting Cruz's citizenship.

Joyce said he was hesitant to file the lawsuit out of concern that getting involved in such a high-profile case could be detrimental to his own law practice. "I tried to talk myself out of it and was unable to do so," Joyce said. "It's plain as day that Ted Cruz is not a natural-born citizen of the United States."

Cruz, at a CNN-hosted town hall meeting Wednesday night, defended his citizenship and right to run, saying he was born in Canada to a U.S. citizen, making him an automatic U.S. citizen. His mother was born in Wilmington, Del., Cruz said.

"I never breathed a breath of air on this planet when I was not a U.S. citizen," he said. "It was the act of being born that made me a U.S. citizen." Cruz spokesman Rick Tyler had no comment about the lawsuit, and the Trump campaign could not immediately be reached for comment.

A federal lawsuit was filed in Texas last month asking for a determination of Cruz's eligibility to run. Voters in New York, who raised similar concerns about Cruz's citizenship, on Thursday filed a challenge with the state Board of Election challenging the senator's eligibility to be on the ballot.

Constitutional law professor Sanford Levinson of the University of Texas School of Law said Joyce would have to prove standing – or why Cruz's potential ineligibility affects him specifically – for the judge to proceed with the case. Even if the judge declares Cruz to be ineligible to run, the GOP candidate's campaign would undoubtedly file an appeal, potentially tying the case up for months.

It's surprising that a lower court would even agree to hear the case, which is entangled in broader constitutional issues, Sanford said. "I'd be very, very surprised if [the judge] were to say he's ineligible," he said. "At that point, all hell would break loose."

Title: Libertarian Party Ticket Gains Momentum as General Election Approaches

Article:

The Libertarian Party ticket, consisting of nominee Gary Johnson and running mate William Weld, is experiencing a surge in support as the 2016 U.S. presidential election enters its final stages. This surge in interest could potentially place Johnson on the highly coveted debate stage this fall.

Despite the unpopularity of the Republican and Democratic candidates, few anticipate the Libertarian ticket to pose a significant threat akin to Ross Perot's 1992 campaign. However, the party is garnering attention due to rumors of high-profile Republicans considering their support, a well-received video from Johnson and Weld, and polls showing Johnson receiving close to 15 percent, the threshold required to secure a place on the debate stage alongside Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton.

According to the RealClearPolitics average, Johnson is currently at 8.4 percent in a four-way race that includes Trump, Clinton, and Green Party candidate Jill Stein. This is an increase from 4.5 percent in June. The latest poll, released on Wednesday, places Johnson at 12 percent. An NBC poll taken during the Democratic convention placed Johnson at 9 percent, a level consistent with prior polling.

Nicholas Sarwark, chairman of the Libertarian National Committee, stated that the unpopularity of the Republican and Democratic candidates provides the party with an "unprecedented opportunity." Sarwark emphasized that Johnson's record as a two-term New Mexico governor, who was re-elected as a Republican in a Democratic state, strengthens his credentials and appeal.

However, it remains unclear whether the polling support will translate into votes at the ballot box. In 2012, Johnson won just 0.99 percent of all votes cast, making him the most successful White House candidate in Libertarian history, but not making a significant impact on the overall race.

This year, there are indications that more voters are seeking an alternative candidate. At the Democratic convention last week, many Bernie Sanders supporters expressed support for the Green Party's Jill Stein. However, Johnson is currently polling better among third-party candidates.

Johnson and Weld generated buzz before the conventions with a slick video ad highlighting their accomplishments. Johnson stated in an interview with the Los Angeles Times that he believes the Libertarian stance on social issues and foreign policy could attract Sanders voters.

Sarwark stated that the party is banking on the fact that while Trump and Clinton are well-known, Johnson still has an opportunity to introduce himself to voters unfamiliar with his story, particularly if he is able to secure a place on the debate stage.

Currently, Johnson's support is higher than in past years, but an 8.4 percent average is still a significant distance from the 15 percent he would need to make the debates. Johnson has until the middle of September to reach 15 percent in not just one poll but an average of five recent polls chosen by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

"Politically, where we stand, is we have to get into those presidential debates to really stand a chance," Weld told The Wall Street Journal last week. "If we catch a break or two, we may get there."

Even if Johnson reaches the 15 percent threshold, the historical record for third-party or independent candidates is not strong. In recent political history, the one who came closest to the presidency was businessman Ross Perot in 1992, who was an independent, not technically a third-party candidate. At one point, Perot led in some polls against then-President George H.W. Bush and Democratic challenger Bill Clinton. However, after dropping out of the race before re-entering, he lost support and eventually garnered 19 percent of the vote. Some Republicans argue that Perot split the GOP vote and handed the election to Clinton.

Republicans were arguably given a boost by Green Party candidate Ralph Nader in 2000, when Nader picked up 2.7 percent of the vote against Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W. Bush. Johnson's potential impact is difficult to gauge, but the latest poll found Johnson siphoning support about equally from the Democratic and GOP candidates. Johnson could receive a boost in the coming weeks as some Republicans reportedly consider backing him.

Most notably, 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush are reportedly considering endorsements for Johnson. Marvin Bush, youngest brother of Jeb and George W., also endorsed Johnson last week. According to Sarwark, the party is still considering endorsements from the Bush and Romney camps.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Same-Sex Marriage Cases, Encouraging Lower Courts to Uphold Same-Sex Marriage

Article:

In a significant development, the Supreme Court declined on Monday to take on the issue of gay marriage, effectively allowing same-sex marriage to proceed in several states. The affected states include Indiana, Oklahoma, Utah, Virginia, and Wisconsin, which have been instructed to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

The Supreme Court's decision not to intervene indicates a preference for lower courts to continue striking down traditional marriage laws across the country. The Court is expected to wait until a majority of states have been compelled to recognize same-sex marriage by lower-level appeals courts before establishing a "trend-line" and declaring a new standard.

The logic behind this approach was previously demonstrated in the 2003 case of Lawrence v. Texas, where the Court waited 17 years to overrule Bowers v. Hardwick (1986), which had criminalized anal sex. In Lawrence v. Texas, the Court stated that the earlier ruling no longer applied due to an "emerging awareness" that liberty provides substantial protection for adult persons in matters pertaining to sex.

Justice Scalia, in his dissent, argued that the Court's statement was false, as states still regulate various sexual activities, such as prostitution, adult incest, adultery, obscenity, and child pornography. He also noted that Constitutional entitlements do not arise because some states choose to lessen or eliminate criminal sanctions on certain behavior.

The Supreme Court's strategy allows lower courts to violate the Constitution, and then declare the Constitution changed due to an "emerging consensus" on violating the Constitution. Critics argue that this approach undermines the democratic process, as citizens cannot pass laws that have been fully Constitutional for two and a half centuries, cannot fight state attorneys general who betray their voters, and must endure the courts playing legal games while awaiting the Court's "evolution" – an evolution that is largely top-down and will be dictated to us by our betters.

Ben Shapiro, Senior Editor-At-Large of ███ and author of the book "The People vs. Barack Obama: The Criminal Case Against The Obama Administration," has been vocal on this issue. He is also Editor-in-Chief of TruthRevolt.org and can be found on Twitter @benshapiro.

Title: FBI and NCTC Assessment Contradicts CIA Director's Account of Benghazi Attack

Article:

Two days after the deadly attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, representatives from the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC) provided briefings to Capitol Hill, stating that the evidence supported an Al Qaeda or Al Qaeda-affiliated attack. This assessment contrasts with the briefing by CIA Director David Petraeus the following day, which described the attack as tied to a demonstration.

The Sept. 13 assessment by the FBI and NCTC was based on intercepts that included individuals believed to have participated in the attack who were celebratory and a claim of responsibility. The briefings also revealed a series of Al Qaeda training camps just outside of Benghazi, where the attack occurred, and the area was described as a hotbed for the militant group Ansar al-Sharia and Al Qaeda in North Africa. There was no mention of a demonstration or significant emphasis on the anti-Islam video that administration officials had cited as a motivating factor for the attack.

On Capitol Hill, Petraeus characterized the attack as more consistent with a flash mob, where militants showed up spontaneously with RPGs. Petraeus downplayed the skill needed to fire mortars, which were also used in the attack and were seen as evidence of significant pre-planning. As previously reported, four mortars were fired, two of which missed the annex, but the mortar team re-calibrated, and the next two mortars were direct hits.

Petraeus seemed wedded to the narrative that the attack was linked to a demonstration and was spontaneous as opposed to pre-meditated. Petraeus was "absolute" in his description with few, if any, caveats. As lawmakers learned more about the attack, including through raw intelligence reports, they were "angry, disappointed, and frustrated" that the CIA director had not provided a more complete picture of the available intelligence.

Reached for comment, a spokesperson for the NCTC referred ███ to the Sept. 28 statement from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which said the assessment changed to indicate that it did not stem from a protest but rather was deliberate and organized.

A U.S. intelligence official disputed the characterization of Petraeus' briefing to lawmakers on Sept. 14, saying: "The first briefing (to the Hill) carefully laid out the full range of sparsely available information, with briefers noting that extremists -- including those with possible links to AQIM and Ansar al-Sharia -- were involved in attacks that appeared spontaneous."

As for the current assessment of the Benghazi attack, a U.S. intelligence official said no one is ruling out the idea that militants may have aspired to attack the U.S., though the bulk of available information supports the early assessment that extremists, with ties to al Qaeda and Ansar al-Sharia, did not plan the attacks for days or weeks in advance.

One source who heard Petraeus brief also told ███, "I can confirm that he explicitly stated both to the House and the Senate oversight committees that members of AQIM and AAS participated in the attack in Benghazi. That assessment still stands."

Intelligence officials have given a mixed picture of what happened that day, acknowledging that an investigation is underway. The office of Director of National Intelligence James Clapper last month acknowledged the strike was a coordinated terror attack, but officials have subsequently said the strike could have been opportunistic, taking their cue from protests over the film in Egypt. Still, some point to the use of mortars and several other strands of evidence to claim the attack involved some premeditation.

Title: Violence Erupts in Cairo as Egyptian Security Forces Disperse Muslim Brotherhood Protests

Article:

Egyptian security forces, utilizing armored cars, bulldozers, tear gas, and automatic weapons, cleared two protest camps in Cairo established by supporters of ousted Islamist President Mohammed Morsi on Wednesday. The clashes resulted in hundreds of casualties, with at least 149 deaths and over 1,400 injuries, according to the Egyptian government.

The smaller camp, located at Nahda Square near Cairo University, was cleared within hours, as reported by The New York Times. However, protesters at the larger camp around the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque in the northeastern suburb of Nasr City continued to engage in battles with police forces into the morning.

Egypt's interim government issued a statement expressing sorrow over the bloodshed. In a statement on state-run TV, a spokesman attributed the violence to the Muslim Brotherhood and urged protesters to refrain from using violence. The spokesman also warned that authorities would not tolerate any attempts to attack state buildings or police stations.

Officials had long warned that they would move to disperse the protest camps, and protesters had been preparing for the anticipated crackdown. The New York Times reported that some protesters were throwing Molotov cocktails and broken paving stones, while military snipers targeted demonstrators.

There were conflicting reports regarding the number of casualties. Western reporters at several morgues and hospitals observed dozens of dead protesters with gunshot wounds to the head and chest, suggesting that authorities were shooting to kill. Muslim Brotherhood leaders claimed that hundreds had been killed by indiscriminate fire from soldiers and police, while the authorities reported approximately a dozen deaths, including two police officers.

Wednesday's events are likely to widen the divide between supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood and secularists and religious minorities who largely supported the military's July 3 ouster of Morsi, following mass protests against his rule. The Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights, a human rights group, reported that the crackdown had already spurred attacks by Brotherhood supporters against Coptic Christian churches in southern Egypt.

Title: Stephen Moore Shares Insights on Trump's Impact on Republican Party and Future Conservatism

Article:

Stephen Moore, a senior economic adviser to Donald Trump, has stated that Trump's victory has shifted the Republican Party into a more populist working-class party. Moore, who was once a doctrinaire libertarian and free-trader, expressed this view in a conversation with House Republicans and in an interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep.

Moore, an economic consultant with FreedomWorks, a grass-roots organization that helped launch the Tea Party, discussed Trump's plans to revive U.S. manufacturing jobs, being tough with China on trade, and the president-elect's personal business holdings.

Regarding Trump's approach to trade, Moore acknowledged the benefits of free trade but also recognized the impact it has had on certain sectors and regions. He suggested that Trump's tough stance on China and potential negotiations could lead to better deals without resorting to protectionism and raising tariffs.

On the issue of China's potential leverage over Trump due to his business dealings, Moore expressed doubt, stating that Trump would put his business dealings aside to act in the national interest.

When asked about the feasibility of bringing back jobs to industries that peaked decades ago, such as steel and coal, Moore expressed optimism, citing the potential for a better tax system, a better regulatory system, and the U.S.'s competitive advantages in terms of trained workers and low-cost energy.

Regarding the possibility of Trump imposing 35 percent tariffs if he fails to renegotiate trade deals with China and Mexico, Moore expressed opposition to tariffs and hoped that Trump would not resort to this measure. Moore stated that he has tried to push Trump in the right direction on these issues and that Trump has expressed support for free and fair trade.

Title: Minnesota Sen. Al Franken Resigns Amid Sexual Misconduct Allegations, Cites President Trump as Part of the Irony

Article:

Minnesota Democratic Sen. Al Franken announced his resignation from the U.S. Senate on Thursday, following a series of sexual misconduct allegations that ranged from groping to forcibly trying to kiss women. In his 11-minute speech, Franken acknowledged some of the complaints against him as "simply not true" and that he remembers others "differently."

During the announcement, Franken took a parting shot at President Trump, stating, "There is some irony in the fact that I am leaving office while a man who has bragged on tape about his history of sexual assault sits in the Oval Office, and a man who has repeatedly preyed on young girls campaigns for the Senate with the full support of his party." Franken was referring to Trump and Roy Moore, the Republican candidate for Senate in Alabama.

Senators, staff, and family members were present for the announcement, with some sitting stone-faced and others crying. Alaska Sen. Dan Sullivan was the only Republican senator present. New York Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand and Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar were also in attendance, among the lengthy list of Democrats pressuring Franken to resign.

Klobuchar stated, "As he and I discussed yesterday, this is the right decision." Virginia Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine had a "detailed conversation" with Franken Wednesday evening, and stated, "He did what I suggested -- and he did the right thing -- so I'm just going to leave it there."

Minnesota Democratic Gov. Mark Dayton will appoint a successor to fill the remainder of Franken's term until a special election is held in 2018. The likely candidate could be Democratic Lt. Gov. Tina Smith, a close ally of Franken.

The calls for Franken's resignation began after California radio broadcaster Leeann Tweeden posted a blog detailing how Franken kissed and groped her without her consent in 2006. Since then, seven additional women have come forward with allegations against Franken.

The latest allegation was from a woman who claimed she was groped at a Media Matters party during the first Obama inauguration. Before that, another woman accused Franken of forcibly trying to kiss her after a taping of his radio show in 2006. The accuser, who was not identified, said Franken tried to kiss her but that she ducked.

The calls for Franken to step down came after Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., retired following numerous allegations of sexual misconduct against him. In Alabama, several women have accused Moore, the Senate Republican candidate, of sexual misconduct when they were in their teens, including one who said she was 14 when Moore molested her. Trump, who had multiple allegations of sexual harassment against himself when running for president, has endorsed Moore.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Kelly Clarifies Immigration Policies, Assures "Dreamers" of Relative Safety

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary John F. Kelly, in an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, clarified the Trump administration's stance on immigration, particularly regarding individuals who are in the country illegally and those protected under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

Mr. Kelly stated that while anyone in the U.S. illegally is subject to deportation by law, the administration is not focusing on "Dreamers" shielded by DACA. He explained that the administration's objectives are to secure the Southwest border and to remove those who reside in the U.S. unlawfully and are considered the "worst" of the undocumented population.

In response to recent concerns about mixed messages regarding who is at risk for deportation, Mr. Kelly emphasized that individuals who are simply in the country illegally are not a priority for enforcement. He also stated that illegal immigrants should still report domestic violence and other crimes, as they can usually do so anonymously.

The administration's immigration policies have been tested in recent weeks, with the case of 23-year-old Juan Manuel Montes, a DACA recipient who was deported to Mexico in February, garnering significant attention. Immigrant rights groups and Democrats have rallied to his cause, but Mr. Kelly has maintained that Mr. Montes gave up his DACA status through "illegal actions."

Sen. Richard Durbin (D-IL) suggested that if President Trump truly wants to protect people, he should stop targeting sanctuary cities that refuse to alert federal officials of illegal immigrants in their custody, allowing undocumented residents to come forward freely when crimes occur. Mr. Durbin also warned against insisting on funding for the border wall with Mexico in a stopgap funding bill, stating it could lead to a government shutdown.

Despite Sen. Durbin's warning, Mr. Kelly gave no indication that President Trump plans to back off the demand for wall funding. Mr. Kelly stated, "I think it goes without saying that the president has been pretty straightforward about his desire and the need for a border wall. So, I would suspect, he'll do the right thing for sure, but I would suspect he will be insistent on the funding."

Title: Libertarian and Green Party Candidates Offer Alternative to Mainstream Presidential Candidates

Article:

The Libertarian Party's candidate, Gary Johnson, and the Green Party's Jill Stein are presenting voters with an alternative to the two main-party nominees, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. Here is a comprehensive overview of the two third-party candidates:

Gary Johnson, a former Republican governor of New Mexico, is the Libertarian candidate. Johnson, who is 63 years old, is a fitness enthusiast who has climbed Mount Everest and is the former CEO of a legal cannabis company. He has long supported marijuana legalization, although he has pledged not to use the drug in the White House if elected. His running mate is another former Republican governor, Bill Weld, from Massachusetts. Both men, while in office, pursued libertarian principles of small government and less regulation, cutting taxes and vetoing spending programs.

Johnson and Weld are campaigning on a traditional libertarian ticket of small government and individual freedom. As fiscal conservatives, they support a single consumption tax and want to scrap the Dodd-Frank law regulating Wall Street. They generally conform to the libertarian belief that government works best by staying out of people's lives, favoring legalizing marijuana and opposing gun restrictions. They initially opposed mandatory vaccinations (though Johnson has since changed his position), and support the right to abortion and gay marriage.

Jill Stein, a Harvard-trained physician turned liberal activist, is the Green Party nominee. She is selling herself as the progressive "Plan B" for disaffected Bernie Sanders supporters. Stein, who is 66 years old, echoes many of Sanders' policies, such as a $15-per-hour federal minimum wage, a "wartime-scale mobilization" to defeat climate change, a single-payer health-care system, and the abolition of all student debt. However, she goes much further to the left, calling for unilateral nuclear disarmament, a 50 percent cut to the military budget, the elimination of all fossil fuels by 2030, and paying reparations for slavery. Stein has expressed concerns about the safety of vaccinations and Wi-Fi. Her running mate, human rights activist Ajamu Baraka, once called President Obama an "Uncle Tom" who has betrayed African-Americans.

The chances of either Stein or Johnson winning the presidency are close to zero. However, the two main-party nominees, Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump, are the least liked candidates in the modern political era. Four out of 10 voters think neither would make a good president, leaving the door wide open for Johnson and Stein to attract a significant protest vote. Johnson has climbed to over 10 percent in some polls, and in a four-way matchup against Trump and Clinton, he and Stein together collect up to 14 percent of registered voters. That is enough to affect whether Trump or Clinton wins in some critical swing states.

Johnson could lose support to Trump among Republican "NeverTrumpers" who do not view the bombastic businessman as a true conservative, and who are attracted to Johnson's fiscal conservatism and pro–gun rights record. Clinton, on the other hand, could lose votes to Johnson, whose support for marijuana legalization and a rollback of government surveillance appeals to young voters. This has led many Democrats to warn that Johnson and Stein could jointly become the Ralph Nader of the 2016 election.

In 2000, Nader, the Green Party candidate, pulled thousands of votes in Florida away from Democrat Al Gore, a state George W. Bush won by just 537 votes. That gave the election to Bush, even though he lost the overall popular vote to Gore. This year, if the election proves tighter than polls currently indicate, it is possible that Johnson and Stein could cost Clinton enough votes in a key battleground state or two to alter the outcome of the election. Johnson embraces the idea of being the "spoiler" candidate. "I will lose no sleep if that's the label given to me," he says. "This is a party that needs crashing." Stein also rejects the idea that voters must choose "the lesser evil," arguing that Clinton is not a true progressive.

Both Johnson and Stein are desperate to make it into the first presidential debate, on Sept. 26. However, they face a steep climb. A candidate needs to hit 15 percent in five national polls to make it onto the stage, according to debate commission rules. Johnson is polling at an average of 8.8 percent, while Stein is at 3.4 percent. The two candidates face a classic catch-22: They won't be included until they prove they are competitive in the polls, but cannot compete without the attention and name recognition a prime-time presidential debate would bring. Johnson and Stein are suing the commission for the right to participate. If they were part of the debates, the race might be very different. "For people to choose Gary Johnson," says political operative Roger Stone, an informal adviser to Trump, "they need to know that he's running." In 2012, Stone backed and provided advice to Johnson's first presidential run as a Libertarian, when he won just 1 percent of the vote in the race against President Obama and Mitt Romney. "There was another choice," Stone says, "it's just that nobody knew about it."

Title: Senate Immigration Bill Faces Criticism Over Border Security and Enforcement Discretion

Article:

The recently released Senate immigration bill, which includes a multibillion-dollar investment in border security, has faced criticism from some quarters over a perceived loophole regarding enforcement discretion. The National ICE Council President, Chris Crane, has expressed dissatisfaction, stating that the bill does not address concerns about the Obama administration's handling of immigration enforcement.

In a letter to Sen. Marco Rubio, a key member of the bipartisan group of lawmakers drafting the bill, Crane expressed disappointment that the bill does not address the issues he raised. The letter was sent shortly before the bill's formal release.

Crane, who represents the union of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, had long sought a meeting with Rubio to discuss his concerns. In the letter, he thanked Rubio for the meeting but criticized the bill for not addressing his concerns about the enforcement of immigration laws.

Crane's concerns revolve around what he describes as the government's discretion in enforcing immigration laws, a practice that ICE agents have long criticized. The Obama administration has been accused of making the job of ICE agents more difficult by preventing them from detaining and deporting certain illegal immigrants.

The Senate bill aims to invest billions in border security, with a focus on a security and fencing plan. To address conservative concerns, the bill establishes a set of "triggers" that must be met before illegal immigrants currently in the country can apply for a green card. These triggers include the Department of Homeland Security launching a new border security and fencing plan and achieving high levels of apprehension along high-risk areas on the Mexican border.

However, Crane has called for the bill to be held until several major issues are addressed, including what he described as "directives" that release "dangerous criminal aliens" back into the community and the Obama administration's "dangerous abuse" of prosecutorial discretion.

The administration has allowed "prosecutorial discretion" to focus on deporting high-risk illegal immigrants. Officials have said that criminal aliens are generally not being released, and that only low-priority individuals are given a reprieve. The administration also issued a directive allowing some illegal immigrants who came to the U.S. as children to stay.

Critics warn that legalizing the millions of illegal immigrants already in the country without establishing a strict system of interior enforcement will allow the problem to persist. Sen. Jeff Sessions, a prominent critic of the immigration bill, echoed Crane's concerns.

Sessions is expected to join Sen. David Vitter for a press conference on the bill Thursday afternoon. The bill is scheduled to come up for its first hearing on Friday. Rubio, like other Republicans, has said the bill should receive a thorough review on Capitol Hill.

The nearly 900-page bill contains a number of other measures, including a new system of temporary visas for low-skill workers and expanded visas for high-skill workers. Unlike the recently stalled gun control legislation, the immigration bill comes out of the gate with bipartisan backing. Rubio was one of four Republicans drafting the bill, and some other Republicans have expressed a willingness to consider an immigration overhaul.

Title: James O' Keefe Accused of Staging Alleged Sexual Assault Story for Roy Moore

Article:

In a recent revelation by The Washington Post, it has been exposed that conservative filmmaker James O' Keefe, in collaboration with Project Veritas, hired a woman to fabricate a story of an alleged sexual relationship with Republican Senate candidate Roy Moore in 1992, which led to an abortion when she was 15.

The woman, Jaime T. Phillips, shared this dramatic story during a series of interviews over a two-week period. During these interviews, she repeatedly pressed Post reporters for their opinions on the potential impact of her claims on Moore's candidacy if she went public.

However, it was later revealed that Phillips was working for O' Keefe and Project Veritas. In essence, O' Keefe hired a woman to lie about sexual assault in an attempt to cast doubt on women who were actually assaulted by Moore.

In another attempt to deceive the public, O' Keefe claimed he would reveal "the truth" including video of a "confrontation" with one of the Post reporters who supposedly forced his way into the offices at O' Keefe's Project Veritas. However, it was the Washington Post that was recording the events, including how O' Keefe himself invited the reporter to come to the office.

The Washington Post sent a team, including reporter Manu Raju and two video reporters, to the Project Veritas offices in Mamaroneck, NY, on Monday morning to determine whether Phillips worked there. They observed Phillips entering the office, and O' Keefe, who appeared minutes later, declined to answer questions. He invited Raju back for an interview shortly after noon.

As is typical for O' Keefe, what his followers received was a highly edited version of this encounter, designed to make it look like he hadn't been caught not only lying, but lying to aid and abet sexual assault.

Voters in Alabama can support the truth by donating to Doug Jones, allowing him to get the actual truth out to every voter in the state.

Title: Obama Announces Ban on Certain Military-Style Equipment for Police, Emphasizes Community Policing

Article:

President Obama has announced a ban on the acquisition of certain military-style equipment by local police departments, stating that such equipment can alienate and intimidate local residents and send the wrong message. The announcement was made during a visit to Camden, New Jersey, as part of an effort to ease tensions between police and minority communities in the wake of several high-profile police-involved shootings.

Under new recommendations, police forces will be prohibited from acquiring equipment such as tracked armored vehicles, weaponized aircraft, and high-caliber weapons and ammunition. The proposal is one of several made by a White House task force, which Obama is implementing through an executive order on Monday.

According to a report issued by the White House, the task force weighed the utility of the equipment to local police against its potential negative impact on the community if used arbitrarily or inappropriately. Local police departments can still purchase this equipment independently, but they cannot acquire it from federal agencies or use federal funds for the purchase.

Obama's visit to one of New Jersey's poorest cities comes as he seeks to increase federal funding for community policing initiatives in the wake of a series of high-profile incidents that have strained trust between officers and residents in Ferguson, Missouri, New York, and Baltimore, among other cities. Camden has historically been one of New Jersey's most crime-ridden cities, but reforms over the past two years have led to falling crime statistics and an increased number of officers in the community.

The White House has also outlined several other initiatives that Obama will highlight on Monday, including:

* The Police Data Initiative, which will help police departments across the country track use of force and police stops, with data scientists assisting some departments in refining an early warning system using data to flag potential problems.
* The release of big data sets by 21 jurisdictions, providing communities with visibility into key information on police/citizen encounters.
* The release of a body-cam tool kit to help police plan and implement body-camera programs.
* The Department of Justice will begin accepting applications for grants designed to advance the practice of community policing in law enforcement agencies through hiring, training, and technical assistance, the development of innovative community policing strategies, applied research, guidebooks, and best practices that are national in scope.

Title: Former Senator Rick Santorum Announces Second Presidential Bid, Focuses on Immigration and Economic Policies

Article:

Former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania has launched his second bid for the presidency, emphasizing his commitment to working-class Americans and their economic well-being. At a manufacturing company in Pennsylvania, Santorum declared his candidacy, stating, "Working families don't need another president tied to big government or big money. Today is the day we are going to begin to fight back!"

Santorum, who finished as the runner-up to Mitt Romney in the 2012 Republican nomination race, has been open about his desire to re-enter the political arena. Surrounded by his family, he outlined a "bold" conservative vision, which includes abolishing the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and replacing the current tax code with a "simple, fair, flat tax."

He pledged to cut government spending, repeal executive orders and regulations that cost American jobs, and to advocate for a stronger education system, military members, and pro-life legislation. In terms of foreign policy, Santorum promised a muscular approach and a commitment to protecting American workers who have been affected by the nation's immigration laws.

Santorum criticized the influx of mostly unskilled workers over the past 20 years, stating that it has led to stagnant wages and family incomes. He contrasted his priorities with those of Hillary Clinton and big business, whom he accused of prioritizing profits and power, while his priority is the American worker.

Political analysts suggest that Santorum's bid for the presidency may face challenges due to the strength of the field and the presence of several fresh faces, such as Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson. Additionally, religious conservatives will have other candidates to choose from, including Cruz, Carson, and former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, who won the Iowa caucuses in 2008.

In 2012, Santorum gained support from voters before the Iowa caucuses as the anyone-but-Romney candidate. He won the caucuses and a total of 11 nomination contests, benefiting from strong support from born-again or evangelical Christians and the financial backing of Foster Friess, who helped fund the pro-Santorum "Red, White and Blue Fund" Super PAC. Friess is supporting Santorum once again and attended his campaign launch.

An immediate challenge facing Santorum could be qualifying for the first GOP-sanctioned debate on Aug. 6, which will be hosted by Fox News and is limiting participants to the top 10 of an average of national polls. According to the latest Real Clear Politics Average of polls, Santorum is currently running tenth.

Santorum is scheduled to make campaign stops in Iowa and South Carolina this week as part of a "Take America Back Tour."

Title: CNBC Republican Debate Marks Potential End of Jeb Bush's Presidential Campaign

Article:

The third Republican debate, held on October 29, 2015, was primarily remembered for two significant factors: CNBC's controversial moderation and the perceived decline of Jeb Bush's presidential campaign. The debate, which was supposed to focus on economic policy, was met with criticism for its slanted nature, factual errors, and a parade of "gotcha" questions.

Several candidates, including Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, directly called out the biased coverage during the debate. Co-host John Harwood, who was perceived as tendentious and argumentative, repeatedly interrupted candidates and failed to clarify his factual errors when pushed back upon.

Jeb Bush, who has underperformed in the polls, was criticized for his handling of the debate. His attempt to take a hard shot at Marco Rubio's missed Senate votes early in the proceedings was met with a strong counter-punch from Rubio, which was well-received by the audience. This exchange, along with several other strong answers, marked a clear turning point in the debate for Rubio.

Ted Cruz also delivered a strong performance, emphasizing the need for entitlement reform, job creation, and his new tax plan. He was particularly critical of the debate's unseriousness and produced an incredulous soundbite that has since become an instant classic.

Other candidates, such as Carly Fiorina, Ben Carson, and Donald Trump, also had their moments during the debate. However, each man issued flat denials on challenges brought by moderators that turned out to be untrue, which may have negatively impacted their credibility.

The debate was widely criticized for CNBC's moderation, with many viewing it as a self-humiliation for the network. The debate marked a significant turning point for Jeb Bush's campaign, with some suggesting that his campaign may have suffered a mortal blow. The future of his campaign remains uncertain, but it is clear that his performance during the debate was underwhelming.

Title: Bloomberg's Unprecedented Campaign Strategy in California and Super Tuesday States

Article:

Billionaire Michael Bloomberg's presidential campaign has significantly expanded its operations in California, hiring 200 employees, according to his campaign, surpassing the 80-strong team of rival Bernie Sanders. This move comes after Bloomberg entered the race in November, following a wave of resources that has allowed him to spend more on television ads nationally than all other Democratic candidates combined.

Bloomberg's unprecedented spending, totaling over a quarter-billion dollars on advertising alone since November, could disrupt the competition in California and the other 13 states voting on Super Tuesday. Super Tuesday, on March 3, will award nearly a third of the 3,979 state delegates that will help select a Democratic nominee. In contrast, the four early states - Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, and South Carolina - award less than 4% of the delegates combined.

While most Democratic candidates have focused on Iowa and New Hampshire since November, Bloomberg has primarily targeted states that don't typically receive attention at this stage in the race. This year's Super Tuesday could prove particularly crucial, especially if the first four states fail to produce a clear front-runner.

In California, Bloomberg has a staff of 150, while Senator Elizabeth Warren, who appears to have the next biggest presence, has more than two dozen paid staffers. Bloomberg's spending spree has also increased the cost of television ads in Texas, potentially making it more challenging for other candidates to keep up, according to an aide for a rival campaign.

Both Sanders and Biden are currently leading in national polls, with Biden appealing to moderates and Sanders to liberals. If Biden emerges as the front-runner in Iowa and New Hampshire, he could consolidate the support of moderates and potentially push Bloomberg aside before he even reaches a ballot, several Democratic strategists said. On the other hand, a Sanders surge could open a door for Bloomberg, given uncertainty among moderate voters about Sanders' ability to beat Republican President Donald Trump in November.

Bloomberg's campaign has 800 staffers in place across 35 states, with hundreds more at his campaign headquarters in New York. In Texas, his campaign's staffing is the second-largest after California. Other candidates' Super Tuesday operations will soon receive an influx of staffers, as organizers depart states like Iowa to bolster efforts elsewhere.

In a recent memo to supporters, Warren's campaign manager, Roger Lau, stated that the campaign has more than 1,000 staff members and more than 100 field offices in 31 states. This includes hundreds of organizers in states that vote after Super Tuesday, such as Pennsylvania and Washington. Sanders is also relying on enthusiastic volunteers, with volunteers holding over 560 events for Sanders in Texas, while the candidate himself has visited four times this primary season.

In an interview with [redacted] last month, Bloomberg stated that he was forced to skip the first four voting states because "all the political operatives were taken up" by the time he decided to enter the race. However, he vowed to go everywhere else, saying, "You want to go where the voters are... And I'd like to go to every one of the states."

Title: Bloomberg News to Maintain Independence During 2020 Presidential Campaign Amid Former Mayor's Candidacy

Article:

Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has entered the 2020 presidential race, and the media angle of his announcement has raised questions about the impartiality of Bloomberg News, given that the media organization is owned by the candidate. In a note to staff obtained by CNN, Bloomberg News editor-in-chief John Micklethwait acknowledged the challenges this presents.

Micklethwait wrote, "There is no point in trying to claim that covering this presidential campaign will be easy for a newsroom that has built up its reputation for independence in part by not writing about ourselves (and very rarely about our direct competitors)." He further stated, "No previous presidential candidate has owned a journalistic organization of this size."

To address these concerns, Micklethwait outlined several measures. The editorials, which have reflected Bloomberg's views, will be suspended, and the editors responsible will take a leave of absence to join his campaign. The columnists, who produce the majority of Bloomberg Opinion's content, will continue to speak for themselves. The news organization will also continue to accept op-ed articles from external sources, although not on the election.

Regarding campaign coverage, Micklethwait stated, "We will continue our tradition of not investigating Mike (and his family and foundation) and we will extend the same policy to his rivals in the Democratic primaries." He added that if other news outlets run investigative pieces on Bloomberg or others, they won't "hide" them from readers.

Currently, Bloomberg News reporters are continuing to investigate the Trump administration, as the government of the day. If Bloomberg is chosen as the Democratic presidential candidate and Donald Trump emerges as the Republican one, they will reassess how they do that.

In conclusion, Bloomberg News editor-in-chief John Micklethwait has outlined measures to maintain the news organization's independence during the 2020 presidential campaign, despite the candidacy of its owner, Michael Bloomberg.

Title: White House Silences Gun Control Groups to Ensure Presidential Unity in Push for New Gun Control Laws

Article:

President Barack Obama's gun control agenda appears to be facing increasing challenges, yet key gun control advocates have remained silent on the matter. The White House, in an effort to maintain a unified front during the push for new gun control laws, has reportedly muted gun control groups by offering them access and involvement in exchange for silence and support.

According to conversations with several involved parties, the White House has implied that gun control groups should avoid infighting, refrain from second-guessing in the press, and support the president and Vice President Joe Biden's proposals. The most crucial requirement is to avoid making waves or getting ahead of the White House.

In return, these groups are granted a voice in the discussions, a role in any final agreement, and weekly meetings at the White House with Bruce Reed, Biden's chief of staff, under the condition that they do not discuss what transpires during these meetings.

One regular attendee described the meetings as a unified front, stating, "It's not like they're being bullies, it's them bringing everybody together, not being one-off meetings with groups that might be interested in things other than the bottom line, not providing the forum for that kind of stuff."

Another participant in the Reed meetings commented, "You're glad to be in the room because this issue has been dead for a long time, and now there's a real opportunity there."

For the White House, which declined to comment on Reed's meetings or the relationships with the gun control groups, this strategy is aimed at ensuring the president has a unified front as he pushes for new laws and avoiding shouldering the blame if and when the negotiations fail.

The White House's strategy has resulted in a significant change for some of Washington's most vocal gun control advocates, including the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, Third Way, Michael Bloomberg's Mayors Against Illegal Guns, and Americans for Responsible Solutions, the organization founded by former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords (D-Ariz.) and her husband, Mark Kelly. In past fights, gun control groups have sparred with each other and dictated the agenda to allies in Congress.

Now, these groups are content with merely being included in the discussion and still holding out hope that something might happen. Paul Helmke, who was the Brady Campaign president from 2006 to 2011, stated, "We need the White House."

This reliance on the White House has persisted even as the prospects for any legislation have diminished on even the most basic measures. On Wednesday, Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) ended bipartisan talks on universal background checks with Sen. Tom Coburn (R-Okla.) and filed his own bill without co-sponsors or the suggestions made by Coburn and Sens. Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) and Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.).

Title: Hillary Clinton's Testimony on Benghazi Attack Sparks Controversy

Article:

The aftermath of Hillary Clinton's testimony on Capitol Hill regarding the 2012 attack on the U.S. mission in Benghazi, Libya, has sparked debate over her response to Wisconsin Republican Sen. Ron Johnson's accusation that the Obama administration initially misrepresented the responsible parties.

Following the hearing, Johnson stated that he perceived Clinton's response as "theatrics," while Washington Post columnist Dana Milbank, known for his liberal views, described her remarks as "a potent brew of righteous outrage." On CBS This Morning, Post columnist David Ignatius suggested that Johnson's questioning might be the first in a series of Republican attacks on Clinton, who is speculated to be a potential Democratic presidential candidate in 2016.

During the hearing, when Johnson pressed Clinton on the administration's knowledge of the attack and when they became aware, Clinton displayed visible anger as she stated:

"The fact is we had four dead Americans. Was it because of a protest or was it because of guys out for a walk one night who decided they'd go kill some Americans? What difference, at this point, does it make? It is our job to figure out what happened and do everything we can to prevent it from ever happening again."

C-SPAN's video library provides two clips of Clinton's exchange with Johnson. The first, lasting 2 minutes and 25 seconds, offers a broad sense of the conversation leading to her animated comments. A shorter version focuses on the sharpest part of the exchange.

Clinton is soon to step down from her position. President Obama has nominated Sen. John Kerry (D-Mass.) to replace her. Today, at 10 a.m. ET, the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, the same committee that held Wednesday's hearing, is holding its confirmation hearing for Kerry.

Kerry, the committee's chairman, will not preside over his own nomination hearing. Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.) will be in the chairman's seat. It is expected that Kerry will face little opposition in the Senate. He is to be "introduced" at today's hearing by Secretary Clinton.

Title: White House Press Secretary Urges Media to Review Controversial Video, Playboy Correspondent Rebuts

Article:

In a press briefing on Tuesday, White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders directed the White House press corps to watch a video from conservative provocateur James O' Keefe, sparking a rebuttal from a Playboy correspondent.

The sequence of events began when deputy press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders was asked a question by Charlie Spiering of Breitbart, a right-wing website, regarding the recent controversy at CNN. Spiering inquired about the Senate's alleged investigation into a meeting between a top Trump campaign staffer and an official from a Russian investment fund, a story that CNN published and later retracted. The error led to three CNN employees, including Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter Eric Lichtblau, stepping down on Monday.

"The president went on Twitter this morning and repeated that CNN was fake news," Spiering said. "Why wasn't [CNN's] response good enough for the president?"

Sanders used this opportunity to express her criticisms of the mainstream media. She also suggested that reporters watch a video from James O' Keefe, which shows a CNN producer criticizing CNN's treatment of the Trump-Russia story. The producer, John Bonifield, works on CNN's health team and does not appear to be connected to CNN's political coverage. It also seems that Bonifield was taped without his knowledge, a major ethics violation.

"There's a video circulating now—whether it's accurate or not, I don't know—but I would encourage everybody in this room, and frankly everybody across this country, to take a look at it," Sanders said. "I think if it is accurate, it is a disgrace to all of media, all of journalism."

Sanders expressed concern about the state of media and journalism, stating, "I think we have gone to a place where if the media can't be trusted to report the news, then that's a dangerous place for America." She further added, "And I think if that's the place where certain outlets are going, particularly for the purpose of spiking ratings, and if that's coming directly from the top, then I think that's even more scary, and certainly more disgraceful."

Sanders also criticized the media's use of unnamed sources. However, her remarks were interrupted by Brian J. Karem, a correspondent for Playboy, who delivered a sharply worded rebuttal:

"Come on, you're inflaming everybody right here, right now, with those words. This administration has done that as well. Why in the name of heaven—any one of us are replaceable, and any one of us, if we don't get it right, the audience has the opportunity to turn the channel or not read us. You have been elected to serve for four years at least. There is no option other than that. We're here to ask you questions. You're here to provide the answers. And what you just did is inflammatory to people all over the country who look at it and say, 'See, once again, the president is right, and everybody else out here is fake media.'"

Sanders responded coolly, stating, "I think if anything has been inflamed, it's the dishonesty that often takes place by the news media."

Title: Historical Analysis of Democratic Presidential Candidates' Post-Election Behavior

Article:

The article discusses a perceived characteristic of modern-Democratic presidential candidates, as noted by some historians, which is their behavior following election losses. The article suggests that, with the exception of former President Barack Obama, these candidates have been described as "sore losers."

The article mentions former President Barack Obama, who won the presidency twice, but is characterized as a "sore winner" due to his alleged grumping and grousing since leaving the White House. The article also compares Obama's economic record with that of current President Donald Trump, stating that Trump's economy is on its way to new records every quarter.

The article then discusses the 1976 election, in which Jimmy Carter lost to Ronald Reagan. Carter reportedly became the first American president to speak ill of a sitting president while visiting foreign soil, which is cited as an example of a sore loser.

In 2000, Al Gore, the inventor of the Internet, lost to George W. Bush in a controversial election decided by the Electoral College. The article suggests that Gore may still be irritable about the election, which was decided by 537 votes after the votes of almost 6 million Floridians were counted.

In 2004, John Kerry, a senator at the time, ran against George W. Bush and is described as delusional due to his exploitation of his Vietnam service and eventual "betrayal of trust" with his comrades while he had returned home to harangue the war and to visit with the North Vietnamese in Paris. The article mentions the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, who turned on Kerry and helped to beat him in the election.

The article also mentions Hillary Clinton's loss in the 2016 election and her continued criticism of President Trump, the Russians, and those in agreement with the President. The article states that Clinton's call to "resistance" should remind readers of her behavior in 1968.

The article concludes by referencing Richard Nixon's 1960 loss to John F. Kennedy by 112,000 votes, stating that Nixon did not contest the results and claiming that American historians dislike Nixon.

Title: US Consulate in Lahore, Pakistan, Closed Due to Specific Threat; US Diplomatic Posts in Pakistan Targeted in Spate of Extremist Attacks

Article:

The United States Department of State has closed the US consulate in Lahore, Pakistan, today and moved all non-essential personnel to the embassy in Islamabad due to a specific threat to the consulate amid a series of extremist attacks against Pakistani targets across the country.

According to The Wall Street Journal, US Embassy spokeswoman Meghan Gregonis stated, "We received information regarding a threat to the consulate. As a precautionary measure, we are undertaking a drawdown of all but essential personnel in Lahore." The consulate was already closed yesterday through Sunday for Eid al-Fitr, a festive holiday marking the end of the holy month of Ramadan. However, the consulate will not reopen on Monday, and there is no date set for it to reopen, reports The Wall Street Journal.

The move is unrelated to the closure of 19 US diplomatic posts throughout the Middle East and Africa in the last week. The US has also issued a travel alert for the country, stating that various groups in Pakistan pose a threat to American citizens there.

US diplomatic posts in Pakistan have been targeted before, most recently the consulate in Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan. A car bomb and grenade attack killed four Pakistanis there in 2010.

The Pakistani government is also on high alert after receiving intelligence that militants had plans to attack key locations in the city, such as the airport and parliament building, according to The Times.

According to Pakistani newspaper Dawn, a major suicide bombing in an Islamabad mosque was thwarted today when the bomber was gunned down before he could enter the mosque and detonate his vest of explosives.

The Wall Street Journal notes that there has been a "wave of extremist violence" in Pakistan. Many of the local groups are linked to Al Qaeda and oppose the Pakistani government's alliance with the US, but the "vast majority" of their victims are fellow Pakistanis, not Americans.

On Friday, gunmen opened fire on worshipers leaving a mosque in the western city of Quetta, killing 10 people who had come to offer prayers for the Eid al-Fitr festival marking the end of the Ramadan month of fasting. Police said the intended target appeared to be a politician present at the site, who escaped unhurt. Pakistani militants unleashed a vicious wave of killings during Ramadan, as the new government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif struggled to get a grip on the security situation. Mr. Sharif, who took office in early June, vowed Thursday to show the militants an "iron fist," as his government announced that its counterterrorism policy would be ready next week.

On Thursday in Quetta, a suicide bomber attacked the funeral of a police officer killed by militants. The bombing killed at least 30 people, including 21 police personnel. Some of the city's most senior police officers perished in the attack.

The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for Thursday's attack in Quetta, saying it was revenge for a police raid on an allied group.

The violence has "rattled" Mr. Sharif's government, reports The New York Times. The prime minister ordered his interior minister to visit Quetta and pushed him to present the national counterterrorism strategy soon.

Critics say the lack of such a strategy has resulted in confusion and a lack of consensus about how to deal with the terrorists. Opposition politicians urged the government to immediately convene a national conference of all political parties to come to a policy consensus. "The delay is causing more acts of terrorism," said Syed Khurshid Shah, an opposition lawmaker belonging to the Pakistan Peoples Party.

"The government cannot leave the country to be a playing-field of terrorists. We will be handling them with an iron fist," Mr. Sharif said, according to the Pakistani newspaper The Express Tribune.

The latest wave of violence has caused some Pakistanis to despair, particularly amid the backdrop of the holy month of Ramadan, as articulated in an editorial in the Pakistani newspaper the Nation titled "A difficult Eid."

Title: House Committee Chairmen Call for Special Counsel to Investigate FBI and DOJ's Handling of 2016 Election Probes

Article:

Two House committee chairmen, Trey Gowdy and Bob Goodlatte, have requested a special counsel to evaluate the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation's handling of the investigations into Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump during the 2016 election. In a six-page letter to acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, the chairmen of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee and the House Judiciary Committee, respectively, expressed concerns about the FBI's decision not to prosecute Clinton for her improper use of a government email.

After a year-long joint congressional inquiry, the committees reviewed thousands of documents and interviewed key witnesses, concluding that former FBI Director James Comey acted improperly when he cleared Clinton of wrongdoing. They claim that some witnesses, including FBI General Counsel James Baker, did not support the exoneration.

The chairmen had initially asked former Attorney General Jeff Sessions to appoint a special counsel in March, but he declined and instead appointed U.S. Attorney John Huber to the task. The lawmakers state that Huber is still conducting the review. If Whitaker does not appoint a special counsel, the lawmakers suggest that Congress should continue the investigation.

The chairmen also raised concerns about the FBI's handling of the probe into Trump's campaign and possible collusion with Russians, specifically citing the alleged bias of federal agents and their different treatment of the candidates during the election. They question how derogatory information about Trump was accessed by the FBI, the sourcing of such information, its vetting, and the government's reliance on it in court pleadings.

The Republicans had questioned Comey and former Attorney General Loretta Lynch for two days on Capitol Hill earlier this month. Lynch did not comment on her closed-door questioning, but Comey stated that the closed-door hearing harms the integrity of the FBI. He also used the hearing as an opportunity to criticize the president.

Republicans had also wanted to speak with Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who has been overseeing the probe into Russian interference and had reportedly joked about wearing a wire to secretly record the president.

Title: Buzzfeed Secures $50 Million Investment from Andreeson Horowitz for Expansion

Article:

Internet media company Buzzfeed has received a $50 million investment from venture capital firm Andreeson Horowitz. The company, currently valued at $850 million, plans to utilize the funds to produce more content, expand its video production unit, and open additional offices worldwide.

Chris Dixon, a partner at Andreeson Horowitz, described Buzzfeed as a "preeminent media company." The website, initially launched in 2006 as an aggregator of light-hearted lists, videos, and quizzes, gained popularity among young people and office workers for its engaging and colloquial content.

Recently, Buzzfeed has shifted its focus towards current affairs, hiring a team of journalists and blending its irreverent style with hard news. The Buzzfeed audience is growing, with 75% of hits coming via social media referrals from platforms like Facebook, Twitter, or Pinterest.
