The site attracts approximately four times more viewers per month than The New York Times and was valued more than three times higher than The Washington Post, which was purchased by Jeff Bezos for $250 million this year.

In a blog post, Chris Dixon explained that Andreeson Horowitz invested in Buzzfeed because it is "disruptive," having significantly altered the online media landscape. One of the reasons for this disruption is Buzzfeed's understanding of the internet, with all content being available and formatted for mobile devices, targeting users who browse while waiting in lines or commuting to work.

One of the primary uses for the new funding will be to allocate more resources towards Buzzfeed Motion Pictures, its video unit based in Los Angeles. The company plans to focus on producing videos ranging from six seconds to one-hour documentaries. Buzzfeed's videos are already popular, often being picked up by mainstream media sites, such as the one examining "What Men Are Really Saying When Catcalling Women." The future may even see the release of a movie based on "23 Ways To Have The Coolest Locker In School."

Title: Study Reveals Rising Political Polarization on Climate Change in the U.S., with WSJ Climate Coverage Accused of Denial and Misinformation

Article:

A new study by a team of sociologists at Oklahoma State University has found that political polarization on climate change is growing in the United States. Today's Republicans are less likely than they were a decade ago to accept that the effects of global warming have begun, that humans are responsible, and that there is a scientific consensus on these questions. Democrats and independents are slightly more likely to answer these questions correctly today than a decade ago.

The study, titled "Politics and Global Warming: The American Public's Changing Attitudes and the Role of the Media," found that climate change is now more polarizing in the U.S. than abortion or gay marriage. At the same time, climate denial has become the norm among Republican policymakers, as they've grown increasingly anti-environment.

The study notes that what was once a modest tendency for Congressional Republicans to be less pro-environmental than their Democratic counterparts has become a chasm, with Republicans taking near-unanimous anti-environmental stances on relevant legislation in recent years, especially in 2015.

Policymakers work for their constituents, so if Republican voters are generally apathetic about the tremendous threats posed by climate change, party leaders have relatively little motivation to tackle the problem (aside from the obvious, like protecting future generations and the long-term viability of their political party).

However, the public responds to cues from intellectual and cultural leaders. Were Republican leaders to start listening to climate science experts, many of their voters would likely follow suit. After all, most American conservatives already support climate policies; they just don't view the issue as a priority. Unfortunately, today's Republican Party is essentially controlled by the fossil fuel industry.

The study argues that the conservative movement, fearful of the regulatory implications of climate change, and seeking to defend the current economic system built on fossil fuel use, has been the driving force behind organized climate change denial.

Public perception and priorities are also heavily influenced by the media. A 2013 study found that conservative media consumers are more likely to distrust scientific experts and reject climate science realities.

Relatedly, a new report by Media Matters on climate coverage in major American newspaper opinion pages found pervasive misinformation in the Wall Street Journal. Out of 93 climate-related opinion pieces published in the Journal during the time period examined, 31 featured climate science denial or other scientifically inaccurate claims about climate change (33 percent).

A study last year found that the WSJ's biased climate coverage extended beyond its opinion pages to its news coverage as well. And during the time of the scandalous #ExxonKnew revelations, Media Matters found that the WSJ was a constant apologist for the oil company.

The WSJ readership is heavily comprised of wealthy, powerful men, and it has become an increasingly conservative paper since Rupert Murdoch purchased it. Conservative media consumers are bombarded with climate misinformation and fossil fuel industry propaganda, usually without the authors' fossil fuel ties being disclosed.

The industry has created an echo chamber in which they control the climate messaging of conservative media and party leaders, which in turn trickles down to misinform Republican voters, growing the partisan gap on climate change. The authors of the Oklahoma State study see no easy way to break through what they call the "denial countermovement":

consisting of fossil fuel corporations and business allies like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, conservative think tanks and their funders, conservative media, and a large supporting cast of front groups, bloggers, and contrarian scientists.

Does any persuasive framing strategy hold special promise for penetrating Republicans' partisan/ideological identities? The evidence so far gives little basis for optimism.

There's plenty of blame to go around. Republican policymakers have failed to deliver much-needed leadership on climate change, American conservatives have relied too heavily on biased media sources, and conservative media outlets like Murdoch's WSJ have misinformed their readers.

Until the fossil fuel industry's control over conservative policymakers and media loosens, American climate action will be up to the Democratic Party. This weekend, President Obama and Chinese President Xi announced they will formally ratify the Paris climate change agreement. If she is elected president, Hillary Clinton likewise plans to rely on executive actions to tackle climate change.

But there's a limit to what the President of the United States can do on his or her own. U.S. Congress still controls American climate policy, or the lack thereof. As long as the conservative media continues to misinform readers and breed a conservative culture of climate denial, American efforts to tackle the threat of climate change will be constrained, and the future of human society and of the Republican Party will be endangered.

Title: A Call for a National Discourse Do-Over: Banning the "Butt Defense" in Political Discussions

Article:

In the spirit of the New Year, the familiar promise of fresh beginnings has arrived, but the hope for a national kumbaya moment seems distant. Instead, the nation has largely abandoned the water cooler discussions for heated exchanges on social media platforms. In an attempt to promote a more civil discourse, one social media user shared a meme featuring a snarling dog and a quote from Proverbs 26:17, "Like one who grabs a stray dog by the ears is he who rushes into a quarrel not his own."

The user's hope for this message to go viral, however, may be unrealistic, as the nation seems eager to stake a position in the day's trending battles. To address this issue, the author proposes a discourse do-over, drawing inspiration from a rule implemented in their household for sibling conflicts.

The rule, known as the "Butt Defense," is a fallback in political discussions that keeps the nation mired in the mess. The author, in their role as a parent, did not teach their children to use the Butt Defense, but rather observed that they employed it naturally in their desire to defend themselves and promote their own interests.

The "Butt Defense" is a defense mechanism where individuals justify their actions by pointing to the actions of others. For example, "Yes, I did hit him, but he hit me first." In the author's household, the "Butt Defense" was swiftly overruled, and the child using it was reminded of the correct response to the situation and what they could do differently in the future. Banning the "Butt Defense" helped the family move forward.

The author suggests that if we could ban the "Butt Defense" in our national conversation, it would help ostracize the extreme elements on all sides and diminish their impact. The call to action for those concerned about the lack of civility in politics is to refuse to defend what should be indefensible and to call hateful or atrocious actions what they are without giving any "cover" in their own circle by employing the "Butt Defense."

The author acknowledges that the original citation of Proverbs in their post contained an editing error, with the correct verse being Proverbs 26:17, not 16:7.

Title: Google Bans 200 Publishers from AdSense Network in Response to Fake News Proliferation

Article:

Google has removed 200 publishers from its AdSense network, an ad placement service, in the fourth quarter of 2016. The ban was enacted due to the proliferation of fake news sites, which mislead users with their content. The publishers were prohibited from the service under an update to an existing policy that bars sites with misleading content.

Not all 200 publishers were targeted as part of the effort to root out fake news sites. The ban occurred in November and December, and included sites that impersonate real news organizations through shortened top-level domains, such as those ending in ".co" instead of the more common ".com." Google declined to provide a listing of the banned sites.

Google's 2016 "bad ads" report, typically released at the beginning of each year, revealed that so-called fake news publishers sometimes take advantage of ".co" domains to appear similar to legitimate news sites.

In addition to the ban on fake news sites, Google's 2016 annual report on violations of advertising policy also included data on ads removed. The company reported that in 2016 it took down 1.7 billion ads for violations, compared to 780 million in 2015. Google attributes the increase in ad removals to a combination of advertiser behavior and improvements in technology to detect offending ads.

Google added a policy mid-year to prohibit ads for payday loans, considered predatory. Roughly five million payday loan ads were disabled over the latter six months of 2016. Also among the removed ads were what Google calls "tabloid cloakers." These advertisers run what look like links to news headlines, but when the user clicks, an ad for a product such as a weight loss supplement pops up. Google suspended 1,300 accounts engaged in tabloid cloaking in 2016.

It is unavailable whether the ban on publishers from the AdSense network and the removal of ads for payday loans and tabloid cloaking were the only actions taken by Google in response to the proliferation of fake news and misleading ads.

Title: Federal Government Shutdown Affects National Parks and Museums, but Essential Services Remain Operational

Article:

The ongoing federal government shutdown, which began on December 21, has led to the closure of several national parks and museums due to a lack of funding. While some federal services and employees deemed "essential" are still functioning, national parks and federal institutions are classified as "non-essential" and have been affected by the shutdown.

The National Park Service, under a contingency plan adopted earlier this year, kept many national parks open for a time without park rangers, maintenance workers, and other staff who have been furloughed due to the shutdown. However, without these workers, trash has accumulated, and restrooms have become dirtier, leading to the closure of Sequoia, Kings Canyon, and Joshua Tree National Parks in California, as well as parts of Yosemite.

In Washington D.C., the Smithsonian and the National Gallery of Art remained open using leftover funds that had been previously allocated. However, these funds have since run out, and the Smithsonian announced today that its museums and the National Zoo would be closing. The National Gallery notes at the top of its website that its status after today "is yet to be determined."

While some people are concerned about these closures, it is essential to understand that these institutions are classified as "non-essential," and their current closures primarily affect leisure activities. The closures are unfortunate for tourists who planned trips around these parks and museums, but there are plenty of privately run institutions that are not affected by the government shutdown, such as the Phillips Collection, the National Building Museum, and the Newseum in Washington D.C.

In California, there is a sprawling state park system that can be visited instead. The supposed "trashing" of the parks is not cause for significant concern, as the issues primarily involve litter, dirty bathrooms, and people relieving themselves in the wrong places. These problems are not hard to remedy once furloughed employees are back on the job. In the meantime, shutting the parks and not letting the trash pile up any further is the right thing to do.

Title: Recall Efforts Target Colorado Democratic Lawmakers Over Tough Gun-Control Laws

Article:

Colorado Democratic lawmakers who recently helped pass some of the nation's toughest gun-control laws are facing political backlash in the form of recall efforts. Two groups, Pueblo Freedom and Rights Group, are targeting state Rep. Mike McLachlan and state Sens. Angela Giron, Evie Hudak, and John Morse.

The Democrat-controlled legislature passed bills that ban magazines holding more than 15 rounds and require background checks for all gun transfers. These bills were signed into law in March by Democratic Gov. John Hickenlooper.

Senate President John Morse pushed a more far-reaching proposal that called for holding owners, sellers, and makers of assault-type weapons liable for havoc inflicted by their guns. He withdrew the bill upon realizing he didn't have enough votes. However, his efforts have still drawn the ire of the groups.

The petition drives require signatures from 25 percent of the vote in each lawmaker's district to trigger a special election. The signature deadline is May 21. Colorado's Secretary of State office has confirmed with FoxNews.com that it has approved the forms for the petition drives.

The legislature also passed a bill before adjourning Friday that prohibits domestic-violence offenders from owning guns. Hickenlooper is also expected to sign that legislation.

Sen. John Morse is getting help from a group called "A Whole Lot of People for John Morse," which is collecting money and petition signatures to fight the recall effort. The group has so far raised $23,050, according to The Daily Caller.

Sen. Evie Hudak angered gun-rights advocates and others due to a comment made to a rape victim testifying against a bill that would have banned concealed weapons on college campuses. She suggested the attacker might have used the gun on the woman had she been carrying a concealed weapon, saying "statistics are not on your side even if you had a gun."

Connecticut, Maryland, and New York also have passed tighter gun-control measures following the Dec. 2012 mass shooting at a Connecticut school in which 20 first-graders and six adults were killed. However, there are no indications of organized recall efforts in those Democratic-leaning states.

Title: North Korea's Threats Against South Korea: Stephan Haggard Suggests Domestic Politics Play a Role

Article:

Stephan Haggard, a political scientist at the University of California, San Diego, has suggested that North Korea's recent threats against South Korea may be more bluff than genuine intent. Haggard's analysis is based on the escalating signals of resolve from North Korea, which he interprets as a sign of nervousness rather than strength.

According to Haggard, the current North Korean leader, Kim Jong Un, may not have fully consolidated his authority, and some of the rhetoric could be driven by domestic politics. March brought a series of what pundits call "provocations" by North Korea, but upon closer inspection, Pyongyang has opted for rhetoric over actual military actions.

The first round of saber-rattling occurred as the U.N. Security Council deliberated on a new sanctions resolution after North Korea's satellite launch in December and its third nuclear test in February. North Korea ultimately "withdrew" from the armistice, but it had done so before, and it is unclear what its recent statements actually mean. The armistice is not a peace treaty but merely a ceasefire.

The armistice is stable not because of verbal commitments but because of the deterrent capability of both sides. Is anything really different as a result of this "re-withdrawal"? It does not seem like it. Equally unfortunate was North Korea's decision to renege on a number of North-South agreements, such as a North-South agreement on the denuclearization of the peninsula. However, Pyongyang's pursuit of nuclear weapons had made these and a number of other agreements moot in any case.

North Korea's bluster had little if any effect on the U.N. debate. If anything, its threats may have been counterproductive. Although the resolution was portrayed as the result of a U.S.-South Korean cabal, China also signed on, and the resolution was passed unanimously.

The measure opens the door for tighter financial sanctions, and there is some preliminary evidence that Beijing may be cooperating in tightening economic exchanges with the country. The next round of statements came as North Korea and the United States and South Korea entered an annual military training cycle. These periods are always fraught with tension, as Pyongyang denounces the routine exercises as provocative.

As the country effectively mobilizes, the North Korean press is filled with pictures of Kim Jong Un directing the troops in exercises, some of which were reportedly manipulated with Photoshop to increase their effect. As a result of these exercises, there is some background of what might be called "ritualized escalation" at work.

However, North Korea did possibly make one major misstep in arguing that it might undertake a pre-emptive nuclear strike. Announcing an intention to pre-empt is dangerous because even small tactical movements can be misinterpreted. Such statements have to be taken seriously, and, if anything, the United States and South Korea may have over-reacted by such a public display of force.

In particular, the U.S. announced a major new ballistic missile defense initiative, training runs by B52 and B2 bombers, and an updated U.S.-ROK Combined Counter-Provocation Plan. In the last few days, the U.S. was again quite public about its deployment of jet fighters to the peninsula as well.

There is a larger game at work here that probably centers on the difficult-to-read domestic politics of North Korea. It is by no means assured that Kim Jong Un has fully consolidated his authority. By ramping up rhetoric, but exercising restraint with respect to actual military actions, the regime can count on the fact that the United States and South Korea are not going to take the first step either.

The result is that North Korea's exercises and threats of retaliation have been successful in deterring attack, even though none was coming. The regime can claim some sort of victory in staring down American threats in its two big political meetings this week, the timing of which suggests that some of the rhetoric has been driven by domestic politics.

North Korea's nuclear and missile programs constitute problems that the five parties in the region—China, Japan, South Korea, Russia, and the United States—need to address through concerted action. However, overheated rhetoric, however disconcerting, is not the same as an intention to attack. Coolly maintaining our deterrent and not over-reacting to hyperbole is the proper course of action. With luck, the leadership will pivot away from nuclear posturing toward economic reform, the main thing that the people of North Korea really need.

Title: Gunmen Identified in Bardo Museum Attack; Islamic State Claims Responsibility

Article:

In the aftermath of the Bardo Museum attack in Tunisia's capital, the two gunmen responsible for the deadly shooting rampage have been identified as Yassine Laabidi and Hatem Khachnaoui, both Tunisian nationals. The Islamic State (IS) has claimed responsibility for the attack, which left 21 people dead, primarily foreign tourists.

The attack occurred on Wednesday at the National Bardo Museum, a popular tourist destination in Tunis, the birthplace of the Arab Spring democracy movement. The two gunmen were killed by police during the attack, and five officers were also wounded.

Thursday saw the arrest of nine individuals, with five of them being directly linked to the two gunmen, and the other four accused of having ties to the terrorist cell involved. Culture Minister Latifa Lakhdar spoke defiantly at the museum, stating, "They are targeting knowledge. They are targeting science. They are targeting reason. They are targeting history. They are targeting memory, because all these things mean nothing in their eyes."

The IS released an online recording claiming responsibility for the attack, praising the "knights of the Islamic State" and referring to the museum as a "den of infidels and vice." The slain gunmen, Yassine Laabidi and Hatem Khachnaoui, were identified by Tunisian Prime Minister Habib Essid, with Laabidi having been flagged by intelligence authorities, although not for "anything special."

More than 3,000 Tunisians are estimated to have joined IS militants in Iraq and Syria, according to the Tunisian government. Training camps in neighboring Libya provide easy access to the fight for Tunisian Muslims discontent with the fledgling democracy in Tunis.

Among the victims were passengers from two cruise ships, the MSC Splendida and the Costa Fascinosa. More than half of the dead were tourists, with 17 of them being foreign nationals. The Islamic State's claim of responsibility for the attack has led to cancellations of future arrivals by five major ship companies.

Japanese tourist Noriko Yuki, 35, was among the victims, having sustained injuries to her back and hands. Her 68-year-old mother also suffered injuries and underwent surgery at a Tunisian hospital. U.S. First Lady Michelle Obama expressed condolences over the attack, stating, "We want to express our condolences over the horrific event yesterday in Tunisia."

Tunisia has faced militant activity since the revolution that ousted President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali in 2011, with assassinations of liberal, secular politicians and attacks on tourist destinations being common occurrences.

Title: President Obama Apologizes for Health Insurance Cancellations under Obamacare

Article:

President Obama has expressed his apologies to Americans who have lost their health insurance due to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), despite his previous assurances that they could keep their insurance plans. In an exclusive interview with NBC News at the White House, Obama stated, "I am sorry that they are finding themselves in this situation based on assurances they got from me."

The apology follows the president's addition of a grandfathering caveat to his healthcare pitch during a speech to Obama for America supporters in Washington D.C. last week. He clarified that individuals who had health insurance plans before the Affordable Care Act (ACA) was enacted and liked those plans could keep them, provided the plans had not changed since the law's passage.

The administration has been denying for nearly two weeks that President Obama lied or misled millions of people about keeping their health insurance plans. However, NBC News and other major news outlets reported last week that the White House knew for years that cancellation letters would be issued and told Americans they could keep their plans anyway.

According to NBC News, citing four sources deeply involved in ACA, about 50% to 75% of the 14 million consumers who buy health insurance individually will receive a "cancellation" letter or its equivalent in the next year because their current policies do not meet the standards laid out by the new law.

Democratic Senators on Capitol Hill are currently working to pass legislation that would allow millions of Americans who have received cancellation notices to get their healthcare plans back. It is unclear if President Obama is willing to support this effort.

Sixty-seven percent of Americans in the individual health insurance market are expected to lose their current health plans as insurance companies comply with Obamacare requirements under the law.

Title: Billionaire Warren Buffett's Philanthropy Focuses on Abortion Funding, Remains Unreported

Article:

May 13, 2014, marks one year since Philadelphia abortion doctor Kermit Gosnell was convicted of first-degree murder for the deaths of three babies delivered alive and then killed at his clinic. Gosnell's case has become a symbol in the pro-life community. However, another figure, liberal billionaire Warren Buffett, has been a significant donor to abortion organizations, contributing over $1.2 billion from 2001 to 2012.

This amount is equivalent to the cost of approximately 2.7 million first-trimester abortions, more than twice the number of abortions that occur in the United States in a year. Unlike Gosnell, Buffett's actions have been entirely legal. However, both Gosnell and Buffett share a commonality: their stories have been largely unreported.

The Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation, named after Buffett's first wife, who was an abortion supporter, is led by pro-abortion activist Tracy Weitz, Ph.D., MPA. Weitz has worked at Planned Parenthood and The Bixby Center for Global Reproductive Health and once defined abortion as "a moral action undertaken by moral agents."

The foundation's website primarily focuses on college scholarships and the "Alice Buffett Outstanding Teacher Award," which recognizes outstanding Omaha Public School teachers (K-12). The award and scholarships do not hint at the darker direction of the massive charity.

The website's content seems deliberately insular, with copyrights on the pages dating back to 2008, and the charity making it clear that they only respond to inquiries about college scholarships and the Alice Buffett Outstanding Teacher Award.

Since 2001, there has only been one tangential mention of Buffett's support for abortion on the broadcast TV network morning and evening news shows. This mention was in the NBC "Nightly News" obituary for his wife, which included her support for Planned Parenthood.

Buffett was never mentioned as a top donor when Live Action embarrassed Planned Parenthood with two videos of staffers assisting a Live Action actor with a possible sex selection abortion. Additionally, in early 2011, Live Action's Lila Rose trained investigators to pose as a pimp and a prostitute running a sex ring composed of 14- and 15-year-olds. Planned Parenthood workers were willing to help provide underage abortions.

Instead, the media portrays Buffett as a grandfatherly, tax-hiking, and investor figure. As a reliable liberal businessman, journalists often turn to him as a source for almost any commentary. It is easy to understand why, as giving $1,000 to a ballot initiative to defend traditional marriage is controversial, while giving $1.25 billion to promote abortion goes unnoticed by journalists who are pro-abortion.

However, with the information now out in the open, watch as the supposedly "neutral" news media does its best to hide it.

Title: Syria Crisis Not Primary Factor in Delay of Immigration Reform, Says Ruben Navarrette

Article:

Ruben Navarrette, a political commentator, has stated that the Syrian crisis did not play a significant role in the delay of immigration reform in the U.S. Congress. He argues that the comprehensive immigration reform is not just on hold for the remainder of this year but will be off the agenda until 2015 and beyond.

Navarrette asserts that the GOP-controlled House of Representatives might vote on a "reform-lite" bill, offering legal status but not citizenship, or provide legal status only to farm workers and DREAMers, undocumented young people who seek preferential treatment due to their intentions to attend college or join the military. However, large-scale reform offering legal status to the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States has faded, and the Congress's limited working schedule, as members only show up for work in odd-numbered years, means the conversation will likely continue in 2015, 2017, and 2019.

Navarrette disputes the claim that the Syrian crisis was the primary reason for the delay in immigration reform. Instead, he identifies three main reasons for the stalemate:

1. The major legislative offering, the Border Security, Economic Opportunity, and Immigration Modernization Act, collapsed under its own weight due to its length and excessive pork-barrel spending.
2. The debate was primarily about politics rather than policy, with many amendments added to secure the support of individual senators.
3. The debate was inherently dishonest, with neither side able to trust the other, leading to posturing and hot air from both parties.

Navarrette suggests that the immigration reform process was focused on providing work permits, the ability to travel, and a driver's license, while ignoring citizenship and voting privileges, which is a repeated deal-breaker for politicians. Additionally, he argues that the Senate bill, due to the Corker-Hoeven "border surge" amendment, offered more agents and fencing, which is not what Border Patrol agents and supervisors requested.

Navarrette concludes that the Syrian crisis provides a convenient excuse for lawmakers looking for an exit from the immigration reform debate, as it allows them to avoid addressing the complexities of the issue.

Title: Warren Buffett Laments Difficulty in Finding Acquisitions, Awaits "Huge" Non-Insurance Deals for Berkshire Hathaway

Article:

Warren Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc, expressed his difficulty in finding suitable companies to buy in his annual letter to shareholders on Saturday. The conglomerate is currently holding $116 billion in low-yielding cash and government bonds due to the challenge of finding "sensible purchase prices."

Buffett attributed the difficulty to a "purchasing frenzy" by deal-hungry chief executives employing cheap debt, which makes the task of finding acquisitions difficult for Berkshire, as the company typically pays all cash for acquisitions.

The letter, which was shorter than in recent years, did not discuss major Berkshire stock holdings such as Apple Inc and Wells Fargo & Co. Buffett often invests in stocks when he cannot find whole companies to buy.

The letter also did not fault excesses of Wall Street and Washington, and said nothing about Berkshire's plan to create a healthcare company with Amazon.com Inc and JPMorgan Chase & Co.

Berkshire reported a record $44.94 billion annual profit, though $29.1 billion stemmed from the slashing of the U.S. corporate tax rate, which reduced the Omaha, Nebraska-based conglomerate's deferred tax liabilities. Book value per share, measuring assets minus liabilities, rose 23 percent in 2017.

It has been more than two years since Buffett made a major purchase, the $32.1 billion takeover of aircraft parts maker Precision Castparts Corp, and his advancing age gives him less time to find more of the "elephants" he prefers.

However, he has given himself and longtime Vice Chairman Charlie Munger, 94, more freedom to focus on investing and allocating capital. Neither has signaled any intention of stepping down soon, though Berkshire last month named two additional vice chairmen who could eventually succeed Buffett as chief executive.

Gregory Abel, who had run Berkshire Hathaway Energy, is now overseeing Berkshire's non-insurance businesses such as the BNSF railroad and Dairy Queen ice cream, all of which employ 330,000 people, while insurance specialist Ajit Jain oversees the Geico auto insurer and other insurance businesses, employing 47,000.

While the Wells Fargo investment has struggled in recent months due to scandals over how it treats customers, Apple has performed better. Buffett revealed in his letter that Berkshire was sitting at year-end on a $7.25 billion paper profit on what has become a 3.3 percent stake in the iPhone maker, worth $28.2 billion.

Some Berkshire stock investments are made by deputies Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who Buffett said together manage about $25 billion, up from $21 billion a year ago.

Buffett also warned long-term investors, including pension funds, college endowments, and "savings-minded individuals," that even with U.S. stock prices near record highs, it would be a "terrible mistake" to assume bonds are safer.

"Often, high-grade bonds in an investment portfolio increase its risk," he wrote.

Fourth-quarter net income quintupled to $32.55 billion, or $19,790 per Class A share, from $6.29 billion, or $3,823 per share, a year earlier. Operating profit, which Buffett considers a better gauge of performance, fell more than analysts expected in the fourth quarter, and slid 18 percent for the year to $14.46 billion.

Full-year results suffered from Berkshire's first full-year insurance underwriting loss since 2002, hurt by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria and wildfires in California. Even so, insurance float, or premiums collected before claims are paid, and which give Buffett more money to invest, rose 25 percent last year, to $114.5 billion.

Title: Former Colorado Governor and 2020 Democratic Candidate Warns Against Embracing Socialism

Article:

Former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, has expressed concerns about his party straying too far to the left as it selects a nominee to challenge President Trump in the upcoming election. In an interview with NPR, Hickenlooper voiced his opposition to some of the party's major policy proposals, such as the Green New Deal and "Medicare for All."

"If we don't stand up and say that we Democrats do not stand for socialism, we're going to end up reelecting the worst president this country has ever had," Hickenlooper said.

During the interview, which was part of NPR's Opening Arguments conversations exploring the presidential candidates' core messages, Hickenlooper criticized the Green New Deal's proposal to guarantee every American a federal job and the "Medicare for All" plan's potential forcible removal of private insurance for 150 million people. He argued that these policies are perceived by many Americans as aspects of socialism.

However, Hickenlooper acknowledged the importance of addressing income inequality, ensuring women's reproductive rights, and addressing civil rights and social justice issues. He emphasized the need to focus on kitchen table issues, such as job creation and economic stability, to win in key swing states like Ohio, Michigan, North Carolina, and Wisconsin.

Hickenlooper highlighted his experience in bringing people together, citing his record of near-universal health care and the No. 1 economy in the country during his tenure as governor. He suggested that his ability to unite businesses, nonprofits, and political parties, as well as his accomplishments, set him apart from other candidates.

Victoria Whitley-Berry contributed to this story and produced for air.

Title: Attorney General Barr's Summary of Mueller Report: Length, Release, and Grand Jury Information

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has released a four-page summary of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on the conclusions of the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. elections. The New York Times reports that the Mueller report "exceeds 300 pages" in length, citing unidentified American officials with knowledge of the matter. However, the exact page count is unclear, with Fox's Andrew Napolitano claiming the report is 700 pages long, and the Times noting that previous lengthy reports, such as Ken Starr's Clinton-Lewinsky report, last year's inspector-general report on the Clinton emails investigation, and the 9/11 Commission report, were significantly longer.

The Attorney General has not revealed the exact number of pages in the Mueller report to House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler, who has only stated that the report is "very substantial." When asked whether that means fewer than a thousand pages, Nadler replied, "I would think so." The Attorney General has not committed to the April 2 deadline House Democrats would like to impose.

The debate over the report's length and the Attorney General's summary has sparked discussions about potential omissions in Barr's summary. The New York Times suggests that the length of the report raises questions about what Barr might have left out. However, Jim Geraghty, in today's Morning Jolt, argues that a lengthy report does not necessarily imply deception in Barr's summary. Geraghty points out that lengthy reports often come with an executive summary that is just a few pages long, and that the Attorney General did not undertake to summarize Mueller's full report; the purpose of his letter was to succinctly state Mueller's principal conclusions.

The Attorney General has pledged to release the report, in as complete a form as is legally and practically possible, in reasonably rapid fashion. The president seems to support, or at least not oppose, release as well. In writing his summary, the AG presumably was operating under the assumption that the report would be released, and that the public and the media would compare his summary with the final document.

The primary restriction that the Attorney General has cited for potential redactions is grand-jury secrecy rules. The grand-jury hurdle to disclosure is real, and IRA (Investigations and Reports Act) of 1970 requires the Attorney General to make the report available to Congress and the public, but with redactions to protect grand-jury material, ongoing investigations, and national security. The Attorney General has stated that he will release as much of the report as he can, while still complying with the law.

The grand-jury secrecy rules are a complex issue, and the Attorney General's ability to release the report without redactions may depend on the interpretation of these rules by the courts. The House, by a 420–0 margin, has already approved a resolution calling for the report to be made public. If there is a long delay in the release of the report, Republicans will likely face pressure to approve disclosure legislation, and the president will be under pressure to sign it. While some information might be withheld based on executive privilege, that privilege is constitutional and could be invoked even if a new disclosure law were enacted.

For now, the release of the Mueller report remains a topic of debate and speculation. The report will be substantially disclosed sooner rather than later, and it remains to be seen whether the Attorney General has faithfully described the report's conclusions, as many expect.

Title: Former Senator Jim Webb Calls for Democratic Party to Focus on White, Working-Class Voters

Article:

Former Virginia Senator Jim Webb, a potential candidate for the 2016 presidential election, has suggested that the Democratic Party should return to its roots of ensuring a voice for those without one in the corridors of power, including white, working-class individuals.

In an interview with NPR, Webb stated, "The Democratic party could do very well by returning to its Franklin Roosevelt/Harry Truman/Andrew Jackson roots, where the focus of the party was making sure that all people who lack a voice in the corridors of power could have one through their elected representatives."

Webb expressed concern about the party's performance with white working-class voters, stating, "I think they can do a better job with white working people, and I think this last election clearly showed that. If you look at the candidates that were getting beaten in areas where traditionally they had won — they [ were ] getting well less than 40 percent of the white vote."

Webb, a Vietnam veteran and former secretary of the Navy under President Reagan, served a single term in the U.S. Senate before stepping down. He has formed an exploratory committee as he considers a 2016 run and has spoken and written throughout his career on the influence of his Scots-Irish ancestors on Appalachia.

When asked about the high African-American voter turnout in past elections, Webb stated, "You’re not going to have a situation again where you have 96 percent of the African-American vote turning out for a presidential candidate — we need to get back to the message that was being developed, a return to the principles of the Democratic party that we are going to give everyone who needs access to the corridors of power that kind of access regardless of any of your antecedents."

Webb also addressed economic issues, stating, "I believe that if you look at our recovery, you will see that if you hold stocks — I hold stocks — you’re doing fairly well under this recovery. The stock market has almost tripled since April of 2009. If you are simply a typical wage-earning American, you haven’t really done that well — wages are actually flat and a little down."

Loans to small businesses have also been down, according to Webb. He emphasized the need to address these issues and protect working people.

If he runs for president, NPR's Steve Inskeep noted, there will be a point during the primary season where Webb would have to address why he should be chosen over the current Democratic frontrunner, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. Webb responded, "I really don’t have an answer for you on that. She has not announced that she’s running; I have not announced that I’m running. If I were to run, it would not be sort of as a counter-point to her. I have issues that I care about, I want to put [them] on the table, and we’ll see."

Title: Obamacare Premium Increases Could Impact Midterm Elections in Key States

Article:

The increase in health insurance premiums under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) may play a significant role in the upcoming midterm elections, particularly in states with competitive Senate races. In Louisiana and Iowa, double-digit rate hikes for individual health insurance plans have become a campaign issue, with Republican candidates criticizing their Democratic opponents for the premium increases.

In Louisiana, Representative Bill Cassidy has criticized the double-digit increases by some insurers, including Blue Cross Blue Shield of Louisiana, as "another hurdle for families and businesses already struggling under the demands of Obamacare." In Iowa, Senate candidate Joni Ernst has used the sharp rate increases for two insurers to attack the Democratic candidate, Representative Bruce Braley, for supporting the law.

However, it's important to note that premium increases are not universal across the country. In most states, premiums for coverage in the Obamacare health insurance exchanges for 2015 are rising at about the normal rate for health insurance throughout the country. In some places, they're even going down.

States like Alaska, where Democratic Senator Mark Begich is struggling to win a second term, are also facing significant premium increases. In these states, it's not all insurers that are raising rates that much. For example, in Louisiana, only rates for the insurers that are raising rates by 10 percent or more are being announced, making the public picture incomplete.

In an election year, a few states—and a few insurers—are enough, especially when they may serve to rekindle passions about a law that was already an Election Day concern for Democrats. Larry Levitt of the Kaiser Family Foundation, who has studied the premium trends around the country, stated, "In general, the premium increases have been pretty modest. But there are exceptions, and the exceptions happen to be in states with competitive races."

Republican strategists have been waiting for the big premium increases to show up as an Obamacare "October surprise." They've been hearing for months through their GOP policy expert contacts that the rate hikes were a possibility. The timing of the next enrollment season, which starts on Nov. 15, is such that the increases would become final around now.

Democrats are not too concerned, as the issue is not dominating the airwaves. With the Louisiana and Iowa Republican Senate candidates, it's been press statements and Twitter for now, although a conservative group did run a TV ad in Alaska that hit Senator Begich over the increases there.

Obama administration officials point out that even in the states with the biggest hikes, most customers won't see them. In Iowa, for example, premiums for the second-lowest-cost "silver" health insurance plans will go down by an average of 7 percent in Des Moines. They also note that the typical premiums for people who get Obamacare subsidies are pretty low to begin with. In Louisiana, for example, the average monthly premium was $68 this year for a "silver" plan.

The reason for the biggest rate hikes in competitive Senate races is not due to a conspiracy, but rather a result of the electoral math. The states with the biggest increases are usually the ones where the political leaders have resisted the Affordable Care Act and haven't done well at enrollment. And some of those states just happen to have the most competitive Senate races.

A study by PwC's Health Research Institute, which researched premium data in 38 states and the District of Columbia, found that the average increase across states was just 6 percent. Only eight states had double-digit increases—but those states included Louisiana and Iowa, as well as Kansas, where Republican Senator Pat Roberts is trying to head off a serious challenge from independent Greg Orman.

Title: Obama Clarifies Scope of Executive Action on Immigration, Faces Protests at Rally

Article:

In a rally held at Del Sol High School in Las Vegas on Friday, President Barack Obama clarified the scope of his recent executive action on immigration, stating that it does not apply to new undocumented immigrants. He emphasized that "borders mean something" and that the action does not apply to those who have recently entered the country or those who might come in the future.

The president's executive actions, signed on Friday, include shielding more immigrants from potential deportation and focusing deportations on individuals with criminal records. The actions have been met with opposition from Republicans in Congress, who argue that they will encourage more illegal immigration.

Republicans have criticized Obama's actions, citing a surge of illegal child immigrants across the U.S.-Mexico border earlier this year. The president, however, dismissed the argument that his actions have made it more difficult to pass a comprehensive immigration bill.

"I understand that some of them are already saying that my actions sabotage their ability to pass a bill and make immigration work better," Obama said, laughing. "Why? I didn't dissolve Parliament. That's not how our system works. I don't have a vote in Congress. Pass a bill. You don't need me to pass a bill."

Protesters outside the high school held signs reading "Impeach Obama" and "No Amnesty." Some chanted, "Worst president ever, Obama!" The president was interrupted several times with joyous chants of "Si Se Puede" and was heckled at one point by a young man who complained that the president's action did not include enough illegal immigrants.

Astrid Silva, a woman who qualified for Obama's deferred action plan because she came to the U.S. illegally as a child, introduced the president. She criticized the inaction by the GOP on immigration, stating, "House Republicans have refused to help me keep my dreams alive."

The president addressed concerns that his action is only applying to Hispanic immigrants, stating, "Not everybody who comes here is Latino. I'm from Chicago. We've got some Irish immigrants whose papers are not in order. We've got some Polish immigrants whose papers are not in order. This is not just a Latino issue. This is an American issue."

Obama also acknowledged that his legal advisers told him that his authority was limited on immigration. "Not everything that we want to do, we can do," he said. "We should be creating new programs for farm workers. We should be adding visas for the high-tech sector. We should be creating a pathway to citizenship. But only Congress can do that."

The president received many letters from Americans urging him not to take these actions, expressing concerns about immigration changing the fabric of the country, taking jobs from hard-working Americans, and economic stress. However, he also received messages reminding him why he had to act, from American family members of hard-working immigrants who fear their families could be torn apart, from dreamers who had stepped out of the shadows, and from Republicans tired of their party refusing to vote on reform.

"We didn't raise the Statue of Liberty with her back to the world. We did it with her light shining as a beacon to the world," Obama said.

Title: Cellphone Data Suggests Protesters at Anti-Lockdown Protests May Contribute to Coronavirus Spread

Article:

A study of cellphone location data has suggested that demonstrators at anti-lockdown protests, some of which have been linked to Covid-19 cases, are traveling hundreds of miles to events and returning to various parts of their states and even neighboring ones. The data, provided to a campaign group called the Committee to Protect Medicare, indicates that the protests may contribute to the spread of the coronavirus in areas that have, so far, experienced relatively few infections.

The data, captured from opt-in cellphone apps, was analyzed by data scientists at the firm VoteMap. They determined the movements of devices present at protests in late April and early May in five states: Michigan, Wisconsin, Illinois, Colorado, and Florida.

Data scientist Jeremy Fair, executive-vice president of VoteMap, stated that many of the devices that are seen to reach state borders are seen to continue across them in the underlying raw data. One visualization shows that in Lansing, Michigan, after a 30 April protest where armed protesters stormed the capitol building, devices which had been present at the protest site can be seen returning to all parts of the state, from Detroit to remote towns in the state's north. One device visible in the data traveled to and from Afton, which is over 180 miles from the capital. Others reached, and some crossed, the Indiana border.

In the 48 hours following a 19 April "Operation Gridlock" protest in Denver, devices reached the borders of neighboring states including Wyoming, Nebraska, Oklahoma, New Mexico, and Utah. In Florida on 18 April, devices returned to all parts of the peninsula and up to the Georgia border. In Wisconsin on 24 April, devices returned to smaller towns like Green Bay and Wausau, and the borders of Minnesota and Illinois.

Following the initial wave of anti-lockdown protests in April, epidemiologists warned that they could lead to a new surge in cases. In North Carolina in late April, one of the leaders of the state's anti-lockdown protests tested positive for Covid-19 but said she would attend future rallies.

Dr. Rob Davidson, executive director of the Committee to Protect Medicare, stated that although "it's hard to draw a straight line between devices, individuals at these protests, and cases," the data suggests that the protests may be epidemiologically significant events. "The behavior we're seeing at protests carries a high risk of infection. We can see protesters are going from a highly concentrated event and then dispersing widely," he added.

Davidson, who has run for Congress as a Democrat, stated that neither he nor his advocacy group were currently affiliated with the Democratic party. The group is made up of more than 300 "doctors who are concerned that the healthcare for their patients has become unaffordable."

In a series of widely shared videos and threads on Twitter, Davidson has criticized President Trump and attempted to dispel what he calls the "distrust in public health" which "Donald Trump has fomented in his movement."

Title: President Trump's Self-Pardon and Ongoing Russia Probe

Article:

In a series of tweets on June 4, 2018, President Donald Trump asserted that he has the constitutional right to pardon himself, but he has not expressed any intention to do so. This statement comes amidst the ongoing investigation into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential election.

Trump's personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, has stated that while the president constitutionally has the power to pardon himself, it is unlikely due to the potential political ramifications. In an interview with ABC's "This Week," Giuliani said, "Pardoning other people is one thing; pardoning yourself is another."

The discussion about self-pardoning stems from a 20-page letter to special counsel Robert Mueller from Trump's former lawyer, John Dowd. The letter, which was recently leaked, argues that it is impossible for a president to obstruct justice and asserts that the president has the power to pardon.

Republican leaders, including House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA), have suggested that the self-pardon issue is a distraction and that it's time to wrap up the investigation. McCarthy stated, "I don't know why we're walking through hypotheticals here in this process. The president has never said he would pardon himself."

The president's frustration with the nearly 13-month investigation into the Russia probe boiled over on Twitter this weekend, with Trump tweeting, "When will this very expensive witch hunt hoax ever end?" He also expressed concern about potential leaks from the special counsel's office and the Department of Justice to the media.

As the investigation continues, Trump faces tensions with Canada over recently implemented tariffs and a high-stakes summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on June 12.

Title: Trump's Bipartisan Wins: A Look at the President's Recent Legislative Achievements

Article:

President Donald Trump has been lauded for his role in leading the bipartisan push for federal prison reform, culminating in the passage of the FIRST STEP Act. The law, signed in December, aims to reduce sentences for drug felonies and other non-violent crimes, limit the sentencing disparity between crack and powder cocaine, and allow prisoners to earn "good time credits" by participating in educational or training programs.

The President celebrated the new law, stating, "This will keep our communities safer, and provide hope and a second chance to those who earn it. In addition to everything else, billions of dollars will be saved."

The FIRST STEP Act is not the only bipartisan victory for President Trump this year. In July, he signed legislation to renew a federal workforce development program that allows states to provide technical education and training for students to develop skills for good-paying jobs.

In September, President Trump again brought Democrats and Republicans together to draft the Protecting Patients From Surprise Medical Bills Act. This law guards patients from unexpected out-of-network bills and prohibits providers from charging patients for the difference if their insurance does not pay the full price of a given service or procedure.

In October, the President signed the SUPPORT For Patients and Communities Act, a sweeping legislation to confront the opioid crisis. The bill provides funding for treatment and recovery, increased security to keep dangerous drugs out of the country, monitoring of opioid prescriptions, and development of non-opioid painkillers, among other key provisions.

The Water Infrastructure Act, signed in the same month, ensures safe and secure drinking water systems across the nation and prevents a recurrence of the Flint, Michigan catastrophe. The bill received a nearly unanimous vote of 99-1 in the Senate.

According to a May report by Quorum, 70 percent of the bills signed into law from this Congress have had at least one Democrat and one Republican sponsor, the highest level of bipartisanship in 20 years. The Trump administration's effectiveness at working across party lines demonstrates the potential for constructive bipartisan collaboration, especially as Democrats and Republicans prepare to share power and responsibility for the agenda of Congress in the new year.

Title: US Intelligence Warns Bernie Sanders of Russian Interference in His Presidential Campaign

Article:

The Washington Post reported on Friday that US intelligence officials have warned Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate, that Russia is attempting to help his campaign. The news follows reports that intelligence officials recently briefed Congress about Russian interference aimed at helping reelect President Donald Trump.

According to The Washington Post, both Sanders and President Trump were briefed on Russia's efforts. Sanders, in a statement to The Washington Post, said, "I don't care, frankly, who [Russian President Vladimir] Putin wants to be president. My message to Putin is clear: Stay out of American elections, and as president, I will make sure that you do."

The Sanders campaign did not immediately respond to The Post's request for comment.

Jessica Brandt, head of policy and research for the Alliance for Securing Democracy, stated, "All of this is part of Russia's much broader effort to cast democracies as feckless, ineffective, and corrupt."

In 2016, Russian misinformation agents and hackers worked to boost Trump's electoral chances while also throwing some support behind Sanders as he ran against Hillary Clinton in the Democratic primary. The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence's definitive look at Russian interference concluded that the IRA's left-leaning accounts focused their efforts on denigrating Clinton and supporting either fellow Democrat candidate Bernie Sanders or Green Party candidate Jill Stein, at the expense of Hillary Clinton.

Clint Watts, a senior fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute who studies Russian interference efforts, stated, "The Kremlin's strategy for a year has been very straightforward. They would like to see Trump reelected."

Russia has already gone after Biden aggressively, likely hacking into Burisma, the Ukrainian gas company whose connection to Hunter Biden has been the focus of a conspiratorial narrative by Trump and his allies. Moscow's disinformation efforts in support of Sanders once again focused on Iowa, whose caucus earlier this month was beset by technical difficulties.

Jessica Brandt of the Alliance for Securing Democracy said, "We saw Russia amplifying conspiracy theories suggesting that delays in reporting returns were part of an effort to deny Senator Sanders a clear win. We also saw them highlighting theories purporting murky ties between other candidates and the company that created the caucus app."

It is unclear if the activity tracked by the Alliance for Securing Democracy led directly to the intel briefings being reported on this week. Sanders told The New York Times Friday that he was briefed a month ago, which would be before the Iowa fallout. However, it does speak to what experts say is Russia's ultimate goal, which is less about Sanders and more about promoting chaos. The point has always been to find democracy's loose seams, and pull.

Title: U.S. and North Korea Leaders Meet for Second Summit in Hanoi, Seeking Progress on Denuclearization

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un began their second summit in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Wednesday, with the U.S. side seeking tangible steps by North Korea towards dismantling its nuclear weapons program. The two leaders will be accompanied by two aides and interpreters during their discussions, which come eight months after their historic summit in Singapore.

Trump arrived in Hanoi on Air Force One late on Tuesday, while Kim traveled by train from Pyongyang, crossing the border from China by train and completing the final stretch by car. The leaders will have a 20-minute one-on-one conversation before a dinner scheduled to last just over an hour and a half.

The summit follows the first meeting in Singapore last June, where the two leaders aimed to break the ice after decades of bitter animosity between their two countries. This time, there is pressure to move beyond the vaguely worded commitment by Kim to work toward the complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.

Trump's critics at home have urged him to avoid cutting a deal that would do little to curb North Korea's nuclear ambitions, while Kim is expected to seek significant U.S. concessions such as relief from sanctions and a declaration that the Korean War is at last formally over.

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also arrived in Hanoi on Tuesday and met with Vietnamese Foreign Minister Pham Binh Minh for talks. While Trump is in Hanoi, his former personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, is testifying before U.S. congressional committees, with the president's business practices the main focus. Anticipation has also been rising about the impending release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election, though a senior U.S. Justice Department official said on Friday it would not come this week.

Some analysts fear that Trump may be under pressure at home to show progress on a foreign policy issue that has confounded multiple predecessors, which could lead him to make concessions that leave the United States less secure. The two sides might agree to a formal end of the Korean War, a move long sought by North Korea, as the war concluded with an armistice, rather than a peace treaty.

Title: Growing Faction of Second Amendment Purists Challenges NRA Leadership

Article:

A faction of gun rights activists, often referred to as "gundamentalists," has emerged within the National Rifle Association (NRA), posing a challenge to the organization's leadership and its ability to maintain moderate support and make potential compromises on gun control measures. This group, which has grown in influence, is demanding that the NRA's leadership remain firm against gun control advocates, according to interviews with gun-rights activists, policy experts, and gun-control advocates.

Adam Kraut, a gun rights lawyer, fell short of the 71,000 votes needed for election to the NRA's board in May, but earned 5,000 more votes than the previous year, signifying the growth of Second Amendment purists within the NRA. This group is known for their staunch support of gun rights and opposition to any form of gun control.

The rise of this faction has caused internal pressure within the NRA, threatening the organization's ability to retain moderate supporters and make compromises that could help fend off tougher gun control measures. The NRA has faced internal divisions before, with an internal revolt at the 1977 meeting in Cincinnati transforming the organization from a polite, sport-shooting group into a powerful political lobby.

The NRA leadership has reportedly put up obstacles to Kraut's election, using bylaws that make it harder for candidates not endorsed by the nominating committee to be elected to the board, and enlisting a senior member to campaign against him. Marion Hammer, a past president of the NRA and one of the group's most successful lobbyists, criticized unsanctioned candidates in a column on the website Ammoland. Although Hammer did not name Kraut, he was one of only two non-approved candidates to run.

The protesters, who marched through the NRA's annual meeting in Dallas in May, were predominantly white men, including bearded outdoorsmen and buttoned-down libertarians. Some concealed their "NRA = Not Real Activists" T-shirts while entering the convention hall for fear of being banned by NRA security.

Kraut, 31, practices firearms law in suburban Philadelphia and hosts a video blog called The Legal Brief on The Gun Collective, a YouTube channel. He has campaigned for the NRA to push for more expansive gun-rights laws and to renew its leadership by changing NRA bylaws, such as imposing term limits for board members and mandatory meeting attendance.

One of Kraut's most prominent supporters, Tim Harmsen, who led the pro-Kraut march through the convention center, has 770,000 subscribers to the Military Arms Channel on YouTube, where he criticizes the NRA for being weak on gun laws. "We're going to continue to apply pressure (on the NRA) every way that we can through social media, and we'll be there again next year," Harmsen said.

These hardline gun-rights activists deeply cherish their right to keep and bear arms, as protected by the U.S. Constitution's Second Amendment. They oppose any form of gun control, arguing that criminals will find ways around gun laws, which only strip lawful gun owners of the right to self-defense and protection against state tyranny.

The gun-rights purists are outraged by any concessions the NRA makes in the wake of mass shootings, even if these concessions are made to avoid stricter gun control laws. Opinion polls, such as a regular Gallup survey, show growing support for gun control in recent years. However, support for gun control typically spikes immediately after mass shootings, then falls closer to pre-massacre levels within a few months.

After a shooter killed 58 people at a country music concert in Las Vegas last year, the NRA supported federal regulation of bump stocks, accessories that the gunman used to fire his semiautomatic rifles more quickly. The Justice Department then ordered an effective ban that is close to being finalized.

Amid nationwide protests that followed a Florida high school shooting that killed 17 people in February, the NRA endorsed strengthening background checks for gun purchasers and emergency protection orders that allow law-enforcement officials to temporarily take guns away from people deemed dangerous.

"For us, some of the things that come out of NRA headquarters are just outrageous and abhorrent," said Jeff Knox, a Kraut supporter whose father, Neal Knox, led the "Revolt at Cincinnati" in 1977. "It's: Holy cow, what are these guys thinking?" The NRA and Marion Hammer did not respond to requests to address the influence of the gundamentalists and the criticism that these activists and other gun-rights groups directed at the lobby.

Title: Trump-Russia Investigation and Iran-US Tensions: Analysis of Recent Developments

Article:

The political landscape in the United States has been marked by two significant developments: the ongoing investigation into the Trump campaign's alleged contacts with Russians and the escalating tensions between the U.S. and Iran, culminating in the assassination of Qassem Soleimani, a top Iranian military commander.

The Trump administration's contacts with Russians during the 2016 election campaign have been a subject of controversy. Critics argue that the appointment of U.S. Attorney John Durham to investigate the origins of the investigation is politically motivated, while supporters maintain that the investigation into the Trump campaign was justified given the numerous contacts between Trump officials and Russians.

The investigation, according to reports, uncovered contacts between Trump's son, son-in-law, campaign chairman, personal lawyer, future national security adviser, future attorney general, and others with Russians. The counterintelligence investigators, concerned about Russian activities and the potential impact of the investigation on the election, proceeded with caution, keeping the investigation secret until after the election.

The Steele Dossier, a largely unconfirmed report on early Russian efforts to influence Trump, has been a point of contention. Trump supporters argue that the Steele Dossier's citation in a footnote of the FISA application undermines the investigation's legitimacy. However, it is important to note that the FISA application disclosed that the Steele Dossier had received funding from those "likely looking for information to discredit" the Trump campaign, and the surveillance on Carter Page was renewed multiple times, including by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, a Trump appointee.

The assassination of Qassem Soleimani, a powerful Iranian military leader, has led to increased tensions between the U.S. and Iran. The main question about the strike isn't moral or legal—it's strategic. Soleimani was not a terror kingpin, and his death doesn't decapitate anything. The only reason to kill Soleimani, according to some analysts, is to enter a new war that the U.S. can win. However, there are concerns about the strategic implications of the strike, including the potential for Iran to retaliate and the impact on U.S. allies.

In the aftermath of the strike, it is crucial for influential Republican senators to remind President Trump of his promise to keep America out of foreign quagmires and prevent further escalation of conflict with Iran. The U.S. must carefully consider the potential consequences of its actions and the credibility of its intelligence in the region.

Title: Graham Threatens to Delay Obama's Defense and CIA Nominees Over Benghazi Inquiry

Article:

Senator Lindsey Graham (R-SC) has threatened to delay the confirmation of President Barack Obama's nominees for secretary of defense and CIA director, John Brennan and Chuck Hagel, unless the Obama administration provides more information about its response to the September 2012 attack on an American diplomatic post in Libya.

During an interview on CBS on Sunday, Graham stated, "I do not think we should allow Brennan to go forward with the CIA directorship, Hagel to be confirmed for secretary of defense, until the White House gives us an accounting." Graham questioned whether the president had taken any action to help those affected by the attack and demanded to know if the president had contacted any Libyan government officials.

Previously, Graham had threatened to put a hold on Hagel's nomination unless outgoing Defense Secretary Leon Panetta testified before Congress on the Benghazi attacks. Panetta testified last week before the Senate Armed Services Committee, stating that, without direct warning or advance intelligence of the September 11, 2012, attack, there was no way for the military to respond in time.

Graham, along with other Republicans, has also criticized the Obama administration's initial response to the attack, particularly the appearance of U.S. ambassador to the United Nations Susan Rice less than a week later on Sunday talk shows, where she blamed the attack on anger generated by an anti-Muslim video. Rice has since explained her remarks as derived from administration talking points, which Graham said on Sunday had not yet been sufficiently explained.

"I want to know who changed the talking points. Who took the references to al Qaeda out of the talking points given to Susan Rice?" said Graham, specifying that he would not filibuster the nominees but rather hold them up until more information is disclosed.

Senator John McCain, a close Republican ally of Graham's in the Senate, said Monday he would not support a filibuster of Hagel, which would be unprecedented for a president's Cabinet nominee.

National Security Council spokesman Tommy Vietor said Sunday in response to Graham's comments that the White House believes "the Senate should act swiftly to confirm John Brennan and Sen. Hagel. These are critical national security positions, and individual members should not play politics with their nominations."

Title: Vacant Senior Positions in the State Department Pose Challenges for Trump Administration

Article:

The Trump administration is facing criticism for the lack of ambassadors in key countries as tensions escalate with North Korea, a situation that could potentially impact the U.S.'s response to the nuclear crisis. According to Evelyn Cheng of CNBC, there are more than 100 senior positions vacant in the State Department, including ambassadors to South Korea, China, Japan, India, and Australia.

As of Friday, no nominee for the South Korean ambassador has been considered. The nominee for the Tokyo embassy was not selected until March and has not been confirmed yet. The nomination for the Beijing embassy, Iowa Governor Terry Branstad, foundered in the Senate due to the Trump administration's inability to complete necessary paperwork.

The issue of vacant positions in the State Department has raised concerns about the administration's ability to handle foreign policy matters effectively. The lack of ambassadors in key countries could hinder communication and coordination with relevant authorities in those countries during critical situations.

The Trump administration's approach to governing has been compared to running a business, a tradition that dates back to the desire to "run the government like a business." However, the government is not a business, and it makes little sense to try to run it like one. The government is a unique entity with its own set of challenges and responsibilities that cannot be compared to a business or a nonprofit organization.

Donald Trump, as a businessman, has faced criticism for his lack of experience in running large organizations. His attempts to run large businesses, such as the Trump Taj Mahal and the Plaza Hotel, have ended in bankruptcy. Trump's career has primarily consisted of licensing deals and media appearances, which are very different from running a large corporation like Microsoft or Ford.

The skills required to run a business are not necessarily transferable to the public sector, and especially not to the presidency. The president proposes a policy agenda and works to forge a political consensus to support it, working with Congress to implement it through legislation. Trump is not doing that. Instead, he is putting on public spectacles and tweeting.

The lack of a clear policy agenda and the inability to implement it effectively has been evident in the ongoing debate over healthcare reform, where Republicans, who control the presidency, the Senate, and the House of Representatives, are struggling to pass a bill.

The Trump administration's failure to fill key positions in the bureaucracy has also raised concerns about the administration's ability to implement its policies. The proverb "Personnel is policy" highlights the importance of having the right people in place to carry out a policy agenda. The Trump administration's lack of personnel in key positions could hinder the implementation of its policies and lead to a lack of coordination and communication within the government.

Title: White House Power Couple's Disagreements with President Trump: A Chronicle

Article:

The relationship between President Donald Trump and his advisers, Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner, has reportedly been strained on several occasions, with their disagreements often making headlines.

This week, The New York Times reported, citing an anonymous source, that Kushner and Ms. Trump had urged the president to denounce the white nationalist protesters in Charlottesville, Virginia, more forcefully. The report came after Trump defended his statements on the matter.

"You look at both sides. I think there is blame on both sides... If you reported it accurately, you would say that," Trump said to an angry media scrum.

This is not the first time President Trump has upset his daughter and son-in-law, only for it to inexplicably find its way to the media. Here are five other instances where the power couple and the president have disagreed:

1. In October 2016, tapes emerged in which President Trump was heard making crude comments about women. The Washington Post leaked the tapes, which nearly derailed Trump's campaign and upset Ivanka Trump. According to The New York Times, she made an emphatic case for a full-throated apology.

2. In June 2017, President Trump announced that the U.S. would pull back from the Paris climate agreement. It was reported that Ivanka and Jared were not pleased, with Politico citing sources saying that the pair were taking it in their stride.

3. In January 2017, Kushner was reportedly "furious" that his efforts were being "undermined" by the President of the United States, according to Vanity Fair. The outlet pointed to a meeting between Trump and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, which Kushner was trying to arrange.

4. In February 2017, news reached Politico that the pair helped kill off an order that would have overturned a 2014 Obama-era executive order preventing LGBT discrimination in the workplace. The White House downplayed the move, saying it was one of hundreds of draft orders being considered.

5. In August 2017, President Trump tweeted that he would not allow trans-identifying people to serve in the military. According to Politico, Kushner and Ms. Trump were "blindsided" by the tweet, with Ivanka reportedly learning of the decision when she saw her father's tweet on her phone.

Adam Shaw, a politics reporter based in New York, reported on these developments for The ███. Follow Adam on Twitter: @AdamShawNY.

Title: Political Parties in Disarray: A Neutral Analysis of the Current State of the Republican and Democratic Parties

Article:

The United States political landscape is currently witnessing a significant level of dysfunction within both the Republican and Democratic parties.

The Republican Party, which currently controls the White House, the Senate, and the House of Representatives, is facing internal strife due to a combination of ideological, political, and structural issues. The party's dysfunctionality is not only evident in its day-to-day operations but also in the unpredictable behavior of its president, who often captures public attention like a spider monkey in a church with a lit stick of dynamite.

On the other hand, the Democratic Party appears to be preoccupied with the spectacle of the Republican Party's dysfunction. In a metaphor reminiscent of a drunken individual, the Democratic Party seems oblivious to its own decrepitude, shouting at the television and boasting about its potential for improvement.

Former Democratic Party functionary Donna Brazile, who served as interim chair in the lead-up to the 2016 election, has revealed in an excerpt from her forthcoming book that the party was in significant debt and was essentially taken over by Hillary Clinton. According to Brazile, the Clinton campaign, through Debbie Wasserman Schultz, controlled the party's messaging and hiring, while raising millions ostensibly for the party but ultimately funneling the funds back into the Clinton campaign's coffers.

The Democratic Party's current unifying principle is its opposition to President Donald Trump. However, when it comes to ideas about governing, the party's passion is primarily focused on two areas: Senator Bernie Sanders' idea of "socialism" and the angry, sanctimony-besotted identity politics popular on college campuses and certain left-wing websites.
