The Democratic National Committee's data-services manager recently sent out an email soliciting applications for new hires in the IT department. In the email, she cautioned that she was not looking for "cisgender straight white males." This could potentially alienate a significant portion of the electorate, particularly working-class men who feel disenfranchised by the party.

The Republican Party, meanwhile, is also facing criticism for its handling of various issues. The party's current state could be seen as a reflection of its inability to adapt to changing societal norms and the increasing diversity of the American electorate.

In conclusion, both political parties are currently grappling with significant internal issues, and their ability to effectively govern and represent the American people is being called into question. The current state of the parties could potentially lead to a shift in the political landscape, with new ideas and leaders emerging to challenge the status quo.

Title: "The Role of Evaluation Apprehension in Political Opinion Polling: A Social Psychological Perspective"

Article:

The concept of "things seldom being what they seem" is a recurring theme in literature, and it appears to be a relevant factor in political opinion polling as well. In a recent article, the author argues that the election polls during the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign were influenced by a phenomenon known as "evaluation apprehension."

Evaluation apprehension, a term coined by the author, refers to an anxiety-induced concern about being positively or negatively judged. This state can influence individuals' responses, particularly in political opinion surveys, where respondents may want to please or avoid displeasing the interviewer, especially when discussing political preferences.

In the context of the 2016 U.S. presidential race, the near-unanimous rejection and derogation of Donald Trump by the media could have triggered evaluation apprehension among Trump supporters, leading to disingenuous responses when expressing their presidential preference. This effect might not have been universal, but it could have been significant enough to skew the data in an inaccurate direction.

Another factor that compounded the problem was the release of the Access Hollywood video, which showed Trump making controversial comments about his sexual behavior. The subsequent dip in Trump's poll numbers was expected, but his rebound after a few days suggested a connection with a substantial and aggrieved sector of the voting public that the pollsters and commentators are only now acknowledging.

The author suggests that a more detailed understanding of public opinion polling would improve political journalism. If journalists had a better grasp of the art (or science, as it is never can be), they would avoid making inaccurate predictions or overly confident assertions.

The author also points out that the error limits calculated statistically in polls are meant to reflect sampling errors, discarded respondents, quota excesses, or poor interviewer performance. These errors are assumed to be randomly distributed rather than one-sided. However, the activation of evaluation apprehension can cause a one-sided tilting of data, which is not easily accounted for in quick cell phone conversations with respondents.

The author concludes by emphasizing the need for a deeper understanding of the psychological factors that influence political opinion polling. This understanding could provide insights into the reasons behind the election of a candidate like Donald Trump, who was perceived as a longshot by many pollsters and commentators. The author calls for future historians and journalists to delve deeper into the factors that led half of the electorate to support a candidate who, in their view, got "so far beyond the windmills."

Title: Trump Outlines Plans for "Renewal of the American Spirit" in Joint Address to Congress

Article:

President Donald Trump is set to deliver a joint address to Congress on Tuesday, outlining his plans for a "renewal of the American spirit" through his economic goals and priorities. The speech, which will reportedly strike an optimistic tone, is intended to present the president's vision for addressing real-world problems and reset the turbulent first month of his presidency.

According to senior administration officials, the speech will emphasize the theme of renewal, with Trump explaining how his administration aims to solve problems for the American people. He is expected to address the backlash to his immigration and travel ban, struggles to develop a replacement healthcare plan, turnover in his national security team, and allegations of ties between his administration and Russia.

As of Monday evening, the president was still working with speechwriters to finalize the speech. The content of the speech is a departure from the dark tone of his inaugural address, which promised to stop "American carnage." This new speech, delivered just over a month later, is the result of listening sessions and meetings with healthcare professionals, law enforcement, union representatives, coal miners, and others.

The speech will focus on two key themes of Trump's campaign and early presidency: growing economic opportunity and protecting the American people. In an interview on Fox News, Trump attributed messaging problems for his rocky first month in office, stating, "I think I get an A in terms of what I've actually done, but in terms of messaging, I'd give myself a C or a C+."

Trump also expressed confidence that a revitalized economy would fund the $54 billion increase in defense spending he is proposing. "I mean you look at the kind of numbers we're doing, we were probably GDP of a little more than 1 percent, and if I can get that up to 3 or maybe more, we have a whole different ball game," he said. The Commerce Department puts the GDP at 1.6% for 2016.

Senior administration officials described Tuesday's speech as an optimistic look forward to what Trump hopes to accomplish in office. The president will also review the promises he made to the American people and argue for what he has kept so far, pointing to his executive orders and memos. National security and foreign policy will also be a significant part of the speech, with Trump expected to issue a new executive order this week regarding his travel ban. The new order is expected to provide more detail and not affect green card holders.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Discusses Russia's Election Interference and U.S. Response on CNN's "State of the Union"

Article:

Senator Rand Paul (R-KY) stated on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday that it is a mistake to hold Russia accountable for its interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, suggesting that many countries, including the U.S., have attempted to meddle in foreign elections.

"They're another country. They're going to spy on us. They do spy on us. They're going to interfere in our elections. We also do the same," said Sen. Paul. He emphasized the importance of protecting the integrity of U.S. elections, stating that the focus should be on ensuring the electoral process is secure rather than attributing blame for past election interference.

Sen. Paul also suggested that, from Russia's perspective, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, was responsible for some meddling during the Obama administration. He clarified that he was not equating the two in terms of moral equivalence but acknowledged that this is how Russia responds.

Ahead of President Trump's meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki, Finland, on Monday, Sen. Paul expressed doubt that the Russians would admit their involvement in the 2016 election interference, comparing it to the U.S.'s reluctance to admit its influence in campaigns in other countries' elections.

Sen. Paul considered the recent indictment of 12 Russian military officers for allegedly stealing Democratic emails and interfering in the 2016 election a "good thing," but he believed the Department of Justice could have investigated the matter without a special counsel. He expressed the view that if there is proof of Russian interference, the focus should shift to protecting the U.S. from future foreign interference rather than pursuing a "witch hunt" on President Trump.

Sen. Paul stated that there is "no evidence" so far that President Trump has been personally involved in the election interference. He concluded by expressing the need to move past the investigation and focus on protecting U.S. elections from foreign interference.

Title: Texas State Troopers Begin Asking Motorists Race and Ethnicity to Improve Data Accuracy

Article:

In response to the discovery of inaccurate racial identification of drivers, particularly Hispanics, during traffic stops due to flaws in an automated system meant to prevent racial profiling, Texas state troopers have begun asking motorists their race and ethnicity.

Department of Public Safety Director Steve McCraw testified before a state House committee that the change took effect on Wednesday, aiming to collect more accurate data. McCraw stated, "What we can do better, and what we should have been doing better, is collect the data accurately as it relates to Hispanics. Plain and simple... I would rather a trooper not have to ask, but if the data does not work... there is a problem."

KXAN-TV in Austin conducted a database review using millions of records going back to 2010, which showed troopers across the state inaccurately reported the race of Hispanic drivers. The television station's investigation of DPS traffic citation records also found that the number of drivers stopped by troopers and recorded as Hispanic has increased annually since 2010—from nearly 208,000 to 351,000 last year—while the number of drivers recorded as white declined in the same time period from 1.9 million to about 1.2 million last year, according to the Associated Press.

Among the most common surnames of drivers listed by troopers as white are Garcia, Martinez, Hernandez, Gonzalez, and Rodriguez. However, a Hispanic name does not necessarily mean a person is of Hispanic descent. The review of DPS records showed more than 1.9 million drivers with traditionally Hispanic names were listed as white, while over the same period, approximately 1.6 million were reported as Hispanic.

To prevent racial profiling, state law requires authorities to document the race of drivers who are arrested, issued warnings, or citations. However, McCraw testified that coding on drivers' licenses only allowed for identification as Hispanic since 2010. Prior to that time, Hispanic motorists were often identified as white.

McCraw testified that he did not know how much it would cost to fix the automated system, leaving no other remedy but to direct troopers to specifically ask for the information. "Officers will advise the individual that the officer is required by law to inquire as to the individual’s race or ethnicity," a DPS memo outlining the new policy stated. "The officer will record the race or ethnicity as stated by the motorist. Only in cases where an individual refuses to provide the requested information and the database reflects their race or ethnicity as 'other,' will the officer use best judgment or ability to determine the race or ethnicity of the motorist."

Despite the current lack of data, McCraw maintained that the agency does not tolerate racial profiling. "Bottom line, it's against the law," he said. "There is no racial profiling within the DPS."

Title: Facebook Apologizes for Flagging Declaration of Independence as Hate Speech

Article:

Facebook has issued an apology to the Liberty County Vindicator after removing an excerpt from the United States Declaration of Independence, citing it as a violation of the social network's policies on "hate speech." The Liberty County Vindicator had been sharing the Declaration of Independence in parts on their Facebook page, but the tenth part was removed by Facebook.

The excised portion of text, which Facebook deemed as "hate speech," is as follows:

He has abdicated Government here, by declaring us out of his Protection and waging War against us. He has plundered our seas, ravaged our Coasts, burnt our towns, and destroyed the lives of our people. He is at this time transporting large Armies of foreign Mercenaries to compleat the works of death, desolation and tyranny, already begun with circumstances of Cruelty & perfidy scarcely paralleled in the most barbarous ages, and totally unworthy the Head of a civilized nation.

Casey Stinnett, managing editor of the Liberty County Vindicator, suspects that the term "Indian Savages" may have triggered Facebook's filtering program. He described the censorship as an "automated action."

Stinnett wrote, "This is frustrating, but your editor is a historian, and to enjoy the study of history a person must love irony. It is a very great irony that the words of Thomas Jefferson should now be censored in America."

Title: Ronan Farrow Discusses Matt Lauer's Firing and Allegations in Upcoming Book on "Good Morning America"

Article:

Ronan Farrow made his first television appearance since excerpts from his upcoming book, "Catch and Kill," revealed new details surrounding Matt Lauer's 2017 firing. In an interview on "Good Morning America," Farrow stood by his book, which is set to be released next week, despite Lauer calling the reporting in "Catch and Kill" false and defamatory.

During the interview, Farrow alleged that there were previous accusations brought to NBC regarding Lauer's conduct before the 2017 complaint that led to his ouster. Farrow, however, could not reveal specific details about conversations with his sources or if he spoke with Lauer. He stated that the former "Today" show co-host's "way of thinking" is represented in the book, and everything printed "extensively fact-checked."

George Stephanopoulos then referenced NBC's statement about the rape allegation in Farrow's book. The network stated Lauer was fired within 24 hours of NBC learning about the complaint in 2017, and any suggestions of NBC trying to cover up for Lauer are "false and offensive."

Farrow claimed that he spent years reporting and fact-checking the claims made in his book, and what he found goes against NBC's statement. He said, years before Lauer's 2017 firing, over a six to seven-year period, there were seven non-disclosure agreements at the network, multiple of which involved Lauer.

Farrow also added that he spoke with NBC senior executives who were made aware of those earlier settlements. NBC issued a statement to ███ in response to Farrow's "Good Morning America" interview, reiterating NBC News Chairman Andy Lack's memo, shared earlier this week, that stated the first NBC heard about allegations of sexual misconduct against Lauer was on the night of November 27, 2017, and he was fired 24 hours after.

The statement added NBC Universal's legal team has conducted interviews and did an exhaustive search of available records and found no claims or settlements that suggest inappropriate conduct by Lauer prior to his 2017 firing. The network stated after his termination is when NBC reached an agreement with two women.

On Tuesday, news broke that Farrow's book includes new details about the allegation that caused Lauer's firing. Brooke Nevils, the previously unnamed accuser at the center of Lauer's fall from grace, is identified in the book, and "Catch and Kill" delves into details of Nevils' allegation that Lauer raped her during the 2014 Sochi Olympics.

In a lengthy letter provided by his lawyer to Variety, Lauer denied the allegation and painted the picture of an accusation full of contradictions. He said he has shied away until now from speaking out on the "false and salacious allegations" against him to protect his children.

"I have never assaulted anyone or forced anyone to have sex. Period," Lauer wrote. "My silence has been a mistake. Old stories are being recycled, titillating details are being added, and a dangerous and defamatory new allegation is being made. All are being spread as part of a promotional effort to sell a book. It’s outrageous. So, after not speaking out to protect my children, it is now with their full support I say 'enough.'"

Nevils stepped forward with a tweet Wednesday. "I want to thank the many survivors who shared their stories with me today and offered their support. It takes courage, and I am truly grateful," she wrote.

In a statement to ███, she said she asked NBC to thoroughly investigate her allegations and to give Lauer "the opportunity to defend himself." She also said she provided "dates, times, evidence of communications and corroborating accounts" to back up her accusations and "both NBC and Farrow found me credible."

She continued: "There's the Matt Lauer that millions of Americans watched on TV every morning for two decades, and there is the Matt Lauer who this morning attempted to bully a former colleague into silence. His open letter was a case study in victim blaming... I am not afraid of him now, regardless of his threats, bullying, and the shaming and predatory tactics I knew he would (and now has) tried to use against me."

Title: Operation Fast and Furious: Inspector General Report Faults Multiple Agencies, Calls for Disciplinary Action

 Article:

 The Inspector General's report on Operation Fast and Furious, a failed anti-gunrunning probe, has led to the resignation of one Justice Department official and the retirement of another, with 14 more officials facing possible disciplinary action. The report, which faults a range of agencies for their handling of the operation, has sparked calls for further action from Republican lawmakers.

 At a hearing on Thursday, Rep. Darrell Issa, R-Calif., chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, stated that "all 14" officials should leave the department. Other lawmakers have suggested senior officials, particularly criminal division chief Lanny Breuer, should face discipline.

 The report, which is the most comprehensive account yet on the deadly operation, accused officials of a "disregard" for public safety. It details how weapons allowed to "walk" across the U.S.-Mexico border resulted in hundreds of firearms turning up at crime scenes in both countries.

 The report states that Attorney General Eric Holder was not made aware of potential flaws in the program until February of last year. However, lawmakers have pointed to a section of the findings that suggests wiretap applications should have raised "red flags" for those who reviewed them, contradicting Holder's earlier testimony.

 The report states: "We reviewed the wiretap affidavits in both Operation Wide Receiver and Operation Fast and Furious and concluded that the affidavits in both cases included information that would have caused a prosecutor who was focused on the question of investigative tactics, particularly one who was already sensitive to the issue of 'gun walking,' to have questions about ATF's conduct of the investigations."

 Inspector General Michael Horowitz repeated this claim during Thursday's hearing, stating: "If you were focused and looking at the question of gunwalking you would read these reports and see many red flags."

 Rep. Jason Chaffetz, R-Utah, said Holder's testimony from earlier this year was a "direct contradiction" to that. Holder had stated that he did not see anything in the affidavits that would indicate gunwalking was allowed.

 Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-S.C., said that in light of Holder's testimony, the IG's conclusion was "startling."

 The Justice Department official said Holder's statements to Congress were accurate, noting that "the affidavits do not explicitly and clearly say gun-walking" and claiming the IG report does not allege that either.

 Gowdy also questioned how employees under Breuer were being disciplined while Breuer so far has not been in any serious way. The IG report criticized Breuer for not notifying Holder about Operation Wide Receiver, the prior Bush-era gunwalking investigation, when he first learned about it in 2010.

 A DOJ official told Fox News that Breuer was "admonished" by Holder last year, but no further action is considered to be warranted. An employee under Breuer, Jason Weinstein, the deputy assistant attorney general for the Criminal Division, resigned after the IG investigation. The report marked him as the highest-ranking DOJ employee in a position to stop the program, though Weinstein disputed that conclusion.

 Attorney General Eric Holder stated that those found responsible for roles in the operation "have been referred to the appropriate entities for review and consideration of potential personnel actions." The department said it could not reveal more details at this time.

 On Capitol Hill Thursday, lawmakers and the inspector general joined in assailing the entire operation as misguided and poorly supervised. The report details a "pattern of serious failures" with the program. No "serious question or concern" about the operation was raised by anyone responsible for the case in the U.S. attorney's office or Phoenix division of ATF, according to the report. Further, it states that investigators found no "persuasive evidence" that supervisors raised concerns about the safety risk or the delay in arresting people who were buying and trafficking these firearms. The report also criticizes flaws in Operation Wide Receiver, the Bush administration-era predecessor to Fast and Furious. The Fast and Furious program caught the attention of Congress and the rest of the country after weapons from Fast and Furious were found at the crime scene of murdered Border Patrol agent Brian Terry.

Title: US Withdrawal from WHO Temporarily, Biden's Pledge to Rejoin, and Global Covid-19 Updates

Article:

The United States is currently not a member of the World Health Organization (WHO), following the Trump administration's decision to withdraw from the global health body in May. The process of withdrawal will take a year, and Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden has pledged to reverse the decision should he win in November.

Dr. Anthony Fauci, the administration's top infectious disease expert, stated this week that the country is "still knee-deep in the first wave" of the Covid-19 pandemic, with over 131,000 deaths and infection numbers rising at a rate of around 50,000 per day. In a reversal of President Donald Trump's migration rhetoric, some border towns in northern Mexico are now trying to stop people crossing from the US, for fear they could spread the virus.

In Brazil, President Jair Bolsonaro has insisted he is "doing fine" after testing positive for Covid-19. Like Trump, Bolsonaro has been widely criticized for his lack of response to the disease, which has killed more people in Brazil than in any other country besides the US.

The WHO has acknowledged fresh evidence of airborne transmission of the virus, saying Covid-19 may spread more widely in the air than the organization previously suggested.

Covid-19 patients with mild symptoms could suffer serious brain disorders, according to neurologists who have studied 40 UK patients with complications ranging from brain inflammation to strokes.

The US government is attempting to claw back the $80 million it loaned to Planned Parenthood under the coronavirus aid program, following criticism from conservative lawmakers. However, Christian anti-abortion groups have also received millions in taxpayer-backed loans.

Some 5,600 fossil fuel companies have collectively accepted $3 billion in federal coronavirus aid amid the crisis, according to an analysis by Documented and ███.

Kanye West's company Yeezy LLC received between $2 million and $5 million in coronavirus aid loans, raising questions about conflict of interest, given the rapper and designer's ties to the Trump administration.

In other news, Mary Trump, Donald Trump's niece and Fred Trump's granddaughter, has written a book about the "malignantly dysfunctional" Trump family, detailing her fear and frustration with the Trump presidency.

The FBI claims that China is pursuing hundreds of Chinese nationals living in the US, trying to force dissidents and critics of the Beijing government to return home. In Hong Kong, the unofficial pro-democracy anthem Glory to Hong Kong has been banned in schools amid sweeping new national security laws imposed from Beijing.

More than 3.5 million people have been advised to evacuate in Japan, after torrential rains and flooding that have already claimed at least 58 lives.

Facebook boycott organizers are "disappointed" after a meeting with Mark Zuckerberg, in which the social network's CEO and other executives failed to commit to concrete solutions for addressing hate speech and misinformation on the platform.

Chechens across Europe are fearful following the killings of several dissidents and critics of the Chechen president, Ramzan Kadyrov. The latest victim is 43-year-old Mamikhan Umarov, who was shot dead in Vienna on Saturday.

Nine in ten Americans say racism and police brutality are problems in the country, according to a poll conducted by Opinium for ███, suggesting Trump is increasingly out of step with public opinion.

Ghislaine Maxwell, the socialite arrested last week on sex trafficking charges over her association with the late Jeffrey Epstein, has been photographed with numerous high-profile individuals, including Donald Trump, Bill Clinton, Kevin Spacey, and Princess Diana, as chronicled by a popular new Instagram account.

In a positive note, a team of young people in Paris is tending to the world's largest urban farm, growing up to 35 different varieties of fruit and vegetables without soil. The innovative approach to agriculture could be a solution to future food shortages.

Finally, the annual firefly festival in the Japanese town of Tatsuno was cancelled this year due to the coronavirus. However, that didn't stop the incandescent insects from showing up. The town's mayor, Yasuo Takei, says watching the spectacle in silence only makes it more poignant: "The brief shining of the light is so impressive, making me feel that I also have to live my best."

Title: House Passes Nonbinding War Powers Resolution to Restrict Presidential Actions Against Iran

Article:

The United States House of Representatives has approved a nonbinding war powers resolution that requires President Donald Trump to seek Congressional consent before engaging in new military action against Iran. The vote, which took place nearly a week after the U.S. drone strike that killed a top Iranian general, was mostly along party lines, with only three Republicans and one independent joining Democrats to pass the measure. Eight Democrats opposed it.

The resolution, sponsored by Rep. Elissa Slotkin (D-Mich.), a former CIA analyst who worked on Middle East policy, was written as a concurrent resolution, which is traditionally considered nonbinding and does not require the president's signature. The Senate could consider a similar measure, but one with the force of law, as early as next week. However, it is unclear if it has enough votes to clear the chamber.

The Trump administration officials maintain that the president already has the authority to take action against Iran under a 2002 war authorization passed by Congress in response to the September 11 attacks. The concerns touch on a years-long discussion over whether the president's war powers are outdated.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) said ahead of the resolution's passage, "We are taking this path because it does not require... a signature of the president of the United States. This is a statement of the Congress of the United States, and I will not have that statement be diminished by whether the president will veto it or not."

The White House has strongly opposed the House war powers measure, with White House Spokesman Hogan Gidley stating, "These Congressional actions are completely misguided... In fact, this ridiculous resolution is just another political move because, under well-established Supreme Court precedent, it's non-binding and lacks the force of law."

The concerns over the war powers measure come after briefings for lawmakers on Wednesday left many Democrats and some Republicans unhappy with a lack of transparency about what fueled the decision to strike the Iranian general. President Trump addressed the vote at a campaign rally Thursday night in Toledo, Ohio, and mocked the idea of consulting Congress while carrying out an operation like the killing of Soleimani.

Some Senate Republicans have expressed interest in recent days to support a similar measure in their chamber. Virginia Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine, who is sponsoring the war powers resolution, says he could bring up his measure for a vote as early as Tuesday. However, it may have to be coordinated with a potential trial if articles of impeachment are sent to the chamber beforehand. Sens. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) and Mike Lee (R-Utah) have already said they will support the measure, and Sens. Susan Collins (R-Maine) and Todd Young (R-Ind.) have also been in talks with Kaine about the legislation and could line up support.

Title: Bloomberg's Presidential Campaign and Ad Spending Plans Amidst Presidential Race

Article:

Presidential candidate Mike Bloomberg, a billionaire businessman and media mogul, has stated that if he does not win the Democratic presidential nomination, he will spend money to support the eventual nominee, contradicting President Trump's claim that Bloomberg would spend little on the Democratic candidate. In a tweet on Thursday, President Trump suggested that Bloomberg is using his rivals in the Democratic primary as a distraction for his own campaign.

Bloomberg, however, has repeatedly stated his intention to back the eventual nominee, regardless of whether he captures the nomination. In a statement to NBC News, Bloomberg's campaign manager, Kevin Sheekey, said, "Mike Bloomberg is either going to be the nominee or the most important person supporting the Democratic nominee for president. He is dedicated to getting Trump out of the White House."

Bloomberg, through a super PAC, has already spent $100 million on digital ads attacking President Trump in crucial general election battleground states such as Michigan, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, and Arizona. These ads, which do not feature Bloomberg beyond legally required disclaimers, are set to run through the end of the primary season, even if Bloomberg does not win the nomination.

In his tweet, Bloomberg also linked to a Mediaite story on a new TV commercial by Bloomberg that refers to an alleged incident in which President Trump verbally attacked military leaders in a Pentagon briefing. The narrator in the ad calls Trump "an erratic and out of control president."

Bloomberg initially flirted with a White House run early last year but decided against it in March, feeling he and former Vice President Joe Biden would split the center-left Democratic vote. However, in late November, with Biden battling other top-tier contenders, Bloomberg entered the race, citing concerns that none of the current candidates could defeat Trump in the 2020 election. He has already spent a quarter-billion dollars on ads for his White House bid.

Title: President Obama Vows to Move Forward with Executive Order on Immigration Reform

Article:

President Barack Obama has vowed to move forward with an executive order to ease immigration laws before the end of the year, disregarding warnings from Republican leaders that the move will strain his relationship with the incoming Republican-led Congress. The president stated that he would grant legal status to most of the estimated 11 million undocumented residents living in the U.S.

In an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation," Obama expressed his intention to address the country's immigration problems, stating, "I'd prefer, and still prefer, to see it done through Congress. But every day that I wait, we're misallocating resources, we're deporting people that shouldn't be deported, we're not deporting folks that are dangerous and need to be deported."

House Speaker John A. Boehner and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, both Republicans, have warned Obama against unilateral action on immigration. Senator John Barrasso, a Wyoming Republican, described the president's executive action on immigration as "like tossing a hand grenade" into his negotiations with the Republican-controlled Congress.

The immigration reform debate adds to the challenges lawmakers will face when Congress resumes this week following a wave of Republican victories in the midterm elections. Lawmakers will also grapple with the budget, tax measures, and the confirmation of New York federal prosecutor Loretta Lynch as the next attorney general.

Obama acknowledged the Democrats' widespread losses in the elections, stating, "We got beat." He added, "The buck stops right here, at my desk." Despite a slow but steady economic recovery, Obama noted that many Americans are still struggling and are frustrated with partisan paralysis in Washington.

In the lame-duck session, lawmakers will also consider Obama's request of $5.6 billion to fight the Islamic State terrorist army, including $1.6 billion associated with a U.S. military buildup to train and equip Iraqi forces. Obama emphasized that U.S. troops would be training and supporting Iraqi and Sunni tribal forces, but would not be engaging in combat operations.

As he risks a confrontation with Republican leaders over immigration, Obama argued that offering legal status and a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants was the only option because "we don't have the capacity to deport 11 million people." Obama insisted that his executive order does not have to be the last word on immigration reform, stating that Congress still has an opportunity to pass legislation that could replace whatever executive action he takes.

In defending his decision to use an executive order, Obama also cited the need to secure the border, which has been a focus of Republicans in the immigration debate. Republican lawmakers have been skeptical of Obama's commitment to border security in the immigration debate.

Title: Rick Wilson Advises GOP Silence on Clinton Email Scandal, Urges Strategic Approach

Article:

Rick Wilson, a national Republican message and media strategist, has offered advice to his colleagues in Congress, the conservative movement, and right-leaning opinion media regarding the ongoing Clinton email story. Wilson suggests that it is better for them to remain silent until they have a clear plan, rather than playing the story by what he terms as the "Clinton Rules."

Wilson argues that the media has been eager to support Hillary Clinton's presidential bid, but the email scandal has brought to light the Clinton's "slimy, predatory enterprise" and its "venal, sleazy, one-step-ahead-of-the-law hillbilly hustle." He suggests that the Clintons are stumbling towards political peril as the story unfolds, with potential legal and political implications for Clinton.

Wilson warns that the media is waiting for Republicans to make a mistake, and that an intemperate remark from a Republican could provide the perfect opportunity for the media to shift the focus away from the Clinton email scandal. He advises Republicans to maintain message discipline, focus on the broader implications of the email scandal, and avoid discussing social issues for a few days.

Wilson emphasizes the importance of having a plan, executing it with discipline, and proceeding against Clinton with a measured pace and tone. He suggests focusing on the national security risks posed by Clinton's email server, as well as the broader implications of the Clinton culture. Wilson encourages Republicans to use a bipartisan tone, reduce expectations, and vary their approach to avoid being demonized by the Clintons. He also advises Republicans to be persistent, serious, and smart in their approach.

Title: Lockdown Leaves Many LGBTQ Indians Hidden and Vulnerable in Homes Amidst Family Discrimination

Article:

The ongoing coronavirus lockdown in India has left many members of the LGBTQ community trapped with their families, leading to instances of physical assault, psychological torture, and widespread discrimination.

Kumar, a young gay man living in a town in northern India, was physically assaulted by his family after they discovered his secret. Shruta Neytra, co-founder of the LGBTQ online youth support group, Yaariyan, shared this information with the AFP news agency.

Kumar reached out to the group for help, but due to coronavirus restrictions on travel and movement, there was little anyone could do. Neytra stated, "We are hearing of so many cases where people are facing harassment and psychological torture by their families."

The colonial-era law banning gay sex was abolished in 2018, and transgender Indians have been legally recognized as a third gender since 2014. However, outside the big cities, LGBTQ individuals still face widespread discrimination and violence.

The lockdown, which began in March, has brought misery to millions, destroying migrant workers' livelihoods and driving many deeper into poverty. The restrictions have also left LGBTQ Indians, who are already living on the margins, vulnerable to further abuse, often at the hands of their own families.

For transgender woman Anjali Siroya, going to work and seeing friends has always been a lifeline, taking her away from the hostile environment of the Mumbai tenement flat she shares with her parents and brother. "They do not beat me anymore after I tried to run away once... but being with them 24/7 is still very traumatic," the 21-year-old told AFP.

As the pressure at home has grown, she has taken to Instagram to celebrate her gender identity with photographs of herself and vocal posts about the fight for equality. "I miss dressing up, putting on lipstick and earrings, and posing for selfies," she said. "I know this might sound silly to some people, but it was a way for me to express myself."

As LGBTQ Indians have increasingly turned to social media and online communities for support, many have also expressed a mounting urge to come out to their families. Seema, a bisexual sociology student in Delhi, told AFP that life under lockdown felt "lonely and claustrophobic."

"Everything I say about girls needs to be said in code," she said, describing how she hides her phone from her mother and grandparents to avoid being accidentally outed. With no room of her own, she said in an emailed interview that she was even unable to speak privately on the phone, forcing her into a life of constant subterfuge.

"I feel compelled to come out on some days," she said as she spoke of not being able to share her dreams of love and marriage with her family. However, she feared that any such move would make her family monitor her movements and further limit her freedom.

"I just want to say 'My wife and I'... instead of hesitating and always being scared that it'll slip out by mistake," she added.

LGBTQ activists have largely advised members of the community to do nothing until life returns to normal. Jo, digital editor for online forum Gaysi, who goes by one name, stated, "As an out and proud trans person, I would never tell another person not to live their truth. But right now, it is simply too dangerous to come out of the closet."

Even those who took the leap and found some acceptance say the aftermath has been complicated and stressful. "I never expected to tell my father I am bisexual, it was nice seeing him react well to it," Tina, a 25-year-old artist, told AFP.

However, as the lockdown wore on, subsequent interactions revealed that her father was "not entirely comfortable," she said. "Earlier, I didn't spend much time thinking about how my parents would respond; now every possibility has become more real," she said. "I do not know how my mum will react if she knows. I do not think she will ask me to leave home, but I am not 100 percent sure."

Title: President Trump Attributes Migrant Child Deaths at Border to Democratic Immigration Policies

Article:

President Donald Trump has attributed the recent deaths of two migrant children at the U.S.-Mexico border to the immigration policies of congressional Democrats. In a series of tweets on Saturday, the President stated that the deaths were a result of liberal immigration policies that encourage foreign families to undertake the dangerous journey to the United States illegally.

The President tweeted, "Any deaths of children or others at the Border are strictly the fault of the Democrats and their pathetic immigration policies that allow people to make the long trek thinking they can enter our country illegally. They can’t. If we had a Wall, they wouldn’t even try!"

This week, House Democrats ordered Homeland Security officials to preserve all evidence related to the two deaths this month of Guatemalan children who crossed the U.S.-Mexico border with their parents. An 8-year-old boy, Felipe Gomez Alonzo, died on Christmas Eve after six days in Border Patrol custody. He had been treated for a cold and fever at a hospital and was released, but was readmitted hours later and died soon thereafter.

His mother in Guatemala stated that the boy's father brought the child on the trip to the U.S. in the belief that gaining illegal entry would be easier with a child. Earlier this month, a 7-year-old Guatemalan girl died after being arrested for crossing the border illegally with her father. Border Patrol agents twice managed to revive her after she fell ill, but she later suffered a heart attack and liver and respiratory failure at a hospital.

President Trump stated that the two children "were very sick before they were given over to Border Patrol." The President also tweeted, "The father of the young girl said it was not their fault, he hadn’t given her water in days. Border Patrol needs the Wall and it will all end. They are working so hard & getting so little credit!"

The circumstances surrounding the deaths of these children are currently under investigation by House Democrats. It is unclear at this time what evidence they are seeking to preserve or the specifics of their investigation.

Title: Christie and Clinton Share the Spotlight at Clinton Global Initiative Event

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, a Republican, is headlining the closing ceremonies of Bill Clinton's annual international forum in Chicago. The event, titled "Cooperation and Collaboration: A Conversation on Leadership," is a product of an unlikely partnership between Clinton and Christie that has developed over the past four years.

In 2009, Clinton campaigned against Christie during his re-election bid, but sources close to both men say they have since developed a friendship. The two have met, traded war stories, and spoken on the phone.

Clinton, a former president, and Christie, a first-term governor, share similar backgrounds, having both served as prosecutors. Clinton was the attorney general of Arkansas, while Christie served as the U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey.

The unpredictable Christie was a key fundraiser and campaigner for Mitt Romney, Obama's GOP challenger in 2012. In return, Christie delivered the keynote speech at the Republican National Convention in Tampa.

Following Superstorm Sandy in 2012, Christie established a bipartisan working relationship with President Obama, which angered some GOP stalwarts. Now, as Christie faces re-election and is being touted as a possible contender for Clinton's old office on Pennsylvania Avenue, Christie is sharing the spotlight with him.

Representatives of both men declined to comment for this story, saying Clinton and Christie will speak when they take the stage at today's Clinton Global Initiative event.

Insiders say the friendship between Clinton and Christie started with Clinton taking note of Christie's political acumen even as he campaigned against Christie. Despite Clinton's speeches painting Christie as hostile toward women, the middle class, and working people, Clinton noticed Christie's tough talk and skill at sparring with reporters.

In 2010, when the two wound up a few rows apart at the Big East basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden, Clinton arranged for a quick chat with Christie. This led to a meeting at Clinton's post-presidential office in Harlem, where the two talked politics and public policy.

For a governor who constantly reminds people he can work with leaders of all stripes, the appearance today and the friendship with Clinton are worth the political risks.

"This is a stature thing," a Christie source said. "It burnishes his [Christie's] bipartisan credentials and it shows the governor is a serious guy. He's talking about leadership with Clinton. That's a big deal."

As for Clinton's efforts to destroy Christie during the 2009 election, a Christie source said, "The campaign's over."

Title: Supreme Court's Religious Freedom Cases Show Potential Shift in Interpretation

Article:

The Supreme Court's defense of religious freedom may be experiencing a shift in interpretation, according to some legal experts. In a series of cases over the past year, the high court has prioritized preventing discrimination over protecting religion, from same-sex marriage to abortion and contraception.

Justice Samuel Alito, in an obscure order issued on the last day of the recent term, highlighted this trend. By refusing to consider a family-owned pharmacy's objection to a Washington state regulation forcing it to stock and sell emergency contraceptives, Alito warned that the court was sending an "ominous sign."

In his statement, Alito expressed concern that if this trend continues, those who value religious freedom may have cause for great concern. The court's recent actions, he suggested, could affect an upcoming case involving a Missouri church's effort to qualify for state playground funds and potentially another challenge to the pharmacy rule.

Under the leadership of Chief Justices William Rehnquist and John Roberts, the court generally has carved out protections for religious groups and individuals. In recent years, it ruled in favor of a Muslim prisoner who sought to wear a beard, a Muslim woman denied a job because she wore a headscarf, and a tiny Arizona church that protested municipal restrictions on street signs.

However, after ruling for the craft giant Hobby Lobby in the 2014 contraceptives case, the court did not side with religious non-profits or the government this year in similar cases, instead sending them back for further appellate review. It struck down Texas restrictions on abortion clinics and, on the final day of the term, refused to hear the pharmacy's petition.

The case was brought by the Stormans family, which operates Ralph's Thriftway in Olympia, Wash. The family had what conservatives considered a slam-dunk case against a unique state regulation that pharmacies must fill prescriptions for contraceptives, including morning-after pills that prevent a fertilized egg from reaching the uterus.

"Ralph’s has made a strong case...that the regulations here are improperly designed to stamp out religious objectors," Alito wrote in his dissent, joined by Roberts and Justice Clarence Thomas. In his final footnote, Alito invited another legal challenge.

Kristen Waggoner, who represented the pharmacy through a federal district court victory and an appeals court defeat, says it's too soon to assume the court has shifted on religious freedom cases. However, she notes the refusal to hear the Stormans case "does cause you to wonder."

"We're seeing the red flags," Waggoner says. "The risk is Americans will no longer have the right to live consistent with their faith without punishment from the government."

Some defenders of religious freedom do not share Alito's fear for the future. Eric Rassbach, deputy general counsel at the Becket Fund for Religious Liberty, says the court has been responsive to religious liberty claims in most of the cases in recent years. "I don’t see a reason to think that the court is going to become deaf to religious claims," Rassbach says.

Douglas Laycock, a religious liberty expert at the University of Virginia School of Law, agrees that the risk arises when core issues important to liberals are at stake, such as women's access to all methods of birth control. "The liberal justices are willing to protect religious liberty when their more favored issues are not at stake, or perhaps when the case is clear enough," Laycock says.

However, when other interests such as preventing discrimination against women, gays and lesbians, or minorities are involved, the court's latest responses please liberal groups. "Religious liberty doesn’t give you a right to impose your views on others," Louise Melling, deputy legal director at the American Civil Liberties Union, says. She sees the court's recent actions as "part of a broader move to advance equality."

Many conservatives are wary that the court—stripped of Scalia's influence and vote, and often controlled by the more mercurial Justice Anthony Kennedy—increasingly may favor government regulators over religious believers. "What we’re seeing is a sort of shift around social norms concerning sexuality," says Jay Richards, assistant research professor at The Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C. "Kennedy is the best Geiger counter. He’s a very good instrument for measuring that."

The next test will come in the fall, when the justices consider a Missouri church's challenge to being denied state funds for playground resurfacing. A second case involving the pharmacy regulations also could be headed their way in the future, along with lawsuits from merchants who refuse to participate in same-sex weddings. "There's more and more of these cases coming up," Waggoner says. "This is not over."

Title: Russia Imposes Import Ban on Food Products from Western Countries in Response to Sanctions

Article:

Russia has announced a one-year ban on imports of meat, fish, milk and milk products, fruit and vegetables from the United States, the European Union, Australia, Canada, and Norway. The decision, announced by Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev, was made in response to sanctions imposed by the West over the crisis in Ukraine.

The ban includes potential restrictions on Western carriers flying over Russia on flights to and from Asia, as well as possible restrictions on imports of planes, navy vessels, and cars. However, Medvedev stated that the government will realistically assess its own production potential before making a decision.

The latest round of sanctions against Russia, imposed by the EU last week, targeted entire sectors of the Russian economy for the first time. The U.S. and the EU have accused Russia, which annexed Ukraine's Crimean Peninsula in March, of fomenting tensions in eastern Ukraine by supplying arms and expertise to a pro-Moscow insurgency. As a result, asset freezes and loan bans have been imposed on a number of individuals and companies.

Medvedev argued that the ban would benefit Russian farmers, who have struggled to compete with Western products. However, experts have expressed doubts about the ability of local producers to fill the gap left by the ban, as Russia's agricultural sector continues to suffer from poor efficiency and a lack of funds.

Analysts predict that the ban will further speed up inflation, particularly in the largest and most prosperous cities such as Moscow, where imported food fills an estimated 60-70 percent of the market. In 2013, the EU's agricultural exports to Russia totaled 11.8 billion euros ($15.8 billion), while food and agricultural imports from the U.S. amounted to $1.3 billion last year, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Medvedev expressed hope that the sanctions would make the West revise its policy and stop trying to pressure Russia with sanctions. "Until the last moment we hoped that our partners would understand that sanctions only lead to a deadlock, and no one needs them," he said. "We hope our partners will put a pragmatic economic approach above bad policy considerations, and they will start thinking instead of trying to scare us."

Title: Pope Francis' Address to Congress: A Critique of Republican Policies and Agenda

Article:

Pope Francis' address to the United States Congress on Thursday, September 24, 2015, was a critique of several Republican policies and an implicit rebuke to the do-nothing, obstructionist GOP agenda. The speech, which was not overtly political, highlighted five key moments that made conservatives uncomfortable.

1. Dorothy Day Shout-out: Francis commended four Americans in particular, whom he held up as examples of pursuing the common good: Abraham Lincoln, Martin Luther King Jr., Trappist monk Thomas Merton, and Dorothy Day. Day, a radical social activist, is noted for founding the Catholic Worker Movement during the Great Depression and urging Catholics to form small, autonomous communities to lead simple lives devoted to the gospel and serving the poor.

2. Abortion Switcheroo: In defiance of the specific guidance not to score political points, congressional conservatives leapt to their feet when Francis delivered the Vatican's standard coded language about abortion. However, they were taken aback when he immediately followed that with a call for the global abolition of the death penalty.

3. Arms Deals: Speaking of death, what about all those arms deals the Republicans are so fond of? Francis questioned who is selling the bad guys all these weapons and why, stating that "money... is drenched in blood."

4. Reminding the GOP We're All Foreigners: As in his speech at the White House on Tuesday, Francis felt the need to remind those who are making intolerance toward immigrants their political stock-in-trade that they, like him, are likely the descendants of immigrant families.

5. Confronting the Climate Naysayers: Francis made it clear that combating climate change, development, and technology can coexist. He explicitly rebuked many conservative critics of his climate change encyclical "Laudato si," who claim that he is anti-commerce and wants to stifle development or reduce the world to subsistence-level farming to stop climate change.

In one of the most moving passages of his speech, Francis said, "Let us seek for others the same possibilities which we seek for ourselves. Let us help others to grow, as we would like to be helped ourselves."

Patricia Miller, author of "Good Catholics: The Battle Over Abortion in the Catholic Church," commented on the speech, stating that Francis' voice of faith was likely a point of contention for conservatives.

Title: El Chapo Escapes Mexican Prison Through Tunnel

 Article:

 Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, Mexico's most notorious drug kingpin, has escaped from prison through a mile-long tunnel, authorities confirmed. The closed-circuit video footage shows Guzman calmly and easily evading surveillance cameras and leaving his monitoring bracelet behind before his escape.

 According to Mexican Interior Minister Miguel Ángel Osorio Chong, Guzman's cell was under 24-hour surveillance, but the system had two blind spots for privacy: the toilet and the shower. Guzman reportedly used the shower's blind spot to slip through a hole under the shower and escape.

 The United States and Mexico are exchanging intelligence and providing technical support in the manhunt for Guzman. Reports claiming authorities from the two countries are not working together are false, according to Deputy DEA Administrator Jack Riley.

 Guzman, also known as "Shorty," has a history of elaborate escapes. In 2001, he managed to break free while hiding in a laundry cart. It took authorities 13 years to catch him. The Sinaloa cartel, which Guzman heads, moves drugs by land, air, and sea, including cargo aircraft, private aircraft, buses, fishing vessels, and even submarines.

 The cartel has become so powerful that Forbes magazine listed Guzman in its 2009 list of "self-made" billionaires. Guzman's estimated fortune at the time was $1 billion. Chicago has labeled him "Public Enemy No. 1."

 The Sinaloa cartel's influence extends globally, supplying much of the marijuana, cocaine, and heroin sold on the streets of the United States. It is likely that prison workers helped Guzman break out, and it is believed that the cartel had spent years infiltrating Mexico's prison system to plan the escape.

 Mexican authorities have released a recent photograph of Guzman, showing him with a shaved head and face, but without his trademark mustache. The tunnel began with a 50-by-50-centimeter (20-by-20-inch) opening inside the shower of Guzman's cell and ended inside a half-built house. The tunnel was complete with lighting, ventilation, and a modified motorcycle on tracks.

Title: Senator Ted Cruz Introduces Terrorist Refugee Infiltration Prevention Act

Article:

Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas), a Republican presidential candidate, has introduced the Terrorist Refugee Infiltration Prevention Act of 2015. The bill aims to temporarily bar refugees from countries with significant terrorist presence, including Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen.

The bill, which is constitutionally sound and common-sense, is a response to the ongoing threat of radical Islamic terrorism and the infiltration of terrorists among the flood of refugees entering Europe and the United States. The bill specifically names these five countries as sources of potential terror and empowers the State Department to identify and designate additional countries as potential sources of terror.

The bill is temporary, sunsetting after three years, and allows for Congress to reevaluate the global situation and make necessary adjustments or let the law expire. It also allows a narrow exception to the refugee ban in cases of genocide victims, such as the Yazidis and certain Christian sects, including Assyrians. This exception would only be available for the severest cases of persecution and would require a high bar of proof.

Senator Cruz emphasized that the bill is a small, first step toward protecting America from the threat of terrorist infiltration. He stated, "The fact of the matter is that no Christian or Yazidi has systematically executed concert-goers while shouting 'Allahu Akbar.' Pretending all the refugees are equally likely or unlikely to commit terrorist acts prevents us from helping those we can while protecting ourselves from a real threat."

The bill is a response to the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, which were claimed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). Cruz stated, "This is a small, first step toward protecting America, and I will never apologize for defending this nation."

Title: Protestors in Kentucky Hang Effigy of Governor Andy Beshear Outside State Capitol

Article:

Protestors in Kentucky, organized by Take Back Kentucky, hung an effigy of Democratic Governor Andy Beshear outside the state capitol during a demonstration on Sunday. The protest was intended to "celebrate freedom and to fight back against the unconstitutional shutdown over the coronavirus," according to a Facebook post.

The around-100 people present began by celebrating the Second Amendment, but the rally eventually turned into a call against coronavirus restrictions. Protestors marched to the governor's house shouting "Come out Andy," according to videos posted on Twitter. They later returned to the state capitol, where "several people" participated in hanging the effigy from a tree, the Courier Journal's Sarah Ladd reported.

The effigy had a picture of Beshear's face on it and a message that read "sic temper tyrannis," a Latin phrase that translates to "thus always to tyrants." The effigy was taken down shortly afterwards, according to the Courier Journal.

The protestor's actions caused swift backlash from members of both parties. Senate Majority Leader and Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell condemned the effigy in a statement posted on Twitter Sunday evening. McConnell, a strong defender of the First Amendment, believed Americans have the right to peacefully protest, but the actions demonstrated at the protest went too far.

Republican Secretary of State of the Commonwealth of Kentucky Michael G. Adams also tweeted, "This is disgusting and I condemn it wholeheartedly. The words of John Wilkes Booth have no place in the Party of Lincoln."

Many others condemned the effigy hanging, the Courier Journal reported. Democratic Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer tweeted, "On Memorial Day weekend, as we honor those who gave their lives for our country, & think of the small sacrifices we make to protect our community from a pandemic, we must condemn this vile act. When we share science, keep each other healthy & safe, freedom will follow."

Kentucky House Democrats also issued a lengthy statement against the effigy, calling it "beyond reprehensible."

Title: Biden Campaign Avoids Unscripted Interviews, According to Media Reporter Joe Concha

Article:

Joe Concha, media reporter for The Hill, stated on Friday that presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden has only been challenged by the media regarding matters on race relations. In an interview on "Fox & Friends," Concha claimed that Biden's campaign staff is attempting to avoid similar situations following his controversial comments during an interview with urban hip-hop host Charlamagne Tha God on "The Breakfast Club."

During the interview last month, Biden made remarks that sparked controversy when he said, "If you have a problem figuring out whether you’re for me or Trump, then you ain’t black." Biden later walked back the comments, stating, "I shouldn’t have been so cavalier."

According to Concha, Biden has not held a press conference in 77 days, and his campaign aims to present a "scripted or homogenized Biden" to the American public. Concha argued that the campaign wants to avoid the "extemporaneous Joe Biden" due to his tendency to make statements that may be perceived as problematic or out of touch.

Biden currently leads President Donald Trump in the race for the White House, as majorities express concerns about racism, unemployment, and the coronavirus's impact on the country's stability, according to the latest Fox News Poll. Biden supporters are more likely to cite fear of Trump winning as their motivation for voting, while Trump supporters are more likely to express enthusiasm for the incumbent president.

The article does not provide information on the specifics of the race between Biden and Trump or the current polling numbers. Additionally, it does not include any statements or opinions from the Biden campaign regarding their media strategy.

Title: Facebook Takes Steps to Combat Deepfakes Ahead of Presidential Election

Article:

Facebook is taking steps to combat deepfakes, manipulated videos created using artificial intelligence (AI) to deceive users. The social media giant is banning videos that are "edited or synthesized" to mislead users but will allow parody and satire. The move comes as concerns grow that deepfakes could be used to mislead voters, similar to the way fabricated news stories influenced public opinion in 2016.

Deepfakes are videos doctored using cutting-edge AI technology to distort reality. The technology, which analyzes real images to generate fake ones, is a growing form of disinformation, and social media platforms have been struggling with how to deal with it. Facebook and other tech companies are sponsoring a "Deepfake Detection Challenge" to encourage AI researchers to develop new ways to automatically detect doctored videos.

The dangers of manipulated recordings
The ability to create fake videos or manipulate existing videos has been around for decades, but typically required some software or skill. In recent years, tools have become popular on social media and elsewhere that allow anyone to manipulate images and video, though this footage usually appears obviously manipulated. Today, powerful new technologies are making it cheaper, faster, and easier to produce deepfakes that are "nearly indistinguishable from reality," says Hao Li, associate professor of computer science at the University of Southern California.

There are also simpler but still effective ways to deceive social media users called "cheap fakes," which typically involve editing videos to spread disinformation or propaganda. Digitally manipulated video is dangerous because we tend to have faith in what we see, Li says. "It's a real problem, and it's something that is advancing really quickly," he says. "Regulators and lawmakers are not catching up with this kind of technology."

Facebook's new deepfake policy is too narrow, says Hany Farid, a computer science professor at University of California, Berkeley, specializing in digital forensics. Under the policy, Facebook would not prohibit videos using lower-tech methods of spreading disinformation, such as last year's video of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, which was edited to make it seem as though she was slurring her speech.

Rachel Thomas, director of the Center for Applied Data Ethics at University of San Francisco, expects "cheap fakes" and the more sophisticated deepfakes to proliferate ahead of the presidential election as part of shadowy campaigns to sway public opinion. Imagining a fake Donald Trump or a fake Joe Biden simulated saying a racial slur, then imagining how quickly those videos would spread on Facebook or YouTube, Thomas says, "The stakes are very high. This kind of misinformation can have a big impact."

When used to target elected officials or political candidates, doctored video can erode trust. Nearly two-thirds of Americans recently surveyed by Pew Research said altered images and videos caused a great deal of confusion in understanding the basic facts of current events.

How can you tell if the video you're watching is a deepfake?
"That is becoming increasingly difficult. The technology behind fake videos is improving almost on a continuous basis," says Siwei Lyu, computer science professor at the State University of New York at Albany and a member of the Deepfake Detection Challenge's advisory group. He recommends "psychological preparedness," as in being constantly on the alert for videos, images, and audio that have been altered.

"Whenever you see an interesting video showing something that is bizarre or exceptional, a certain vigilance should be raised," he says. Examine the video carefully before sharing it on social media. Is the video low-resolution or grainy? Is it a single person talking in the video? Is it relatively short, say 30 seconds or 60 seconds long?

Is the lighting strange or the face discolored or blurry? Is there blurriness between the face and neck or between the face and the hair? Is the sound not synced with the images? Some of the other tell-tale signs discernible to the naked eye, according to Subbarao Kambhampati, a computer science professor at Arizona State University, include different-sized eyes or ill-formed teeth, or more than two eyes, or inconsistencies in the background of the video.

But, says Kambhampati, the rapid improvements in deepfake technology means that we will soon have to rely on AI techniques to detect what the human eye can't. "There is not a 100% foolproof way of identifying deepfakes, not even for AI researchers," Thomas says. "Detection is always going to be an arms race. As people develop more accurate detection algorithms, fakers will develop even more sophisticated frauds."

There are non-technical ways to sniff out a deepfake, just like other forms of disinformation. Ask yourself: Who is the person publishing this information? Is this person reliable? What else has this person posted? Are the claims in the post backed up by sources you trust? When in doubt, turn to nonpartisan fact-checkers who've spent hours, sometimes days, tracking down accurate information, Farid says.

"You never want to jump to a conclusion one way or another, you never want to say: I looked at this and I'm sure it's real or I looked at this and I'm sure it's fake," he says. "The best you can really hope to do is to say: You know what? I should be careful here because I'm not sure, and then research it."

Li says his company, Pinscreen, will demonstrate for attendees of the World Economic Forum in Davos how to livestream fake video. He says it's part of an effort to raise awareness of the need for technologies that root out deepfakes. "In real-time, you can reenact yourself as Will Smith or some celebrity or a politician. You can be George Bush," he says. "The results are very convincing."

Title: Trump's Afghanistan Speech Draws Criticism from Right-Wing Supporters for Shift Away from "America First" Policy

Article:

President Donald Trump's speech on Afghanistan on Monday night was met with criticism from his right-wing supporters, who felt that the president had deviated from his campaign promise of limiting American intervention abroad and focusing on nation-building at home. The speech, which announced an increase in troops for the 16-year-long war, was seen as a return to the "same old fare" that Americans had rejected in November.

Conservative commentator Ann Coulter, who had been an enthusiastic supporter of Trump during the campaign, expressed her disappointment in a tweet, stating, "It doesn't matter who you vote for. The military-industrial complex wins. The only difference: GOP presidents pronounce 'Pakistan' correctly."

Fox News Radio's Todd Starnes accused the president of changing his campaign promise from "America First" to "Afghanistan First." Other right-wingers also reacted negatively to the speech, noting the contrast between Trump's rhetoric on the campaign trail and the new plan.

Radio host Stefan Molyneux contrasted Trump's speech with statements he had made on Twitter on Afghanistan before. Filmmaker and author Mike Cernovich sarcastically offered his congratulations to "President McMaster" and "General Jared," referring to Trump's national security adviser and senior adviser respectively.

Even moderate conservatives struggled to drum up enthusiasm for Trump's policy. Right-leaning Washington Post reporter Robert Costa gave a lukewarm reception to the plan, tweeting, "This is a speech wrapped in layers of non-interventionist rhetoric, sprinkled with Queens and 'Patton'-type bravado, delivered gently." Costa noted the contrast between some of the rhetoric from Trump and the plan itself, tweeting, "Trump is echoing many of the points Bannon made behind the scenes. But he has gone along with a version of McMaster-Mattis plan."

Adam Shaw is a ███ politics reporter based in New York. Follow Adam on Twitter: @AdamShawNY.

Title: Trump's Immigration Stance Remains Unclear as Campaign Muddies Position

Article:

The position of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on immigration has become increasingly unclear, with contradictory statements from the candidate and his campaign in recent weeks. While Trump's stance on immigration was never extensively detailed beyond calls for a border wall and a tough enforcement policy, his recent statements have further obscured his position, which he is set to address in a major speech in Arizona on Wednesday.

A year ago, Trump's stated position on deportations involved the removal of all undocumented immigrants and their family members, including U.S. citizens by birth. This hardline stance, which was popular among Republican primary voters, has been softened in the general election context, with Trump expressing openness to a "touch back" policy, where undocumented immigrants who are deported can re-enter and be put on a path to legalization. However, his campaign manager has ruled out this option.

On birthright citizenship, Republican vice presidential nominee Mike Pence stated on CNN that the issue is a subject for the future. Trump himself has also expressed contradictory views on softening his stance on immigration, only to reverse himself a few days later and suggest a hardening of his position.

Policy experts have expressed a desire for clarity on Trump's immigration policies, with Jacinta Ma of the National Immigration Forum Action Fund stating, "We would really like [Trump] to be more clear about the immigration policies that he’s talking about." Ma added, "The expectation should be that, as president, he should be able to articulate the policies in a clear manner so that we understand what... he wants to do in terms of the direction of the country as it relates to immigration policy."

Experts are skeptical that Trump can provide such clarity, given his past statements and positions on immigration. Ben Johnson of the American Immigration Lawyers Association stated, "A lot of what [Trump] is saying is either completely wrong or completely contradictory. I don’t see a way out for him on this issue unless he makes a really significant, clear change in [his] policy position because so much of the language he’s been using so far has just been unworkable and broadly opposed by the majority of the American people."

Trump's supporters may offer some wiggle room for his immigration stance, as they seem to prioritize the construction of a border wall above other immigration policies. However, with Trump having run for 14 months as an anti-immigrant, "law and order" candidate, any moderation of his views may not be enough to sway voters at this point in the campaign.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Threatens to Ignore Senate Bills in Response to Filibuster Rule Change Threat

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner, a Republican from Ohio, joined Senate Republicans in their ongoing battle to prevent Democrats from limiting filibusters on Thursday. Boehner's threat signifies an escalation of the partisan fight that has been brewing in the Senate for weeks.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat from Nevada, has indicated that he may use a simple majority vote to alter filibuster rules when the new Congress convenes in January. This move, which usually requires a two-thirds vote to change Senate rules, would allow Democrats to amend filibuster rules without GOP support, a prospect that has angered Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican from Kentucky, and other Republicans.

With Democrats set to control the White House and Senate, while Republicans will lead only the House, the Republican party is reportedly making efforts to retain as much power as possible. The Democrats will control the new Senate 55-45, including one Democratic-leaning independent.

Boehner criticized Reid's plan, stating, "The threat [Reid's plan] is clearly designed to marginalize Senate Republicans and their constituents while greasing the skids for controversial, partisan measures." He added, "Any bill that reaches a Republican-led House based on Senate Democrats' heavy-handed power play would be dead on arrival."

The rules change would not take effect until the new Congress begins in January, but Boehner suggested that it could poison the atmosphere even sooner, "at a time when cooperation on Capitol Hill is critical."

Currently, congressional leaders are negotiating deficit-cutting measures to avoid the so-called fiscal cliff of big tax increases and deep spending cuts scheduled to begin in January unless lawmakers find a way to avert them.

Minority parties in the Senate use filibusters, parliamentary delays, to slow or kill legislation. These can only be ended by 60 votes, a margin neither party can achieve without some cooperation from the other side. Democrats argue that Republicans are abusing filibusters by resorting to them too frequently, while Republicans claim they are blocked from presenting amendments by Democrats.

Reid's plan would forbid the use of filibusters when a bill is initially being brought to the Senate floor for debate and require filibustering senators to be physically present on the Senate floor, a practice that has been long-abandoned.

In response to Boehner's threat, Adam Jentleson, a spokesman for Reid, stated, "It is a shame to see Speaker Boehner join Sen. McConnell's desperate attempt to double down in the status quo of Republican-led gridlock in Washington."

The battle has prompted numerous sharp exchanges on the Senate floor in recent days between Reid and McConnell. Neither side has ruled out negotiating a solution to the dispute.

Title: Trump's Election Victory and the Pursuit of Obamacare Repeal

Article:

The 2016 presidential election results have shown a significant shift in the political landscape, with Donald Trump's victory over Hillary Clinton. Despite many commentators, including some who predicted Trump's win, underestimating his electoral prospects, the outcome has paved the way for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare).

According to the first major post-election voter survey, 74% of Republicans expressed a desire to repeal the Affordable Care Act when Donald Trump takes office. This sentiment is not limited to the Republican party, as a majority of Americans also want to be rid of the law. In late October, Gallup reported that 51% of Americans favored repealing Obamacare. A week before the election, Rasmussen reported that a majority of voters wanted changes in Obamacare, with more calling for its outright repeal.

The media's response to the repeal of Obamacare has been met with a wave of skepticism and resistance. The Washington Post warns that Donald Trump will face a "rude awakening" over Obamacare, while the Los Angeles Times declares that "repealing Obamacare will be almost impossible." Politico has even gone so far as to claim that "Obamacare defenders vow 'total war.'"

However, the media's pessimism may be misplaced. The GOP will have control of both the presidency and Congress, and they have shown in the past that they can repeal parts of Obamacare without a filibuster-proof majority in the Senate. In 2015, the GOP used the budget maneuver, reconciliation, to pass H.R.3762, a bill that would have eliminated the individual and employer mandates, many of its taxes, and phased out its subsidies. Although President Obama vetoed the bill, Speaker of the House Paul Ryan stated that the GOP had shown a "clear path to repealing Obamacare without 60 votes in the Senate."

In 2018, at least 6 of the 48 Democrat Senators who will retain their seats after January must face reelection in red states where the voters will not reward them for obstructing repeal. These vulnerable Democrats may well be willing to cooperate with the Republicans in breaking a filibuster.

Even if these red state Democrats remain intransigent, the worst elements of Obamacare can still be repealed by sidestepping a filibuster. The GOP leadership can utilize the same budget maneuver, reconciliation, to repeal parts of the law.

Conspicuously absent from the discussion is any discussion of which provisions of the President's "signature domestic achievement" are supported by the 60.3 million voters who cast their ballots for Trump, the majority of people living in the red states that cover most of the electoral map. The answer to that question, oddly enough, appears to be of little interest to the media, the anti-Trump rioters, or the thumb-suckers of the Snowflake Rebellion.
