Nonetheless, last Tuesday's exit polls have a story to tell about Obamacare for anyone willing to listen: "Voters feeling that the law went too far are breaking decisively for Trump, 80% to 13%." In flyover country, we call this a mandate.

Title: Divergent Approaches: Obama and GOP Focus on Minimum Wage and Obamacare, Respectively

Article:

In a clear demonstration of contrasting priorities, the White House and congressional Republicans have taken different approaches in the ongoing election year. The Obama administration has shifted its focus towards economic and income-equality issues, while the GOP remains centered on the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) and its impact across the nation.

In his weekly address, President Obama reiterated his call for a minimum wage increase from the current $7.25 to $10.10 for all Americans. He highlighted his recent executive action to implement a pay raise for federal contractors as part of his "opportunity agenda."

However, in this week's GOP address, Representative Tom Rooney of Florida did not mention the president's minimum wage push or related issues. Instead, he focused solely on Obamacare.

The minimum wage increase for all Americans is a significant component of President Obama's "opportunity agenda," and unlike other parts of this agenda, it requires congressional approval. In his address, President Obama stated, "Raising the minimum wage wouldn't just raise their wages—its effect would lift wages for about 28 million Americans. It would lift millions of Americans out of poverty and help millions more work their way out of poverty without requiring a single dollar in new taxes or spending."

Republicans, on the other hand, are relying on the continued emergence of Obamacare-related issues between now and November, hoping to increase their majority in the House and potentially capture the Senate. Representative Rooney highlighted instances of constituents losing access to their primary care physicians and specialists due to changes in their health plans.

In his address, Rooney stated, "This goes well beyond a glitch or a pocketbook issue. This is a breach of faith. The president's promises have proven false for working families, and now they are proving false for our seniors as well." He also called for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, despite previous attempts to do so having failed more than 40 times in the past.

The president and fellow Democrats aim to make the minimum wage and the broader issue of income inequality a top concern leading into the fall elections. Republicans, conversely, are banking on the persistence of Obamacare-related issues to bolster their position in the upcoming elections.

Title: Senate Faces Constitutional Obligation as Obama's Nominees Face Obstruction from Republicans

Article:

The United States Senate is facing a significant constitutional obligation as President Barack Obama's nominees for key positions, including the Secretary of Labor, Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Consumer Financial Protection Bureau director, and the National Labor Relations Board, face obstruction from Republican senators. The Senate's approval or rejection of these nominations could potentially impact the functioning of these agencies and the broader democratic process.

The Senate is expected to deliberate on these nominations in July. If the Republicans continue to block "yes" or "no" votes on Obama's executive and judicial nominees, the majority may be forced to revisit Senate rules to put an end to the Republican efforts to subvert the Senate's constitutional duty to provide advice and consent.

The nominee for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Richard Cordray, is a notable example of this obstruction. The CFPB was established as part of the Wall Street reform law to protect consumers of financial products. Despite the CFPB's purpose to safeguard consumers from financial products like mortgages to credit cards, Republicans have refused to confirm Cordray. In fact, Republicans have stated they will not confirm anyone to run the CFPB, aiming to render the agency ineffective as intended by law.

The Republican obstinacy is equally apparent in the president's nominees for the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), an independent agency responsible for protecting workers' rights. A hearing on these nominees this month showed no signs of a thaw in the Republican resistance. As a result, Cordray and some current NLRB members had to be appointed through recess appointments.

A recent decision by three Republican-appointed judges of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has further complicated the situation. This decision, which goes against decades of precedent, argues that the president does not have the power to make recess appointments. This decision is part of a pattern in which the D.C. Circuit has blocked Wall Street reforms, undermined labor rights, and rolled back environmental protections.

Initially, there were four vacancies on the 11-member court. Although Republicans allowed one of these vacancies to be filled last month, they are attempting to prevent the president from filling the remaining three and restoring balance to the D.C. Circuit. Republicans are aware that when senior judges, who handle a reduced caseload, are counted, this court still is dominated by Republican appointees. In a desperate effort to maintain this dominance, the latest underhanded tactic from Republican senators amounts to a 'pre-emptive filibuster'—an attempt to eliminate the three remaining vacant judgeships on the court to prevent Obama from exercising his constitutional obligation.

Title: Trump Transition Team Accelerates Activity, Deploys "Landing Parties" to Federal Agencies

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump's transition team has stepped up its efforts this week, deploying "landing parties" to federal agencies responsible for national security and reportedly offering the first major appointment of the new administration. On Thursday, visits to the National Security Council, Departments of Defense, Justice, and State were made to lay the groundwork for the handover in January.

According to The Associated Press, citing an anonymous senior Trump official, Trump has offered the post of White House national security adviser to retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, a former Defense Intelligence Agency chief. The status of Gen. Flynn's acceptance of the offer was unclear as of Thursday evening.

Trump held numerous interviews at Trump Tower in New York with potential Cabinet members and advisers, and met with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Vice President-elect Mike Pence met with leaders of both parties on Capitol Hill.

Following a "very candid" meeting with Abe, the Japanese Prime Minister expressed confidence in Trump, stating, "I will be able to establish a relationship of trust." Abe was the first foreign leader to meet Trump face-to-face since his election victory over Hillary Clinton.

Meanwhile, the landing-party members huddled in conference rooms at the agencies, receiving thick binders and detailed presentations that included organization charts, budget forecasts, and parking space assignments, according to veterans of previous transitions.

Douglas Brook, who worked on outgoing transition teams for Presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush, noted that both sides typically are professionals who "speak the same language" in their fields of expertise, regardless of policy differences. However, he emphasized that a concerted effort is required to achieve a smooth handover, as accomplished by the Bush-Obama teams.

The transition team's timetable has been emphasized due to repeated news reports about slow progress and turmoil, which Trump transition officials dispute. Trump's pace in filling his Cabinet is not off the pace of most recent presidents, as when Barack Obama was putting together his first administration in 2008, he did not make his first Cabinet appointment until three weeks after the election.

Trump's landing parties will tackle federal agencies in three waves: national security, economic, and domestic. The next wave will reportedly involve the Treasury, Commerce Department, U.S. Trade Representative's office, Small Business Administration, and Social Security Administration. The final team will focus on domestic agencies, including the Departments of Interior, Agriculture, Homeland Security, Energy, Labor, Transportation, Education, and Health and Human Services, as well as independent agencies such as the Office of Management and Budget, Federal Trade Commission, and NASA.

Trump's meeting schedule in New York on Thursday included diplomatic legend Henry Kissinger, South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, retired Army Gen. Jack Keane, and Family Research Council leader Ken Blackwell. The most unexpected meeting was reportedly set for this weekend with Mitt Romney, the 2012 presidential nominee who was the party's most outspoken critic of Trump during the race.

Trump's transition meetings will move to the private Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey, on Friday, and the Trump-Romney meeting is expected to take place there due to Trump's plans to stay in Bedminster until Sunday night.

Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama, a transition team member who is a potential pick for U.S. attorney general, expressed support for Trump meeting with people like Romney, stating, "There are a lot of talented people that he needs good relationships with, and I think Mr. Romney would be quite capable of doing a number of things."

Romney is reportedly under consideration for secretary of state, although this could not be confirmed. Other possible candidates to lead the State Department include Nikki Haley, former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations John R. Bolton.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner's Lawsuit Against President Obama: A Boon for the White House

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, House Speaker John Boehner's lawsuit against President Barack Obama over the use of unilateral executive authority has been met with a welcoming response from the White House. The lawsuit, which some view as a bold move by the Republican party, has been embraced by the White House as an opportunity to highlight the President's executive actions and address a long-standing political challenge.

Since the Republican party took control of the House in 2010, President Obama has faced a fundamental political challenge in terms of public understanding of the U.S. constitutional order. The average American voter expects the government to improve their lives, and when this doesn't happen, they often grow frustrated with the President. When the President's agenda is stymied in Congress, the public is not interested in discussions about filibusters or the Speaker's ability to keep bills from reaching the floor. Instead, they question why the President is not leading and getting things done.

To address this issue, President Obama has not only relied on unilateral executive action to advance his policy aims but has also worked to highlight these actions. These actions, often small-bore in nature, have been difficult to attract substantial public attention due to their relatively minor impact.

The specter of a U.S. Congress engaging in a high-profile political fight over the idea that the President has been doing too much is, therefore, a valuable opportunity for the White House. The lawsuit allows the President to refute the argument that he is not leading, demonstrating that he is indeed taking action, albeit within the bounds of his executive authority.

In a statement to reporters, White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest criticized Republican leaders in Congress for playing "Washington politics" rather than working with the President on behalf of hardworking Americans. The implication is that, were it not for the lawsuit, Republicans would be engaged in constructive compromises with the White House. However, the real-world alternative to litigation is simply doing nothing—the parties do not agree, and nothing Obama or Boehner does or says is likely to change that.

The current partisan debate is often described as a stalemate, but it may be more accurately captured by the chess term "Zugzwang," a situation in which the optimal move would be to pass and force the other player to make a move—except that passing is against the rules of chess. The best strategy for House Republicans this summer and fall might be to do nothing, given the President's low approval rating, the GOP's expected midterm gains, and the need to avoid rocking the boat.

However, conservative activists are unlikely to tolerate a passive strategy. They are critical of Obama and want Speaker Boehner to take action that expresses this criticism. Lawsuits are a less extreme move than impeachment, so given the realities of the situation, the litigation may be a shrewd move by Boehner rather than a blunder. Yet, the impatience of the activist right remains a gift to the White House, allowing the President to underscore the basic reality of the situation—there are things he would like to do that Republicans are fiercely opposing.

Title: Trump Cancels Peace Talks with Taliban Following Deadly Kabul Bombing

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Monday that peace negotiations with the Taliban are off following a bombing in Afghanistan that resulted in the death of an American service member. The bombing, claimed by the Taliban, occurred in Kabul on August 15, 2019.

The planned meeting between Taliban leaders and representatives of the Afghan government, which was set to take place at Camp David on Sunday, was called off by President Trump in response to the Kabul bombing that resulted in the death of a U.S. soldier and 12 other individuals. Critics had previously criticized the planned meeting, scheduled just days before the 18th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, as disrespectful.

President Trump stated that the decision to cancel the meeting was his own, and he did not consult with any other individuals. "It was my idea," Trump told reporters. "I didn't discuss it with anybody else. When I heard... that they killed one of our soldiers and 12 other innocent people, there's no way I'm meeting."

The president also disputed reports that he had overruled advisers, including National Security Advisor John Bolton and Vice President Mike Pence, to schedule the meeting in the first place.

In a tweet on September 9, 2019, Trump wrote, "A lot of Fake News is being reported that I overruled the VP and various advisers on a potential Camp David meeting with the Taliban. This Story is False! I always think it is good to meet and talk, but in this case I decided not to."

President Trump also criticized the prolonged U.S. presence in Afghanistan, recalling his promise to bring home the approximately 14,000 American troops currently stationed in the war-torn country. In a separate tweet on September 9, 2019, Trump stated, "We have been serving as policemen in Afghanistan, and that was not meant to be the job of our Great Soldiers, the finest on earth. Over the last four days, we have been hitting our Enemy harder than at any time in the last ten years!"

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also commented on the canceled meeting, stating on Sunday, "We're going to walk away from a deal if others try to use violence to achieve better ends in the negotiations. It's not right. It's not appropriate. It killed an American. And it made no sense for the Taliban to be rewarded for that kind of bad behavior."

Title: Media's Role in Political Violence: A Neutral Analysis of Escalating Tensions

Article:

The article discusses the increasing political violence in the United States and the role of the media in shaping public discourse. The author suggests that the emergence of the "angry left" and the Occupy movement, as well as the alt-right, neo-Nazis, and the Klan, have led to an escalation of violent incidents.

The author notes that the media has played a significant role in this escalation, with the media's attention and approval, either overt or subtle, being seen as a form of endorsement for these groups. The author cites examples such as the assassination attempt on Congressman Steve Scalise and the violence at Charlottesville, Virginia, as instances where the media's attention has contributed to the groups' visibility.

The author also points out that the left and right have their own violent practitioners, with the left-wing practitioners being described as "pretty much marginal" and the right-wing practitioners being kept in the news due to their criminality. The author notes that the left has escalated things by threatening the right's advertisers, with the more timorous corporate titans bowing to the left's threats, only to return when they found the left's threats to be mostly hollow.

The author also mentions the support that conservative media figures like Sean Hannity and Laura Ingraham have received from media mogul Rupert Murdoch, who is praised for breaking the left's monopoly on media with his Fox News channel. The author suggests that the left's threats to advertisers are a continuation of their attempts to influence media content, citing the left's successful attempts to drop conservative columnists from newspapers in the past.

The author concludes by suggesting that the media's role in shaping public discourse and its influence on political violence is a complex issue, with the media's attention and approval being seen as a form of endorsement for certain groups, and the media's neglect being seen as a form of marginalization for others. The author also suggests that the media's role in shaping public discourse is a matter of concern, with the growing acrimony on newspaper pages being a potential cause for concern.

Title: Tillerson Urges International Community to Implement and Strengthen UN Sanctions Against North Korea

Article:

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson addressed the United Nations Security Council on Friday, urging member countries to financially cut ties with North Korea and freeze access to funds that could be used for nuclear weapons development. Tillerson called for the full implementation of U.N. sanctions and the suspension or downgrading of diplomatic ties with North Korea.

Tillerson stated, "With each successive detonation and missile test, North Korea pushes northeast Asia and the world closer to instability and broader conflict." He emphasized the real threat of a North Korean attack on Seoul or Tokyo. Tillerson added that it was "only a matter of time" before Pyongyang targets the United States, and urged the international community to take concrete steps to prevent North Korea from carrying out its threats.

Tillerson's comments followed an intense week in Washington, during which the Trump administration held closed-door briefings with U.S. lawmakers regarding the escalating North Korean threat. The Trump administration aims to pressure North Korea into dismantling its missile and nuclear programs through tightened economic sanctions and diplomatic measures with allies and regional partners.

U.N. Secretary General António Guterres, who also spoke at the meeting, condemned North Korea's violations of U.N. resolutions on nuclear and missile testing and development. Guterres expressed concern over the risk of a military escalation in the region.

China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who also spoke at the meeting, pledged that Beijing would fully implement all U.N. sanctions on North Korea. Wang stated, "Due to the recent efforts by [North Korea] to accelerate missile and nuclear development, China agrees to the international community to step up efforts of non-proliferation."

On Thursday, Tillerson told Fox News that he favored diplomatic sanctions as a means to bring North Korea into compliance. Tillerson's call for sanctions came as President Trump indicated direct conflict with the rogue regime is possible. Trump told Reuters, "There is a chance that we could end up having a major, major conflict with North Korea. Absolutely." On the same day, Pyongyang released a propaganda video simulating an attack on the White House.

Title: Supreme Court Faces Decision on Staying Utah Same-Sex Marriage Ruling

Article:

In the last week, hundreds of same-sex couples have been married in Utah following a federal court ruling that overturned the state's ban on same-sex marriage. The question for the Supreme Court in the short term will be whether to block this ruling while appeals proceed.

Judge Robert J. Shelby's decision has faced challenges, with a two-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Denver agreeing not to stay the ruling. The state's request for a stay will initially be directed to Justice Sonia Sotomayor, a member of the court responsible for overseeing the Tenth Circuit. However, she is expected to refer the matter to the full court.

The Supreme Court will face difficult calculations, ones it did not have to confront in reviewing decisions from federal courts in California striking down Proposition 8, the state's ban on same-sex marriage. In that case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco stayed both the trial judge's ruling and its own as appeals went ahead.

Professor Dorf, a legal scholar, suggests that there are probably not five votes on the Supreme Court to block Judge Shelby's ruling. "On the strictly legal argument," he said, "it's hard to justify granting a stay."

However, Professor Dorf added that the lower courts should have granted a stay, partly because of the potential cruelty of voiding the new marriages and partly because the Supreme Court is hard to predict. "It's pretty clear that even the five justices who are sympathetic to same-sex marriage would rather take a few years before getting there," Professor Dorf wrote in a blog post on Tuesday. "If their hand is forced, as it now will be, it's impossible to say with certainty what they'll do."

Whatever the Supreme Court does regarding a stay, it is hard to see how it could hear the larger issue in the case in the current term. However, a decision in the court's next term, culminating in a decision in June 2015, is entirely possible.

Title: John Kasich Suspends Presidential Campaign, Leaves Trump as Presumptive Republican Nominee

Article:

John Kasich, known for his conciliatory approach in a tumultuous election year, suspended his presidential campaign on Wednesday, leaving Donald Trump as the presumptive Republican nominee. The Ohio governor's decision leaves Trump as the sole remaining candidate in the race.

Trump, in response, sounded conciliatory, stating that Kasich might be helpful in the general election and expressing interest in vetting him as a potential vice presidential running mate.

Kasich's withdrawal was met with mixed reactions. Some viewed his exit as a loss of civility in the race, while others saw it as a strategic move that could have united anti-Trump forces.

Despite Kasich's strategic goal of a one-on-one match-up with Trump, he ultimately chose to withdraw, given Trump's strong lead and the Republican National Committee chairman's reference to Trump as the "presumptive nominee."

Kasich's campaign was not without challenges. He won only his home state of Ohio and was at less than 20 percent in the national polls in a three-man race by the end. Technically, Kasich finished in fourth place, even though he was the last losing contender to drop out.

The question remains whether Trump would consider Kasich as a running mate and if Kasich would accept such an offer. Trump has expressed a preference for a politician as a vice president, and the Ohio governor would provide balance in terms of experience and message. However, the pair never clashed significantly, and Trump has mocked Kasich's losing ways and his eating habits.

For Kasich, a vice presidential slot might validate his quixotic effort and provide a cap to his long and varied political career. However, joining Trump's campaign would mean aligning with a candidate who has shown little eagerness to embrace light and hope, qualities Kasich has often associated with himself.

Title: Armed School Officer's Response to Florida School Shooting Draws Criticism from President Trump

 Article:

 U.S. President Donald Trump has criticized the armed officer who stood outside Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, during last week's shooting that left 17 people dead. The officer, Scot Peterson, resigned after an investigation found he failed to confront the suspect.

 Speaking to reporters outside the White House on Friday, President Trump described Mr. Peterson as a "coward" who "did not react properly under pressure." He added, "He trained his whole life but when it came time to do something, he did not have the courage."

 Florida Governor Rick Scott, meanwhile, has called for law enforcement officers to be placed in every public school in the state. At the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in Maryland, President Trump proposed arming teachers as a solution to school safety, a method long championed by the National Rifle Association (NRA) gun lobby.

 Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel revealed on Thursday that Mr. Peterson, the 54-year-old school resource officer, stood outside while the alleged gunman shot students at the high school. He said video footage showed Mr. Peterson arriving at the building where the shooting broke out about 90 seconds after the first shots were fired, and that he remained outside for about four minutes. The attack lasted six minutes, Sheriff Israel said.

 "I am devastated. Sick to my stomach. He never went in," Sheriff Israel said. Asked what Mr. Peterson should have done, Sheriff Israel said, "Went in, addressed the killer, killed the killer."

 Mr. Peterson is yet to publicly comment on what happened. Officers are reportedly guarding his home. It is unclear if he will face charges.

 The suspect used a semi-automatic AR-15 rifle, police say, and escaped the scene before being captured later. School resource officers are sworn law enforcement officers who are responsible for safety and crime prevention in schools, although their exact roles differ from school to school and authority to authority. They document incidents and can make arrests, as well as working on areas such as mentoring and education.

 There are between 14,000 and 20,000 such officers in the U.S., according to the National Association of School Resource Officers. Mr. Peterson had been in his position at the school since 2009, local media report. The Sun-Sentinel newspaper said he had worked for the sheriff's office since 1985 and office records showed his salary for 2016 was $75,673 (£54,137).

 Concerns have been raised about both the school's video surveillance system and whether warnings about the former student charged with the massacre were ignored. It has been reported that the person watching the surveillance system was relaying information 20 minutes old to police, so officers believed the gunman was in a certain area when he was not. Calls were also reportedly made to the authorities in 2016 and 2017 expressing concern about the suspect, including one saying he was planning to attack the school.

 A transcript of one call to the FBI was released to U.S. media on Friday, in which a tipster warns that the suspect "wants to kill people" and that "he's going to explode." The female caller, whose identification was redacted in the report, said that the suspect once brought a bird inside "threw it on his mother's kitchen counter and he started cutting it up." She also warned that the suspect was receiving an inheritance of $25,000 per year, and that he may spend that money on guns.

 Governor Rick Scott called for "active shooter training" for all students and staff at public schools in the state. He said he planned to raise Florida's minimum age for buying guns to 21 years old. Governor Scott also pledged to make it "virtually impossible for anyone who has mental health issues to use guns."

 "If a court involuntarily commits someone because they are a risk to themselves or others, they would be required to surrender all firearms and not regain the right to purchase or possess a firearm until a court hearing," he said during a speech about a new proposal on guns in Tallahassee.

 President Trump added, "What I'd recommend doing is the people that do carry, we give them a bonus. We give them a little bit of a bonus."

 However, Randi Weingarten, president of the 1.7 million-member American Federation of Teachers union, disagreed that arming teachers was a suitable solution. "Anyone who wants guns in schools has no understanding of what goes on inside them - or worse, does not care," she said.

Title: North Korean Troops' Loyalty to Kim Jong Un: A Former South Korean General's Warning

Article:

Retired Lt. Gen. In-Bum Chun, a decorated former South Korean military leader, has warned that a potential war with North Korea would not be like toppling former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, but more akin to trying to eliminate Allah. Chun, who spent nearly 40 years in the South Korean military, including a stint leading the country's special forces, made these remarks at a London think tank this week.

Chun, who has firsthand knowledge of North Korea, described the North Korean military as highly indoctrinated and potentially employing kamikaze-style attacks due to the age of their aircraft. The North Korean air force has around 1,000 planes, and North Korean soldiers receive 100 hours of weapon training annually starting at the age of 14.

The general's primary concern, however, is the loyalty of North Korean troops and citizens to Kim Jong Un during a foreign invasion. This loyalty is attributed to the country's system of mutual surveillance, where North Koreans spy on other North Koreans. Defectors who have spoken to Chun have expressed an innate belief in the system, despite having defected.

Chun used religious language to describe the North Korean soldiers' aggression, stating that they revere members of the Kim family, who have led the country for decades, as gods. The first leader was Kim Jong Un's grandfather, Kim Il Sung, who was in power from 1948 to 1994. He is still known today as the "Great Leader" and the "Eternal President," and monuments glorifying his reign are everywhere in the country.

Since Kim Il Sung's death in 1994, his son and grandson, Kim Jong Il and Kim Jong Un, have carried on his legacy. The current Kim has made some economic reforms and put more emphasis on improving the nuclear and missile programs. However, they purposely demonstrate in their own propaganda how closely they hew to Kim Il Sung's style of governance.

Kim Jong Un even goes out of his way to look as much like his grandfather as he possibly can in hopes of inspiring the same admiration his grandfather did. More than 400,000 North Korean soldiers died or went missing fighting for Kim Il Sung in the Korean War. The frightening reality is that many, many more might be willing to fight to the death if war came to the peninsula once again.

It's important to note that a war with North Korea is still very unlikely. North and South Korea are currently engaged in diplomatic negotiations for the first time in more than two years. On January 4, North Korea reopened a military crisis hotline with its southern neighbor after nearly two years of silence, a move that could lower the chances of an accidental war between the two longtime foes. And on Tuesday, Pyongyang agreed to send its athletes to the Olympics in South Korea next month.

War may not be imminent, but it's crucial to understand the potential consequences of such a conflict.

Title: Florida Governor Rick Scott Accuses Sen. Bill Nelson of Fraud in Closely Contested Senate Race

Article:

Florida Governor Rick Scott declared on Sunday that he has won the closely contested Senate race against Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson, accusing his opponent of "committing fraud" to steal the election. Scott made these statements during an interview on Fox News Sunday.

The Florida Senate race is one of three statewide contests that will undergo an automatic recount, following the unofficial deadline for counties to report results. As of Saturday, Scott's lead over Nelson had narrowed significantly, with Scott ahead by just over 12,000 votes as Democrat-rich counties like Broward County continued to report additional numbers.

During the interview, Scott repeated his allegations of fraud without evidence, suggesting that the increase in votes for Nelson is a result of fraudulent activities. Both Scott and President Donald Trump have accused Democrats of attempting to "steal" the election.

Scott's comments center around two issues that surfaced after Election Day. In one case, Nelson's team of lawyers objected to the cancellation of a ballot cast by a noncitizen, who is barred from voting. In another case, Nelson's lawyers are seeking a judge's permission to count all absentee ballots, including those where the signature on the mail-in envelope doesn't match the signature of the voter in file.

The governor also stated that he has asked the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to investigate potential fraud. However, both the department and the secretary of state, agencies that Scott oversees as governor, have previously stated that there is no evidence of fraud.

Nelson and his legal team have maintained that the increase in votes for the incumbent is due to the counting of previously uncounted votes.

As the recount begins, Scott stated that he has "already won the race two times" and intends to be sworn in as Florida's junior senator. Sen. Nelson was also invited to appear on the show but declined.

The Senate currently stands at 51 Republicans to 46 Democrats. Races in Arizona (where Democrat Kyrsten Sinema leads Republican Martha McSally) and Mississippi (which is headed to a runoff later this month) are also still to be resolved.

Title: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell Expresses Doubts on Repealing the Affordable Care Act

Article:

In the aftermath of the Supreme Court's ruling on the constitutionality of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell has expressed doubts about the possibility of repealing the health care law. The Kentucky Republican stated on Monday that it is challenging to undo a law of such magnitude, referring to the 2,700-page health care law.

McConnell made these comments during visits to Hardin Memorial Hospital in Elizabetown, discussing the law's future following last week's Supreme Court ruling that the law was constitutional. The court upheld the law's crucial mandate that individuals buy health insurance or face a penalty. Chief Justice John Roberts, a conservative, provided the pivotal vote in that decision by ruling that the penalty was legal under the government's taxing authority.

While the federal government passing a massive new entitlement program, such as the Affordable Care Act, makes it difficult to repeal it, McConnell's views on the subject are less cynical. He suggests that electing new members of Congress, as well as a new president, is the surest way to repeal the law, which has been consistently despised by more than half of Americans since its enactment two years ago.

If given control of the Senate next year, McConnell stated he would support using budget reconciliation rules to repeal the law. This approach would prohibit Senate filibusters and require only 51 votes to succeed. In 2010, Republicans criticized Democrats for relying on these rules to pass the health care bill, labeling their tactics as unusual and hyperpartisan.

The Supreme Court's 5-4 decision to uphold the law may, in fact, make it easier for lawmakers to repeal it. While the constitutionality of the mandate has been resolved, millions of Americans will still be uninsured, health care costs will remain high, and all Americans, including those who refuse to buy health insurance, will still be taxed. In short, if this isn't motivation enough to elect leaders who will repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act with more practical and sensible reforms, it is unclear what will.

Title: Justice Department Seeks Public Tips for Potential Civil Rights Case Against George Zimmerman

Article:

The Department of Justice (DOJ) is soliciting email tips and information regarding the case of George Zimmerman, the former neighborhood watch volunteer, as it deliberates a possible federal civil rights case against him. This move appears to expand the ongoing investigation, following Attorney General Eric Holder's statement on Tuesday to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) that the department would "consider all available information" before deciding whether to proceed.

On Monday, the DOJ held a conference call with civil rights leaders, including those from Sanford, Florida, and other parts of the country. The call was organized by Tom Perez, the assistant attorney general for the Civil Rights Division. The department has previously used such tip lines in high-profile investigations, such as the probe last year of the Albuquerque, New Mexico, police department.

Some legal experts have expressed doubts about the feasibility of a civil rights case against Zimmerman, given that the current investigation has reportedly found no evidence or claims of racial bias. Trayvon Martin, who was fatally shot by Zimmerman, was African-American. However, some lawmakers seem to have already reached a conclusion.

"We do know that Mr. Martin's civil rights have been violated," said Rep. Corrine Brown (D-Fla.), with other members of the Congressional Black Caucus expressing similar views.

In addition to the ongoing investigation, Holder has taken further action in response to the acquittal. On Tuesday, he criticized "stand-your-ground" laws, which permit individuals to use lethal force when they believe their lives are in danger, even if they have the option to retreat. The National Rifle Association (NRA) criticized Holder for these comments, stating that self-defense is a "fundamental human right."

Holder also shared his own experiences with racial profiling during his address to the NAACP.

Title: U.S. Troop Withdrawal from Northern Syria Sparks Controversy and Concerns

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw U.S. troops from northern Syria has sparked criticism from both political sides, with concerns that the move could lead to a resurgence of the Islamic State (ISIS) and damage U.S. credibility as a reliable ally.

The withdrawal, announced on Sunday evening, has been met with criticism due to the potential consequences for ISIS and the Kurdish-led forces in the region. The Kurds have been key partners in the fight against ISIS, and their abandonment could lead to the release of tens of thousands of former militants and family members currently held in Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) controlled camps.

The decision has been described as a "stunning" and "betrayal" of the Kurds, who have been historically betrayed by the U.S. in their relationship. The U.S. has been a key ally to the Kurds, but the latest betrayal has been particularly concerning given President Trump's repeated claims of defeating the Islamic State and restoring U.S. credibility with traditional Middle Eastern allies.

The U.S. partnership with the Kurds in Syria occurred after three years of failed attempts to get Turkey to stop supporting radical and extremist groups in Syria. About 90% of foreign fighters entering Iraq and Syria to fight with al Qaeda or the Islamic State traversed the Turkish border, often with the facilitation of Turkish security forces.

The withdrawal of U.S. forces and the greenlighting of a Turkish incursion could lead to a revival of the Islamic State and renewed conflict in one of the only peaceful parts of Syria. It may also foreshadow terrorism and civil war inside Turkey, as the Kurds in northeastern Syria were their safe-haven.

The decision has also been criticized for potentially putting the U.S. on a collision course with Turkey, as President Erdoğan has been more of an adversary of the U.S. than an ally, strategically aligning with both Russia and Iran. The Kurds in Rojava are a bulwark not just against ISIS but against perfidious action by all three of those regimes unfriendly to America.

The decision has also put President Trump in conflict with the Pentagon and his own Republican allies, and there is speculation that he may walk back the decision in part or in whole. However, the decision has raised questions about the U.S.'s reliability as a stalwart partner and determined adversary in the eyes of U.S. allies and foes alike.

Title: Bill Clinton Delivers Bipartisan-Themed Address, Highlights Decades of Interaction with Bob Dole

Article:

Former U.S. President Bill Clinton's decades-long interactions with Bob Dole were a recurring theme in Clinton's bipartisan-focused address at the University of Kansas on Monday.

"One of the things I always liked about Bob Dole is that he could fight you like there's no tomorrow, but he never closed the door on something that could help a real person," Clinton said. He added that no matter what else the two men were doing, they kept their doors open, "and we found a way to try to do what's best for the American people."

Clinton, a Democrat and the 42nd president of the United States, was in Lawrence to accept the 2015 Dole Leadership prize, an annual award bestowed by KU's Dole Institute of Politics, named after the former Republican U.S. Senator from Kansas. Dole, 92, did not attend the event.

Clinton described the current age as the most "interdependent" in human history, one in which positive and negative forces are colliding. He emphasized bipartisanship as the key to ensuring a prosperous future, urging America and the world to focus on shared goals instead of differences.

"The polarization of American politics is present not just in Washington but in American life," Clinton told a capacity crowd at the 2,210-seat Lied Center auditorium on the KU campus.

Clinton highlighted the progress made in overcoming bigotry in America over the past 100 years, stating that the country is less racist, sexist, religiously bigoted, homophobic, and intolerant of those who disagree.

Clinton attributed Dole's ability to identify with others to an experience Dole had while lying in the hospital recovering from wounds sustained in World War II. Clinton said this ability to empathize is the essence of the test we all face today.

Clinton referenced his autobiography, stating that he had pulled for Dole over other Republican contenders during an election. He believed that if he lost, the country would be in more solid and moderate hands with Dole.

Clinton emphasized the importance of diverse groups making decisions and working together, stating that in the face of insecurity, the most predictable path is to stick to one's own kind and push others away.

In the age of smartphones, the internet, and globalization, "we can't escape each other," Clinton said.

Throughout his address, Clinton interspersed references to current events, examples of efforts initiated during his term as president, as well as recent efforts by his charitable foundation, the Clinton Foundation. One cause Clinton worked on with Dole was the Families of Freedom Fund, initiated after Clinton left the White House to provide education funding for the survivors of those killed in 9/11, regardless of citizenship. So far, the fund has awarded $118 million.

One of the missions of the Dole Institute is to foster civil dialogue about political and economic issues in a balanced and bipartisan environment. The Dole Institute stated that Clinton was selected for the prize this year "for his work balancing the budget and practicing bipartisanship while in office."

Other recipients of the prize have included former Sen. George McGovern, former Polish President Lech Walesa, former President George H.W. Bush, and former South African President Nelson Mandela.

After leaving office in 2001, Clinton established the Clinton Foundation, which funds health care, human rights, and economic development programs both domestically and internationally. Clinton's wife, Hillary Clinton, is considered the Democratic frontrunner in the 2016 race for president.

The Dole Leadership prize comes with a $25,000 award, which Clinton has chosen to donate back to the Dole Institute. Dole Institute director Bill Lacy said the money will seed the Dole Institute's new Women and Leadership Lecture Series, expected to launch in the next couple of years.

Title: Republican Party Shifts Strategy: Establishment Candidates to Receive Unlimited Funding from Super PACs

Article:

The Republican Party is undergoing a significant strategic shift in its approach to funding, with establishment candidates receiving unlimited funds from Super PACs to fend off challenges from the Tea Party. This change marks the biggest reevaluation of the Republican Party's outside money strategy since the dawn of the super PAC era.

Consultants and attorneys, including the co-founder of the pro-Mitt Romney super PAC, are laying the groundwork or have already filed paperwork for dozens of super PACs organized to support individual candidates running in the upcoming years. These super PACs are permitted to raise and spend unlimited funds, unlike congressional campaigns, but are forbidden from coordinating with the campaigns.

The strategy shift reflects the growing internal conflict within the Republican Party, which is likely to characterize the 2014 and 2016 campaigns. The Senate Conservatives Fund, a group that has vowed to attack GOP candidates deemed insufficiently conservative, is one example of this internal conflict.

In recent election cycles, well-established conservative groups like Karl Rove's Crossroads network and the Koch-linked Americans for Prosperity have largely stayed out of primary fights. However, tea party-associated groups have helped unseat more moderate Republicans in these contests.

The shift in strategy is a response to donors' dissatisfaction with the results of big money groups in recent years and their willingness to take their funds elsewhere. This is evident in the rise of single-candidate super PACs, a sign that party leaders believe donors are seeking more accountability and metrics in their investments.

In the special Massachusetts Senate election to replace John Kerry in 2013, a single donor bankrolled the deceptively-named Americans for Progressive Action on behalf of GOP senate candidate Gabriel Gomez, despite major GOP groups like Crossroads and Americans for Prosperity taking a pass on the race. This trend suggests a shift in donor focus from relationships to accountability, as donors are now asking for detailed strategic plans before making contributions.

Title: Polling Data Suggests Tightening Race Between Clinton and Trump Ahead of Election Day

Article:

As the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election approaches, the race between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump has shown signs of tightening, despite months of polling data suggesting a more stable outcome for Clinton. Polling aggregators and election prediction markets have consistently shown Clinton with a lead over Trump, but the race has become more unpredictable following the announcement by F.B.I. Director James Comey regarding the renewal of an investigation into Clinton's use of a private email server.

According to FiveThirtyEight, Trump currently lags behind Clinton by just 3.3 points in a polls-only forecast. In 2012, average polling was off by 2.7 points, and if this trend were to repeat in 2016, it could be enough to flip states like Wisconsin and Minnesota from Clinton's column to Trump's.

There is a degree of variation among polling aggregators, data scientists, and political analysts. While HuffPost Pollster, which excludes outlier polls, currently gives Clinton a 97.9% chance of victory, Nate Silver's model is more conservative, giving Clinton a 68.1% chance to account for increased volatility.

Some analysts, such as neuroscientist Sam Wang, who out-predicted Silver in 2012, argue that while individual polls may show a narrow lead for Clinton, Trump's rise should not be confused with momentum. Wang suggests that voter opinion has become entrenched, and the movement of voter opinion has been within a narrow range. He believes that if the regression to the mean holds, there will be a little movement back to Clinton, but the outcome remains uncertain.

In conclusion, while polling data has consistently shown a lead for Clinton, the race between Clinton and Trump has become more unpredictable in the final weeks leading up to the election. The outcome of the election remains uncertain, and voters should remain informed and vigilant as they make their decisions.

Title: Democratic Debate Highlights Diverse Field and Challenges for Biden

Article:

The second night of the opening Democratic debates in Miami on Thursday showcased a competitive field of candidates, with California Senator Kamala Harris and South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg emerging as standouts. The debate expanded the possibilities of the Democratic contest, as both Harris and Buttigieg were crisp and commanding, driving the conversation more than front-runner Joe Biden and second-ranked Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders.

The debate highlighted the unprecedented diversity of the Democratic field in terms of demography and generation. The participants included six women, two African Americans, a Latino, and an openly gay man. The contrast in age was striking, with South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, 37, standing to the right of Joe Biden, who is 76 and already served in the U.S. Senate for nine years by the time Buttigieg was born.

One of the most notable moments of the debate came when Senator Harris directly addressed Biden, stating, "I do not believe that you are a racist," before discussing his recent comments on his compromises with segregationists in the Senate and his opposition to school busing. Biden, in response, accused Harris of mischaracterizing his comments and his position on busing.

Biden's performance left some of his supporters concerned, and Harris's performance made her the top trending topic on Google for a time. Biden was folksy, but he failed to articulate a clear vision for his presidency. Harris was forceful, displaying the prosecutor's skills she honed as San Francisco district attorney and California attorney general. However, her decision to raise her hand when asked which candidates would eliminate private health insurance as part of Medicare-for-All could complicate her appeal to more moderate Democrats in the primaries.

Buttigieg also had a good night, coming across as low-key and thoughtful when he was asked about a fatal police shooting in South Bend last week. "It's a mess, and we're hurting," Buttigieg said, stating that he had taken some steps but not enough to deal with the issue before the tragedy happened.

The debates gave most candidates the biggest audiences of their lives, a chance to break through with voters across the country who had never seen them before. More than 15 million people watched on Wednesday, according to NBC. After the opening night, former Housing secretary Julian Castro and New Jersey Senator Cory Booker got an immediate boost from what were seen as strong appearances.

The debates also marked a historic moment, as Buttigieg became the first openly LGBTQ candidate in a presidential debate. The debates spotlighted the diversity of the Democratic field and the need for a new generation to take over, as California Representative Eric Swalwell argued. The debates will continue with 11 more debates scheduled, including a second next month in Detroit. The opening Iowa caucuses are still more than seven months away.

Title: Obama's Limited Role in 2014 Midterm Campaign Contrasts with 2010 Rally

Article:

President Barack Obama's role in the 2014 midterm campaign stands in stark contrast to his active participation in the 2010 campaign, as evidenced by a rally on October 10, 2010, where he urged supporters with the famous phrase, "Are you fired up? Are you ready to go?" At a Philadelphia park, the crowd responded with the iconic chant, "Yes we can!"

Four years later, on Thursday, October 10, 2014, Obama was speaking to a small group of wealthy donors at actress Gwyneth Paltrow's Los Angeles home, far from the public eye. His tone was markedly different from the energetic rally of 2010.

"Democrats have many good qualities, but a congenital disease is, A: We get depressed too easily; and B: We're terrible at paying attention to midterm elections," Obama said.

No cameras were allowed at the event, and no local Democratic candidates received a presidential shout-out. Obama's low-key appearance at Paltrow's home was not an exception this year; he has headlined no public campaign events this election cycle, and since Labor Day, he has appeared in person with only two candidates—in the Democratic states of California and Illinois.

By this point four years ago, Obama had led three rallies, and in the weeks since Labor Day, he had held political events with five candidates, even with an approval rating of 47%, according to the Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll at the time.

Now, with his approval at a low-water mark of 40%, according to the Journal/NBC poll, the president has been relegated to fundraising and small, targeted photo-ops like one he did Thursday when he dropped by the Los Angeles campaign office of House candidate Ted Lieu.

Rep. Steve Israel of New York, the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said he hoped Obama's appearance with Lieu was "a preview of similar engagements by the president."

"We'd love to see more of that," Mr. Israel said.

The president's campaign schedule will pick up in coming weeks, with the White House announcing a Connecticut rally next week. However, the contrast between 2010 and 2014 is likely to become more evident as the fight for control of the Senate is the year's top battle.

Administration officials say much of Obama's time on the campaign trail will be spent stumping for gubernatorial and House candidates. With Obama so unpopular in most states with close Senate races this fall, Democratic candidates are putting as much distance between themselves and the president as they can.

At a newspaper editorial board meeting on Thursday, Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Kentucky, refused three times to say whether she had even voted for Obama in 2008 and 2012, saying instead that she is "a Clinton Democrat through and through."

The White House has yet to announce any campaign events Obama will hold with Democratic Senate candidates, though he has recorded get-out-the-vote phone calls, radio ads, and videos for them to target selected constituencies.

The campaign of Charlie Crist, Florida's Democratic candidate for governor, is now wary of inviting Obama to publicly appear with him out of concern that it would shift the focus of the race to national issues, according to a person familiar with Crist's campaign strategy.

A recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Annenberg survey found that an endorsement from Obama would leave a more negative view of a congressional or Senate candidate, with 38% saying they would see a candidate less favorably, compared with just 28% who would have a more favorable view after a presidential endorsement.

Findings like those are one reason that Republicans say they welcome Obama's just-announced campaign stop with Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy. A Malloy spokesman said the governor is happy to stand with the president and discuss shared views on issues like the minimum wage and gun laws.

Democratic Party leaders say Obama can play an important role in the campaign. Each of the three states with the highest concentration of competitive House races—New York, California, and Illinois—is friendly Obama territory, Mr. Israel said.

However, White House officials say Obama wants to help Democrats in the weeks before the Nov. 4 election, even if that means staying away from them. Last week, after Obama said that while he isn't on the ballot this November, his policies are, Republican Senate candidates rushed to produce ads replaying the remark. At Thursday's fundraiser at Ms. Paltrow's house, Obama tweaked the comment, saying instead "our values" and "our ideals" are on the ballot.

Many presidents have seen a similar downgrade in their role in midterm elections as their popularity wanes. Republicans distanced themselves from George W. Bush in 2006 as his popularity fell over the Iraq war. "There are always places where the incumbent president just isn't popular," said Steve Elmendorf, a Democratic strategist.

In the absence of campaign rallies this cycle, Obama has maintained a busy fundraising schedule, headlining 58 events so far this year, with another on tap Saturday. That is comparable to his 2010 schedule, said Brendan Doherty, an associate professor of political science at the U.S. Naval Academy who compiles presidential-fundraising data.

David Winston, a Republican strategist, said the White House has a long-term interest in demonstrating that Obama still has some political capital. "If there was a sense that he was in a situation where he couldn't help any Democratic candidate, that's just not a good setup for his last two years," Mr. Winston said.

Title: Study Reveals Decreased Family Time During Thanksgiving Due to Political Polarization

Article:

A new study published in the journal Science this week reveals that families with mixed political views spent less time together during Thanksgiving in 2016 compared to families with similar political beliefs. The study, conducted by Keith Chen of the University of California, Los Angeles, and Ryne Rohla of Washington State University, used smartphone location data to analyze the duration of Thanksgiving dinners in politically polarized households.

The researchers found that families with mixed politics spent 20 to 50 minutes fewer at the table than politically like-minded groups. The difference was more pronounced among Republicans, who left earlier than Democrats, with some Republicans leaving more than an hour earlier. Democrats were more likely to skip the holiday altogether. The effect was three times stronger in areas with heavy political advertising.

The study's authors estimate that partisan differences cost Americans 73.6 million person-hours of family time that Thanksgiving. Political psychologist John Jost of New York University, who was not involved in the research, finds the study intriguing. "In recent years political scientists have done an admirable job of documenting the political costs of asymmetric polarization," Jost says. "This new work suggests that there may be social and personal—even familial—costs as well."

The researchers initially set out to study the nation's growing geographic polarization but became interested in the potential impact of political disagreements on family gatherings after hearing anecdotal reports of a rocky holiday in 2016 following Donald Trump's shock win over Hillary Clinton. To measure the effects of political disagreements on Thanksgiving festivities, Chen and Rohla used communication and location technology.

They obtained smartphone location data from a company called SafeGraph, which was gathered via partner applications such as weather or navigation apps that ask permission to log coordinates. The resulting anonymous, aggregated data sets reported the locations of some 10 million smartphones at various points in time. Chen and Rohla overlaid that data with voting tallies by precinct, each representing about 200 to 1,000 people who used the same polling place.

The researchers then made some assumptions based on probability. They took their best guess at what precinct a person lived in by asking where their smartphone was from 1 A.M. to 4 A.M., most mornings. For example, if a smartphone's location data suggested a person was 80% likely to be a Clinton voter, the researchers could then look at where the person spent Thanksgiving dinner and how long they spent at Thanksgiving dinner.

To ensure the effect they identified was political, the researchers took several additional steps. They compared meal lengths for matched pairs of families who lived within a mile of each other and had traveled to eat with host families who lived equally close. Of these, families with a higher probability of tearing into each other over the turkey did indeed prove more likely to leave early.

Next, the scientists compared Thanksgivings in 2016 and 2015. Families who were more likely to be politically distant yet ate together in 2015 were less likely to do so in 2016. Finally, Chen and Rohla considered the effect of political advertising. Voters in states such as New York and California saw almost no political ads, while those in Orlando, Florida, for example, were exposed to more than 20,000 political television ads during the campaign. In such saturated areas, the diminishment of time together at Thanksgiving tripled.

Some critics of the study note that a presidential election year is different in many ways from the years on either side, so comparing 2015 to 2016 would be of limited use. Chen and Rohla do not disagree. They plan to analyze the aftermath of the 2018 midterm elections, but they recognize that 2020 and subsequent presidential election years will better clarify what happened in 2016.

Others have expressed concern about the use of smartphone data, considering it an invasion of privacy. Chen and Rohla point to the anonymity of the data and the fact that the applications involved require permission. "They do have to allow the location," Rohla says. "My feeling is that math-geolocated data is going to be at the forefront of a lot of social science going forward."

Methodology aside, the authors say they have captured a trend they would like to see disappear. "I hope the effect is short-lived and that American families find a way past this," Chen says. Rohla can attest at least one family—his own—did. "Everyone learned their lesson in 2017," he says. "It was much better."

Title: U.S. Customs and Border Protection Welcomes Storm Refugees, President Trump Contradicts Statement

Article:

In the aftermath of Hurricane Dorian, there has been confusion over whether individuals fleeing the Bahamas would be allowed to seek refuge in the United States. Acting Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Mark Morgan, announced during a news conference on Monday at the White House that anyone in need due to the hurricane would be allowed entry, regardless of travel documentation.

However, President Donald Trump later contradicted this open-arms sentiment, stating that everyone fleeing the storm "needs totally proper documentation" to seek assistance in the U.S. Trump expressed concerns about allowing individuals who were not supposed to be in the Bahamas to enter the United States, citing potential security risks, including "very bad people and some very bad gang members and some very very bad drug dealers."

According to The Washington Post, existing U.S. policy allows for Bahamians to enter the United States without a visa by providing a passport and proof of no criminal record and going through pre-screening conducted by CBP in Freeport and Nassau. The current situation has left tens of thousands homeless on the islands following the hurricane.

Title: Georgia Grand Jury to Review Fatal Shooting of Ahmaud Arbery

Article:

The fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old black man in Georgia, is gaining widespread attention following the release of a graphic video showing the incident. Ahmaud Arbery was killed on February 23, after being pursued by two armed white men, Gregory McMichael and his son, Travis McMichael.

According to a police report, Gregory McMichael spotted Arbery jogging and called 911 to report a "black man running down the street," suspecting him of being involved in recent burglaries. McMichael called his son, and the pair armed themselves before tracking Arbery down on the road.

The police report states that Gregory McMichael told officers he and his son first tried to stop Arbery by shouting, "Stop, stop, we want to talk to you!" The father claimed that Arbery attacked his son, and they got into a struggle for a shotgun. Police said the son fired two shots.

Arbery's family maintains he was simply out for a jog at the time. The video shows a black man running at a slow pace toward a white truck that is stopped in the middle of a country road. Two men are seen outside the vehicle, including one standing on the truck's bed. The black man seems to attempt to run around the truck, and the moment he clears the vehicle, a shot rings out.

A brief struggle ensues in what looks like an effort to control a shotgun, and another two shots are heard, according to the video. The runner staggers away and collapses. The man in the truck's bed is seen holding a handgun after he climbs out to approach the others.

Georgia's Republican Governor, Brian Kemp, spoke out, noting that the Georgia Bureau of Investigation was assisting the prosecutor who has been placed on the case "to ensure a thorough, independent investigation into the death of # AhmaudArbery."

Georgia Attorney General Chris Carr said, "I am deeply concerned with the events surrounding the shooting of Ahmaud Arbery," in a brief statement. A grand jury will be reviewing the case.

The public developments in the case have prompted calls for justice from various lawmakers and public figures, including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., who tweeted, "Justice must be blind. Bring # Ahmaud Arbery's killers to justice."

Former Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-S.C., who is a former prosecutor, expressed surprise that it took the video being released to get prosecutors to ask for a grand jury review. "I guess my first question would be, why did it take the video [becoming public]?" Gowdy asked Fox News' Dana Perino on "The Daily Briefing." "If you have someone who is jogging, who is unarmed, who is shot and killed by officers who are not officers—they are not even law enforcement officers—why did they take video?"

The video has also prompted comments from other public figures, including former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams, who said, "It looks like murder. It looks like vigilante behavior that should be charged and criminalized." Abrams also called for the police to detain the McMichaels, who have not been charged, in the meantime.

The McMichaels are expected to remain free until at least June 13, due to Georgia's orders to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, as a grand jury would not be able to convene until then. Some have called for the police to detain the McMichaels until their trial.

Title: Comedian Louis C.K. and Action Star Chuck Norris Criticize Common Core Academic Standards, Sparking Debate and Pop Culture Backlash

Article:

The Common Core academic standards, once widely hailed as a bipartisan success story, are now facing criticism from both liberals and conservatives, with comedian Louis C.K. and action star Chuck Norris among the latest to voice their disapproval. The debate over the standards has intensified, with the issue dominating education policy debates and roiling political campaigns for over a year.

This week, Louis C.K. tweeted to his 3.3 million followers, "My kids used to love math. Now it makes them cry. Thanks standardized testing and common core!" He followed this with several pictures of third-grade math problems he deemed incomprehensible or nonsensical. Within a day, his original protest had been retweeted over 7,000 times. He continued his criticism on Thursday evening, tweeting, "Kids, teachers, parents are vocally suffering. Doesn't that matter? Listen to them. Adapt and slow down CCSS. Cool it with the testing."

The tweets highlight a significant challenge for the Common Core. Proponents aim to focus attention on the goal of raising academic standards and preparing American students for a global economy. However, parents are more concerned about their children crying over confusing homework and experiencing test-day anxiety, which are the stories that resonate, particularly on social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube.

Comedy Central's Stephen Colbert and authors Judy Blume, Maya Angelou, and Matt Damon have also weighed in with critiques on standardized testing. The populist attack on Common Core is not always fair, as some of the most widely mocked examples of so-called Common Core math were featured in textbooks and used in classrooms before the standards were introduced. The blame for some of the confusing assignments rests on individual teachers, not the standards, which outline what children should learn in each grade but do not dictate lesson plans or homework. High-stakes testing was also introduced before the Common Core and can be stressful for some students regardless of the exams' content.

Opposition activist Jim Stergios acknowledges that he would prefer to focus on more sober-minded critiques of the "mediocre quality, dubious legality, and outsized costs" of the Common Core. However, he admits that he is not displeased that complaints about the standards have become a pop culture meme.

"You know that discomfort and even outright opposition has reached a critical mass when the core becomes a frequent punch line in the repertoire of late-night comedians," said Stergios, executive director of the Pioneer Institute, a Boston think tank.

Supporters of the Common Core acknowledge that the campaign against the standards is taking a toll. "What harms the cause for improving education in this country is the attempt by the opposition and the media, who should know better, to perpetuate these misunderstandings, until eventually people think they are truths," said Cheryl Oldham, executive vice president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation.

The Common Core exams were introduced as the next generation of standardized tests, requiring students to write more, analyze complex texts, and perform hands-on experiments in the classroom. Backers hoped parents would embrace them as far more challenging and meaningful than traditional fill-in-the-bubble multiple-choice tests.

However, due to the new components, the exams are longer than many states' former assessments. They are taken on computers, which this spring have proven vulnerable to crashes, server outages, and even cyberterrorism. Common Core exams are graded on a tougher curve, leading to high failure rates in states that adopted them last year. Additionally, recent tests given to students in New York featured questions studded with brand names like Nike and iPod, raising concerns about commercialization.

Any parents who saw benefits in the new exams were swiftly drowned out by the chorus of protests on social media. By the tens of thousands, parents have refused to let their children take the tests. They have taken to social media to explain why. And their fury has seeped into pop culture.

Colbert aired a series of clips of parents explaining how the tests had rattled and stressed their children. His wry conclusion: "Common Core testing is preparing students for what they'll face as adults—pointless stress and confusion."

Title: President Trump's Grand Welcome in Saudi Arabia Kicks Off First Foreign Trip

Article:

President Donald Trump's first foreign trip as the U.S. President began on Saturday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, with an elaborate red carpet ceremony at the Royal Court Palace. King Salman of Saudi Arabia greeted the president, who was presented with the Collar of Abdulaziz Al Saud, the Saudi nation's highest honor.

Upon arrival at King Khalid International Airport, the Trumps were greeted by King Salman, with Ivanka Trump and her husband Jared Trump exiting the jet from the back steps before the president. Ivanka wore an ankle-length dress, while the first lady was dressed in a flowing black jumpsuit and a gold belt.

The president and first lady then walked into the terminal, where a coffee reception with King Salman was held. The pair spoke through an interpreter inside the terminal, according to The Associated Press.

The high-profile welcome stands in stark contrast to the low-key reception President Barack Obama received in the kingdom last year. The Saudis offered Trump an elaborate welcome, with billboards featuring his image lining the highways of Riyadh and the luxury hotel bathed in red, white, and blue lights.

During the hours leading up to Trump's arrival in Riyadh, White House principal deputy press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders tweeted photos of the city's preparations.

The trip marks the first time a U.S. president has made Saudi Arabia, a Muslim-majority country, his first stop. After Saudi Arabia, the president will travel to Israel, Italy, Vatican City, and Belgium. During the trip, Trump will meet with King Salman of Saudi Arabia, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, Pope Francis, Italian President Sergio Mattarella, King Philippe of Belgium, and the leaders of the G7 countries, among others.

The president will take part in bilateral meetings with the Saudi royal leadership while in the kingdom. The Trumps will join the Saudi royal family for an official dinner Saturday night. On Sunday, Trump will deliver a speech at the Arab-Islamic-American Summit on U.S. relations with the Muslim world and the global effort to confront religious extremism and promote moderation. He will also help inaugurate a "Global Center for Combating Extremist Ideology." The president will also attend meetings with the Gulf Cooperation Council members.

Title: Justice Department Inspector General Criticizes FBI for Errors in Russia Probe

Article:

Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz testified before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee on Wednesday, rebuking the FBI for "failures" during the initial phase of the Russia probe. Horowitz's testimony followed his extensive report on the investigation's origins and the process used to obtain a surveillance warrant for former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page.

Horowitz revealed that there were 17 inaccuracies and omissions in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant applications for Page, which included a doctored email and the failure to include exculpatory information about Page that may have impacted the court's decision to grant the warrants.

Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) questioned the FBI's actions during the hearing, asking, "Were they just all incompetent?" Hawley noted the complexities involved and stated, "It doesn’t sound like they’re very stupid to me."

Horowitz clarified that he did not reach any conclusions regarding intent but did not necessarily accept the reasons people provided during his investigation. He stated, "There are so many errors, we couldn’t reach a conclusion or make a determination on what motivated those failures other than we did not credit what we lay out here were the explanations we got."

This echoed Horowitz's statement in his opening remarks, where he made clear that "although we did not find documentary or testimonial evidence of intentional misconduct, we also did not receive satisfactory explanations for the errors or the missing information and the failures that occurred."

Horowitz previously appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the aftermath of his report on the subject, but Wednesday's hearing before the Senate homeland security panel comes a day after the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) sharply criticized the FBI in a rare public order that referenced his findings.

Horowitz stated that both Justice Department attorneys and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court "should have been given complete and accurate information," adding, "That did not occur and as a result, the surveillance of Carter Page continued even as the FBI gathered evidence and information that weakened the assessment of probable cause and made the FISA applications less accurate."

After Horowitz released his report, Democrats defending the Russia investigation pointed to the lack of a determination of political bias as evidence that President Trump's campaign was not being unfairly targeted. Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) indicated that this would be a flawed assumption, questioning whether Horowitz's inability to find evidence of bias really meant that there had not been any bias.

"Just because you didn’t find it doesn’t mean it didn’t exist," Paul said, noting that there could have been 15 people involved whose bias influenced their decisions, but it just wasn’t provable.

"We could not prove it. We lay out here what we can," Horowitz replied.

During his Senate Judiciary Committee testimony, Horowitz also stated that as far as political bias is concerned, while the launch of the Russia probe itself appeared to be in line with FBI policy, the issue "gets murkier" when it comes to the FISA process.

FISC Judge Rosemary Collyer used strong language in her four-page order. "The FBI's handling of the Carter Page applications, as portrayed in the [Office of Inspector General] report, was antithetical to the heightened duty of candor described above," Collyer wrote. "The frequency with which representations made by FBI personnel turned out to be unsupported or contradicted by information in their possession, and with which they withheld information detrimental to their case, calls into question whether information contained in other FBI applications is reliable."

The homeland security committee's leaders each took a step back and offered a big-picture take on Horowitz's findings. "I would argue that based on what the report reveals about early knowledge within the FBI, we should be asking a more fundamental question," said Chairman Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.). "At what point should the investigation into possible collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign have been shut down?"

Ranking member Sen. Gary Peters (D-Mich.) asserted that the most significant information to come out of Horowitz's work has to do with past and present threats to the country. "The most important fact that we should take away from this report and this hearing is that Russia, a foreign adversary, engaged in a sweeping and systematic effort to interfere in the 2016 presidential election, and that the FBI was right in investigating those who may have been involved," Peters said.

Horowitz's report also described how the FBI relied on information gathered by former British spy Christopher Steele as part of opposition research for Fusion GPS on behalf of the Clinton campaign and Democratic National Committee. Steele's information helped lead officials to approve seeking a FISA warrant for Page, even though the information had not been vetted as required by FBI policy.

Title: Former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld Challenges Donald Trump for 2020 Republican Presidential Nomination

Article:
