Former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld has become the first Republican to challenge President Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election. Weld, 73, released a campaign video contrasting his political style with the current president's. However, he faces an uphill battle to take over a Republican party that has been reshaped in Trump's image.

Weld served as governor of Massachusetts from 1991-97 and was part of President Ronald Reagan's administration in the Department of Justice. He was the running mate on the Libertarian ticket during the 2016 presidential election.

In a recent interview on CNN, Weld stated, "I really think if we have six more years of the same stuff we've had out of the White House the last two years, that would be a political tragedy." He added, "So I would be ashamed of myself if I didn't raise my hand and run."

Weld's campaign video emphasizes his cross-party credentials as a Republican who was elected in the Democratic stronghold of Massachusetts. The three-minute production contrasts his record with clips of provocative statements by Trump. The video concludes with the slogan, "A Better America Starts Here."

Despite Weld's efforts, party leaders have already rejected his campaign. The Republican National Committee issued a statement saying, "Any effort to challenge the president's nomination is bound to go absolutely nowhere." According to the most recent Gallup poll, 89% of Republican voters approve of the president.

Trump's campaign reportedly raised more than $30 million in the first quarter of this year, significantly outpacing the political war chests of individual Democratic candidates. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who was bested by Trump during the 2016 election, has recently been calling for a Republican to oust the president next year. Former Ohio Governor John Kasich and Maryland Governor Larry Hogan have also been mentioned as potential party challengers to Trump.

Next year, both Republican and Democratic voters will hold primaries to pick their respective party's standard bearer for the November 2020 presidential election. Sitting presidents do not usually face internal challengers, and only a few have ever been denied renomination by their party.

In addition to Weld, Democratic candidate Pete Buttigieg has also joined the race to prevent Trump from being re-elected. As the election approaches, it remains to be seen who else will join the race to become the next president.

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry Indicted, Hires High-Powered Legal Team

Article:

Texas Governor Rick Perry will be booked at the Travis County criminal courthouse in Austin today, according to his lawyer, Tony Buzbee. Perry is facing charges of public corruption, following an indictment by a grand jury last week. Perry's defense lawyers have rejected the indictment as an attempt to criminalize politics and damage his prospects as a potential presidential candidate in 2016.

Perry's legal team includes high-profile attorneys with notable records in significant cases. BP is among the clients represented by one of Perry's attorneys following the Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico. Another attorney argued before the U.S. Supreme Court and won changes to campaign finance laws. George W. Bush's former lawyer during the Florida recount that decided the 2000 presidential election is also part of Perry's defense team. An Austin attorney, who has been paid at least $80,000 in taxpayer money since the grand jury was first seated in April, is also on the team.

The exact payment sources for the lawyers, whether state funds or other defense funds, have not been clarified yet, according to Tony Buzbee. Perry did not attend Monday's unveiling of his new all-star defense team at an upscale Austin hotel.

Perry became the first Texas governor since 1917 to be indicted on Friday. He is facing charges of coercion and official oppression that carry a maximum sentence of 109 years in prison for carrying out a threat to veto funding for the state's public integrity unit last summer. The governor has emphatically stood by his veto and denied all wrongdoing.

A summons has been issued for Perry to be arraigned on Friday, though the case may be waived by Perry altogether. Perry spokesman Felix Browne stated that the governor would not need to appear personally.

Perry's indictment stems from a threat to veto $7.5 million in funding for the state's public integrity unit after Travis County District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg, a Democrat, refused to resign following a drunken driving arrest. The ethics unit is housed under Lehmberg's office.

No one disputes that Perry has the power to veto measures approved by the Legislature, but his threat to do so before actually carrying it out prompted a complaint from a left-leaning watchdog group. The grand jury met for months before handing down its indictment, and Perry's $450-per-hour defense attorney, David L. Botsford, was paid using state funds.

Aides said the case would not prevent Perry from maintaining his packed upcoming schedule, which includes visits to the key presidential battleground states of Iowa, New Hampshire, and South Carolina in the next two weeks. Perry also has a Thursday speech on immigration at the Heritage Foundation in Washington.

Title: White House Clarifies Alterations in Benghazi Talking Points, Senate to Investigate

Article:

Reports from Friday suggested that the intelligence community had initially determined the likelihood of terrorist involvement in the 2012 Benghazi attack, but this information was allegedly omitted from the final talking points circulated by the Obama administration. However, on Saturday, the White House disputed this claim, stating that they made only minor adjustments to the talking points used to prepare Susan Rice for her Sunday talk show appearances.

According to the Weekly Standard, the White House's statement clarified that the only edit made to the talking points was the change of "consulate" to "diplomatic facility" since the Benghazi facility was not formally a consulate. The White House emphasized that they worked off the points provided by the intelligence community.

Senator John McCain, on CBS's Face the Nation, criticized the Obama administration's handling of the Benghazi attack, suggesting that the president may have misled the American public to support the narrative of diminishing al-Qaeda influence in the Middle East. On the other hand, Chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee Dianne Feinstein expressed confidence that high-ups in the White House were not behind the alleged disconnect between intelligence and talking points. Feinstein stated that Congress still plans to investigate the matter to determine where the disconnect occurred. The New York Times reported that it is evident that someone somewhere made a significant error in the process.

Title: Increased Reports of Violent Attacks Invoking President Trump's Name

Article:

A series of violent attacks on individuals, some of whom were mentally disabled, in various parts of the United States have been reported, with the common thread being the assailants' apparent hatred towards President Donald Trump. While the victims' political affiliations are not always clear, the attacks have been linked to Trump's election.

In one incident in Chicago, a man was bound, gagged, and beaten while his captors reportedly yelled racial and anti-Trump slurs. Another incident, captured on video in November, began as a minor car accident. The victim, in an interview with The Chicago Tribune, stated that when he asked someone from the other car if they had insurance, a group of men began beating him. The attack was recorded, and some of the attackers were heard saying phrases such as "You voted Trump?" and "Don't vote Trump!"

In another incident, a 15-year-old student at a Maryland high school was beaten up by several people while wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat during a student walkout to protest Trump's election.

A New York City man was also attacked on the subway after a man asked him if he supported President-elect Trump. Corey Cataldo, the victim, told ABC7, "The next thing I know, I have hands around my neck and I'm being choked. I try to fight him off, and another gentleman comes over, pretends like he's going to help me and says 'get off of him.' He shoves me up against the wall, up against the window."

During an anti-Trump protest in Los Angeles, an activist told a CNN reporter, "We can't just do rallies. We have to fight back. There will be casualties on both sides. People have to die." She added, "People have to die."

A survey also found that at least 2,000 educators around the country reported hearing racial slurs and other derogatory remarks being used against white students in the days immediately following Trump's victory, according to The New York Post.

Chicago, the site of both video-recorded attacks, was also the location of a March primary rally that Trump was forced to cancel due to security concerns after protesters and supporters clashed.

While these incidents have drawn little media attention, far more press has been given to alleged crimes committed by supposed Trump supporters. In many cases, these have later turned out to be hoaxes.

Among the more notable incidents: In November, a black man in Mississippi was arrested for spray-painting his own church with a "vote Trump" tag and lighting the house of worship on fire. Muslim women in Louisiana and New York have also lied about assaults by alleged pro-Trump aggressors.

Title: Constitutional Scholars Debate Legality of Obama's Airstrike Campaign Against ISIS in Iraq

Article:

The legality of President Barack Obama's sustained and targeted airstrike campaign against ISIS forces in Iraq has become a topic of debate among constitutional scholars. While there is agreement that short-term military operations are constitutionally acceptable, the prolonged nature of the current campaign has sparked discussions.

According to Louis Fisher, a scholar at the Constitutional Law Project, a conflict lasting a few days could be justified, but President Obama's statement that the campaign could last for a year or more raises questions. Under the War Powers Act, Obama is required to report to Congress within 48 hours of the airstrikes commencing, and he has 60 days to gain Congress' approval or withdraw troops. He can extend this period by 30 days if the troops' lives would be endangered by an immediate withdrawal.

The president has yet to seek Congress' permission to continue the airstrikes, despite the prolonged nature of the campaign. The legal implications become more complex when the nature of the attacks is considered. Initially, airstrikes were deemed lawful due to their purpose of protecting American citizens. However, recent airstrikes are aimed at protecting the ethnic minority population in northern Iraq.

President Obama has defended the airstrikes against ISIS near Mt. Sinjar as a "humanitarian effort" to prevent genocide. However, the legality of these airstrikes is questionable, as they are not aimed at defending Americans. According to Professor Peter Raven-Hansen, Obama may not have constitutional authority to use American forces in combat to defend foreigners.

However, not all constitutional scholars agree on this point. Robert F. Turner, a national security professor at the University of Virginia, defends Obama's actions in Iraq. Turner argues that Obama can continue ordering airstrikes against ISIS because they are not a foreign state, but a terrorist group. Turner states, "What he’s doing, it’s not an act of war. He’s essentially coming to the defense of Iraq."

Regardless of the legal interpretations, the president's pursuit of airstrike campaigns without Congress' approval, and against the advice of his top legal advisors, has raised concerns about executive overreach. If Obama continues this practice, even with well-intentioned actions, the cries of executive overreach are likely to grow louder.

Title: Mario Lopez Apologizes for Comments on Transgender Children, Vows to "Be More Informed and Thoughtful"

Article:

In an interview with conservative commentator Candace Owens, entertainment host Mario Lopez made comments about transgender children that sparked outrage. Lopez later called his comments "ignorant and insensitive" and pledged to "be more informed and thoughtful."

During the interview, Owens, who hosts her own show on the PragerU YouTube channel, discussed what she referred to as "weird trends" in Hollywood. She mentioned that celebrities, such as Charlize Theron, are revealing that their children are choosing their gender. Theron recently disclosed that her 7-year-old child Jackson does not identify as a boy.

Lopez agreed with Owens and expressed his own confusion about the issue. "I'm blown away too," he said. "I'm never one to tell anyone how to parent their children... if you come from a place of love, you can't go wrong." However, Lopez also stated that he finds it "dangerous" for parents to make a determination about their child's gender when they are young.

Owens shared her own experiences, stating that as a child, she went through a "tomboy" phase before going through puberty. If she had decided to shave her head and become a boy at that time, she would have been depressed once she went through puberty and started liking boys, according to Owens.

Lopez agreed with this sentiment, stating, "My daughter thinks some boys have cooties. You do not know anything about sexuality, you're just a kid."

Gender and sexuality are two separate aspects of a person's identity. Gender refers to a person's identity as male, female, a continuum or blend of both, or perhaps conforming to neither. Sex refers to a person's biological makeup, while sexual orientation is about who they are attracted to. Experts say transgender individuals do not "choose" their gender or sexuality.

Throughout the discussion, the two hosts seemed to confuse gender and sexuality.

Owens expressed her concern about the trend in Hollywood, stating, "I think that's a very scary trend we're seeing in Hollywood right now, and to me, at the core of it, seems like narcissism." Lopez, a father of three, stated that parents need to let their kids be kids, but at the same time, they need to be the adults in the situation.

Lopez, who initially identified as politically independent during the interview, stated that he does not talk about politics because he is "in the people business."

"I don't want to alienate anyone. I want everyone to want to watch me," Lopez said. However, his comments about transgender youth drew criticism from Twitter users, some of whom stated that he has been "cancelled" as far as they are concerned.

In a statement obtained by ███, Lopez apologized for his comments, stating, "The comments I made were ignorant and insensitive, and I now have a deeper understanding of how hurtful they were. I have been and always will be an ardent supporter of the LGBTQ community, and I am going to use this opportunity to better educate myself. Moving forward, I will be more informed and thoughtful."

The LGBTQ organization PFLAG offered to provide Lopez with "more education on what being # transgender means, the difference between # sexualorientation, # sex, and # gender... and a whole lot of other things." The group offers a guide to help loved ones understand these issues better.

Title: Study Finds Google News Search Results Favor Left-Wing News Sources

Article:

A report released by AllSides on Tuesday suggests that Google News' search results exhibit a bias towards left-wing news sources. The report, authored by John Gable, CEO of AllSides, attributes this bias to the general bias of popular websites online, rather than intentional manipulation by Google.

AllSides, a group specializing in identifying media bias, based its findings on a media bias rating system that ranks media outlets as either left, right, or center. The group determines these ratings by surveying individuals about their own political bias and the bias of articles from various sites.

The study, which was conducted over 14 days from August 23 to September 5, 2018, analyzed the political bias of Google News and Google News search results. The results showed an overall bias of 65% left, 20% center, and 16% right in Google News.

The position of a link on a page is crucial, as the majority of traffic goes to the first links displayed on Google, with an estimated one-third going to the first result. The study found that the average position of the first result from left, center, or right sources differed significantly. The first result from left sources was, on average, one of the top two results, while the first result from right sources was below the fold, requiring users to scroll down before seeing their first news article from the right.

AllSides' findings are consistent with past research and observations, as the group often finds it difficult to find perspectives from the right when using Google News. The report does not suggest intentional favoritism for media sources from the left, nor does it suggest the opposite. Instead, it demonstrates that the choice of links provided by Google News has a significant bias in favor of the left.

The full report, which includes detailed methodology and findings, is 39 pages long and can be found here. The report suggests that Google may be reflecting a bias rather than directing one.

Title: House Republicans Introduce Debt Ceiling Bill, Sparking Constitutional Debate

Article:

House Republicans have unveiled a new debt ceiling bill, marking the first legislative battle of President Obama's second term. The bill, set for a vote on Wednesday, allows the government to continue borrowing until May 18. The bill also includes a provision known as "no budget, no pay," which has raised questions about its constitutionality.

Under the "no budget, no pay" provision, Congress would withhold the pay of lawmakers in either the House or the Senate if their chamber fails to pass a budget by April 15. The proposal is intended to pressure Senate Democrats to pass a budget, as the Senate has not passed one since Obama's first year in office.

However, critics argue that the provision violates the 27th Amendment, which states that no law varying the compensation for senators and representatives shall take effect until an election of representatives has intervened. Representative Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.) stated that the 27th Amendment may not permit Congress to alter its pay in the midst of a current session.

House Republican leadership defends the plan, stating that members would ultimately get paid, as they are constitutionally required to do. The plan would not violate the 27th Amendment, they suggest, because it would temporarily withhold pay, as opposed to reducing pay. Under the plan, members' pay would be held in escrow starting on April 15 for any chamber that has not passed a budget resolution.

The debt ceiling provision of the bill does not set a specific limit; instead, it would automatically increase the limit by the amount required to fund U.S. government obligations through May 18. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated that Obama would not block the bill if it passes.

Democrats in Congress have generally reacted coolly to the three-month extension, as it leaves other deadlines, such as sharp, across-the-board spending cuts and the possibility of a partial government shutdown, in place. However, failing to meet these deadlines would have less serious consequences than defaulting on U.S. obligations like payments to bondholders.

Obama has vowed he would not bargain over the debt limit. If the debt cap is not raised, the government would default on its obligations by as early as Feb. 15, according to the Treasury. House Republican Leader Eric Cantor confirmed that the House will vote on the package on Wednesday.

The debt-ceiling bill stands as the first legislative test of Obama's second term, following his public oath of office during the inaugural ceremony in Washington. The debt ceiling, the automatic spending cuts, and the expiration of the current budget are the immediate domestic challenges facing the administration and Congress. These issues also present opportunities to tackle the country's bloated deficit, though the president in his inaugural address pushed back on calls to cut entitlements.

In addition to addressing the debt ceiling, the president has other inaugural obligations to complete, including attending a prayer service and celebrating with campaign and White House staffers at inaugural balls. Tuesday is expected to be a normal working day at the White House, with the president meeting with top aides and press secretary Jay Carney briefing the press.

Behind the scenes, Obama and his advisers are working on plans to unveil a comprehensive overhaul of U.S. immigration laws, which is expected to be a central topic in Obama's Feb. 12 State of the Union address. The president is also seeking support from a wary Congress for the far-reaching package of gun control proposals he unveiled last week, including an assault weapons ban and universal background checks for gun purchasers.

Title: Sessions Defends Character Amidst Allegations at Senate Hearing for Attorney General Nomination

Article:

Sen. Jeff Sessions, the former federal prosecutor and Alabama attorney general, will defend his reputation against accusations of racism, sexism, and homophobia at a Senate hearing on Tuesday, as he seeks confirmation to become the Attorney General of the United States. In his prepared opening remarks, Sessions plans to emphasize his lifetime commitment to law and order, and his understanding of the historical impact of discrimination and the denial of voting rights on African-Americans.

Sessions is the first of President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet nominees to face a Senate confirmation hearing, and he is one of the most controversial nominees. He is the chief target of liberal groups hoping to derail Trump's agenda, with activists for civil rights, gay rights, illegal immigrants, and marijuana legalization pressuring Senate Democrats to oppose him.

The chief complaint about Sessions has been over race, stemming from accusations that as U.S. attorney in Alabama in the 1980s he improperly prosecuted black voting rights activists and made racially insensitive comments. He is accused of joking that he thought the Ku Klux Klan was OK until he learned its members smoked marijuana.

In 1986, the same accusations derailed his nomination for the federal bench when he was also grilled by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Sessions has vehemently denied making racially insensitive statements or holding racist views. He has pledged to uphold the law fairly and equitably. However, his critics are far from satisfied.

In his opening statement, Sessions will emphasize his long-standing relationship with his Senate colleagues and his commitment to the rule of law. He will outline goals for battling gun crimes, illegal immigration, drug-trafficking cartels, and other criminal gangs. He also will pledge to protect voting rights, support local law enforcement agencies, and build mutual respect between police and minority communities.

Sessions will insist that his lifetime commitment to law and order includes the protection of the rights of every American. He understands the demands for justice and fairness made by the LGBT community, and he understands the lifelong scars born by women who are victims of assault and abuse.

If confirmed, Sessions has pledged to be worthy of the office and the special trust that comes with it. He is ready for the job and will do it right, he says.

Title: Senate Approves Landmark Bill to Ban Workplace Discrimination Based on Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity

Article:

The U.S. Senate on Thursday approved a bill, known as the Employer Non-Discrimination Act (ENDA), to ban workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. The final vote was 64-32, with 54 Democrats and 10 Republicans supporting the legislation.

The bill, which applies to work sites with more than 15 people, exempts religious organizations and the U.S. military. The legislation is intended to ensure that all citizens, regardless of where they live, can work without fear of discrimination based on their sexual orientation or gender identity.

The ENDA has been introduced in nearly every Congress since 1994. It came one vote shy of passage in 1996, but had not been given a full Senate vote since. Existing federal laws ban employer discrimination based on race, color, sex, nationality, religion, age, and disability.

The GOP-controlled House, however, is not scheduled to vote on the bill. Speaker John Boehner's office stated that he does not plan to allow a vote, citing concerns that the legislation will cost small-business jobs and increase "frivolous" litigation. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor's office also stated that there is no vote scheduled.

In a statement, President Obama urged House leaders to bring the bill up for a vote. "One party in one house of Congress should not stand in the way of millions of Americans who want to go to work each day and simply be judged by the job they do," he said.

Opponents argue that the legislation is unnecessary because most private businesses, including the vast majority of Fortune 500 companies, have self-adopted policies that prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation. Twenty-two states and Washington, D.C. have already enacted laws prohibiting such discrimination. A June 2013 Pew Research survey of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender adults reported that 21% of respondents said they have been treated unfairly at work because of their sexual orientation.

Title: House of Representatives Approves Budget Reconciliation Legislation to Repeal Affordable Care Act

Article:

The United States House of Representatives has passed legislation that allows Republicans to proceed with the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. The measure, which passed in the House 227-198, will now move to the Senate for approval.

The legislation, if passed, will enable Republicans to use a procedure known as "budget reconciliation" to dismantle key provisions of the healthcare law. The move comes amid concerns about the replacement of the law, as Republican leaders have expressed their intention to "repeal" and "replace" Obamacare simultaneously to avoid disruptions in healthcare coverage. However, they have yet to agree on a replacement plan.

House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin hailed the move as a "critical first step toward delivering relief to Americans who are struggling under this law." In a rare floor speech, Ryan stated, "This is a critical first step toward delivering relief to Americans who are struggling under this law."

Democrats, who are united in their opposition to the repeal, have criticized the move, with House minority leader Nancy Pelosi of California stating, "For six years they have had a chance to propose an alternative. We see nothing."

The Affordable Care Act, signed into law by President Barack Obama in 2010, covers an estimated 20 million Americans. Republicans have been trying to repeal the law since its passage. With both chambers of Congress and the White House now in Republican control, they finally have the opportunity to do so.

President-elect Donald Trump, who campaigned on the promise of repealing the law on "day one" and replacing it with "something terrific," has offered few details about his proposal. During a CNN town hall meeting, House Speaker Ryan stated that Congress would draft a replacement plan "definitely within these first 100 days" of Trump's presidency.

The repeal process is only a first step. Lawmakers will now begin drafting the legislation to replace the bill, a lengthy and exhaustive process that will take place across four committees.

In a separate development, Congress also approved legislation that would allow retired Marine General James Mattis to become defense secretary, granting him an exemption from the law that bars former service members who have been out of uniform for less than seven years from holding the top job at the Pentagon. The measure is expected to be signed by President Obama before he leaves office next week.

Title: Supreme Court Hears Oral Arguments on Presidential Immunity and Investigations

Article:

The Supreme Court heard oral arguments on Tuesday, via teleconference, regarding the power to investigate the President of the United States. The case, which involves President Donald Trump's tax returns and other financial records, stems from New York City prosecutors' demand for these documents as part of a criminal investigation into the president's hush money payments to porn actress Stormy Daniels, as well as the House of Representatives' investigation into potential conflicts of interest of a president who still owns a business.

Trump's lawyers have argued that a president should not be subject to investigation while in office. "We're asking for temporary presidential immunity," attorney Jay Sekulow said.

Andrea Bernstein of "Trump, Inc." and NYU law professor Melissa Murray listened to the oral arguments and discussed their observations with co-host Ilya Marritz. A few takeaways:

1. Fights between the legislative and executive branches are not normally heard in front of the Supreme Court. Congress and the White House have typically negotiated solutions to such disputes. "And the fact that we're in court is because this president hasn't acceded to those norms," Murray said.

2. The phrase "presidential harassment" was repeatedly mentioned. This language, used frequently by Trump on Twitter and raised by his lawyers in court, has transformed what would be considered, in other times, ordinary and essential legislative oversight into what accounts to bullying, harassment, and mere partisan politics, according to Murray.

3. A number of the justices, including the liberal Stephen Breyer, expressed sympathy for the White House's arguments against the House's demands for documents, but they were far more skeptical about the claim that the president is immune from even criminal investigation. "The court seemed not to be amenable to that kind of argument at all," Murray said.

The justices are expected to deliver a decision in the cases—Trump v. Mazars, Trump v. Deutsche Bank, and Trump v. Vance—this summer.

For more updates on WNYC's ongoing investigations, sign up for email notifications from WNYC and ███. You can contact us via Signal, WhatsApp, or voicemail at 347-244-2134. For secure communication, here's more about how you can contact us:

"Trump, Inc." is a production of WNYC Studios and ███. Support our work by visiting donate.███.org or by becoming a supporting member of WNYC. Subscribe here or wherever you get your podcasts.

Title: Right-wing Media's Denial of Racism: A Dangerous Fiction

Article:

Recent controversial remarks from Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy and Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling have brought to light a recurring theme in right-wing media: the denial of the existence of racism in contemporary America. This perspective, which has also surfaced in recent Supreme Court decisions, provides a cover for modern racists and policies that negatively impact minorities.

Fox News personality Eric Bolling, among others, has asserted that there is no racism. This viewpoint, which has become commonplace within the conservative media sphere, is echoed by Fox contributor Charles Krauthammer, who argues that policies protecting against racial discrimination are no longer necessary because they are perceived as giving "advantages to people who 50 years ago" were disadvantaged. Co-host of Fox's The Five, Andrea Tantaros, has argued that civil rights laws are no longer needed "because there is equality." Bill O'Reilly has stated that racism is "an individual problem," "not a country problem," and that America's history of discrimination is "all in the past."

This willingness to ignore the existence of racism provides a cover for intolerance on the fringe. In the past month, right-wing media has propelled Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy to folk hero status for evading millions in federal taxes, only to distance themselves when he was caught on tape questioning the circumstances of black people's enslavement. Similarly, billionaire Donald Sterling, the owner of the NBA's Los Angeles Clippers, was banned for life from the NBA after his alleged racist comments to his mistress were exposed.

While many Fox News hosts and contributors eventually condemned Bundy and Sterling's racism, the rhetoric is reminiscent of right-wing media's stereotypes of minorities and denial of the existence of racism. In the wake of their racist rants, both Bundy and Sterling denied they held any racist views.

Bundy and Sterling are extreme examples of cognitive dissonance, but the racism-denialist mindset is a pervasive and dangerous one. The Supreme Court's recent decision in Schuette v. BAMN, which effectively overturned decades of civil rights precedent and gutted a core component of equal protection law, is evidence of this.

In her dissenting opinion, Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote about a country where the Bundys and Sterlings still hold considerable sway. She went beyond the simple bigotry of the Bundys and Sterlings and found that more subtle wounds of racism still exist in this country. "Race matters," she wrote, "because of the slights, the snickers, the silent judgments that reinforce that most crippling of thoughts: 'I do not belong here.'"

Decisions made and policies created on the premise that racism no longer exists in America have damaging impacts on civil rights and minority communities. The Supreme Court's recent decision in Michigan, which opened a door for state majorities to change their political systems to unfairly disadvantage minorities, is evidence of this. Such consequences are already being felt by minority students in Michigan, with a dramatic decrease in African-American student enrollment.

The Supreme Court's recent disregard for history and legal precedent is reminiscent of the court's June 2013 blow to voting rights, a decision also made on the premise that racism no longer exists in America but in reality had a negative impact on minorities. In the June 25 decision, the conservative majority invalidated the provision within the Voting Rights Act that prevents states and local jurisdictions from enacting racially discriminatory election practices. States wasted no time after the Supreme Court's gutting of the Voting Rights Act pushing highly restrictive voting laws that history has shown serve to make it harder for minorities to cast a vote.

Apparently, within the conservative bubble, it's easy to praise such devastating policies so long as you deny the existence of racism at all, a refrain that ultimately helps keep discrimination alive.

Title: Neil Gorsuch's Judicial Philosophy and Speech at Case Western University School of Law

Article:

Neil Gorsuch, a justice on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, delivered a lecture at Case Western University School of Law in 2016, where he discussed the need for reform of the civil justice system. However, the sudden death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia led Gorsuch to shift the focus of his speech to the legacy of Scalia.

In his speech, titled "Of Lions and Bears, Judges and Legislators, and the Legacy of Justice Scalia," Gorsuch outlined his and Scalia's shared judicial philosophy. He emphasized that judges should apply the law as it is, focusing on text, structure, and history to determine the law's meaning at the time of the events in question. Gorsuch argued against deciding cases based on personal moral convictions or policy considerations.

Gorsuch stated that judges should use traditional tools of interpretation to determine the law, rather than shaping the law according to their political views. He also highlighted the importance of impartiality, stating that judges should regularly issue judgments with which they may disagree, as they believe that is what the law demands.

Gorsuch expressed his belief that the traditional account of the judicial role, which Scalia defended, will endure. He acknowledged the criticism and temptations to join the critics but remained optimistic about the enduring nature of this judicial philosophy.

In a separate context, Neil Gorsuch is a federal judge nominated by President Donald Trump to serve as an associate justice on the Supreme Court. His nomination and confirmation have been a topic of debate, with some supporting and others opposing his appointment. Further information about Gorsuch's background, case for, and arguments against his nomination can be found in other articles.

Title: House of Representatives Begins Process to Dismantle Affordable Care Act

Article:

The House of Representatives initiated the process of dismantling the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) on Friday, approving a budget resolution on a largely party-line vote. The Senate passed the measure earlier in the week. This resolution allows Republicans in Congress to use a process known as "budget reconciliation" to roll back significant parts of the health care law.

Nine Republicans crossed party lines to vote against the measure, including Reps. Justin Amash, Charlie Dent, Brian Fitzpatrick, Walter Jones, John Katko, Raul Labrador, Tom MacArthur, Thomas Massie, and Tom McClintock. No Democrats voted for the resolution.

Representative Dent, a Pennsylvania moderate, expressed concerns about the lack of a clear plan to replace Obamacare, stating, "If there's uncertainty and these markets are already collapsing without us doing anything, this type of action could accelerate the collapse. So we have to make sure we have a clear idea of how we're going to land this plane."

Representative MacArthur of New Jersey stated, "I couldn't vote because I think we're going a little too fast." However, he added, "That said, I understand Leadership's goals, and I agree with them. We have to fix what is clearly broken with Obamacare. We have to fix that. I have for years said we have to repeal and replace."

Amash, a Michigan Republican, opposed the measure due to broader concerns about government spending. The vote also approved budget guidelines for the current fiscal year.

The focus of the debate is primarily on Obamacare, which is expected to dominate much of the time in Washington in the coming months. House Majority Whip Steve Scalise stated, "This is a signal that we are very serious about what we've campaigned on for years. It's the very beginning."

House Speaker Paul Ryan compared the current situation to the debate in 2010, stating, "My colleagues, this experiment has failed. This law is collapsing as we speak. And we have to step in before things get even worse. This is nothing short of a rescue mission."

Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who led the passage of the law in 2009 and 2010 when Democrats controlled the House, accused Republicans of attempting to "cut and run" on people with health insurance and argued that Republicans would end up cutting Medicare benefits as well.

By using the budget process, Republicans are taking advantage of the same process Democrats used seven years ago to pass the law, using a special budgeting rule that allows them to skirt a filibuster in the Senate. However, this strategy only works for fiscal measures in the healthcare law, like tax credits, and leaves untouched some of the more popular slices of the law, such as allowing children to stay on their parents' plans until they are 26.

The vote will clear the decks for Republicans to begin working on a repeal of the law, but the larger debate has engulfed the Capitol over how and when Republicans would replace the law. The debate over replacement has exposed some rifts within the Republican Party, which now controls the White House and both chambers of Congress.

Competing plans to replace Obamacare exist, and No. 2 Senate Republican John Cornyn has indicated that the party may opt to move smaller pieces of legislation as opposed to one overarching replacement. Ryan told CNN's Jake Tapper at a town hall that the goal is to move everything at once. "We want to do this at the same time, and in some cases in the same bill," Ryan said. "So we want to advance repealing this law with its replacement at the same time."

Title: Democratic Fundraising Outpaces Incumbent President Trump in 2020 Race

Article:

The seventh Democratic primary debate of the 2020 presidential campaign season took place on January 14, 2020, at Drake University campus in Des Moines, Iowa. In a notable distinction, President Donald Trump's reelection bid has been outraised by the Democratic presidential candidates in 2019, according to an analysis of Federal Election Commission filings and campaign statements.

No incumbent president this century has been so thoroughly outraised by a field of challengers in the year before a reelection contest. In 2012, the main Republican challengers to President Barack Obama in 2012 barely took in more than the incumbent in 2011. President George W. Bush narrowly topped his challengers in fundraising in 2003, the year before he won reelection in 2004.

Sarah Bryner, director of research and strategy at the Center for Responsive Politics, stated, "The field is trouncing Trump in fundraising, and that is unprecedented." Bryner attributed this cash edge to a Democratic voter base energized and motivated since Trump's 2016 election. She added that the pace of donations could reflect a dislike of Trump more than a fondness for any particular candidates, though Democratic contender and prolific fundraiser Sen. Bernie Sanders has a famously devoted following.

Trump still had a fundraising advantage over any of his potential challengers entering 2020. His campaign reported raising $46 million in the fourth quarter, higher than Sanders' $34.5 million, the biggest haul in the Democratic field. The Trump campaign had more than $100 million in the bank at the end of 2019, while most Democratic campaigns will not announce cash on hand numbers until the end of the month.

The following table and visualization list the fundraising figures for Trump, his two predecessors, and their challengers in the year prior to their reelection bids, with total receipts (which include transfers from other campaign committees) and contributions from individuals listed separately.

| Year | Incumbent President | Total Receipts | Contributions from Individuals |
|------|---------------------|---------------|---------------------------------|
| 2019 | Donald Trump        | $143.1M       | $125.5M                         |
| 2011 | Barack Obama        | $75.0M        | $60.2M                         |
| 2003 | George W. Bush       | $100.0M       | $80.0M                         |
| 2003 | Democratic Challengers | $27.0M      | $22.0M                         |
| 2019 | Democratic Challengers | $139.7M     | $122.2M                         |

Title: Six Democratic Presidential Candidates Face Off in Iowa Debate as Tensions Rise

Article:

The first Democratic presidential debate of 2020 took place in Des Moines on Tuesday night, less than three weeks before the Iowa caucuses. The event, hosted by CNN, featured a slim cast of six hopefuls: Senators Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Amy Klobuchar; former Vice President Joseph R. Biden; Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana; and billionaire Tom Steyer.

The debate comes amidst a growing rift between Senators Sanders and Warren, who are both vying for the progressive vote. Nate Ashworth, editor of Election Central, wrote that the election is now underway, and the Democratic hopefuls are foes and rivals, not friends.

The Washington Post declared that the debate was a "battle for heads, not hearts." The Los Angeles Times advised that "uncertainty reigns" in the run-up to the debate.

In other news, Texas Governor Greg Abbott presented the Governor's Medal of Courage, the Lone Star State's highest civilian award, to Jack Wilson. Wilson, a former reserve deputy sheriff, took out a shooter who opened fire in a Fort Worth church in late December, killing two members of the church. Wilson, 71, heads up the church's volunteer security squad.

President Trump will hold another rally in Milwaukee on Tuesday. The rally, which takes place in the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Panther Arena, has caused controversy among students, leading Chancellor Mark Mone to explain that the campus has naming rights for the venue but does not own or control the site.

A Pew Research Center poll of 6,878 U.S. adults conducted Sept. 16-29 and released Friday found that 66% of U.S. adults say the federal government should have "a lot of responsibility" in reducing economic inequality in the U.S. Other findings include:

- 62% overall say large business and corporations should have responsibility
- 52% overall say state governments should have responsibility
- 46% overall say wealthy individuals should have responsibility
- 13% overall say churches and religious organizations have the responsibility

The poll also found that 44% of Republicans and 75% of Democrats agree that the federal government should have a lot of responsibility in reducing economic inequality. The poll did not provide specific numbers for other demographics.

Title: President Obama Addresses Baltimore Riots: Six Points on Ongoing Crisis

Article:

In a surprise move during a scheduled news conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Tuesday, President Barack Obama addressed the ongoing Baltimore riots, offering six points on the issue that he had carefully outlined in notes ahead of the conference. The focus of the meeting was originally intended to be on trade and the formalities of a state visit.

The president's six points essentially boiled down to one main point: "This has been a slow-rolling crisis. This has been going on a long time."

Obama expressed concern that sending police to contain the situation would not solve the problem, stating, "If we think that we’re just going to send police to do the dirty work of containment, we’re not going to solve this problem." He apologized to Prime Minister Abe for deviating from the intended topic, acknowledging that the issue was essentially irrelevant to the Japanese relationship.

The president has historically been criticized for his comments on race, and he has felt that his previous remarks have been misconstrued. In 2009, he was criticized for stating that the police acted "stupidly" in arresting Henry Louis Gates, which led to a "beer summit" to calm tensions. In 2012, his comments about Trayvon Martin, "If I had a son, he'd look like Trayvon," sparked controversy. Last year, during the Ferguson unrest, he was criticized for appearing too deferential to the police and not showing enough anger, while he was on vacation instead of joining the marches.

White House aides stated that Obama's lengthy, deliberative response was not intended to initiate a long, end-of-term conversation about race in America. Despite becoming more comfortable discussing race over his time in office, the president's views on the subject have not significantly changed. His six points were an attempt to express his current thoughts on the issue while navigating the other challenges he has faced over the years.

In his address, Obama expressed sympathy for the family of Freddie Gray, avoiding assigning blame or making any statements that could interfere with the Justice Department's investigation into Gray's death while in police custody. He also expressed sympathy for the police officers injured in the riots and their families. The president condemned the rioters' violence, stating that they were not protesting or making a statement, but stealing.

Obama emphasized that focusing solely on the violence distracts from both the peaceful protests and the efforts to defuse the violence. He argued that he has taken action, having established a task force on policing and working with local communities to implement police reforms.

The president acknowledged the difficulty in federalizing every police force and forcing them to undergo retraining. However, he stated that he could collaborate with them to facilitate change within their departments.

In his sixth and final point, Obama called for national introspection, stating that people, not just those with sons who resemble Trayvon Martin, need to take responsibility for the children suffering in disadvantaged communities, many of whom are black. He emphasized that if the country truly wanted to solve the problem, it could, but only if it considered those children as its own and prioritized their well-being.

The president will continue to discuss race and inequality, but in the context of other priorities, such as criminal justice reform, job training, early childhood education, and his mentoring program for black youth called "My Brother's Keeper." However, without congressional funding or local leadership, these initiatives may not make significant progress.

"What I’ve tried to do is to promote those ideas that would make a difference," Obama concluded. "But I think we all understand that the politics of that are tough because it’s easy to ignore those problems or to treat them just as a law-and-order issue, as opposed to a broader social issue."

Title: Key Questions Arise Over Bergdahl-Taliban Prisoner Swap

Article:

The recent prisoner swap between the United States and the Taliban, which resulted in the release of long-missing Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, has sparked a wave of criticism from lawmakers who have labeled the move as both reckless and lawless. The White House is now facing questions about the decision, including why Congress was not informed of the deal beforehand, as federal law requires, and what went into the administration's media strategy.

President Barack Obama defended his administration's efforts to rescue Bergdahl from captivity during a speech in Warsaw on Tuesday. He stated, "Regardless of the circumstances, whatever those circumstances may turn out to be, we still get an American soldier back if he's held in captivity. Period. Full stop. We don't condition that."

However, the president's arguments are unlikely to quell the questions. Concerns include the potential precedent the deal could set for other individuals in U.S. custody and American service members who might be captured in the future. The future of Sgt. Bergdahl remains uncertain.

Here are some key questions about the Bergdahl-Taliban trade:

1. Did the administration comply with the 30-day notification requirement for transferring prisoners out of Guantanamo Bay? Over the weekend, it appeared that the administration had not complied with the legislation requiring the president to give Congress 30 days' notice before transferring prisoners. However, the formal notification did not take place until Monday, according to congressional officials.

2. What was the administration's media strategy regarding the Bergdahl case? The administration's media strategy, including comments made by National Security Adviser Susan Rice on a Sunday morning talk show, is under fresh scrutiny.

3. What was the rationale for the president's decision to act without Congressional notification? The White House has stated that they had earlier briefed Congress on the outlines of a possible swap.

4. What is the health status of Sgt. Bergdahl? Some Republicans have questioned whether Bergdahl was in grave health, as administration officials claimed was the reason for not abiding by the 30-day notification requirement.

5. How does the Bergdahl-Taliban trade compare to the Benghazi controversy? Some Republicans see the prisoner swap as a reflection of what is wrong with President Obama's leadership, particularly his tendency to negotiate with foreign actors and disregard the rule of law.

The prisoner swap is becoming a significant point of contention, particularly within conservative circles, and may have lasting implications for U.S. policy regarding the treatment and release of detainees.

Title: Celebrity Anti-Semitic Remarks and the Apatholypse: A Threat to Social Justice

Article:

Recent incidents of anti-Semitic comments from sports and entertainment celebrities have raised concerns about the future of the Black Lives Matter movement and the overall state of social justice. The muted response to these incidents is troubling, as one might expect a more passionate public outcry given the current climate of "New Woke-fulness" in Hollywood and the sports world.

In June, rapper and actor Ice Cube posted a series of tweets that implied Jews were responsible for the oppression of blacks. NFL player DeSean Jackson shared several anti-Semitic messages, including a quote incorrectly attributed to Hitler, stating that Jews had a plan to "extort America" and achieve "world domination." NBA player Stephen Jackson, a self-proclaimed activist, agreed with DeSean Jackson's anti-Semitic comments and expressed support for Louis Farrakhan, a notorious homophobe and anti-Semite.

Performer Chelsea Handler, who is Jewish, posted videos of Farrakhan to her 3.9 million followers. This means nearly 4 million people received a subliminal message that some Jews support anti-Semitism.

President Donald Trump's reelection campaign has also been criticized for exploiting anti-Jewish biases, despite the fact that Trump's son-in-law and campaign advisor Jared Kushner is Jewish and his daughter Ivanka converted to Judaism before they married. The campaign issued a letter accusing three billionaires of Jewish descent of using their fortunes to "rig the November election."

These incidents share the same scapegoat logic as oppressive groups throughout history, blaming a minority group for societal problems. It is disheartening to see people from marginalized groups perpetuating this kind of prejudice without realizing that it perpetuates racism.

Some of the celebrities involved have apologized, while others continue to defend their comments. Their responses have confirmed people's worst opinions rather than dissuading them. In a CNN interview, Stephen Jackson was angry and belligerent when called out for his comments, stating, "I stated I could have changed my words. There's nothing that I said that I support any of that. There's nothing I said that I hate anybody."

In 2013, there were 751 reported hate crimes against Jews, but by 2019, the number had nearly tripled to 2,107. In the same year, a gunman in San Diego entered a synagogue and murdered one person while wounding three.

The song "Strange Fruit," written by a white, Jewish high school teacher, Abel Meeropol, and performed by Billie Holiday, is a powerful example of the struggle against racism. The song, which was first recorded in 1939, met strong resistance from radio stations afraid of its graphic lyrics about lynching, but it went on to sell a million copies that year and became Holiday's best-selling record ever.

The lesson never changes: No one is free until everyone is free. As Martin Luther King Jr. explained, "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere. We are caught in an inescapable network of mutuality." Let's act like it. If we're going to be outraged by injustice, let's be outraged by injustice against anyone.

Title: Obama: Individuals Responsible for VA Record Manipulation to be Held Accountable

Article:

President Barack Obama has stated that anyone found to have manipulated or falsified Veterans Affairs (VA) records will be held accountable. The president's comments were made during a meeting with White House deputy chief of staff Rob Nabors, who has been detailed to work with the VA since last week.

Speaking about reports of long wait times and efforts to cover up delays, Obama described the behavior as "dishonorable" and "disgraceful" if proven true. He emphasized that he will not tolerate such actions and neither should anyone else.

The president mentioned that Nabors is currently investigating reports of misleading statistics about veteran care at a facility in Phoenix, Arizona. Obama mentioned accountability several times in his prepared remarks, noting that some employees had already been placed on administrative leave.

Obama also addressed the challenges faced by the VA, citing an influx of new veterans from recent U.S. military conflicts and an aging population of Baby Boomer veterans. He stated that there are 85 million appointments scheduled over a year.

The president defended Secretary of Veterans Affairs Eric Shinseki, stating, "No one cares more about our veterans." However, he added that he expects accountability and improvement in the full report on the VA's problems.

Earlier this month, Shinseki told NPR's Robert Siegel that he would take swift and appropriate action if reports that the Phoenix Veterans Affairs Health Care system kept two lists of veterans waiting for care – one for sharing with Washington and another showing wait times that sometimes reached beyond a year – were substantiated.

The VA is currently the subject of two main inquiries: an inspector general investigation of hospitals accused of fudging their reported statistics, and a broader audit ordered by Shinseki of all VA health centers. The findings of both inquiries are expected to be released this summer.

Title: Obama Addresses Race in America: A National Conversation on Race and the Trayvon Martin Case

Article:

In the aftermath of the George Zimmerman acquittal in the killing of Trayvon Martin, a national conversation on race has been a prominent topic in the United States. Simon, a political columnist, expresses relief that the conversation has come to an end, stating that it was a draining and exhausting experience that lasted for more than a week.

The president, Barack Obama, spoke movingly and personally about race in an unexpected appearance in the White House briefing room on Friday. Obama stated that the African-American community is looking at the issue of race through a set of experiences and a history that "doesn't go away."

Obama's most quoted line was "Trayvon Martin could have been me 35 years ago." He went on to discuss the pain felt by the African-American community and the experiences of racial profiling and stereotypes that many African-Americans face.

Obama expressed that politicians trying to organize conversations on race have not been productive, and instead, suggested that deep, serious, and difficult discussions should take place in families, churches, and workplaces. He encouraged people to ask themselves if they are wringing as much bias out of themselves as they can and judging people based on the content of their character rather than the color of their skin.

The president has already moved on to other topics, with a White House release announcing that he will spend the week delivering a series of speeches on rebuilding an economy that puts the middle class and those fighting to join it front and center.

Roger Simon, the author of the article, expresses his agreement with Obama's suggestion for deep and serious discussions on race, but notes that such conversations are unlikely to take place on a national scale. Simon is the chief political columnist for ███ and the author of the e-book "RECKONING: Campaign 2012 and the Fight for the Soul of America."

Title: APA Survey Reveals Rising Stress Levels Among Americans Over Election, Health Care, and Mass Shootings

Article:

The American Psychological Association (APA) has released its annual "Stress in America" survey, revealing that sociocultural issues, including the 2020 presidential election, access to health care, and mass shootings, are causing the most stress for American citizens. The survey, conducted between August 1 and September 3, polled 3,617 adults across the U.S.

The survey indicates that while overall stress levels have not significantly changed over the past few years, the proportion of Americans who find specific issues stressful has risen over the past year.

The 2020 election is already a significant stressor for 56% of adults, a year before Election Day. This is an increase from the 52% who found the 2016 presidential election stressful. The election is proving to be a more stressful topic for survey respondents identifying as Democrats, versus those identifying as Republicans, by almost 25%.

The survey also cites 69% of adults pointing to health care, specifically the costs thereof, as a notable point of stress. Additionally, 71% of adults cited mass shootings as stressful, making it the most common source of stress among those surveyed, with a rise of almost 10% from the APA's 2018 survey.

Other stressful topics cited include climate change, immigration, national security, and abortion. The presence of these "hot-button" issues in the news cycle is likely not a coincidence, the APA found. In 2019, 54% of those surveyed said they "want to stay informed," but that the news is stressful. 39% of respondents said they have "taken steps over the past year to reduce their news consumption."

The impact of discrimination was also deemed stressful by a majority of survey respondents identifying as part of a minority community. 63% of people of color surveyed said that discrimination has kept them from having a fully productive life. 64% of LGBT adults surveyed said the same thing.

Stress levels as a whole decreased drastically across respondents categorized by age group, the survey found. Members of the baby boomer generation and "older adults" were found to have significantly lower average stress levels, and their younger Gen X, Gen Z, and millennial peers.

Arthur C. Evans Jr., APA's chief executive officer, said in a statement accompanying the survey's release, "There is a lot of uncertainty in our world right now. While [there] are important societal issues that need to be addressed, the results also reinforce the need to have more open conversations about the impact of stress and stress management, especially with groups that are experiencing high levels of stress."

The survey found that 59% of those surveyed felt they had not received enough emotional support to mitigate their stress levels. Research shows that prolonged feelings of anxiety and stress can affect overall physical and mental health, Evans noted.

According to the APA, the best ways to manage stress are to get a good amount of sleep every night, exercise regularly, and maintain a healthy network of social support.

Title: U.S. Stocks Rise as Tech and Energy Sectors Gain, Dollar Falls

Article:

U.S. stocks rose on Wednesday, with tech and energy sectors leading the gains, while the dollar fell and Treasuries clawed back from an early retreat amid speculation the Federal Reserve may soften its stance on raising interest rates. Most major U.S. equity benchmarks were up in light pre-Thanksgiving trading, although they gave back some ground in the afternoon to finish near session lows.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended flat, while the small-capitalization Russell 2000 Index climbed 1.3 percent to pace the gains. The Nasdaq 100 Index wiped out nearly half of its decline from Tuesday. Energy was the strongest group in the S&P 500 Index, as WTI crude rebounded from a one-year low to leap back above $54 a barrel.

Apple Inc. surrendered an earlier gain to close down for a third straight day, bringing its loss this week to 8.6 percent. Foot Locker Inc. jumped 15 percent, the most since May, after posting strong third-quarter earnings. CBS Corp. rose amid speculation of a coming merger with Viacom Inc., which also saw its stock climb. Gap Inc. added almost 5 percent despite reporting weak earnings as investors appeared to finally buy the dip on a company that had lost almost 10 percent this month.

The dollar weakened after MNI reported the Fed is considering ending a cycle of interest rate hikes as early as the spring. In addition, U.S. data showed that durable goods orders declined, and filings for unemployment benefits rose.

Banks and telecommunications companies led an advance in the Stoxx Europe 600 Index as optimism for a compromise on Italy's budget buoyed stocks. The euro gained and Italian bonds firmed on reports the Italian government may be open to budget revisions as the European Union took a first step toward imposing fines on the country.

Elsewhere, emerging-market shares climbed, and an index tracking developing-nation currencies reached the highest since August. Bitcoin advanced after a recent sell-off. It's a shortened trading week because of the Thanksgiving holiday in the U.S. In addition, Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving, marks the traditional start to the U.S. holiday shopping season.

The S&P 500 rose 0.3 percent to 2,649.93, and the Nasdaq 100 gained 0.8 percent. The Japanese yen declined 0.3 percent to 113.07 per dollar. The MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index rose 0.1 percent to the highest since August. The yield on 10-year Treasuries was little changed at 3.0609 percent. Germany's 10-year yield climbed three basis points to 0.376 percent. Britain's 10-year yield added one basis point to 1.396 percent. West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2 percent to $54.48 a barrel, the largest gain in seven weeks.

Title: President Obama Praises Ongoing National Dialogue on Race Relations as Healthy for the U.S.

Article:

In an interview with National Public Radio (NPR), President Barack Obama expressed his belief that the ongoing national dialogue about race relations, particularly minority communities' interactions with law enforcement, is beneficial for the United States. He stated that the protests in cities such as New York and Ferguson, Missouri, are not evidence of increased racial tensions but rather a sign that the issue has come to the forefront, potentially leading to long-term solutions.

The president recorded the interview before departing for a two-week vacation in Hawaii. He asserted that the nation's racial divide has not worsened over the past six years, and the protests are a positive development that brings attention to the issue.

"I actually think that the issue has surfaced in a way that probably is healthy," Mr. Obama said. "The issue of police and communities of color being mistrustful of each other is hardly new; that dates back a long time. It's just something that hasn't been talked about, and for a variety of reasons."

The president has addressed the issue multiple times in recent months, including after grand jury decisions in New York and Ferguson not to charge white police officers in connection with the deaths of black men. He also condemned violence after a gunman assassinated two NYPD officers, claiming he acted in retaliation against law enforcement for its treatment of the black community.

On a broader scale, the president stated that many white Americans have beliefs on racially tinged issues that stem not from racism but from a lack of information or social awareness. For example, he said white Americans may not understand that African-Americans statistically are more likely to be pulled over by police.

"If you'd asked whites in those jurisdictions — ‘Do you think traffic stops were done fairly?— the majority of whites probably would say yes because it's not something they experience," Mr. Obama said. "It's not because of racism. It's just that it's not something that they see."

Title: Ted Cruz Outlines Strategy to Unite Republican Delegates and Trump Supporters

Article:

In an interview with Mark Halperin and John Heilemann for Bloomberg Television's With All Due Respect, Senator Ted Cruz has expressed his strategy for winning over Donald Trump's supporters, even if he does not secure Trump's endorsement. Cruz believes that if he earns a majority of delegates at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, he can continue to energize and unite Trump supporters for the November election.

Cruz highlighted his effectiveness in appealing to blue-collar workers, a key demographic within Trump's base, stating, "The issues that energize and excite the Trump voters—illegal immigration, securing the border, keeping this country safe, and bringing jobs back to America—bringing them back from China, back from Mexico—those issues are right at the heart of our campaign."

Trump has predominantly won among voters who have not graduated from college, but Cruz won those voters in Wisconsin, the most recent primary. Trump has threatened "riots" and suggested his supporters will abandon the Republican Party en masse if he is denied the nomination at the July convention. Cruz acknowledged the potential for divisions within the party at a contested convention but emphasized the support he has received from other Republican candidates, such as Rick Perry, Lindsey Graham, Jeb Bush, Scott Walker, and Carly Fiorina.

Cruz also mentioned that his campaign is currently examining potential vice presidential nominees and pointed to the original GOP field as evidence of an "abundance of good choices" for the position. The socially conservative candidate declined to offer his opinion on Bruce Springsteen's decision to cancel a concert in North Carolina due to the state's controversial "bathroom law." Cruz argued that both Springsteen and the people of North Carolina have free speech rights, and that the people of North Carolina are entitled to pass laws that reflect their values.

The full interview is set to air Friday at 5:00 p.m. Eastern time on Bloomberg TV's With All Due Respect.

Title: Georgia's Sixth Congressional District Special Election Results in a Runoff Between Jon Ossoff and Karen Handel

Article:

The special election for Georgia's Sixth Congressional District has resulted in a runoff between upstart Democrat Jon Ossoff and former Georgia Secretary of State Karen Handel. The election, held on Tuesday, failed to produce an outright winner, as Ossoff garnered 48 percent of the vote, falling just short of the majority threshold required in the so-called "jungle primary."

Handel, the top GOP vote-getter, received 20 percent of the vote, comfortably ahead of technology executive Bob Gray, who received 11 percent, and former State Senators Judson Hill and Dan Moody, who each received 9 percent of the vote.

In a tweet late Tuesday, Gray expressed support for Handel, stating, "We are going to rally around Karen Handel. We wish her Godspeed."

The winner of the runoff between Handel and Ossoff will succeed Tom Price, who resigned to become Trump's health and human services secretary.

Ossoff, a 30-year-old documentary filmmaker and former congressional aide, had sought to capitalize on opposition to President Donald Trump to secure an outright victory that would have emboldened Democrats ahead of the 2018 midterm elections. His campaign attracted more than $8 million in donations, most of which came from outside the state.

Republicans nationally and in Georgia acknowledged before polls opened that Ossoff would likely top the slate of 11 Republicans, five Democrats, and two independents who appeared together on one primary ballot. Earlier Tuesday, the GOP criticized Ossoff for living outside the district and portrayed him as a conservative's nightmare who would increase taxes and take away guns.

The Republican National Committee issued a statement, saying, "These liberal Democrats failed to inspire voters with a candidate who couldn’t even vote for himself, received 97 percent of his donations from outside the district, and consistently lied about his own weak resume."

Ossoff acknowledged Tuesday that he lives just south of the district, in Atlanta, so that his girlfriend is close to her work at Emory University's medical complex.

Republican groups ran a blitz of ads trying to tie Ossoff to House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) has spent more than $2 million on these and other attacks.

Trump himself posted several messages on Twitter encouraging Republicans to vote in the special election and recorded a get-out-the-vote call, saying, "Liberal Democrats from outside of Georgia are spending millions and millions of dollars trying to take your Republican congressional seat away from you. Don’t let them do it."

Trump posted another tweet early Wednesday, saying, "Despite major outside money, FAKE media support and eleven Republican candidates, BIG 'R' win with runoff in Georgia. Glad to be of help!"

National attention on the Georgia race, already significant, intensified after last week's closer-than-expected GOP victory in a Kansas special House election. Trump did not perform as well as other Republicans last November in the Georgia district, an affluent, well-educated swath of Atlanta's northern suburbs filled with the kind of voters Democrats need if they hope to reclaim a House majority next year.

Handel has maintained her distance from Trump, rarely discussing him unless asked. Polling day took a bizarre turn in the district when key electronic voting logs were swiped from a Cobb County poll worker's pickup truck. The chairman of the county's Republican Party told media outlets that the theft raised the specter of fraud. However, there were no reports of voting irregularities at Cobb County polling places Tuesday.

Title: 97% of Scientists Agree: Humans Contribute to Climate Change, Yet Public Trust in Scientific Community Remains Low

Article:

A study by the University of Wisconsin indicates that only 42% of American adults have a great deal of confidence in the scientific community. This lack of trust, combined with other factors, contributes to the ongoing debate about climate change, despite a 97% consensus among scientific experts that humans are causing global warming.

Anthony Leiserowitz, the director of the Yale Project on Climate Change Communication, has been studying the reasons behind this debate for over a decade. He identified six categories of responses to the issue: "The Alarmed," "The Concerned," "The Cautious," "The Disengaged," "The Doubtful," and "The Dismissives."

"The Alarmed" (16% of the public) believe climate change is an urgent problem but have no clear idea of how to fix it. "The Concerned" (27%) believe climate change is a problem but think it's more about polar bears and tiny islands than a problem that directly affects them. "The Cautious" (23%) are people on the fence, unsure whether global warming is real or man-made. "The Disengaged" (5%) are uninformed about climate change. "The Doubtful" (12%) do not think climate change is man-made, believing it's natural and poses no long-term risk.

Leiserowitz considers "The Dismissives" (15%) the most problematic, as they deny the existence of climate change or claim it's a hoax, often citing unfounded conspiracy theories. This vocal minority has been amplified by the media, political stage, and funding from organizations within the fossil fuel industry.

A recent study by Drexel University found that conservative foundations and others have bankrolled climate denial to the tune of $558 million between 2003 and 2010. This infusion of cash has given these voices a megaphone in the public square, according to environmental scientist Robert J. Brulle, the study's author.

However, extreme weather events are forcing people to think about the impact of global warming on their lives, and religious leaders, including evangelicals, are increasingly taking a stand on the issue. The Pope may soon release an encyclical on ecology, instructing the faithful to respect the environment.

In the face of mounting evidence and growing awareness, the debate about climate change may gradually shift, as more people come to understand the urgency of the issue and the role humans play in it.

Title: U.S. Military Officials Provide Varying Explanations on Triggers for Airstrikes Against Islamic State in Syria

Article:

U.S. military officials have provided conflicting and sometimes confusing explanations regarding the triggers for U.S. airstrikes against Islamic State targets in Syria. On Monday, Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Martin Dempsey appeared to tone down earlier comments he made about the growing terror network that has taken root in Iraq and Syria.

Dempsey, speaking to reporters on board a military plane traveling to Afghanistan, said he believes the Sunni insurgent group, formerly known as ISIS, is a regional threat, and he would not recommend airstrikes in Syria until they have become a direct threat to the U.S. He stated that the group is not currently plotting or planning attacks against the U.S. or Europe.

However, Dempsey's spokesman, Col. Ed Thomas, clarified to Fox News on Monday that Dempsey "believes that ISIS is a regional threat that will soon become a threat to the United States and Europe." Thomas added that Dempsey is preparing options to "address" ISIS in both Iraq and Syria "with a variety of military tools including airstrikes," and believes a coalition of partners is necessary to confront the threat.

Regarding what could prompt U.S. airstrikes in Syria, a senior U.S. Defense spokesman told Fox News that the judgment on whether the Islamic State is a threat against the homeland is just one trigger. "Any threats against U.S. personnel and interests could drive action against ISIL in Syria," the official said.

Last week, Dempsey and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel spoke in dire terms about the threat posed by the Islamic State, with Dempsey saying the organization could not be defeated without some action in Syria. The senior U.S. Defense spokesman said Monday that the message was the U.S. and its allies need a "long-term strategy" to separate ISIS from the population. "In the meantime, if we see a plot against the homeland, of course we'll attack it," the official said.

Asked Monday on Fox News whether the White House had pushed back on military officials' statements from last week, Pentagon spokesman Rear Adm. John Kirby said no. "There has been no direction from the White House or anybody else to tone down the way we're speaking about ISIL," Kirby said.

ISIS has repeatedly made threats to attack the U.S. through social and conventional media. Earlier this month, in a Vice News documentary, a spokesman for the group vowed to "raise the flag of Allah in the White House." The group took over Iraq's second largest city, Mosul, in June, and has since declared an Islamic state, or caliphate, in a swath of territory covering northeastern Syria and northern and western Iraq. U.S. airstrikes and a new policy of direct military aid to Kurdish Peshmerga fighters have served as a check on a threatened ISIS advance toward Kurdish territory in northern Iraq.

On Sunday, Dempsey contrasted ISIS with the Yemen-based Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, which has plotted and attempted attacks against the U.S. and Europe. As a result, the U.S. has conducted counterterrorism strikes against the group within Yemen. Dempsey said that so far, there is no sign that the Islamic State militants are engaged in "active plotting against the homeland," so it's different than that which we see in Yemen.

Dempsey also told reporters that he believes that key allies in the region -- including Jordan, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia -- will join the U.S. in quashing the Islamic State group.
