"I think ISIS has been so brutal, and has wrapped itself in a radical religious legitimacy that clearly threatens everybody I just mentioned, that I think they will be willing partners," said Dempsey, who added that those regional partners could come together and squeeze the Islamic State group "from multiple directions in order to initially disrupt and eventually defeat them." It has to happen with them, much less with us."

Up to now, when asked about airstrikes inside Syria, Dempsey and Hagel have said all options remain on the table. However, so far, there has been no broader authorization for such operations. The Obama administration has authorized airstrikes within Iraq to protect U.S. personnel and facilities and to help Iraqi and Kurdish forces assist refugees driven from their homes by the Islamic State. Most of the recent strikes have been around the Mosul Dam, which Islamic militants had taken, but it is now back in the hands of the Iraqi and Kurdish troops.

Senior U.S. leaders, from the White House to the Pentagon, have said the key to success in Iraq is the formation of an inclusive government that will include disenfranchised Sunnis. Officials have suggested that any additional military assistance from the U.S. to Iraq is contingent on those political and diplomatic steps by the government. One possibility, said Dempsey, would be to have U.S. forces provide more expanded advice and assistance to the Iraqi force. He said military assessment teams looked at about 50 Iraqi brigades and a number of the Kurdish units and have a good idea which ones have appropriate training and equipment and have not been infiltrated by militia. So far, Dempsey said the U.S. has not sought or received permission to put advisers into Iraqi brigades or headquarters units and accompany them into combat. To date, U.S. forces have conducted a total of 96 airstrikes across Iraq. Of those, 62 have been around the Mosul Dam.

Title: Senate Republicans and Democrats Differ on Sequester Cuts

Article:

Sen. John Barrasso (R-WY) stated on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday that the country should prepare for the sequester spending cuts to take effect on March 1, despite a proposal by Senate Democrats last week to delay the cuts. The sequester, aimed at reducing the deficit by $1.2 trillion over the next decade, was initially set to begin at the start of the year but was postponed by two months in the scaled-back fiscal cliff bill.

With less than two weeks remaining, lawmakers face another countdown before the sequester cuts are scheduled to commence. Senate Democrats proposed a $110 billion measure on Thursday to once again delay the cuts. The proposal includes increasing tax revenue from millionaires through closing loopholes, ending agriculture subsidies, and reducing defense spending after the war in Afghanistan ends.

Sen. Barrasso, along with other Senate Republicans, expressed displeasure with the proposal, particularly the provision dealing with tax revenue. "Taxes are off the table," he told CNN's chief political correspondent Candy Crowley. "The American people need to know that tax cuts are off the table, and the Republican Party is not in any way going to trade spending cuts for a tax increase."

President Barack Obama had vowed during his re-election campaign that the sequester would not occur, and he called on Congress earlier this month to pass a short-term measure to postpone the cuts. However, when his chief of staff, Denis McDonough, was questioned about it on NBC's "Meet the Press" on Sunday, McDonough sounded less certain the sequester would be prevented.

"I sure hope it doesn't (happen)," he said. To "ensure" the cuts do not take place, McDonough said, the president "will continue to make very reasonable and balanced proposals, as he has time and time again."

Meanwhile, Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York expressed optimism about the issue. "I think that Democrats have the high ground both substantively and politically, and we will win on this issue," he said on "State of the Union." He argued that Republicans have no choice but to "come on board."

"Their arguments are untenable and do not meet the favor of hardly anyone other than themselves and the few whose special interests they're protecting," he added.

Title: Democratic Candidates Embrace Protectionist Trade Policies, Mimicking Trump's Approach

Article:

In the 2020 presidential race, the likelihood of President Donald Trump securing a second term is expected to maintain his protectionist economic views and skepticism towards foreign trade as a guiding force in federal policy. This is evident as leading Democratic candidates, rather than distancing themselves from Trump's trade war-induced challenges for farmers and manufacturing workers, have been more inclined to address their concerns.

During Tuesday's debate, the Democratic candidates, while expressing disagreements with Trump's methods, generally agreed with his approach to trade policy. For instance, Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) praised the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), Trump's proposed replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), as an improvement over NAFTA. However, this improvement, as both Warren and Trump suggest, equates to less free trade.

The USMCA includes higher barriers to duty-free trade for automobiles and car parts, imposes new labor standards that increase the cost of manufacturing in Mexico, and has a 16-year sunset clause that introduces long-term uncertainty. While Warren is willing to support these steps, she also advocates for further protectionist measures.

Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) and South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg also endorsed Trump's USMCA deal, while former Vice President Joe Biden offered a generally positive review, though he did not explicitly endorse it. The only significant note of disagreement came from Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), who, like Warren, voted against NAFTA. Sanders criticized Trump's USMCA because it does not go far enough in his view.

The disagreement between Warren and Sanders on trade has garnered post-debate headlines, but the difference between their stances is primarily cosmetic. Both candidates aim for less free trade than currently exists, and both have expressed support for more trade barriers than what Trump has already implemented. This consensus that trade is detrimental to Americans, led by Trump, Warren, and Sanders, presents a challenge to those who favor free trade.

If any candidate in the Democratic primary field is expected to stand against this protectionist consensus, it would be Biden. He voted for NAFTA, attempted (and failed) to get Congress to pass the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) when he was part of the Obama administration, and occasionally makes valid points about the benefits of trade. However, Biden's stance on trade remains unclear, as he seems to be leaning towards the "no new trade deals" view advocated by Warren, albeit with fewer conditions.

The outcome of this trade policy shift, should Trump secure a second term, is likely to be detrimental for most, as it restricts free trade and may lead to economic turbulence for American farmers and manufacturers.

Title: U.S. Public Opinion on President Trump and Economic Conditions

Article:

A recent study by Pew Research Center revealed that a majority of Americans expressed various negative emotions towards President Donald Trump's statements. The survey found that 76 percent of Americans were "concerned," 70 percent were "confused," 69 percent were "embarrassed," 65 percent were "angry," 62 percent were "insulted," and 56 percent were "frightened" by the things Trump says.

However, these negative sentiments do not seem to significantly impact Trump's re-election chances, according to the article. The author cites three reasons for this:

1. The improvement in Americans' perception of economic conditions. The survey found that 76 percent of Americans rate economic conditions positively, an increase from 48 percent at the time of Trump's election.

2. The progressive left's perceived hostility towards mainstream values, as suggested by the ongoing controversy over J.K. Rowling's tweet defending a woman who was fired for her views on transgenderism.

3. The left's perceived overreaction and lack of accuracy in their criticisms of Trump, as the catastrophes they predict do not materialize, and the conspiracy theories they propose often prove unfounded.

The article also notes that Trump's average approval ratings have been steadily increasing since the end of October, suggesting that middle-of-the-road America views the president as less problematic than his critics claim.

The author also suggests that in a contest between Trump and his potential Democratic opponents, the unapologetic nature of Trump might give him an edge, despite the negative sentiments towards him.

The article concludes by highlighting several long-term risks to the U.S. economy, including a declining birthrate, a national debt over $23 trillion, the erosion of the global free-trade consensus, threats to the political independence of the Federal Reserve, and the popularization of economic theories such as Modern Monetary Theory.

Title: Nationwide Protests Erupt Over Ferguson Decision: A Summary of Events

Article:

Protests erupted across the United States for the second consecutive night following the grand jury's decision not to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson for the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown in August. The demonstrations in Ferguson, Missouri, subsided on Tuesday night into early Wednesday morning, with the National Guard protecting the Ferguson Police Department, handling crowd control, arrests, and use of tear gas, while local officers managed the situation. A total of 45 people were arrested, primarily for failure to disperse.

In Ferguson, one woman was taken into custody after protesters threw what appeared to be smoke bombs, flares, and frozen water bottles at a line of officers. Elsewhere, demonstrations in Oakland, California, resulted in vandalized police cars, damaged storefronts, and set fires in city streets. In Minneapolis, a car struck a protester and drove through a group of others, while in Portland, Oregon, police used pepper spray and made arrests after protesters disrupted bus and light rail traffic.

Thousands of people marched in Manhattan, gathering in Union Square and causing traffic disruptions on FDR Drive, Williamsburg Bridge, Manhattan Bridge, and the Queens Midtown Tunnel. NYPD Commissioner William Bratton stated that the police were giving protesters "breathing room," as long as they remained nonviolent and did not cause fear or vandalism.

In other cities, protests took place. A car struck a pedestrian at a rally in an unspecified location, causing minor injuries. In Cleveland, several hundred people marched down a freeway ramp to block rush-hour traffic, protesting the Missouri developments and Saturday's fatal shooting by an officer of 12-year-old Tamir Rice of Cleveland, who was carrying a pellet gun that resembled a real firearm.

In St. Louis, riot police arrested demonstrators on Interstate 44 near the Edward Jones Dome, causing traffic disruptions for several hours before they were dispersed with pepper spray. In Atlanta, Georgia, several hundred people from historically black schools Morehouse College and Clark Atlanta University held peaceful demonstrations, but some groups split off and tried to block a freeway, resulting in broken windows and the arrest of 21 people, primarily for failure to disperse when asked, with one person facing a weapons charge.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Call for Impeachment of President Trump

Article:

In the latest development, Beto O'Rourke, a Democratic presidential candidate, has joined the chorus of his fellow contenders advocating for the impeachment of President Donald Trump. O'Rourke's call stems from Trump's recent comments suggesting he would be open to accepting foreign intelligence on his 2020 rivals.

While Trump has since walked back these comments, they have sparked calls for impeachment from several Democratic presidential hopefuls. O'Rourke stated during an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" that Trump's admission of accepting foreign assistance in future elections is grounds for impeachment proceedings.

This call for impeachment follows similar sentiments expressed by another Democratic candidate, Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar. Klobuchar argued that soliciting something of value from a foreign country for campaign purposes is illegal, and Trump's actions are reminiscent of his 2016 campaign, when he publicly urged Russia to find and publish Hillary Clinton's emails.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, another Democratic presidential candidate, also weighed in on the issue, stating that Trump's willingness to accept a foreign power's help in his 2020 campaign should prompt Congress to initiate impeachment hearings. De Blasio described Trump's assertion that he would not have to call the FBI if a foreign country offered information about an opponent as "openly treasonous."

The idea of impeachment, while popular among Democratic base voters, is not yet supported by a majority of the general public, according to polls. The recent comments from the candidates raise questions about the Democrats' willingness to uphold norms of governmental behavior, such as the usually bright line between politics and federal prosecutions, that Trump has allegedly shattered.

Title: Justice Department and North Carolina File Lawsuits Over Controversial "Bathroom" Law

Article:

The Justice Department and the state of North Carolina have filed dueling lawsuits over the state's controversial "bathroom" law, with the Obama administration responding to a lawsuit filed by Republican Governor Pat McCrory with legal action of its own.

In a suit filed late Monday in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, the DOJ alleged a "pattern or practice of employment discrimination on the basis of sex" against the state over the law requiring transgender people to use bathrooms that correspond with the sex on their birth certificate.

Attorney General Loretta Lynch stated in a press conference late Monday afternoon that the suit was filed due to the creation of "state-sponsored discrimination against transgender individuals."

McCrory, in his lawsuit, accused the administration of a "baseless and blatant overreach" in trying to get the policy scrapped. The state's suit, filed in U.S. District Court in the Eastern District of North Carolina, stated that the administration is attempting to "unilaterally rewrite long-established federal civil rights laws."

McCrory, speaking at his own press conference, said Congress should get involved and "bring clarity" to federal anti-discrimination provisions, but urged the court to intervene in the current dispute. He stated that this is not just a North Carolina issue, but a national issue.

The state had faced a DOJ-imposed Monday deadline to respond to its demand that North Carolina either scrap the law or face legal action and risk losing federal funds. The DOJ, according to Lynch, retains the option of curtailing federal funding to the state Department of Public Safety and University of North Carolina.

The state law also limits state anti-discrimination protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people and blocks local governments from establishing their own. House Bill 2 has been criticized by gay rights groups, and entertainers including Bruce Springsteen and Pearl Jam have canceled shows. PayPal reversed plans to open a 400-employee operation center in Charlotte, and Deutsche Bank froze expansion plans near Raleigh.

Nearly 200 corporate leaders from across the country, including Charlotte-based Bank of America, have urged the law's repeal, arguing it's bad for business because it makes recruiting talented employees more difficult.

Several other states have proposed similar laws in recent months limiting protections to lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people. On Monday, the American Civil Liberties Union of Mississippi sued that state over a law that will allow workers to cite their own religious objections to same-sex marriage to deny services to people.

McCrory states that the North Carolina law applies only to government offices, universities, and road-side rest stops, not every bathroom in the state. The Justice Department, though, had sent McCrory a letter last Wednesday stating the law violates federal civil rights laws.

McCrory, speaking over the weekend with "Fox News Sunday," said he asked the department for an extension and was given only until the close of business Monday. He stated that "I don't think that three working days is enough time for such a pretty big threat." He also stated that "It's the federal government being a bully, making law."

McCrory also said he doesn't have the legal authority to change laws and that the expectation that he can is "unrealistic." McCrory, who signed the bill into law in March, said last week that the department seems to be breaking new ground in claiming the North Carolina law violates Civil Rights Act protections against discrimination in education and the workplace. He also stated that the administration's warning means the issue is no longer confined to North Carolina.

"This is not just North Carolina," said McCrory, arguing that every university that accepts federal funding is now in the same situation as those in his state. Meanwhile, the administration is expected to soon take the bathroom issue further, to ensure that transgender student rights are fully protected under federal law, according to Politico. The move reportedly would be related to a federal law that prohibits sex-based discrimination in federally funded education programs and activities, and multiple agencies are expected to be involved.

Title: College Students' Reactions to Allegations Against Presidential Candidate Donald Trump

Article:

The allegations against Presidential candidate Donald Trump have been a significant topic in the ongoing White House campaign to address sexual assault and end the perceived "rape culture" on college campuses. Some college students have expressed surprise at Trump's continued support, despite his comments about women and the allegations against him. However, many voters have already made up their minds and are unlikely to change their stance solely due to the issue of sexual misconduct.

Alex Abbott, a senior at Hampden-Sydney College, an all-male campus in Virginia, stated, "The idea that a candidate with a major-party backing has allegations of this nature on his record is vile." Yet, he added, the responses from men he had encountered were either "I would never do anything like that," or "Every guy does that, and it's not out of the ordinary."

Surveys indicate that voters are primarily concerned about the economy and terrorism. However, the negative attention on Trump's sexual behavior is reportedly hurting him with female voters and independents, according to Republican pollsters. Despite this, Clinton's support has not significantly increased, suggesting that many Republicans still view Trump as morally acceptable, at least compared to the Clintons.

Alan Abramowitz, a political science professor at Emory University in Atlanta, explained this phenomenon as "negative partisanship." He stated, "We vote against the other party/candidate more than for our own party/candidate, and that is especially true this year for Republicans."

Democrats, such as Jon Robin Baitz, an acclaimed Broadway playwright, also express disapproval of Trump. Baitz's latest work, "Vicuña," explores a tailor's relationship with a blustering Trump-like candidate, and will run this fall at the Kirk Douglas Theater in Los Angeles. Baitz lamented, "My heart is broken. There is, to me, a kind of fundamental American decency, and it’s just been lost in the prurient shallowness of the discourse."

Title: The Clash of Rights: Same-sex Marriage and the Debate Over Religious Freedom

Article:

A contentious debate is unfolding in the United States over the intersection of same-sex marriage and religious freedom. The issue has sparked a heated discussion, with some arguing that opposition to same-sex marriage is a violation of a newfound "right," while others maintain that the freedom of religion, speech, and association are being infringed upon.

Television personality Bill Maher, in a controversial statement, referred to homosexual activists who oppose dissenting views as the "gay mafia." These activists argue that same-sex marriage is not only a right but a matter of moral justice, while others contend that it is a preference, not a right.

The question at the heart of the debate is not whether laws can legislate morality, but rather, "Whose morality will we legislate?" While religions may teach certain moral rights, such as the right to life or property, these rights can be supported without religious affiliation. The issue of legislating morality is distinct from legislating religion, as the former involves the regulation of behavior, while the latter concerns religious practices and institutions.

Liberals, in particular, have been criticized for their intolerance towards those with differing views. In the name of tolerance and diversity, some have been excluded or faced legal consequences for not conforming to the liberal agenda. This has led to a growing clash between real rights and the new right of same-sex marriage.

Homosexual author Andrew Sullivan, in an article, expressed his disapproval of the intolerance displayed by some gay activists, citing the forced resignation of former Mozilla CEO Brandon Eich as an example. Sullivan argued that such behavior is antithetical to a tolerant and diverse society.

The conflict between homosexuality and religious liberty has led some to question whether there is a middle ground between celebrating same-sex marriage and upholding religious beliefs that prohibit such celebrations. Some argue that there is no middle ground, as the two positions are fundamentally incompatible.

Lesbian activist Chai Feldbaum, appointed by President Obama to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), has stated that religious liberty should take a backseat to the right of same-sex marriage. This stance has fueled concerns that the real rights of freedom of religion, speech, and association are being sacrificed in favor of the invented right of same-sex marriage.

The debate over same-sex marriage and religious freedom is a complex and emotionally charged issue, with both sides appealing to principles of justice, equality, and freedom. As the debate continues, it is essential to maintain a clear understanding of the rights at stake and to strive for a society that respects and protects the diversity of beliefs and perspectives.

Title: Sanders' Momentum in Democratic Race: A Look at the Nevada Caucus Winner's Path to the Nomination

Article:

Senator Bernie Sanders, following his victories in the Iowa, New Hampshire, and Nevada caucuses, is gaining momentum in the Democratic primary race. With crucial battles in South Carolina on Saturday and Super Tuesday on March 3, Sanders is poised to potentially capture the Democratic nomination and transform the party.

The upcoming contests, however, may present challenges for Sanders, as he faces criticism for his self-proclaimed socialist ideology and concerns about his electability in the general election. Despite these attacks, Sanders has demonstrated his ability to defend his positions, and potential opposition may expose the political desperation of his opponents.

In South Carolina, former Vice President Joe Biden faces a significant challenge, as Representative Jim Clyburn, a powerful black politician in the state, is expected to endorse Biden. Clyburn warns that nominating a socialist like Sanders could lead to electoral disaster. With Clyburn's endorsement, Biden becomes the favorite in the primary, where 60% of the vote is African American.

Biden also faces competition from billionaire Tom Steyer, who has invested heavily in South Carolina, hired black leaders, and pledged to support reparations for slavery. Polls show Steyer gaining support among black voters, potentially taking votes away from Biden. For Biden, South Carolina is a do-or-die state. If he wins here, he is revived.

Sanders is predicting victories in California and Texas, two of the megastates holding primaries on Super Tuesday. He has been gaining in the polls on Senator Elizabeth Warren, even in her home state of Massachusetts, which also holds its primary on Super Tuesday.

The question remains: With Biden, Buttigieg, Warren, Steyer, and Klobuchar—none of whom has beaten Sanders in the popular vote—who can beat a surging Sanders? When and where do they beat him?

Michael Bloomberg, with his vast resources, may be able to buy enough votes to win some states. However, it remains unclear whether the other Democratic candidates, who have been competing for a year, would stand aside to yield the field to Bloomberg, an ex-Republican, to save their party from Sanders.

The Democratic establishment is concerned that if the "moderates" in the race do not start dropping out and uniting behind a single candidate to challenge Sanders, they may lose the nomination to Sanders and the election to President Donald Trump.

Sanders' vision for the Democratic Party includes Medicare for All, abolition of private health insurance, a Green New Deal, free college tuition, student debt forgiveness, open borders, Supreme Court justices committed to Roe v. Wade, welfare for undocumented migrants, and a doubling of the minimum wage to $15 an hour.

As Winston Churchill once observed, "Some regard private enterprise as if it were a predatory tiger to be shot. Others look upon it as a cow that they can milk. Only a handful see it for what it really is—the strong horse that pulls the whole cart." Sanders sees free market capitalism as a means to be hectored, squeezed, and beaten into producing more. Those most receptive to his message are the young.

Patrick Buchanan, an adviser to three presidents, two-time candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, and the nominee for the Reform Party in 2000, offers insights into the Sanders phenomenon in his latest book, "The Greatest Comeback: How Richard Nixon Rose From Defeat to Create the New Majority." For more of his reports, visit the provided link.

Title: NSA's XKeyscore Surveillance Program Revealed in Leaked Documents by Edward Snowden

Article:

Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency (NSA) contractor, has leaked new documents that disclose the existence of a surveillance program called XKeyscore. The program, which the NSA claims is their "widest-reaching" program, allows NSA analysts to search through vast databases of emails, chats, and browsing histories from millions of people without prior authorization.

In the leaked documents published by The Guardian on Wednesday, the NSA boasts about XKeyscore's capabilities. A June 10 video by Snowden states that as an NSA agent, he had the ability to "wiretap anyone, from you or your accountant, to a federal judge or even the president, if I had a personal email." Intelligence officials have disputed this claim, but the documents on XKeyscore seem to provide more details on what Snowden was referring to.

The documents are training manuals for XKeyscore and detail how the NSA can mine enormous databases by filling out a simple on-screen form. The request doesn't undergo any court review or need clearance from higher-ranking NSA officials. According to one document, the XKeyscore search can cover "nearly everything a typical user does on the Internet," and even monitor a person's online activity in real-time.

It isn't just metadata that the analysts can see. XKeyscore allows the NSA access to the content of emails and chats. XKeyscore can search by name, telephone number, IP address, and keywords. It does not require a warrant, nor does the person performing the search require legal authority.

XKeyscore can also monitor activity on social media. Using the same tool that allows an NSA analyst to read the contents of stored emails, XKeyscore can read the content of Facebook chats and other private messages. An NSA analyst simply needs to input a Facebook user name and date range into a XKeyscore search.

The NSA claims that the system is effective. It asserted in one document that it had captured 200 terrorists with XKeyscore by 2008. One slide indicated that XKeyscore can search HTTP activity with a keyword, allowing the NSA to monitor "nearly everything a typical user does on the Internet."

The Guardian published the documents on the same day that senior intelligence officials met with members of the Senate to release classified documents about the collection of phone records, PRISM, and the FISA court. The details of these programs and their legality are currently under debate.

Title: Trump's Fundraiser for Veterans Charities Yields Less Than Half of Promised Amount

Article:

More than two months after Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump claimed to have raised $6 million for veterans' charities at a fundraiser held on the eve of the Iowa caucuses, most of the organizations targeted to receive the money have received less than half of that amount, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal.

The Journal, citing a survey of the 22 groups listed by Trump's campaign as prospective recipients for the money, reported that 19 organizations had obtained a total of $2.4 million from Trump's foundation or associates. Of the three other charities, one declined to disclose how much it had received, another said it needed to submit more paperwork before receiving any money, and the third did not respond to questions by the Journal.

Fox Business Network first reported in late February that only a fraction of the pledged donations had made their way to the veterans groups. At the time, FBN reported, several groups said they had not received any money. And seven of the 22 told Fox Business Network they had received a total of $650,000. Other groups did not respond to inquiries at the time.

Trump held the Jan. 29 benefit in lieu of attending a GOP debate hosted by ███. The real estate mogul had declined to appear at the debate, claiming that he had not been treated fairly by the network.

All 19 groups that confirmed receiving money from the Trump event got checks in the mail. Sixteen charities saw donations arrive in late February in increments of $50,000 or $100,000. The other three reported smaller donations in March, with those amounts averaging between $5,000 and $15,000.

Keith David of the Task Force Dagger Foundation told the Journal that he was confused about whether a $50,000 check from Trump associate Stewart Rahr's foundation was tied to the Iowa event. He said he had been informed by a Trump representative that it was. "It’s a little weird," David said. "It looks like it’s from a totally separate organization."

Hope Hicks, a spokeswoman for the Trump campaign, told ███ that Trump has in fact “given to the 22 groups we originally announced and many others.”

“Additionally, we are continuing to distribute the money raised as it comes in and we are expanding the list of groups receiving contributions,” she said in a statement. “If the media spent half as much time highlighting the work of these groups and how our Veterans have been so mistreated, rather than trying to disparage Mr. Trump’s generosity for a totally unsolicited gesture for which he had no obligation, we would all be better for it. He has raised millions of dollars for the Vets, and rather than being thanked, he is attacked. As Mr. Trump said, ‘No good deed goes unpunished.’”

She did not say how much money raised at the event had been distributed, or how much each group has received.

The Journal, citing the Trump Foundation's tax returns, reported that the nonprofit had given just $180,000 to veterans' charities over the past decade. Hicks said that amount did not include personal donations by the candidate.

At least one prominent charity declined to receive any money from the January fundraiser. Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America (IAVA) founder Paul Rieckhoff called the event a "political stunt."

Title: Romney Hesitates to Comment on Obama's Deportation Policy Reversal for Certain Illegal Immigrants

Article:

In response to President Obama's recent order to halt the deportation of some illegal immigrants, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, declined to state whether he would reverse the policy if he were to occupy the White House. During the Republican primary debates, Romney expressed his intention to veto the Dream Act, a legislation that would provide a path to citizenship for some illegal immigrants. However, in a more equivocal stance regarding Obama's order, Romney expressed support for a long-term solution for undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children.

On the CBS program "Face the Nation," Romney stated, "With regards to these kids who were brought in by their parents through no fault of their own, there needs to be a long-term solution so they know what their status is."

Republican lawmakers, including Romney, have accused President Obama of making a politically motivated move by issuing the order and bypassing Congress. Romney stated, "If he felt seriously about this, he should have taken action when he had a Democratic House and Senate, but he didn't."

The president's order allows work permits and prevents deportation for as many as 1.4 million undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children. The president's support for the Dream Act in 2010 was blocked by Republicans in the Senate.

The president's immigration policies, which have focused on deportations, have been a source of concern for losing the enthusiasm of Hispanics, a crucial voting bloc. The president's move may have pre-empted Romney on a solution to illegal immigration, as he was reportedly edging toward an embrace of a Republican alternative to the Dream Act proposed by Senator Marco Rubio of Florida.

Advisers to Romney have stated that he is working on immigration policies and is expected to unveil them on Thursday when he speaks to the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials in Florida. Ana Navarro, an adviser on Hispanic issues to Senator John McCain in 2008, tweeted on Sunday, "After Obama move, it's time. Romney NALEO speech Thurs is I-Day."

In other news, Romney expressed a hands-off approach to the European economic crisis, stating, "We're not going to send checks to Europe. We're not going to bail out the European banks." He also reiterated economic proposals from the primary season, such as lowering tax rates and cutting government spending from 25 percent of the economy to 20 percent, which he said would "ignite growth."

Regarding another round of monetary stimulus from the Federal Reserve, known as QE3, Romney expressed skepticism, stating, "We'll go through that process with Congress."

Romney is currently on a six-state bus tour of small towns to connect with everyday Americans. CBS's Bob Schieffer mentioned an alternative image of Romney from Saturday: the success of a dressage horse that his wife, Ann Romney, co-owns. The horse, Rafalca, won a berth on the United States Olympic team. Romney joked, "I joke that I'm going to send her to Betty Ford for addiction to horses."

Title: Investigative Report: Allegations of Misrepresentation Surrounding 2012 Benghazi Attack

Article:

The events surrounding the 2012 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, have been the subject of ongoing controversy, with allegations that the Obama administration provided misleading information to the American public.

Initially, the administration claimed that the attack was a result of a protest demonstration against an anti-Islamic video produced by an American. However, this account has been disputed, as there was no evidence of a protest demonstration in Libya during the attack, and officials on the ground in Libya did not report such an incident.

The highest-ranking American diplomat on the scene in Libya, who spoke directly with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton by phone, stated that it was a terrorist attack. The President of Libya also announced that it was a terrorist attack, and the C.I.A. informed the Obama administration that it was a terrorist attack.

After the initial account was discredited, the administration claimed that the information provided was the best available at the time from intelligence sources. However, this claim has been called into question, as 12 drafts of the Obama administration's talking points about Benghazi have been released, and each draft was revised to omit the clear and unequivocal statement that this was a terrorist attack.

Attempts to suggest that Ambassador Susan Rice's false story about a "spontaneous protest" was the result of a lack of accurate information from intelligence sources have been exposed as a second lie to excuse the first lie.

The difference between an honest mistake and a calculated lie to deceive the American people, in order to win an election, has been a point of contention. The Obama administration's election campaign had claimed the death of Osama bin Laden as an accomplishment of the administration, as part of a general defeat of Al-Qaeda and other terrorists. Admitting that these terrorists were still active and capable of carrying out a well-coordinated attack would have been politically damaging during the election campaign.

The Obama administration's excuse for not attempting to provide help to the Americans in Benghazi while they were under attack has also been questioned. The administration claimed that it would take too long to deploy help, but this claim has been called into question, as a small fighting unit in Tripoli was ready to deploy to Benghazi when they were ordered to "stand down."

Thomas Sowell, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, Stanford University, has written extensively on the subject, suggesting that the Obama administration's actions were politically motivated and that the truth is dangerous to liars. The Obama administration has yet to provide a full account of the events in Benghazi, and further investigations are likely to be necessary to determine the full extent of the misrepresentation and to hold those responsible accountable.

Title: Kayleigh McEnany's Journey: From Bible Teacher to Political Commentator

Article:

Kayleigh McEnany, the current White House Press Secretary, has recounted her journey as one of strengthening her faith and beliefs during her time as a Bible teacher. This period also marked her experience as a minority in an oppositional environment. In a recent tweet, she acknowledged the late Christian pastor Ravi Zacharias as a significant influence, stating, "When peers challenged the intellectual foundation for my faith" at Oxford, Zacharias "was the usher between the heart & the mind."

McEnany's admiration for Zacharias mirrored her desire to study at elite universities. She described Zacharias as someone who, from an academic perspective, could equip individuals with arguments for their faith without compromising intellectual integrity. This desire to defend her beliefs led McEnany to engage in intellectual debates with her peers during her time at Oxford.

During a visit to Fox News, her potential talent caught the attention of Alan Colmes, then Sean Hannity's liberal antagonist on the program Hannity & Colmes. Colmes' mentorship led McEnany to an internship on his show. The two often engaged in political debates, and Colmes appreciated her for it. Later, he supported her as she faced challenging panels on CNN.

After her 2010 college graduation, McEnany worked as a producer for former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee's Fox News show. During this time, she maintained a blog titled "Defending Reagan Conservatism." Her political commentary was characterized by an air of righteousness, and her reading recommendations favored publications like The Economist.

McEnany's social media posts during this period occasionally leaned towards Trump-style birtherism and controversial comments about political figures. Despite this, she remained devout, regularly attending church and tweeting about her faith.

Elie Mystal, a writer at the progressive magazine The Nation, remembers debating with McEnany on various political issues before his appearances on Huckabee's show. "We disagreed, but we disagreed honorably," he told a reporter. Several years later, when McEnany was in law school, her acquaintance with Mystal led to her position at Above the Law, a prominent legal blog where Mystal was writing at the time.

In Mystal's account, McEnany filled the token conservative slot for the mostly liberal website. He described the website as catering to what generates clicks, stating, "You're looking at what makes clicks. And being crazy is going to get you clicks." However, he added, McEnany came across as a true believer in her arguments, not merely doing it for show, money, or power. Instead, her core belief lent authenticity to her work.

Throughout her career, McEnany has maintained a conservative political stance, serving as a commentator on various cable news networks and, most recently, as the White House Press Secretary. Her journey from Bible teacher to political commentator highlights her dedication to her beliefs and her ability to engage in intellectual debates while maintaining a strong faith.

Title: Trump's Data-Driven Strategy: A New Approach to Presidential Campaigning

Article:

In the ongoing race for the 2016 U.S. presidency, Donald Trump, a controversial figure, has garnered significant attention and support, according to recent polls. The New York Times/CBS News poll indicates that Trump has 35 percent of the Republican vote, more than double the 16 percent of runner-up Ted Cruz. This article explores Trump's data-driven strategy and its potential impact on the upcoming primaries.

Trump's unconventional approach to campaigning has generated controversy and widespread contempt since his presidential candidacy announcement in June. However, his data-driven strategy has proven effective, as he has been able to capture and analyze vast amounts of data that his opponents can learn from.

Politics, in the modern era, is heavily reliant on data analysis. Trump's social media presence, particularly on Twitter and Instagram, provides a wealth of data that his opponents can analyze to understand voter preferences and behaviors. His provocative statements and responses create a trove of data that a tech-savvy opponent should leverage to their advantage.

Trump's Twitter account, with over 5.2 million followers, and his Instagram account, with more than 650,000 followers, serve as valuable sources of data. Every tweet, retweet, Facebook post, Instagram blast, and newscast lead generates data that can be captured, analyzed, and used against him.

The Washington Post reported that Trump uses his social media accounts to deliver snarky messages and short videos, generating a significant amount of data that his opponents can analyze. This data can help opponents understand what resonates with voters and what does not, allowing them to tailor their messages and strategies accordingly.

Data analysis played a crucial role in Barack Obama's presidential campaigns, as he used data to identify undecided voters, learn about them, and persuade them to vote for him in the final days of the campaign. Jim Messina, who headed Obama's re-election campaign in 2012, stated that they based their tactics on big data, running 66,000 computer simulations of the election to inform their strategies.

Trump understands the importance of data in modern politics and has applied this concept to his campaign. He has tapped into the public's desire for provocative, edgy, and controversial content, shaking up the electorate and forcing them to react. While some may dislike his statements, it is undeniable that his strategy is working, as he has been at the top of the polls for months.

However, Trump's data-driven strategy also presents an opportunity for his opponents. Instead of focusing on condemning his statements, opponents should focus on understanding and learning from the data he generates. By analyzing the data, opponents can learn what resonates with voters and tailor their messages and strategies to appeal to those voters.

In the upcoming Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, the time to invest in data analysis is now. The candidate who is smart enough to invest in the infrastructure needed to organize and analyze the Trump data trove will have a significant advantage in the race for the presidency. As Jim Messina stated, "We spent two years and about $400 million trying to build up a capacity to predict people's behaviors and match that with social media... The final 96 hours of the 2012 race, a majority of Americans... went to the incumbent. And when you ask them why: 76 percent of those said because their friend or family member talked to them on social media and told them why they had to support Barack Obama."

In conclusion, Trump's data-driven strategy has proven effective in capturing and analyzing vast amounts of data. His opponents should learn from this strategy, using the data he generates to understand voter preferences and tailor their messages and strategies accordingly. The candidate who is smart enough to invest in data analysis will have a significant advantage in the upcoming primaries and, ultimately, the race for the presidency.

Title: Federal Tax Code Shifts Toward Renewable Energy Over Past Decade

Article:

The past decade has seen a significant shift in the U.S. tax code's benefits for various fuel sources, with renewable energy surpassing its counterparts in the oil, gas, and coal sectors. Federal tax "preferences," such as tax credits for energy production, specific write-offs or deductions, or other benefits aimed at an energy subsector, have moved toward wind, solar, and other renewable fuels since 2008. This increase has come as tax preferences for fossil fuels have declined or remained relatively stable year after year.

In 2016, renewable energy received $10.9 billion in tax preferences compared to $4.6 billion for fossil fuels. A decade ago, fossil fuels received $8.2 billion while renewables pulled in only $5.3 billion in tax preferences, according to Congressional Budget Office (CBO) figures recently presented to Congress.

The dynamic began to shift in the early days of the Obama administration. The massive American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, along with increased production in the wind and solar power sectors, shifted tax preferences toward renewable energy. From 2008 to 2009, for example, tax preferences for green fuels jumped by nearly $10 billion, from $7.4 billion to $17.1 billion.

At the same time, tax preferences for fossil fuels decreased from $5.5 billion in 2008 to $3.6 billion in 2009. While the gap has narrowed since then, it still indicates a tilt toward renewable fuels in the current tax code.

The latest CBO figures also come against the backdrop of a broader debate about tax reform. Both President Trump and his Republican allies in Congress are eager to rewrite the tax code, lower rates, and eliminate deductions. However, specialists say they will have an uphill battle to strip all of the energy carve-outs that have been implemented over the past decade.

"I think it's pretty difficult. Look at the wind production tax credit—it keeps getting extended because there are a bunch of Republican senators from wind states," said Benjamin Zycher, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute who specializes in energy and environmental policy.

"It's supposed to be phased out, but we'll see. I have my doubts. It's difficult to get rid of these things," he said.

Indeed, tax credits for the production of wind power are routinely extended by Congress, though they're currently being phased out and are scheduled to end by 2019. That tax credit, along with other tax preferences for solar power and other renewable sources, accounted for more than $6 billion in tax preferences last year, according to CBO numbers. Another $4.2 billion went to biodiesel and renewable diesel credits, the CBO said.

Specialists routinely point out that much of the tax preferences have come about because of increased production in renewable energy, not just because of the establishment of new government policies favoring a given source.

The shift has been the result of tax policies and changes within the energy industry itself. The wind production tax credit, for example, was first enacted in 1992. The following year, renewable energy received just $900 million in tax preferences, compared to $2 billion for fossil fuels.

The tax credits have become more valuable in terms of dollar amounts simply because of the wind industry's expansion and significant increases in production, analysts say.

"These tax expenditures don't represent a shift—there have been no changes in the tax provisions that deliver fossil fuel tax expenditures over the past decade—but an increase in the renewable power investment and output that qualifies for the renewable tax expenditures," said Joseph Aldy, a professor of public policy at the Harvard Kennedy School who studies energy and tax policy.

Additional government investment and preferential treatment through the tax code has spurred that production even more, creating a cycle. From 2007 to 2014, for example, wind capacity in the U.S. nearly quadrupled.

On the fossil fuels side, many of the tax-preference policies have been in place for decades. In 2016, the sector received $1.8 billion in tax preferences for the "expensing of exploration and development costs for oil and natural gas," the CBO said, along with billions of dollars in benefits for the depreciation of gas distribution lines, "geological and geophysical expenditures" related to exploration, and other activities.

Leading lawmakers, in theory, say they want to eliminate many of those tax preference schemes while lowering the broader tax rates for all businesses. Such a huge overhaul of the tax code will be politically difficult and incredibly complicated, but GOP leaders have the support of Mr. Trump, and the president seems especially interested in pushing through a tax-reform package following the failure to repeal Obamacare earlier this year.

"House Republicans are working to lower tax rates for all businesses to ensure they keep more of their earnings and decide how to best use their resources to create jobs and fund their operations," said Emily Schillinger, communications director for the House Ways and Means Committee, the chamber's tax-writing panel.

Title: Pope Francis: A Humble and Unconventional Leader

Article:

Pope Francis, born Jorge Mario Bergoglio, took his name from St. Francis of Assisi, a medieval friar known for his devotion to the poor and nature. The Argentinian is not the first pope from outside Europe, but he is the first non-European pope in modern times.

Francis, the first Jesuit and the first Latin American to lead the Catholic Church, differs significantly from his recent predecessors, John Paul II and Benedict XVI, in several ways. Unlike them, he does not have a numeral after his name, as he is the first to take the name Francis.

The pope's choice of name is a tribute to St. Francis of Assisi, a man who renounced his family's wealth to live among the poor and the destitute. The Rev. Thomas Rosica, the Vatican's deputy spokesman, noted similarities between the two men, stating, "Francis of Assisi is someone who turned his back on the wealth of his family and the lifestyle he had, and bonded with lepers and the poor."

Pope Francis is also known for his care for AIDS patients and single mothers whose babies were refused baptism by priests in his diocese. In 2013, he scolded those priests, saying, "How can you turn these people away when they belong to us?"

In addition to his religious duties, Pope Francis has broken with tradition in several ways. He is a humble man who takes public transportation, lives in an apartment instead of the archbishop's palace, and cooks his own meals. In his first public act as pontiff, he asked the estimated 150,000 people packed into St. Peter's Square to pray for him, rather than blessing the crowd first.

Pope Francis also refused to use a platform to elevate himself above the cardinals standing with him as he was introduced to the world as Pope Francis. Cardinal Timothy Dolan, archbishop of New York and the president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, noted, "He met each of us on our own level."

Francis opposes same-sex marriage and abortion, but his career as a priest in Argentina coincided with the so-called Dirty War, during which as many as 30,000 people died or disappeared. Francis was accused of complicity in the 1976 kidnapping of two liberal Jesuit priests, but he denied the charge.

Pope Francis takes the helm of a church that has been rocked in recent years by sex abuse by priests and claims of corruption and infighting among the church hierarchy. He may need to find a way to draw new Catholics into the church, where it is in decline, and to work with shifting viewpoints among Catholics, particularly on issues such as contraception and immigration.

Title: McConnell Defends Vote to Raise Debt Ceiling, Faces Criticism from Primary Opponents

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) defended his decision to join Democrats in a vote to clear a filibuster hurdle for a bill to raise the debt ceiling on Friday at a campaign appearance in Louisville.

McConnell was one of 12 Republican senators to join Democrats on Tuesday in voting to end debate on the debt-ceiling bill, which will extend the federal debt limit for a year. This move has been criticized by his opponents, including Matt Bevin, a tea party conservative challenging McConnell in the Kentucky GOP primary in May.

Bevin, in a statement after the vote, said, "Kentucky and America can literally no longer afford such financially reckless behavior from the likes of Mitch McConnell."

Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who threatened to filibuster the vote, criticized Senate Republicans for joining with Democrats to vote for the bill, saying, "Every Senate Republican should have stood together."

When asked about his opponents' comments, McConnell defended his position, stating, "My preference is for a debt ceiling to carry additional legislation that does something about the debt."

McConnell pointed to his role in negotiating the Budget Control Act with Vice President Biden in August 2011, which led to a deficit-reduction package that reduced government spending for two years. He attributed the House's inability to come together on a different version of the bill as the reason for his vote in favor of a clean debt-ceiling bill.

House Speaker John Boehner, after unsuccessfully trying to gather enough Republicans to vote on a new version of the bill, joked, "You know, Mother Teresa is a saint now, but if the Congress wanted to make her a saint and attach that to the debt ceiling, you probably couldn't get 218 Republican votes."

McConnell also defended his record as a legislator who averts crises, stating, "I believe I have to act in the best interest of the country, and every time we've been confronted with a potential crisis, the guy you're looking at is the one who stepped up and solved the problem."

Title: David Gergen Praises Bill Clinton's Effective Speech at Democratic National Convention

Article:

In the third and final night of the Democratic National Convention, former President Bill Clinton delivered a rousing speech that, according to political analyst David Gergen, added strength to the convention and effectively attacked the Romney-Ryan budget plan. Gergen, a political adviser to four U.S. presidents, noted that Clinton's speech was particularly effective in highlighting President Obama's stewardship and exposing vulnerabilities in the Republican budget plan.

Clinton's speech, which was well-received by the audience, was described as the best and most influential he has given since leaving the White House over a dozen years ago. The former president's ability to tell Obama's story and critique the Republican budget plan was seen as a potential game-changer, particularly in terms of appealing to older voters and those who may be swayed by Democratic arguments.

However, Gergen emphasized that the Democratic Party still faces challenges, particularly in terms of President Obama's ability to deliver a compelling case for re-election. Obama is expected to speak on Thursday, and Gergen noted that the president has given numerous prime-time speeches in the past, with audiences shrinking over time. Voters, Gergen said, are increasingly skeptical of words and are seeking deeds.

Furthermore, Gergen pointed out that no one at the convention has yet provided a clear sense of Obama's plan to address the economic crisis. The public, Gergen noted, is unlikely to be persuaded by half-measures and vague assurances about future economic growth. Instead, they are seeking a detailed roadmap for economic recovery.

In conclusion, while the Democratic National Convention has revived Democratic spirits and set up President Obama for a strong speech on Thursday, the ultimate success of the party rests on Obama's ability to deliver a compelling case for re-election, address voter skepticism, and provide a clear plan for economic recovery.

Title: Snowden Reveals Concerns Over U.S. Cyberterrorism Program "MonsterMind"

Article:

In an interview with Wired magazine, former National Security Agency (NSA) contractor Edward Snowden discussed his decision to leak government secrets, focusing on a controversial cyberterrorism counterattack program known as "MonsterMind." Snowden, photographed for the story with an American flag, stated that the program, designed to detect and respond to foreign cyberattacks, could potentially cause more harm than good due to the risk of misdirection.

Snowden explained that malware could be routed through an innocent third-party country, leading to potential retaliation against unintended targets. He stated, "These attacks can be spoofed. You could have someone sitting in China, for example, making it appear that one of these attacks is originating in Russia. And then we end up shooting back at a Russian hospital. What happens next?"

Snowden, who is 31 years old, also expressed his desire to return to the U.S. someday, stating, "I told the government I'd volunteer for prison, as long as it served the right purpose. I care more about the country than what happens to me. But we can't allow the law to become a political weapon or agree to scare people away from standing up for their rights, no matter how good the deal. I'm not going to be part of that."

Snowden leaked details of U.S. surveillance programs to The Guardian and The Washington Post in June 2013, sparking a global uproar. At the time, Snowden was in hiding in Hong Kong and later fled to Moscow, where he currently resides.

President Obama pledged to scale back surveillance of American citizens, and Germany ordered the CIA station chief out of the country. The Guardian and Post won the Pulitzer Prize for public service for their coverage.

Snowden has previously expressed interest in returning to the United States, but he fears an unjust trial on charges of espionage and theft of government property could result in a lengthy prison sentence. He remains adamant that his actions were for the good of the country.

Regarding the MonsterMind program, Snowden told Wired that it could potentially start a war and poses a significant threat to privacy, as it requires the NSA to gain access to virtually all private communications coming in from overseas. Snowden stated, "The argument is that the only way we can identify these malicious traffic flows and respond to them is if we're analyzing all traffic flows. And if we're analyzing all traffic flows, that means we have to be intercepting all traffic flows. That means violating the Fourth Amendment, seizing private communications without a warrant, without probable cause or even a suspicion of wrongdoing. For everyone, all the time."

Snowden's comments highlight the breadth of NSA surveillance and the potential risks associated with such programs. He warned of the slippery slope created by accepting and justifying rule-breaking and dishonesty in the name of national security.

Title: President Obama Urges Congress to Complete Immigration Reform Legislation

Article:

President Barack Obama used a naturalization ceremony at the White House on Monday to call on Congress to complete the ongoing immigration reform process. The event, held in the East Room, served to increase pressure on lawmakers whose leaders are reportedly nearing agreement on a comprehensive immigration bill.

During the ceremony for 28 new U.S. citizens, President Obama stated, "The time has come to fix it once and for all." He emphasized the need for political courage to address the nation's immigration system, stating, "We've just got at this point to work up the political courage to do what’s required to be done."

Congress is currently on a two-week recess for Easter, during which time aides are continuing to draft legislation that is expected to be introduced next month. A bipartisan group of senators is working on a proposal that would provide a path to citizenship for 11 million illegal immigrants while allowing tens of thousands of new high- and low-skilled workers into the country.

One of the sticking points in the proposal is the wages for lower-skilled temporary workers, which has led to a dispute between the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the AFL-CIO. Under the proposal, as many as 200,000 immigrants would be granted visas each year for low-skilled jobs that U.S. employers have difficulty filling.

In the House, Speaker John A. Boehner has stated that a bipartisan bill could be introduced in the next few weeks. President Obama called the progress "good news," but he emphasized the need for Congress to complete its work soon.

The legislation will call for increased border control, though U.S. Customs and Border Protection recently informed lawmakers that it does not have a way to effectively measure border security. Not all powerful lawmakers are on board with the "speedy bill" approach favored by President Obama and Capitol Hill's leaders.

Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama and five other Republican senators have called for more hearings and time to study before any bill is pushed through the committee. They pointed out that 43 new senators have joined the chamber since 2007, when the last major congressional push on immigration happened.

While in the past the issue divided each party and its constituents, Democrats are increasingly united behind President Obama's push. However, Republicans are split between concerns about border security and a desire to win over Hispanic voters, who have been reluctant to vote for GOP presidential candidates in the past two elections.

President Obama has made immigration one of the top priorities of his second term, mindful of a long-standing promise to Hispanic voters that he would achieve the goal. The movement on the issue since November's elections also reflects concern among Republican lawmakers about Hispanics' growing support for Democratic candidates, and the perception among Hispanics that the GOP is anti-immigration.

Thirteen of the people who took the oath of citizenship at the White House are members of the U.S. military. The president praised them for "a willingness to risk their lives in defense of a nation that was not yet their own." He added, "That's a remarkable act, [which] made each of them in some ways American even before it was official, because that kind of service and sacrifice has defined our nation for more than two centuries."

Title: Asian Vote Emerges as New Battleground in U.S. Congressional Elections

Article:

In the 2022 U.S. Congressional elections, a new focus has emerged on the Asian-American population, particularly in urban and suburban areas. This shift is evident in regions such as Fairfax, Virginia, and other areas like northern New Jersey, the greater Atlanta area, Minneapolis, Las Vegas, and the West Coast.

Candidates from both major parties have intensified their efforts to win over this diverse and rapidly growing immigrant population. They have emphasized their support for small businesses, public education, and issues specific to various ethnic groups.

At a recent event in Fairfax, Congressman Gerry Connolly addressed the crowd in several languages, including Korean, Chinese, and Thai. Former Lt. Gov. Don Beyer, running for Congress in a nearby district, highlighted the number of foreign-born employees at his Volvo dealerships. Republican state Del. Barbara Comstock, a contender for the open 10th District House seat, touted her support for legislation referring to the Sea of Japan as the East Sea, a name favored by Koreans.

Nonpartisan voter turnout leaflets emphasized the importance of participating in the democratic process, recalling historical events such as World War II-era Japanese internment and racially restrictive 19th-century immigration rules.

Texas Sen. John Cornyn, whose campaign has run TV ads in Vietnamese and offers versions of its website in Mandarin and Hindi, stated that it is essential for the Republican Party to "show up" before these communities' distrust of Republicans becomes permanent.

California Rep. Judy Chu, the Democrat who leads the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, noted that both parties increasingly view Asian Americans as a "margin of victory" population in some challenging races. She pointed to the Virginia race between Comstock and Democratic Fairfax County Supervisor John Foust as a prime example.

Pollsters caution that it is difficult to generalize about Asian-American voters due to the vast diversity within the population. However, partisan strategists and Asian-American activists suggest that there are common preoccupations across culturally disparate immigrant groups, such as an intense focus on education and concern about the economic environment for small, family-owned businesses.

There is also a growing affinity for the Democratic Party, which is perceived as the party that stands for racial and ethnic diversity and a more inclusive federal immigration policy. In the 2012 elections, Asian Americans voted for the president by a larger margin (47 points) than Latinos. In swing-state Virginia, where Asian Americans made up 3% of the electorate, they supported Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine by 32 points. In 2010, in Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's close reelection fight, Asian voters were 4% of the Nevada electorate, and nearly four in five supported the embattled incumbent.

Title: FBI Releases Court Records Detailing Surveillance of Former Trump Campaign Aide Carter Page

Article:

WASHINGTON – The FBI has released over 400 pages of material filed with a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) court to request a wiretap on Carter Page, a former Trump campaign aide who investigators believed was collaborating with Moscow. The documents provide new detail about the early phases of the FBI's probe into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. Presidential election.

The documents, which were redacted in vast portions, reveal that two requests to extend the surveillance of Page were approved by Trump's appointees in the Department of Justice, including Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

The FBI's applications suggest the bureau had broader suspicions about Page and his potential ties to the Russian government. Four federal judges, all appointed by Republican presidents, approved the surveillance requests, each finding the government had shown "probable cause" that Page was acting as an agent of Russia.

Page, a former campaign aide to Trump, denied that he collaborated with the Russian government to interfere with the election. Speaking for the first time since the documents were made public, Page told CNN the allegations were "a complete joke." Page has not been charged with a crime, despite the extended surveillance.

The FBI began monitoring Page in October 2016. The surveillance was carried out under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, which allows the government to monitor communications when it can persuade a judge that someone is working as an agent of a foreign power. The documents show the surveillance continued into 2017.

Investigators said that they had collected evidence that "the Russian Government’s efforts to influence the 2016 U.S. Presidential election were being coordinated with Page and perhaps other individuals associated with Trump’s campaign."

The documents were made public after a week in which the White House was repeatedly forced to walk back comments made by President Trump about Russia, including during a joint appearance with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki. During a joint news conference last week, Trump appeared to accept Putin's denial of Russia's attempt to influence the election, but later clarified he thought Moscow was involved. The White House then clarified that Trump believes Russia is still attempting to target U.S. elections after the president appeared to answer a reporter's question hours earlier saying Russia is not.

███ and the James Madison Project, a nonpartisan organization that promotes government accountability, filed a lawsuit last year under the Freedom of Information Act seeking records about surveillance of Trump’s campaign. The suit came after Trump claimed the Obama administration "wire-tapped" Trump Tower before the election.

Title: Trump Promotes 'Fair Trade' Agenda at Davos, Stresses U.S. Economic Growth

Article:

President Donald Trump emphasized his commitment to prioritizing American interests in trade during his address to the World Economic Forum in Davos on Friday, stating, "America First, not America alone." The U.S. is open for business, he said, and urged foreign investors to take advantage of the country's competitive economic environment.

In his inaugural speech at the global finance summit, Trump lauded the economic achievements of his first year in office, including cutting corporation tax and lowering the unemployment rate. He highlighted the strong economy as a reason for foreign investors to "bring your money, your jobs, your businesses to America."

Despite the "America First" policy's apparent contradiction with the Davos conference's goal of promoting globalization and cooperation, Trump's message was more nuanced than expected. He stated that the U.S. did not want a trade war but instead sought fair trade.

Trump's comments come amid concerns about increased protectionism and potential trade barriers under his administration. However, he demanded a reformed international trade system that was "fair and reciprocal" and accused unidentified countries of unfair practices, including "massive intellectual property theft" and providing state aid to industry.

The U.S. president also expressed a preference for bilateral fair trade agreements with other countries, including those that were part of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) from which he has withdrawn. He suggested negotiating with TPP states collectively if it was in America's interest.

Trump's speech was met with a muted response from the audience, with some expecting a more conciliatory tone. However, he had an overall positive reception, with cheers on his arrival and a meeting with UK Prime Minister Theresa May, where he expressed optimism about increased trade between the U.S. and Britain in the coming years.

In a question and answer session after his address, Trump faced boos when he attacked the media and repeated accusations of them reporting "fake news." He also expressed a willingness to apologize for retweeting posts from a British far-right group, a move that sparked a Twitter row with May.

The speech comes days after the U.S. announced new tariffs of up to 50% on imported washing machines and solar panels, prompting an outcry from China and South Korea, the primary targets of the measure. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, also in Davos, has warned of "more to come" on trade tariffs.

Title: President Obama Prepares to Issue Executive Orders on Gun Control in Response to Oregon Shooting

Article:

President Barack Obama has expressed his anger following the shooting at an Oregon community college campus that left nine dead and several more injured. This latest shooting at a school campus has reportedly prompted the President to prepare executive orders to expand background checks for gun buyers.

The Republican response has primarily been to defend against the onslaught of progressives advocating for more gun control and a reduction of guns in the country. The President, however, feels that the public may be near a tipping point, and his own time in office is slipping by without any progress on this issue.

The article suggests several proposals to reduce mass shootings, focusing on separating legal gun ownership from illegal ownership, modifying HIPAA laws to prevent people with severe mental illnesses from purchasing a gun, installing metal detectors in publicly funded schools, arming trained and tested employees in schools, and outlawing gun-free zones.

The article argues that these proposals address the issue of mass shootings without conceding the argument that guns are the issue and they need to be regulated even more. The proposals do not expand background checks or create more restrictions on gun ownership but instead aim to add common sense to the difficult issue, help protect those in vulnerable settings, and respect the right of the Second Amendment.

The article concludes by stating that what is needed is a Republican courageous enough to advance a set of proposals like this and not back down. It calls for the need to stop allowing ourselves to be painted into a defensive corner and to take back the narrative on guns from those who use it to control us.

Title: CNN Continues to Pursue Counterintelligence Investigations Despite Mueller Report's Conclusion

Article:

In a summary of the Mueller report, Attorney General William Barr stated that the Special Counsel did not find any evidence of U.S. persons or Trump campaign officials or associates conspiring or knowingly coordinating with the Russians in their efforts. However, CNN continues to pursue counterintelligence investigations and speculate on potential compromises between President Trump and Russia.

On Monday night, host Erin Burnett began her show, OutFront, by discussing the possibility of President Trump or members of his inner circle being "compromised" by the Russians. She referenced California Congressman Adam Schiff, who often claimed to have direct evidence of collusion but was proven incorrect by the Special Counsel.

"Our investigation is always focused on counterintelligence issues, that is, is the President or anyone around him compromised in some way. That work has to go on," Schiff said in a soundbite. Burnett questioned whether this was part of Mueller's investigation, and CNN crime and justice reporter Shimon Prokupecz responded that it was and continues to be something that the FBI and counterintelligence investigators will always look for.

Early in CNN's Tuesday prime time lineup, CNN analyst Ralph Peters claimed that the debunked Steele dossier still "rings true to me" despite Mueller's findings. He received no pushback from host Anderson Cooper.

Later in the evening, Prime Time host Chris Cuomo emphatically asserted that "there could be ample proof" of collusion in Mueller's full report. Cuomo suggested that evidence for collusion could be folded into the counterintelligence investigation, which the AG did not mention in the summary.

Despite the summary stating that the Special Counsel did not find evidence of collusion, CNN's #FactsFirst mantra appears to have been called into question, with some hosts and analysts continuing to speculate on potential compromises and counterintelligence issues.

Title: Hillary Clinton to Attack Donald Trump's National Security Plans in Major Foreign Policy Speech

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential frontrunner, is set to deliver a major speech on foreign policy on Thursday in San Diego, California. The speech, scheduled for 11:30 a.m. local time, will outline a clear contrast between Clinton's plans and those proposed by her Republican counterpart, Donald Trump.

Clinton's campaign has stated that the speech will address Trump's national security plans, including his proposal to have Mexico pay for a border wall and his suggestion of temporarily banning Muslims from entering the U.S. Jake Sullivan, Clinton's senior policy adviser, has indicated that the speech will outline why Trump is "fundamentally unfit" to be president.

Sullivan further stated, "You will hear in her speech a confidence in America and our capacity to overcome the challenges we face while staying true to our values – a strong contrast to Donald Trump's incessant trash-talking of America."

Clinton's campaign expects to secure the final delegates needed to officially become the party's nominee after the California and New Jersey primaries on June 7. Clinton currently has 2,312 delegates, including 543 super delegates, to Bernie Sanders' 1,545 delegates, including 44 super delegates, according to the Associated Press.

In a Wednesday night speech at Rutgers University in New Jersey, Clinton called Trump a "fraud." Her remarks focused on newly released documents that show Trump University encouraged staff to target prospective students' financial weakness in order to enroll them in expensive courses. Clinton stated, "This is just more evidence that Donald Trump himself is a fraud."

Meanwhile, Barack Obama delivered a hit on Trump in a speech in Elkhart, Indiana, the same day. The U.S. president stated that a Trump presidency would increase the risk of a financial crisis. Obama said, "The Republican nominee for president has already said he'd dismantle all these rules that we passed. That is crazy."

Trump is also campaigning in California. Speaking in Sacramento on Wednesday night, he responded to Obama's claims by calling the president "a total lightweight."

Title: The Parallels Between Digital Surveillance and Speech Control in the U.S. and Authoritarian States

Article:

The ongoing digital surveillance and speech control measures during the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States are not unprecedented, as they represent an acceleration of long-standing trends towards increased censorship and surveillance of digital networks. The practices adopted by American tech platforms during the pandemic are not a departure from prior developments but a continuation of them.
