On Thursday, President Donald Trump blocked the release of hundreds of records related to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy, citing potential harm to national security. He placed these files under a six-month review while releasing 2,800 others to meet a deadline mandated by law.

The documents that were released show federal agents actively pursuing leads and managing worldwide rumors in the days following the assassination on November 22, 1963. The materials also cast a wide net over various activities of the Kennedy administration, including its covert efforts to destabilize Fidel Castro's government in Cuba.

A CIA spokesperson told Fox News that the agency had released all but 18,000 of its more than 87,000 documents related to the assassination, with the remaining records to be made available. The spokesperson added that some of the withheld documents contained redactions to protect information that, if disclosed, would harm national security, including the names of CIA assets, current and former CIA officers, as well as specific intelligence methods and partnerships still relevant to national security today.

Title: GAO Report Concludes President Trump Violated Law in Freezing Ukraine Funds

Article:

A report released by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) on Thursday concluded that President Donald Trump violated a 1974 law when he froze assistance funds for Ukraine last year. The White House has maintained that Trump was acting within his legal authority.

The decision to freeze military aid appropriated by Congress is at the center of impeachment proceedings against the president, which are currently transitioning from the Democrat-controlled House to the majority-Republican Senate. Democratic lawmakers have accused Trump of abusing his office by withholding hundreds of millions in assistance in order to pressure Ukraine to investigate his political rivals.

The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) blocked the Defense Department from spending money designated by Congress on July 25, citing a pending policy decision, according to OMB General Counsel Mark Paoletta. The hold was lifted on Sept. 12. However, the GAO report states that the 1974 law governing budget procedure within the government "does not permit OMB to withhold funds for policy reasons."

Thomas Armstrong, general counsel for the GAO, said, "Under the Impoundment Control Act, it is illegal for OMB to withhold money that has been appropriated by Congress and signed into law." If the White House wants to delay or deny funds, it must first alert Congress.

Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) asked the GAO to assess Trump's decisions to freeze the Ukraine aid. Van Hollen stated, "We now have a GAO decision stating conclusively that the Trump administration violated the law. We know the president ordered that violation of law. And it's just all the more important that Republican senators support a fair trial."

Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) opposes the introduction of fresh witnesses or evidence into a Senate trial, arguing the Senate's role is to assess the House's fact-finding, not to conduct new investigations. Senators are expected to vote on that question, and it is unclear whether there might be sufficient support from enough Republicans to bring in new evidence or witnesses.

After the release of the GAO report, the OMB issued a statement disagreeing with the findings. OMB spokeswoman Rachel Semmel said, "OMB uses its apportionment authority to ensure taxpayer dollars are properly spent consistent with the president's priorities and with the law." In a letter to GAO in December, OMB lawyer Paoletta argued that the holdup of the Ukraine aid was a simple "programmatic delay" and therefore did not require prior notice to Congress.

However, national security online forum Just Security reported in early January that Defense Department emails showed repeated warnings from the department to OMB that the delays put its ability to distribute the aid at risk.

Title: Gillette's New Commercial Challenges Toxic Masculinity: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

Gillette, the shaving company, has released a new commercial that addresses the concept of "toxic masculinity" and encourages men to behave better towards women and each other. However, the advertisement has sparked controversy among some conservative commentators, who have accused Gillette of promoting cultural Marxism, catering to leftist social priorities, and granting the premises of social justice warriors (SJW).

Upon closer examination of the ad, it becomes clear that these strong claims are exaggerated. The commercial primarily depicts men choosing not to bully each other, harass women, or commit violence. These actions are not necessarily "leftist social priorities" and are generally considered undesirable by both conservatives and liberals.

Ben Shapiro, a well-known conservative commentator, has criticized Gillette for promoting what he perceives as leftist ideals. However, it is important to note that the ad does not claim that all men are bad or that masculinity is always a dangerous ideal. Instead, it makes a modest call to action: treat people better.

Shapiro's criticism of the ad overlooks the importance of promoting respectful behavior and the reduction of violence and harassment. It is true that not all men engage in such behaviors, and it is also true that some women can be abusers. However, the ad does not make collectivist assumptions about men or women.

In a separate point, Shapiro emphasizes the importance of young men having strong male role models in their lives. He argues that young men should learn from men who treat women well and act as protectors rather than victimizers. Interestingly, this is exactly the message conveyed in the Gillette ad.

In conclusion, while some may find Gillette's ad controversial, it is important to consider the ad's message in a factual and unbiased manner. The ad does not promote cultural Marxism, leftist social priorities, or the idea that all men are bad. Instead, it encourages men to treat people better, which is a message that can be beneficial for society as a whole. People are free to choose which brands they support, but it is worth questioning whether boycotting companies for promoting respectful behavior is a worthwhile pursuit.

Title: Study Reveals Impact of News Consumption on Mental Health During National Crisis

Article:

Alison Holman, a researcher, was conducting a study on mental health across the United States when the Boston Marathon bombings occurred on April 15, 2013. The tragedy resulted in three deaths, including an eight-year-old boy, and hundreds of injuries, with sixteen individuals losing limbs.

In the aftermath of the bombings, news organizations provided extensive coverage, including footage of the explosion and its aftermath, as well as haunting images of blood-spattered streets, grieving spectators, and visibly shaken victims.

Holman and her colleagues from the University of California, Irvine, found themselves in possession of data about the mental wellbeing of nearly 5,000 people before the tragedy. They decided to investigate if the mental health of the participants had changed in the weeks following the event.

It was intuitively obvious that being physically present for or personally affected by a terrorist incident would negatively impact mental health. However, the study revealed a surprising twist. Those who had not witnessed the explosion in person but had consumed six or more hours of news coverage per day in the week following the event experienced higher levels of acute stress.

"It was a big 'aha' moment for us," says Holman. "I think people really strongly, deeply underestimate the impact the news can have."

The study suggests that news coverage is more than a neutral source of facts. It can influence our attitudes, shape our views of foreign countries, and possibly impact the health of entire economies. It can increase the risk of developing post-traumatic stress, anxiety, and depression. There is also emerging evidence that the emotional fallout of news coverage can affect our physical health, increasing the chances of having a heart attack or developing health problems years later.

Crucially, just a few hours of news consumption each day can have a significant impact beyond what one might expect. The reason for this is not yet fully understood.

Title: Red-State Democrats Face Re-election Challenges After Voting Against GOP Tax Bill

Article:

One red-state Democrat, Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia, stated that the GOP did not reach out enough to him on the tax-cut bill, while others said they could not find enough common ground to secure their votes. These Democrats, many of whom face re-election battles next year in states President Trump won by double-digit margins, are hoping voters will not punish them for their votes against the tax bill.

Sen. Joe Manchin said he had tried to find areas to collaborate with Republicans on the tax bill, but could not do so this time. He expressed concerns about the bill's focus on corporate tax cuts, particularly the permanent nature of these cuts compared to the planned expiration of individual rate reductions.

Congress passed the tax bill without any Democratic support, as they remained in opposition to the package. Several red-state Democrats, however, said they could have been partners on taxes if the GOP had taken a different approach.

Republican leaders claimed they welcomed Democratic support but said once the minority party's leaders decided to oppose the package, there was little hope for collaboration. After the vote, President Trump said Democrats would have to explain their stance.

"Unfortunately, the Democrats don't like to see tax cutting," President Trump said. "They like to see tax increases. And they like to complain. But they don't get it done, unfortunately. But they complain a lot."

While President Trump is considered political poison in some blue states, red-state Democrats took pains to say they tried to work with him. Sen. Claire McCaskill, for example, framed her vote against the bill as a disappointment that the plan favored corporations over individuals.

At a town-hall meeting in Missouri last week, Sen. McCaskill argued the bill betrayed the principles President Trump had originally proposed. However, some voters in her state expressed confusion about her opposition to the bill.

In Indiana, Sen. Joe Donnelly told his voters he met with President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence over the tax bill. He expressed a willingness to partner with Republicans, Democrats, and the Trump administration but noted that the bill produced by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan was the opposite of what he and the president had discussed.

In North Dakota, Sen. Heidi Heitkamp, who had previously expressed openness to voting for the bill, cited the additional $1.5 trillion in deficits as a reason for her vote against it. However, some voters in her state do not see this as a valid reason for opposition.

Doubling the death tax, a point of contention for Democrats who argue it benefits large corporations rather than farmers, is one aspect of the bill that people in agricultural North Dakota are paying close attention to. Daryl Lies, president of the North Dakota Farm Bureau, expressed support for the bill, stating that the increased deduction for the full purchase of equipment would benefit local farmers. He also noted that crop insurance "enhanced" during the time the bill was being debated.

Title: GOP Senators Request Information on Hunter Biden's Business Dealings and Travel Records

Article:

Two Republican senators, Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and Ron Johnson (R-Wis.), have requested clarification on potential conflicts of interest regarding Hunter Biden's business dealings in Ukraine and China. The senators sent a letter to Secret Service Director James Murray on Wednesday, inquiring about whether Hunter Biden used government-sponsored travel for private business purposes and seeking details of his travel records.

The senators' inquiry comes shortly after President Donald Trump's acquittal by the Senate on articles of impeachment related to his conduct in Ukraine. During the impeachment proceedings, Republicans have alleged that Joe Biden, while Vice President, conducted foreign policy to benefit his son's business interests in Ukraine, a claim for which there is no evidence.

The senators' letter is part of a broader effort by Republicans to shift focus from Trump's actions in Ukraine to the Biden family's business dealings. The claim is that Joe Biden pushed out a former Ukrainian prosecutor to quell an investigation into a Ukrainian energy company for which Hunter Biden served on the board. However, it was Joe Biden's position that the prosecutor was not effective in addressing corruption cases in Ukraine, a view shared by international leaders and anti-corruption groups.

Democrats have argued that Trump sought investigations to damage Joe Biden in the 2020 election, while Trump's legal team maintained that the president had legitimate reasons for concern.

In addition to Grassley and Johnson, Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) has also stated his intention to pursue the Bidens, suggesting that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee may call witnesses, including Hunter Biden, to testify about the matter in the coming weeks.

Joe Biden has dismissed all allegations as conspiracy theories but acknowledged that his son's role created a "bad image." In a recent statement, Joe Biden said, "No one's found anything wrong with his dealings with Ukraine except they say it sets a bad image."

Title: USCIS Director Francis Cissna Resigns, to be Replaced by Former Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli

Article:

The Director of the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), Francis Cissna, has resigned from his post on Friday, following a request from President Donald Trump, according to his resignation letter. Cissna will be succeeded by former Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli, as per a source familiar with the situation.

In his resignation letter, Cissna emphasized his commitment to enforcing the rule of law and laying the groundwork for effective immigration reform during his tenure. He wrote, "We are the government servants charged with lawfully, efficiently, and fairly adjudicating requests for immigration benefits, while protecting Americans, securing the homeland, and honoring our nation’s values."

Cissna's departure from his post has been in the works for several weeks, as Trump has sought to reshuffle his immigration officials. Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and Ronald Vitiello, who was acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, also left their positions last month. Republican lawmakers had urged the president to retain Cissna, but White House adviser Stephen Miller had sought to remove him for several weeks.

Rumors of Cuccinelli's selection to a top immigration post raised eyebrows earlier this week. Cuccinelli led the charge among the Republican National Convention to back Sen. Ted Cruz's nomination in 2016. However, members of Trump's inner circle told ███ earlier this week that the president had put their past differences aside and has come to admire Cuccinelli.

USCIS, which oversees legal immigration and traditionally defends it, has been a key element in the hardline crackdown on immigration under the Trump administration and Cissna's leadership. Cissna has overseen the significant reduction of the country's refugee program, the creation of a "denaturalization task force" aimed at stripping citizenship from those who committed fraud, and a change in policy to make it easier for visas to be denied.

In an interview with ███ Magazine in September, Cissna stated that he was not driven by anti-immigrant sentiment but rather a "strong commitment to the law, and to the rule of law."

Title: Congressional Leaders Criticize Obama's Surveillance Program Review, Accuse White House of Reacting to Events

Article:

Congressional leaders have criticized President Obama for his plan to review and potentially alter government surveillance programs, with some lawmakers taking aim at the White House's perceived reaction to the Edward Snowden leaks rather than the programs themselves. The changes proposed by the president on Friday were intended to address concerns that the federal government is eroding Americans' Fourth Amendment rights, but lawmakers argue that the administration has been slow to respond and has failed to explain the lawful programs that have saved lives and stopped terrorist plots.

In a news conference on Friday, President Obama asked Congress to review portions of the Patriot Act that allow the National Security Agency (NSA) and other agencies to monitor telephone records and gather other forms of data. The depth of these programs was first revealed by Edward Snowden, the former government contractor who was granted asylum in Russia and has been charged with espionage and other offenses by the Justice Department.

In addition to reviewing the Patriot Act, Mr. Obama also proposed putting privacy advocates in the courtroom to argue against the government's case for search warrants and enhanced snooping efforts. He also called for greater transparency around these programs, an effort to restore skeptical Americans' trust in their leaders.

Critics argue that the administration has fallen into the trap of reacting to events, such as the Snowden leaks, and the public pressure that results. Rep. Peter T. King, a New York Republican and a member of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, said on CBS' "Face the Nation" that the president has been "silent for the last two months."

"He's allowed the Edward Snowdens and the others of the world to dominate the media, and now we have people who actually think the NSA is spying on people, is listening to our phone calls, is reading our emails," Mr. King said.

In recent weeks, lawmakers' voices have become louder in the larger debate. Rep. James E. Clyburn, a South Carolina Democrat, joined Republicans last month in voting to defund NSA surveillance programs. He said he did so not because he doesn't trust the president but because he thinks Congress must be more involved.

"The president spoke out on this issue long before Snowden. And I was very comfortable with the president's position on this," he said on CNN's "State of the Union."

"It's just that every now and then, you cast a vote in order to let your constituents know, and for your colleagues to know, exactly how you feel about a situation, and sometimes, let the White House know that this is something that we can not allow you to have just a blank check on," he said.

Mr. Obama's proposed changes have also drawn criticism from outside Washington, including from Edward Snowden's father, Lon.

"What I've seen is much political theater," he said on ABC's "This Week." "I was disappointed in the president's press conference. I believe that's driven by his clear understanding that the American people are absolutely unhappy with what they learned. Much of what he suggested is superficial."

Lon Snowden appeared on the show alongside his attorney, Bruce Fein, and the two confirmed that they have secured visas and will travel to Russia soon to meet with Mr. Snowden.

Edward Snowden's revelations and the national debate they have spawned underscore a deeper problem in American society, some lawmakers say. Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican, said on "Fox News Sunday" that he doesn't disagree with any of the reform ideas that the president laid out last week but that efforts also must focus on the broader goal of restoring public confidence in elected leaders.

"There's a careful balance here between preserving our assets and capabilities and making sure the American people are convinced that their privacy is not being violated," Mr. McCain said.

"Right now, there is kind of a generational change. Young Americans do not trust this government. Without trust in government, you can't do a lot of things."

Mr. McCain cited the disparate reactions to the Snowden leaks as an example of the generation gap.

"There's a young generation who believes he's some kind of Jason Bourne," he said.

Title: U.S. and China Heading Toward Escalation in Trade Conflict

Article:

The United States and China are moving closer to a point where neither side can back down, with President Donald Trump announcing plans to impose 10 percent tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese-made products by August 30. The new tariffs, combined with previously announced tariffs of $50 billion, would affect almost half of all goods the U.S. imports from China.

China has seven weeks to respond or risk escalating the conflict further. President Xi Jinping has vowed to respond in kind, already imposing retaliatory duties on products from states that support Trump, such as Iowa soybeans and Kentucky bourbon. Matching the latest U.S. tariffs would force China to either levy higher tariffs or take more disruptive measures, such as canceling purchase orders, encouraging consumer boycotts, and imposing regulatory hurdles.

Trump has framed his trade actions as necessary to protect American businesses and farmers from harmful trading practices. "Other countries' trade barriers and tariffs have been destroying their businesses," Trump said in a Twitter post from Brussels, where he is attending a NATO summit. "I will open things up, better than ever before, but it can't go too quickly."

The trade conflict has already had an impact on the global economy, with stocks falling and commodities sliding on Wednesday. The S&P 500 Index ended the longest rally in a month, and the Stoxx Europe 600 Index retreated. Economists warn that a full-blown trade war could derail the strongest economic upswing in years.

The Chinese Commerce Ministry has stated that it will retaliate against the U.S. tariffs, and there have been no confirmed high-level talks between the two sides since an early June visit by U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross that achieved no breakthroughs. Beijing "never yields to threat or blackmail" and will retaliate against the "groundless" tariffs, according to China's Vice Minister of Commerce Wang Shouwen.

The trade conflict is expected to feature prominently in November's U.S. congressional elections, and the announcement has exposed fissures between Trump and his Republican Party about the strategy. Some Republican lawmakers have expressed concern about the trade spat with China and the uncertainty it is creating among farmers and businesses.

The latest move suggests that Trump may be compromising on his pledge to spare consumers from the pain of the trade war. The tariffs could raise the prices of a wide range of consumer products, including baseball gloves, handbags, and digital cameras, just as voters are heading to the polls. Other high-profile items, such as mobile phones, have so far been spared.

The U.S. has accused China of unfair trade practices and the abuse of American intellectual property, and has rejected Chinese offers to trim its trade surplus by buying more American goods. The Trump administration is demanding more systemic change, such as rolling back China's "Made-in-China 2025" program, a signature Xi initiative to dominate several strategic industries.

China's slowing, trade-dependent economy may not be able to withstand a sustained attack from Trump, which has already weighed heavily on stock prices. China has a million and one ways to retaliate, according to Scott Kennedy, deputy director of China studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

Title: House GOP Budget Proposes Pro-Growth, Balanced Spending Plan

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has stated that the new GOP House budget, passed this week, offers opportunities for middle-class families and small businesses to thrive. In a column for the Cleveland Plain Dealer, Boehner argued that the budget addresses the problem of spending under President Barack Obama, paves the way for job creation, and institutes a simpler and fairer tax code.

Boehner criticized Obama's proposed budget, stating it includes a 65 percent increase in spending over 10 years, more than $2 trillion in new taxes on working families, and $8.5 trillion in new debt for future generations. He claimed that many middle-class families are currently earning less under Obama's administration, facing high energy prices, rising food prices, and a difficult jobs market.

Boehner emphasized the need for bold new reforms to stimulate economic growth and expand opportunities for all. He highlighted the House's efforts to address the problem of spending directly while also protecting programs like Medicare and Social Security. The House also voted overwhelmingly to replace Medicare's Sustainable Growth Rate (SGR) formula with a system that rewards quality and innovation.

According to Boehner, this permanent SGR solution is a significant victory for the American people, marking the first real entitlement reform in decades. He explained that this change will help ensure seniors have access to their doctors, strengthen Medicare, and provide long-term savings for taxpayers.

Boehner concluded by expressing optimism for the House's accomplishments in the first 100 days of 2015 and looking forward to continued progress. He emphasized the House's commitment to listening to the American people and making decisions that benefit the country, rather than taking the easy route.

Title: Manhunt for Berlin Christmas Market Attack Suspect, Anis Amri, Across Europe

Article:

German prosecutors have identified a suspect in Monday's deadly lorry attack on a Berlin Christmas market as Anis Amri, a 23-year-old Tunisian national. Authorities are currently searching for Amri, who is believed to be armed and dangerous. His residence permit was found in the cab of the lorry.

According to reports, Amri had been under German surveillance earlier this year on suspicion of seeking to buy guns. The German authorities are offering a reward of up to €100,000 for information leading to his arrest.

The attack resulted in 12 deaths, and it is suspected that Amri may have been injured in a struggle with the lorry driver. The German authorities are investigating the incident, with police searching a migrant shelter in the Emmerich area of North Rhine-Westphalia, where Amri's permit was issued.

Chancellor Angela Merkel has met with her security cabinet to discuss the investigation into the attack. In another development, the German cabinet has approved plans to allow more video surveillance of public places.

Anis Amri reportedly travelled to Italy in 2012 and then on to Germany in 2015, where he applied for asylum and was granted temporary leave to stay in April of this year. Ralf Jaeger, the minister of interior of North Rhine-Westphalia, stated that the claim for asylum had been rejected in June but the papers necessary for deportation had not been ready.

Security agencies exchanged their findings and information about this person with the Joint Counter-Terrorism Centre in November 2016. Tunisia had initially denied Amri was its citizen, so the authorities had to wait for temporary passport documentation from Tunisia.

Judicial sources suggest that Amri was monitored in Berlin between March and September on suspicion of planning a robbery to pay for automatic weapons for use in an attack. Sueddeutsche Zeitung reports that the suspect moved within the circle of an Islamist preacher, Ahmad Abdelazziz A, known as Abu Walaa, who was arrested in November.

Investigators believe the lorry was hijacked on Monday afternoon as it stood in an industrial zone in north-western Berlin. The only confirmed death is that of Polish lorry driver Lukasz Urban, who appears to have fought the attacker before dying of stab and gunshot wounds.

Italian expatriate Fabrizia di Lorenzo, 31, from Sulmona near L'Aquila, is feared dead. It is understood her phone and metro pass were found at the scene. A woman from Neuss, near the west German city of Duesseldorf, is believed to be among the dead while her son, aged 40, is among the injured.

The German authorities have asked the family of Israeli woman Dalia Elyakim, missing since the attack, for DNA samples to help identify her; her husband Rami was seriously injured. A Spanish student, 21-year-old Inaki Ellakuria, survived the attack with leg injuries. He has been tweeting about his experiences.

There appears to be evidence that, despite being stabbed, Mr. Urban wrestled his hijacker for the steering wheel. The post-mortem examination suggests that Mr. Urban survived up until the attack and was shot dead when the truck came to a halt. No gun has been recovered.

Police say they are acting on hundreds of tips from the public and are examining DNA traces from the cab of the truck. The IS group claimed the attack through its self-styled news agency, saying it was "in response to calls to target nationals of the coalition countries."

Title: Job Market Weakens in December, Adding Only 74,000 Jobs

Article:

The U.S. job market experienced a significant slowdown in December, with the economy adding only 74,000 jobs, according to the government's report. This is the weakest month for job growth since January 2011 and fell far short of economists' expectations of an additional 193,000 jobs.

For the entire year of 2013, the economy added 2.2 million jobs, which is on par with 2012's gains. Some economists attribute December's weak job gains to a fluke, citing other strong economic data. They anticipate that the government will revise the numbers higher in the coming months.

Tim Hopper, chief economist for TIAA-CREF, stated, "Just about every other measure of job growth suggests that employers are either hiring or intending to hire, extending hours and laying off fewer people." Heidi Hartmann, president of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, added, "Let's not panic. It's not a horrible year, all things considered."

The government noted that "unusually cold weather in parts of the country" could have impacted construction jobs, as this sector lost 16,000 jobs in December.

The unemployment rate fell to 6.7% in December, but the decrease was primarily due to workers leaving the labor force. This could indicate that job market dropouts are retiring, enrolling in educational programs, or taking care of relatives. However, many have given up hope of finding work.

Only 62.8% of the adult population is participating in the labor market now, which matches the lowest level since 1978. In the job market's 2007 heyday, unemployment was under 5%, but in the two years that followed, the recession wiped out 8.7 million jobs. To this day, not all those jobs have returned.

Heidi Shierholz, economist with the Economic Policy Institute, stated, "We're going to have a long-term unemployment crisis for a long time."

Several individuals who have been unemployed for an extended period have shared their stories with CNNMoney. Jamie May, a former senior manager for a corporate housing company, has been job hunting for over a year. She has submitted applications for positions around the country and has indicated a willingness to take jobs in the $30,000 to $40,000 range.

Fred Royal, a former administrative assistant for a grocery chain, lost his job in March and has received the same message in interviews. "Many have said they think I will leave for a better paying job," he said. "Better paying job? I can't even get one job."

Both May and Royal were among the 1.3 million Americans who received their final check in federal unemployment benefits last week after Congress agreed on a budget that left out the recession-era program. Democrats are pushing for an extension of the program, but Republicans insist on finding a way to pay for it through cost-cutting elsewhere.

The ongoing tension between Washington policymakers is exemplified by the haggling over budget cuts versus aid to the still fragile economy. While Congress has focused on reducing government spending, the Federal Reserve has been injecting trillions of dollars into the economy in an attempt to help the job market.

Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke will end his second term at the central bank later this month without reaching his goal of "full employment." In a speech last week, he blamed part of the problem on government policy, stating, "Excessively tight near-term fiscal policies have likely been counterproductive."

The federal government has cut 98,000 jobs over the past three years, not including the Postal Service, which is independently funded but has also been slashing jobs. The Postal Service workforce is around its lowest level since the 1960s.

Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, forecasts it could take until the end of 2016 to get to a 5.5% unemployment rate. Shierholz calculates it could take even longer to get to a pre-recession job market—when unemployment was below 5%.

"Even if we did have 200,000 jobs a month, we would need five years to get there," she said.

Are you unemployed? Share your story with CNNMoney's Annalyn Kurtz.

Title: Super Typhoon Mangkhut Makes Landfall in Guangdong, China, After Wreaking Havoc in Hong Kong, Macau, and the Philippines

Article:

A powerful super typhoon, named Mangkhut, made landfall in China's Guangdong province on Sunday, the country's most populous province, following destructive impacts in Hong Kong, Macau, and the Philippines. The typhoon, considered the strongest to hit the region this year, has reportedly caused the deaths of potentially more than 50 people in the Philippines.

With winds exceeding 200 kph (125 mph) at its peak, tropical cyclone Mangkhut surpassed the strength of Hurricane Florence, which reached maximum sustained winds of 150 kph (90 mph) when it struck North Carolina in the United States on Friday. The eye of Mangkhut, named after the Thai mangosteen fruit, skirted approximately 100 kilometers (62 miles) south of Hong Kong, but the former British colony was still affected by the typhoon's swirling bands of rain and gale-force winds.

In Hong Kong, the city raised its highest No. 10 typhoon signal as fierce winds uprooted trees, shattered windows in buildings, and caused some structures to sway. Water levels surged 3.5 meters (12 feet) in some areas, and waves flooded roads and threw live fish into residential blocks and a mall in the eastern Heng Fa Chuen district.

In the Philippines, the reported death toll from Mangkhut's impact could exceed 50, with most fatalities occurring in landslides in or near mountainous areas of the Cordillera region. As of Sunday evening, various agencies reported 33 dead and 56 missing, but the head of the military's Northern Luzon Command, Emmanuel Salamat, stated that at least 19 more were killed in landslides in one part of Benguet province.

In Macau, which temporarily halted casino gambling late on Saturday, there was significant flooding of up to 2.5 meters (8.2 feet), with some people requiring rescue from their homes using rubber dinghies. Around 20,000 Macau households also experienced a power blackout, according to local media.

The typhoon, known as the "King of Storms" by Chinese media, made landfall in Haiyan town at 5 p.m. local time. Ports, oil refineries, and industrial plants in the area have been shut, and power to some areas was reduced as a precaution. In Shenzhen, the electricity supply to more than 130,000 homes was cut at one point on Sunday.

Mangkhut is expected to continue its northwesterly track, bringing heavy rain and winds to the autonomous region of Guangxi early on Monday. The storm is forecast to weaken into a tropical depression when it reaches southwestern Yunnan province in the early hours of Tuesday.

Title: Physician David Nathan Disagrees with David Frum's Stance on Marijuana Legalization for Adults

Article:

In a recent op-ed for CNN.com, conservative political commentator David Frum argued against the legalization of marijuana. However, clinical psychiatrist David Nathan, who shares Frum's concerns about the potential harm of marijuana, particularly for young people and the psychiatrically ill, disagrees with Frum's stance on the drug's legalization for adults.

Nathan, who is a father and a physician, believes that the negative legal consequences of marijuana use are far worse than the medical consequences. He argues that by keeping marijuana illegal, dangerous drugs like alcohol and tobacco are also kept illegal, which he considers an unjust and harmful policy.

Nathan proposes a different approach, suggesting that marijuana should be legal for adults and regulated like alcohol, with education about the risks provided to children from a young age. He argues that by making marijuana illegal, it has been elevated to a forbidden fruit, making it more attractive to young people.

Throughout his career as a clinical psychiatrist, Nathan has seen lives ruined by drugs like cocaine, painkillers, alcohol, and tobacco. He has also witnessed the devastation caused by marijuana use, but he attributes this not to the drug itself, but to the justice system that chooses to punish users rather than provide education and support.

Nathan points out that alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, caffeine, and refined sugar are among the most commonly used, potentially habit-forming recreational substances. He argues that all should be left out of our daily diets, but only marijuana is illegal, while alcohol and tobacco are clearly more harmful.

Nathan also argues that the dangers of alcohol, such as pancreatitis, gastritis, cirrhosis, permanent dementia, physiological dependence, and fatal withdrawal, far surpass the dangers of marijuana. He also notes that alcohol causes severe impairment of judgment, which results in violence, risky sexual behavior, and more use of hard drugs.

Nathan also argues that the illegal purchase of marijuana exposes consumers to dealers who push hard drugs, while the legal purchase of marijuana could decrease the consumption of more dangerous drugs. He also points out the potential for adulteration of black-market cannabis and the substitution of more dangerous copycat compounds, which can be harmful or even fatal.

Nathan concludes that the ban on cannabis was based on bad science and fabricated stories of violence perpetrated under the influence, and that America can fix this mess through marijuana legalization and regulation. He suggests that federal, state, and local governments can regulate the cannabis trade as they do with alcohol and tobacco, monitoring the production process for safety and purity, controlling where it is sold, taxing all aspects of marijuana production and consumption, and redirecting resources from punishment to prevention.

Title: Donald Trump's Presidential Campaign: A Look at the Businessman and Reality TV Star's Political History

Article:

The 2016 presidential race has attracted a diverse field of major candidates, with Donald Trump standing out among them. On Tuesday, he officially joined the race, two days after his 69th birthday.

Donald Trump, often referred to as "The Donald," is a billionaire real estate developer and television personality. He is known for his signature properties, such as Trump Plaza in Manhattan, golf resorts in Florida, and casinos in Atlantic City. Trump gained national recognition through his successful run as a reality TV star on The Apprentice and The Celebrity Apprentice.

In the past, Trump has made forays into national politics. In late 1999, he was among several contenders for the Reform Party nomination, the remnant of the third-party movement begun by billionaire H. Ross Perot in 1992. Trump eventually withdrew from that contest, but in 2008 and 2012, he expressed interest in seeking the Republican presidential nomination. He was a vocal critic of President Obama's policies during those years and appeared frequently with other candidates, such as Sarah Palin.

Trump was a proponent of the so-called birther movement, questioning President Obama's eligibility for the office based on allegations that he was born outside the United States. Despite definitive documents from Obama's birth in Hawaii in 1961, Trump continued to question Obama's birthplace.

Trump was sent to the New York Military Academy at the age of 13 to learn discipline. He later attended Fordham University and the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of finance. Trump initially went into business with his father, a developer of middle-class housing in Queens and other outer boroughs of New York, but he soon shifted his focus to Manhattan and participated in higher-risk, higher-reward projects.

Trump has been drawing about 5 percent among Republicans in some national polls, which would qualify him for the Fox News debate on Aug. 6, featuring the top 10 candidates in an average of national polls. Although his actual net worth has been a matter of dispute, Trump is estimated to be worth $4.1 billion by Forbes magazine.

In 2000, Trump received 15,311 votes in the California Reform Party primary, 44 percent of the total, despite not campaigning for the primary. Trump's NBC TV show, The Apprentice, was a hit from its introduction in 2004. He has also been a frequent guest on TV talk shows, including The Late Show With David Letterman, and has appeared in TV ads for various products.

Trump's big breakthrough in business came when he was 34, with the acquisition of the old Commodore Hotel near Manhattan's Grand Central Station. Trump and various partners redesigned the hotel as the Grand Hyatt, a major success after extensive restoration of Grand Central itself. He later bought and renovated the iconic Plaza Hotel at the southeast corner of Central Park and the Barbizon at the southwest corner.

Trump has been married three times and has five children. His three children from his first marriage—Donald Jr., Ivanka, and Eric—are now in their 30s and involved in the Trump Organization businesses. Trump's first marriage to Ivana lasted from 1977 to 1991, and they appeared in Pizza Hut ads together after their separation, joking about how they would split up the pie.

Title: Water Infrastructure Crisis in the U.S. Highlighted by Flint, Michigan Incident

Article:

The water crisis in Flint, Michigan, serves as a stark reminder of the fragile state of the nation's water infrastructure. The aging water infrastructure in the United States, which serves over 300 million people through approximately 150,000 public water systems, is riddled with rusting, leaky pipes and outdated plans. If not addressed, this issue could have severe and lasting consequences on numerous communities.

The Flint crisis, which began in 2014 when the city switched its water supply from Detroit's system to the Flint River as a cost-saving measure, is a potential precursor to similar situations in other communities. The negligence that led to the contamination of Flint's water supply, exposing families and young children to lead, is alarming.

Lead, a harmful compound, has well-documented effects on a developing brain and body. In 1978, a successful campaign to remove lead from home paint products resulted in a new law due to the risks associated with lead poisoning from ingesting paint chips. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) established an action level for lead in public drinking water at 15 micrograms per liter in 1991, requiring water supplies to routinely test household tap water for lead levels.

Exposure to lead can occur through direct consumption of contaminated water with unsafe levels or indirectly through inhalation of contaminated water particles. Once lead enters the human body, it can accumulate in bones or major organs like the liver or kidneys, disrupting their normal cellular biology and potentially leading to chronic diseases. The most significant damage from lead poisoning is inflicted on the brain, particularly in young or unborn children. Lead deposits in a developing fetal brain can cause irreversible damage, resulting in low IQ, severe cognitive delays, memory disruptions, learning disabilities, and other neurological deficits.

The Obama administration has reportedly appointed Dr. Nicole Lurie to address the crisis in Flint, but efforts should extend beyond Michigan. Lurie and other officials must evaluate other areas of the U.S. where residents are most at risk of a similar disaster. The government's failure to protect Flint underscores the urgent need for action to safeguard other communities.

Title: Professor Vanessa Tyson Accuses Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of Sexual Assault

Article:

Vanessa Tyson, a professor who has accused Virginia Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax (D) of sexual assault, issued her first statement Wednesday detailing her allegation against him.

"What began as consensual kissing quickly turned into a sexual assault," Tyson, a college professor from California, said in the statement. "Mr. Fairfax forced me to perform oral sex on him."

Tyson has accused Fairfax of sexually assaulting her at the 2004 Democratic National Convention in Boston. Fairfax has denied the accusation.

In a statement earlier Wednesday, Fairfax maintained that his interaction with Tyson was consensual. "At no time did she express to me any discomfort or concern about our interactions, neither during that encounter nor the months following it, when she stayed in touch with me, nor the past fifteen years," Fairfax said in the statement. "She in no way indicated that anything that had happened between us made her uncomfortable."

The governor's office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Tyson contradicted Fairfax's denial, saying, "I can not believe, given my obvious distress, that Mr. Fairfax thought this forced sexual act was consensual. To be very clear, I did not want to engage in oral sex with Mr. Fairfax and I never gave any form of consent."

"I suffered from both deep humiliation and shame," Tyson said, adding that she did not tell anyone for years.

She did approach The Washington Post with her story last year, but the paper said it did not publish her story because it could not find anyone to corroborate it.

Tyson is a professor of politics at Scripps College in California, although she is on fellowship at Stanford University this year. In addition to being a professor and author, Tyson advocates for sexual assault awareness and prevention, according to the Scripps College website.

She said in her statement that the allegations are not politically motivated and that she is a "proud Democrat."

Tyson is represented by Katz, Marshall & Banks, the same law firm that represented Christine Blasey Ford, who accused Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh of assault last year. The firm did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The allegation against Fairfax surfaced after a photo was released Friday of Virginia Governor Ralph Northam's (D) medical school yearbook page that pictured a man dressed in blackface and another dressed in Ku Klux Klan robes. Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring (D) on Wednesday also admitted to using blackface as a teenager, deepening the leadership crisis in the Commonwealth.

Title: Donald Trump Alters Political Landscape, Exposes GOP Challenges

Article:

In a series of political developments, Donald Trump, a presidential candidate and business magnate, has been vocal about his criticisms of the Republican Party, alleging that it is led by delusional and incompetent politicians who have failed to deliver significant victories. Trump's comments come amidst a backdrop of a 15-year-long war, during which the GOP has spent two trillion dollars and lost thousands of American lives without achieving any tangible results.

For years, numerous politicians have promised to reform Washington, D.C., but have failed to deliver on their promises. According to Trump, the Obama administration has manipulated the weak House of Representatives and Senate, leading to widespread dissatisfaction among Americans.

Trump's candidacy has gained momentum, with Senator Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio struggling to gain traction in the race. This dynamic has allowed Trump to maintain a strong position in the Republican primary race. The current state of the Republican Party, according to Trump, is a reflection of the self-serving nature of politicians who prioritize their personal status over the common good of the country.

In the past nine months, Trump has reportedly dismantled the Jeb Bush campaign and has been successful in making a mockery of the two first-term senators. Trump's campaign strategy has put him on a clear path to winning the Republican nomination.

Trump's unconventional approach to politics has resonated with a significant portion of the American electorate, particularly those who have been yearning for a'shake-up' in the political landscape. Trump's campaign has been successful in various regions across the country, catapulting him to the forefront of the race.

While Trump is not without flaws, his candidacy has exposed the Republican Party for what many perceive as its true nature. Some Americans view Trump as a real, action-oriented candidate who is unafraid to challenge the status quo, causing politicians to quiver in their shallow shoes. The future of the Republican Party and the 2016 presidential race remains uncertain, but Trump's impact on the political landscape is undeniable.

Title: House Democrats Begin Process to Obtain President Trump's Tax Returns

Article:

House Democrats will initiate the first step toward obtaining President Donald Trump's personal tax returns, with a hearing scheduled for Thursday by the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Oversight. The hearing aims to discuss legislative proposals and laws governing the process to acquire the documents.

The hearing will feature testimony from a group of tax law experts, including a 1924 measure that allows the chairman of the tax-writing panel to privately examine anyone's tax returns. A majority vote from the committee would be required to publicly release the returns, if obtained.

Democratic leaders argue that the filings could provide insight into Trump's global businesses, wealth, debt, charitable giving, and potential conflicts of interest. The call for Trump to make his tax returns public dates back to the early days of the 2016 presidential campaign, but he never released them.

House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, D-Md., has suggested a cautious approach, preferring to hold a hearing before acting to obtain the documents. Hoyer stated, "A president of the United States is in a very unique position to individually do things, as this president has displayed probably more than most. And, therefore, it's important that the American people know whether the president is acting on their behalf or in his interest."

Republican opposition to the release of Trump's tax returns is not necessarily about Trump's returns but rather about "protecting the rights of every private taxpayer," according to Rep. Kevin Brady, the top Republican on the committee who chose not to pursue Trump's returns during the last Congress.

Five witnesses are expected to testify at the hearing, including Joseph J. Thorndike, George K. Yin, Noah Bookbinder, Steven M. Rosenthal, and Ken Kies. The hearing will provide insight into the legal and political implications of obtaining President Trump's tax returns.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Arizona's Immigration Law's "Show Me Your Papers" Provision, Strikes Down Criminal Penalties

Article:

The Supreme Court of the United States on Monday issued a 5-3 ruling that struck down most of Arizona's controversial immigration law, SB 1070, as an unlawful infringement on federal power. However, the court upheld the provision that allows police to stop and question individuals they suspect are in the country illegally, often referred to as the "Show Me Your Papers" provision.

Arizona Governor Jan Brewer, a Republican, announced plans to move forward with enforcing the upheld part of the law, despite the rest of it being struck down. The ruling comes less than a week after President Obama announced a policy change to stop deporting most young adult illegal immigrants.

In the complex ruling, all eight justices agreed that Arizona police can question the legal status of those they stop, but the five-justice majority struck down the parts of the law that sought to impose Arizona's own criminal penalties for immigration violations. The majority argued that this power is reserved exclusively for the federal government.

Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, writing for the majority, stated that states cannot act in areas in which the Constitution grants powers to Congress, specifically citing Article I, Section 8, Clause 4, which grants Congress powers over naturalization.

Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas, and Samuel A. Alito Jr. each wrote dissents, arguing that Arizona should have been allowed to enact its own penalties for immigration violations, as long as they do not conflict with federal law.

The law, signed by Governor Brewer in 2010, required police to check the immigration status of those they encountered whom they had reasonable suspicion were in the country illegally, and required them to contact federal immigration authorities to give them a chance to put the individuals in deportation proceedings. The law also imposed state penalties on illegal immigrants who applied for jobs.

The Obama administration sued to stop the law, and lower courts stayed both of those parts of the law. Governor Brewer appealed, and the case went to the Supreme Court.

In the intervening two years, a handful of other states moved ahead with their own crackdown laws, while other localities codified so-called sanctuary-city policies that discouraged police from reporting illegal immigrants to federal authorities. The Obama administration has not taken action against the sanctuary city policies.

During the debate over SB 1070, President Obama and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. both criticized the law as opening up the chance for racial profiling. However, when they sued, they did not make that argument, instead confining their challenge to issues of federal versus state power.

The racial profiling challenge could still come later, as the law begins to be enforced. Governor Brewer expects this and has issued an executive order asking that training materials be distributed to all police to refresh them on what constitutes reasonable suspicion for a stop. Race or ethnicity alone is not enough to meet the threshold.

It remains to be seen whether Thursday's ruling opens the floodgates for other states to follow suit. In 2011, the court upheld an earlier Arizona law that required all businesses in the state to use E-Verify, the voluntary electronic system the federal government makes available for businesses to ensure their new hires are legal workers. After Arizona, a series of other states passed similar E-Verify laws, but that pace slackened in 2012, according to a study by ImmigrationWorks USA, which pushes for a broad national legalization solution to illegal immigration.

Title: George Zimmerman Verdict and the Persistence of Racial Bias in American Society

Article:

The verdict in the George Zimmerman trial, which resulted in his acquittal, has sparked widespread debate and controversy. The case, which revolved around the shooting of Trayvon Martin, a young African-American, by Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch volunteer, has been met with mixed reactions.

The case, according to some analysts, is a reflection of a more subtle form of racial bias in American society, often referred to as "laissez-faire racism." This form of racism, as explained by Harvard sociologist Lawrence Bobo, is based on the notion that African Americans themselves and their cultural norms are to blame for their social and economic position in American life.

This perspective is encapsulated in the quote by Chief Justice John Roberts: "The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race." The shift from overt racism to a more subtle form, as described by Roberts, has led to a situation where overt racism is no longer enshrined in law, but the application and effects of that racism are still being felt.

The case of Jordan Davis, another shooting incident in Florida, is often cited as a parallel to the Trayvon Martin case. These incidents are not about the law, although Stand Your Ground may embolden those who might have otherwise retreated, but a culture that treats all black youth as potential suspects, as potential drug dealers or gang members, or almost definitely a gun owner, despite doing little more than listening to music loudly.

It's important to note that African-Americans do not commit crimes at higher rates than whites. According to data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Justice Statistics, rates of robbery and serious property offenses among black youth are at their lowest in 40 years. Rates of violent crime and victimization also show a similar trend.

However, young black men are a disproportionate share of the nation's murder victims. This disproportionate representation is often linked to factors such as hyper-segregation, entrenched poverty, and lack of economic opportunities in many black communities.

The prevalence of violence in these communities has led to the emergence of numerous inner-city anti-violence groups that focus on creating opportunities for young, disadvantaged African-Americans through education, mentoring, and community programs.

Critics argue that the U.S. has not reached a post-racial society, and that laws are not free of racism. The Atlantic's Ta-Nehisi Coates, in his analysis of the Trayvon Martin case, states that the injustice in the case was not due to a weak prosecution, but rather a result of a country that has, for the majority of its history, erected a pariah class.

In conclusion, the George Zimmerman trial and the subsequent verdict serve as a stark reminder of the persistence of racial bias in American society. The case is not about the law, but a reflection of a culture and system that is not designed for equality. The first step towards addressing this issue, as acknowledged by many, is acknowledging and understanding the extent of this problem.

Title: 9th Circuit Court of Appeals Upholds Injunction Against Revised Travel Ban

Article:

The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals on Monday upheld a lower court ruling that blocks parts of President Trump's revised travel ban, marking the second time the court has ruled against the administration on the matter. The California-based court affirmed the Hawaii District Court ruling, which temporarily bars nationals from six Muslim-majority countries from entering the U.S., suspends the entry of all refugees, and reduces the cap on the admission of refugees from 110,000 to 50,000 for the 2017 fiscal year.

In a unanimous ruling, a three-judge panel on the court said President Trump's revised order does not offer a sufficient justification to suspend the entry of more than 180 million people on the basis of nationality. The judges noted that the Immigration and Nationality Act gives the president broad powers to control the entry of foreigners, but stated that the president's authority is subject to certain statutory and constitutional restraints.

The judges cited President Trump's tweets in defending their finding that the order does not provide a reason why permitting entry of nationals from the six designated countries under current protocols would be detrimental to the interests of the United States. They also vacated the part of the lower court ruling that blocked the government's ability to conduct interagency reviews of its vetting procedures, but ordered the court to issue a new order that blocks the temporary ban while allowing the government to proceed with its review.

The court also called the government's argument that the District Court erred in issuing an injunction that runs against the president himself "well taken." They vacated that part of the District Court's injunction to the extent the order runs against the president, but said it still applies to the remaining defendants and all their respective officers, agents, servants, employees, and attorneys, and people in active concert or participation with them.

The decision marks the second time the 9th Circuit has ruled against President Trump. In February, the court refused to reinstate Trump's first travel ban after a federal District Court judge in Washington state blocked it. President Trump revised the order to address the court's concerns, removing Iraq from the list of banned countries, eliminating the indefinite ban on Syrian refugees, and deleting language that gave preference to religious minorities when the refugee program resumed.

The administration has already asked the Supreme Court to step in. The Department of Justice filed two emergency applications on June 1 asking the Supreme Court to block the 4th Circuit and Hawaii District Court rulings blocking the ban and to review its case. The Supreme Court had asked the groups fighting the ban to respond to the department's requests by 3 p.m. on Monday. The 9th Circuit is now the second federal appeals court to rule against President Trump's revised travel ban. A full panel of 13 judges on the Richmond, Va.-based 4th Circuit Court of Appeals also refused to reinstate it, but focused on the statements Trump made while on the campaign trail and in office in finding the order discriminatory. The judges said in their 10-3 ruling that the revised order "speaks with vague words of national security, but in context drips with religious intolerance, animus, and discrimination."

Title: The Democratic Party's Decline During the Obama Presidency

Article:

The Democratic Party is currently facing a political crisis, with the potential for the situation to worsen if they do not win the White House in November. One aspect of President Obama's legacy is the weakening of his party. While Obama achieved numerous successes during his tenure, such as health care reform, climate change regulations, and Wall Street reform, his legacy will also include a significant failure: a diminished Democratic Party.

During Obama's eight years in office, the Democrats have lost more House, Senate, state legislative, and governor seats than under any other president. When Obama took office, there were 60 Democratic senators; now there are 46. The number of House seats held by Democrats has shrunk from 257 to 188. There are now nine fewer Democratic governors than in 2009. Democrats currently hold fewer elected offices nationwide than at any time since the 1920s.

The electoral landscape in the United States can be divided into two distinct categories: Presidential Election America and Midterm Election America. Presidential Elections attract a diverse electorate that is younger, browner, more single, more secular – more Democratic. In contrast, Midterm Elections attract an older, whiter, more rural, more church-going – in other words, more Republican – electorate. The majority of governorships and state legislative seats are elected during Midterm Elections, and the Democrats are currently at a low ebb in these positions.

President Obama himself has acknowledged this issue, lamenting the Democrats' inability to mobilize voters during Midterm Elections. He suggested that Democrats may not view Midterms as "sexy enough." The Democrats also faced a significant setback due to the Republicans' Tea Party-fueled surge in 2010, which coincided with the decennial census and allowed the Republicans to draw new congressional and state legislative district boundaries, disadvantaging the Democrats.

Former Pennsylvania Governor Ed Rendell noted the impact of this redistricting in his state, stating, "When I left office in January of 2011, there were 13 Democratic congressmen and six Republican congressmen. As a result of redistricting in the 2010 election, that turned around, and we now have 13 Republican congressmen and five Democratic congressmen."

The Democratic Party's decline is not solely due to bad timing and gerrymandering. Mo Elleithee, a former Democratic National Committee official, notes that the Democrats have historically neglected state legislative races, while the Republicans prioritize these races. This disparity makes it easier for the Republicans to draw congressional and state legislative districts that disadvantage Democrats.

Democratic voters are often clustered in urban areas, which, for the purposes of winning elections, means that Democratic voters are not efficiently distributed. This is why, despite being in red states like Texas and Utah, there are cities that are solidly Democratic, and why lesbian mayors were elected in Houston and Salt Lake City. When Democrats cluster in and around cities, they win local elections, but this does not help them win suburban or rural congressional seats.

This November, the stakes for the Democrats could not be higher. Without the White House, assuming party control elsewhere remains the same, the Democrats would be truly out in the cold.

Title: ICE Council President Criticizes Gang of 8 for Excluding Law Enforcement Input in Immigration Overhaul

Article:

In a recent hearing on the new Gang of 8 illegal immigration overhaul, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Council President Chris Crane expressed frustration with the lack of law enforcement input in the development of the new legislation. Crane stated, "Never before have I seen such contempt for law enforcement officers as what I've seen from the Gang of 8."

Crane claimed that law enforcement agents, including border sheriffs, interior sheriffs, deputies, and immigration agents, came to Washington D.C. with the hope of having their concerns heard. However, according to Crane, not one member of the Gang of 8 attended the two meetings held on separate days. Furthermore, Crane was escorted out by police during a recent Gang of 8 press conference after asking a question.

Crane has previously stated that the Gang of 8 plan does not address the criminal alien and cartel element in the United States, and falls short in allowing ICE agents to enforce current immigration laws both on the border and on the interior of the country. In a phone call with reporters two weeks ago, Crane said, "We are not even scratching the surface on the criminal illegal alien problem in the United States." He also noted that the drug cartels, their lieutenants, and troops are operating within the interior of the United States, and that many other criminal elements and individuals are also present.

Crane expressed concern that the debate on immigration reform is primarily political and not focused on addressing the problems within the broken immigration system and ensuring public safety. He stated, "That conversation is almost completely absent from this entire public conversation about what's happening... It's just another part of this debate that gives us this concern that this is all about politics and not about really fixing the problems that we face within our broken immigration system and providing for what is best for everyone, including and most importantly, public safety."

The Gang of 8, a bipartisan group of senators, is responsible for drafting the immigration overhaul bill. The bill aims to address issues such as border security, a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, and the modernization of the legal immigration system. The bill has been met with both support and criticism from various groups, including law enforcement, business, and immigrant rights organizations. The hearings on the bill are ongoing.

Title: GOP Criticism Mounts as Trump Continues Attacks on Khans, Parents of Army Captain Killed in Iraq

Article:

In the aftermath of a controversial week that saw Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's wife, Melania, accused of plagiarizing passages from Michelle Obama's convention speech, Trump continued his attacks on Khizr and Ghazala Khan, the parents of an Army captain killed in Iraq.

Khizr Khan delivered a powerful speech criticizing Trump at last week's Democratic National Convention. Trump's sustained hostility towards the Khans has made other Republican candidates and officeholders deeply uncomfortable. On Monday morning, Arizona Sen. John McCain, whom Trump once mocked for being shot down and captured during the Vietnam War, issued a nearly 700-word statement denouncing Trump's critiques of the Khans.

"In recent days, Donald Trump disparaged a fallen soldier's parents. He has suggested that the likes of their son should not be allowed in the United States — to say nothing of entering its service," McCain said. "I can not emphasize enough how deeply I disagree with Mr. Trump's statement."

McCain continued, "I claim no moral superiority over Donald Trump. I have a long and well-known public and private record for which I will have to answer at the Final Judgment, and I repose my hope in the promise of mercy and the moderation of age. I challenge the nominee to set the example for what our country can and should represent."

"Arizona is watching. It is time for Donald Trump to set the example for our country and the future of the Republican Party. While our Party has bestowed upon him the nomination, it is not accompanied by unfettered license to defame those who are the best among us," McCain added.

Lastly, McCain said, "I'd like to say to Mr. and Mrs. Khan: thank you for immigrating to America. We're a better country because of you. And you are certainly right; your son was the best of America, and the memory of his sacrifice will make us a better nation — and he will never be forgotten."

On the final night of the Democratic convention, Khizr Khan spoke out against Trump's call to temporarily ban all Muslim immigrants from the United States, asking whether the candidate had read the Constitution before pulling out a copy from his suit jacket and offering to lend Trump his personal copy.

Trump, in turn, criticized the Khans in TV appearances and on Twitter. Speaking to ABC's This Week, he asked whether Ghazala Khan "was not allowed to have anything to say." (Her response: speaking about her dead son is too painful for her to do in public.)

Republicans like House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell spent the weekend issuing statements distancing themselves from Trump's attacks on the Muslim immigrants. However, Trump continued to tweet on Monday morning.

Despite a Sunday night statement issued by Trump's running mate, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, that sought to paint a more conciliatory picture, saying, "Donald Trump and I believe that Captain Humayun Khan is an American hero and his family, like all Gold Star families, should be cherished by every American," Trump continued to tweet.

Gold Star families is a term the military uses for the parents, siblings, and children of men and women killed in combat.

In a Monday morning appearance on the Today Show, Khizr Khan said of Trump's response, "this candidate amazes me — his ignorance. He can get up and malign the entire nation. The religions, the communities, the minorities, the judges."

Khan continued, "And yet a private citizen in this political process, in his candidacy for the stewardship of this country, I can not say what I feel? That proves the point he has not read the Constitution of the country."

Despite being dragged into a feud with the GOP's presidential nominee, Khan said his last week was a positive experience. "My belief in the goodness of America is reaffirmed," he said. "Everywhere people are supporting our message. People are hugging, holding hands, wanting to get pictures. That is the goodness of America I was speaking about."

Title: Trump Administration Proposes to Alter Long-standing Flores Settlement on Immigrant Child Detention

Article:

The Trump administration has announced a proposal to alter a decades-old legal settlement, known as the Flores agreement, which currently prevents the long-term detention of immigrant children when families are arrested for attempting to enter the United States illegally. The proposal, announced as a rule change in the Federal Register, aims to allow families to be detained together until their immigration cases are decided.

The proposal, if implemented, would circumvent the 1997 Flores agreement, which restricts authorities from detaining children for more than 20 days. The administration earlier this year was denied by a federal judge in California when it asked to detain families beyond the 20-day limit.

The new proposal would allow families, most of whom are seeking asylum, to be detained together throughout the duration of their lengthy immigration proceedings. The proposal states that it would offer protections similar to those outlined in the Flores settlement.

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen stated in a statement that the rule addresses the department's inability to enforce immigration laws due to legal loopholes. The rule is scheduled to be published in the Federal Register on Friday, and the public will have 60 days to comment.

The zero-tolerance policy, implemented earlier this year, resulted in the separations of children from their families who were arrested at the border. President Trump, facing a widespread outcry, then ordered an end to the separations. The government has reunited nearly 2,000 once-separated children but is still trying to reconnect almost 500 children whose parents have been deported.

Under the Flores agreement, immigrant children must be held in licensed child-care facilities. The government has been unable to obtain such licenses for the two largest family detention centers in Texas and has bed space for more than 3,000 people. A smaller facility in Pennsylvania is licensed to care for children but has room for only about 100 people.

The administration wants to now "create an alternative to the existing licensed program requirement for family residential centers, so that ICE [Immigration and Customs Enforcement] may use appropriate facilities to detain family units together during their immigration proceedings, consistent with applicable law."

The proposal has faced swift condemnation from immigration advocates and others. Omar Jadwat, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Immigrants' Rights Project, stated, "It is sickening to see the United States government looking for ways to jail more children for longer. That's the complete opposite of what we should be doing."

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) stated, "My position's been really clear about this: We should not be separating people at the border." He added, "I believe that's what the administration also agrees...we shouldn't be separating families at the border."

In addition, the administration announced on Thursday that ICE deported more than 191,000 immigrants between October and the end of June, a 9% increase from the same time last year. During the Trump administration's first year, 226,199 immigrants were deported, a nearly 6% decrease from the last year of the Obama administration. The agency has also made nearly 120,000 arrests, a 16% increase since last year. About 55% of those arrested were convicted criminals, according to Nathalie Asher, the ICE official running the agency's enforcement and removal operations. She stated that the majority of noncriminal immigrants arrested "came to ICE's attention due to criminal charges."

Title: Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein Defends Justice Department's Handling of Mueller Report

Article:

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, in his first interview since the conclusion of the special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, defended the Justice Department's handling of the still-secret report, stating that Attorney General William Barr is "being as forthcoming as he can" in the process of redacting and releasing the roughly 400-page document.

In the interview, Mr. Rosenstein countered suggestions that Mr. Barr is misleading the public by releasing only a four-page summary of Mueller's investigation. The attorney general, in his letter, stated that the Mueller probe found no evidence of President Trump and his campaign conspiring with Russian interference in the 2016 election but reached no conclusion about whether the president obstructed justice. With no recommendation, Mr. Barr and Mr. Rosenstein determined Mr. Trump's actions were not criminal.

Democrats have demanded access to the full report, which Mr. Barr said he would release, likely next week, after blacking out portions for sensitive information. Mr. Rosenstein dismissed concerns that Mr. Barr is seeking to protect the president from politically damaging information the report may contain.

"He's being as forthcoming as he can, and so this notion that he's trying to mislead people, I think is just completely bizarre," Mr. Rosenstein said.

Mr. Barr is under pressure to quickly produce the edited report amid concerns from Democrats that the attorney general, a longtime advocate of executive-branch authority, is withholding information. Their worries were heightened after reports that some investigators on Mr. Mueller's team had told associates in recent days that they believe the report is more critical of Mr. Trump on the obstruction issue than Mr. Barr indicated in his summary. Mr. Rosenstein declined to discuss why Mr. Mueller rendered no conclusion on that critical question.

"It would be one thing if you put out a letter and said, 'I'm not going to give you the report,'" Mr. Rosenstein said. "What he said is, 'Look, it's going to take a while to process the report. In the meantime, people really want to know what's in it. I'm going to give you the top-line conclusions.'"

Mr. Rosenstein, Mr. Barr, their top advisers, and a member of Mr. Mueller's team have been involved in reviewing the report for material related to intelligence sources, continuing investigations, grand-jury matters, and the privacy of individuals not charged with crimes. Mr. Rosenstein declined to discuss the progress of this process, only expressing confidence in Mr. Barr.

The interview took place in Mr. Rosenstein's fourth-floor office at the Justice Department, in his waning days on the job. With the special counsel investigation he oversaw now complete, Mr. Trump's nominee to replace him, Deputy Transportation Secretary Jeffrey Rosen, awaits Senate confirmation. After nearly 30 years in the department, Mr. Rosenstein, 54, said he doesn't know what he will do next, only that he hopes to start a new job at the end of the summer.

On the day before the interview, Mr. Barr announced he would form a team to examine the origins of a 2016 counterintelligence investigation that conducted what he termed as "spying" on people associated with the Trump campaign. This characterization has been found disturbing by Democrats and some former Justice Department officials, including fired FBI Director James Comey.
