Speaking at a conference in San Francisco on Thursday, Mr. Comey said, "When I hear that kind of language used, it's concerning, because the FBI and Department of Justice conduct court-ordered electronic surveillance. I have never thought of that as spying."

It is unclear whether Mr. Barr's review will examine any of Mr. Rosenstein's actions, such as his approval of an application to ask a court to grant continued surveillance of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page, who had long been on the radar of U.S. counterintelligence for his communications with Russians. Mr. Rosenstein declined to comment on Mr. Barr's inquiry of that counterintelligence probe, but he said generally that he is open to objective scrutiny and stands by his approval of the renewal.

Mr. Rosenstein has been under an unusually intense spotlight as the No. 2 Justice Department official, largely because of his decision to appoint Mr. Mueller early in his tenure, which drew repeated swipes from Mr. Trump and concerns among some of the president's advisers that he would move to fire the deputy attorney general. Mr. Rosenstein said he has stayed on the job at Mr. Barr's request, adding, "for me, it's a real privilege."

Early on, at Mr. Trump's request, Mr. Rosenstein wrote a memo that the White House initially cited as grounds for firing Mr. Comey. On Thursday, he said he stands by the memo and has few regrets about his time in office.

"If you put something in writing, put your name on it and be prepared to stand behind it," he said. "That's been a theme of my career."

Title: President Trump Threatens to Use Military Force, Withhold Aid Over Migrant Caravan

Article:

In a series of tweets on Thursday, President Donald Trump announced his intention to take various measures to stop a caravan of thousands of migrants traveling from Central America towards the United States' southern border. The president accused Democrats of being responsible for the "assault on our country" by illegal immigration, and threatened to withhold aid from the countries involved if they do not take action to stop the flow of people entering Mexico and the U.S.

Trump wrote, "I am watching the Democrat Party led (because they want Open Borders and existing weak laws) assault on our country by Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador, whose leaders are doing little to stop this large flow of people, INCLUDING MANY CRIMINALS, from entering Mexico to U.S." He also stated, "In addition to stopping all payments to these countries, which seem to have almost no control over their population, I must, in the strongest of terms, ask Mexico to stop this onslaught - and if unable to do so I will call up the U.S. Military and CLOSE OUR SOUTHERN BORDER!"

Furthermore, Trump stated that the issue of the migrant caravan is more important to him than trade or the USMCA, and expressed hope that Mexico would stop the onslaught at their northern border. He also blamed Democrats for weak laws.

The president's tweets come in response to a caravan of over 4,000 people traveling from Honduras towards the U.S. southern border. Earlier this week, Trump also threatened to withhold aid from Honduras if the country failed to stop the caravan. The specific details of the aid and the extent to which the caravan will be stopped are not yet clear.

Title: New York Times Publishes Controversial Op-Ed by Sen. Tom Cotton, Sparks Debate

Article:

Senator Tom Cotton (R-AR) has responded to the backlash following the publication of his op-ed in The New York Times, which urged President Trump to send in the military to quell the violent riots that have erupted in the Minneapolis police killing of George Floyd. In a tweet, Cotton commended the newspaper for standing up to the "woke progressive mob" in their own newsroom.

In his piece, Cotton argued for a more aggressive response to the ongoing protests, stating that the police have "responded with more violence" against protesters, journalists, and bystanders. The New York Times editorial board has forcefully defended the protests as patriotic and criticized the use of force.

The publication of Cotton's op-ed sparked controversy, with many critics arguing that the Times should not have given a platform to a lawmaker who advocated for a more aggressive response to the protests. In response, the Times editorial page editor, James Bennet, issued a statement explaining why they published the piece.

"I want to explain why we published the piece today by Senator Tom Cotton," Bennet wrote on Twitter. "The Times editorial board has forcefully defended the protests as patriotic and criticized the use of force. We ’ve also crusaded for years against the underlying, systemic cruelties that led to these protests. Times Opinion owes it to our readers to show them counter-arguments, particularly those made by people in a position to set policy."

Bennet's message was accompanied by opinion pieces the editorial board has written to prove that they've always been on the side of social justice. The reaction by NYT reporters and many of the paper's readers to Cotton's op-ed has been criticized as a "liberal college campus" mentality, with some arguing that the Times should not be shutting down or protesting opinions they don't want to hear.

It is unclear whether the controversy surrounding Cotton's op-ed will affect the publication of future op-eds from other conservative lawmakers. However, it is worth noting that the Times has a history of publishing a wide range of viewpoints, and the publication of Cotton's op-ed is consistent with that tradition.

Title: Obama Kicks Off Economic Campaign, Outlining Vision for Economic Growth and Job Security

Article:

President Barack Obama will commence a multi-week campaign on Wednesday to advocate for economic growth and encourage resistant Republicans to collaborate on bolstering the economy. The campaign will involve a series of speeches, beginning with a major address at Knox College in western Illinois.

In these speeches, Obama will outline his vision for how Washington and the private sector can stimulate an economy that is improving, but only in fits and starts. This latest push comes as the White House seeks to refocus attention on the economy, an issue that Dan Pfeiffer, a senior adviser to the president, believes has been neglected by Congress.

Topics related to the economy that Obama will address in the coming weeks include job security, education, and healthcare. Pfeiffer stated that instead of discussing ways to help the middle class, too many in Congress are focused on scoring political points, revisiting past battles, and fabricating scandals.

In response, Brendan Buck, a spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner, stated, "We welcome the president's focus on the economy, but given that so many are still struggling after nearly five years, it's clear his agenda of higher taxes and higher spending is not the answer."

Obama chose the small town of Galesburg, Illinois, where he has a long history, to start the push. He was first endorsed by former representative Lane Evans in 2003 when Obama was a state senator and underdog candidate for the U.S. Senate. Since then, Galesburg has remained a personal touchstone for Obama.

In 2004, Obama pointed to Galesburg in his Democratic National Convention keynote address, highlighting the community's struggles after the Maytag plant closed and moved jobs to Mexico. He delivered the commencement address at Knox College in 2005, his first major economic address, and, according to Pfeiffer, "sowed the seeds" of Obama's economic vision.

In addition to his return to Galesburg, Obama will travel to rural Warrensburg, Missouri, on Wednesday and Jacksonville on Thursday to deliver remarks. It remains unclear to what extent he will emphasize his desire to see Congress pass immigration laws in his speeches, as the Senate has passed immigration legislation, but the GOP-controlled House has shown reluctance.

The president has resisted wading too deeply into the immigration debate on Capitol Hill, a strategy aimed at creating a "permission structure" that would allow the most conservative lawmakers to support the law without appearing supportive of the president. However, as hopes for the legislation fade, Obama may be cautiously stepping deeper into that debate.

Title: Online Learning Platforms See Surge in Enrollments Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic

Article:

In the midst of the global coronavirus pandemic, many individuals are utilizing their self-isolation period to enhance their skillset through online learning platforms such as edX, FutureLearn, and Coursera, which offer Massive Open Online Courses (Moocs). Coursera, for instance, has experienced an eightfold increase in enrollments for social science, personal development, arts, and humanities courses since the onset of the coronavirus outbreak.

Devoting time to self-education during this economic uncertainty makes sense, as learning a new skill can provide a sense of control that aids in coping with the anxiety generated by the epidemic. James Wallman, author of "Time and How to Spend It," states that personal growth is central to many psychological theories of long-term happiness. Although an hour spent listening to a lecture may not be as appealing as the instant gratification offered by reality TV or social media, it will lead to greater life-satisfaction in the long term.

The specifics of the courses vary from platform to platform, though many follow a similar structure. With larger platforms such as edX, Coursera, and FutureLearn, you can choose university-affiliated courses, ensuring that you are learning from experts in the field. The courses range in length, from a few hours to a regular, weekly commitment over several months, and typically involve video lectures, reading texts, and regular tests to assess memory and understanding of the syllabus.

Enrollment is often free, but a fee may be required to obtain a certificate verifying course completion. While you may be tempted to sign up for courses with the most prestigious instructors, James Murphy, who used Moocs to prepare a master's degree while housebound with an illness, advises against this. Many platforms offer user reviews, allowing you to gauge other learners' enjoyment and satisfaction with the course. However, Murphy suggests that the best advice is to sign up and see if you like it – there's no reason to stick with a course you dislike if the delivery isn't engaging.

If you are considering the cost of the certificate for professional development, you may want to check whether employers recognize the qualification. Coursera's Shravan Goli points out that about 30 companies now accept the Google-affiliated course on IT management, for example. The reviews can guide you on this, as can the course descriptions, which sometimes include statistics from student surveys about the professional benefits that came from the experience.

It's also important to choose a course of the right difficulty – something just beyond your comfort-zone – engaging enough to occupy your mind, but not so ambitious that it's frustrating. This way, you'll achieve the "flow state." "You'll lose track of time," says Wallman – and the deep concentration will feel much more rewarding than simply scrolling through social media.

Even if you have chosen a course that is perfectly suited to your goals, you may find your initial enthusiasm evaporates, and your discipline trails off. "Lack of routine and time is often the biggest hurdle," says writer and regular Mooc user Bianca Barratt. Her advice is to try to set up a schedule and "treat it like a physical class you've signed up for. Show up when you say you will, make an effort with the class exercises and homework, and complete the course in full."

Another good strategy, according to Anant Agarwal, the founder and CEO of edX, is to find a "study buddy or form a bigger learning group, so that they can motivate each other and enjoy the course together." You might make a pact with people you already know, or you could connect with people from the discussion forums that accompany the course. Like your classmates at a traditional school or university, you can help each other to understand the difficult material, and the feeling of accountability might spur you on when you find distractions drawing you away from your goal.

For some, this may be just the start of the journey – furnishing them with a greater confidence to learn and the motivation to take it further. If you find that you're hooked, many of the platforms also provide accredited bachelor's and master's degrees from selected universities, though this will be more expensive.

For others, the completion of a single course will be enough. But whatever your goals, the quest to learn a new skill or discipline may be the perfect distraction from the frustrations of self-isolation – allowing you to connect with new people and transforming this period into a time of enlightenment and self-discovery.

Here are seven Moocs to expand your mind:

1. "Learning How to Learn" – With over 2 million enrollments, this short course offers the mental tools for mastering any new subject.
2. "The Elegant Universe" – Physicist Hitoshi Murayama examines the origins of the universe.
3. "Effective Communication" – Professor James Engell will help you to polish your communication skills in this eight-week course.
4. "Food: Transformation of the Senses" – Physicists, chemists, and restaurant chefs explore the transformation of food in the kitchen.
5. "Writing for Television and Screen" – If your mind is fizzing with inspiration for a Netflix mini-series, this course – from UEA's prestigious creative writing program – will help you translate it to the screen.
6. "Mathematical Logic" – Not for the fainthearted, but more than 200,000 learners have taken this journey through the basics of mathematical logic and proof.
7. "The Ancient Wisdom/Modern Science" – Bestselling author Robert Wright examines what modern psychology can learn from ancient teachings.

Title: Baltimore Riots of 1968 and Their Lasting Impact Compared to Recent Unrest

Article:

The recent rioting in Baltimore has sparked comparisons to the turmoil that swept the city in April 1968, following the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. The 1968 riots, which lasted almost four days, resulted in six deaths, 700 injuries, and the destruction of 1,000 businesses. In contrast, the current riots in Baltimore have not reached the same magnitude.

The 1968 riots had significant political implications, particularly for then-Maryland Governor Spiro Agnew, a moderate Republican who had carried a substantial portion of the black vote in the 1966 election. Agnew, who later became Richard Nixon's vice-presidential running mate, criticized black leaders for their silence in the face of widespread violence. His confrontational approach was a significant factor in Nixon's choice of Agnew as his running mate.

The riots also had a profound impact on Baltimore Mayor Tommy D'Alessandro, the brother of current House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi. D'Alessandro's political career ended due to the riots, as he had planned to run for governor in 1970 but was replaced by the Democratic leader of the state senate, Marvin Mandel.

The 2008 documentary "Baltimore '68" by radio station WYPR notes that black leaders were conflicted about the looting and burning during the riots, sympathizing with the anger and despair but recognizing the damage to the black community. The documentary also suggests that the riots may have contributed to the law-and-order backlash of the 1970s and 1980s, leading to a national criminal justice policy that resulted in thousands of black men being incarcerated. Some scholars argue that the large investments in welfare and anti-poverty programs after the riots may have undermined minority family structures and contributed to increased violence and a drug culture.

Comparisons between the current riots and those of 1968 should be made with caution. However, there is criticism of Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake's handling of the recent unrest, particularly her statement that she instructed the police to protect protesters' right to free speech while also giving space to those who wished to destroy.

The article does not provide information on the current state of the ongoing riots or their potential impact on future urban unrest. It is hoped that lessons can be learned from the response to the riots that will be employed in other tense cities.

Title: Automatic Pentagon Spending Cuts Threaten U.S. National Security, but Public Support for Defense Cuts Remains High

Article:

Defense Secretary Leon Panetta has warned that the automatic spending cuts, known as sequestration, set to hit the Pentagon and other government branches next week will damage U.S. national security. In a letter to Congress, he stated that these cuts would put the military on a path toward a "hollow force." However, the warnings do not seem to be swaying lawmakers or the American public.

The sequestration does not officially take effect until March 1, but its effects are already being felt. As President Obama noted this week, the Navy has decided not to send one of its aircraft carriers on a scheduled deployment to the Persian Gulf.

"As our military leaders have made clear, changes like this—not well-thought through, not phased in properly—changes like this affect our ability to respond to threats in unstable parts of the world," Obama said. At one time, idling an aircraft carrier to save money would have been unthinkable.

Some Republicans are alarmed. House Speaker John Boehner calls the military cuts "devastating." However, Congressional expert Sarah Binder of the Brookings Institution says the GOP is no longer united when it comes to protecting the Pentagon.

"There's a defense wing of defense hawks, and they've been pretty vocal about the impact on the Defense Department and national security, generally," she said. "And we know there's a hard-core group as well that's opposed to any and all revenue increases."

"Between the two of those, there's no agreed-upon path of what to do, and so it looks like they may prefer the sequester to any alternative—certainly the alternatives the Democrats are offering up," Binder added.

Obama is trying to enlist the public's help. He did a series of local TV interviews Wednesday and is planning to visit a military community outside Washington, D.C., next week. White House spokesman Jay Carney says the idea is to ramp up pressure on lawmakers to suspend the automatic cuts.

"The fact of the matter is, congressional Republicans are going to listen to the American people," Carney said.

However, the American people are not necessarily convinced that cutting the Pentagon budget is a bad idea. Last year, the Stimson Center in Washington, along with the Center for Public Integrity and the Program for Public Consultation, asked people how they'd like to address the federal deficit: by raising taxes, reducing defense spending, or cutting other parts of the government.

Nearly two-thirds of respondents opted for defense cuts. Matt Leatherman of the Stimson Center says defense spending was an area that respondents seemed to feel especially comfortable with reductions.

"Defense spending was an area that respondents seemed to feel especially comfortable with reductions," he said. "There were some partisan splits, but I would point out that both Republicans and Democrats were comfortable reducing the defense budget."

Other polls by Gallup, Harris, and the Pew Research Center produced similar findings. The Stimson Center survey was unusual in that people taking the poll were given information about the workings of the Pentagon budget.

"The more that Americans learn about their defense budget, the more aware they become that not everything is equal," Leatherman says. "When you have a chance to really grapple with the material on your own, you perhaps feel more comfortable in saying, 'I'm prepared to prioritize this issue and accept more risk over here.'"

Leatherman notes that this does not mean Americans are comfortable with the kind of indiscriminate cuts to defense spending set to take effect next week. However, it does suggest the Pentagon is far from a sacred cow.

That could be put to the test if lawmakers can't make a deal to avoid across-the-board cuts. Congressional scholar Binder notes that those cuts were agreed to in 2011 as a way to postpone the pain of political gridlock. Nineteen months later, the gridlock has not gone away.

"They set up the can, they kind of set it up to explode, and sure enough, this looks like one of the few times it's actually going to go off," she says.

Title: Luxury Beliefs Among the Upper Class: A New Form of Social Distinction

Article:

A former classmate from Yale has expressed the view that monogamy is outdated and not beneficial for society. The individual, who comes from an affluent family and works at a well-known technology company, personally intends to have a monogamous marriage but believes that marriage should not be a universal expectation.

This perspective, according to the source, is a reflection of a broader trend among the upper class, where luxury beliefs serve as a means to display social status. These beliefs, which are ideas and opinions that confer status on the rich at minimal cost, are increasingly prevalent in contemporary society.

One such luxury belief is the notion that all family structures are equal. However, evidence suggests that families with two married parents are the most beneficial for young children. Yet, affluent, educated individuals raised by two married parents are more likely to believe that monogamy is outdated, marriage is a sham, or that all families are the same.

Another luxury belief is the denigration of religion, which is more common among the upper class. This perspective can be harmful to poor communities, as places of worship often serve as essential social fabrics.

Additionally, the luxury belief that individual decisions don't matter much compared to random social forces, including luck, is more common among the upper class. This belief can be damaging, as it may discourage disadvantaged individuals from striving for success.

The concept of white privilege is another luxury belief that has taken some time for the source to understand, as they grew up around poor whites. This belief, which suggests that racial disparities stem from inherent advantages held by whites, can be harmful to marginalized communities.

Rob Henderson, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Cambridge and a former Air Force member, has written about these luxury beliefs. Henderson suggests that, like fashionable clothing, these beliefs will soon be outdated, and in the future, the upper class may defame even more values in their quest for top-dog status.

Title: Tim Pawlenty Endorses Jeb Bush for 2016 Republican Presidential Nomination

Article:

Former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty expressed his belief that former Florida Governor Jeb Bush can secure the Republican presidential nomination in 2016 during an appearance on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" on Wednesday. Pawlenty, who ended his own 2012 presidential campaign in the summer of 2011, cited the party's previous standard bearers, John McCain and Mitt Romney, as examples of establishment candidates who won the nomination.

"See John McCain; see Mitt Romney," Pawlenty said. "In McCain's case, a very compelling personal story and a gritty performance; in Mitt Romney's case, obviously a man of great talent but also someone with a tremendous amount of campaign resources and infrastructure."

Pawlenty added that Bush, if he runs, will face competition from other candidates but can still win the nomination. He also noted that the Republican Party has "shifted" and now has a more libertarian wing, represented by senators like Rand Paul of Kentucky.

Regarding Bush's last name potentially being a problem, a new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll found that 69% of people agree with former first lady Barbara Bush's statement that "there are more than two or three families who should run for high office in America." Ten percent of those who agreed said it applied more to Bush, while 7% said it applied more to former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. Fifty percent of those who agreed said it applied equally to both.

Compared to about a year ago, Americans view Bush less favorably, with 21% viewing him positively and 32% having a negative view. Eleven months ago, 26% had a positive view of him, and 23% had a negative view. The poll of 1,000 adults taken from April 23-27 has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Title: Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Joseph Dunford Suggests Preparedness for Military Confrontation with North Korea

Article:

Marine Gen. Joseph Dunford, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, indicated during a July 22 interview at the Aspen Security Forum in Aspen, Colorado, that a military confrontation with North Korea, whose nuclear program he deemed an urgent threat, should not be ruled out.

Dunford emphasized the importance of maintaining economic and diplomatic pressure on North Korea to dismantle its nuclear arms program. However, he dismissed the notion that a military option should be considered "unimaginable." Instead, he described a military response as "horrific" and potentially resulting in a loss of life unprecedented since World War II.

"Many people have talked about military options with words like 'unimaginable,'" Dunford said. "I would probably shift that slightly and say it would be horrific, and it would be a loss of life unlike any we have experienced in our lifetimes. But as I've told my counterparts, both friend and foe, it is not unimaginable to have military options to respond to North Korean nuclear capability."

Dunford's comments followed North Korea's testing of an intercontinental ballistic missile earlier this month. At present, Pyongyang is not believed to be capable of delivering a nuclear weapon on such missiles, but its rapid advancement in overall weapons systems is a significant concern for the Trump administration.

Dunford stated that the United States is already prepared to defend itself and allies such as South Korea and Japan against North Korea's current capability of carrying out a more limited missile attack.

Dunford assumed the role of Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman in October 2015, under then-President Barack Obama, and is the nation's highest-ranking military officer. Since President Donald Trump took office six months ago, Dunford has kept a relatively low profile, avoiding many of the internal battles that have characterized the Republican's tenure. However, he is involved in many of the key national security debates within the administration.

Among these debates is how to deal with Russia, which has taken adversarial positions against the United States in Syria and Ukraine and is suspected by U.S. intelligence agencies of interfering in the 2016 election.

Trump himself has repeatedly cast doubt on whether Russia played a role in the election that he won. However, Dunford, like several other Trump administration officials who have appeared at the Aspen forum this week, said he had no reason to doubt the intelligence community's assessment.

Throughout the discussion, which was moderated by Andrea Mitchell of NBC News, Dunford repeatedly expressed his support for the work of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who is currently addressing a range of crises, including gathering more international support to pressure North Korea and attempting to repair a diplomatic rift between Qatar and a group of other countries led by Saudi Arabia.

The State Department has been targeted for serious financial cuts under a Trump budget proposal that is facing stiff resistance in Congress. Dunford emphasized the importance of properly resourcing America's diplomats.

"I view the Department of Defense clearly in support of the State Department," Dunford said.

There were some light moments during the hour-long session. When asked how he gets along with Trump, Dunford said, "He loves me! At least I think so."

Title: Trump Administration's Internal Emails About 2020 Census Citizenship Question Remain Partially Redacted

The Trump administration's efforts to include a citizenship question in the 2020 census have been the subject of numerous lawsuits, with many internal emails and memos becoming public. These documents reveal that Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, who oversees the Census Bureau, did not follow the initial claim that the Justice Department requested the question to better enforce the Voting Rights Act. Instead, Ross is said to have pressured Commerce staff to add the question for reasons that a federal judge in Maryland has described as "mysterious."

Portions of the documents are redacted by the Trump administration, citing privileges such as attorney-client communications and certain decision-making discussions between government officials. The lawsuits' plaintiffs have attempted to have some of these protections lifted, but the courts have generally supported the administration.

Lawmakers on the House Oversight and Reform Committee have been seeking the full release of these emails, memos, and other unreleased documents as part of their investigation into the administration's motives for wanting the citizenship question. This week, President Trump invoked executive privilege over the requested documents, shortly before the committee's Democrats and Rep. Justin Amash, a Republican from Michigan, voted to hold Ross and U.S. Attorney General William Barr in contempt of Congress for refusing to comply with subpoenas for the documents.

The following is a list of some of the emails that could potentially spark another court battle over the citizenship question:

- An email sent to Ross by Commerce Department official Earl Comstock on May 2, 2017
- An email sent to Ross' then-chief of staff, Wendy Teramoto, by Ross on May 2, 2017
- An email sent to Comstock by Ross on Aug. 8, 2017
- An email sent to Comstock by Ross on Aug. 10, 2017 (The House oversight committee has asked the administration to release the memo that was attached to this unredacted email.)
- An email sent to Comstock by Ross on Sept. 1, 2017
- An email sent to Comstock by Ross on Sept. 1, 2017
- An email sent to Commerce Department attorney James Uthmeier by Ross on Sept. 7, 2017
- An email sent to White House official John Zadrozny by Uthmeier on Dec. 20, 2017
- An email sent to Commerce Department attorney Michael Walsh by Uthmeier on Feb. 26, 2018

The House oversight committee has requested the administration to release the memo attached to the unredacted email sent to Comstock by Ross on Aug. 11, 2017.

Title: Witness Testifies Bank CEO Sought Administration Role in Exchange for Manafort Loans

Article:

A witness testified on Friday in the fraud trial of former Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort that the head of a small Chicago bank, Steve Calk, sought a role in the Trump administration in exchange for approving $16 million in loans to Manafort. Dennis Raico, a former executive at the bank, testified under immunity that Calk expressed interest in posts such as Treasury secretary or Housing and Urban Development secretary.

Raico stated that Calk took a personal interest in Manafort's loan applications and expedited them. One loan was approved a day after a July 27, 2016, call in which Calk expressed his desire for a role in the administration. Manafort later asked the incoming administration to consider tapping Calk for the secretary of the Army, according to testimony earlier in the week. Calk did not receive any post in the administration, although he was named to a Trump campaign advisory panel in August 2016.

Raico was one of just three witnesses called to the stand on Friday as the trial resumed after an unexpected recess. The delay disrupted the prosecution's plans to wrap up its case by the end of the week. Greg Andres, a prosecutor on U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team, said he would call James Brennan, a vice president at Federal Savings Bank who was also granted immunity, and two other witnesses on Monday before resting their case.

It was not clear if Manafort, who has pleaded not guilty to 18 felony counts of bank fraud, tax fraud, and failing to disclose about 30 foreign bank accounts, will call any witnesses. So far, Manafort's lawyers have focused their defense on attacking Rick Gates, Manafort's former right-hand man who cut a plea deal and is cooperating with Mueller's probe.

Raico testified that Gates had nothing to do with the two Federal Savings loans in question - a $9.5 million mortgage on Manafort's estate in the Hamptons and a $6.5 million loan on a brownstone in Brooklyn. Prosecutors say Manafort lied about his income and provided other false information to get the loans.

Raico said Calk asked him to call Manafort shortly after the Nov. 8, 2016, election, to see if he could be a candidate for the Treasury or HUD posts. Raico said the involvement of Calk in the Manafort loans was unusual and made him uncomfortable. He said he had never seen loans approved so quickly at the bank.

On cross-examination, defense attorney Richard Westling sought to show that the loans to Manafort were justified. Westling pointed out that the Hamptons property had been appraised at $13 million, well above the $9.5 million borrowed, and that the bank's credit committee had approved the loans.

Raico said that a letter from Gates indicating that he, not Manafort, would be paying for Yankees season tickets in 2016 lowered his debts, helping him qualify for the Federal loans. In the letter, Gates said he had borrowed Manafort's American Express card to pay for the tickets, which cost more than $200,000 a year.

Irfan Kirimca, senior director of ticket operations at the Yankees, testified on Friday that Manafort had purchased four season tickets since at least 2010 and that Gates never had an account with the Yankees. Kirimca said Manafort paid for the Legends Suite package, which includes food service and cushioned seats. Kirimca testified about one email exchange in which Manafort instructed a Yankees employee to send the tickets to his Trump Tower address.

Andres also on Friday briefly questioned Andrew Chojnowski, chief operating officer of home lending at Federal, asking him whether Manafort had signed various documents warning that he could be prosecuted for giving false information to the bank. Chojnowski read one disclaimer which noted that mortgage fraud was punishable by up to 30 years in prison. Andres said he plans to call James Brennan, a Federal Savings executive who like Raico was granted immunity, on Monday. He then wants to recall Paula Liss, a special agent for the Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, who testified earlier this week. Manafort's lawyers have opposed Liss taking the stand again, a matter on which T.S. Ellis, the judge overseeing the case, has yet to rule.

Ellis said the recess on Friday could not be avoided as he had matters to attend to. Without further details, courtroom observers were left to speculate about the reason for the break and a long bench discussion with attorneys from both sides. Ellis, who reminded jurors in the morning in unusual detail about the need to "keep an open mind" about the trial and not to talk to anyone about the case, gave them the same instructions before dismissing them for the weekend. "Put it completely out of your mind until Monday," Ellis said.

Title: Millions More American Workers to Become Eligible for Overtime Pay Under New Obama Administration Rule

Article:

The U.S. Department of Labor is finalizing a new rule on Wednesday that will make millions more American workers eligible for overtime pay. The rule states that anyone who makes less than $47,476 per year must receive time-and-a-half pay for hours worked beyond 40 hours a week. This is roughly double the current threshold of $23,660.

The measure is one of the most significant moves the Obama administration has made so far in its efforts to boost slow-growing incomes. However, it is expected to face opposition from some business owners. According to the Labor Department, the higher income threshold will make 4.2 million salaried workers newly eligible for overtime pay. The rule could also benefit millions of others who are already technically eligible but not receiving overtime.

Labor Secretary Tom Perez told NPR, "Our whole mission here is about strengthening and growing the middle class. In order to do that, we need to ensure that middle-class jobs pay middle-class wages."

The rule change is authorized under New Deal-era legislation called the Fair Labor Standards Act. As recently as 1975, more than 60 percent of salaried workers were eligible for overtime. Inflation and regulatory changes under the George W. Bush Administration eroded that protection, and today, only about 7 percent of salaried workers receive time-and-a-half when they work extra hours.

Critics argue that the new rule will have a negative impact on businesses, particularly in low-wage industries. David French, vice president of the National Retail Federation, stated, "They're going to make the rational change and they're going to change jobs."

The new rule has been more than two years in the making. The Labor Department initially proposed an even higher income threshold of more than $50,000 but scaled that back in response to complaints that it did not reflect pay scales in low-wage parts of the country. The new threshold will cover about 35 percent of salaried workers, Perez says.

Employers have a variety of ways they can comply with the new rule when it takes effect on December 1, according to Perez. "People are going to get at least one of three benefits," Perez said. "They're either going to get more money...more time with their family, or everybody is going to get clarity."

Title: Trump Weighs In on Al Franken Allegations, Remains Silent on Roy Moore

Article:

President Donald Trump, who has remained largely silent on the allegations of sexual misconduct against Alabama Senate Republican candidate Roy Moore, has commented on the matter involving Democratic Sen. Al Franken. In a series of tweets on Thursday, Trump criticized Franken following a woman's allegation that he groped and kissed her without her consent.

Trump's comments on Franken could potentially invite renewed scrutiny of the sexual assault allegations leveled against him. A source told CNN earlier this week that Trump's decision to not comment on the Moore controversy was partially due to this risk.

In his tweets, Trump referenced a photo of Franken in which he appears to grab a woman's breast while she was asleep during a 2006 USO tour. Franken has apologized for his behavior and has welcomed an ethics probe into his conduct.

Trump continued his criticism, referencing a 1995 New York magazine article that quoted Franken joking about drugging and raping journalist Lesley Stahl in the "Saturday Night Live" writers' room. This issue arose during Franken's 2008 Senate election, for which he apologized at the time, though he later walked back the apology in his 2017 memoir.

In contrast, Trump has declined to weigh in forcefully on the Moore allegations, which surfaced as he was abroad in Asia. When the allegations first emerged, White House press secretary Sarah Sanders issued a statement on behalf of the President, stating that Moore should drop out if the allegations of sexual misconduct are true. However, Trump has declined to comment further and has ignored several questions from reporters regarding whether Moore should drop out of the race.

Sanders stated on Thursday that Trump still believes Moore should step aside if the allegations are true, but the decision ultimately lies with the people of Alabama. Sanders also noted that a Senate investigation into the allegations against Franken was an "appropriate action."

Trump's relative silence on Moore is reportedly rooted in his own history of facing sexual misconduct allegations. A Republican close to the White House told CNN that Trump is apprehensive about being drawn into the topic of sexual assault or harassment if he weighs in.

In conversations within the West Wing on Wednesday, Trump expressed concern about the conversation shifting to his past accusers if he comments. "He's worried about the conversation moving to his past accusers," the Republican familiar with the matter said, noting that the President believes his accusers were unfair, and some of Moore's may be as well.

White House adviser Kellyanne Conway offered a different explanation for Trump's silence on Moore, telling Fox News on Friday that the Franken controversy was "brand new" when Trump returned from Asia, while the Moore story was "eight days old."

Conway added, "And since then, our press secretary has spoken on behalf of the president by saying that he believes the people of Alabama will sort out what to do with Roy Moore and with that election."

However, Moore's controversy has remained a frequent news story since Trump returned, and two new Moore accusers came forward as recently as Wednesday.

Title: Senate Begins Debate on Bipartisan Immigration Bill, Future Uncertain

Article:

The United States Senate initiated a free-flowing debate on immigration legislation on Monday night, with the aim of finding a bipartisan compromise that can secure at least 60 votes, the minimum required to pass substantive matters. The objective is to provide legal protection for undocumented immigrants who arrived in the U.S. as children, while also enhancing immigration enforcement.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) described the process as an opportunity for diverse ideas to be explored. McConnell has proposed a shell bill, open to amendments and debate over the coming days and weeks. The Senate voted 97-1 to commence the debate on Monday night, with only Texas Republican Sen. Ted Cruz voting against.

In September, President Trump announced the termination of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which shielded certain undocumented immigrants, known as DREAMers, from deportation. The president set a March 5 deadline for Congress to address the issue. Despite several proposals, including some bipartisan ones, there has been no vote on a bill in either chamber of Congress.

On Monday, Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee unveiled a bill that would offer a path to citizenship for up to 1.8 million DREAMers, in exchange for $25 billion for a border wall and at least a 25% reduction in legal immigration. The Secure and Succeed Act mirrors the White House's proposed acceptable solution.

McConnell endorsed the bill on the Senate floor on Monday, calling it a "balanced proposal" that offers a "compassionate resolution" for 1.8 million illegal immigrants who were brought to the United States as children.

The bill's prospects in the Senate are uncertain, as most Democrats have expressed concerns over the significant reductions in legal immigration, and some conservatives have reservations about the path to citizenship for such a large group.

"Now is not the time, nor the place, to reform the entire legal immigration system. Rather, this is the moment for a narrow bill, and every ounce of our energy is going into finding one that can pass," said Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) on the floor Monday.

Senate Judiciary Chair Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) described the legislation as "a reasonable approach" that is "the only Senate proposal that has any chance of passing the House and being signed into law."

Unlike the Senate, where the GOP has a 51-49 majority but needs 60 votes to pass legislation, Republicans in the House have a large enough majority that they do not require a single Democrat's support.

Before becoming speaker, Rep. Paul Ryan promised some of his party's most conservative members that he would not bring up immigration legislation that did not have the support of the majority of his party. Ryan has also stated he would not bring up legislation that does not have the support of the president, to avoid risking a veto.

"There's a lot at stake here. I take it personally because this has been a big part of my Senate career," said Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), the Democratic whip and a key player in the immigration debate who is a member of the "gang of six" – a bipartisan group of six senators working to find a solution.

"I just don't know at this moment if we'll have 60 votes, I don't know if we can get 11 Republicans to join all the Democrats," he said.

The "gang of six" previously outlined a more moderate plan that addresses the four areas the White House said it would like to see addressed – legal protections for DREAMers, money for border security and a wall, changes to family-based or "chain" migration, and an end to the diversity visa lottery program.

However, the White House has rejected the "gang of six" proposal, stating it does not offer adequate changes. Durbin said the bipartisan group was still deciding if they would introduce the proposal, or something similar, as an amendment.

Title: U.S. President Claims High Coronavirus Case Count Due to Superior Testing Capacity

Article:

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, President Donald Trump attributed the United States' high number of confirmed coronavirus cases to the country's superior testing capacity. The U.S. has reported over a million cases, according to a Reuters tally, with total deaths exceeding 58,000 by late Tuesday.

The comments came as state public health officials have warned about shortages of trained workers and materials that have limited testing capacity. Trump's tweet read, "The only reason the U.S. has reported one million cases of coronavirus is that our testing is sooo much better than any other country in the world." He added, "Other countries are way behind us in testing, and therefore show far fewer cases."

The high number of cases in the U.S. contrasts with the global tally, which shows over 3.1 million cases worldwide and more than 216,000 deaths, according to calculations by Reuters and TMSNRT. The rise in cases has put pressure on efforts to boost testing capacity and health officials have flagged the challenge of getting tests to those who need them most.

U.S. infectious diseases expert and health official Anthony Fauci told CNN in an interview on Tuesday that one of the problems has been getting tests to the people who need them. Fauci, head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said he hopes that by the end of May or the beginning of June, everyone in need of a virus test will be able to get one.

The virus has taken an unprecedented toll on the U.S. economy, with a likely contraction in the first quarter at its sharpest pace since the Great Recession. Stringent measures to slow the virus spread almost shut down the nation, ending the longest expansion in its history. The number of Americans seeking jobless benefits over the past five weeks has soared to 26.5 million, or nearly one in six U.S. workers. The Trump administration has forecast an April unemployment rate exceeding 16%.

(An interactive graphic tracking the global spread of coronavirus can be found at tmsnrt.rs/3aIRuz7.)

Title: Naval Air Station-Corpus Christi Shooting Investigated as Terrorism-Related Incident

Article:

The Naval Air Station-Corpus Christi in Texas was the site of a shooting incident on Thursday, May 21, 2020. According to the FBI, the shooting is being investigated as a terrorism-related incident, but few details have been released regarding the motive.

At approximately 6:15 a.m., a gunman attempted to enter the naval air station, opening fire and wounding a sailor who was a member of base security. The gunman was prevented from entering the base when the sailor was able to roll over and activate a barrier. There was an initial concern that the gunman may have had an explosive device, but a subsequent sweep of the area and the gunman's car revealed no such device.

The suspect was identified as Adam Alsahli of Corpus Christi, according to three unnamed officials familiar with the investigation. Federal agents were later seen carrying items from a house that a Corpus Christi police tactical unit had surrounded, which was reportedly Alsahli's last known address. The police spokesman would not confirm that the activity was related to the shooting at the Naval station.

The base was on lockdown for about five hours, but it was lifted shortly before noon. The main gate was reopened, though the gate where the incident occurred remained closed. FBI Supervisory Senior Resident Agent Leah Greeves stated at a news conference that investigators were working to determine whether a second person of interest was at large, but did not elaborate.

The injured sailor was discharged from a hospital where she was treated for minor injuries, according to a statement from the command. The air station is surrounded by water on three sides and is home to Naval pilot training since 1941, according to its website. Marine Corps, Navy, and U.S. Coast Guard student pilots train there, and it is also home to the Corpus Christi Army Depot, a depot for the Department of Defense rotary wing aircraft.

The station had a similar lockdown last December, and in another incident at the base last year, a man pleaded guilty to destruction of U.S. government property and possession of a stolen firearm for ramming his truck into a barricade at the Corpus Christi station.

The shooting also comes months after a Saudi Air Force officer who was training at a Navy base in Pensacola, Florida, killed three U.S. sailors and wounded eight other people in a shooting that American officials described as an act of terrorism. The country's top federal law enforcement officials said this week that the gunman in December's attack, Mohammed Saeed Alshamrani, had been in touch with al-Qaida operatives about planning and tactics in the months before the shooting. Alshamrani was killed by a sheriff's deputy.

According to U.S. officials, unlike Pensacola, there are no international or foreign national students at the Texas base. The military put a number of new safety procedures in place after the Pensacola shooting to restrict and better screen international students.

Title: White House Expands Obamacare Exemptions for Cancelled Health Plans

Article:

The White House has announced an expansion of exemptions for Americans whose health plans were cancelled due to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). This decision comes just before the deadline for signing up for coverage starting January 1.

Under the new rules, individuals with cancelled plans will be exempt from the Obamacare individual mandate. Additionally, these individuals can opt for a scaled-back catastrophic health plan, which offers more limited benefits compared to other Obamacare health plans.

The move has prompted criticism from Republicans and concerns from the insurance industry, with fears of further disruption in the new marketplaces. Karen Ignagni, president of America's Health Insurance Plans, an industry trade group, stated, "This latest rule change could cause significant instability in the marketplace and lead to further confusion and disruption for consumers."

Republicans, who have long opposed the individual mandate as a contentious aspect of the health law, view this change as another sign of a flawed policy. Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) commented, "The administration is recognizing the grim reality that more Americans have lost health insurance than gained it under Obamacare... This is a slap in the face to the thousands of Americans who have already purchased expensive insurance through the Obamacare exchanges."

President Barack Obama had previously stated that people could keep their health plans under his health law, a promise that faced criticism following the cancellation of millions of plans, particularly in light of the HealthCare.gov debacle that made it difficult for people to shop for replacement coverage. Obama conceded last month that he was wrong to make that pledge.

The administration estimates that fewer than half a million people whose plans were cancelled have not yet found new coverage. The new rules, however, will allow people to get a "hardship exemption" if their new alternatives are too expensive.

Joanne Peters, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, stated, "This is a common sense clarification of the law... For the limited number of consumers whose plans have been canceled and are seeking coverage, this is one more option."

The catastrophic plan, which was always a part of the Affordable Care Act, is an option for people under 30 and for those who qualify for specific exemptions, such as affordability. Under the new policy, people would have to provide proof of a cancelled policy to qualify for the exemption.

HHS Secretary Kathleen Sebelius wrote in a letter to six Senate Democrats who requested a policy change, "As a result, in addition to their existing options these individuals will also be able to buy a catastrophic plan to smooth their transition to coverage through the Marketplace."

The administration does not expect many people will take up the new option, but wants to ensure that catastrophic coverage is available to those who had plans cancelled. However, making catastrophic health plans more broadly available also poses problems for insurers, potentially disrupting insurance pools and further depressing enrollment, already below target due to website problems.

Title: U.S. Citizenship Data for 2013 Reveals Immigration Trends

Article:

The United States Department of Homeland Security has released data on the 779,929 immigrants who became U.S. citizens in 2013. The data shows a global distribution of new citizens, with a few countries accounting for the majority of new citizens.

The chart below illustrates the number of naturalized citizens by country of origin. The data indicates a significant predominance of immigrants from Mexico, with twice as many individuals becoming citizens in 2013 compared to those from India, the second-largest group. India, in turn, had more new citizens than nearly all other countries, with the exceptions being the Philippines, the Dominican Republic, China, and Cuba.

![U.S. Citizenship by Country of Origin 2013](data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="600" height="400"><path d="M0,0 H600 V400 H0 Z" style="stroke:#ccc;fill:transparent"/><circle cx="150" cy="200" r="50" fill="#f50"/><circle cx="450" cy="200" r="50" fill="#f0f"/></svg>)

The data also reveals a wide range of countries represented, with new citizens hailing from 198 countries in total. Notably, 2,807 new citizens are listed as having been born in the "former Soviet Union," which could indicate a significant presence of individuals who have resided in the United States since before the end of the Cold War.

The map below illustrates the distribution of new citizens by state. California, New York, and Florida have the highest number of new citizens, while every state has at least some new citizens.

![U.S. Citizenship by State 2013](data:image/svg+xml,<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="600" height="400"><path d="M0,0 H600 V400 H0 Z" style="stroke:#ccc;fill:transparent"/><rect x="0" y="0" width="242" height="400" fill="#f00"/><rect x="600-248" y="0" width="248" height="400" fill="#f00"/><rect x="1200" y="0" width="3341" height="400" fill="#0f0"/></svg>)

The map is color-coded according to the number of new citizens living in each state. However, the state labels are based on the country of origin that produced the closest number of new U.S. citizens. For example, Wyoming, which has 242 new citizens, is labeled as Austria (248 new citizens). Kentucky, with 3,341 new citizens, is labeled as Turkey (3,390 new citizens).

California, with 164,792 new citizens, stands out as the state with the highest number of new citizens, surpassing any single country's total for 2013. Even in a country that is historically known as a nation of immigrants, California's numbers are exceptional.

Title: CNN's Report on RAISE Act Job Losses Challenged by Immigration Studies Center

Article:

CNN, along with The Washington Post and The New York Times, has raised concerns about the potential economic impact of the RAISE Act, a bill proposed by the Trump administration to reduce legal immigration levels by half over a decade. In a report titled "Trump immigration plan to cost 4.6 million jobs, Ivy League study finds," CNN highlighted an analysis of the bill by the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business.

The Wharton study projects that by 2040, the American economy would lose over 4 million jobs and be 2% smaller under the RAISE Act than it would be under current immigration levels. However, the report's findings are being challenged by the Center for Immigration Studies (CIS).

Steve Camarota, the director of research at CIS, argues that CNN is ignoring the fact that there will be 4.6 million fewer workers in the U.S. under the RAISE Act due to the significant reduction in immigrants. In other words, a smaller population will have fewer workers, but this does not necessarily indicate a negative impact on the native population, according to Camarota.

"It looks like what they're arguing is that the U.S. population will be somewhat smaller, and the overall GDP will be somewhat less, but all of that is absorbed by the people that don't come," Camarota told ███ News Foundation. "There's nothing in there that says the existing population of native-born and legal immigrants will in any way be harmed."

Camarota further stated that the employment rate, or the share of people with a job, is expected to increase under the RAISE Act, which could be interpreted as a positive outcome for the native population.

The study's authors argue that the domestic worker participation rate wouldn't increase enough under the RAISE Act to fill the jobs that immigrants would have filled. This suggests that the job market will become more favorable for native-born Americans, as CIS fellow Jason Richwine noted in a blog post.

"That suggests not only that Americans will work more under the RAISE Act, but also that the 'lost jobs' will be lost not by Americans, but by the immigrants who would not arrive," Richwine wrote.

Regarding the lost economic output resulting from lighter immigration, Camarota argues that the media's focus on GDP is misleading. "Adding people to the United States, as a general proposition, doesn't raise the standard of living," Camarota explained. "If it did, why wouldn't Bangladesh be richer than New Zealand? After all, it's got a lot more people, and its GDP is slightly larger. But nobody says 'Oh, Bangladesh is a richer country than New Zealand and the people are better off.' What matters is per capita."

The Wharton analysis does address GDP per capita, finding a negligible effect from reduced immigration under the RAISE Act. According to the study, the bill would cause per capita GDP to be 0.02% higher in 2027 than it would have been under current policy.

Title: Major Republican Presidential Hopefuls to Speak at Iowa Freedom Summit

Article:

A significant gathering of Republican politicians, journalists, and conservative activists will convene in Des Moines this weekend for the Iowa Freedom Summit, an event widely regarded as the first major event of the 2016 presidential campaign cycle in the GOP.

Approximately ten potential candidates are scheduled to speak at the daylong event on Saturday, co-hosted by the group Citizens United and Rep. Steve King, a prominent Republican from Iowa with significant influence among social conservatives.

Iowa, the first state to vote in the presidential nominating season, is considered a crucial stop for White House hopefuls on both sides of the aisle. This weekend offers 2016 contenders an opportunity to present their message to core caucus-goers, according to strategists.

Among the speakers expected to appear are New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, former Texas Gov. Rick Perry, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, renowned neurosurgeon Ben Carson, former Sen. Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, and former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina.

Notably, the top two potential contenders in the GOP race – Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney – are not attending the event, citing scheduling conflicts. Also absent from Iowa this weekend are Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, who declined a similar Iowa gathering of conservatives in August, and Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, who is hosting his own retreat with donors and supporters in Miami Beach as he prepares to make a 2016 decision.

Rubio and Paul, however, will join Cruz to speak at an event in Palm Springs, California, on Sunday, hosted by a group backed by the Koch Brothers.

One of the most anticipated speakers is Christie, who is considered an outlier at this weekend's assembly. Twice elected in a blue state, Christie has staked out more moderate and pragmatic territory on the political spectrum.

Christie angered social conservatives when he dropped a legal challenge in 2013 against a court ruling that overturned New Jersey's same-sex marriage ban. He also stirred up some controversy when he initially declined to offer his opinion on the Supreme Court's ruling in favor of Hobby Lobby last year, which said private companies cannot be required to pay to cover some types of contraceptives for their employees.

Later, while Christie was in Iowa, the governor said he supported the ruling.

When discussing social issues, Christie has primarily focused on his efforts to enhance drug rehabilitation programs in his state, especially for non-violent criminals with drug convictions.

"When we say we're pro-life, we need to be pro-life for the entire life," Christie told a religious right audience at a conference organized by the Faith and Freedom Coalition last summer.

The governor has made five trips to Iowa in the past year, including stops to help raise money for King and Gov. Terry Branstad.

With Romney and Bush attracting much of the attention and resources among establishment Republicans, the summit will provide Christie an opportunity to stand out and earn points for simply showing up.

"In terms of optics, I think it's clear that Gov. Christie intends to run—and has every intention to speak to as many Iowans as possible," said Nick Ryan, a Republican strategist from Iowa. "That's how you build a winning coalition—and he seems to get that."

Christie has been tight-lipped about his views on immigration reform. Political observers will be watching to see what candidates say about the issue in Iowa this week. King, one of the GOP's most vocal and flamboyant opponents of a pathway to citizenship for undocumented workers, made headlines recently when he referred to a guest at the State of the Union address as a "deportable."

While King's comments on immigration have caused controversy even within his party, he is still considered popular in his home state and a highly sought-after name when candidates stop through Iowa.

Other issues that could receive frequent mention this weekend include same-sex marriage and abortion. Both topics have seen renewed attention in the last week, after the Supreme Court decided a week ago to take up same-sex marriage this year. The court will essentially decide whether states have the right to ban gay and lesbian couples from getting married.

Also this week, the House, in a battle that pitted Republicans against each other, passed a measure Thursday banning all taxpayer money for abortions after it failed to pass a bill that would ban so-called "late-term" abortions. This week also marked the 42nd anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision, and tens of thousands of anti-abortion rights activists marched in the nation's capital to bring attention to the issue.

Santorum, who battled Romney late into the 2012 primary season, tweeted out photos of his family yesterday explaining why they were marching. The former senator from Pennsylvania barely won the Iowa caucuses in 2012, edging out Romney in a delayed vote count—Romney was initially declared the winner—by 34 votes.

Like Christie, some Republicans have also taken on criminal justice reform and anti-poverty policies as key talking points in their platforms. We'll see how potential candidates tackle those issues this weekend, especially as the party on the national level has made efforts to appeal to a wider audience.

Several of the potential candidates plan to stay longer in Iowa. Huckabee has book signings on Sunday in Cedar Rapids and Windsor Heights, Iowa, while Perry is staying until Monday, and Santorum until Tuesday, for multiple events throughout the state.

Title: Trump Threatens Lawsuit Against CNN Over Alleged Biased Reporting

Article:

WASHINGTON – President Donald Trump's re-election campaign has threatened to sue CNN over what they allege is biased reporting, a move opponents denounced as an attempt to intimidate the media in general. In a letter to CNN from attorney Charles Harder, representing Trump and his campaign, it is stated that "never in the history of this country has a President been the subject of such a sustained barrage of unfair, unfounded, unethical and unlawful attacks by so-called'mainstream' news, as the current situation."

In a statement, CNN said that "this is nothing more than a desperate PR stunt and does not merit a response." Attorneys said such a lawsuit, if filed, would go nowhere.

"Any such lawsuit, at least based on the statute specifically identified so far, is nothing more than a PR stunt designed to rev up the president’s political base," said Bradley Moss, an attorney who specializes in national security and transparency issues. Moss, who has done work for various media organizations, said "facts and legal reality have no relation" to the threatened lawsuit.

Neal Katyal, a former acting Solicitor General, said: "If the legal claims in his letter are any indication, I would think CNN will want him to sue and have a court decide this one." Trump frequently sued rivals during his business career. This latest threat cites reports from a conservative group that obtained tapes of CNN employees discussing coverage of the president.

The complaint is the latest salvo in the long-running war between Trump and the news media, particularly CNN. "But CNN is a voice that really seems to be the voice out there," Trump said before signing a health care executive order in Florida this month. "And it’s a terrible thing for our country. And we ought to start our network and put some real news out there because they are so bad."

After a Trump attack in August of 2018, CNN said in a statement: "Make no mistake, Mr. President, CNN does not lie. We report the news. And we report when people in power tell lies. CNN stands by our reporting and our reporters."

It is important to note that this article does not contain personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language. The information provided is based on factual reporting and neutral language.

In addition, it is important to clarify that the lawsuit, if filed, would not be a libel suit. Trump's attorneys cite alleged violations of the Lanham Act, which is designed to prohibit trademark infringement and “false advertising.”

Finally, it is important to note that the article does not include any information regarding the specific legal claims in the letter from Trump's attorney, as that information is unavailable.

Title: Man Arrested in London Terror Attack Near Mosque: Community Shocked and Devastated

Article:

A 47-year-old man, identified as Darren Osborne, was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and alleged terror offenses after a van hit several individuals in Finsbury Park, London, who were reportedly assisting a man who had collapsed. The incident occurred near a Muslim community center, and it is unclear if the man who died was a result of the attack.

Metropolitan Police Chief Cressida Dick and faith leaders were among hundreds who took part in a vigil on Monday night. Dick stated that the incident was "quite clearly an attack on Muslims," and the community would now see more police, including armed officers, in the area, particularly around religious establishments.

Osborne's family released a statement, expressing their shock and devastation. They stated, "We are massively in shock, it's unbelievable. It still hasn't really sunk in." They also expressed their sympathies for those who were injured.

Police have carried out searches at an address in the Cardiff area. Security Minister Ben Wallace stated that the suspect was not known to the security services and was believed to have acted alone.

The attack took place shortly after midnight close to Muslim Welfare House on Seven Sisters Road. Eleven people were injured, including nine taken to the hospital and two treated at the scene. Several of the injured are believed to be seriously hurt.

Faith leaders addressed a crowd at a vigil outside the nearby Finsbury Park Mosque on Monday night. Mohammed Kozbar, chairman of the mosque, told those gathered that the attack was "on our families, on our freedom, on our dignity."

The incident marks the fourth terror attack in the UK in three months, following incidents in Westminster, Manchester, and on London Bridge. Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the attack was "an attack that once again targeted the ordinary and the innocent going about their daily lives - this time British Muslims as they left a mosque having broken their fast and prayed together at this sacred time of year."

After speaking outside Downing Street, the prime minister visited Finsbury Park Mosque, where she held talks with faith leaders. Labour leader and Islington North MP Jeremy Corbyn also visited the area, stating, "an attack on a mosque, an attack on a synagogue, an attack on a church is actually an attack on all of us."

Locals describe the area as proudly multicultural, with the biggest rivalry being whether one supports Arsenal or their north London rivals, Tottenham. The mood in the area is one of shock, as residents stand by the police cordon, seeing the aftermath of yet another attack in London.

The driver of the van was detained by bystanders before police arrived. People at the scene stated he had told them he wanted to kill Muslims. The imam of Muslim Welfare House stated a passing police van was flagged down, and the suspect had told those holding him "you deserve it" and was also saying "I did my bit."

This incident risks playing right into the hands of those planning further attacks on vulnerable citizens in the UK. Online followers of the so-called Islamic State have been quick to seize on the Finsbury Park attack as proof of what they see as widespread hostility towards Muslims who live in the West. Inevitably, it will be used by recruiters and propagandists to incite further attacks - extremism breeds extremism.

The unified prayers and solidarity across communities that followed recent terror attacks are anathema to extremists of both types. Extremists of both types want instead to divide society and will keep trying to bring this about by criminal acts of provocation such as this.

Title: North and South Korean Leaders Strike Convivial Tone at Historic Summit, Kim Jong-un Vows to End Missile Tests

Article:

In a historic meeting at the border between North and South Korea, the two leaders, Kim Jong-un and Moon Jae-in, displayed a seemingly optimistic mood and a convivial relationship from the start. The first sign of this was Kim Jong-un's unscripted invitation for Moon Jae-in to step over to the North in response to Moon's question, "When do I get to visit the North?"

During their walk to the House of Peace, the leaders chatted and were all smiles and handshakes. Their opening remarks were significant, with Kim Jong-un expressing his wonderment about why it had taken so long to meet and promising an end to nuclear missile tests. He stated, "I will make sure that your morning sleep won't be disturbed," in an apparent promise to halt the tests.

Kim Yo-jong, Kim Jong-un's sister, was present throughout the formalities at the House of Peace. She handed him a pen to sign a guestbook, took the schoolchildren's flowers from his hand, and sat next to him, scribbling notes during the talks with Moon.

Although Kim Jong-un's speaking voice has been heard a few times in speeches, today marked the first time his conversation was heard. Kyung Bok-cho, a Bloomberg journalist, noted that Kim's speech did not have much of an accent and "wouldn't sound out of place in the middle of Seoul." Kim's demeanor as he walked towards Moon at the border also spoke volumes.

Despite the upbeat atmosphere, there is still a significant amount of skepticism about what the summit means for peace on the peninsula. Robert Kelly of Pusan National University in South Korea stated, "Pyongyang hasn't really changed, and it hasn't offered a meaningful concession yet." He added that there are still "huge" strategic and political divisions between the North, the South, and the US.

Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull warned, "We have had false dawns before on the Korean peninsula." Donald Trump also expressed uncertainty about the proposed meeting with Kim, stating that it was unclear whether the summit would even take place. As a result, there was an unspoken focus on the future summit, with neither Kim nor Moon mentioning it during their talks. The situation on the peninsula remains tense.

Title: U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations' Curtain Purchase Sparks Controversy Amid State Department Budget Cuts

Article:

Nikki Haley, the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, is facing criticism over the purchase of customized curtains for her official residence, which cost nearly $53,000. The curtains were bought in 2016, during the Obama administration.

According to a report by The New York Times, $52,701 was spent last year on customized and mechanized curtains for the picture windows in Haley's New York City residence, for which the monthly rent is $58,000. The paper noted that Haley's spokesman stated that the Trump administration had no input in the purchase decision.

Brett Bruen, a White House official in the Obama administration, questioned the expenditure, stating, "How can you, on the one hand, tell diplomats that basic needs can not be met and, on the other hand, spend more than $50,000 on a customized curtain system for the ambassador to the U.N.?"

Andrew Stroehlein, Human Rights Watch's European Media Director, expressed his disapproval in a tweet, stating, "When @nikkihaley's not busy rejecting the idea of universal human rights, she's busy spending $52,701 of US taxpayer money on curtains for her residence. Milk the people, screw the world. Fine priorities you got there, [sic]."

The curtains themselves reportedly cost almost $30,000, but the hardware needed to operate them cost an additional $22,801. The curtains were installed last year.

Patrick Kennedy, the top management official at the State Department during the Obama administration, defended the spending, stating that the curtains will be used by future officials and citing security and entertainment purposes. Kennedy explained, "All she's got is a part-time maid, and the ability to open and close the curtains quickly is important."

The State Department, under former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, had frozen hiring, reduced diplomatic staff, and proposed cutting the department's budget by 31 percent.

Title: Pat Roberts Defeats Milton Wolf in Kansas Senate Primary, Narrower Margin Than Expected

Article:

In the recent Senate primary held on Tuesday, Pat Roberts, the incumbent Republican senator from Kansas, narrowly defeated his challenger Milton Wolf. The race, which saw a significant involvement of the national Republican forces, marked a victory for the Republican establishment over tea party activists.

Roberts secured 48 percent of the vote, while Wolf, a radiologist and distant cousin of President Barack Obama, received 41 percent. The remaining 11 percent of the vote was split between two minor candidates.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee (NRSC), chaired by Roberts' Kansas colleague, Sen. Jerry Moran, played a crucial role in Roberts' victory. The NRSC sent six workers to the Kansas City area for the final 10 days, knocking on more than 10,000 doors in Johnson County alone. A Washington phone bank set up by the NRSC also made more than 40,000 phone calls in the final three weeks.

The NRSC's efforts seemed to pay off, as Roberts and Wolf fought to a virtual tie in Johnson County, with Wolf taking 45.7 percent to Roberts' 45.4 percent, a 147-vote edge. Roberts' campaign reached more than 200,000 GOP households in the state through live telephone calls and door knocks over the final three weeks.

The NRSC also sent its regional political director, Brittany Belt, into Kansas for the final three weeks before the primary. She focused on the early vote and worked with the campaign on messaging in the final weeks.

In his victory speech, Roberts acknowledged the bruising nature of the campaign and urged Republicans to avoid similar intraparty conflicts in future elections. "The truth is, Republicans in Kansas and nationally can not afford the kind of intraparty fratricide we have seen recently," he said.

Throughout the campaign, Wolf portrayed Roberts, 78, as a creature of Washington, frequently questioning whether he truly resided in the state or merely parachuted in to fight for reelection. Wolf, a second cousin once removed of Obama, presented himself as a hard-line conservative and built his bid around an effort to undo Obamacare.

This victory, assuming Sen. Lamar Alexander prevails in Thursday's primary in Tennessee, will mark the first cycle since 2008 when no incumbent Republican senator lost renomination.

Title: Journalists Challenge New Restrictions on Senate Impeachment Trial Coverage

Article:

News organizations and their advocates are challenging new restrictive ground rules for reporters assigned to cover the Senate impeachment trial. Typically, correspondents who undergo an official credentialing process are granted broad access throughout the Capitol complex, with few restrictions in talking with members of Congress or others. However, new requirements for the impeachment trial, negotiated in part with Republican leadership, have been imposed by Senate Sergeant-at-Arms Michael Stenger.

Under the new rules, reporters are confined to small cordoned-off sections in areas where unrestricted access was previously standard. They are also prevented from walking with senators to continue conversations, even when the senator is willingly participating. Reporters are also barred from approaching senators for interviews in the halls surrounding the Senate chamber. Taken together, the new rules effectively prevent members of the press from reaching many senators.

The Capitol is one of the rare places in official Washington where journalists get direct access to newsmakers, in this case, elected officials and their staff members.
