Elsewhere, such as in the White House or the State Department, reporters' movements are more closely controlled, and access to principals can be severely limited. The Senate's new security measures are unusually strict, even more so than the security protocols generally put in place for the annual State of the Union address, which is attended by the president, many members of the Cabinet, and the Supreme Court. The president is not expected to attend the trial.

Stenger and the Capitol Police may fear that the additional attention drawn to the Senate impeachment trial may increase risks to members of Congress. However, members of the press corps are vetted through a longstanding system and pass through security checks every time they enter the Capitol complex.

Nearly 60 news organizations, including NPR, signed a letter organized by the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press on Thursday, urging Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., to relax the new restrictions on reporters. "Absent an articulable security rationale, Senate leaders, the Senate sergeant at arms, and the United States Capitol Police have an obligation to preserve and promote the public's right to know," the letter said. "Reporters must have the ability to respond quickly to rapid developments and need reasonable access to lawmakers who wish to speak to the press."

Patricia Gallagher Newberry, president of the Society of Professional Journalists, faulted the new Senate restrictions because they deny reporters the ability to fully cover a once-in-a-generation spectacle. "To deny journalists their constitutional right to document the historical events occurring now is a gross injustice to the American people," she said. "The press is charged with holding the government accountable. It is through its access that the public is informed. When the public is informed, it can make better decisions. The American public should also be outraged about these restrictions."

Angela Greiling Keane, president of the National Press Club Journalism Institute, warned that the prospect of these continued restrictions could chill reporters' ability to cover big events or even normal business in the Capitol in the future. "These restrictions set a horrible precedent and reinforce the lie that the news media is dangerous and the 'enemy of the people,'" Keane said. "Congress should be the most accessible institution in government. As the branch closest to the people, it is ironic that these limits only isolate those who are elected to serve."

News organizations that assign correspondents to the Capitol, including NPR, are continuing to negotiate ground rules with Stenger (the sergeant-at-arms) and the Capitol Police.

Title: House of Representatives to Vote on $2 Trillion Coronavirus Relief Bill Despite Last-Minute Hurdles

Article:

House Democratic leaders have vowed to pass a $2 trillion coronavirus relief bill on Friday, despite last-minute obstacles posed by a conservative member that have prompted lawmakers to return to Washington. Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) stated, "We're going to pass it today," as she entered the Capitol shortly before 9 a.m.

Initially, House leaders aimed to pass the extensive stimulus package, which was approved by the Senate on Wednesday night, without convening the full chamber due to concerns about travel and crowding. They intended to do so through a voice vote, allowing some members to debate the legislation and voice their concerns without the need for the entire House to reconvene.

However, a conservative lawmaker, Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.), has threatened to force a roll-call vote on Friday, necessitating party leaders to devise a contingency plan for moving the package to President Donald Trump's desk.

House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) has been in discussions with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) to find a swift solution. "I've talked to McCarthy last night, and we're working together to get this done," Hoyer said.

If Massie forces a roll-call vote, party leaders expect to have enough lawmakers on the floor on Friday to form a quorum, the minimum number of members required to stage a recorded vote. In this case, the House can approve the measure on Friday, despite Massie's maneuver.

The House opened the floor at 9 a.m. to begin the debate, which was initially expected to last for two hours. However, Pelosi stated that the debate has been extended to three hours. "We will respect the congressional traditions, and we will have a little longer debate than we had anticipated. My understanding is it will be extended to three hours, and then we'll have the votes," she said.

When asked whether the vote would be by voice or a recorded vote, Pelosi did not provide a definitive answer. Rep. Kevin Brady (R-Texas), speaking earlier on CNBC, remained uncertain about the Friday vote, highlighting the ongoing efforts by leaders to finalize the process.

"So we get this done one way or the other today or tomorrow," said Brady, the top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee. "I think there's a better than even chance we get this done today. We do have some names mentioned of people who might call for a roll-call vote. I hope that doesn't happen. But in case it does, members are coming back for this vote."

Title: Trump Shifts Stance on Border Wall Funding, Clearing Path for Government Spending Bill

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed a willingness to delay the funding for a border wall with Mexico until later this year, potentially paving the way for lawmakers to reach a deal to avoid a government shutdown on Saturday, according to White House officials. This shift in stance could remove one of the last remaining hurdles in the ongoing negotiations between congressional Democrats and Republicans over the five-month spending bill they must pass this week to prevent a partial government shutdown.

Initially, the president and his administration officials had indicated that they wanted to include funding for the border wall in the bill to maintain government operations after its current funding expires at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday, also marking the president's 100th day in office.

During a reception with conservative media at the White House on Monday, the president addressed the border wall issue. The president's new flexibility regarding whether the wall is funded in the current spending bill or a later one in late September could facilitate a swift agreement on the spending bill.

The ongoing debate over the Republican healthcare bill is likely to be postponed to avoid a shutdown, according to Republican lawmakers and aides. Without the border wall issue, lawmakers may be able to reach an agreement on the spending bill relatively quickly. Both Democrats and Republicans had signaled their willingness to increase funding for the military and broader border security before administration officials last week indicated that President Trump would press for funding to begin building the border wall.

Little appetite for funding the border wall specifically was found among Republicans on Capitol Hill, while Democrats, whose votes will be needed to pass the spending legislation in the Senate, had stated they would oppose a spending bill that included money to start building the border wall.

"It's good for the country that President Trump is taking the wall off the table in these negotiations," Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said in a statement on Monday night. Earlier in the day, Mr. Schumer had labeled the wall as a "nonstarter" for Democrats. "Now the bipartisan and bicameral negotiators can continue working on the outstanding issues," he said.

Democratic votes will be necessary, as Republicans hold just 52 seats in the Senate, where spending bills need 60 votes to clear procedural hurdles. House GOP leaders will also likely need some Democratic support, as some conservative Republicans are expected to oppose the spending bill.

Many Republicans have stated they would be content with a spending bill that includes funding to strengthen security along the border in ways other than building a wall. "Border security's the main issue—whether that includes a wall or technology, drones, or repairing what we have," said Sen. Shelley Moore Capito (R-W.Va.) on Monday evening. Ms. Capito added that she wasn't interested in risking a shutdown over the border wall. "I'm not going to risk a shutdown over anything," she said.

Other Republicans echoed that their top priority was ensuring they crafted a spending bill that could pass both chambers before the government runs out of money. "I wouldn't mind funding the wall, but it's a question of what we can do up here, what's doable," said Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.), a senior member of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

In March, the administration requested $1.4 billion in spending for the current fiscal year for the wall, with an additional $2.6 billion for the next fiscal year, beginning Oct. 1. Administration officials stated that the fiscal 2017 money would cover 48 miles of new border and levee wall systems, as well as 14 miles of replacement fencing, along with some technology improvements and road construction.

One remaining unresolved issue is whether the five-month spending bill under negotiation would include payments to health insurers known as "cost-sharing reductions," as requested by Democrats. The payments support Affordable Care Act insurance plans by helping insurers lower costs for low-income consumers. An abrupt withdrawal of the payments would pose an immediate threat to health-insurance markets, potentially causing the collapse of health plans midyear.

Title: Syrian Refugee Turns to Food Business in Britain After Journey Through Calais "Jungle" Camp

Article:

Mohammed Rahimeh, a Syrian refugee, left Damascus in December 2015 to avoid conscription into the Syrian army. His journey to London took him through Lebanon and Greece, including an 11-month stay in the notorious "Jungle" camp in Calais. Despite leaving Syria with no cooking qualifications or English skills, he is now in the process of setting up a food business in Britain.

Mr. Rahimeh, while waiting for his asylum claim to be processed in Britain, was not allowed to take a job. However, he developed his cooking skills, focusing on a recipe involving eggs, onions, tomatoes, and spices. With the help of Alexandra Simmons, a volunteer he had met in Calais, he set up Mo's Eggs, a business that offered a Syrian brunch. He took advantage of a trend for pop-up restaurants, venues that only exist for a day every week or month.

The first site was a pizza restaurant in Archway, in north London, and his first event was Ms. Simmons' 30th birthday party. He served around 60 people every month until the venue closed, but will soon open a new place in Tooting Broadway, in the south of the city. In the interim, he has been working at a market stall to learn more about the food trade.

Similar paths were followed by Majeda Khoury, a human-rights activist who made her way from Damascus to Britain. She learned to cook thanks to a charity called Migrateful and prepares food associated with different Syrian cities; a favorite dish in Damascus, harak osbao, features lentils and pasta with tamarind, coriander, garlic, and pomegranate molasses. Now she runs catering at big events for charities that want to focus on Syria.

Both Ms. Khoury and Mr. Rahimeh benefited from sales and marketing training by the Entrepreneurial Refugee Network (TERN), a charity. Charlie Fraser, TERN's co-founder, says the aim is to launch 1,000 refugee-led businesses in Britain by 2025.

It is very hard for refugees to start a business when they cannot leave the camps in the first place. Paul Hutchings is trying to help those people who are stuck. He used to be a market researcher, before going to Calais to help refugees in 2008. In 2016 he set up Refugee Support, another charity, which has been involved in camps in Bangladesh, Cyprus, Greece, and Mexico.

The model is to promote dignity rather than dependence; instead of just handing out food and clothes, the charity set up a shop. It created tokens so residents could buy their own things. Dina Nayeri, a former refugee, says this is very important; at one camp she attended, people had to search through piles of old clothes that were dumped on the floor. Ms. Nayeri says that many refugees struggle with trauma, feelings of shame, and inferiority, and the expectations of other people that they should always be grateful. After she made it to America, Ms. Nayeri became a writer, publishing two novels and a non-fiction book, "The Ungrateful Refugee."

Dignity also requires that refugees find work. If they stay in the camps, they qualify for grants from the EU, but the risk, Mr. Hutchings says, is that they become institutionalized. At first, Refugee Support tried to give microloans to let people set up small businesses. But this ran into a regulatory brick wall.

So instead, Mr. Hutchings rented a building, now called the Dignity Centre, where people can learn skills. One of the projects is a sewing cooperative which has 18 machines, where refugees make bags, cushion covers, and aprons. The charity provides the material, machines, and electricity and sells the goods online at Refumade.org; each item comes with a message about the person who made it. The sewing workers are mostly women. For the men, the charity has set up a bicycle-sharing scheme in Cyprus to help them find work away from the camps.

The refugees interviewed had undergone an immense struggle to reach their current position. Their determination to make something of their lives was truly striking. That is the kind of work ethic any company, and any country, ought to value.

Title: House GOP Proposes Deficit Reduction Plan, Including Tax Reform and Medicare Cuts

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner, a Republican, has presented a deficit reduction plan that includes revenue increases and spending cuts, aiming to avert the impending fiscal cliff. The plan promises $2.2 trillion in deficit savings over the next decade, with $800 billion from tax reform, $600 billion from Medicare reforms and other health savings, and $600 billion in other spending cuts. The plan also pledges $200 billion in savings by revising the consumer price index.

The plan, however, has been dismissed by the Obama administration as not serious due to its lack of demands for increased taxes from the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. House Republican leadership aides have described the plan as a "credible plan that deserves serious consideration by the White House."

The move comes amid a heated battle between the two sides, with each side claiming the other is not sincere about striking a deal to avoid automatic tax increases and spending cuts in January. The tax issue has stymied deficit reduction talks for two years.

Senior Obama administration officials have criticized the Republican plan, calling it a step backward in negotiations and not worthy of its own counteroffer because it is not serious enough. White House spokesman Dan Pfeiffer criticized it for not meeting "the test of balance." Another Obama spokesman, Jay Carney, stated that the president "will not sign a bill that extends those tax rates for the top 2%," as the GOP proposal would do.

The Republican plan includes $800 billion in deficit savings through tax reform, including an unspecified amount of revenue raised by eliminating tax deductions and loopholes. The GOP letter said the offer is based on a framework proposed last year by Erskine Bowles, a Democrat and one-time White House chief of staff who co-chaired a bipartisan deficit reduction panel appointed by Obama in 2010.

The plan's release follows pressure for a House vote on a measure already approved by the Senate to extend tax cuts for families making less than $250,000 a year and to allow rates to return to Clinton-era levels for wealthier households. Lower tax rates set in 2001 and 2003 were extended for two years as part of budget talks in 2010.

In his response, Pfeiffer said the Republican proposal "includes nothing new and provides no details on which deductions they would eliminate, which loopholes they will close or which Medicare savings they would achieve."

The failure to reach a fiscal cliff deal and devise a framework for a broader deficit reduction package to be negotiated when the new Congress is seated in January will cause economic turmoil and threaten the U.S. credit rating, according to experts. The non-partisan Tax Policy Center estimates that middle-class families would pay about $2,000 a year more in taxes without action.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Acknowledges Ancestral Slave Ownership, Emphasizes Reparations and Policy Changes

Article:

Former Democratic congressman Beto O'Rourke, a White House hopeful, revealed in a Medium post on Sunday that he and his wife, Amy, are descendants of slave owners. O'Rourke's paternal great-great-great grandfather listed two women, Rose and Eliza, as his possessions.

In the post, O'Rourke wrote, "That those enslaved Americans owned by my ancestors were denied their freedom, denied the ability to amass wealth, denied full civil rights in America after slavery also had long-term repercussions for them and their descendants." He added, "I benefit from a system that my ancestors built to favor themselves at the expense of others."

O'Rourke's post is a defense of reparations, stating, "We all need to know our own story as it relates to the national story. It is only then, I believe, that we can take the necessary steps to repair the damage done and stop visiting this injustice on the generations that follow ours."

O'Rourke outlined several policy promises, including addressing underfunding for minority-majority public schools, giving federal capital to minority- and women-owned businesses, universal health care, and criminal justice reform, in the context of addressing the legacy of slavery. He also emphasized his support for reparations for the descendants of slaves, "beginning with an important national conversation on slavery and racial injustice."

The debate over reparations reentered mainstream political discourse after the House Judiciary Committee held the first hearing on the issue in a decade in June. A bill sponsored by Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-Texas) to form a commission to study whether black Americans should receive reparations for slavery has been gaining steam in the House, with many 2020 hopefuls endorsing the move.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has roundly opposed the initiative. Following his opposition to reparations, a report from NBC News found McConnell's ancestors owned a total of more than a dozen slaves. In response, McConnell said, "You know, I find myself once again in the same position as President Obama. We both oppose reparations, and we both are the descendants of slaveholders."

Title: White House Visitor Logs: Obama-Era Policy and Trump's Return to Precedent

Article:

Tom Blanton, the director of the National Security Archive, has stated that the national security argument for withholding White House visitor logs is a "falsehood," as the Obama-era policy already made exceptions for such information. This week, the National Security Archive, along with two other organizations, sued the government for visitor logs from the White House, Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., and Trump Tower.

According to Mr. Blanton, the lawsuit was initiated due to the government's attempt to hide the logs. He stated, "We went to court because we saw this coming."

During the Bush administration, government transparency groups began filing lawsuits demanding specific visitor information for the White House, only to be met with resistance from the president's lawyers. The issue was not resolved by the time Obama took office, but his administration, which emphasized its commitment to transparency, adopted the position that visitor logs would be released with certain exceptions, in line with those recognized under the Freedom of Information Act.

Although a federal court ruled in 2011 that visitor logs could be kept secret, the Obama administration continued to provide them. Lawyers exercised what they maintained was a right to omit some entries, including in cases of highly sensitive meetings, such as interviews for prospective Supreme Court candidates and those dealing with national security or intelligence matters. The Obamas also routinely left out the names of celebrities and top donors who attended personal events at the White House, drawing criticism for doing so.

The Trump policy effectively means that none of the White House visitor logs will be available for at least five years. Under the Presidential Records Act, the public can gain access to records starting five years after the end of an administration, although the president may seek to keep them secret for up to 12 years.

The issue of the logs recently gained intense attention after the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Devin Nunes, confirmed that he was on the White House grounds when he received what he described as evidence that President Trump or his closest associates might have been "incidentally" swept up in foreign surveillance by American spy agencies. Logs recording Mr. Nunes' visit on March 21 have not been released to the public.

The visitor records, maintained by the Secret Service, list the names of those entering, the White House staff member who obtained permission for them to enter, and the name of the person they are to meet.

Title: US President Donald Trump and North Korean Leader Kim Jong-un Meet in Singapore for Historic Summit

Article:

US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un have convened in Singapore for a historic summit, marking a significant shift in the relationship between the two nations.

Donald Trump arrived aboard Air Force One a few hours after Kim's arrival with his entourage. Both leaders are staying in separate hotels, not far from each other, in preparation for Tuesday's meeting on the resort island of Sentosa.

Kim told Singapore's Prime Minister, "the entire world is watching," while Trump described it as a "one-time shot" at peace. The US hopes the summit will initiate a process leading to North Korea giving up nuclear weapons.

The two leaders have had an unpredictable relationship over the past 18 months, exchanging insults and threats of war before abruptly changing course and moving towards a face-to-face meeting.

Due to the reclusive nature of North Korea, even the plane Kim would be flying in from Pyongyang to Singapore was the subject of speculation. The BBC's Rupert Wingfield-Hayes reported that three aircraft took off from Pyongyang, including an Ilyushin transport plane carrying Kim's armored limousine, an Air China 747, and Kim's personal jet, a Soviet-era Ilyushin 62.

The St Regis hotel where Kim is staying was shrouded in secrecy, with only North Korean media workers, dressed in identical black suits, moving freely around the building. Tourists taking photos in communal areas were reportedly accosted by guards.

Trump landed in Singapore later in the evening, having flown from a contentious G7 meeting in Canada. He expressed feeling "very good" about the summit before heading to his hotel, the Shangri La, about half a mile from Kim's.

The first year of Trump's presidency was marked by bitter exchanges with Kim as North Korea conducted several ballistic missile tests in defiance of international warnings. Trump vowed to unleash "fire and fury" if Pyongyang continued threatening the US, and referred to Kim as "little rocket man." In response, Kim called Trump "mentally deranged" and a "dotard."

Despite the White House's "maximum pressure" campaign, the North remained defiant and carried out its sixth nuclear test in September 2017. Kim declared that his country had achieved its mission of becoming a nuclear state, with missiles that could reach the US.

However, in early 2018, North Korea began attempts to improve relations with South Korea by sending a team and delegates to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. In March, Trump surprised the world by accepting an invitation from Kim - delivered via Seoul - to meet in person.

Since then, the path to the summit has been rocky, with Trump at one point calling it off completely. But after some diplomatic scrambling, the two leaders will now sit down together. Singapore is only the third country Kim has visited since he became leader in 2011.

The US wants North Korea to get rid of its nuclear weapons in an irreversible manner that can be verified internationally. Only when steps begin to be taken in that direction will it "receive relief" from the grip of UN sanctions, according to Defense Secretary Jim Mattis.

However, this does not mean the US is expecting to get a final deal in Singapore. President Trump has described it as a "get-to-know-you situation" and said, "It's going to be a process." Analysts suggest that Kim, by winning the prestige of a meeting with the world's most powerful leader, has already gained a victory. They also question whether Kim would give up his nuclear weapons after pushing so hard to obtain them.

Some experts believe Kim would never do it unless everyone else on the Korean peninsula disarms, including the US. However, Kim has also expressed a desire to focus on building the North Korean economy and wants sanctions relief and international investment. The question is what concessions Kim is willing to make, and whether he will stick to any promises. Pledges to scrap the nuclear program have been made before by his predecessors.

It's unclear what specific agreements may be reached during the summit, but Trump has signaled that they could sign an agreement to formally end the Korean War, which ended in a truce in 1953. Doing so would likely be "the easy part," Trump said. The US president has also said that if things go poorly, he will walk out of the meeting, but if things go well, Kim could receive an invitation to the White House.

Title: President Obama to Highlight Health Insurance Rebates in Upcoming Speech

Article:

President Obama will deliver a speech at the White House on Thursday, focusing on the medical loss ratio provision of his signature health care law, which is forcing health insurance providers to return money to consumers in the form of rebates. The speech comes as the administration faces deadlines to establish health care exchanges in all 50 states by Oct. 1 and as GOP lawmakers continue to call for a repeal of the law.

The medical loss ratio provision requires insurers to refund customers when they spend less than 80% of premiums they collect on medical care. This year, the provision will result in 8.5 million Americans receiving $500 million in rebates later this summer, according to the Department of Health and Human Services. The average rebate is estimated to be about $100 per family.

The speech follows the Obama administration's announcement earlier this month that it would delay until 2015 the requirement that businesses with more than 50 employees provide health insurance to their workers or pay a penalty. The GOP-led House has also approved multiple votes to gut the health care law, but these efforts lack support in the Democratic-controlled Senate.

To emphasize the benefits of the Affordable Care Act, the White House has invited Americans who have received a refund from their insurance companies to join Obama on stage for his speech. However, Republican lawmakers, including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, argue that their constituents are seeing premiums skyrocket and that premium increases would outweigh the rebates.

In 2011, 4.1 million people received about $152 per family, or a total of $1.1 billion, in rebates. The White House attributes the decrease in rebate money in 2012 to insurers more strictly following the law and charging lower premiums. Additionally, some states, including New York, California, and Oregon, are projecting lower premiums due to health insurance exchanges being set up under the law.

The debate over the health care law continues, with both sides presenting differing perspectives on its impact on American families. The White House maintains that the law is designed to provide peace of mind and security for individuals and their families, while Republican lawmakers argue that the law is causing premiums to rise.

Title: Supreme Court Allows Broader Implementation of Refugee Ban, Paving Way for Potential Entry of 24,000 Additional Refugees

Article:

The United States Supreme Court on Tuesday granted a request from the Trump administration to implement a broader ban on refugees entering the country from around the world. The decision allows up to 24,000 additional refugees to enter the United States than would otherwise have been eligible, according to the Justice Department.

The Supreme Court's ruling gives President Donald Trump a partial victory as the high court prepares for a key October hearing on the constitutionality of Trump's controversial executive order, which suspended travel for people from Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen for 90 days and limited refugee admissions.

The March 6 order took effect in late June following a Supreme Court ruling that narrowed the scope of lower court rulings. In a ruling last week, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals exempted grandparents, aunts, uncles, and cousins of legal U.S. residents from the travel ban. The Justice Department opted not to appeal that part of the 9th Circuit decision.

However, the 9th Circuit also ruled that Trump's refugee policy was too broad, and the court allowed entry to refugees from around the world if they had a formal offer from a resettlement agency. The Justice Department appealed, and the full Supreme Court on Tuesday sided with the administration in a one-sentence order.

Naureen Shah, Amnesty International USA's senior director of campaigns, said the refugee ban is inherently cruel. "The Supreme Court today has dealt yet another devastating blow to vulnerable people who were on the cusp of obtaining safety for themselves and their families," she said. "They continue to be subjected to unimaginable violence and fear while their lives are in limbo."

Earlier on Tuesday, the state of Hawaii, which challenged the policy, said in a court filing that the U.S. government could still "bar tens of thousands of refugees from entering the country." Hawaii's lawyers added that the 9th Circuit ruling only "protects vulnerable refugees and the American entities that have been eagerly preparing to welcome them to our shores."

Hawaii Attorney General Doug Chin said he respected the Supreme Court's decision and is preparing for the hearing there on Oct. 10.

Title: Rand Paul Modulates Rhetoric on ISIS, Faces Criticism for Shift in Stance

Article:

Senator Rand Paul, a potential Republican presidential candidate, has been known for his skepticism towards military intervention overseas. In a party that is often associated with a hawkish stance, Paul has been advocating a more dovish position. His critics label this as isolationism.

Last week, Paul criticized former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's stance on Syria in an op-ed for the Wall Street Journal, stating that arming Islamic rebels in Syria could have led to the rise of the Islamic State. He also criticized Clinton's eagerness to intervene in Syria, stating that a regime change might have resulted in ISIS taking over.

However, Paul has recently softened his rhetoric, stating that as president, he would seek congressional authorization to destroy ISIS militarily. He aims to avoid being perceived as soft on ISIS, but his stance is a departure from his previous anti-interventionist views.

Former Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has also entered the debate, publishing an op-ed in the Washington Post, stating that the radical Islamic State and other global hotspots require a strong response from the U.S. military.

The tone of the political argument is shifting, with a national debate on how to deal with global hotspots causing a halt to the anti-interventionist mood in the Republican Party. The debate has led to clashes between libertarian-leaning conservatives and hawkish Republicans, such as Sen. John McCain (Ariz.) and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie.

Paul has a history of expressing anti-interventionist views, as seen in a previous op-ed in the Wall Street Journal where he argued against U.S. military intervention in Iraq's civil war. In a recent op-ed, Paul criticized the U.S.'s unhinged and flailing foreign policy, stating that America cannot police or solve every problem across the globe.

Paul's latest comments have sparked accusations of flip-flopping from the right. Conservative Washington Post blogger Jennifer Rubin stated that Paul's stance is a result of the dangers of the outlook he previously espoused. Rubin also criticized Paul, stating that he is not a presidential candidate who has the strength of his convictions.

The issues at hand are complex, and it is possible to believe that America was too quick to make war in the Middle East and that ISIS is a threat that needs to be addressed. However, for Rand Paul, whose political brand is built on wariness of foreign entanglements, his new approach risks muddling his message.

Title: Fox News Host Criticizes President Trump's Budget Signing, Expresses Doubt in Future Funding for Border Wall

Article:

Fox News host Jesse Watters criticized the budget signed by President Trump on Friday, expressing his disapproval of the lack of funding for the proposed border wall. In a tweet, Watters stated, "This was a huge defeat for [@POTUS] on a signature issue... I know he wanted more money for the military, and that's incredibly important, but he sacrificed everything else to get it."

Watters expressed concern over the limited funding allocated for the border wall, with only 1.6 billion dollars set aside, and questioned the feasibility of using the new concrete wall prototypes that President Trump recently surveyed. He also noted that the proposed funding is only for 93 miles of the 3,000-mile border, with the majority of the funding allocated for backup fencing and repairs.

Watters further criticized the budget, stating, "The border is a mess, and crying [Senator] Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) gets all the money he wants for a tunnel from New Jersey to New York and there's no border wall funding?" He also pointed out various instances of domestic spending, such as half a billion dollars for Planned Parenthood and forty million dollars for the John F. Kennedy Center, while the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) budget remains at a historic high.

Watters questioned President Trump's promise to never sign such a bill again, stating, "I do not see how he's going to change the dynamic in Congress to have this never happen again. Democrats are never going to work for border wall funding and Republicans aren't going to go to the mattresses for it." He suggested alternative methods for funding the border wall, such as private funding from Trump's wealthy supporters or privatizing the wall.

Trump initially indicated he was considering a veto of the budget on Friday, but ultimately signed it. Trump allies Laura Ingraham and Ann Coulter have expressed concern that the budget could lead to Trump's impeachment after losing the House of Representatives to Democrats in the midterms.

Title: Obama's Proposal for Free, High-Quality Preschool Sparks Mixed Response

Article:

President Obama's plan to provide free, high-quality preschool across the nation is receiving a mixed response, with broad support for aiding disadvantaged children but concerns about expanding entitlements and the effectiveness of similar programs. During his State of the Union address last week, the president argued that the U.S. should begin preparing its citizens for the new, high-tech economy at the "earliest possible age."

"Study after study shows that the sooner a child begins learning, the better he or she does down the road," Obama stated. However, less than 30 percent of 4-year-olds are enrolled in a "high-quality" preschool program, he said.

The president argued that most middle-class parents cannot afford several hundred dollars a week for private preschool, and that poor children, who need help the most, could be at a disadvantage "for the rest of their lives" without access to such education.

During a visit to a preschool in Decatur, Ga., on Thursday, the president provided more details about the plan. The federal government would match state spending to create high-quality preschool programs for 4-year-olds from low- and moderate-income families. The plan also reportedly would provide extra federal money to states that expand their public preschool programs to middle-class families, offering tuition on a sliding scale.

The cost of the program remains unclear, but the president argues that investing in high-quality early education will save Americans by increasing graduation rates and reducing teen pregnancy and violent crime. Obama pointed to Georgia and Oklahoma, where, he said, studies show such programs help former students keep a job and maintain a stable family.

Critics argue that the U.S. is already approximately $16 trillion in debt and point to a Department of Health and Human Services study that shows limited benefits after third grade for those enrolled in preschools under the $7 billion Head Start program.

Kirsten Powers, a Daily Beast columnist and contributor, stated, "This isn't a liberal or conservative thing... I think everybody wants to help our children do better in school (but) this doesn't seem to be the thing that's doing it."

Andrew J. Coulson, director of the Cato Institute's Center for Educational Freedom, told The New York Times that there is a big difference between touting a handful of small pre-K programs that may have had lasting and significant benefits and replicating such programs on a national level.

The Center for American Progress estimates the Obama plan would cost roughly $98 billion over 10 years. The liberal-leaning think tank also cited several studies that bolster Obama's argument about the benefits of preschool education and said families making less than $1,500 a month must spend about 53 percent of their income on care for their children 4 years old and younger.

"With all these benefits, universal preschool shouldn't be a partisan issue," the group said. "And indeed, Republican-controlled states such as Oklahoma and Georgia have become national leaders in early childhood education."

However, Georgia Republican Sen. Johnny Isakson told The Wall Street Journal that his state's program, which offers free pre-kindergarten to all 4-year-olds, works because it "started locally, is funded locally and doesn't have a dime of federal money."

Title: U.S. and Iraq Disagree on Troop Withdrawal as Tensions with Iran Escalate

Article:

Washington and Baghdad find themselves at odds over the withdrawal of U.S. troops in Iraq, as tensions between the U.S. and Iran escalate following the U.S. killing of Iranian commander Qassem Soleimani. Iraqi Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi has requested preparations for a U.S. troop withdrawal, in line with a vote in Iraq's parliament last week. However, the U.S. State Department stated that any U.S. delegation would not discuss the withdrawal of U.S. troops, as their presence in Iraq is considered "appropriate."

The latest flare-up in the long-standing covert war between Iran and the U.S. began with the U.S. killing of Soleimani, Iran's top general, in a drone strike on Jan. 3. Iran responded on Wednesday by firing missiles at U.S. forces in Iraq. In an interview with Fox News, President Donald Trump stated that Iran had planned to attack the U.S. embassy in Baghdad and aimed to strike four U.S. embassies when Soleimani was killed.

Iraq's top Shi'ite Muslim cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, condemned the U.S.-Iranian struggle happening on Iraqi soil, stating that Iraqis stand to suffer most from the U.S.-Iranian conflict. Sistani called for no foreign powers to decide Iraq's fate and for Iraq to govern itself.

In the aftermath of the conflict, both sides have backed off from further escalation, but the region remains tense. Iran has increased its calls for U.S. forces to leave Iraq, with Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei stating that ending the U.S. military presence in the region is Tehran's main goal. U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, however, stated that Washington had specific information about an imminent Iranian threat, including to U.S. embassies.

In Iraq, gunmen killed two local journalists covering protests in the southern city of Basra. Ahmed Abdulsamad, a correspondent for Dijla TV station, was killed immediately, while his camera operator succumbed to his wounds in the hospital. Essam Faraj, a demonstrator in Baghdad, stated, "Politicians and clerics... are either with Iran, the U.S. or other countries. Our allegiance is to Iraq only, not to factions and politicians."

The U.S. has $35 billion of Iraq's money "sitting in an account," according to Trump, and he stated that if Iraq wanted the U.S. to leave, they would have to pay for the money spent. A NATO delegation is currently in Washington to discuss the future of the Iraq mission and a plan to "get burden-sharing right in the region."

Title: North Korea Accuses U.S. of Gangster-like Tactics in Nuclear Disarmament Negotiations

Article:

North Korea has accused the United States of employing "gangster-like" tactics in its efforts to push North Korea towards nuclear disarmament following a recent round of high-level talks. The North Korean foreign ministry issued a statement, carried by the official KCNA news agency, that provided a starkly different account from that of U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who had stated progress was made during his two-day visit to Pyongyang.

The statement, issued anonymously, characterized the U.S. attitude at the meeting as "extremely troubling." North Korea claimed the U.S. had gone against the spirit of the June summit between Donald Trump and Kim Jong-un in Singapore by putting unilateral pressure on the country to abandon its nuclear weapons.

During the summit, Kim Jong-un had pledged to work towards denuclearization, but details on how this will be achieved remain unclear. A key aim of Pompeo during his visit was to firm up North Korea's commitment to disarmament. However, the North Korean statement accused the U.S. of adopting a "gangster-like mindset" and warned that its "resolve for denuclearization... may falter."

At the talks, Pompeo did not meet with Kim Jong-un, but instead with Kim Yong-chol, who is seen as his right-hand man. In his assessment, Pompeo gave little away, but he did say they had discussed at length a timeline for disarmament, including the destruction of a missile engine testing facility.

After the Singapore summit, which also saw the U.S. offer "security guarantees" to North Korea and promise to end its military drills with South Korea, President Trump claimed that the North no longer posed a nuclear threat. However, the president has since renewed sanctions on North Korea, while U.S. intelligence officials have stated there is evidence North Korea continues to upgrade the infrastructure for its nuclear and missile programs.

A state department spokesperson said Pompeo had been "very firm" in focusing on denuclearization, as well as on security assurances and the return of remains of U.S. service personnel from the Korean War. As Saturday's meeting got underway, Kim Yong-chol joked that Pompeo may not have slept well during his overnight stay at a guesthouse in Pyongyang. Pompeo responded that he "slept just fine."

On Sunday, the U.S. secretary of state will meet the foreign ministers of Japan and South Korea in Tokyo.

Title: Hong Kong Protests Enter 17th Week Amidst Ongoing Political Crisis

Article:

The ongoing political crisis in Hong Kong, which began in June over an extradition bill, has reached its 17th week. The bill, which has since been withdrawn by Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam, has sparked widespread protests that have "ruptured" the trust between Hong Kong residents and the city's institutions, according to The Washington Post.

During an unsanctioned rally on Sunday, protesters set objects on fire and smashed windows at a train station, according to Bloomberg. Hundreds of pro-China supporters turned out for a counter-protest on the same day, as reported by the Associated Press.

On Saturday, hundreds of thousands protested during a sanctioned rally commemorating the 5th anniversary of the 2014 Umbrella Movement, which also saw protesters take a stand against the Chinese government. Police used tear gas and water cannon to disperse the crowds, as reported by Reuters.

The New York Times reports that the prolonged protests in Hong Kong may be a result of both Beijing's overreach and seismic changes in Hong Kong identity. "Hong Kong’s eruption into monthslong protests may have been the result not only of Beijing’s overreach, but also of seismic changes in Hong Kong identity itself," the report states.

The 2014 Umbrella Movement took hold after Beijing submitted a proposal that would limit Hong Kong's democracy and would not allow the city to vote for its own leader, according to The Washington Post. Over the course of a few months, protestors staged sit-in street protests and carried umbrellas against pepper spray from riot police. Police fired 87 canisters of tear gas in 2014. Thus far in 2019, police have fired over 3,000 canisters and hundreds of rubber bullets in an effort to quell the protests, according to the Washington Post.

Looking ahead, Hong Kong residents are threatening to stage a counter-rally during a celebration for the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China, according to The Washington Post. The exact details of the planned event are not yet clear.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Advances USA Freedom Act, Signaling Potential Reform of NSA's Phone-Snooping Program

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee has taken a significant step towards reforming the National Security Agency's (NSA) phone-snooping program with a bipartisan majority vote for major changes to the USA PATRIOT Act on Thursday. The 25-2 vote indicates that Republicans and Democrats in the House are unlikely to support a full renewal of the PATRIOT Act, whose key data-collection powers are set to expire at the end of May.

The development deals a blow to Senate Republicans, including Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has advocated for the retention of the snooping powers to ensure national security. In contrast, House Speaker John A. Boehner has expressed his support for the reform bill that passed the Judiciary Committee and is now set for a vote on the full House floor.

The legislation, known as the USA Freedom Act, aims to rewrite the PATRIOT Act's Section 215, which authorizes the government to collect records from private businesses. The bill prevents the federal government from indiscriminately collecting and storing Americans' data and increases transparency in the secret court that oversees intelligence collection.

The NSA's phone data collection program, revealed by former government contractor Edward Snowden, has been a source of concern for many Americans. The program, which collects and stores five years' worth of records of the numbers, times, and durations of phone calls made within the U.S., has been defended by the NSA, which claims it only probes the records when it believes a number is associated with a terrorism investigation.

The USA Freedom Act, which was designed to end bulk collection and secret laws, has garnered bipartisan support in the past. However, an identical bill that passed the full House last year foundered in the Senate after a filibuster led by Mr. McConnell during a lame-duck session of Congress late last year.

Senate Democrats generally oppose Mr. McConnell's bill, and even some Senate Republicans are divided, with hawks supporting it but civil libertarians, including presidential candidate Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, fiercely opposing it. Mr. McConnell has limited leverage in the debate, as the sunset of Section 215 is scheduled for June 1 without any action. He could attempt to push for a short-term extension or a lesser alternative, but his strategy remains unclear.

The issue appears to be moving away from Mr. McConnell, with the biggest threat to the House bill coming not from the hawks but from the other side, where Republicans and Democrats teamed up to try to further limit government searches under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. That amendment failed, though, after some hand-wringing by lawmakers who wanted to vote for it but feared upsetting the carefully crafted consensus. The two "No" votes on the bill came from Rep. Ted Poe, Texas Republican, and Rep. Jim Jordan, Ohio Republican.

Title: President Trump Accuses Mueller and Comey of Conflicts of Interest Ahead of Key Russia Probe Developments

Article:

President Donald Trump launched a series of tweets on Friday, alleging a number of internal "conflicts of interest" for Special Counsel Robert Mueller and former FBI Director James Comey, as key developments in the Russia probe and congressional testimony by Comey were set to unfold.

In a pre-dawn barrage of tweets, Trump questioned the impartiality of Mueller and Comey, who have worked together for years. He suggested that these conflicts of interest should be included in the final report of the Russia investigation.

Trump accused Mueller and Comey of having a close relationship, dating back to at least 2003 when Mueller was FBI director and Comey was deputy attorney general. The president also questioned the role of a woman, who he claimed is overseeing the potential prosecution of Jerome Corsi, an ally of GOP political operative Roger Stone. This woman is likely Jeannie Rhee, a federal prosecutor on Mueller's team. Rhee is a former partner at WilmerHale, the law firm where Mueller worked prior to taking on the special counsel role.

Trump also questioned the political leanings of Mueller's team, stating that the majority of prosecutors are registered Democrats or have a history of making political donations to Democratic candidates and causes. Andrew Weissmann, who has reportedly been grilling Paul Manafort, has been a subject of controversy due to past prosecutions that resulted in dismissed convictions and allegations of prosecutorial misconduct.

The president also attacked Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who appointed Mueller after assuming oversight of the Russia investigation amid former Attorney General Jeff Sessions' recusal. Justice Department official Bruce Ohr, who allegedly was a key player regarding the controversial anti-Trump dossier, has also come under scrutiny in recent months. Ohr's wife, Nellie, has worked for Fusion GPS.

Trump's tweets come as Mueller faces a court-imposed Friday deadline to file potentially revealing memos outlining how Manafort allegedly broke his cooperation agreements with the government, as well as how Michael Cohen should be punished for lying to Congress in 2017 about an abandoned Trump real estate project in Russia.

Meanwhile, Comey is testifying behind closed doors before the House Judiciary and Oversight committees, after dropping his legal challenge to congressional Republicans' subpoena earlier this week when they agreed to make public a transcript of his remarks. A key focus of questioning will be Comey's decision to write the July 2016 statement recommending against filing criminal charges in the Hillary Clinton email probe before the former secretary of state was even interviewed, as well as the apparent political bias demonstrated in a slew of text messages and leaks by top FBI officials.

Republicans are also expected to ask about the comparably favorable treatment afforded by the FBI to Clinton advisers. In October, U.S. District Court Judge Royce Lamberth said he was "shocked" and "dumbfounded" when he learned that the FBI had granted immunity to former Clinton chief of staff Cheryl Mills during its investigation into the use of Clinton's server.

Title: House Democrats File Resolution to Block National Emergency Declaration, Setting Up Clash Over Presidential Powers and Immigration

Article:

House Democrats will file a resolution on Friday aimed at blocking President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration to finance his proposed border wall, setting up a clash over funding, immigration policy, and the constitutional separation of powers. The effort, while likely to ultimately fall short, will allow Democrats to take a defiant stance against Trump, pleasing liberal voters, and may put some Republican lawmakers from swing districts and states in a difficult position.

The resolution, if passed by the Democratic-led House, will move to the Republican-controlled Senate, where there may be enough GOP defections for approval. The measure would then be sent to the president's desk for a potential veto. If the House and Senate initially approve the measure, Congress seems unlikely to muster the two-thirds majorities in each chamber needed to override a veto.

The battle is over an emergency declaration Trump has issued to access billions of dollars beyond what Congress has authorized to start erecting border barriers. Building the wall was a prominent campaign promise for Trump. Congress approved a vast spending bill last week providing nearly $1.4 billion to build 55 miles of border barriers in Texas' Rio Grande Valley, while preventing a renewed government shutdown. That measure represented a rejection of Trump's demand for $5.7 billion to construct more than 200 miles of barriers.

Besides signing the bill, Trump also declared a national emergency and used other authorities to access an additional $6.6 billion for wall construction. That money would be transferred from a federal asset forfeiture fund, defense department anti-drug efforts, and a military construction fund. Federal officials have yet to identify specifically which projects would be affected.

The timing of the vote in the House is uncertain, but it seems assured due to a timeline spelled out by law. If the resolution passes in the House and Senate, it would be sent to the president's desk. If the measure is initially approved, it would require a two-thirds majority in both chambers to override a potential veto.

The votes could cause discomfort for other Republicans who have expressed concerns that Trump's declaration sets a precedent for future Democratic presidents to declare emergencies to address their own favored issues. The moderate Republican senator Susan Collins of Maine has already announced her support for the resolution to block the emergency declaration. With Republicans holding a 53-47 majority, three more GOP senators would need to vote with Democrats for the resolution to win initial approval.

It remains unclear whether Democrats will wait for congressional action to play out before going to the courts. Outside activists said they understood from conversations with congressional staff that Democrats were likely to file their own lawsuit, rather than simply joining other actions that 16 state attorneys general and liberal, environmental, and other organizations have commenced separately. The battle over the national emergency declaration is ongoing.

Title: Facebook Prioritizes "Trusted" News Sources, Raises Questions About Trust and Its Definition

Article:

Facebook, a leading social media platform with an estimated 214 million users in the United States, has announced plans to prioritize "trusted" news sources in its News Feed. The decision was made following a survey of a diverse and representative sample of people across the US to gauge their familiarity with and trust in various news sources.

The relationship between Facebook and the news media is complex, with the social network serving as a significant disseminator of news produced elsewhere. Some of this news is fake, and Facebook's users are prone to spreading extreme content, including literal propaganda. In 2016, Russian agents used Facebook to disrupt the US elections, exposing 140 million people to their trolling.

Facebook acknowledges the problem, with its product manager for civic engagement stating that social media could "corrode democracy." The company has implemented efforts to expose untruths and deter people from sharing misinformation.

The question of how Facebook can determine what news organizations people trust is not the primary concern. Instead, the question is whether this is the right question to ask. Facebook plans to gather data through a poll, asking users about their familiarity with and trust in various news sources.

In a post on Facebook, founder Mark Zuckerberg outlined the poll, which asks users about their familiarity with and trust in news sources from a provided list. The poll's five possible answers range from "entirely" to "not at all," easily coded as one through five or five through one.

In his 2002 book "Trust and Trustworthiness," the late political scientist Russell Hardin noted that trust has messy definitions and is not widely agreed upon. However, he attempted to define trustworthiness as the raw stuff that a person or institution might possess, while trust is what someone feels. Trust is a three-part relationship: A trusts B to do X. If you only have two elements, that's not really trust.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder Reflects on His Legacy as He Nears End of Tenure

Article:

In the aftermath of his resignation as Attorney General, Eric Holder made a visit to Scranton, Pennsylvania, the site of his first major trial as a young public corruption prosecutor. The visit, Holder said, felt like completing a circle, having started his legal career in the same courthouse.

After his early years as a prosecutor, Holder rose through the ranks, becoming the U.S. attorney in Washington, D.C., and the deputy attorney general in the Clinton administration. In February 2009, he became the first African-American attorney general.

Holder described the attorney general position as the best job he would ever have, one that shaped him as a lawyer and a person. During his farewell speech, Holder became emotional, reflecting on his personal and professional journey.

Holder shared stories about his parents, particularly his late father, who was denied a seat in a whites-only train car while in military uniform. He also spoke about his mother, who lived long enough to see him become attorney general but grew sick and died before what Holder views as his most significant civil rights accomplishments.

Looking ahead, Holder plans to continue his work on criminal justice and civil rights issues, particularly in bridging the gap between communities of color and law enforcement. He also expressed regret over the lack of progress in gun safety measures following the Newtown, Connecticut, school shooting.

If he stays at the Justice Department through December, Eric Holder will be the third-longest-serving attorney general in U.S. history. Holder indicated that his public life may not end with his government service.

Title: GOP Presidential Race Takes Shape as Hillary Clinton Announces 2016 Bid, Romney Considered a Contender

Article:

Matt Latimer, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, is a co-partner in Javelin, a literary agency and communications firm based in Alexandria, and a contributing editor at an unspecified magazine. For conservatives, the start of a presidential cycle is a time of excitement, as every Republican candidate promises to be the next Ronald Reagan. However, over time, these candidates often resemble Gerald Ford.

The 2016 presidential race is no exception, with Hillary Clinton announcing her bid for the Democratic nomination. Clinton, who lost the 2008 Democratic primary to Barack Obama, is running as the overconfident and inevitable nominee, with safe speeches and a bloated campaign staff that is already leaking against each other in the press.

The Republican field is also taking shape, with several high-profile candidates considering a run. The GOP field is expected to be so crowded that the first debate may have to be held on an aircraft carrier, with the USS Ronald Reagan as a possible venue. The candidates, who are generally of quality and worth, have impressive resumes and realistic shots at the nomination, if circumstances fall a certain way.

However, some candidates may be running to build their brand rather than to win the presidency. These candidates may have a skeleton crew of neophytes and are likely to run only to score a few book deals and up their speaking fees.

One of the most frequently mentioned candidates is Mitt Romney, who is considered a contender by many. Romney, who lost the 2012 presidential election to Obama, is reportedly considering a run again. However, Romney, who is cautious and practical, may find the risks of running to be greater than the potential reward.

There is no clear frontrunner in the GOP race, and many in the D.C. pundit class are preparing to take apart the candidates bit by bit. In 1980, the same D.C. insiders thought anybody but Ronald Reagan would be the GOP nominee, but Reagan won anyway. This year, the line is that Jeb Bush has the GOP nomination for the taking, but many outside the D.C. bubble find this idea vaguely depressing, as it suggests a possible Bush-Clinton rematch of the 1992 election.

Title: Pelosi Suggests Open Discussion on Mueller Indicting President Trump

Article:

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, likely to be the next Speaker of the House, stated in an interview on Thursday that it is an "open discussion" on whether Special Counsel Robert Mueller could seek an indictment of President Donald Trump. In an interview on NBC's "Today," Pelosi said, "I think that that is an open discussion."

When asked if Mueller "should honor and observe the [Department of Justice] guidance that states a sitting president can not be indicted," Pelosi responded, "I do not think that that is conclusive. No, I do not."

Pelosi later added that lawmakers should focus on getting results for the American people and see what Mueller reports. She stated, "Everything indicates that a president can be indicted after he is no longer president of the U.S."

The comments come as Mueller's probe into Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential election and possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Moscow continues into 2019. In December, Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen was sentenced to 36 months in prison for a series of crimes he committed while working as Trump's personal attorney.

The sentence occurred after Cohen pleaded guilty to federal charges, including campaign finance violations stemming from payments to keep two women quiet after they say they had affairs with Trump more than a decade ago. Prior to Cohen's sentencing, federal prosecutors in New York said in a memo that Trump directed Cohen to make the illegal payments to the women, marking the first time prosecutors made those accusations against the president.

The allegations have led to scrutiny about the Justice Department guidelines around indicting a sitting president. Sen. Christopher Coons (D-Del.) said last month that the evidence presented against Cohen "might well form the basis for an indictment after the president leaves office."

In a poll released last month, a majority of Americans said they think that a sitting president should be subject to indictment. Seventy-one percent of respondents, including 49 percent of Republicans, said sitting presidents should be subject to indictment, while 21 percent said they should not.

Title: Supreme Court Tie Results in Stalemate on Obama's Immigration Policies

Article:

The Supreme Court has reached a 4-4 decision on two controversial immigration policies proposed by President Barack Obama, leaving in place a lower court ruling that blocks the implementation of the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) and an expansion of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

The tied vote prevents the administration from implementing a program that would allow undocumented immigrants who are parents of U.S. citizens or lawful permanent residents to remain in the United States for three years and apply for work permits. It also halts the administration's efforts to expand the DACA program, which was issued in 2012.

This is the most prominent Supreme Court case to stall in a 4-4 tie, and it increases the stakes for this fall's presidential election. The vacancy on the court, created by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia in February, has led to a standoff between the White House and Senate Republicans, who have refused to consider President Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland.

In response to the Supreme Court's decision, President Obama criticized the lack of a decision by the eight-justice court, stating, "The fact the Supreme Court wasn’t able to issue a decision today doesn’t just set the system back even further, it takes us further back from the country we want to be."

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) blasted the GOP Senate majority for failing to consider Garland, stating, "This 4-4 decision is clear evidence we need nine justices on the court."

Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump has pledged to place tough new restrictions on illegal immigration, including the construction of a wall along the U.S.'s southern border. Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) stated, "The Supreme Court’s ruling makes the president’s executive action on immigration null and void."

Thursday's action does not affect the original DACA decision, which allows certain children who entered or stayed in the United States illegally to remain in the country and apply for work permits. The lawsuit filed by the 26 states challenging the administration's immigration policies is still working its way through the court system.

When President Obama took action to expand his immigration programs, it was part of a last-ditch effort to take action after Congress failed to pass a sweeping overhaul of the nation's immigration system. Immigrant rights activists have criticized Obama as the "deporter in chief" for ramping up the pace of deportations during his first term. Since then, he has taken steps to narrow the focus of immigration enforcement. His executive actions were seen as a centerpiece of his push to reverse that trend.

Title: State Department Designates Groups Involved in 2012 Benghazi Attack as Terrorist Organizations

Article:

The United States Department of State, on Friday, designated Ansar al-Sharia in Benghazi, Ansar al-Sharia in Darnah, and Ansar al-Sharia in Tunisia as terrorist organizations, citing their involvement in the 2012 attack on the U.S. Special Mission and Annex in Benghazi, Libya. The department also labeled Sufian bin Qumu, head of the Darnah branch, and Ahmed Abu Khattalah, head of the Benghazi branch, as terrorists.

The State Department's announcement comes after initial claims that the attack was spontaneous, related to protests over an anti-Islam film that were raging elsewhere in Africa and the Middle East. However, the department has since backed off that explanation, though has not ruled out the film as having played some role.

The State Department specifically discussed allegations against the Ansar al-Sharia branches, stating that they have been involved in terrorist attacks against civilian targets, frequent assassinations, and attempted assassinations of security officials and political actors in eastern Libya. The department also cited the September 11, 2012 attacks against the U.S. Special Mission and Annex in Benghazi, Libya, and noted that members of both organizations continue to pose a threat to U.S. interests in Libya.

Sufian bin Qumu, who was a former Guantanamo Bay detainee, has historic ties to the Al Qaeda network, including training at Usama bin Laden's Torkham camp. Ahmed Abu Khattalah, in October 2012, told Fox News that while he was at the U.S. consulate that night, he was not responsible for the attack, claiming he was helping Libyan security workers defending the compound.

The new terror designation bars anyone from providing or trying to provide "material support or resources" to those organizations and individuals, and freezes any assets they have in the U.S. The State Department also updated its Rewards for Justice website to include a reward of up to $10 million for information leading to the arrest or conviction of anyone involved in the Benghazi attack. The department had faced criticism for not including that reward on the website, though officials claimed reward offers had nevertheless been made.

Four Americans died in the 2012 attack, and so far, nobody has been brought to justice in connection with the killings. The U.S. government is committed to taking all appropriate actions against the organizations and individuals responsible for the attacks against the U.S. diplomatic facilities in Libya and Tunisia, according to the State Department.

Title: Fox News Legal Analyst: Quid Pro Quo Not Criminal, but Biden's Actions Raise Questions

 Article:

 Fox News senior judicial analyst Andrew Napolitano stated on "Fox & Friends" early Tuesday that while Hunter Biden's overseas business dealings "look bad," none of them are criminal. Napolitano explained that the Chinese often invest in entities associated with individuals they believe can provide them a foothold in American society.

 The analysis follows Hunter Biden's announcement that he is stepping down from the board of a Chinese company and declaring he will not engage in any foreign work if his father, former Vice President Joe Biden, is elected president in 2020.

 In an interview with ABC News, Hunter Biden admitted that his involvement with foreign companies provided a platform for critics to attack him over alleged conflicts of interest. He stated, "I gave a hook to some very unethical people to act in illegal ways to try to do some harm to my father. That's where I made the mistake."

 Joe Biden, who will debate other Democratic presidential candidates Tuesday evening, has not conducted any sit-down interviews with national broadcast media outlets since President Trump began attacking the Bidens last month.

 Trump and Republicans have accused Hunter Biden of profiting off his father's office and claim the former vice president is corrupt. However, Joe Biden has denied acting with his son's interests in mind. There is no evidence of any criminal wrongdoing by either of the Bidens.

 House Democrats launched an impeachment inquiry into Trump last month following revelations that he pressured Ukraine's president to investigate the Bidens.

Title: Fox News' Role in U.S. Immigration Reform Debate Remains Uncertain

Article:

In the ongoing debate over a potential path to citizenship for the United States' 11 million undocumented immigrants, Fox News Channel is positioned to play a significant role. The question is whether it will assume a more neutral role or fan the flames of opposition to a comprehensive reform plan.

Rupert Murdoch, chairman and CEO of News Corp., Fox's parent company, is a wild card factor in determining Fox News' stance. Murdoch, an Australian-born U.S. citizen, has become an outspoken advocate for immigration reform and the mass legalization of undocumented immigrants, partnering with New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg in this cause. Whether Murdoch's personal views will influence the network's coverage remains uncertain.

Ira Mehlman, spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform and a frequent Fox News guest, opposes the widespread legalization proposed by President Obama and a bipartisan group of U.S. senators. Mehlman believes Fox News could be a crucial ally in the battle for public opinion on immigration, crediting the network with helping to derail a similar legislative push in 2006 and 2007.

However, 2013 is shaping up to be a different game, with Fox News potentially emerging as a potential boon for immigrant advocates. Sean Hannity, Bill O'Reilly, and Charles Krauthammer, prominent Fox hosts and commentators, have expressed support for immigration reform, suggesting the network could be a valuable forum to court moderates.

Murdoch's personal views and their impact on Fox News' coverage remain unclear. During a 2010 hearing on Capitol Hill, Murdoch advocated for a "full path to legalization" for the millions living and working in the shadows. He has since been vocal about his support for immigration reform on Twitter.

Fox News' primetime viewership has been on the decline in recent months, but it remains a highly-profitable network with the largest news audience on cable. Its median prime-time viewership was 1.9 million in 2011, well ahead of MSNBC (773,000) and CNN (654,000), according to the Pew Research Center.

Many advocates caution against overstating the influence of Fox News, insisting the network will not play a decisive role in the immigration debate one way or the other. Ali Noorani, executive director of the National Immigration Forum, believes the diversity and bipartisanship of advocates for a reform plan will override any single, particular influence.

Murdoch has tried to downplay his network's influence on political debate over immigration, stating, "We are home to all views on Fox. We do not censor that or take any particular line at all. We are not anti-immigrant on Fox News." The outcome of the immigration reform debate remains uncertain, with Fox News' role in the debate yet to be determined.

Title: Florida ICUs Reach Capacity as Coronavirus Cases Surge

Article:

Florida hospitals have reported that their intensive-care units (ICUs) are at capacity or dangerously low on beds due to the surge in coronavirus cases. At least 56 Florida ICUs have run out of beds for coronavirus patients, and 35 more have reported bed availability dropping to 10 percent or lower.

The latest data comes as Florida recorded over 7,300 new coronavirus cases, 380 new hospitalizations, and 63 more deaths from the infection on Tuesday. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis stated on Tuesday that the death rate in his state has begun to taper off, noting that most of the new cases are younger patients.

Several other states, including Georgia and California, have also seen a surge in coronavirus cases after reopening large swaths of their economies. Georgia passed 100,000 positive coronavirus cases on Tuesday, making it the ninth state to reach that number. California recorded a record daily increase of over 10,200 new coronavirus cases and a record 6,000 hospitalized patients on the same day. Some Texas counties have also warned that their hospital ICUs will run out of beds over the next two weeks.

Dr. Anthony Fauci, the chief medical adviser for the Trump administration's coronavirus task force, noted on Tuesday that the death rate from the virus has decreased but warned against "false complacency" as the pathogen continues to spread.

"It's a false narrative to take comfort in a lower rate of death," Fauci said. "There's so many other things that are very dangerous and bad about this virus, don't get yourself into false complacency."

"The death rate is lower, I admit that. Because people in general, who are young or healthier. But that doesn't mean that you could not get seriously ill," he added.

The U.S. has recorded more than three million positive cases of coronavirus, and 131,200 people in the country have died after being infected.

Title: Judge Rules Trump Exceeded Authority in Reversing Offshore Drilling Bans

Article:

In a ruling on Friday, U.S. District Court Judge Sharon Gleason overturned President Trump's executive order that reversed bans on offshore drilling in vast parts of the Arctic Ocean and dozens of canyons in the Atlantic Ocean. The ruling restores the Obama-era restrictions that were a significant part of his environmental legacy.

Presidents have the power under a federal law to remove certain lands from development, but they cannot revoke those removals, according to Gleason. The judge's decision states that the wording of President Obama's 2015 and 2016 withdrawals indicates that he intended them to extend indefinitely and be revocable only by an act of Congress.

The American Petroleum Institute, a defendant in the case, disagreed with the ruling. In a statement, the organization argued that developing offshore resources could provide billions in government revenue, create thousands of jobs, and strengthen national security.

Erik Grafe, an attorney with Earthjustice, welcomed the ruling, stating that it "shows that the president can not just trample on the Constitution to do the bidding of his cronies in the fossil fuel industry at the expense of our oceans, wildlife, and climate." Earthjustice represented numerous environmental groups that sued the Trump administration over the April 2017 executive order reversing the drilling bans.

The case centered around the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act. Acting Assistant U.S. Attorney General Jeffrey Wood argued during a hearing before Gleason in November that environmental groups were misinterpreting the intent of the law written in 1953. He stated that the law is meant to be flexible and sensible and not intended to bind one president with decisions made by another when determining offshore stewardship as needs and realities change over time.

In 2015, Obama halted exploration in coastal areas of the Beaufort and Chukchi seas and the Hanna Shoal, an important area for walrus. In late 2016, he withdrew most other potential Arctic Ocean lease areas, covering about 98 percent of the Arctic outer continental shelf. The bans were intended to protect polar bears, walruses, ice seals, and Alaska Native villages that depend on the animals.

In the Atlantic, Obama banned exploration in 5,937 square miles (15,377 square kilometers) of underwater canyon complexes, citing their importance for marine mammals, deep-water corals, valuable fish populations, and migratory whales.

Title: Merkel's White House Visit Focuses on Ukraine Crisis, Amidst Ongoing NSA Spying Tensions

Article:

German Chancellor Angela Merkel's visit to the White House on Friday will be marked by the ongoing tension from last year's revelations of US eavesdropping on her cellphone, but the crisis in Ukraine is expected to dominate the agenda. Facing the gravest challenge to stability in Europe since the cold war, Merkel and President Obama will be looking to each other for leadership in addressing the Ukraine storm.

Merkel, the Western leader with the closest personal relationship with Putin and whose country has the strongest economic ties to Russia, is expected to argue for a careful "step-by-step" approach to Russian aggression. She has been deeply disappointed by Putin's annexation of Crimea and the campaign of destabilization he is carrying out in eastern Ukraine, and now believes a tough Western response is in order.
