At the same time, Merkel is likely to encourage Obama to continue with his approach of coordinating with Europe and prioritizing transatlantic unity over unilateral action. This, despite the domestic criticism Merkel knows Obama faces for not moving faster.

"Merkel's response to the crisis has been a little bit tougher than some might have expected," says Christopher Chivvis, a specialist in European and Eurasian security at RAND Corp. in Arlington, Va. "It's also true, he adds, that because of Germany's leadership role in Europe and its dominant role in relations with Russia, 'what she says has a really big impact in the region.'"

As a result of Merkel's somewhat surprising firmness and the influential role she plays, Obama is expected to try to enlist Germany to go farther and do more. "I would expect the president will try to lean in a little bit on Ukraine," he says.

Obama has refrained from imposing sanctions on entire sectors of the Russian economy in part because of European reluctance to go that route. But the president is expected to try to pin down with Merkel what additional Russian actions in Ukraine would trigger tougher measures from the Europeans, including broader sectoral sanctions, US officials say.

On the Ukraine file, the two leaders will have more than just the issue of sanctions on Russia to keep them busy. Another priority item will be how to help ensure that the national elections Ukraine has scheduled for May 25 go off without major hitches (many regional experts believe Russia is doing everything it can to undermine the vote) and result in a legitimate and authoritative national government.

Ukraine's economic survival will also be on the agenda. In addition to her White House visit, Merkel will also meet with International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde to discuss what financial and economic help Ukraine will need to get back on its feet.

Merkel is also scheduled to address the US Chamber of Commerce Friday afternoon, focusing on the transatlantic free trade and investment agreement that the US and European Union are hoping to conclude next year. She was planning to dine with a group of US senators upon her arrival in Washington Thursday evening.

Yet even as Ukraine receives top billing in Merkel's visit, the outrage she – and indeed much of Germany – felt upon learning last year of NSA spying on German leaders, including Merkel, will not be far below the surface.

When Obama invited Merkel to Washington earlier this year, she said pointedly that the process of reestablishing trust would take "more than one trip." Germany has pressed for a "no-spy" accord with the US like the one the US has with Britain and a few other English-speaking allies, but the US has made it clear it is not prepared to take that step, and Merkel is not expected to insist on that point.

This willingness to downplay an important issue that risks getting in the way of addressing another will put Merkel's pragmatism on full display. It also provides a stark contrast with the response of another world leader who found her country embroiled in the NSA spying controversy.

Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff had been invited for what would have been the only state visit to the Obama White House last year. But with Brazilians still furious over revelations of US spying in their country, Ms. Rousseff called off the visit. US-Brazilian relations have not recovered since.

Merkel also faces heightened anti-American sentiments at home, German experts note. But she also supports a strong transatlantic partnership, these experts emphasize, and she represents a Germany that sees a continuing US leadership role in Europe as all the more important in the era of an aggressive and even expansionist Russia.

"The Germans want to stay close to the US," says Charles Ries, international vice president and expert in European Affairs at RAND. "They don't want the story [from Merkel's visit] to be one of divergence."

But Ambassador Ries, who just returned to Washington from Europe, says German leaders and many of their European colleagues want the US to consult with them and take their concerns into consideration even as it retains an active role in Europe.

"Often they grumble if we don't set out a clear [path]... but they can also grumble if we do," says Ries. "What they really don't like is when the US seems to be not acting."

That ambivalence presents "a leadership challenge for the US," he says. Some public expression of understanding from Obama about Germany's spying concerns might be enough to deliver the picture of firm accord on Ukraine the White House wants. "If [Merkel] gets that," Ries says, "it's likely the US 'can get an outcome from the White House visit that [projects] strong alliance unity and resolve.'"

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Policies and Charter Schools: A Contentious Issue

Article:

Attorney General Eric H. Holder's policies towards charter schools and school discipline have been a contentious issue, with critics accusing him of prioritizing the interests of teachers unions over the education of poor and minority children. One of the notable instances was Holder's attempt to suppress the spread of charter schools in Louisiana, and his nationwide threats of legal action against schools that discipline more black students than he deems appropriate.

Charter schools, often criticized by teachers unions and the educational establishment, seem to be particularly targeted when they succeed in educating minority children, a demographic that the educational establishment often claims cannot be educated effectively. The success of these schools often lies in their ability to hire non-unionized teachers and avoid adhering to the dogmas prevalent in the educational establishment.

Last year, there was an attempt to shut down the American Indian Model Schools in Oakland, California, schools that were ranked among the top in the nation, with top test scores in their district and the fourth-highest scores in the entire state of California. The reason given was financial irregularities alleged against the former head of these schools. However, a court order prevented this planned vindictive closing of this highly successful charter school with a predominantly minority student body.

Holder's threats of legal action against schools where minority students are disciplined more often than he wants are a more sweeping and damaging blow to the education of poor and minority students across the country. The education of many ghetto schools is often hindered by disruptive students whose antics, threats, and violence can make education virtually impossible. If only 10% of the students are this way, it sacrifices the education of the other 90%.

The idea that Holder, or anyone else, can determine how many disciplinary actions against individual students are warranted or unwarranted in schools across the country would be laughable if it were not so tragic. Relying on racial statistics tells you nothing, unless one believes that black male students can not possibly be more disruptive than Asian female students, or that students in crime-ridden neighborhoods can not possibly require disciplinary actions more often than children in the most staid, middle-class neighborhoods.

Critics argue that Holder's policies are politically motivated, with the intention of promoting a sense of grievance from charges of racial discrimination to energize the black vote and secure Democratic support, especially in the wake of Obama administration scandals and fiascoes. Holder's other major racial crusade - against requiring identification for voting - is similarly criticized as a political game, orchestrated to promote fears and hysteria.

Michael J. W. Malbin, a senior fellow with the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, has been critical of Holder's policies, stating that sacrificing the education of children, especially those for whom education may be their only ticket out of poverty, is a new low.

Title: BuzzFeed Publishes Unverified Allegations Against Trump: A Look at the Controversy

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and debate within the journalism community, online news outlet BuzzFeed published an unverified dossier containing allegations against President-elect Donald Trump on Tuesday. The dossier, which was also referenced in a report by CNN, includes claims of Russian efforts to compromise Trump and salacious personal details.

The decision by BuzzFeed to publish the dossier, while stating "there is serious reason to doubt the allegations," has been met with criticism from Trump, his team, and other media outlets. Trump called BuzzFeed "a failing piece of garbage" that will "suffer the consequences" of its actions, while Vice President-elect Mike Pence blamed the situation on "media bias."

CNN, which initially reported on the briefing of the allegations to President Obama and Trump, chose not to detail the specific claims due to their unverified nature. However, by referencing the fact that Trump was briefed about a two-page synopsis, CNN put the allegations in the public sphere, raising doubts about whether Trump had been "compromised" in some way.

The furor began when CNN anchor Jake Tapper reported that the nation's top intelligence officials had provided information about Russian efforts to compromise Trump to both Obama and Trump last week. BuzzFeed, in turn, published the entire dossier, which can be found elsewhere online.

The situation has put the rest of the media in an uncomfortable position, as they report on an unproven story while trying to avoid the details. Some websites have been happy to repeat the rumors, but others, such as The New York Times, have chosen not to publish the allegations due to a lack of corroboration.

Dean Baquet, executive editor of The New York Times, stated, "We, like others, investigated the allegations and haven't corroborated them, and we felt we're not in the business of publishing things we can't stand by."

BuzzFeed defends its decision to publish the dossier, claiming it is being "transparent" with its readers. However, the transparency has allowed the public to witness what some consider to be shoddy journalism, as BuzzFeed is also known for its pop culture-focused content, including articles such as "How Bitchy Is Your Resting Face?" and "Would you get rid of your phone just to have an orgasm?"

The controversy has sparked a larger discussion about the role of journalism in 2017, with some arguing that BuzzFeed's decision to publish the unverified dossier is a perversion of journalistic practices, while others argue that it is important to report on all information, even if it is unverified. The situation remains a contentious issue within the journalism community.

Title: Former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert Indicted for Trying to Evade Currency Reporting Rules and Lying to the FBI

Article:

A federal grand jury has indicted former House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert on charges of trying to circumvent currency reporting rules and lying to the FBI regarding payments he was making for past "misconduct." The indictment does not describe the nature of the misconduct, but it paints a picture of a cover-up, stating that Hastert agreed to pay $3.5 million to an individual identified as "Individual A" to conceal his past behavior.

Beginning in 2010, Hastert, 73, and Individual A would meet every six weeks, with Hastert providing $50,000 during each meeting. Federal investigators became involved when Hastert, after being questioned by his bank about large withdrawals, began making smaller withdrawals of less than $10,000, then bundling them to evade reporting requirements.

The indictment, handed up from a grand jury in Chicago, alleges that Hastert lied to FBI investigators in December about the withdrawals, stating he was keeping the cash. From 2010 to 2014, Hastert withdrew approximately $1.7 million in cash from various bank accounts and provided it to Individual A. Beginning in July 2012, Hastert started structuring his cash withdrawals in increments of less than $10,000 to evade Currency Transaction Reports, according to the U.S. Attorney's office.

The case was pursued by the FBI and the IRS' criminal investigation division. Hastert served two decades in the House and was speaker from 1999 through 2007, notching the longest tenure of any Republican speaker in history. He stepped down after overseeing a disastrous election for House Republicans in 2006, and led the lobbying arm of Dickstein Shapiro LLP, a Washington law firm, until his resignation on Thursday.

Hastert did not respond to an email request for comment Thursday evening. He has a public policy center named for him at Wheaton College in Illinois, and served on several corporate boards. CME Group announced Thursday that he had stepped down from its board, according to news reports.

According to the indictment, Hastert has turned over about $1.7 million of the $3.5 million he had agreed to pay to Individual A. Of that, $952,000 was taken out in increments of less than $10,000, which investigators said was done in violation of the currency law.

When the FBI questioned Hastert, they asked if he was keeping the money because he didn't feel safe with it in the banks. "Yeah … I kept the cash. That's what I'm doing," he told them, according to the indictment.

Hastert was a high school teacher and wrestling coach in Yorkville, Illinois, from 1967 to 1981, and the indictment states that Individual A is a resident of the same town and "has known defendant John Dennis Hastert most of Individual A's life." The indictment also mentions that the two met repeatedly in 2010, and during one of those meetings, they discussed past misconduct by Hastert against Individual A that had occurred years earlier.

During his time as House speaker, Hastert served with former Rep. Tom DeLay, who had to step down after he was indicted on charges of conspiring to launder campaign contributions. DeLay was found guilty by a jury, but an appeals court later ruled the evidence was insufficient and dismissed the case.

Title: Investigation of Race-Based Discrimination in College Admissions Initiated by Department of Justice

Article:

The Department of Justice (DOJ) is reportedly investigating potential race-based discrimination in college and university admissions, according to a document obtained by The New York Times. The DOJ is allegedly seeking lawyers interested in "investigations and possible litigation related to intentional race-based discrimination in college and university admissions."

The DOJ's actions have been met with various interpretations, with The New York Times describing the intent as "redirecting resources" to protect "white applicants." However, the DOJ's actions could be seen as enforcing the law, as the investigation aims to address allegations of discrimination against Asian-American applicants in higher education institutions.

In 2015 and 2016, Asian-American groups filed complaints against several elite American colleges, presenting evidence of race-based discrimination in college admissions. For example, they alleged that Asian Americans have the "lowest acceptance rate for each SAT test-score bracket." To gain admission to college, Asian-American students had to score 140 points higher than white students, 270 points higher than Hispanic students, and 450 points higher than black students.

The complaints also presented strong evidence of prohibited quotas, as the college-admission rate for Asian-American students stagnated as the Asian-American population expanded, similar to anti-Semitic administrators' use of caps on Jewish students in the past.

The complaints rightly assail the damage caused by the quotas and the obvious and extreme higher standards applied to Asian-American students. The discriminatory practices by Yale, Brown, Dartmouth, and other Ivy League colleges have caused stress, mental health issues, pressure to study more, lack of trust in American institutions, self-identification crises, and fortification of racial barriers for students in the Asian-American community.

The DOJ's investigation aims to address these issues and enforce the law, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, and national origin in federally funded educational institutions, as stated in Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution, which establishes that no state can deny any person within its jurisdiction the "equal protection of the laws."

Decades of leftist judicial and regulatory activism have reversed the meanings of these protections, with the Supreme Court repeatedly reaffirming that the 14th Amendment permits the use of race in admissions for the sake of advancing the "compelling state interest" of a properly diverse student body. However, the exceptions are supposed to be relatively narrow, and colleges are supposed to reject formulas and quotas. The admissions process is supposed to be "holistic," with race merely one of many factors considered. In practice, quotas exist, and race isn't just one factor in admissions—time and again, it's the most important factor.

Title: Mueller's Team Denies Trap-Setting in Flynn Interview

Article:

WASHINGTON – In a recent court filing, Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team has denied any suggestion that former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn was tricked by FBI agents during his interview regarding his communications with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak. The interview took place at the White House on January 24, 2017, just days after President Donald Trump's inauguration.

According to the new court documents, the interview was voluntary and lacked any indicia of coercion. This response comes after Flynn's attorneys earlier this week suggested that the FBI may have deceived the former national security advisor by not warning him about the criminal consequences for lying to agents during the interview.

Mueller's prosecutors argue that a sitting national security advisor, former head of an intelligence agency, retired lieutenant general, and 33-year veteran of the armed forces should be aware of the consequences of lying to federal agents. They also asserted that the court should reject Flynn's attempt to minimize the seriousness of his false statements to the FBI.

The new filings are made in advance of Flynn's December 18 sentencing. Prosecutors have recommended no prison time for the former Trump administration official who has provided substantial cooperation in the ongoing Russia investigation. Flynn's attorneys have also asked for leniency and no prison time for their client.

Before the interview, FBI officials had decided that they would not warn Flynn about the potential criminal jeopardy he faced for making false statements. The interview was arranged by then-Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe, who was subsequently fired for unauthorized disclosures to reporters. The primary interviewing agent was Peter Strzok, a senior counterintelligence official who was later dismissed for making disparaging comments about candidate Donald Trump in text messages exchanged with an FBI lawyer who was Strzok's girlfriend.

Despite the questions raised about FBI tactics, prosecutors continued to support leniency for the former administration officer, who will be the first former White House official to be sentenced in Mueller's continuing inquiry. Last week, Mueller's prosecutors provided an account of Flynn's extensive cooperation, citing the former three-star general's "substantial" assistance to the Russia inquiry and at least two other undisclosed investigations in recommending that he serve no prison time.

Flynn, according to prosecutors, has met with investigators 19 times since he pleaded guilty last year to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Kislyak during the run-up to Trump's inauguration. Prosecutors have lauded Flynn's assistance, claiming that his early guilty plea and decision to cooperate "likely affected the decisions of related firsthand witnesses to be forthcoming with the (special counsel’s office) and cooperate."

Flynn, who memorably called for the jailing of Democrat Hillary Clinton during the 2016 Republican convention, discussed U.S. sanctions with Kislyak on Trump's behalf during the presidential transition, and members of the president's inner circle were aware of, and in some cases directing, his efforts, according to the plea. Flynn had urged Kislyak not to respond to sanctions imposed by the Obama administration in response to Russian election interference. Flynn's FBI interview came just weeks before he was forced to resign in February 2017. The White House said he was fired for misleading Pence and other senior officials about the content of his conversations with Kislyak. As part of his plea, Flynn also admitted to lying about Turkish lobbying and research work. He belatedly registered with the Justice Department as a foreign agent for the work weeks after he left the White House.

Title: Key Lawmakers Express Concern Over Obama Administration's Plan to Send F-16 Fighter Jets to Egypt

Article:

Key lawmakers in the United States have expressed concerns about the Obama administration's plan to send 20 F-16 fighter jets to Egypt, as the country's new President Mohamed Morsi's allegiances and grip on power remain uncertain. The U.S. is providing the planes under a foreign aid deal signed in 2010, during the tenure of Morsi's U.S.-friendly predecessor, Hosni Mubarak.

The first four jets are set to be delivered beginning January 22, according to a source at the naval air base in Fort Worth, where the planes have been undergoing testing. The $213 million gift, however, is raising questions on Capitol Hill, as Morsi is under fire for attempting to seize dictatorial powers and allegedly siccing thugs and rapists on protesters.

Florida Rep. Vern Buchanan, who recently called for ending foreign aid to Egypt altogether, said the Muslim Brotherhood-backed Morsi government has been sending increasingly troubling signals to Washington, and giving it state-of-the-art fighter jets is a dangerous idea.

"American tax dollars must not be used to aid and abet any dictatorial regime that stands with terrorists," Buchanan said.

Rep. Mac Thornberry (R-Texas), vice chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, told FoxNews.com that Egypt is a wild card under Morsi.

"At this point, we do not know where Egypt is headed," Thornberry said. "We should be cautious about driving them away, but we should also be cautious about the arms we provide."

Last week, vigilante supporters of Morsi captured dozens of protesters, detaining and beating them before handing them over to police, according to human rights advocates. Morsi-backed groups have also been accused of using rape to intimidate female protesters who have gathered in Cairo's Tahrir Square to protest a Sharia-based constitution and Morsi's neutering of the nation's legal system.

The U.S. government ordered and paid for the fighter jets for Egypt's military back in 2010. However, since Mubarak's ouster, the democratically elected Morsi has sent mixed signals about whether he wants an alliance with Washington, even meeting with leaders in Iran earlier this year.

"The Morsi-led Muslim Brotherhood government has not proven to be a partner for democracy as they had promised, given the recent attempted power grab," a senior Republican congressional aide told FoxNews.com.

Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.), who chairs the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, recently criticized U.S. military aid to Egypt:

"The Obama administration wants to simply throw money at an Egyptian government that the president can not even clearly state is an ally of the United States," Rep. Ros-Lehtinen said.

The package had to be approved by lawmakers in Washington. While the basic F-16 has been a military workhorse for top air forces for more than 25 years, the cockpit electronics are constantly updated, and the models Egypt is getting are the best defense contractor Lockheed Martin makes.

"This is a great day for Lockheed Martin and a testament to the enduring partnership and commitment we have made to the government of Egypt," said John Larson, vice president, Lockheed Martin F-16 programs. "We remain committed to providing our customer with a proven, advanced 4th Generation multirole fighter."

"In an air combat role, the F-16's maneuverability and combat radius exceed that of all potential threat fighter aircraft," the U.S. Air Force description of the plane reads.

"The F-16 can fly more than 500 miles, deliver its weapons with superior accuracy, defend itself against enemy aircraft, and return to its starting point. An all-weather capability allows it to accurately deliver ordnance during non-visual bombing conditions," the U.S. Air Force description continues.

A Pentagon spokesman said the U.S. and Egypt have an important alliance that is furthered by the transfer.

"The U.S.-Egypt defense relationship has served as the cornerstone of our broader strategic partnership for over thirty years," said Lt. Col. Wesley Miller. "The delivery of the first set of F-16s in January 2013 reflects the U.S. commitment to supporting the Egyptian military's modernization efforts. Egyptian acquisition of F-16s will increase our militaries' interoperability, and enhance Egypt's capacity to contribute to regional mission sets."

However, Malou Innocent, a foreign policy analyst at the Cato Institute, warned that Egypt's murky intentions could lead to the prospect of U.S. ally Israel facing an air assault from even more U.S.-made planes.

"Should an overreaction [by Egypt] spiral into a broader conflict between Egypt and Israel, such a scenario would put U.S. officials in an embarrassing position of having supplied massive amounts of military hardware… to both belligerents," Innocent said. "Given Washington's fiscal woes, American taxpayers should no longer be Egypt’s major arms supplier."

Title: Former BBC Director General Mark Thompson Clarifies Knowledge of Jimmy Savile Abuse Investigation

Article:

The former Director General of the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), Mark Thompson, has attempted to clarify his knowledge of a journalistic investigation into sexual abuse allegations against Jimmy Savile, a late children's TV presenter. The investigation, which was initially dropped in late 2011, has been a subject of controversy in recent weeks.

In a statement on Monday, Thompson stated, "I was not notified or briefed about the 'Newsnight' investigation, nor was I involved in any way in the decision not to complete and air the investigation." He also claimed, "During my time as Director General of the BBC, I never heard any allegations or received any complaints about Jimmy Savile."

However, in a report published in the New York Times on Tuesday, Thompson was quoted as saying that a BBC reporter informed him about the investigation at a party in December.

In a letter to British MP Rob Wilson, Thompson offered an explanation to reconcile his two statements. He explained that he learned of the investigation but not its details and was satisfied when he inquired to his senior management and was told that it had been dropped for journalistic reasons.

Thompson added that he did not question the decision to drop the investigation because such decisions are common. He also expressed his shock and concern over the sexual abuse allegations against Savile.

The controversy has raised questions about who knew what and when about the alleged abuse of young teenage girls, and it threatens lasting damage to the reputation of the UK's public broadcaster. The Metropolitan Police in London launched a criminal investigation into claims of child sexual abuse by Savile and others last week.

The BBC said on Monday that the editor of 'Newsnight' was "stepping aside" over questions about why his show never broadcast its investigation into Savile. The furor has shocked a generation in Britain who grew up watching Savile, one of the most recognizable figures in British showbiz from the 1960s to the 1980s, or listening to his radio shows.

The controversy has also prompted a wider examination of an apparent culture of sexism at the BBC in past decades that may have fed into abusive behavior. The allegations against the famous Savile are a reminder of how little the public really knows about celebrities, said Robert Thompson, director of the Bleier Center for Television and Popular Culture at Syracuse University.

"It's another one of these instances that shows us whenever there's someplace we think we won't see scandal, eventually, we end up seeing it," he said. The scandal brings the venerable BBC into question and feeds the state of cynicism that the public feels for media institutions, he added.

Title: Colin Kaepernick Announces Memoir Release and New Publishing Company Focused on Diversity

Article:

Former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, who gained political prominence for his protests against police brutality and social injustice during NFL games, has given an interview to USA Today and announced the release of a memoir under his own publishing company, Kaepernick Publishing. The memoir, yet to be titled, will delve into the life experiences that led him to protest during his NFL career.

In the interview, Kaepernick explained, "I've had a lot of questions surrounding what got me to the point of protesting. Which led me to wanting to share that story and give insight." He further elaborated on his decision to protest, stating, "Why did I do it? Why did I do it at that moment? Why wasn't it earlier in my career?"

Kaepernick Publishing, established in 2019, will focus on promoting writers of color and giving power to black and brown voices globally. The company aims to offer unprecedented ownership options to collaborators and bring greater diversity and representation to literature and spoken word.

Kaepernick's activism off the field includes the creation of the Know Your Rights Campaign, which hosts educational camps, and an endorsement contract with Nike in 2018. Despite being unsigned by any NFL team since 2017, Kaepernick has sued the NFL for collusion and reached a settlement for less than $10 million in February 2019.

Kaepernick expressed his readiness to return to the football field, stating, "My desire to play football is still there. I'm ready to go, I'm ready for a phone call, tryout, workout at any point in time." He added, "I'm still waiting on the owners and their partners to stop running from this situation. So I hope I get a call this offseason."

The NFL attempted to organize a workout for Kaepernick in 2019, but the event fell apart due to last-minute changes and Kaepernick's refusal to sign a liability waiver.

Title: Louisville Police Department Fires Officer Involved in Breonna Taylor Shooting

Article:

The Louisville Metro Police Department has terminated the employment of Officer Brett Hankison, one of the officers involved in the March shooting of 26-year-old emergency medical worker Breonna Taylor. In a letter to Hankison, tweeted by the department, Louisville police chief called his conduct "a shock to the conscience."

Taylor was fatally shot on March 13, when officers entered her home seeking illegal drugs. Officials claimed the officers knocked on the door and announced themselves, and only started shooting after they were "immediately met by gunfire" from Taylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker. However, Taylor's family stated in a lawsuit that the officers did not identify themselves, and that Walker, a licensed gun owner, thought someone was trying to break in.

The letter states that Hankison was found to have violated two standard operating procedures: obedience to rules and regulations and use of deadly force. Hankison violated the first procedure when he "wantonly and blindly fired ten (10) rounds" into Taylor's apartment, Chief of Police Robert Schroeder wrote in the letter, adding, "These rounds created a substantial danger of death and serious injury to Breonna Taylor and the three occupants of the apartment next to Ms. Taylor's."

Schroeder said Hankison also violated the department's use of force procedure when he fired the rounds "without supporting facts that your deadly force was directed at a person against whom posed an immediate threat of danger or serious injury to yourself or others."

"In fact, the ten (10) rounds you fired were into a patio door and window which were covered with material that completely prevented you from verifying any person as an immediate threat or more importantly any innocent persons present," he added.

Schroeder also said three of the rounds Hankison fired entered the apartment next to Taylor's, "endangering the three lives in that apartment."

"Based upon my review, these are extreme violations of our policies," Schroeder wrote. "I find your conduct a shock to the conscience. I am alarmed and stunned you used deadly force in this fashion. You have never been trained by the Louisville Metro Police Department to use deadly force in this fashion. Your actions have brought discredit upon yourself and the Department."

"I can not tolerate this type of conduct by any member of the Louisville Metro Police Department," he added. "Your conduct demands your termination."

The three officers involved in the shooting—Hankison, Jon Mattingly, and Myles Cosgrove—had all been placed on administrative reassignment throughout the investigation. None of the officers have been charged, despite widespread protests and calls for arrests.

In the wake of Taylor's death, Louisville passed a ban on "no-knock" warrants, which allow police to enter a home without first announcing their presence.

Title: Fact-Checking in Elections: Influence and Challenges

Article:

In the ongoing 2020 U.S. election, fact-checking has experienced significant growth, with numerous websites and news shows providing voters with information about the factual accuracy of political claims. However, the impact of fact-checkers on the public and politicians remains unclear.

Julian Zelizer, a political historian at Princeton University, questions the effectiveness of fact-checkers, stating that politicians continue to stretch the truth or fabricate facts with little evidence of public outrage or significant changes in their behavior.

One of the main challenges for fact-checkers is the deeply distrustful political culture that has existed since the 1970s, with consistently low trust in government and politicians. The public's general impression of their leaders is often confirmed rather than challenged by fact-checking revelations.

Fact-checkers also operate in a media environment that has become more polarized and openly partisan in recent years. The public tends to rely on sources that align with their political views, making it difficult for objective fact-checkers to gain traction.

Moreover, fact-checkers must compete with openly partisan fact-checkers, as political parties and organizations use these operations to further their own agendas. The distinction between partisan and real fact-checkers becomes blurred, making it challenging for the public to discern the truth.

Partisanship in politics has resulted in a world where it is difficult to distinguish fact from partisan fiction. Fact checkers, with the objective of helping Americans understand the election choices, struggle to gain traction. When one of the players calls "B.S." during the political cycle, people might be listening, but it's not clear that there are lasting consequences.

Title: House Committee Subpoenas Former Trump Administration Official Over Security Clearance Allegations

Article:

WASHINGTON – The House Committee on Oversight and Reform, led by Democrats, voted Tuesday to subpoena Carl Kline, a former personnel security director for the Trump administration, to discuss the granting of security clearances to individuals with questionable backgrounds. The vote was along party lines.

The committee is investigating allegations that the White House overruled security clearance denials made by lower-level officials, potentially posing a risk to national security. The subpoena is based on testimony from a whistleblower, a longtime White House security adviser who claimed that she and colleagues denied security clearances to about 25 applicants, only to see those decisions overturned by higher-ups in the Trump administration.

Tricia Newbold, a career employee who has returned to work at the White House, testified, "I would not be doing a service to myself, my country, or my children if I sat back knowing that the issues that we have could impact national security."

The group of 25 applicants may include President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, who was granted a top-secret security clearance despite concerns from officials, according to reports by The New York Times and The Washington Post in February. The specific applicants have not been identified by the committee.

Issues with some applicants include ties to foreign influence, conflicts of interests, questionable or criminal conduct, financial problems, and drug abuse, according to testimony. The White House has rejected document requests from the committee, citing privacy and arguing that Congress does not have the authority to see these documents.

White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders stated, "We're not going to exploit individuals and their personal information." Speaking with Fox News host Laura Ingraham on Monday, Kushner said, "I did not want to discuss the clearance process, but I can say over the last two years that I’ve been here, I’ve been accused of all different types of things, and all of those things have turned out to be false."

House Democrats are planning subpoenas in a number of investigations of the Trump White House. The House Judiciary Committee will meet Wednesday to authorize a subpoena for special counsel Robert Mueller's full report and the evidence his investigators gathered, setting up what could be a historic legal clash with the Justice Department. The committee also plans to vote to authorize subpoenas for evidence from some of Trump's former top advisers, including strategist Steve Bannon, communications director Hope Hicks, Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, White House counsel Donald McGahn, and counsel Ann Donaldson.

Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), the top Republican on the House Committee on Oversight and Reform, accused the Democrats of politicizing security clearances and exaggerating the problems. "For instance," he said, "the 25 examples of overruled recommendations by Ms. Newbold heralded by the Democrats include nonpolitical officials such as a GSA custodian."

Chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Reform, Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md), stated, "The evidence suggests the administration has been careless with security clearances and access to the nation's secrets." Newbold's testimony, he said, reflected "the grave security risks she has been witnessing firsthand over the past two years."

Title: U.S. Diplomats Call for Military Pressure on Syria's Assad Regime through Dissent Channel

Article:

More than 50 U.S. State Department officials have signed an internal memo advocating for a change in the United States' approach to Syria, specifically urging military pressure on Bashar Assad's regime to push him toward the negotiating table. The diplomats expressed their opposition to the current U.S. policy through a cable on the State Department's dissent channel, a mechanism established for such purposes.

According to NPR's Michele Kelemen, it is unusual for so many officials to sign on to such a cable. The cable reportedly calls for targeted military strikes against the Assad regime, a measure the Obama administration has been reluctant to implement. Such action would put the U.S. on a potential collision course with Russia, which is currently backing the Assad regime and working with Secretary of State John Kerry on a cease-fire and a diplomatic path that has stalled.

The New York Times, which has seen a copy of the memo, reports that the diplomats argue they are not advocating for a confrontation with Russia. However, they believe a credible military threat against Assad is necessary to pressure him to negotiate.

The cable reportedly states, "The moral rationale for taking steps to end the deaths and suffering in Syria, after five years of brutal war, is evident and unquestionable... The status quo in Syria will continue to present increasingly dire, if not disastrous, humanitarian, diplomatic and terrorism-related challenges."

The American Foreign Service Association, which represents active and retired members of the Foreign Service, said in a statement that "constructive dissent is a core tenet of the Foreign Service." The association added, "America's diplomats are tasked with addressing some of the world's most complex challenges in order to protect America's people and national security—a charge that requires a professional environment that values candor and debate when the stakes are high and the costs of failure are unacceptable. We applaud the individuals who had the intellectual courage to express their dissent."

The dissent channel was established in 1971 during the Vietnam War and is meant for "dissenting and alternative views on substantive foreign policy issues." Messages sent through the channel are immediately distributed to the secretary of state and other leaders in the department. Cables sent through the channel are supposed to remain confidential.

In 2004, Michele reported on the State Department diplomats who expressed their objections to the war in Iraq. At the time, she reported that about six messages a year were sent through the channel. "One little lonely voice out in the wild reaches of Mongolia was certainly not going to turn the train of war around," one diplomat who sent an anti-war dissent cable told Michele. However, even if it would not change history, the diplomat wanted her concerns put in writing and read by the country's top diplomat.

Title: Trump's Controversial Pardons Raise Concerns Over Clemency Abuse and Impact on Anti-Corruption Efforts

Article:

In a move that has sparked criticism from the left, former President Donald Trump granted clemency to several individuals with personal connections to him, raising concerns about the potential impact on the federal government's anti-corruption efforts. The pardons, which were granted in the final days of Trump's presidency, have been criticized as self-serving and politically motivated.

The individuals granted clemency include Rod Blagojevich, a former Illinois governor who was convicted on charges of bribery, fraud, and lying to investigators, among other offenses. Blagojevich was a contestant on Trump's reality TV show, "Celebrity Apprentice," and was prosecuted by Patrick Fitzgerald, a close friend of and lawyer for James Comey.

Other recipients of Trump's clemency include Michael Milken, a financier who has hosted annual financial conferences that are frequented by Trump's wealthy associates, and Bernard Kerik, a former police commissioner who was appointed by Rudolph Giuliani. Additionally, Trump granted clemency to Ed DeBartolo Jr., a former San Francisco 49ers owner, who was pardoned after a large group of former professional football players, with whom Trump has had a favorable relationship, championed his cause.

The pardons were granted personally by Trump, and there is concern that the grants were made as a reward for political support or personal favoritism. The world will not change significantly as a result of these actions, as only Blagojevich was still incarcerated at the time of the pardons. However, critics argue that the pardons further degrade the government and move the system closer to a cult of personality.

Trump has also been accused of misrepresenting the nature of the Blagojevich case, claiming that Blagojevich was only charged for one phone call that could have been just talk. In fact, the charges related to a month's worth of discussions and three separate corruption-related incidents.

The pardons have also raised concerns about the potential for Trump to grant clemency to convicted associates such as Paul Manafort, Trump's 2016 campaign chairman, and Roger Stone. If Trump were to grant clemency to figures such as Manafort and Stone, it would be an even more egregious corruption of the pardon power.

Presidents do have the unquestioned power to grant clemency, and past presidents have used it to pardon or commute the sentences of acquaintances or friends of friends. However, no past president has been as transparently transactional in doling out clemency as Trump. Friend, friend of a friend, or famous individual seems to be a good chance of being considered for a pardon in Trump's world.

Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi has also been in the news recently, following her decision to tear up a copy of Trump's State of the Union address on live television. Pelosi's talents have always lain in the less glamorous, less public side of politics. She is good at whipping up votes in her caucus and disciplining dissenters. She is good at offering incentives and punishments to get Democratic members of Congress to do what she wants them to do. To rip up the speech on television was a bit of theatricality, sure – a ploy designed to get attention. It also worked. The day after Trump made a long speech full of misinformation that tried to make a case for his re-election, no one is talking about him. Instead, we are talking about the speaker of the House. That, too, is a skill, one that Pelosi seems to be honing.

Title: Millennial Voters Favor Libertarian Gary Johnson Over Hillary Clinton, Polls Show

Article:

A number of recent polls indicate that Libertarian presidential nominee Gary Johnson is performing well among millennial voters, while Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton is underperforming with the same demographic that helped President Obama build winning coalitions in 2008 and 2012.

According to a New York Times/CBS poll, 26 percent of voters under the age of 29 support Johnson, with an additional 10 percent supporting Green presidential nominee Jill Stein. A Quinnipiac poll shows Johnson at 29 percent of young voters, and Stein at 15 percent. In that poll, Clinton barely edges out Johnson among young voters, receiving 31 percent, while Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump is at 26 percent among that demographic. A Global Strategy Group poll of millennials in 11 battleground states found 73 percent of millennials labeling Trump as a racist, and just 38 percent supporting Clinton in a four-way matchup.

The results have sparked concern among older liberals who feel the vote of millennials belongs to them. Clara Jeffrey, editor-in-chief of Mother Jones, tweeted that she has "never hated millennials more" in response to the NYT/CBS poll, which garnered refreshing responses from millennials. New York Times columnist Ross Douthat quipped that it looked "like 'liberaltarianism' is a real thing" and that Donald Trump was "very glad" of it.

While Republicans have a few politicians who could be called 'liberaltarian,' Trump is not. In a tight race, those votes could be crucial, and Trump has nothing to offer them. Similarly, Democrats' nominee has nothing to offer a demographic that has increasingly become more libertarian-friendly.

A 2014 McClatchy-Marist poll of millennials found 66 percent of them believing government was wasteful and inefficient, even as many said they planned to vote Democrat in that year and in 2016. The drop-off in support for Democrats is unsurprising, given that the rhetoric about government that Democrats deploy does not match the reality on the ground.

The narrative of the older generation of liberals is that Donald Trump is so bad, voters have to hold their nose and vote for Clinton. The option alone of a third-party vote is skewered online, mostly by establishment liberals who have increasingly come to represent the poor policy-making that has led to a mammoth-sized debt and veritable police state in the U.S. and U.S. warfare state abroad. Donald Trump does not "scare" millennials as much as the mess older voters have made of the country. Clinton's courting of neo-conservatives and figures like Henry Kissinger only serves to alienate millennials more.

Johnson's refusal to play political games, like powering through a question about Aleppo without knowing what it's in reference to, while it makes him an easy target for the media establishment to mock, likely ingratiates him to millennials who see both Trump and Clinton as products of a corrupt political system their parents' generation has glorified.

Clinton and President Obama's decision to call Trump a break from Republican tradition instead of the inevitable evolution of it, as more dishonest partisans might frame it, has also placed Johnson and the Libertarian Party in a better position. Millennials are used to start-ups. They are early adopters whose behaviors and decisions are helping drive old giants of industry out of business, from Blockbuster to taxicabs. The latest polls suggest they have the potential to disrupt the political industry in this country in the same way they've disrupted so many others.

All the fearmongering over Trump, the cries of false equivalency, and the attempts by millennial "influencers" like Vox.com to frame the Clinton campaign as something transformative millennials ought to get behind, won't bring millennials to heel in the way major parties were able to in days gone by. Neither will false alarms about "spoilers" (spoiler: third parties are not spoilers, shitty candidates are).

The persistence of never Trump Republicans (even if they do not go for Johnson) combined with Obama and Clinton's refusal (as of yet) to smear the principles of limited government, freedom, and Constitutionalism with Trumpism because of Republicans' history of running on those principles while never acting on them, and the Libertarian party's decision to nominate socially tolerant and fiscally responsible candidates (as many millennials describe themselves) means millennials have the chance to catapult the Libertarian party into major party status, if not through this election cycle alone, almost certainly in cycles to come. Both millennials and Libertarians should expect the smears and attacks to become more vociferous and detached from reality as the old establishment partisan order slowly but surely comes to an end.

Title: Presidential Candidates Take Divergent Approaches to National Unrest and Police Violence

Article:

The ongoing protests following the killing of George Floyd have dominated the national conversation for the past two weeks, with demonstrations starting in Minneapolis and spreading to cities across the country showing no signs of abating. As the upcoming presidential election, which is less than five months away, approaches, the issues of police violence and civil unrest are likely to remain at the forefront.

The two candidates, President Donald Trump and presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden, have taken drastically different approaches in their responses to the protests. President Trump has repeatedly called on authorities to "dominate" demonstrators, going so far as to suggest invoking his authority to deploy the U.S. military in American cities. "I am your president of law and order," Trump said in an address last week before leaving the White House to walk to a nearby church in an area that had recently been cleared of peaceful protesters by police and the National Guard.

In contrast, Joe Biden has attempted to strike a more unifying tone while speaking out about the need to address "systemic racism" in the country. He has visited protests in several cities and met privately with Floyd's family in Houston on Monday. "I won't traffic in fear and division. I won't fan the flames of hate," Biden said during a speech last week.

The last time the country experienced such widespread unrest was in 1968, during one of the most chaotic periods in American history, marked by the assassinations of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy and deadly riots in several cities. Republican Richard Nixon emphasized a return to "law and order" en route to a decisive win over Democrat Hubert Humphrey.

By echoing Nixon's message, Trump could appeal to voters who crave a return to stability. The intense focus on police violence also draws attention away from the administration's response to the coronavirus, which voters largely see as a failure, according to polls. The coming months may also provide the president with an opportunity to capitalize on divisions within the various wings of the Democratic Party, such as the debate over defunding the police.

Skeptics argue that an election 52 years ago shouldn't be treated as indicative of what might happen today. Besides, Nixon in 1968 was running to replace a Democrat in the White House. It's much more difficult for a sitting president to make the case that he'll bring a return to normalcy when he's been in charge the whole time, some pundits argue.

Even if a "law and order" message could be effective, Trump is the wrong candidate to capitalize on that opportunity given the upheaval he's brought to Washington during his presidency, political analysts argue.

Early polling suggests that Trump's response is hurting rather than helping. Trump's appeal to order could be convincing for some voters, according to Ron Grossman of the Chicago Tribune. On the other hand, Biden's history makes him a poor messenger for police reform, as noted by Charles Lane of the Washington Post. The focus on race relations turns attention away from the coronavirus, according to Stephen Collinson of CNN. Trump can also blame Democratic leaders for issues in their cities, as pointed out by Timothy J. Lynch in The Conversation.

It's too early to know how the ongoing unrest will affect voters come November, but early polling suggests that Trump's response is hurting rather than helping.

Title: Trump Shifts to a More Positive Tone for State of the Union Address

Article:

Former Republican House speaker Newt Gingrich, who has advised President Donald Trump, stated that the president is transitioning from his combative persona to a more victorious one in his upcoming State of the Union address. Gingrich described this shift as a move from "Trump the fighter" to "Trump the winner."

According to Gingrich, the president is adopting a more conciliatory tone, expressing a sense of not needing to engage in confrontations. This change is aimed at promoting the booming economy and the enactment of his tax plan without the use of divisive language that may cloud his message.

While some of Trump's advisers may prefer a darker and more strident tone, White House officials are aiming for a more inclusive speech in terms of tone, if not substance. The speech has been compiled by Stephen Miller, another speechwriter, and Rob Porter, the president's staff secretary, who coordinated input from various government departments.

There is a heightened awareness among White House officials and Republicans on Capitol Hill that Trump's tendency to deviate from the script, insert divisive remarks, and make confusing non-sequiturs often overshadows the main topic. However, officials believe that as long as Trump adheres to his script during the address, he will be viewed positively in many circles.

Corey Stewart, a Tea Party Trump supporter from Virginia running for Senate in the state, commented that Trump is looking forward to the midterm elections in November and his own re-election in 2020. Stewart added that Trump understands the need to mobilize his base but also expand it by discussing non-contentious issues.

Title: Historical Parallels and Consequences of Political Polarization in the United States: A Case Study of Moses Dunbar

Article:

Political polarization in the United States, as evidenced by unfavorable opinions and fear of opposing parties, has intensified since the 2016 Pew Research Center surveys. This is not the first time the nation has experienced such divisions, with historical examples dating back to the birth of the nation and the American Revolution.

One such example is the story of Moses Dunbar, a Connecticut farmer who remained neutral during the American Revolution but faced severe consequences as a result. Dunbar, who supported the British monarchy but not the Parliamentary taxes and measures that drove patriots into opposition, was seen as a threat by Connecticut patriots.

As the imperial crisis escalated in 1774, Dunbar called for a peaceful resolution to the "Unhappy Misunderstanding" between Britain and the colonies. However, once the war began in April 1775, such calls for moderation had little chance of being heard. Fear of British military retaliation led Connecticut patriots to identify suspected loyalists and subdue them by any means possible.

Dunbar was arrested, convicted of treason, and executed on March 17, 1777. He was the only loyalist executed for treason by the state of Connecticut. The authorities' extreme measures against suspected British sympathizers, as demonstrated by Dunbar's case, offer a vivid example of what can happen when fear and suspicion lead people to translate a complex situation into a stark opposition of friends versus foes.

However, the aftermath of Dunbar's execution demonstrates how a fractured society can begin to heal its wounds. Once the War for Independence ended, many loyalists fled the United States, but many more stayed in the new nation. Dunbar's descendants belonged to this group, and some of them continued to reside among the very people who had harassed and betrayed him. Despite the years of conflict, former adversaries evidently made a decision to cease making enemies of their neighbors, concentrating on what they had in common rather than what drove them apart.

The story of Moses Dunbar serves as a reminder of the dangers of extreme partisanship and the importance of finding common ground in a divided society. The image credit for this article is a postcard depicting Old Newgate Prison, where Dunbar was imprisoned.

Title: Obama Vows to Pursue Closure of Guantanamo Bay Detention Facility

Article:

President Barack Obama has expressed his intention to push for the closure of the Guantanamo Bay detention facility during his final two years in office, potentially fulfilling a campaign promise he has yet to accomplish. In an interview with CNN's Candy Crowley, Obama stated, "I'm going to be doing everything I can to close it."

The President cited the facility's role in inspiring jihadists and extremists worldwide as a reason for its closure, stating, "It is contrary to our values." The President's comments follow a series of executive actions, including an overhaul of U.S. immigration rules, new regulations aimed at curbing environmentally-harmful emissions, and a deal to thaw economic relations with Cuba.

The Guantanamo Bay detention facility, which Obama pledged to shut down as part of his 2008 campaign, has been a point of contention due to a law passed by Congress that prohibits the President from doing so. Obama has transferred many of the detainees housed at the facility to other countries in recent months, and plans to continue this process, as Congress has not allowed him to shift those detainees into federal Supermax facilities within the United States.

Obama stated, "We are going to continue to place those who have been cleared for release or transfer to host countries that are willing to take them." The President acknowledged the challenge of dealing with "some really hard cases" where "we know they've done something wrong and are still dangerous." However, he expressed his desire to close the facility, stating, "I think that it does not make sense for us to spend millions of dollars per individual when we have a way of solving this problem that's more consistent with our values."

Title: The Dilemma of Ambition and Femininity: A Personal Reflection on Hillary Clinton's Presidential Campaign

Article:

The ongoing struggle faced by women in balancing ambition and traditional gender roles is a common experience shared by many, as demonstrated in a personal account by an unnamed author. The author describes an internal, critical voice that has persistently judged her professional decisions, either for being too feminine or not feminine enough. This dilemma, the author argues, is a result of the societal expectation that ambitious and successful women often face a backlash for challenging traditional gender norms.

The author's personal account is set against the backdrop of Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, which offers a glimpse of a world where such restrictive gender norms may no longer be a barrier to success. The author suggests that Clinton's campaign will inspire a realization of the absurdity of these gender norms and allow women to overcome their internal critical voices.

The author criticizes a recent column by Maureen Dowd in The New York Times, which offers advice to Hillary Clinton on how to campaign as a woman. Dowd's column suggests that Clinton's past political failures were due to her not embodying the correct amount of femininity. The author finds this criticism absurd, as Clinton is more hawkish than the rest of the Democratic Party and advocates for issues such as paid leave for working women, which is not currently guaranteed in the United States.

The author concludes by expressing relief at the absurdity of the standard being shriveled in the sunlight and finding humor in the suggestion that Hillary Clinton should emulate the bossy and ambitious caricature of herself portrayed on Saturday Night Live. The author ends by using Clinton's political career as a measure of success and stating that if failure is defined as Clinton's career, then the author is ready to sign up.

Title: Supreme Court and Subsidies for Health Plans on Federal Exchanges: A Political Battle

Article:

The Supreme Court is not currently facing a serious legal case to eliminate subsidies for health plans on federally facilitated health insurance exchanges. This assertion is made by New York Times' Supreme Court columnist Linda Greenhouse in a recent article, stating that such a decision would contradict the conservative justices' previous views on statutory interpretation.

Greenhouse argues that the conservative justices, who form a 5-4 majority on the Supreme Court, would have to disregard their established approach to statutory interpretation and their views on how Congress should interact with the states to reject the government's defense of the law.

The political leanings of the conservative justices are a point of contention, with Greenhouse suggesting they may be motivated by a political agenda to dismantle the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The decision, it is believed, will once again fall on the shoulders of Chief Justice John Roberts, who upheld the individual mandate in 2012, albeit in a manner that was not considered a neutral interpretation of the law.

Roberts' decision to uphold the individual mandate, but not on the Commerce Clause, and his gutting of Medicaid, may have led him to regret allowing the Affordable Care Act to survive. This second opportunity to revisit the issue could provide him with an opportunity to reverse his previous decision.

The potential chaos that a ruling against the government in King v. Burwell could cause to the country's healthcare system is a concern for Roberts, a political consideration that should not factor into a justice's decision-making process. The White House is reportedly focusing on convincing Roberts that there is no safety net for such a ruling, while the Republicans are working to convince him that everything will be "hunky-dory" if he rules in their favor and eliminates subsidies for insurance plans bought on federally facilitated exchanges.

During a testy hearing before the Senate Finance Committee, HHS Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell was pressed for details on the administration's backup plan should the court eliminate subsidies for insurance plans bought on federally facilitated exchanges. Burwell repeatedly dodged questions, stating her focus is on meeting targets for the open enrollment period.

Two former Bush HHS officials who spoke with The Hill suggest that the administration is keeping their contingency plans close to the chest to avoid signaling "weakness" to Chief Justice John Roberts. Former HHS Secretary Michael Leavitt, who left office in 2009, added that he isn't surprised that senior officials would rather face a day of bad headlines than signal weakness to the Supreme Court.

The Republican party, which controls both chambers of Congress, is reportedly working to signal strength, comfort, and reassurance, while the administration is keeping their plans close to the chest to avoid signaling weakness to the Supreme Court. This dynamic is a part of the ongoing political battle surrounding the Affordable Care Act and the subsidies for health plans on federally facilitated exchanges.

Title: Obama's Visit to Hiroshima Amidst Asian Nuclear Arms Race Concerns

Article:

President Barack Obama's upcoming trip to Asia, which includes a stop in Hiroshima, will focus on the city's dark nuclear past. However, Obama's visit comes at a time when U.S. and Asian officials express concerns about a potentially dangerous nuclear future in the region, potentially reversing Obama's pledge to curb the spread of nuclear arms.

North Korea is reportedly expanding its nuclear arsenal and upgrading its ballistic missiles. China is modernizing its nuclear stockpile. Notably, Pentagon planners worry that Japan and South Korea might, for the first time, consider developing nuclear arms of their own. This speculation is partly due to the recent conclusion by U.S. and South Korean intelligence agencies that North Korea's unpredictable regime can now mount a small nuclear warhead on missiles capable of striking Japan and South Korea.

Donald Trump's recent comments on Asia's nuclear-weapons-free Japan have raised concerns. Trump questioned the assumption of a nuclear-weapons-free Japan, stating, "Wouldn’t you rather, in a certain sense, have Japan have nuclear weapons when North Korea has nuclear weapons?" Japan, scarred by the horrors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, has forsworn nuclear weapons since World War II, though it operates a nuclear energy program.

Obama's visit to Hiroshima, which was devastated by a U.S. atomic bomb in August 1945, will promote a message contrasting Trump's. "It’s an opportunity to focus the world’s attention on the need to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and seek a world without them," said deputy national adviser Ben Rhodes.

Obama's broader goal of limiting nuclear proliferation, a long-stated objective, has yielded mixed results. Obama secured a nuclear deal with Iran that halted its path to a bomb, but has not achieved significant reductions in the U.S. nuclear arsenal due to Russia's resistance to comparable cuts. He has also not slowed nuclear expansions in North Korea and Pakistan.

Asia now emerges as a potential nuclear danger zone, following the Iran deal that averted a predicted nuclear arms race in the Middle East. North Korea continues to press on with its weapons program, with recent satellite imagery suggesting it may be preparing for its fifth nuclear test.

Governments in Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan are growing impatient with international efforts to thwart Pyongyang's program. Some suspect China is content with a status quo that keeps North Korea contained and stable.

Concerns about the U.S.'s reliability as an ally are increasing, particularly in Japan, which has a post-World War II policy of pacifism enshrined in its constitution. Last year, Japan passed legislation reinterpreting its constitution to allow foreign military operations for the first time since World War II, though only for defensive purposes.

Some officials and analysts suggest the anti-nuclear taboo is being revisited, especially as China asserts new territorial claims, including over islands and waters claimed by Japan. At the same time, many Japanese leaders feel that Obama has not challenged Beijing forcefully enough. Trump's suggestion that Japan and South Korea might need to fend for themselves has only exacerbated these concerns that America can no longer be relied on for protection.

"Careless American rhetoric that calls into question America’s security commitment in general and extended nuclear deterrent in particular fuels Tokyo’s security planners to develop hedging strategies," said Patrick Cronin, senior director of the Asia-Pacific Security Program at the Center for a New American Security.

"It has often been thought that Japan has a bomb in the basement, and it would just have to assemble the parts to create a bomb," Cronin added. "The technical challenges might actually be much greater than that, but it is the political hurdles that remain the real barriers to Japan acquiring nuclear weapons."

Shortly after Trump's comments in March, the governor of Japan's Osaka prefecture told reporters that the country should revisit the question of nuclear weapons. "What do we do if America’s military strength [in Japan] disappears?" asked the governor, Ichiro Matsui. "Wishful thinking doesn’t get us anywhere."

Other Japanese conservatives have made similar arguments in recent years, including Shintaro Ishihara, who served as Tokyo's governor until 2012 and said in 2011 that Japan "should absolutely possess nuclear weapons."

Such talk has been striking to Japan experts in the U.S., who have assumed for decades that the country would remain non-nuclear. "Very few except the extreme fringes used to talk about nuclear weapons" in Japan, said Richard Samuels, director of MIT's Center for International Studies.

Pro-nuclear weapons sentiment in Japan remains mostly on the far right. However, the same conversation is brewing in South Korea, where a 2013 poll found that two-thirds of South Koreans support developing nukes in response to its bellicose northern neighbor.

"Seoul can no longer sit idly by as the [nuclear] talks lead to no results and Washington and Beijing are busy blaming each other for their diplomatic failures," argued an editorial in Seoul's conservative Chosun Ilbo newspaper earlier this year.

Such talk "is driven by a deep fear of abandonment" by the U.S., Cronin said. Obama himself was dismissive when asked about Trump's talk of allowing Japan and South Korea to build their own nuclear weapons, stating they reveal that "Trump doesn’t know much about foreign policy, or nuclear policy, or the Korean Peninsula, or the world generally." The U.S. alliance with Japan and South Korea, he added, "is one of the foundations, one of the cornerstones of our presence in the Asia-Pacific region," he said, adding that it "has prevented the possibilities of a nuclear escalation" in the region.

Title: Health Insurance and the Problem of Overconsumption: Understanding Adverse Selection and the Death Spiral

Article:

The regulation of healthcare professionals, such as physicians, dentists, and nurses, is a response to the challenge of monitoring product quality in the healthcare industry. Similarly, the Food and Drug Administration oversees the safety and effectiveness of pharmaceuticals.

Healthcare spending can be unpredictable and expensive, contrasting with the predictability of expenses for items like housing, food, and transportation. Healthcare expenses can arise unexpectedly and significantly impact a person's finances.

Health insurance addresses this issue by pooling risks among the population, reducing financial uncertainty. However, this reliance on third-party payers introduces a new problem: insured consumers may overconsume healthcare services due to reduced financial incentives.

For instance, when insurance covers doctor visits without out-of-pocket costs, patients may seek medical attention more frequently for minor symptoms. Physicians may also order unnecessary tests when insurance companies cover the bill.

To counteract this issue, insurers implement copays, deductibles, and service access restrictions. However, these measures reduce the pooling of risks and can create conflicts between insurers and their customers.

Another problem that arises in insurance markets is adverse selection. This occurs when customers differ in relevant ways (such as having a chronic disease) and these differences are known to the customers but not to insurers. This can result in an expensive mix of insured individuals.

Adverse selection can lead to a phenomenon known as the death spiral. In this scenario, if insurance companies charge everyone the same price, basing the price on the average person's health characteristics may lead to healthier individuals dropping out of the insured pool. With a sicker customer base, the company faces higher costs and must increase the price of insurance. This higher price induces the next healthiest group of people to drop insurance, leading to a cycle of rising costs and prices. As this process continues, more people drop their coverage, the insured pool becomes less healthy, and the price keeps rising. In extreme cases, the insurance market may disappear.

Title: Egyptian Interim President's Office Denies Appointment of Mohamed ElBaradei as Prime Minister

Article:

The office of the interim Egyptian president has denied reports of the appointment of Mohamed ElBaradei as prime minister. This development comes after the second-largest Islamist party in Egypt, Salfi el-Nour, reportedly rejected the appointment.

Initially, reports of ElBaradei's appointment were made by news agencies such as Reuters, Al Jazeera, BBC, and the Associated Press, citing "presidential" sources. The Associated Press also heard the same from an "opposition source." ElBaradei's spokesman had informed NPR that he would be sworn in as prime minister around 1:30 p.m. ET, but later retracted the statement.

The nation's military, following Wednesday's ousting of President Mohammed Morsi, installed Adly Mansour, chief justice of Egypt's Supreme Constitutional Court, as interim president. He is expected to serve until elections can be held. Morsi, Egypt's first democratically elected president, was in office for just one year and was removed after massive protests due to discontent over Egypt's economic problems and his Muslim Brotherhood Party.

Mohamed ElBaradei, a former head of the International Atomic Energy Agency and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has a history in diplomacy. As special assistant to the Egyptian foreign minister in 1978, he served on the negotiating team at the historic Camp David peace talks that led to Egypt's peace treaty and diplomatic relations with Israel. He began his U.N. career in 1980 and was sent to Iraq in the wake of the 1991 Gulf war to dismantle Saddam's nuclear program.

Title: China's Response to the COVID-19 Outbreak: A Look at Transparency, Deception, and the Global Impact

Article:

The novel coronavirus, responsible for the ongoing global pandemic, is believed to have undergone natural selection, with the ability to infect and spread among humans. The genetic material in the current virus shares an 82% match with the earlier SARS virus, while another type of coronavirus found in bats matches at 89%. The origin of the virus remains unclear, with some evidence suggesting it could have originated from animals or an inadvertent spill from the Wuhan Institute of Virology, which conducted research on bat coronaviruses.

In the early stages of the outbreak, China's system and its deceptions are said to have worsened the situation. Local officials attempted to clamp down on information, and when doctors expressed concern about the new sickness, they were reprimanded for spreading rumors. One of these doctors, Li Wenliang, a 34-year-old ophthalmologist, later died of the virus. He had spoken up in an online chat group on Dec. 30, 2019, while the Wuhan Health Commission was telling hospitals not to say anything publicly.

In the critical early weeks of January 2020, as the virus spread, the local and national governments kept the lid on public information. President Xi Jinping was reportedly aware of the virus spread on Jan. 7, but the public was not warned until Jan. 20, seven days later. Wuhan was put into lockdown on Jan. 23.

China's official death toll seemed low compared to the size of the population, and anecdotal evidence described many more deaths. On Friday, China revised the Wuhan death toll upward by 50%, to 3,869. This revision is a welcome step towards transparency, but more investigation is needed for the whole country.

China has launched a campaign to portray President Xi as the hero who vanquished the virus. Some Chinese officials have gone so far as to claim that the United States created the virus, while others have claimed that China's authoritarian model should be emulated. However, the part of China's campaign that is most troubling is the claim that China's system should be emulated. The model, characterized by deception, cover-up, and rewriting history, is part of the problem, not the solution.

The United States and China need to cooperate to deal with the pandemic and its aftermath. China is critical in the global supply chain for drugs and personal protective equipment, and is an economic superpower. China and the rest of the world must also confront infectious disease together, not use it to score points. The model, deception, cover-up, and rewriting history, is part of the problem, not the solution.

Title: Unemployment Claims Reach Record High as Coronavirus Pandemic Continues

Article:

The Department of Labor reported a new weekly total of 28.9 million Americans filing for unemployment benefits, adding to the 22 million who had sought benefits in previous weeks. This unprecedented volume has overwhelmed state systems for processing unemployment claims. Economists estimate the national unemployment rate to be between 15 and 20 percent, significantly higher than during the Great Recession in 2008 and 2009, when the peak unemployment rate was about 10 percent.

The unemployment rate during the Great Depression was approximately 25 percent. The new weekly jobless claims figure is comparable to the 5.2 million people who filed for unemployment benefits for the week ended April 11.

As the coronavirus began spreading in the United States earlier this year, many businesses rapidly closed, with hotels, restaurants, and airlines being particularly hard-hit. However, few businesses have remained unaffected by the economic toll. The problems have worsened each week, as more Americans reduced their spending and more businesses cut workers due to the sharp decline in income.

Labor economist Julia Pollak of ZipRecruiter stated that many businesses quickly "cut to the bone" when they realized the pandemic would gut sales. Now, many of the new layoffs stem from businesses like news organizations and tech companies that weren't directly affected by people staying home but are suffering the consequences of vanishing ad revenue and paid subscriptions.
