Consumer spending, the engine behind the longest economic expansion in U.S. history, has evaporated. If they're still operating, many offices are working with skeleton staffs and staring down months of dismal revenue.

The White House and Congress have tried to intervene, but with limited impact so far. New funding for small businesses in a $2 trillion March emergency spending package quickly dried up in the face of overwhelming demand, prompting the Senate to expand funding by $310 billion on Tuesday. The bill would direct an additional $60 billion to a separate small-business emergency grant and loan program. The House approved the measure 388 to 5 on Thursday afternoon.

Even with all the new government spending, hopes for a sharp economic rebound are fading, overtaken by the public fear of going back to restaurants, movie theaters, schools, and gyms. The growing possibility of a W-shaped recovery—in which a resurgence of the virus or a spike in defaults and bankruptcies triggers another downturn—has analysts reframing what a reopened or rehabilitated economy might look like.

This year defies historical comparison. In 2020, 28.9 million people have filed for unemployment benefits. Halfway through the fourth month of the year, the figure has already eclipsed the full-year totals of every year but 1982 (30.4 million) and 2009 (29.8 million). At this rate, it will overtake both within a week or so.

Less than half of working-age Americans will be earning a wage next month, said James Knightley, ING Chief International Economist.

"In an election year, this means that the call for politicians to reopen the economy is only going to get louder, irrespective of the health advice," Knightley said.

In five weeks, 9.4 percent of the working-age population has filed for unemployment insurance, said Nick Bunker, Indeed Hiring Lab's director of economic research. That's about twice the share of the population that lost a job during the Great Recession. In some states, such as Michigan, about one in four workers has filed an unemployment claim in the past few weeks.

"The numbers detailing the shock to the U.S. labor market are so large, and cover such a short time, that your first reaction is that they're a typo," Bunker said.

Employers are also unlikely to be hiring at the same levels they were before the pandemic. As of April 16, job postings on Indeed were down 34 percent compared with last year, Bunker said.

The job losses, like the epidemic itself, haven't fallen evenly across the country. In three states—Hawaii, Kentucky, and Michigan—about 1 in 4 workers have filed for unemployment benefits in the past five weeks. In Michigan, plant shutdowns and furloughs have ravaged the manufacturing economy, which had only recently recovered all the jobs it lost in the Great Recession.

On the opposite of the ledger sits South Dakota, where Gov. Kristi L. Noem (R) has resisted calls to lock down the state's businesses to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Only 6 percent of the state's labor force has applied for unemployment benefits. It may be a regional trend: Neighboring Wyoming and Nebraska, and nearby Utah, also have unusually low claims numbers.

As part of its sprawling stimulus package, Washington has rolled out relief for millions of households and small businesses struggling to make ends meet. However, money for struggling businesses quickly ran dry, and system glitches have prevented $1,200 stimulus checks from reaching some of the neediest.

On Tuesday, the Senate passed a bill to expand the Paycheck Protection Program for small businesses by $310 billion, and flood a separate small-business emergency grant and loan initiative by an additional $60 billion. Meanwhile, many low-income veterans and Social Security recipients still haven't received the stimulus money in their bank accounts, while other IRS checks are going to dead people. People who didn't file tax returns last year or don't have direct-deposit information may have weeks more to wait.

Title: Carly Fiorina Shines in Republican Debate, Trump's Performance Remains Consistent

Article:

The 2016 Republican presidential debate, held at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, may have been more fitting at the Hearst Castle, given the shared history between William Randolph Hearst and the current frontrunner, Donald Trump. Both Hearst and Trump ran for president, and both were known for their affinity towards wealth and perceived concern for the common people.

The debate aimed to answer three key questions:

1. Could the GOP's non-politician trio - Trump, Dr. Ben Carson, and Carly Fiorina - demonstrate they are more than a protest vote?
2. Could former Florida Governor Jeb Bush display passion and wit, traits he is known to possess but seldom shows?
3. Could Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker rejuvenate a campaign that has stalled in the early primary states?

Trump, as expected, maintained his usual style, offering no signs of growth in his domestic and foreign policy views. Carson spoke sparingly, a stark contrast to other attention-seeking debaters. Carly Fiorina's performance will be discussed later in this article.

Jeb Bush showed improvement from his performance in the Cleveland Fox News debate. Notable moments included standing up to Trump and defending his brother, and choosing "Eveready" as his Secret Service name. This should reassure his nervous financial base, at least for now.

Walker had another challenging night, facing criticism for skipping the California Republican Party's convention. His campaign struggles continue, as he focuses on regaining momentum in Iowa.

A recurring issue in the GOP debates is the uneven playing field, with Trump often dominating the close-up moments, leaving other candidates in a disadvantageous position. This could be due to Trump's compelling rhetoric or the moderators' efforts to maintain audience engagement.

Carly Fiorina, the standout of the debate, demonstrated depth and clarity in her responses, particularly on defense strategy and her criticism of Hillary Clinton. She handled Trump's interruptions with grace and offered thoughtful responses to questions, distinguishing herself from the other candidates.

Trump had several flat moments, including comments about Rand Paul's hair and his interactions with Columba Bush. His ideas remained underdeveloped, suggesting that his campaign may not be as enduring as some might think.

In conclusion, Carly Fiorina's performance was a highlight of the debate, while Trump's performance remained consistent. The GOP is likely to face internal conflicts over government shutdowns, Planned Parenthood funding, and the Iran deal, which could fuel Trump's campaign. However, signs suggest that the appeal of Trump's unconventional style may be starting to wear thin.

Title: Trump Acknowledges Regret Over Past Comments, Shifts Tone in Campaign Speech

Article:

In a significant shift in his campaign strategy, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump acknowledged that his past comments may have caused pain and expressed regret for some of his statements during a rally in Charlotte, North Carolina. The remarks came as Trump was trying to rescue a campaign that has struggled since the Democratic and Republican nominating conventions from a series of self-created distractions.

Trump, reading from prepared text, said, "Sometimes in the heat of debate and speaking on a multitude of issues, you do not choose the right words or you say the wrong thing. I have done that." He added, "And believe it or not, I regret it—and I do regret it—particularly where it may have caused personal pain."

The GOP nominee pledged to "always tell you the truth" and promised to be the "voice for every forgotten part of this country that has been waiting and hoping for a better future." Trump's decision to tap Stephen Bannon, a combative conservative media executive, as his new campaign chief, suggested a more confrontational approach. However, a new Trump emerged on Thursday: a less combative, more inclusive candidate.

Earlier Thursday, Trump moved to invest nearly $5 million in battleground state advertising to address daunting challenges in the states that will make or break his White House ambitions. The New York businessman's campaign reserved television ad space over the coming 10 days in Florida, North Carolina, Ohio, and Pennsylvania. While Democrat Hillary Clinton has spent more than $75 million on advertising in 10 states since locking up her party's nomination, Trump's new investment marks his first of the general election season.

Trump's shift in tone and attempt to appeal directly to non-white voters was met with skepticism by Clinton's campaign. Clinton's spokeswoman, Christina Reynolds, stated, "We learned tonight that his speechwriter and teleprompter knows he has much for which he should apologize. But that apology tonight is simply a well-written phrase until he tells us which of his many offensive, bullying, and divisive comments he regrets—and changes his tune altogether."

It remains to be seen whether Trump's reboot comes too late, and whether he has the discipline to maintain it. Trump now trails Clinton in preference polls of most key battleground states. Election Day is 81 days away, with early voting in the first states set to begin in five weeks.

Title: U.S. Political Figures React to U.K.'s Decision to Leave the European Union

Article:

The United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union has sparked reactions from U.S. political figures, with President Barack Obama and presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump offering contrasting views on the historic vote.

In a written statement, President Obama, who had advocated for Britain to remain in the union, said, "The United Kingdom and the European Union will remain indispensable partners of the United States even as they begin negotiating their ongoing relationship."

Trump, who was in Scotland touring his golf resorts as the verdict came in, linked the campaign to his own populist bid. He said the vote underscores the need for "tested leadership" and suggested the result could be attributed to Obama's meddling.

Trump held a press conference, highlighting what he described as the "big parallel" between the sentiments driving Britain's "Leave" campaign and those driving his own presidential bid. He emphasized the anger over high immigration levels, stating, "They're angry over borders, they're angry over people coming into the country and taking over, nobody even knows who they are."

Presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, hours later, released a statement echoing Obama and others in saying the U.S. respects the choice of U.K. voters. Clinton also suggested the vote should strengthen her appeal in the U.S., stating the uncertainty "only underscores the need for calm, steady, experienced leadership in the White House to protect Americans' pocketbooks and livelihoods."

The Dow began to tumble as the vote results were announced, prompting Clinton to say, "Our first task has to be to make sure that the economic uncertainty created by these events does not hurt working families here in America."

The outcome in Britain potentially sets up a domino effect of similar votes across Europe, testing the cohesion of the Western alliance, while throwing into question Britain's future trade relationship not only with E.U. countries but the United States.

Obama, in urging against Britain leaving the union, warned in April that Britain would be at the "back of the queue" in terms of striking a trade deal with the U.S. if it leaves. Trump, if he's president, vowed, "They'll always be at the front of the line."

Trump's reason for his trip to Europe was not politics, but rather to check on a pair of championship-level golf resorts he owns in Scotland. Trump, unlike previous presidential candidates, did not schedule any political meetings while abroad. He spent Friday morning marking the $200 million-plus rehabilitation of the famed Turnberry golf resort nestled on the rocky coast facing the North Atlantic Ocean.

Title: Trump Delivers Unscripted, Controversial Speech in Pennsylvania Ahead of Special Election

Article:

In a 73-minute campaign speech in Moon Township, Pennsylvania on Saturday, President Donald Trump delivered a swaggering, unscripted address that included taunts, insults, and vulgarity, while occasionally praising the man he was there to support, congressional candidate Rick Saccone. The stakes for Tuesday's special election are high for the Republican Party, with Saccone barely ahead of Democratic candidate Conor Lamb in a district that Trump won by 20 points.

Trump's speech was not solely focused on the upcoming election, but also touched on various political issues, foreign policy, and personal matters. He expressed concern about the potential loss of Republican control of the House, stating that if Democrats were to retake the lower chamber, it would pose an existential threat to his presidency, as impeachment would become a possibility.

Trump criticized Democratic leaders, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Representative Maxine Waters, labeling Waters as a "low-IQ individual." He also spoke about the ongoing investigations into his campaign's ties with Russia, stating that the Democrats are "people that want to obstruct" and "want to stop us from doing things."

The speech also included references to foreign policy, with Trump criticizing Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto for refusing to pay for a border wall, threatening a trade war with the European Union over tariffs on steel and aluminum, and expressing his views on drug dealers, sanctuary cities, and "chain migration."

Trump also revisited the 2016 election, getting key facts wrong, such as claiming he received 52 percent of the women's vote, a statement that is only true if all non-white voters are excluded. Exit polls show that Trump won only 25 percent of Hispanic women and just 4 percent of black women.

The speech concluded with Trump's new slogan for the 2020 campaign: "Keep America Great!" He also mentioned his potential 2020 opponents, stating that he'd "love to beat Oprah" and that he knows "her weakness."

As is typical at any Trump rally, the president took aim at the "fake" media, labeling CNN as "fake as hell" and "the worst," and referring to Meet the Press host Chuck Todd as a "sleeping son of a bitch."

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Accuses Koch Brothers of Trying to "Buy the Country" in Political Activities

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) criticized the political activities of the Koch brothers on Thursday, accusing them of attempting to "buy the country." The comments came in response to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) who criticized President Barack Obama's crackdown on politically active tax-exempt organizations.

McConnell, in his remarks, described the administration's proposed rules on those groups as a "war on free speech" and compared it to the Internal Revenue Service's targeting of outside groups. He accused Democrats of trying to stifle their election-year critics.

Reid countered by labeling the networks backed by David and Charles Koch as political organizations masquerading as social welfare groups. He criticized McConnell's efforts to help the Koch brothers.

"Because of a United States Supreme Court decision called Citizens United, there’s been some really untoward stuff going on in the political world," Reid said. "We have two brothers who are actually trying to buy the country."

Reid further stated that the Republican leader has been an opponent of campaign finance reform and that it is no surprise he opposes the administration's efforts for greater disclosure. He accused the Koch brothers of pretending to be social welfare organizations.

The administration's proposed rules would limit the ability of nonprofit groups organized around "social welfare" to engage in political activities. McConnell argued that Democrats are surveying a difficult midterm election cycle and trying to muzzle groups that back Republican candidates.

"Democrats think 2014 is shaping up to be a tough year for them politically," McConnell said. "So instead of trying to persuade the public that they’ve got the best answers to the problems we face, they try to shut everybody else out of the political process, they try to shut them up."

The Koch brothers, though major conservative financiers, have previously given to Democrats, including Senate Democrats. In 2010, they gave nearly $200,000 to Democratic candidates, including a $30,000 donation to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

Reid acknowledged that the Koch-backed groups' spending poses a threat to Democrats, who are fighting to keep the Senate and preserve some control of Congress during Obama's last two years in office.

"What they’re doing is spending their dollars on governors races, and on the state level and, of course, spending huge amounts of money around the country attempting to defeat Democrats both in the House and the Senate," Reid said. "The Koch brothers hide all their campaign efforts. They disguise themselves with rare exception as social welfare organizations, with all these fancy names going after people who are trying to improve the country."

Such groups, also called 501(c)(4) nonprofits after a section of the Tax Code, have become an integral part of the campaign finance landscape in recent years. Democratic operatives as well as Republicans have used tax-exempt groups to shield donors from public scrutiny while still participating in elections. Government watchdogs say that such electoral activity might be a violation of tax law. The Treasury Department is currently considering new rules that would curtail some 501(c)(4) political activity.

Title: Democratic Party Faces Challenges as Progressive Stances Elicit Mixed Reactions

Article:

The Democratic Party is currently grappling with a series of political developments that have raised concerns about the party's direction and potential impact on its electoral prospects. In recent weeks, the party has been embroiled in debates over immigration policy, Supreme Court nominations, and the treatment of government officials.

The initial focus was on the controversial policy of family separations at the U.S.-Mexico border, which drew widespread criticism. President Trump's reversal of the policy was seen as a victory for the Democrats, who have minimal control in Washington. However, the party's stance has since shifted, with several senators, including Elizabeth Warren, Kirsten Gillibrand, Kamala Harris, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, advocating for the abolition or significant reform of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency.

This position has been criticized as a call for open borders and easily caricatured as such by opponents, including President Trump. The rhetoric has prompted concerns that the party is alienating moderates and independents who support some level of border enforcement.

Another issue that has put the Democrats on the defensive is the treatment of Trump administration officials. Liberal voices have been vocal in their criticism, with some advocating for the harassment of officials such as Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Kirstjen Nielsen, and Stephen Miller. This has led to calls for distancing from such rhetoric, as it risks being perceived as condoning personal harassment of government officials.

Furthermore, the retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy has sparked a debate over Supreme Court nominations. Some liberal commentators are demanding that Democrats block any vote on any Trump nominee this year, citing the treatment of Merrick Garland in 2016. This stance could potentially leave the party open to charges of obstruction.

The Washington Post highlighted these challenges in a front-page story, stating, "Growing liberal agitation over a pivotal Supreme Court retirement and a simmering crisis about immigrant child separation have left Democratic leaders scrambling to keep the political outrage they'd counted on to fuel midterm election wins from becoming a liability for the party."

The article also noted that "Bernie Sanders-style rhetoric, including costly guarantees of government jobs, free health care, and free college could backfire in parts of the country where Trump won in 2016, and where Democrats will have to win in November to reclaim control of Congress."

These developments underscore the challenge of balancing the party's progressive wing with the need to appeal to moderate and independent voters in key states. While a handful of presidential aspirants may not speak for the entire party, their positions and the media attention they receive can significantly influence the party's image and electoral strategy.

Title: Obama Hails Progress of Iran Nuclear Deal, Addresses Missile Program and Detained Americans

Article:

President Obama, in a speech on Sunday, declared that the United States, the region, and the world will be more secure due to the recently completed nuclear deal with Iran. He stated, "This is a good day, because once again we're seeing what's possible with strong American diplomacy."

The nuclear deal, which was finalized over a 24-hour period, marks a significant milestone in preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. Obama emphasized, "Yesterday marked a milestone in preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon." He further added, "We achieved this historic progress through diplomacy, without resorting to another war in the Middle East."

In addition to the nuclear deal, the International Atomic Energy Agency certified that Iran has complied with its agreement to scale back its nuclear program. As a result, Obama signed an executive order lifting nuclear-related sanctions.

In a side agreement, Iran released five Americans who were held captive, and Obama granted clemency to seven Iranians held in the United States. Obama described his use of the constitutional pardon power as "a one-time gesture to Iran, given the unique opportunity offered by this moment and the larger circumstances at play."

Obama also announced that the United States and Iran had settled a decades-long dispute regarding Iranian assets frozen during the 1979 Tehran hostage crisis. The $400 million in Iranian funds, intended to buy military equipment, were frozen when Muslim students stormed the United States embassy in Tehran and took 66 hostages. This money, along with $1.3 billion in interest, has been returned to settle claims at the Iran–United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague. U.S. citizens had already recovered $2.5 billion in claims against Iran through the same tribunal, according to the State Department.

Earlier on Sunday, the Treasury Department announced it was imposing sanctions on 11 people and companies involved in Iran's ballistic missile program. Obama stated, "We will continue to enforce these sanctions vigilantly."

Obama had initially planned to speak on Saturday night, but waited until all the Americans, including Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, were able to leave Tehran. Two senior administration officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive details of the exchange, said two issues held up the plane's departure: The crew needed enough rest before the long flight to Switzerland, and they wanted to make sure that Rezaian's wife and mother were also on the plane.

Even as Obama spoke to reporters in the Cabinet Room of the White House, Republican presidential candidates condemned the deal on Sunday morning television. Senator Ted Cruz, R-Texas, on Fox News Sunday, stated, "It reflects a pattern we've seen in the Obama administration over and over again of negotiating with terrorists, and making deals and trades that endanger U.S. safety and security." Cruz further added, "Barack Obama is in the 'Let's-Make-A-Deal' business."

Title: Keystone XL Oil Pipeline: What You Need to Know About the Contentious Project

Article:

The Keystone XL pipeline, a controversial project stretching from Alberta, Canada, to the Gulf of Mexico, is at the center of a years-long debate among politicians, energy companies, and environmentalists. The Senate is scheduled to vote on Tuesday on the completion of the pipeline, with President Obama potentially having the opportunity to sign off on or veto the project.

Here are a few key points to help understand the Keystone XL pipeline debate:

1. Completion Status and Function:
Approximately 40% of the total project has been built, with oil flowing through two segments: a 298-mile stretch from Steele City, Nebraska, to Cushing, Oklahoma, and a 485-mile segment between Cushing and Nederland, Texas. The remaining segment, if approved, would run between Alberta and Steele City. If fully completed, the Keystone XL pipeline would be able to move up to 830,000 barrels a day of crude from Canada's oil sands to the U.S. Gulf Coast.

2. Environmental Impact:
Opponents argue that some of the crude would be exported, but TransCanada, the company building the pipeline, states that this would not be financially viable. Alberta estimates it has the third-largest proven oil reserves in the world after Saudi Arabia and Venezuela. However, the oil is valuable only if producers can get it to a market where it can be sold. A pipeline is the least expensive way for the industry to do that.

Producing crude from oil sands emits an estimated 17% more greenhouse gases than traditional oil drilling in the U.S. This is due in part to the need to heat the crude to separate it from the sand.

3. Economic Impact:
The State Department estimates the construction phase would create about 42,000 direct and indirect jobs and generate about $2 billion in earnings in the U.S. Opponents dispute some of those numbers. Once construction is finished in about two years, the pipeline would create only about 50 new permanent jobs.

4. Presidential Permit and Legal Challenge in Nebraska:
Because it crosses the U.S.-Canada border, the Keystone XL pipeline requires a "presidential permit." President Obama has guarded this power jealously. In 2015, when Congress tried to force him to make a decision by issuing a 60-day deadline, he simply rejected the permit application.

The political challenge for Obama is that Democrats are divided on the issue, with construction unions favoring the project and some environmental activists opposing it. No matter what he decides, some constituents will be unhappy—so the president has effectively stalled.

If the legislation passes the Senate Tuesday and becomes law, the pipeline would get an immediate green light.

5. State Department Review and Legal Challenge in Nebraska:
The State Department was required to conduct an environmental assessment of the final, proposed leg of the pipeline because it will cross the U.S.-Canada border. The State Department's basic environmental review was completed in January. It concluded that the pipeline would have "little impact" on the price consumers pay for gasoline in the U.S.

The State Department is waiting for the outcome of a Nebraska Supreme Court case that could affect the pipeline's route. The court battle is over where the pipeline will be located, with opponents arguing that the governor does not have the authority to approve the new route.

6. Alternative Pipelines and Legal Challenges:
There are other pipelines that can move oil sands crude (including a controversial plan by the company Enbridge), but there's not enough capacity for all the oil being produced in Alberta. Producers in Canada are pursuing transporting oil sands by rail cars, even though it's more expensive than moving it by pipeline.

That becomes even less attractive as world oil prices fall, however. Crude from oil sands is some of the most expensive oil to produce in the world. When the extra cost of moving it by rail is added on, some producers will find it difficult to make money.

Title: Trump Aims for New Hampshire Victory in Final Day of Campaigning

Article:

In the final day of campaigning before the New Hampshire Republican primary, businessman Donald Trump urged voters to support him in order to secure his first victory in the presidential primaries. Trump, who has led in polling in New Hampshire for the past six months, is the favorite to win, with around 30% of the vote.

Trump received a warm welcome at the Verizon Wireless arena in downtown Manchester on Monday night, with thousands of supporters braving a storm to attend the rally. The candidate walked onto the stage to the Beatles song "Revolution."

"So this is now crunch time," Trump said. "We have a movement going that is incredible." He added, "Tomorrow, you have to get out and you have to vote no matter what."

New Hampshire Republicans and independents, who are allowed to vote in the GOP primary, are expected to help narrow the Republican field. Businesswoman Carly Fiorina and three current or former governors each need a strong showing to remain viable.

Sen. Marco Rubio, the Florida Republican who finished third in Iowa, is hoping to regain his momentum after a rough debate performance on Saturday. Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas is aiming to avoid a significant drop from his first-place finish in Iowa.

The race will move on to South Carolina, where Trump also leads in the polls, then to Nevada, and then to Super Tuesday on March 1, when numerous delegates to the nominating convention are at stake. This showdown has been labeled the SEC primary because many of the battles are in states that make up the collegiate Southeastern Conference.

Trump told the crowd, "Tomorrow is going to be the beginning. We have to celebrate tomorrow evening. We have to have a great victory. It is so important because we are going to make America great again."

Trump, along with the rest of the field, has been campaigning intensively in New Hampshire, targeting the large number of undecided voters. Sen. Rubio, hoping to regain his Iowa momentum, vowed to build a coalition that will be needed to defeat the likely Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton.

Sen. Rubio's debate stumble has energized the three governors - John Kasich of Ohio, Chris Christie of New Jersey, and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush - who are competing to consolidate the support of donors and voters looking for an alternative to Trump and Cruz.

Gov. Kasich, at his 105th town hall meeting, said his appeal goes beyond the Republican Party to include blue-collar Democrats who helped power Ronald Reagan's winning campaigns. Gov. Bush continued to trade verbal barbs with Trump, criticizing the billionaire businessman's campaign for being based on insulting women, castigating Hispanics, and ridiculing disabled people.

Three candidates dropped out of the race after the Iowa caucuses, and the primary in New Hampshire is likely to eliminate more. Political analysts suggest it will be challenging for Bush, Kasich, Christie, and Fiorina to survive disappointing showings.

Speaking in Hudson, Gov. Christie downplayed polls showing him struggling in the mid-single digits, stating that they were taken before Saturday's debate. He said that affair proved to voters that Rubio cannot carry himself.

"When the lights get that bright, you either shine or you melt," Christie said. "We can not afford to have a president who melts."

History suggests that the stakes are high in New Hampshire, as the eventual Republican nominee has won in either Iowa or New Hampshire since 1976. Trump faces lingering questions about whether he can turn his strong polling into victories after he led surveys in Iowa but finished second. However, Trump has since argued that his showing is more impressive than the pundits think, given that he is a political newcomer, the caucus process is "weird" and "complex," and there are questions about whether the Cruz camp hurt his chances with some campaign shenanigans.

Title: Iowa Caucus to Provide Clarity in Republican and Democratic Nominating Contests

Article:

The Iowa caucuses, scheduled for Monday, will mark the culmination of over ten months of campaigning by more than a dozen presidential candidates from both the Republican and Democratic parties. The results of the caucuses could offer clarity in the nominating contests, although a high voter turnout could potentially complicate the picture.

Voting in a caucus is more complex than in a primary, as Iowans must physically attend their designated caucus site at a specific time and, in some cases, stay for several hours. A large turnout is generally beneficial for the two frontrunners, Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, while a lower turnout could advantage Ted Cruz and Hillary Clinton. Both Trump and Sanders have been actively reaching out to first-time caucus-goers, with Trump appealing to non-college-educated, white, working-class voters, and Sanders targeting young voters.

The previous record for Republican turnout in Iowa was 122,000 votes in 2012. If Trump manages to mobilize his supporters who attend his rallies to caucus sites on Monday, the number could potentially reach as high as 150,000 votes. In 2008, Barack Obama shattered Iowa records and helped the state's Democratic turnout reach 240,000. While a similar turnout is not expected this year, Sanders needs a turnout above the 124,000 that turned out in 2004 to remain competitive.

Weather conditions could impact turnout, as a winter storm is predicted to start on Tuesday, potentially affecting Monday night's caucuses.

The state of Iowa is considered favorable terrain for Ted Cruz, with a significant conservative evangelical voter base. Cruz needs to win Iowa to maintain a viable path to the nomination. If Cruz finishes second to Trump, his road to the nomination will become significantly more challenging. Cruz has been emphasizing to his supporters that a Trump victory in Iowa would make him virtually unstoppable, as Trump does not need to win Iowa to secure the nomination but would gain considerable momentum.

Marco Rubio has adopted a 3-2-1 strategy: placing third in Iowa, second in New Hampshire, and then winning a subsequent state. Rubio requires a strong third-place finish in Iowa to reassure donors of his clear path to the nomination. The Republican establishment is hoping to rally behind Rubio as an alternative to Trump or Cruz, but they have been hesitant to do so. A stronger-than-expected finish in Iowa could help Rubio consolidate the mainstream wing of the GOP.

If Rubio manages to surpass Cruz and finish second in Iowa, he will be well-positioned to place second to Trump in New Hampshire and emerge as the clear establishment alternative.

On the Democratic side, the question remains whether Bernie Sanders has the organizational prowess to unseat Hillary Clinton. Clinton, who finished third in Iowa eight years ago, has built a robust get-out-the-vote operation. However, organization alone is insufficient without enthusiasm, and Sanders has excited Democrats with his calls for breaking up the big banks and making college and healthcare free.

Sanders started organizing late in Iowa and, like Cruz, needs a victory in Iowa to maintain momentum. If Sanders beats Clinton in Iowa, it would be an upset, and he would head into New Hampshire with even more momentum. Sanders currently holds a significant lead in New Hampshire, as neighboring-state candidates typically do (Sanders is from Vermont). A win in both Iowa and New Hampshire for Sanders could alter the dynamic in the South, where Clinton has built a firewall based on her support among African-American Democrats.

Unlike the Republican caucuses, Democrats report delegate totals, not vote totals. Delegates are awarded through a formula based on how candidates perform in precincts across the state. Sanders could potentially face a disadvantage in this regard, as his support has been heavily concentrated in college towns and urban areas. The Sanders campaign has been attempting to expand its reach to rural areas. Clinton's team is filled with Obama field-operation veterans who have built an organization for Clinton that reaches all of Iowa's 99 counties and 1,683 precincts.

For more information, NPR's Iowa briefing book is available for download. On Monday night, NPR's politics team can be found on local NPR stations, NPR.org, and on Facebook and Twitter.

Title: Illinois Man with Concealed Carry Permit Stops Armed Robbery Suspect, Crime Rates Decline

Article:

An 86-year-old Illinois man, whose identity remains undisclosed, used his concealed carry permit to stop an armed robbery suspect last month. The man, described as a "model citizen" by law enforcement authorities, prevented others from entering an AT&T store during a holdup and allowed the police to make an arrest.

Since Illinois started granting concealed carry permits this year, the number of robberies resulting in arrests in Chicago has decreased by 20 percent compared to the previous year, according to police department statistics. Reports of burglary and motor vehicle theft are also down by 20 percent and 26 percent, respectively. In the first quarter, the city's homicide rate was at a 56-year low.

Richard Pearson, executive director of the Illinois State Rifle Association, attributes the decrease in crime rates to the increased number of concealed carry permit holders. "It isn't any coincidence crime rates started to go down when concealed carry was permitted," said Pearson. "The police department hasn't changed a single tactic—they haven't announced a shift in policy or of course—and yet you have these incredible numbers."

As of July 29, the state had 83,183 applications for concealed carry permits, with 68,549 licenses issued. By the end of the year, Mr. Pearson estimates that 100,000 Illinois citizens will be carrying concealed weapons. When Illinois began processing requests in January, gun training and shooting classes—required for the application—were filling up before the rifle association was able to schedule them, according to Mr. Pearson.

The Chicago Police Department has credited better police work as a reason for the lower crime rates this year. Police Superintendent Garry F. McCarthy noted the confiscation of more than 1,300 illegal guns in the first three months of the year, better police training, and "intelligent policing strategies."

The Chicago Police Department did not respond to a request for comment from The ███. However, the impact of concealed carry cannot be dismissed. Instead of creating more crimes, as many gun control advocates warn, increased concealed carry rates have coincided with lower rates of crime.

A July study by the Crime Prevention Research Center found that 11.1 million Americans have permits to carry concealed weapons, a 147 percent increase from 4.5 million seven years ago. Meanwhile, homicide and other violent crime rates have dropped by 22 percent.

John Lott Jr., president of the Crime Prevention Research Center, stated, "There's a lot of academic research that's been done on this, and if you look at the peer-reviewed studies, the bottom line is a large majority find a benefit of concealed carry on crime rates—and, at worst, there's no cost."

Within Illinois, Cook County, which encompasses Chicago, has the state's largest number of concealed carry applications, with 28,552 requests, according to the county's website. Accounting for population, however, less than 1 percent are carrying. Mason County has the top per-capita rate in Illinois, with 14 percent of its residents holding concealed carry licenses, followed by Shelby County, with 9 percent.

Sheriff Miller of Shelby County, located in southwestern Illinois, about an hour and 45 minutes driving time from St. Louis, attributes the high concealed carry rate to residents wanting to exercise their Second Amendment rights. He doesn't anticipate concealed carry to change the statistics much, as the county doesn't have a significant gang problem or serious violent crime.

Mason County Sheriff Paul Gann said it's too early to tell whether an increased carry rate will have an influence on crime rates. "What I can tell you is we haven't seen a spike in crime," said Mr. Gann. "We haven't seen a spike in anything that's gun-related—brandishing a firearm, shootings, robberies, nothing. These are law-abiding individuals."

From a national perspective, Florida has the most active concealed carry permits, at nearly 1.3 million. Texas is second, with just over 708,000. Hawaii, at 183, has the fewest of states whose data were available. At 300,000 concealed carry licenses, Illinois would compare with Virginia, which has 363,274, and Alabama, with 379,917.

Title: President Trump Cancels Denmark Visit Over Greenland Purchase Dispute

Article:

President Donald Trump abruptly canceled a planned meeting with Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen on Tuesday, citing Frederiksen's dismissal of the idea of the U.S. purchasing Greenland as "absurd." The visit, initially scheduled for September 2-3, was part of Trump's trip to Europe, but there were no solid indications that the visit was centered on buying Greenland until Trump's Tuesday tweets.

In a series of tweets, Trump wrote, "Denmark is a very special country with incredible people, but based on Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen’s comments, that she would have no interest in discussing the purchase of Greenland, I will be postponing our meeting scheduled in two weeks for another time." He added, "The Prime Minister was able to save a great deal of expense and effort for both the United States and Denmark by being so direct."

The White House later confirmed that the entire trip to Denmark, including a planned meeting with the Queen of Denmark, had been scrapped. The sudden cancellation came as a surprise to many, including U.S. ambassador to Denmark, Carla Sands, who tweeted just hours before Trump's pullout, "Denmark is ready for the POTUS @realDonaldTrump visit!"

The Wall Street Journal first reported last week that Trump was interested in buying Greenland, a semi-autonomous territory under Danish control with a population of approximately 56,000. According to the paper, Trump asked his advisers about acquiring the island due to Greenland's "abundant resources and geopolitical importance."

In the past, the U.S. made a similar effort to buy Greenland in 1947, albeit without the publicity of social media. The idea led some left-wing commentators to mock the White House, but most found humor in the situation. Trump himself seemed to join in on Monday, tweeting a meme depicting a lavish Trump skyscraper looming over a mostly empty village in Greenland.

However, Greenland is not for sale, according to Frederiksen. "Greenland is not Danish. Greenland is Greenlandic. I persistently hope that this is not something that is seriously meant," Frederiksen told reporters during a trip to meet Kim Kielsen, the premier of Greenland.

Speaking to reporters in New Jersey on Sunday, Trump compared the proposal to "a large real estate deal." He stated, "A lot of things can be done. It’s hurting Denmark very badly because they're losing almost $700 million a year carrying it [Greenland]. So, they carry it at great loss, and strategically for the United States, it would be nice. And, we're a big ally of Denmark and we help Denmark."

At the same time, Trump said buying Greenland was not a top priority for him or his administration.

Title: The Invaluable Contribution of Women Judges: A Perspective from Leah Ward Sears, Former Chief Justice of the Georgia Supreme Court

Article:

Retired Chief Justice of the Georgia Supreme Court, Leah Ward Sears, has expressed her support for Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's intention to serve on the bench for at least five more years, until she turns 90. Sears, who is a partner in the litigation section at Smith, Gambrell & Russell, LLP, emphasizes the unique and invaluable role women like Ginsburg have played in shaping a fair and just jurisprudence in the United States.

In her commentary, Sears highlights the erosion of the "judicial boys' club" as women began to serve as judges and take more gender-sensitive positions. She points to Ginsburg's significant role in exposing hidden gender biases and working towards improving the situation for women and everyone else.

One of Ginsburg's notable decisions was the 1996 majority opinion in United States v. Virginia, where she argued against gender-exclusive admissions policies, stating that such policies are not inherently unsuitable for women. In the 2016 case Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, Ginsburg's concurring opinion emphasized the risks women face when access to safe and legal procedures is severely limited.

Sears argues that women's lives, with their higher likelihood of experiencing discrimination and the burdens of child and elder care, add a unique perspective to judicial discussions. She suggests that female judges, who have balanced their professional lives with family responsibilities, have inspired generations of young women to pursue legal careers and see themselves as judges and other legal professionals.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, according to Sears, has not only had an impressive judicial record but has also been a strong advocate for women's rights and human rights. Sears expresses her happiness about the opportunity to benefit from Ginsburg's experience and expertise for at least the next five years and hopes for more.
